





l e m e . l i b r a r y . u t o r o n t o . c a

s t c 6 7 4 8

v e r . 1 . 0  ( 2 0 1 8 )



A
Dictionarie French 
and English:
Published for the benefite of the stu­
dious in that language:

Gathered and set forth by Clau­
dius Hollyband.

For the better vnderstanding of the or­
der of this Dictionarie, peruse the
Preface to the Reader.

Dum spiro, spero.

Imprinted at London by T.O. for
Thomas Woodcock. 1593.














A Tres-noble, Honorable, & ver­
tueux Seigneur, Monseigneur Edward
Zouche, ferme base, pillier et vray
Mecœnas de toutes mes
estudes.


COmme ainsi soit que la natu­
re et inclination des humains
est differente et diverse, pour la
plus part: aussi sont les juge­
ments et desseings d'un chas­
cun en particulier differents et
divers, selon que les occurren­
ces, rencontres, et objects cor­
respondent et symbolizent avec leurs affections: en
sorte que difficilement en trouvons nous deux, aus­
quelz vne mesme chose plaise en tout poinct, & sans
contre-dict quelconque: ains, selon l'ancient pro­
verbe, Chascun à sa guise. Et cecy n'experimentons
nous seulement aux elections des paäs, contrées, vil­
les, situations et terroirs: mais aussi au chois des ars,
tant mechaniques, que liberaux. Mais que dy-je des
ars et sciences, veu que mesmes nous differons en la
poursuite des vertus? Quant est des vices, nous n'en
faisons point de chois, si nous ne sommes du tout
dénaturez. Or si lon me dit, que les malins eslisent





plus tost le mal que le bien, mesme qu'ilz se plaisent
en mal-faisant, je diray seulement, laisssant ceste que­
stion indecise, que nous sommes promps au mal, &
par trop duits, choisissans, à prendre le pite. Mais, bon
Dieu, et qui nous meine ainsi à tors et à travers?
mesme à vn labyrinthe et gouffre de toute impieté?
qui est, en somme, ce tant detestable peché d'ingrati­
tude: lequel, à mon advis, est si abhorrant de l'uma­
nité, que mesmes les bestes sauvages l'ont heu en
haine, fuy, et evité: je n'entens pas des plus trai­
tables, mais bien des cruels et plus fiers lyons, les­
quelz par signes externes ont monstré de recognoi­
stre les biens et benefices receux des homes, et aultres
petites bestelettes. Et nous qui sommes creatures
raisonnables, n'ensuyvrons nous en rien ce petit di­
stique, ou semblable?

Le plus grand bien dont l'home est revestu,
C'est quand de Dieu il ensuit la vertu.

Or est-il notoire à tous, que Dieu haäst et persecu­
te sur tout aultre, ce tant detestable vice d'ingrati­
tude: ostant le plus souvent, et privant les ingrats
des biens, dons, et graces. lesquelz au paravant il leur
avoir liberallement eslargis. Donc, Monseigneur,
pour n'estre trouvé au rang et trac de telles gens, j'em­
brasseray ce, dont cestui-cy m'admonneste.

Ceux que verras en ce monde bien vivre,
Ce font ceux-la qu'il te convient ensuyvre.

D'entre lesquelz j'ay choisi les memoratifs et re­
cognoissans les gentillesses receuës: desquelles, Mon­
seigneur, vous n'avez tellement comblé en vostre
long, lointain, penible et dangereux voyage d'oultre





mer, que vous vous estes plus-tost monstré pere, ou
baston de vieillesse en mon endroit, que non pas mai­
stre, Seigneur, our commandeur: de maniere que ny
à moy, ny à tout vostre train et suite, rien n'a man­
qué, voire en lieu ou n'y avoit creature vivante, tant
sagement aviez prouveu &a grave; tout event. Et mesme si je
vouloye, ou bien osoye discourir de vostre liberalité
en general envers les estrangers, mais en particulier
gens de sçavoir, et d'esprit, du soin et estude que
vous avez employé pour enrichir les facultez de l'e­
sprit, je ne vouldroye proposer devant les yeux de
tous voyagers aultre exemplaire et patron, que cel­
luy lequel je vous ay veu embrasser et suyvre. Mais
d'aultrant que je cognoye vostre modestie, Mon­
seigneur, je n'entreprendray pour le present, à hault­
louër voz vertus heroïques: maid seulement &grave; vostre
arrivée tant desirée en Angleterre, et en recognoi­
ssance des faveurs lesquelles vous m'avez faites sa­
vourer, je vous offriray ce present faisceau de plu­
sieurs mots, peu de sentences, et moins de pro­
verbes icy semez et espars, en ce mien Dictio­
naire: lesquelz toutes-fois, s'ilz sont recueuillis et
bien assortis ensemble, comme vostre Seigneurie
en sçait fort bien le style, ilz rendront vne sym­
metrie bien concordante, et vn son doux et har­
monieux.

Vous supplyant, Monseigneur, de l'accepter com­
me venant de celuy qui ne desire que à vous faire
tout humble service, et mettre en avant chose pour
l'esclarcissement et facilité de nostre langue Fran­
çoise, en laquelle je sçay que prenez vn singulier





plaisir: afin que vous les studieux et desireux d'icel­
le, en sachent gré à vostre Seigneurie, et moy à icelle
sois de plus en plus, tenu et obligé: à laquelle
bien humblement voud baisant les mains, tous
mes travaux je recommende. De Lon­
dres ce dixiesme jour de 
Avril, 1593.

Par le tout vostre
Desainliens.








Claudius Holliband, to the Students
of the French tongue.


HAuing alreadie (gentle Reader) for
thine ease and facilitie in attaining
of our French tongue, set foorth my
Bookes De pronunciatione linguæ 
gallicæ, & French Littleton , where­
by I haue opened the way to all sorts
aswell learned as vnlearned, for the
perfect reading and pronunciation
thereof: and yet perceiuing thy want
and indigence of a sufficient meane for the vnderstanding of the
same, I haue now for thy further auaile, published this my pre­
sent worke, whereby for the most part, thou maiest be satisfied.
For, besides that I haue expounded all the hard words by diuers
and sundrie examples, I haue furthermore giuen thee the
Theame and principall Tenses of all our most difficult Verbes. I
call the Theame, speaking to the vnskilfull in the Latin tongue,
whereby we begin to decline a Verbe, as by example: In other
Dictionaries thou hast onely the Infinitiue moode of any Verbe,
as Aimer, to loue: Vouloir, to will or to be willing: Lire, to reade,
Fuir, to run away: and yet for all that thou art not much the wi­
ser, because thou knowest not how to begin in the present tense, so
that thou canst say in French, to loue, Aimer: but thou doest tra­
uaile to say, I loue, thou louest, I haue loued, read, taught, I shall
or will goe, sleepe, play, walke, &c. And behold, here I deliuering
thee out of such perplexitie, doe set it very plainly before thine
eyes, thus: First I doe specifie the Infinitiue moode, Parler, to
speake: Courir, to run: and straightway I shewe the present
tense of the Indicatiue, which is, je parle, I doe speake: then fol­
loweth the first perfect tense, je parlay, I spake: thirdly, the se­
cond perfect, j'ay parlé, I haue spoken: Last of all the future
tense, je parleray, I shal or will speake: so that thine order goeth
thus: to speake: then thou beginnest, I speake, I spake, I haue spo­
ken, I shall or will speake: and so thou must iudge of the rest: do





that hauing al these tenses, thou maiest easily decline any verbe
through all moodes and tenses, because all the rest are deriued
and formed of those which be here specified in this Dictionarie,
as from their head spring. And yet to ease thee the better in
this thy labour, I haue put forth to light a little worke, called A
Treatise of Verbes: so that hauing here thy chiefest Tenses, and
in that Pamphlet the examples of all the Coniugations declined
at length through all moodes and tenses, with the Heteroclites:
ioyning these three workes togither, that is, the French Little­
ton, or my sayd booke De Pronuntiatione, this Dictionarie, &
my Treatise of Verbes, thou shalt haue occasion, I trust, taking
my labour in good part, to giue me thankes. Furthermore, I ad­
uise thee to make a difference betweene this, j, which is a conso­
nant, and the other, i, common: likewise of this, v, in the middest
of the word, least thou shouldest pronounce it as this u, being a
vowell: and that thou looke not for the theame and tenses of all
Verbes, whose Infinitiue doe end in er, as enseigner, bailler, be­
cause they be the easiest to be found of all the rest: for hauing the
Infinitiue moode, one may finde the present tense, by taking away
r, as of marcher, trencher, you say, je marche, I goe: je tren­
che,, I doe cut: all whose declining you may frame by these two
Verbes Abandonner, and Abbayer, which you shall finde at the
first page of this booke: which cannot be sayd of Verbes whose
Infinitiue doe end in oir, re, or it: the which for the most part,
haue a speciall or particular forming of their Theame and Ten­
ses. Finally, our learner shall knowe our three genders, thus: the
Masculine gender is knowne by this letter, m: the Feminine, by 
f: the Common of two, com. But why doe I keepe thee so long,
seeing that all these difficulties be made easie by our sayd Trea­
tise of Verbes? Take then, these our labours to thy furthe­
rance, praying the Lord, so to blesse thy studies, that
it may redound to his honour and glorie, and
the commodities of the Com­
mon weale.










A, one of the sixe vowels in the
French tung, a,e,i,o,u and y,
is pronounced fully with an open
mouth, and hath diuers significati­
ons: first, it is the third person sin­
gular of the verbe, i'ay, I haue: tu
as, thou hast: il a, he hath: as, Ie­
han Wheeler a de bon vin: Iohn
Wheeler hath good Wine. Le Roy
a vne grand'armée: the king hath
a great armie. Sometimes being
ioyned with a participle, expresseth
the perfect tense of th' indicative
moode: as, Thomas Barns a faict
le voyage des Indes, Thomas
Barns hath made the voiage of the
Indes: Ma fame a passe sa cholere,
my wife hath asswaged hir choler.
Many times it serueth to expresse
the Datiue case: as, Ie l'ay don­
né à mon pere, I gaue it to my Fa­
ther. Sometime it serueth for the
Preposition To: as, Ie m'en vay à
mon pere, I goe to my Father: à
Paris, to Paris: à la ville, to the
towne.

A cause, à cueur, à droict, à l'aduen­
ture, à loisir, à propos, à raison, à
sçauoir, à temps, à tort, & sembla­
bles, seeke, Cause, Cueur, Droict,
&c.

A, is taken sometime for, en, as, à la
presence des Evesques, in the
presence of the Bishops.

A, sometime signifieth pour, for: as,
il est tenu à perdu, it is counted
for lost: à sot, for a foole: à fable,
for a tale or lye: à filz de roy, for
the Kings sonne.

A, sometime is taken for avec, with:
as, il est eschappé à peu de perte,
he is escaped with a small losse.

A, sometime is taken for like, or after
the fashion or manner, as, il est ve­
stu à l'Italienne, he is clothed af­
ter the Italian fashion.

Sometimes also A, is taken for a
signe of the Infinitiue moode, as,
S'il a chose à dire à l'encontre,
qu'il le die, if he hath any thing to
say against it, let him speak.

Aage, age: m.

Bas age, vnder age.

L'aage de quatorze ans pour les
masles, et douze pour les femeles
 th' age of fourteene yeeres is for
menkinde, and twelue for the fe­
male kinde.

Ilz font tout d'un aage, they be of
like age.

Il est de ce'st aage là: he is of that
age, that is, of those daies.

En ce'st aage là, il y avoit des gens
sçavans, in that age there were
learned men.

Des son jeune aage il a aymé Dieu,
 euen from his childehoode he did
loue God.

Rapporter l'aage l'un à l'autre, to
confer both th' age together.

Selon que l'aage le porte, le permet
le souffre, as th' age beareth, re­





quireth.

Quel aage a-il? of what age is he?

Home de bon aage, a man of good
age, or striken in yeeres.

Aagé, as, il est aagé de six ans, de
dix ans, &c. he is six yeares, ten 
yeeres of age, &c.

Home fort aagé, ou de grand aage,
 a very olde man.

Quel aage vous est-il aduis que
j'aye? of what age thinke you that I
am of?

Estre plus aagé qu'vn autre, To be
older then an other.

Abaisser, seeke Abbaisser.

Abandon, bandon, licence, liberty: m.

Abandonner, j'abandonne, j'aban­
donnay, j'ay abandonné, j'aban­
donneray, to giue ouer, or to li­
cence, to cast off: as also to deliuer
a thing to the libertie, will, or plea­
sure of any man.

Vne femme abbandonnée, a woman
for euery mans lust or will, a com­
mon woman.

S'abbandonner à tous plaisirs, to
giue him selfe to all pleasures.

Abbandonner femmes et enfans, to
forsake wife and children.

Il m'a abbandonné quand il estoit
question de ma vie, he hath forsa­
ken me vpon the point of my life.

Celuy duquel la vie est abban­
donnée au premier qui le tuera,
 an outlaw.

Abbandonnée, as Encor que tou­
tes choses me fussent abandonées
et libres, though all things were at
my commaundement.

Abandonné, forsaken, giuen ouer,
cast off.

Abandonnement, a giuing ouer: m.

Abandonnément, licentiously.

Abastardir, jabastardis, j'abastardi,
j'ay abastardi, j'abastardiray,
corrompre, to corrupt, or abastar­
dise, to counterfait.

Abastardir, to degenerate.

Abbaisser, j'abbaisse, j'abbaissay,
j'ay abbaissé, j'abbaisseray, to a­
base or bring lowe.

Abbaisser quelque chose en la de­
sprisant, to abate or bring lowe a
thing in dispraising the same.

Abaisser les vivres, to bring victuals
to a lower price.

Ie me fuy abbaissé jusques là, I haue
humbled my selfe so farre.

Abbaisseur, he that bringeth low: m.

La riuiere va en abbaissant, the ri­
uer decreaseth.

Abbaissé, abased or brought low.

Abbaissement de voix ou de son
estat, a speaking soft, a decay of e­
state.

Abbatre, j'abbas, j'abbati, j'ay ab­
batu, j'abbatray, to beate downe,
throwe downe, to hewe, to hurle
downe.

Il porte vn synople à trois Lyons
d'argent, he beareth a green shielde
with, &c.

La faim et la soif abbatent le corps,
 hunger and thirst do beate or bring
downe the body.

L'huile d'olif abbat l'yvrongnerie
d'une personne, et le desenyvre,
 salet oyle doth driue away drunken­





nes, &c.

Abbattement, a throwing downe, also
the thing throwne downe.

Abbatis, an ouerthrowing, as, faire
grand abbatis, to make a great
slaughter: m.

Abbatu, beaten, or throwne downe, as
il l'a Abbatu de son cheual, he hath
beaten him down from his horse.

Il a le coeur Abbatu, his hart is out
of hope.

Abbay, barking: m.

Abbayer, j'abbaye, j'abbayay, j'ay
abbayé, j'abbayeray, to barke.

Abbayement, a barking: m.

Abbayeur, a Barker, or teller of
faultes: m.

Abbayant, which crieth and raileth.

Abbois or abbais, see, render.

Abbaye, an Abbey: f.

Abbé, an Abbot: m.

Abbesse, an Abbottesse: f.

Abbecher, to feede or baite as birds
do their yong.

Abbecher, to entice or allure.

Abbeché, baited, or fed: one that is
enticed.

Vn abregé or abbreuié, a shorte
summe, an abstract: m.

Ce fera le plus abbregé, that will be
the next way.

Abbreger, j'abbrege, j'abbrejay,
j'ay abbregé, j'abbregeray, to
shorten, to abridge.

Pour abbreger, to make it short.

Abregement, a shortening: m.

Abbrever or abbruver les cheuaux,
 to water horses.

Abbruver vn drap, vn vaisseau, vne
bouteille, to shrinke a cloth, to sea­
son a vessell, bottell, &c.

Abbruver aulcun d'vne opinion ou
persuasion, to endue one, to print
an opinion in ones minde.

Toute la ville en est abbruvée, all
the towne knoweth it, or is priuie
with the matter.

Vn abbrevoir, a watring place: m.

Abbeille, see Aueille Abesti, waxed
a beast, entangled with loue.

Abhorrir, or abhorrer, to abhor.

Abhorrent, as Ie ne suy pas trop
abhorrent de ceste opinion, I dis­
agree not much from this opinion.

Vn a b c, an a b c.

Abject, as chose abjecte a vile
thing.

Abile, see Habile.

Abiller, seeke Habiller.

Ablatif, the ablatiue case.

Abisme, see Abysme.

Able or Ablette, a kinde of white
fishe.

Ablution, a washing or cleansing.

Abjurer, to forsweare, to deny, or to
recant.

Abjurement, a recanting: m.

Abolir, j'abolis, j'aboly, j'ay aboly,
j'aboliray, to abolish, to disallow, to
abrogate.

Aboli, hors d'vsage, abolished, or out
of vse.

Lettres d'abolition, the pardon graun­
ted by the Soueraine to a whole
Countrey, hauing offended; towne,
or village: but lettres de grace, a
pardon for one or certaine particu­
lar persons named in the same.





Abolition de creances et vieilles
scedules, a generall forgiuing of
olde debts.

Abolissement, an abolishing: m.

A voir en abhomination, to abhorre,
to loath, to despise.

Abominer, to haue in abomination.

Abominable, com: abominable.

I abomine cela, I detest or abhorre
that.

A bon escient: in good earnest.

Abonder, to abound, to flowe, to be
plentifull.

Abondant, aboundant, plentifull.

Abondance, abundance, plentiful­
nesse: f.

Abondant, moreouer.

Abondamment, abundantly, plen­
tifully.

Abonner vne chose, to put a thing to
an equall price: as, if a Tenant o­
weth a dais worke to his Landlord,
and doth pay for the same in money
a shilling more or lesse.

Aborner, also is to fall in composition
with a Farmer of the custome for
all such marchandise which the 
Merchant shall vtter in a certaine
time limited.

Aborder, j'aborde, j'aborday, j'ay
abordé, j'aborderay, to arriue at,
or common and talke with, to land
at any place.

Abordement, ou abord, an arriuing
or bordering: m.

Abordable, com: easie to arriue to.

Aborner, or abonner, to value a
thing or ware to a certain reasona­
ble price: as, Ce paire de gans ont
esté Abonnez à deux gros: this
paire of gloues hath beene valued
at two groates.

Aboutir, quand quelque apostu­
me aboutist, to drawe to head or
wax ripe, when an Apostume draw­
eth to head.

Aboutir à quelque lieu, to draw to
some place.

Les aboutissans d'vne maison, ou
terres, the end or corners of an
house or ground.

Aboutissement de terres, the end or
limits of any ground: m.

Abradante, as melancholie abra­
dante, a consuming melancholie, 
a wearing or scraping.

Abri, m: où le soleil frappe tous­
jours, a Sunnie banke,: as se met­
tre à labri.

Mettons nous à l'Abri pour euiter
la pluye, let vs goe vnder the roofe
for the raine.

Abricot, a fruit called an Appricot.

Abricotier, an Apricot tree: m.

Abrier, the steele of a Crosbow.

Abroger, to abrogate or to put away.

Abrogée, taken away or put away.

Abrutir vn home, sens et entende­
ment, to make a mans sences and
vnderstanding brutish and like a 
beast.

Ilz sont Abrutis, they are become
brutish.

Abruver, see abbreuer.

Absconcer, to hide.

Absconsement, or Esconsement de
soleil, the going downe of the Sun.

Abscynte, Wormewood.





Absent, absent, absence.

Absenter, to absent, to be absent.

Absouldre, j'absouls, j'absolvi, j'ay
absoul, j'absoudray, to absolue.

Absouls, absolued.

Absoubs à pur & à plein des cas à
luy imposez, absolued, discharged
of such crimes laied vpon him.

Absolte, a generall absolution of 
sinnes granted to the people, by the
Bishop at Easter weeke.

Absolution & declaration de n'a­
voir commis aucune faulte, an ab­
solution: f.

Absolutoire, as lettre absolutoire,
ou condemnatoire, a letter or token
cast into the chest, absoluing or con­
demning one.

Abstenir, je m'abstiens, je m'ab­
stins, je me suy abstenu, je m'ab­
stiendray, to abstaine, to forbeare,
or temper.

S'abstenir de manger: to forbeare
meate.

Abstinence: abstinence, refraining
forbearing: f.

Abstinence de vin, forbearing of 
wine.

Abstinence de souper, refraining of 
supper.

Abstersif, clensing.

Abstersive: f. idem.

Abstrus, as c'est chose abstruse it is
an hidden, hard, or difficult matter.

Absurde, difformed, hatefull or wic­
ked, inconuenient, fearefull, vnlike,
or hard to be knowne.

Absurdement, absurdly, difformed­
ly, or vnlikely.

Absurdité, deformitie, vnlikenesse,
inconuenience, foolishnesse, absur­
ditie: f.

Absynte, abscinte or absince, worm­
wood.

Vin d'absynte ou d'alvine, worme­
wood wine.

Abuser de quelque chose, to misuse
or abuse a thing.

Abuser aucun, to misuse a man or de­
ceiue him.

Abusé, misused, deceiued, beguiled.

Abus, an abuse or deceit: m.

Abusement, abusing: m.

Abuseur, a beguiler, a deceiuer: m.

Abusif, deceauing, things deceitfull,
full of guile.

Abusive, any things causing deceite
in vs.

Abusivement, abusiuely, which is not
taken in his right vse or sence.

Abysme, a botomlesse pit.

Villes abysmées, townes deuoured
and swallowed vp by earth quake.

Abysmer, to destroy, to ouerthrowe.

Acariastre, to be madde or out of wit, 
to be furious, braineles.

Acabler quelqu'vn, to snarle, or en­
trap a man, to ouerwhelme.

Acablé, beaten downe, ouerwhelmed.

Acablé de coups, d'injures, de po­
vreté thrown down with blowes, in­
iuries, pouertie.

Acablée, as l'armée des N a esté a­
cablée par foudre et tempeste, 
comme les Cananeens, the armie
of the N hath been ouerthrowne
by thunderboltes and tempest,
as &c.





Ilz ont tous estez acablez par la
cheute d'une maison, they haue
been slaine by the fall of a house.

S'Accagnarder, to giue himselfe to
slouthfulnes.

Accelerer, to haste: as Accelerer la 
mort de son pere par sa desbau­
che, to hasten his fathers death by
rioting.

Acceleration, quickening, haste ma­
king: f.

Accent acut or aigu, a sharpe accent.

Accentuër, to marke and note the
accents vpon syllables: also to rise,
lift vp or depresse the syllables.

Accepter, to accept, to admit: as, je
l'accepte pour mon seruiteur, I
do accept him for my seruant.

Acceptation, an accepting, receiuing
or allowing.

Avoir acception des personnes en 
justice, to haue a regarde or respect
of the persons iniustice.

Acceptable, which is to be accepted.

Acceptilation, is an imagined debte
or quittance betweene the creditor
& debitor thus: Tiens tu pas pour
heu et receu ce que je t'ay promis?
doost thou not holde for receiued,
such thinges as I haue promised
thee? the other answereth, Ouy, je
le tiens: yea, I doo holde or confesse 
it.

Accasement, asswaging, easing: as
la force du poison fust aulcune­
mente retardée, par vn acasement
de ceste violence, the force of the 
poyson was somewhat stayed, by the
abbating of, &c.

Accez, Facile accez & entrée; en­
vers aucun, easie comming or en­
trie to any man: m.

Accez de fiebvre, a fitte of an A­
gue: m.

Accession, accesse, sometime belon­
ging to: f.

Accessible, com: easie to come to, fa­
miliar, gentle.

Accessaires, accidents, things hap­
ning to the principall charge.

Accessaire, com: partaker or accessa­
rie.

Accidental, m: casuall, by chance.

C'Et vne chose Accidentale, a
chance.

Accident, pour circonstance, ou
qualité, & aussi adversité, a hap, a
chaunce, a fortune: m.

s'Accointer d'aucun, to become ac­
quainted.

Accointance & familiarité qu'on à
les vns avec les autres, acquaint­
tance and familiaritie: f.

Accointable, com: easie to bee ac­
quainted or made familiar.

Accoinctement, mot peu vsité, m:
 this word is little in vse.

Il est mon accoint, m: he is my fa­
miliar friend, or of mine acquain­
tance.

Accoiser, to asswage, to appease, to 
mitigate, to make quiet.

Qui n'est point Accoisé which is not
yet appeased.

Accoller, to colle, to kisse, to em­
brace.

Donner l'accolée or accolade, to
dubbe a knight.





Vne Accollée, or accollade, doulce
& amoureuse, a sweete and louely
embracing.

Accommoder, to apply to our pur­
pose.

s'Accommoder au temps, to frame
himselfe to the time.

Accommoder aultrui de son bien,
 to helpe or ease any other with his
goods.

Accommodez vous, set your selfe
at ease as well as you may.

Accommodation, healping: f.

Accommodable, com: any thing
which may be placed, framed, or
commodiously handled.

Accompaigner aucun, to companie,
to keepe fellowship.

Qui Accompaigne, a companion.

Accompaigné, accompanied.

Accompaignement, keeping fellow­
ship: m.

Accomparager, to compare.

Accomplir, j'accomplis, i'accom­
pli, j'ay accompli, j'accompliray,
 to fulfill, to finish or ende, to per­
forme.

Il est Accompli de toutes les bonnes
parties qu'vn home scauroit avo­
ir, he is indued with al the perfecti­
ons which a man can haue.

I'ay Accompli ma promesse: I haue
fulfilled my promise.

Accomplissement, an accomplishing
or fulfilling: m.

Acconduire, to leade or bring to.

Les meschants Acconduirent les
Romains jusques au faint tem­
ple de Ierusalem, the wicked
brought the Romaines to the holy
temple, &c.

Acconsuyvre, j'acconsuy, j'accon­
suyvi, j'ay acconsuyvi, j'acconsuy­
vray, to followe, or ouertake.

Si vous piquez vn peu, vous l'Ac­
consuivrez aisément, if you spurre 
a little, you shall ouertake him ea­
silie.

Accoquiner, to make one a truant, to
allure him to beggerie.

Accorder, to agree, to consent, to
make agreement betweene two.

Accorder sa fille en mariage, ou son
fils, to betroth or make sure a sonne
or daughter.

Vn son accordant, a concorde in 
tune.

Accordé, agreed on.

Vne Accordée, a mayde made sure: f.

Accord de sons & choses diffe­
rentes, agreeing of disagreeing
things: m.

Accord, m: & convenance, f: coue­
nant or agreement.

Accord & consentement, an agree­
ment or consent.

Accord, paction, convention, a bar­
gaine, or composition.

Accordance, agreement: f.

Accordailles, a betrothing, or ma­
king sure: f.

on fera les Accordailles, or fian­
çailles, they shall be made sure.

Accort, wittie, wise, circumspect, craf­
tie, and subtile: m.

Accortesse, towardnes, good behaui­
our, finenes of wit: f.

Fame bien Accorte, a woman which





is wittie: &c. f.

Accortement, discreetly, pretilie,
finely.

Accoster, to drawe neere, to become
familiar with one.

Accotter, to proppe or staye vp, to
reare.

Accoté & appuyé contre vn arbre,
 stayed vp against a tree, reared vp.

Accortement, a butteresse or a sho­
ring.

Accote-pot, m: a stay for the pot by
the fier.

Accouder, to staie vpon his elbowe.

Vn Accoudoir, m: a forme or prop
whereupon you doe leane on the
elbowe.

Accoucher d'enfant, to lie in childe
bedde.

Femme qui accouche de son pre­
mier, shee that lieth in of her first
childe.

Vne Accouchée & gisante, a child­
bed wife: f.

s'Accoucher & s'alicter, to lie downe
sicke.

Accouchement, m: a laying downe,
or deliuerie of a woman in childe­
bed.

Accoupler, to ioyne or yoke toge­
ther.

Accouplement de bœufs, a yoking
of oxen: m.

Accourber, to crooke or make croo­
ked, to bend.

Accourcir, j'accourcis, j'accourci,
j'ay accoursi, j'accourciray, to
shorten.

Nous avons Accourci nostre che­
min, we haue shortened our way.

Accoursi, shortened.

Accourcissement, m: a shortening.

La grace de Dieu n'est en rien Ac­
courcie envers nous, the grace of
God towards vs, is in nothing short­
ned.

Accourir, j'accours, j'accouru, j'ay
accouru, j'accourray de toutes 
parts, to runne from all partes.

Accourement & assemblement de
gents, a running together, or as­
sembly of men: m.

Accours, m: Idem.

Il m'a Accousiné, he hath cousned
me.

Accousiner, to acknowledge one for
his cousine, to cousen one.

Ace, as, à ce propos, je dy cecy,
 touching the talke or matter be­
fore spoken I say this.

s'Accouster à l'oreille d'aucun, to
draw nigh into a mans eare.

Accouster, see escouter.

Accoustrer, to decke, to trimme, to
dresse.

Accoutré, decked, trimmed.

Accoustrement, decking or trim­
ming, apparell: m.

Accoustumer, to custom, or to enure.

s'Accoustumer, to vse, to custome
himselfe.

Accoustumé, customed.

Accoustumance, custome: f.

Acravanter, to burst out, to bruise.

Il s'Accravante de manger, hee ea­
teth so much that he bursteth.

Accrocher, to graspe, or to catch.

Accrocher le jugement d'vn pro­





ces, to stay the iudgement of a suite.

Accrochement, a clasping, a stay­
ing.

Accroire quelque argent, to trust
money.

Accroistre, to increase, to augment, to
multiply: j'accroy, j'accru, j'ay ac­
cru, jacroistray.

Accroissement, an increasing: m.

Accroissance, f: idem.

La malice humaine est tant accreue 
que, &c. Mens malice is so much
increased, that &c.

Acereu, encreased.

Accroupir, as if one should set vpon
his rumpe, to coope.

"coop" in this sense not found in OED.



S'accroupir, je m'accroupis, je m'­
accroupi, je me suy accroupi, je
m'accroupiray: to coope, to sitte
vpon his tayle.

Vne vieille accroupie, an olde coo­
ping iade.

Il est tous-jours accroupi au coin
du foyer: he is always cooping at
the chimnie corner.

Accubes, f: as tendre des pauillons
& accubes, to set his pauillions,
tents, or other cabines like, to rest
and lie in.

Accueil, il m'a fait vn bon accueil,
 he hath receiued me friendly.

Accueillir, to approch to a man, to
come neere, to welcome one.

Acrueillez-le, welcome him, receiue
him courteously.

Si vous ne saulpoudrez celà d'un
peu de sel, les vers s'y Accueilli­
ront, c'est à dire, s'y engendreront,
 except you powder it with salt, ma­
gots will ingender: it will be full
of magots.

Acculer vn home; to set one on his
tayle, to ouerthrow one.

Ie suy Acculé: I am set at non plus.

Acculer vn soulier, to treade downe
the heele of a shooe.

Accumuler & amasser: to gather or
heape together.

Accumulation, f: an heaping, a ga­
thering together.

Accumulateur, m: a gatherer.

Accumulatrice, f: a she gatherer.

Accuser aulcun, to accuse one.

Accuser & reprendre quelcun, to
lay a fault, to rebuke one.

Se mesler & faire mestier d'Accu­
ser, to make a trade to accuse.

Il a esté Accusé envers le magistrat,
 he hath beene accused before the 
magistrate.

Elle a esté Accusée de paillardise,
 she was accused of whoredome.

Vn Accusé, m: a man accused.

Vne Accusée, f: a woman accused.

Accusati, f. Accusement, m: an accu­
sation.

Vn Accusateur, m: an accuser.

Accusatrice, f: celle qui Accuse: she
which accuseth.

Acenser, to giue or take a Farme.

Acenseur, a Farmer.

Acensement, m: a letting to Farme.

Acerer, to forge with steele.

Harnois bien aceré, an harnesse very
strong, or steeled.

Acertener, to certifie.

I'en suy Acertené, I am certified
thereof.





Acertenement, m. a certifiyng.

A certes, in good earnest.

Achalander, to draw customers, as
Merchants doe.

Vne boutique bien Achalandée, a
shop well customed.

Acharner, to flesh.

Ilz sont tellement acharnez l'vn sur
l'autre, they are so earnest in fight,
so fleshed.

Acharner vn leurre pour reuoquer
le faulcon, to flesh a lure to call a
faulcon: Descharner, is the con­
trarie, as Descharner vn os, to pull
off the skin of a bone.

Achasser, to draw towards one.

Acconveter, to oppresse, to couer or
smoother.

De l'Ache, Smallage. f.

Achemes, m: long wormes in the
earth.

S'acheminer, to take his way.

Acheminer aucum & l'avoyer, to
put one into his right way.

Achemmer vne espousée, to trim a 
Bride.

Achemes, all kinde of decking for a 
woman. f.

Achemmeresse, or attourneresse, f: a Chamberer, one that apparelleth
her mistresse.

Achenal, a chanel: Eau es conduites
dans la ville, par des Achenaux
de huict paumes de large, waters
conueied into the town by chanels,
eight palmes broade: m.

Acher, or agacer les dents, to set his
teeth on edge.

Acheter, to buy, to redeeme, to bar­
gaine.

Acheté, bought or redeemed.

Acheteur, a buyer, m.

Acheteresse, f: she that buyeth.

Achat, a bargaine, a thing bought.

Achever, to end, to conclude, to finish:
j'acheve, j'acheuay, &c.

Achevé & parfaict, ended and per­
fect.

Achevement, an ending, a perfe­
ction: m.

l'Achiles de la cause, m: the chiefest 
poynt in a matter.

Vne achoise fort grande, a very good
occasion.

Acier, steele, m.

A coup, sodainly.

Acquerir, j'acquiers, j'acquis, j'ay
acquis, j'acquerray, to get, to ob­
taine, to purchase.

Acquest, as il n'y a point d'acquest
en luy, there is nothing to be gotten
at his hand: m.

Acquis, gotten, obtained.

Acquests, goods bought after one is 
maryed.

Conquests, goods purchased in ma­
riage

Acquereur, or Acquesteur, m: a
purchaser.

Biens Acquis, goods purchased or
gotten.

Chose mal Acquise, f: a thing ill
gotten.

I'ay Acquis sa bien veillance, I haue
got his good will or friendship.

Acquisition, purchase.

Acquisition de la Seigneurie, the
getting of the Lordship by prescrip­
tion.





Acquiescer à ce qui est jugé, S'ac­
corder & obeïr de la sentence, to
stand to the iudgement, to agree 
to the sentence.

Il Acquiesce à tout, hee yeeldeth or
agreeth to all, and in all.

Letres d'Acquiescement, m: letters
to his counsailer or attourney to a­
gree with the partie.

S'acquitter, to be quit, to dispatch,
to rid or vnburden.

Acquitté de son serment, free or quit 
of an oath.

Vn Acquit, a quittance: m.

Il a produit en jugement faulx Ac­
quits, he hath brought forth to the 
court false quittances or writings.

Faire quelque chose laschement,
& par maniere d'acquit feule­
men pour en estre depesché, to
do a thing sleightly with riddance,
only to be dispatcht of it.

Ie le feray, mais par acquict, I will
doe it, but it shal be ouerly done, or
to be ridden of it.

Acquoiser, to pacifie: see Accoiser.

Acre, com: comme oignons, aulx, 
cives, &c. sharp: as onions, garlick,
and such like.

Acrimonie, f: sharpenesse.

Acroteres, a promontorie, an hill
or high place like an elbow in the
Sea seene farre off.

Acte, m: common letters, writings, or
instruments exhibited by the iud­
ges in the court, for confirmation
of any matter.

Touchant le tort à moy fait, en ceste
cour, j'en requiers Acte, Touch­
ing the wrong done vnto me, in this
court, I doe require to haue it in
writing, for a president.

Par Acte registres, & enserigne­
ments publicques, le fait est ave­
re, the fact is made euident by re­
gisters and authentical writings.

Actes & faits d'une personne,
 deeds of any man.

Vn home Actif, an actiue man.

Action, f: an action, or deede.

Actions de graces, thanksgiuing.

Iete iudge selon tes Actions, I doo
iudge thee according to thy deedes
and actions.

Action & droit de poursuivre en ju­
stice ce qui nous est deu, an acti­
on in Law.

Intenter Action en cas d'injures à
l'encontre de quelcun, to enter an
action against any, by reason of in­
iuries.

Actuel, ready, spedy, effectuall.

Actuellement, presently, out of
hand.

C'est vn commun Adage, it is a com­

Home Adestré, an apt man to all things.

Qui adjoinct, a ioiner to, an adder to.

Il commence à adjourner, it waxeth

Ie t'adjure au nom de Dieu, I con­

nishement: f.

Addresser quelqu'vn au chemin, to

S'adresser à Dieu, to meddle, to rise,
and as if it were, to make warre a­
gainst God.

S'il s'addresse à moy, j'e l'en feray 
repentir, if he doth meddle with
me, I will, &c.

himselfe in some thing.

Vne adresse & coursiére, a short or

Affiches, bils set vpon streets or cor­

Afficter, to annexe or giue for a time.

Donner Adresses à aulcun, to giue

Adroit, as c'est vn home bien adroit
à cecy, ou à cela: an handsome and 
fit man to this or that thing.

Home mal adroit, the contrary.

Advancer, see Advancer, to goe for­
ward.

Advantage, seeke Avantage.

Adveillé, full of sorrowe.

Advenant, comelie, handsome, de­
cent, sitting.

Home adroit et advennant, a fit man
to any thing.

Il est jeune et gaillard à l'advenant,
 he is yong and lustie accordingly.

Advenir, to happen, to chaunce, to be­
tide, to come to passe: il advient, il
advint, il est aduenu, il adviendra,
a verbe impersonall.

Il est advenu, it happened, it chan­
ced, it came to passe.

Qui est advenu & commis, which
came to passe, or was commit­
ted.

Advenement, a chaunce, a hope, a
comming: as au second advene­
ment du filz de Dieu, at the second
comming of the sonne of God: m.

Advenamment, as cela est fait fort
advenamment: that is done very
directly, comely, or handsomely.

Garder les advenuës, to keepe and
watch the accesse or entries into a 
place: f.

Reciter les Advenuës passées, to re­
hearse the haps and chances passed.

Aduenture, a chance, a fortune, an
aduenture: f.

S'adventurer, to aduenture.

Il est fort Aduentureux: m. 

Aduersaire, an aduersarie, an ene­
mie.

Adversité, aduersitie, mishap, misfor­





tune, ill successe: f.

Aduertir, j'advertis, j'adverti, j'ay ad­
verti, j'advertiray, to aduertise, to
warne, to declare.

Adverty, monished, or warned.

Advertissement, an admonition: m.

A mon adueu, on my word or fideli­
tie: m.

Faites cela à mon adveu, do that in
my name, I will auouch it.

Adveux et contrats, agreements and
contracts.

Advienne, j'a ne m'advienne que je 
pense ainsi, let not this chaunce 
happen vnto me that &c. God for­
bid that I, &.c.

Ia ne t'Advienne que, &c. God for­
bid that you should do that: let not
such chance happen vnto thee, that
&c. see Advenir.

Advis & opinion, deuise, counsell, or
iudgement: m.

Adviser, to aduise, to consider, to de­
termine.

Adviser aucun, to giue one aduise.

Bien advisé, well aduised, circum­
spect.

Advisement & esgard qu'on a à
faire quelque chose, taking ad­
vise or warinesse, in dooing any
thing: m.

Aduisement, aduisedly, warily, circum­
spectly.

Adulateur, a flatterer: m.

Adulatoire, com: pertaining or like
to flatterie.

Vn Adultere, an adulterer, one that
committeth whordome in mariage.

Commettre Adultere, to commit a­
dulterie: m.

Le fait d'adultere, adulterie.

Advocat, an Aduocate, an Attorney,
a Procurator: m.

Advocasser pour aucun, & le desen­
cre en jugement, to plead or stand
in a mans case.

Advouër quelque crime & confes­
ser l'avoir commis, to avouche a
crime, or confesse the deed.

Advouäison, an admission, as when a 
Prince doth auow an other Prince
to be vnder his protection: f.

l'Advouë, he which is in protection.

Aduste, parched, burned, com.

Adustion, f: burning, parching.

Aele, a wing: see Aile.

Aerin, m: brasse.

Aerolle, ou empoule, f: a blister.

Affable, gentle, curteous, louing,
meeke: com.

Affabilitté f: gentlenes in hearing.

Affablement, gently.

Affadir, to wax vnsauerie.

Affaicter, to trim, to make fine.

Affaicter vn Faulcon, to tame a 
Hauke, to make him gentle.

Affaire, businesse, affaires: m.

C'est ton Affaire, it is thy matter, it
standeth thee vpon.

s'Affaisser, to bee ouerladon, to
shrinke.

Affaissement de quelque grande
chose pesante quand ille s'est a­
baissée & affaissée, a shrinking vn­
der a great burthen, an ouerburthe­
ning, a quelling: m.

Affamer vne ville, to famishe a
towne.





Affamé, famished.

Vn stile trop affecté, a kinde of
speeche or writing too fine, or pre­
cise.

Affecter de se mettre en la male
grace d'aucun, to get the ill will of
any man.

Affectation folle, a foolish desire, a
precise endeuour of will to doe a
thing, f.

Affection, affection, desire, will, the
disease of the minde: f.

Affectionné, affectionate.

S'affectionner à quelque chose, to
giue his minde to any thing.

Affectioner aucun, to entise one.

Affectuëusement, affectuously, wil­
lingly, desirously.

Affermer, to affirme, to confirme, to 
assure, to giue to farme.

Affermir, j'affermis, j'affermi, j'ay
affermi, j'affermiray, to fortifie, to
make firme, to stablish.

Qui Affermit, which establisheth.

Affetterie, subtiltie, craft, wilinesse,
dissembling: f.

Il est fort affété, he is very nice and
craftie withall.

Afficher, to fasten.

Affichement, fastening: m.

Affiches, billes set vp in streetes or
corners: f.

Afficter, to annexe or giue for a
time.

Affiert ou conuient, it behooueth, or
seemeth, also it is taken for to certi­
fie: as Ie vous affie qu'il est ainsi,
that is, Ie vous assure.

Affier des arbres de tous fruits, to
plant and graffe trees of all sortes
of fruites.

Cela ne m'Affiert en rien: that
pertaineth nothing vnto me: it tou­
cheth me nothing at all.

Cecy Affiert fort bien: convient ou
est Afferant à vn home de telle
dignité que vous estes: this becom­
meth well, &c.

Affiller, to whet, to sharpen.

Affin, write afin, that, or to the ende
that: see, fin.

Affiné, that which is fined or tried:
made finer, deceiued.

Affiner les fins, to beguile the craf­
tie.

Affineur or trompeur: m: a decei­
uer.

Affineur d'or, a golde finer: m.

Affins & alliez par mariage, kin or
allies: m.

Affinité, affinitie or alliaunce: f.

Vn Afiquet, a iewell, a carquenet, it
may be called a brooch: m.

Affiquets de nulle valeur, trifles,
toyes, trinkets: m.

Affirmation, an affirmation, a soo­
thing: f.

Affirmateur, m: a confirmer.

Afflater aulcun, see Flatter.

Affliger, & vexer, ou tourmenter, 
to afflict, to greeue, or torment.

Affligé & tourmenté, afflicted and 
tormented.

Affliction, affliction: f.

Affluence, plentie, aboundance: f.

Entreprendre de s'Affoler soymes­
me, to goe about to hurt himselfe.

Affoiblir, to weaken to decay.





Affoibli, decayed, waxen weake.

Affoiblir la monnoye, to delay or a­
bate golde or siluer: j'Affoiblis,
j'affoibli, j'ay affoibli, j'affoibliray.

Affoiblissement, a weakening: m.

Affoler pour blesser, to hurt, to fel
one downe.

Ie suy Affolé, I am vndone.

Afolure, f: hurt.

Affouchié, that is, mis à la fouchié­
re,  or fouchere, when wilde boares
doe roote out the roote of the ferne,
and make great holes in the ground
with their snout.

Affourrer les montons ou chevaux, 
 to put hay or strawe into sheepes or
horses mangeres: to serue the cat­
tell.

Affranchir vn serviteur, & luy don­
ner liberté, to set a seruant at liber­
tie: I'affranchis, j'affranchis, j'ay af­
franchi, j'affranchiray.

Affranchisseur, m: he that setteth at
libertie.

Affres, as bailler les affres à aulcun, 
to fray one: f.

Il luy a fait belles Affres, hee hath
made him muche astonied, afraide.

Affreux, roughe, horrible, grimme: m.

Affreusement, grimly, sturdily.

Affreuseté, sturdinesse, grimlinesse: f.

Affriander, Affrioler, to cocker, to
make likerish, to pamper.

Affriandé, affriolé, intised, allured.

Affriolement, m: intising, a prouo­
cation.

Affronter aucun & abuser, to de­
ceiue.

Vn Affronteur & Abuseur, a decei­
uer, a beguiler: m.

Affubler, to clothe, sometime to
shroude and hide one.

Affublé, cloathed: couered with a 
cloake.

Affublement: m: & converture: f:
 clothing or couering.

Affuir, that is, Accourir, to runne to
vs for helpe or succour.

Affust d'artillerie, m: the carriage of
artilerie.

Les Affusts sont tous rompus, all the
cariages, frames, or stocks are bro­
ken.

Affuster, as Affuster l'artillerie to
sette the artillerie in the stocke or
frame.

Aga, mon army, see, looke friend, a 
word spoken merely, or in mockage.

Agacer aucun, to egge, to stirre, to
prouoke.

I'ay les dens toutes Agacées, my
teeth be set on edge.

Agacement, a stirring or prouo­
king: m.

Agacement de dens, setting the 
teeth on edge.

Agaric, a mushrome, a kinde of 
gumme: m.

Vne Agasse or Agache, a Maget­
apie.

Agay, m: among falconers, is the
marrowe out of bones.

Agape, a loue, banquet, or feaste
that was vsed in the Primitiue 
Church: f.

Agate pierre precieuse, an Agath: f.

Agencer, to make fit, iuste, or apt.

Agent, as le Senat n'est que l'agent





du peuple, the Senat is but the
executor or doer, for or insteed of
the people.

Il a son Agent en la cour, he hath his
dooer at the court: m.

Les Marchants ont leurs facteurs, &
les princes & seigneurs leurs A­
gents, Marchants haue their fac­
tours, and Princes and Lords their
doers: m.

Agesimos, a wondring voice or ex­
clamation: m.

s'Agenouiller, to kneele, to bowe a 
mans selfe.

Aggluer, to ioyne, to glue, to soulder to
gether.

Agglué, congealed together.

Aggrandir, j'aggrandis, j'aggrandi,
j'ay aggrandi, j'aggrandiray, to
make great, to enlarge.

Aggravanter, ou Aggraver, to aggra­
uate, or make haynous.

Aggravée, aggrauated, vexed, or
made haynous.

Excommunier, Aggraver, & Reag­
graver, cursed and cursed againe by
a solemne excommunication in the
Church.

Comminations & Aggravations,
 execrations, or cursings.

Aggreable, agreeable, acceptable,
pleasant.

Il n'Aggrée point à l'oreille du com­
mun populaire, it liketh not the
common people.

Aggreger, to assemble, to gather to­
gether.

Aggrener, to feede a beaste with
graine.

Aggresseur, the first assaulter: the gi­
uer of the onset: m.

Aggression, f: the first setting on.

Agilité, nimblenesse: f.

Agilement, nimblely, lightly.

Agir en matiere d'injures, to sue an
action of trespasse, j'agis, j'agi,
j'ay agi, j'agiray.

Agir personnellement, to agree vp­
on a matter propounded: to sue an
action.

Les corps celestes Agissent en ces
terrestres, the celestiall planets doe
worke in these earthly.

Agitation & esmouvement, mouing,
working, exercising, tossing: f.

Agité, moued, tossed, exercised.

Agneau, a Lambe: m.

Agneler, to yeane or bring forth a 
Lambe.

Agnelet, a little Lambe: m.

Agonie, f: anguish, griefe.

Agoure de lin, m: a weed called Pod­
der, winding about hempe or other 
like.

Agrandir, to enlarge or make grea­
ter, see Aggrandir.

Agraphe, f: to buckle of a girdle, a 
claspe, or brace, a graple.

Agraphiner or egraphigner, to
scratche one.

Agré, see Gré: a liking or pleasing.

Agreable, see Aggreable.

Agri-paulme, an hearbe called mo­
ther-worte.

Agreslir la voix, to squeake out, or sing
shrill, j'agreslis, j'agresli, j'ay a­
gresli, j'agreliray, to waxe leane.

Elle est fort Agreslie, shee is waxed





verie leane, small, or slender.

Agriculture, tillage of the ground: f.

Agu, sharpe.

Aguets, as les Marchants sont sub­
jects aux aguets des pirates & bri­
gands, Marchants are subiect to
the ambushes, waites or intrappings
of pirats and theeues: m.

Aguille à coudre, a sowing needle: f.

Aguillette, a point: f.

Aguilleter, to tie ones pointes.

Vn fer d'aguillette, a tagge.

Aguillon, to pricke or goad, a sting: m.

Aguilloner, to pricke forward, to stir,
to prouoke.

Aguillonnement, a pricking for­
ward: m.

Aguillonneur, a pricker forward, a 
stirrer, a mouer: m.

Aguïser, to sharp, to whet, to grinde.

Pierre Aguïsoire, a whetting stone.

Aguïsement, sharpening: m.

Aguëment veoir, sharpe sight.

Agyos or agios, blessings and cros­
sings which the papisticall priests
doe vse in their holy water, to make 
a mearlew muse: f.

Ahanner, to toile, or ouerworke.

Ahan or ahen, m: a great labour or
toile.

Adherdre, to catch, to snatch, to take.

Aheurté en son opinion, obstinate in
opinion, selfe willed, stifnecked.

Aheurtement, Le vice d'obstinati­
on, obstinacie, selfe will-nesse: m.

Vn Aheurté plaideur, m: an obsti­
nate suiter in the lawe, a man ful of
strife.

A hocquer see Accrocher.

Ahontir vn home, to make one asha­
med

Ahurir, to make one astonied.

Ahurté, see Aheurte.

Ahy, mot qui sé dit quand on a 
peur, out alas.

Aider, to helpe, to assiste, to further,
to set forward, to succour.

Qui Aide, a helper, or furtherer.

Aide, helpe, succour, furtherance: f.

Lever Aides sur les subjets, to leuie a 
subsidie vpon his subiects: f.

Vn Aigle, an Ægle.

Aigremoine, Egrimony: m.

Estre Aigre, to be sharpe.

Aigret, tirant vn peu sur l'aigre, tart,
or almost sowre.

S'aigrir, je m'aigris, je m'aigri, je me 
suy aigri, je m'aigriray, to waxe
sowre or tarte.

Aigrir & irrirer aucun, to stirre or
moue one to anger.

Aigreur, sharpenesse, tartnesse: f.

Aigrement, sharpely, sowerly.

Aigret somewhat tart or sharp.

Fruit Aigrets, fruites somewhat
sower.

Aigre-foin, m: a kinde of fish.

Aigrette, a bird much like an Herne,
but white: f.

Aigrun, m: any thing or meane which
maketh a sore, disease or sicknes
worse.

Aigue, as apportez moy de l'Aigue, 
bring mee some water, as they speak
in Langdock.

An Ail, and in the plurall numbar, des
Aulx, m: garlick.

Aulx-oignon, m: great garlick.





Il sent l'Aillade, he smelleth or sent­
eth Garlick: f.

Les ailées qu'on baille à vn cheval, 
 to giue a horse the head.

Aile d'oyseau, ou d'autre beste qui
vole, the wing of a bird, or any o­
ther beast that flieth: f.

Vn Ailler à prendre cailles, a kinde
of net to take Quailes: m.

Ailette, f: Ailerette, f: or Aileron,
m: a little wing.

Ailleurs, elsewhere.

Ailleurs enuoyé, sent somewhither
else.

D'ailleurs, from some otherplace.

Vne pierre appellée Aimant, the
Lode-stone: m.

Foy Aimantine, faithe as strong as
that stone drawing yron: f.

Aimer, to loue, to delight in any
thing.

Aimant, a louer, a sweet hart, m: A­
miable, com: digne d'estre Ay­
mé, worthie to be loued.

Aines, f: the grine.

Ainçois, ains, rather.

Ainsi, euen so, after the same man­
ner.

Aïnsi comme, euen as, as it were.

Airer, to be angry.

Il est aïré, he is angry.

Air, the aire: m.

Airin, m: full of ayre, abounding with
ayre.

L'aire d'une granche, the floure of a 
Barne: f.

Aireau, a plough: m.

Longues Aires és jardins, a bed in a 
Garden: f.

Aire, the nest of a Hawke, or bird of
praye: m.

Estre debonnaire, & sans ma­
lice, to be gentle and without ma­
lice.

Airer, or els nicher: when birds make
their nests.

Ais, a boord: m.

Paver d'ais, to floore with boords.

Aisance, ease, commoditie: f.

Aisceau, m: or Aissette, f: a chippe
Axe.

Aisé à faire, easie to be done.

Estre fort aisé en son mesnage, to be
well setled, to be in good estate.

Aise, pleasure, ease: m.

Il prend ses aises, he taketh his 
ease.

Aisément, easily, with small paine.

Aisements, m: or Aisances, f: priuies
or iakes houses.	

Aisné, first borne: le filz aisné, la
fille aisnée, the eldest Sonne, the el­
dest Daughter.

Aisnette, as le droict d'aisnesse, the
prerogatiue or right of the first
birth: f.

Aisselle, ou les aeles, the arme holes: f

Aisselle, a little boorde: f.

S'alachir, to waxe slowe.

Alaigre, nimble, actiue, lustie.

Alaigrement, lustily, actiuely, nimbly,
cheerefully.

Alaigreté, cheerefulnesse: f.

Alegresse: idem.

S'alangourir, to waxe sluggish.

S'alangourir, idem: je m'alanguis, je
m'alangui, je me suy alangui, je
m'alanguiray. 





Alarme, as donner l'alarme, to as­
saile, to set on, to runne to take his
armour: f.

Alberges, a kinde of small peaches.

Vn Alberger, m: a tree bearing
such fruit.

Albrent, a yong wilde Ducke: m.

Chasser aux Albrents, to hunt yong
wilde Ducks.

Aireau, a plough: m.

Alcoran, the law of Mahomet: m.

Alebastre, Aleblaster: m.

Aleman, a Germane: m.

Alembic, a Stillitary, a Limbeck: m.

S'alanmbiquer, to weare away, to con­
sume.

Aleiner, to breath, to smell.

Alenois: see cresson: kerse or cres­
ses.

s'Allentir, je m'alentis, j'm'alen­
ti, je me suy alenti, je m'alentiray,
 to waxe slacke, to refraine, to be
lesse earnest.

Vne Alesne, an aule or bodkin: f.

Aleu, or aloy, as vn champ tenu du
franc aleu, a feelde in fee simple,
which acknowledgeth no Lord, a
free tenure, not acknowledging any
superiour Lords: m.

Alicté perpetuellement de maladie,
 he that lieth bedred: m.

Alienation, an alienation or making 
away: f.

Aliené, alienated.

Aliener & estranger, to alienate, to
make strange, to take away.

Il est Aliené de son entendement:
 he is out of his wit, he is not in his
right minde.

Alienation, f: an alienation.
Ie ne fay conte de toutes tes Al­
legations, f: I set nothing by all thy
reasons.

Algarade, a swift and sodaine inuasi­
on of Riuers vpon the Sea: a braue­
rie of horsemen or souldiers going
out of a fort against their enemies: f

Alignement, Carde or draught: m.

Prendre les alignements, & mesu­
res d'vne ville, to take the draught
of a towne.

Alibi, a Latin word signifiyng, ano­
ther place, and is vsed in french
thus: Il veult signifier par vn A­
libi, qu'il n'est point consentant
à la trahison, he will shew by his be­
ing in another place, that &c.

Cercher des Alibi forains, to seeke
crafty shifts in matter of law.

Aliage, the allaying or abasing of
golde or siluer, to stiffen it or har­
den it: m.

Aliment & nourriture, food, nourish­
ment: m.

Alimenté, fed, nourished.

Alisier, a tree that groweth in A­
strike, and is called a Lote tree: m.

Allaicter, to giue sucke.

Qui allaicte, she that giueth sucke.

Alaictement, a giuing sucke: m.

Allan, a kinde of strong Dog: m.

Alleger, to heaue vp, to ease, to suc­
cour, to lighten.

Alleguer taulsement & malicieuse­
ment, ou mettre à sus quelque
chose à quelqu'vn, falsely to lay 
to ones charge.

Alleguer ses moyens, causes &





raisons, to alledge the causes.

Allegeance, an easing or succou­
ring: f.

Allegement, easing or succouring: m

Aller, je vay, j'allay, je suy allé, j'
iray, to goe, to walke, to wander, to
iourney.

Aller à pied, to goe a iourneye on 
foote.

Aller à cheval, to goe by horsse, to
ride.

Aller au devant, to meet with, to pre­
uent.

Aller contre aucun par fureur, to
goe furiously against one.

Aller apres aucun, to goe after one.

Aller vers aucun, to goe towards one.

Aller ça & là de costé & d'autre, to
wander, to goe hither and thither, to
stray.

Aller jus, to runne headlong, to de­
cay.

Allée, an alley, a path, a way: f.

Allée ou Gallerie, & autre lieu où
on se pourmeine, an alley or gale­
rie, a walking place.

Allure, f: gate or going.

Alliarie, or els, herbe aux aulx: 
iacke of the hedge tasting as Gar­
lick.

Allouer, to allow, or to approue.

Allouée, approued or allowed.

s'Allier avec aucun, to plight friend­
ship with any, to ioyne with another.

Allier la voix avec la corde, to ioyne
the voice with the string of the in­
strument, that is, to sing and play to­
gether.

Fort Allié & grand ami, very great
friends.

Peuples Alliez, people confederate,
brethren, fellowes: m.

Alliance, alliance: f.

Faire Alliance, to make alliance, to
make peace.

Allicher, to allure, to mittigate.

Allicheir, an enticement: m.

Allichement, enticement, prouocati­
on, temptation: m.

Alloigner, to chase or driue farre in 
hunting.

Allouvi, as hungry as a wolfe.

Allumer, to lighten, to kindle, to en­
flame.

Allumettes, matches made of brim­
stone: f.

Allusion, an alluding or applying to
an other thing: f.

Almandes, little Boates made with
barkes of trees, which wilde men in 
Affrike vse: f.

Alme, com: beautifull, nourishing.

Alonger, to lengthen.

Alongé, lengthened.

Alongement, m: a lengthening.

Alopécie, when through sicknesse the
haires doe fall: f.

Alors, at that time, then.

Alose, a fish named a shad: f.

Se Allouser, to praise himselfe.

Vne Alouëtte, a Larke: f.

Aloy, money, alay or value of golde
or siluer: m.

Alouër, to allow.

Les Alpes, mountaines in Italie cal­
led the Alpes: m.

Alquemie, or Arquemie, Alcu­
mistrie: f.





Faire l'alquemie des dents, or avec 

Ales dents, to fast.

Alterer, to encrease thirst.

Qui est Alteré, thirstie.

Par Alterations & changemens:
d'ans, by altering and changing of
yeeres.

Estant en ces altéres, being in those
passions: m.

Pierreries alterées, iewels or preci­
ous stones falcified.

Il est tout Alteré et changé, he is al­
together changed.

Alternatif: that is done by turne or
course one after an other, chan­
gingly.

Alternativement: by course or turn,
one after another.

Faire les offices Alternatifs, to make
or create offices by turnes, or one after
another.

Alternations, f: as, faire par alterna­
tions: when men do things one af­
ter an other, or by turnes.

Alterquer, to wrangle, to brawle.

Alterquation, f: brawling, wrang­
ling.

Alterquateur, m: a brawler or wrang­
ler.

Alumelle, or alemelle d'espée ou
cousteau, a blade.

Alumette, see Allumettes , a match.

Alvine, Wormewood, see Absynte.

Alun, Allume: m.

Amadouër, & appaiser de belles
paroles, to delight, to flatter with
faire words.

Amodouëur, a flatterer, a fair spea­
ker: m.

Amadouëment, flatterie, faire
speech, lulling a sleepe: m.

Amaigrir, je m'amaigris, je m'a­
maigri, je me suy amaigri, je m'a­
maigriray, devenir gresle & me­
nu, to wax leane or thin.

Vne Almande. an Almonde: f.

Vn Amandier, an Almond tree: m.

Amantelé, cloaked.

Amaranthe, or els, passe-velours,
 flower gentill.

L'Amarri: m, ou matrice d'une
femme, the wombe or matrix of a

Amas, monceau, & tas, a heape, a

Amas, de blé, a heape of corne.

Grand Amas de bois, a great pile of
wood.

Amas de gens & assemblée, a great
number of people.

Amasser, to gather together, to heap
together.

s'Amasser, to agree or gather in one.

Qui est Amassé & amoncelé, which
is gathered and heaped.

Amassement, a gathering toge­
ther: m.

Amasseur, m: a gatherer.

Amasseresse, f: a she gatherer.

Amateur, a louer: m.

Amathyste, pierre precieuse, a preci­
ous stone called an Amathist: f.

Ambages, or ambageois, a circuit
of words, a long folish discourse: m.

Amie, a she freend, a loue: f.

Amiable, com: louing.

Amiableté, f: gentlenes.

Ambagieux: going by circuit or 





crooked waies.

Ambassades, Ambassadeur: an
Ambassador.

Ambiguëment parler à deux en­
tentes, dire parolles doubteuses
par lesquelles on ne sçait qu'en­
tendre, to speake doubtfully, or with
double vnderstanding.

Ambiguité, ambiguitie: f.

Ambition, ambition, desire of ho­
nour: f.

Ambitieux, qui brigue & pour­
chasse honneurs, ambitious.

Aller les Ambles, to amble, to goe
roundly: f.

Ambre, amber: m.

Ambre gris, amber to make per­
fumes: m.

Parlement ambulatoir, the high
Court of Parliament going from
place to place, or hauing no stedfast
place: the circuit of judges.

Ame, as rendre l'ame, to giue vp the 
ghost: f.

Vne ame damnée, a damned soule.

Ameliurer, to waxe better: also to
mend a thing, and to make it better.

Amende, an amercement, a fine: f

Condamner à l'Amende, to con­
demne one to pay a fine.

Amender, to correct, to amend.

Amender vn champ, to make fertill
or battell a fielde.

Amendement, a mending: m.

Demander l'Amendement d'au­
cun méfaict à l'encontre d'aucun,
 to demaund recompence of a man.

Amener, to leade, to bring.

Amenement, mot peu vsité, a
bringing in: m.

Amenuiser, to make thinne, to make
slender.

Qui est Amer, bitter.

Amerement, bitterly.

Amertume, bitternesse: f.

Amesnager sa maison, to furnish a 
house.

Ameuter, when houndes brought vp
togither, do agree in hunting.

Ami, a friend, a louer: m.

Amiablement, louingly, friendly,
gently, amiably.

Amieller le peuple par doulces pa­
rolles, luy desrober le cueur, to
entise the people with faire words,
and to win their harts.

Amignotter, to pranke or to trim, to
cocker.

Amignarder: idem.

Amignottement, cockering: m.

Amitié, friendship, loue, concord: f.

Gomme Ammoniac, gumme: m.

Amomon, a pleasant little shrubbe
growing in Armenia.

Amodiation, or ferme, the Kings cu­
stome giuen to farme.

Amoderer, to moderate, to asswage.

Amoindrir, j'amoindris, j'amoindri,
j'ay amoindri, j'amoindriray, to
lessen, to diminish.

Amoindrissement, a lessening: m.

Amollir, to make softe: j'amollis, j'­
amolli, j'ay amolli, j'amolliray.

Amonceler, to gather, to heape toge­
ther.

Racourci & amoncelé, shortened, or
brought in lesse roome.

Amoncelement, a gathering togi­





gether, a heaping: m.

Amont, vpward.

Amorce, a bayte: f.

Amorcer, to lay a bayte.

Amortir, to quench: j'amortis, j'am­
orti, j'ay amorti, j'amortiray.

Lettres d'Amortissement, m: let­
ters patents, by the which all sutes
are dead.

Amour, loue, friendship, charitie: m.

Vn Amoureux, a hee louer: m.

Amoureuse, a she louer: f.

Amoureusement, louingly.

Amourachement, inticing to loue: m.

Ampeser, to starch.

Ampois, starch: m.

Amphisbeine, a kinde of Serpent ha­
uing a head at his taile, where with
he biteth going, and fighting as
well backward as forward: m.

Ample, ample, large.

Plus Ample, more large.

Tresample, most large, or ample.

Amplement, largely, aboundantly.

Amplié, & augmenté, encreased, or
augmented.

Ampliateur & augmentateur, an
augmenter: m.

Ampliation, f: enlarging.

Ampois, m: Starch.

Ampeser, to starch.

Ampesé, starched.

Amuser à veoir vn danseur par des­
fus la corde, to spend the time to see
one daunce on acorde.

Vn Amuseur, m: one that keepeth
the people in gasing.

Amusement, gasing, sporte: m.

Amuser aucun, to set one in a dumpe,
to busie one.

Amydon, wheate softened in water 
and milke, & then dried in the sun:
it may be called furmentie: m.

An: m. ou année: f. a yeare.

Les neiges d'Anten, snowe of the
last yeare.

Anarchie, a common wealth without
head or gouernour: f.

Anagrammatisme, a pretie posie by 
setting of the letters together of
some mens name: m.

Anatomie, an Anatomie: f.

Ancelle, f: a mayd-seruant.

Anches: f. a pipe that hath as it were
a little tongue or tenon, which min­
strels doe put into their holt-bois,
which they holde in their mouth.

Anchois, a fish called Anchoes, eaten
like a pickle herring.

Ancholie herbe, an hearbe or flower
called Columbine: of some Capons
fether, or setwall."fether" in this sense not found in the OED.

Anchuses, an hearbe called wilde
buglos or orchanette.

De l'Aneth or Anet, m: dill or any-
seede.

Les Ancestres, our auncestors: m.

Ancien, auncient, olde, of long conti­
nuance: m.

Les Anciens, the auncients.

Ancienneté, ancientie: f.

Anciennement, in time past.

Ancoigneure, a wedge: hauing cor­
ners like a wedge: f.

Vne Ancre à retenir les navires, an
anchor: f.

Ancrer au port, to cast anchor.

Vn Ancrier, a vessell to keepe incke,





an inckehorne: m.

Andain, it is as much space as a man
can comprehende with both his
legges.

Andouilles, chitterlings or guttes
salted and hanged in the smoake.

Andouille, or andoille, Linkes, a
kinde of meate made of Hogges
guts kept in brine: f: chitterlings.

Androgyne, he that is both man and
woman: m.

Aneau, seeke Anneau.

s'Aneantir & ne tenir compte de 
soy, to abase or not esteeme him­
selfe: j'aneantis, j'aneanti, j'ay
aneanti, j'aneantiray.

Ange, an Angel: m.

Le bon & mauvais Ange que les
Payens estimoyent estre deux di­
eux privez, & familiers, qui s'ap­
pliquoyent à vn chascun dés
l'heure de sa naissance, a ghost.

Vn Ange or Angelot de mer, a scale
fish: m.

Vn Angelot, a cheese so called: m.

L'herbe qu'on appelle Angelique, 
 an hearbe called Angellica.

Angle, a corner: f.

Vn Anglet, ou coing de toutes cho­
ses, the corner of any thing: m.

Angler vne personne, & ferrer a
l'estroict, to shut one vp in a corner,
to bring into a straight.

Angoisse, anguish, griefe of minde: f.

Pomes d'angoisse, choking apples.

Angoisser, to grieue.

l'Angouste, a Grashopper: f.

Anguille, an eele: f.

Anguste, narrowe, straight, of a small
compasse.

Angustie, distres, griefe, narrownes: f.

Aniler, to abate, to darken.

Anilles, crutches: m.

Animal, a creature, beast, cattell: m.

Tous les animaux de la terre, all
the creatures or beastes of the
earth.

Animer & inciter à son de fleutes
les gents à frapper, to encourage,
or harten men to fight, by the sound
of a flute.

Animer & bailler courage, to encou­
rage, to giue life.

Animosité, stoutnes.

De l'Any, Anniseede: m.

Annales & chroniques, yearely
Chronicles: f.

Annate, the first fruite of any bene­
fice: f.

Anneau qu'on met au doigt, a
ring: m.

Vn Anneau ou cachet, a sealing
ring.

Annelet que on met aux habille­
mens, hookes of golde or siluer vpon

Annelets d'vne cotte de maille, or
escailles d'une brigantine, the
rings of a priuie coate, or scales of
a brigandine.

Annexer, to ioyne to.

Annexée, ioyned, coupled, or linked.

Estre tellement Annichilé, qu'il
n'en demeure point vn, so vani­
shed away, that nothing remaineth.

Annichiler, to bring to nothing.





Annuël, yearely.

Rente Anuëlle, a yearely rent.

Annuëllement, done euery yeare.

fect, &c.

before.

s'Annonchalir, Aneantir, to pine, to

Il est Angouë, he is almost choaked,
when the mosel is so great, that one
canot swallowe it down: see Engouë.

Anten, the last yeare.

Ie te crains aussi peu, que les neiges
d'Anten, I feare thee as little, as I
doe snowes of the last yeare.

Antenois, of the last yeare.

Antichambre, the for-chamber, m.

Anterieur, that is in the former place,

uenting.

Antidater vne obligation, to giue an
Antedate to an Obligation: which 
beareth a date of a day and time
before it was made.

Antidote, m: a counter-poyson.

Antidoter vn home, to giue a man a
preseruatiue against euill aire or 
poyson.

Antimonie, concordance, agree­
ment: f.

De l'Antimonion, a white stone
found in siluer mines, good for the
eyes.

Antipathíe, repugnance, disagree­
ing of nature, humors and conditi­
ons: f: contrarietie of naturall
qualities: sympathie is the contra­
rie.

Antipodes, people going directly a­
gainst vs, foote to foote.

Vn Antipodium, m: the addition or
aduantage aboue measure: an o­
uerplus.

Antique, auncient.

Chose faite à l'Antique, a thing
made after the ancient fashion.

Antiquement, after the olde sorte.

Vn Antrac, ou charbon, a coale; al­
so a sore called a carbuncle; some­
time a precious stone so named: m.

Antre, m: a denne.

Anuï to daye.





Ie ne bou geray d'Anuï de ceans, I
will not goe all this day out of this
place.

Anuïter, to keepe vntill night.

Il apert, it appeareth.

Apeu de gens, with small companie.

of grosse humours, filling the recep­
tories or vessell in the braines, de­
priuing vs of feeling.

Apoué, as Ie suy Apoué, I am so full
that I can eate no more.

Appodi, or agorie, a townes name.

Appaiseur, m: a pacifier.

Appanager, to giue one his portion.

pease, to asswage, to please, to pacifie,

S'appaiser, to be quiet, to be pacified,
and asswaged.

Appaisé, apeased, quieted.

at a becke.

Apparenté, goodkinred, a man of a 
good house.

Apparenter aucun, to acknowledge
one to be of our kinred.

s'Apparessir, or S'apparesser, to wax 
a sluggard.

Il s'est du tout apparesseé, he is be­
come altogither a sluggard.

Approfundir, to make deeper.

Apparier, to couple, to match, to ap­
point together.

Amour les avoit appariez, loue had
matched and coupled them toge­
ther.

Vn Appariteur, m: sometime a pur­
siuant, an officer, or a hangman.

De l'Apparitoire, ou de la parietai­
re, herbe croissant sur les murs, an
herbe called Parietary, commonly
Pellitoirie: m.

Apparoir, ou Apparoistre, to ap­
peare, to seeme: j'apparoy, j'appa­
ru, je suy apparu, j'apparoistray.





Faire Apparoir vne chose & mon­
strer, to cause a thing to seeme or
shew.

Apparoissance & apparence de va­
leur ou device qui reluit en jeu­
nesse, the shewe, disposition, or to­
wardnesse of Children: f.

L'Apparoissance de quelque chose
qui passe oultre vne autre, the ap­
parance or excellencie of one thing
by another.

Apparence, appearance, significati­
on, signe, shewe: f.

Apparemment, apparantly.

Apparition, an appearing: f.

Appartenir, to pertaine, to belong: a
verbe Impersonall.

Il Appartient, it behoueth.

Appartenance d'vn chacun, the due
or propertie of a man: f.

Il a vendu sa maison avec toutes
les Appartenances dicelle, he hath
solde his house with all the perti­
nances thereof.

Appast, a baite, an allurement: m.

Appasteler, to feede, to entice.

Appaster, to allure.

Les Appeaux, the chimes: also a 
court of office in Paris: m.

Appel, an appeale: m.

Appeller aucun, to call, to whoop for,
to name.

Appellée, she called: f.

Appellation, f: on obstant oppositi­
on ou Appellation quelconque,
 notwithstanding any thing to the
contrary.

Appendre, to hang vp as standarts
in churches and such like.

Appennage, the portion which the fa­
ther giueth to his second sonne, but
properly of Kings & Princes: m.

Les puisnez de la corone de France
ne tiennent rien que par appen­
nage, the yonger sonnes of the kings
of Fraunce, doe possesse nothing but
by gift.

Appens, as faire quelque chose de
guet Appens, to do a mischeefe de­
liberately or purposely, with a due
determination.

Appenser, to determine: as Ie mes­
toye Appensé de faire cela: I did
purpose to doe that.

Appennager, & Appenner, to giue
aportion to their yonger sonnes for
their entertainement.

Vne Appentis contre vne maison, 
 a penthouse: f.

Appercevoir, to perceiue, to spie out,
to marke: j'apperçoy, j'apperceu,
j'ay apperceu, j'apercevray.

Appercevance, knowledge or percei­
uance: f.

I'en ay quelque Appercevance, I
haue an inkeling of the matter.

Les Appercevances y font, the steps
or markes do appeare in it.

C'est vn home Appert et habile, he 
is a man of skill, of iudgement, of
wit.

Appertise, f: skillfulnesse, wit, hand­
somnesse in doing any thing.

Appertement, finely, handsomely.

Il Appert, it appeareth, it is mani­
fest.

Appesantir, to burthen, to presse
downe: j'appesantis, jappesanti,





j'ay appesanti, j'appesantiray.

s'Appesantir, to waxe heauy.

Appetisser, to deminish, to lessen, to
imbesill.

Appetissement, a diminishing: m.

Appetit conuoitise, desire: m.

I'ay bon appetit, I haue a good sto­
macke.

Tout faire à l'appetit d'vne fame,
 to doe all things after a womans fantasie.

Vivre à son Appetit, to liue after his
owne fansie or minde.

Appetits, a kinde of Garlicke, Oni­
ons, or Scalion.

Appeter & souhaiter, to desire or
wish for.

j'applaniray.

Applanissement, a planing: m.

Applaudir, to clappe hands, to reioyce
at one: to flatter or stroke one: j'ap­
plaudis, j'applaudi, j'ay applaudi,
j'applaudiray.

Applaudisseur, m: a flatterer, a prai­

Applaudissement, m: clappings of
hands.

Applausement, idem.

Appliquer, to apply, to giue our selues
to.

Appliquer son esprit à quelque
chose, to giue our mindes to one
thing.

Application, an applycation, or ap­
plying: f.

Aplommer, to lull on sleepe.

Applommé de sommeil, ouercome
with sleepe.

Appointer le bout de quelque
chose, & luy faire vne pointe bien
agué, to sharpen the pointe of any
thing.

Appointer & convenir de quelque
affaire qui estoit en doubte, to 
make agreement, to ende a matter
in controuersie, to decide.

Appointé, decided, appointed, en­
ded.

Appointement & accord qu'on 
fait entre aucuns qui avoyent
esté grans amis, an agreement
made betweene freendes fallen
out: m.

Appointement que baille le ma­
gistrat sur l'estat de la posses­
sion d'vne chose contentieuse, a
sentence or decree which is giuen
by the Magistrate for possession of
any thing in strife: m.

Il n'y a home qui sceust fournir à
l'appointement d'une feame lu­
brique, there is neuer a man
which may satisfie or fill the flesh­
ly lust of an vnchaste woman: m.

garnishe with fishe: as, Appois­
sonner vn estang, to putte
fishe into a ponde or poole for en­
crease.

Appoissonnement, such fishing for
encrease: m.

pront l'alliance, to set a fine for

Apposé, ioyned to: set to.

body to say or doe indirectly.

value.

hend one, to take a conceite.

conceite.

Apprendre, to learne, to conne.

rote: j'apprens, j'apprins, j'ay ap­

Apprenant, learning.

Apprins & enseigné, taught, instruc­
ted.

Noveau & Apprenti, new, a learner,
a prentise: m.

Apprentissage, prentiship: m.

Le Theatre des jouëurs est vn ap­
prentissage de toute impudicité,
lubricié, paillardise, ruse, finesse,
meschanceté: the theatre of stage
of players is a lesson or learning of
all lecherie, hooredome, guyle, craft,
wickednes.

Qui Appreste & appareille, which
trimmeth, or maketh ready.

liar.

ching: f.

riue.

Approchement, a drawing neere: m.

Approfiter, to procure profite to any
man.

low.

sooth.

Approuvé, par plusieurs gents d'au­

Prendre vn arbitre, & s'accorder à
luy to put it to dayes men.

Franc Arbitre, free will: m.

Vn Arbosier, a tree called of some a
straw-berie or arbute tree.

Vn lieu ou il y a beaucoup d'Arbris­

Arbuste, M; a groue where nothing
groweth but trees.

Arc à fleiches, a long bowe: m.

l'Arc au ciel, the raine bowe.

Arcs triomphans faict en memoire
de ceulz qui avoyent esté, victori­
eux, Arches made in remembrance
of some great victorie.

Arc-boutans, chiefest pillors or but­
tresses.

L'Arc d'un pont, the arche of a
bridge: m.

Arceaux, little arches: m.

Archiatre, a chiefe Phisition.

Archive, a dungion, the chiefest towre

Arc-boutant: a buttresse, a prop: m.

Archeprestre, an Archepriest, or
chiefe priest, or Archdeacon: m.

Arceau, or arçon, a saddle bowe: also
carpenters working place: m.

Faire vuïder les Arçons, to put one
out of the saddle, to cast him to the
ground: see Desarçonner.

Arcasse, Calasse or Gaillard, bee the
strongest place, and as it were the
castell of the hinder parte of the
ship.

Arcenal, m: an armorie or storehouse
for ordinance or ships.

Arceler, see Harceler.

Arche, a chest: f.

Les arches d'vn pont de pierre, the
arkes of a bridge.

Archerot, a little Archer: m.

Architecte, he that taketh vpon him
to builde an house: m.

Archer, an archer.

Archers de la garde, the archers of
the garde.





Arçon, see Arceaux.

Arçonné, the contrary is Desarçon­
né, cast out of the saddell.

Ardan or fuirolles, flittering fiers, or
flame seene by night.

l'Archet d'vn rebec, ou autres tels
instruments, the bowe of a Viole, or
such like instrument: m.

Architrave, the principall beame of
a building, m: also the chapter of
a piller.

Ardre ou ardoir, j'ards, to burne.

Ardoir de desir, to burne in desire.

Ardoise, a slate: f.

La Bourse de Londres est couverte
d'ardoises, the Royal Exchange is
couered with slates.

Ardoisiere, f: the pit where slates are
taken out.

Couverture Andolsine, couering
with slates.

Ardant, burning.

Estre fort ardent aux estudes, to bee
earnestly giuen to study.

Fort ardant & bruslant, very hot or 
burning.

Ardeur, ardour, feruencie: f.

Ardamment, ardently, greedilie, fer­
uently.

Ardillon, the tongue of a buckle: m.

Arene, f: ou Sable, m: ou Gravier, m:
 grauell.

Areneux, sandie, full of grauell.

Areniere, f: or sablonniere, the san­
die pit.

Arer, to plough.

Arreste de poisson, the smale bone of
a fish: f: also the eiles or beard vp­
on the eare of corne.

Argent, siluer, money: m.

Argent le Roy, siluer whereof the
foure and twentieth part thereof is
of another metall.

Argenté, siluered or monied.

Argenter, to siluer.

Argenteux, full of money.

Vn Argentier & autre ayant charge
de manier l'argent de son mai­
stre, a Steward, a purse bearer: m.

Herbe appellée, Argentine, an hearb
called Argentine: f.

de l'Argille, clay: f.

Argu, avoir la teste pleine d'argu,
 full of irkesomnesse, heauinesse, a
headful of proclamations, of vaine
and friuolous arguing or questions:
see Ergots.

Arguër, to rebuke, to argue.

Argument, an argument: m.

Ari, qui à perdu son humeur natu­
rel, dried vp: m.

Aridité, drinesse: f: drieth.

Arignée, seeke Araignée.

Aristocratie, the state of a common 
weale gouerned with fewe: f.

Arithmetique est la science de
computer & nombrer, the arte of
numbring: f.

Armaires, armorers: m.

Armaires à mettre livres, presses for
Bookes: f.

Armes, harnes weapons: f.

Armer, to arme.

Armé, armed.

Armes, an armie: f.

Armure, armour: f.

Armoiries, armes, cognisance: f.

Arné, feeble backed.

Arner, to breake ones back.

Odeurs Aromatiques, sweete smell

Arondelle, a swallow: f.

Demi Arpent, halfe an Arpent, that
is, nine hundreth foote of ground.

Arracher, to roote vp, to teare vp, to

out with violence.

Arraché, pluckt vp, torne away.

Arracheur, a plucker vp: m.

Arachement, plucking vp: m.

Arraisonner, to fall in talke with one.

spose.

Arranter, to lette out for yearelie
rent.

Arrentement, m: a letting for
rent.

Arres, to leaue earnest for a thing, an 
earnest peny: f.

Arresser, when a mans yard is vp.

Arressement, m: stifnes of that ac­
tion.

Arrester, to staie, to arrest.

s'Arrester, to staye in a place, to a­
bide.

s'Arrester de faire quelque chose, to
forbeare the doing of a thing.

Arrester le bestes, to stoppe wilde
beasts.

Arreste toy, stand, stirre not.

I'ay arresté, pensé, & pourpensé, I
haue stayed, be thought, and aduised
my selfe.

Arresté, stayed, or settled.

Arrest & determination de quel­
que chose, laquelle apres avoir es­
té disceptée & debatuë est mise à 
fin, an ordinance, or constitution, a
decree, a finall iudgement: m.

Arreste-bœuf, m: an hearbe called
Rest-harrow, Whyne, and of some,
Cammocke.

Arrest du Senat, a decree of the Se­
nate.

Vn Arrest, & toute chose de quoy
on retient & arreste-on vn autre,
 an action, a stay: m.

Arriére de nous, farre from vs.

Aller en arriere, or à reculon, to goe
backward.

Arrierobam, m: see Bam.

Arriere-boutique, a back-shop.

Arriere-fais des femmes, the second
birth: the skinne or bedde wherein
the child is wrapped in the wombe.

Arrier-fief, m: a ground or fee de­
pending of another.

Arriere-fossé, m: a dike behind the
first: a double dike.

Arriere-main, f: a blow with the hand
backward.

Arriere-point, arriere-foin: a backe
stich: late ward hay: later math.Antedates earliest OED citation for "back-stitch" (1611).

Arriereages, arrerages: m.

at the shoare.

rache: m.

rogant, to ascribe too much to him­
selfe.

ouerweening: f.

Les Ars d'vn cheval, the flancke of

Il est ars, or ards, he is burned.

Aspron, m: a little rough fish like a

Assaillir aucun, j'affaux, j'affailly,

Assabler, as le bateau est assablé, the
boate hath taken sand.

Assault qu'on baille à vne ville, the

Assener, to strike.

Assener aucun en ruant quelque
chose, to hit one.

Baillez moy vne assiette nette, giue

Ferme & asseuré, firme, assured, sta­

Asseuré en bien, bold, without doubt.

Asseuré, où il n'y a point de doubte,
 assured, without feare, an vndoub­
ted thing.

Asseurance, assurance, confidence: f.

Asseurement & hardiment, assured­

Dire quelque chose assurément, to
tell a thing boldly.

C'est Assez parlé de cela, it is suffi­

En avez vous assez? haue you e­
nough?
