Assidu, continuall, frequent.

Qui assiege vne ville, which besie­

matched.

Tu ne feras jamais Assouvi de ri­

s'Atrister, to become sad.

Atroce, tough, iniurious.

Attacher, to fasten, to tye, to sticke, to
claspe.

Attaché, fastened, tyed.

S'il s'Attache à moy, il s'en repen­
tira: if he doth cope with me: or if
he doth meddle with me, he shall re­
pent it.

Il ne s'ose Attacher à moy: he da­
reth not cope or fight with me.

Attaindre, to attaine, to bring to
passe, to hit or strike, to ouertake:
j'attains, j'attaint, j'ay attaint,
j'attaindray.

Attaindre & gaigner aucun en che­
min, to ouertake one in the way.

Tu n'attaindras jamais au sçavoir
de ton pere, thou wilt neuer reach
to such learning.

Estre attaints & convaincus d'au­
cun cas, to be attainted of a crime,
to be appeached.

Attainte, f: otherwise, choc, coup: a 
blowe, a stroake.

Il est venu à ses Attaintes: he is
come to his pretence.

Il luy baillo tousiours quelque At­
tainte en passant: he euer giueth
him a nip by the way.

Attalenter, to prouoke ones desire,
and as if it were, to set his teeth an
edge.

Attaquer, to match in fight with one,
to meddle with, either in wordes or
deeds.

S'il s'Attaque à moy, il s'en repen­
tira, if he medleth with me, he shall
repent it.

Attaques, as, descrire les Attaques
de guerres, to describe or declare the
skirmishes, meetings, or fight in
warre: f.

Attedier, to wearie one.

Atteler, les chevaux, to spang horses,
or fasten them to the chariot.

Attelier, a frame or a workehouse: m.

Attelles, little splintes which Surge­
ons set about ones legge or broken
arme: f.

tendu, j'attendray, to looke, to

Faire attendre quelqu'vn, to cause
one to tarrie.

s'Attendre aux promesses d'aucun,
 to stay vpon the promise of any.

Attente, looking for, expectation: f.

Attente & desir, desire, hope.

Attendrir, to soften, to mollifie.

j'attendris, j'attendri, j'ay attendri,
j'attendriray.

Attenir, to withholde or stay backe.

Attenter, to attempt, to enterprise, or
take in hand.





Attentif, attentiue, diligent.

marke a thing aduisedly, to ponder

Attiédy, soaked or tempered: waked

Attiffer, orner, accoustrer, to trim, to

Attiffement, pranking: m.

Attiltrer, to instruct a false witnesse,

Attimon, the maine saile: as l'atti­
mon levé au vent, tirêrent vers la
rive, hoysed vp the maine sayle to

Attiraux, all the tooles belonging to

Attirail: m. all the traine following a

Attiquets: as prendre les attiquets:
 to get tiquets by harbingers: m.

Attinter, to pranke.

Attirer ou attraire, to draw, to allure.

Fame bien attintée, a woman pran­
ked vp.

Attiser & souffler le feu, to blow the

Attise-querelle, a marker of debates,
or a renewer of old quarrels betwixt
parties.

Attoucher, to touch, to feele.

Attouchement, touching, feeling: m.

Les Attours d'vne femme, the at­
tire of a woman: m.

Voila vn bel Attour, there is a faire
attire.

Attourneur ou Attourneresse, a wai­
ting seruant, man or woman.

Attraire, ou Allicher, to entice, to al­
lure, to prouoke.

Attraict, & Alliché, enticed, or al­
lured.

Attractif, m: a drawing thing: a 
drawer.

Cest vne fame fort Attractive, f: an
alluring woman, that draweth one
to her minde.

Attrayement, enticement, or allure­
ment: m.

Attrapper, to snare, to entangle, to
catch.

Attrappoires, catchings, entrap­
pings: f.

Attremper & gouverner, to temper,
to mixe, sometime to soake or moy­
sten, to rule.

Attrempé & moderé, tempered or 
moystened.

Attrempement, a tempering or soa­

Attrempément, temperément, &
moderément, temperatly, coolely,
moderatly.

Attrempance, modestie, tempe­

Attribuër, to attribute, to impute.

S'Attribuer quelque chose, & en





son propre, to attribute a thing to
himselfe.

Trop s'Attribuer, to attribute too
much to himselfe.

S'Attruander, s'accoquiner, to loy­
ter, to become a truant.

S'Avachir, to become a dastard, a
coward, to be like a cow, to bee flag­
ging or faded.

Avaindre, to take but, to reach, as je
ne peux avaindre au plat, that is
attaindre.

Avaller, to swallow, to let downe.

Avaller sans mascher, to swallowe
downe whole.

Avaller du hault en bas, to swallow
downe right, to lay downe.

Avallé en bas, swallowed downe.

Avallement de quelque liqueur,
 the swallowing downe of some li­
quor: m.

Avallement de vin, swallowing of
wine.

Vn grand Avalleur de vin, m: a
swallower of wine, a great drinker.

Avallage, wine porters wages when
they doe lay wine into the seller: m.

Avaller aulcun dans vn puys, to let
one downe into a Well.

Avalluër, to set a price.

Avant brasw d'vn harnois, the poldern
of an armoure: m.

Avancer & haster, to set forward, to
fasten.

Avancer, mettre plus avant, to ad­
uance, to set forward.

s'Avancer, or advancer, & profiter,
 to goe forward, to profite.

S'avancer d'aller & de marcher, to
mend our pace.

Avancer argent, to giue money a­
forehand.

Avancé, aduanced, promoted.

Advancement, aduancing, promo­
ting: m.

Avancer à quelque chose, y four­
nir, & satisfaire, to beare all the
charges to the perfection of a thing.

Avant, deepe, or farre in.

Bien avant dedens, very deepe in, far
in.

Plus Avant, inner or more within.

Mettez-le plus Avant, thrust it
inner, more in.

Venir en Avant, to come forth.

Mettre en avant quelque chose, to
put forth a thing.

Avant le temps, before the time.

D'icy en avant, from this time for­
ward.

Avant que, before that.

D'Avantage, furthermore, besides
this.

Avoir l'avantage & estre superieur
de l'autre, to haue the vantage, and
to ouercome the other: m.

Bailler d'avantage, to giue more.

Ie di d'Avantage, I say further.

Desavantage, hinderance: m.

Desavantager, to hinder.

Estre plus avantagé que lautre, to
excell other, to be better preferred
then another.

Lieu fort Advantageux, m: a place
with great aduantage.

Advantageusement parler, to speak
with great aduantage.

Avant-chien, m: the name of the





starre whereby the dogge-dayes be­
gin.

Avant-coureur, to forerunner: m.

Avancourement, forerunning: m.

Avant-cour, f: the little court you
find before you come to the great
court of a pallace, lodging or house.

Avant-garde, the forewarde of an
armie: f.

Avant-hier, this other day, or the day
before yesterday.

Avant-jeu, m: an assay, tryall, or
proofe before the game begin.

Vn avantin, m: the arme of a Vine.

Avant-logis, m: a little forelodging 
or house.

Avant-mur, m: a fore-wall.

Avant-parleur, m: a fore-speaker.

Avant-penser, to thinke before, or
premeditate.

Avant-pesches, timely peches.

Avant-portail, m: the fore-porch.

Avanture, Avanturer, seeke Adven­
ture.

Vn Avanturier de guerre, a venturer
in warre: m.

Vn Avanturier vagabond qui fait la
regnardiére de peur des coups, a
hedgecreeper.

Avarice, couetousnesse: f.

Aaricieux, couetous: m.

Avarement, avaritieusement, co­
uetously.

Avau l'eauë, down the water, with the
streame.

Aubades, as donner vne aubade, 
such musicke as minstrels doe play
at ones window at the breaking of 
the day, morning musicke: f.

Aubain, escheate, land fall to the
Princes hands for lacke of heire.

Droit d'Aubaine, such right of Es­
cheate.

L'Aube, f. & poinct, m: du jour, the
dawning of the day.

Vne Aube, a crisom, the albe or sur­
plesse of a priest: f.

Aubespin, m: ou Aube épine, f: se­
lon que dient aucuns, whitethorne
as some thinke, an hawthorne.

Aubier d'vn arbre, the gumme or fat
of a tree, m: we doe call it also Au­
bin or Aubour.

Aubifoin, a precious stone called a 
Turkise: m.

L'Aubin d'vn œuf, the gleare or
white of an egge: m.

Aucteur, auctoriser, see Autheur.

Aucun, somebody.

Auncuns, some persons.

En ancun lieu, somewhere.

Aucune-fois, sometimes.

Aucunement, somewhat.

Audace, boldenesse: f.

dacitie.

de tel carrefour: right or toward
that corner of the streete.

Avec soy, with him.

Auec ce, with that.

other such like thing: see Avain­
dre.

Digne & Avenant, worthy.

Aveneron, barren oates: m.

a verbe impersonal: il advient, il
avenoit, il advint, il est avenu, il
estoit avenu, il aviendra.

Avenement, a comming to passe: m.

Avérer quelque meschanceté, to

fantasticall.

Avet, a firre tree.

waxeth darke, night draweth on.

Les Augussins, the blacke friers.

S'Aviander, to deede himselfe.

Les vivres sont Avilez, victuals are

Au-jour-dhuy, today.

Qui est Batu, which is beaten.

Battemare, the water Swallow: it is

of the Sea.

laundrers do vse to wash their buck
and clothes.

Batures, stripes and beatings: f.

Ville Batable, a towne which may be
beaten with artillerie.

Vne ceincture & Baudrier à pen­
dre l'espée, a sworde girdle: m.

Baudroyeur, a currier of lether: m.

Baube, com: as Neoptolemus estoit
baube, was a pratler.

Bave, f: glauering, foame, froath.

Baver, to trifle, ieste, dallie, toy, glauer, 
to fome, to cast froath.

Baveur, bavard, a trifler, a prater: m.

Bavette, or Baverette, a bibbe, a muc­
keter.

Baverie, trifles, toyes, mockes: f.

Baustrer, to rauen or eate gredily.

Bauge, lime, or lome and strawe toge­
ther: also an heape of durte: also 
the place where the wilde boare or
any other beast did lie: m.

Retirer les homes des Bauges, to
withdraw men from beastly liuing.

Controuver vne Baye, or baie, to i­
magine some lie.

Donner la baye à quelcun, to pay or 
tell one a lie: to giue a frump.

Bauche de muraille, m: a rowe of
bricks, or stones, or any other stuffe
in a wall.

Bauds, certaine dogges very fitte to
hunt.

Baude, com: merie.

Baudement, merily.

Baudir, or els resiouïr, to make me­
rie, to reioyce.

Du Bausme, baulme, m.

Vn cheval Bay ou Bayart, a baye
horse.

Bayer à la mamelle, to seeke or baye
for the dugge.

Bayer l'argent, to lay wayte for mo­
ney.

Il Baye vers la Grece, he watcheth
to Greece ward, or standeth at a bay.

Bazoche, see Basoche.

Vn Bayard, m: an earnest beholder.

Vne Bayarde, f: a woman beholding
or gasing on any thing very ear­
nestly, or attentiuely.

Beatifier, to make one blessed.

Beatitude, blessednes, happinesse.

Beau, fayre, seemly, beautifull, com­
ly, honest: m.

Bellot, prety, handsome: m.

Beauté, beauty, comelines, fayrenes: f.

Bel home, a fayre man.

Beaucoup, much.

Beaucoup moins, much lesse.

Beaucoup de gens, many folkes, ma­
ny men.

Beaucoup de nations, many nations.

Le Bec d'vn oyseau, a birds hill: m.

Tesmoins à qui lon fait le Bec, wit­
nesses instructed what they shal say.

Becasse, a Woodcocke: f.

Vn Bec figue, oiseau vivant de fi­
gues, a bird like a nightingale fee­
ding on figges and grapes.

Becher la terre, to dig the ground.

Bechée, as much as a bird carrieth in





her bil: f.

Becu, or Bechu, hooked, sharpe.

Becquer, or Becqueter, to picke as
chickens doe.

Bequillon, m: a little bill.

Beccard, the female of a Salmon.

Vne Becquée, as much as a bird car­
rieth with her bil feeding her young
ones: a pecke, or pecking: f.

Bedeau, a sword-bearer, or such like:
m.

Ce n'est que vn Bedier, m: he is but
a great calfe.

Vn Bedon ou Tabourin, a tabret:
m.

Bedonner, to play vpon the drumme.

Beller, to bleat.

Gueule Béée, with an open mouth
like a Beare, &c.

Beellement, a bleating: m.

Beffler de parolles, to deceiue one
with fayre wordes.

Se laisser Beffler, to suffer to be de­
ceiued.

Ce ne sont que niais & Begaux,
 they are but sottes and stuttering
fellowes.

Vn Beffroy, m: ou eschauguette, f:
 a Beacon, also a sodaine feare.

Begue, one that stutteth.

Begueyer, to faffle, to stut, to stammer.

Begayement, a stutting, a stamme­
ring, faffling: m.

Beguin, the biggin of a child: m.

Bejaune, a doltish one.

Beiaunise, nicenes, doltishnes.

Payer sen Beiaune, to pay for his
welcome.

Bel seeke Beau.

Vne Bellete, a Wesell: f.

Belistre, ou belitre, a poore knaue, a 
begger, a vagabond: m.

Belistrer, to bege.

Vn Belier, a ramme, m: also an in­
strument in the olde time to beate
downe the walles.

Beliner, to lambe.

Bellement, gently, leasurely, softly.

Beliqueux, warlike, valiaunt, out­
ragious.

Bende, bender, Bendelette, seeke
Bande.

Benediction, f: blessing.

Benefice, pleasure, a good turne, a
benefite, a benefice: m.

Beneficier, he which hath a bene­
fice: m.

Beneficiez, men hauing many bene­
fices.

Beneficience, a wel-doing, or good
turne, mercie and gentlenes: f.

Benevolence, a good will, beneuo­
lence: f.

Bening, gentle, courteous.

Benir aucun, to blesse one, or wish one
well: je benis, je beni, j'ay beni,
je beniray.

Benoistier, or Benestier, the holywa­
ter stock: m.

Benict, holy, blessed.

Du pain Benict, holy bread.

Benoict, a mans name.

Benisson, & bonne priere qu'on 
fait à Dieu pour aucun, blessing
or prayer that is made to GOD for
any: f.

Du Benjoin, Beniamin: m.

Bercail, a flocke, as Iacob paissoit le 





bercail de Laban, Iacob fed or kept
Labans sheepe or flocke: m.

Vn Benivin, m: the iuyce of the
hearbe called Laserpitium.

Le Berceau d'vn enfant, les langes
& petits drapeaux, the childs cradle
and swathling cloutes: m.

Vn berceau de treille, an arbor.

Berceaux couvers de rosiers mus­
cats, groseliers, &c. Arbors coue­
red with muske-rose trees, & goose­
berrie trees, &c.

Bercer, to rocke.

Berche, a little small peece of Artil­
lerie vsed in ships: f.

Berchot, a little bird called a Wren: m.

Berée, or pinson, a bramline bird: m.

Berlong, any thing longer of one side
then of the other: m.

Berger, a sheepeheard: m.

Bergiere, a she sheepheard: f.a She­
perine.

Bergerie, sheepefold: f.

Berlans, common tipling houses, hou­
ses of ill rule or gaming: see Brelan.

Berlue, poare blind, or sand blind.

De la Berle, herbe, yellow water cres­
ses: f.

Bernage, all the carriage either of the 
Prince, or of the Campe: m.

Berner, to vanne, as corne in a
Vanne.

Bers de chariot, m: the sides or racks
of a wagon.

Bertourder, to shaue or clippe ine­
qually.

Beryl, pierre precieuse, a pretious
stone called Beryl: m.

Besace, a wallet, a scrippe: f.

Besacier, m: hee that beareth the
wallet.

Besague, a twible to bore holes: m.

Besant, or Byzantin, an ancient peece
of golde of Fraunce worth a Duc­
ket: m.

Vn houë ou Besche, a pickaxe, a
mattocke, but rather a spade: f.

Bescher, to digge: to delue.

Beschement, a deluing or digging.

Vn Bescheur, a deluer or digger: m.

Le Besle, or tillac d'un navure: the 
hatches of a ship.

Il est besoing de faire cela, it is need­
full to doe that thing.

Ie n'ay Besoin de rien, I haue needs
of nothing.

Besongne, workmanship: f.

Besongnette, little worke: f.

Besongner, to worke.

En Besongnant, in working: as I was
working.

Besson, twaines: m.

Vne Beste, a beast: f.

Bestelette, a little beast: f.

Bestement & lourdement, beastlie
and doltishly.

Bestise & faulte de sens, beastlinesse,
blockishnesse: f.

Bestial, cattell: m.

Home Bestial, a beastly man: a vi­
cious man: vsing himselfe like a 
beast.

Bestiole, or bestion, a little beast.

Besycle, or Besycles, f: spectacles.

De la Betosne, or Betaine, f: an
hearbe called Betanie.

Des Bettes, Beetes, an hearbe.

Beturre, a sincke hole: f.





Beuf: m: ou Bache: f: an Oxe or
Cow.

Vn Bouvier, m: a Cowe-beard: a 
Neat-heard.

Bouvi, smelling of the Oxe smell: m.

Bouvillon, a little Oxe: m.

Beurre, butter: m.

Beurrier, a butter man: m.

Vne Beurriere, a butter woman: f.

Vn Bezoard, m: the cod of a goate
or beast so called: it is taken for a 
counter-poyson.

Bezer, to doe as a Cowe when flies doe
sting her.

Biffé, scraped out, cut off, blotted out.

Bruvage ou brouvage, seeke Boire.

Vn bon Biberon, a bibber, a tipler,
a quaffer.

Biberon ou esguiere, an ewer.

La BIBLE, the Bible.

Bicarne, a kinde of Grapes, onely to
make Veriuice.

Biche, a Hinde.

Bicoque, a dogge hole, a place not 
able to withstand a siege: as En sait
de siege, les Capitaines ne doy­
bvent jamais tenir en telles Bi­
coques & pouliers plur d'vn 
jour: touching a siege, the Cap­
taines ought not to withstand or
hold in such holds or henne rousts: f.

Vn Bidet, a little curtall: m.

Bien, well. Ou bien, or els.

Le bien que le pere delaisse à ses en­
fants, apres son trespas, the goods
which the father leaueth to his
children after his decease.

Les Biens successions qu'vn ch­
scuna à soy, meubles ou imme­
ubles, the goods that any man pos­
sesseth.

Tous Biens exterieurs, all outward
goods.

Bien-heurer, to make one happie.

Bien-heureux, happie, blessed.

Bienfaicteur, m: a benefactor.

La Bienseance & rapport des par­
ties l'vne à l'autre, well besitting of
the members or parts one to another.

Bienvenuë, payer sa bienvenuë, to 
pay for his welcomming.

Bies, biace.

Bigle, that looketh a squint: gogle
eyed.

nies: m.

Par Bigotise, superstitiously: f.

Bignets, vne façon de pain pour les

De bihay, by biace.

Bihayser, to goe by biace.

Bille, a little small boule: f.

Monnoye de Billon, Bullion money: 
that is neither gold nor siluer: m.

tall into bullion, or wedges: m.

mettall, or forging of money of

Billonner la monnoye du Prince, to

Monnoye Billonnée, money cast in
wedges.

Vn Billot d'Or, an ingot of Gold: m.

Vn Billot de bois, a billet, a logge.

Bimauve, ou Guymauve, a marsh
mallow: f.

Binarchie, when two Princes doe rule
with equall authoritie: f.

Biner les vignes, to cut and trimme
vines, to digge and labour them.

Bieneur,  a vineworker, a weeder.

Binement, a vine working, weeding.

Binoter, to dig and trim the vines
for the second time.

Birrasques, great whirlewindes vpon
the sea, tempest: m.

Bis, du pain bis, wheaten bread.

Bisaquier, he which doth carrie the
scrip among beggers: m.

Vne Bistarde, or oustarde, f: a Buz­
zard, or Owle.

Bisayeul, le pere de mon pere grand,
 my grandfathers father: m.

Donnez moy vne Biscaye, je iouë­
ray à vous: giue me a bisket, and I
will play with you.

Biscuit, a bisket: m.

Vent de Bise, the Northeast winde:
la Bise souffle: f.

Bisexre, bisext: m.

Vne Bisnoire, f: a mattocke or such
instrument to pare vp weedes.

Bitume, glew, lime: m.

Vn Bizet, or Biset, m: a kind of doue.

Bizarre, as vne nature bizarre a fan­
tasticall and strange nature.

Blaffard, pale faced: m.

Blaffarde, a pale woman: f.

Blaireau, a Gray, a Brocke, a Badger: 
m: a Bauson.

Blanc, white.

Vn blanc, a kinde of French coyne
worth little aboue a halfepenie: m.

Vn Blanchet, ou couverture delict,
 a blanket: also a white peticoate as
maidens doe weare in Bourbonnois.

Blancheastre, whitish.

Qui est Blanchet, which is whitish.

Blancheur, whitenesse: f.

Le Blanchissage ou crepissure d'vne
massonnerie, white lyming of a
house: f.

Blanchir & devenir blanc, to blanch,





to become white.

Blanchir, je blanchis, je blanchi, j'ay
blanchi, je blanchiray quelque
chose, to white a thing.

Les Dames des Blancs-manteaux,
 Nunnes in Paris so called.

Blance, a kind of wheate.

Blandir aucun, to allure one.

Blandissement, alluring, flatterie: m.

Blandisseur, an allurer, or inticer: m.

accusing: m.

Blasmer aucun & luy reprocher ou
mettre à sus quelque cas, to blame,
to reproch, to lay to ones charge.

Estre Blasmé & reprins, to be blamed,
or reproued.

Blason, the armes, also for praise: m.

Blasonner aucun & dire mal de luy,
 to blase out ones name, or speake e­
uill of him, to specifie ones armes, to
praise.

Blasonneur, an euill speaker: m.

Blasser, to asswage or mitigate a sore,
but specially when one doth strike
soft and often with salt and water
the foote of an horse.

Blasphemer, to blaspheme.

Blasphématoires, as parolles blas­
phématoires, words full of blasphe­
mies, blasphemous words.

Blaveoles, ou Aubifoins, the floure
called blew bottles: f.

Blé, corne: m.

Toute sorte de Blé, al sorts of corne.

Batre le blé, to thresh corne.

Vn Blatier, or monopolier, a mar­
chant of corne: one that keepeth
corne in store to sell it dearer.

Blésme, pale, bleake.

Blesmir, to waxe pale or bleake.

Blesmet, m: which is somewhat pale.

Blesmissement, m: bleakenes.

Blesser, to hurt, to grieue, to annoy, to
wound, to offend.

Blessé, wounded, offended.

Blessure, a hurt, a wound: f.

Blette, espece de porée, beetes: f.

Bleu, blew: skie colour.

weede.

Bloc, all kind of confused marchan­
dise: m.

Acheter en bloc, to buye diuers
things altogether.

Blocul, or bloquil, the chiefest pole
which vpholdeth the tent: m.

Blocaille, or Bloccage: see Moylon.

straw colour.

Perruque Blonde f: flaxen haires.

Blondelet, of, or much like that co­
lour.

Blond, yellow haired.

Bloquer, to conclude any bargaine.

Bluëttes, little sparkes in the ayre in

Bluter, to boult meale.

Bluteur, m: he that boulteth meale.

Bobans, riotte, excesse, superflui­
tie: m.

Bobeliner, to mend an old thing.

Bobelineur, a butcher, a cobler: m.





Bobine, a quill of the wheele where
women doe spin: f.

Bobulaire, like an Oxe: bigge or
monstrous.

Bocage, a thicket, or wood: m.

Vn Bocal ou esguiére, an ewer: m.

Vn Bocon, a morsell: it is an Italian
worde taken for poyson: as garde 
toy du Bocon, take good heed thou
be not poysoned: see Boucon: m.

Boire, je boy, je bu, j'ay bu, je boi­
ray, to drinke, to bib, to quaffe.

Boileau, a drinker of water: m.

Boquet, see Bosquet.

Bosseau, Bosselet, seeke Boisseau.

Buvage, as apres vn long buvage,
 after a long drinking: m.

Buverie, Idem: f.

Buveur, a drinker: m.

Buveter, or buvotter, to sippe whole
glasses full, to drinke often, to bibbe.

Petit Buvetereau, m: a little drin­
ker.

Beuvette, Vin de despence, small
household wine: f.

Bruvage, a drinke or potion: m.

C'est vn Bruvage amer d'aimer sans
estre aimé, it is a bitter kinde of
drinke, to loue, and not be loued a­
gaine.

Le Bruvage des petis enfants, chil­
drens drinke as they call it, bum.

Le boire: m: ou boisson: f: drinke.

Bois, wood: m.

Vn bois de plaisance, a pleasant 
wood, or groue.

Vne mesure semblable à nostre
boisseau, a measure like to our bu­
shell: m.

Boisselet, a small bushell: m.

Vne croix Boissée, when the crosse is 
compassed with branches of a boxe
tree.

Boisson, any kind of drinke to quench
mens thirst: f.

Voi-cy de fort bonne Boisson, or
voi-cy de bon boire, here is verie 
good drinke.

Boiste de bouys, a boxen boxe: m.

La boiste des os, the pan wherein the
huckle bone falleth.

Boister, to halt.

Boisteux, lame: m.

Boistement, haltingly.

Boliévre, a lippe: f.

Du Bombasyn, Bombasie, cotton: m.

Bombance, or bobance, bragging,
vaunting, excesse, superfluitie: f.

Bobancier, m: a riotous man, a spen­
der, or waster of goods.

Bon, good, honest, vertuous: m.

Vne bonne pome, a good apple: f.

Tenir bon, Estre ferme & constant,
 to stand in a matter, to be firme and
constant.

Sentir bon, to smell well.

Bonté, goodnesse, honestie, vertue: m.

Bonasse c'est à dire, Tranquillité de 
vent en la mer, a faire weather on
the Sea: f.

Les Bondes & ouvertures par où on
fait ouverture à l'eaue, comme
d'vn estang, a chanell or gutter
from a pond, sluces: f: a damme: a
flood-gate: a weaer.

Bondir, je bondis, je bondi, j'ay
bondi, je bondiray, to rebound, to





leape backe: to slippe.

Le Bond que fait vn estœuf, m: the
bound of a ball, or the rising thereof
at tennise.

Elle a fait vn faux Bond, she hath
done amisse.

Bondonner, to stop tunnes or vessels
with a stopple.

Vn Bondon, a bung, or stopple: m.

Qui est debonnaire & doulx de na­
ture, which is gentle and milde of
nature.

Bonnaireté, faithfulnesse, vpright­
nesse: f.

Bonnairement, & à la bonne foy, vp­
rightly, in good faith.

Pourveu que bonnement tu le pu­
isses faire, so thou maiest doe it
well.

Bonnes, as Il est en ses bonnes, he is
in his good moode: f.

Bonnet à couvrir sa teste, a cap: m.

Vn Bonneton, m: a little cap.

Vne Bonnette, f: a kinde of small 
saile.

Vn bonnet de fer, a scull, a sallet.

Bonneter aucun, to put off his cap to 
one and often, to crouch to one.

Bonté, seeke Bon.

Boques, sluces: m.

Boquet, a groue: m.

Le bord d'vn habillement, the hem
or seluidge: m.

Le bord de quelque chose que ce
soit, ou le bout, the trim or end of a 
thing.

Il est cruel oultre Bord, he is cruell
beyond measure.

Quand je seroye sur le Bord de ma
fosse, encore louéroye-je le seig­
neur: though I were at my pittes
brinke, yet should I praise the Lord.

Le Bord de l'eaue, the water side or
brimme.

Le Bord & rivage de la mer, ou ri­
viére, the sea shore, or riuer side.

Border & couvrir le bord, to border,
to welt.

Bordeur, & autres qui besongnent
à l'esguille, an embroderer: m.

Autant pour le Bordeur, or Brodeur, 
a kind of speech spoken in mockerie:
as if one should say, a figge for him:
or if one telleth a tale which you
iudge to be vntrue, you say, Autant
pour le brodeur, all this for the em­
broderer: that is, all this which is 
told, is a lye.

Bordure d'habillement, a border, or
welt of a garment: f.

Vn bordeau, a brothel house com­
monly called the Stewes: m.

Borde, a house alone in the countrey: f.

Vn Bordier, m: a Fermer.

Bordelier & putier, brothels, or
whorehunters: a smell feast: m.

Bordelage, whorehunting: m.

Bordereau & petit cayer, a note, a
briefe, a pamphlet: m.

Borgne, one eyed: m.

Borgnet, a little poare blind.

Vne Borgnesse, m: a woman poare
blind.

Vne Borne, a limite, a bound, a lot: f.

Borner quelque chose, to limite out
a place.

Champ Borné, a field lotted out, or
diuided.





Borneur, a limiter, or parter forth: m.

Borrais, wherewith Goldesmiths sol­
der golde: m.

Bosquet ou petit bois, a thicket or
groue: m.

Vne Bosse en quelque partie du
corps, a wenne.

La malle Bosse te tue, a plague on
thee: f.

la Bosse & cabochon, ou elleveure
de pierre precieuse, the embossing
of a Iewell.

Vne Bosse de terre, a Mole-hill, or
hillock.

Bossette, a little heape of earth: f.

Bossette d'os, de bois, ou de corne
que les anciens mettoyent sus les
livres achevez, the Bosse of a booke:
f: also a bullion in bridles or poitrels
for ornament: a stud.

Bosseteur, a Bosse-maker: m.

Bossuër, to make crooked.

Bossu, downe-backed, crooke-shol­
dered.

Lieu fort Bossu, a hollow or crooked
place.

Botargues, hard-row of fishes salted
for drinkers.

Vn Bot, m: a wooden shooe.

Vn pied Bot, a crooked foote.

Vne Botte comme de lattes, & sem­
blables, a faggot, a bundle of 
lathes: f.

Bote, a boote: f.

Ie suyboté & esperonné, I am boo­
ted and spurred.

Ie me vay Botter, I goe put on my
bootes.

Boteau de foin, & autre chose, a
bottle of hay: m.

Vn Boteau & glu de foarre, a bundle
of long straw.

Vn Bouc, a he Goate: m.

Vn Bouquin, a Kyd: m.

Boucaner, to doe like a hee Goate.

Sentir le Bouquin, to stinke like a he
Goate: stinking or rammish like a
male Goate.

Boucanier, as cela est Boucanier,
 the same is out of season, it is no
more in vse.

Avoir Bouche a cour, to eate and
drinke scot-free.

Bouche, a mouth: f.

Les Bouches de la playe, the entrie
of a wound.

Bochette, a little mouth: f.

Bouchée, a morsel, a mouth full: f.

Boucher, seeke Bouscher.

Boucheron, see bouscher.

Vn Bouchon, a stopple, a wispe: m.

Bouchonner vn cheval, to rubbe a 
horse with a wispe.

Vn Bouchier, a Butcher: m.

Boucherie, a butchery, a slaughter: f.

Vne Boucle, a buckle: f.

Bouclier, a buckler: m.

Boucon, poyson venim: m.

Bailler le boucon, to poyson one.

Boudin, a pudding: m.

Vne Boudine, f: the nauell.

Bouë & fange, dirt mire, mud: f.

Bouëux, ou plein de bouë, dyrtie,
myrie.

Bouffée de vent, a puffe of winde: f.

Bouleverser, to ouerturne all.

La Boulingne, or bouringne, f: the
sayle next the top of the mast.





Bouffer le feu, to blow the fire.

Bouffer de courroux & maltalent,
 to swell with anger.

Bouffi, Harenc bouffi, puffed vp, a 
full Herring, swelled vp.

Bouffons, flatterers for aduantage:
m.

Danser les Bouffons, to daunce a 
morris daunce with belles about the
legges.

Boufron, m: a cuttle, fish.

Bougie, a searing candle: f.

Bougier, to seare veluet or any silke
cloth.

Bouge, le bouge d'vn bouclier, the
bosse of a buckler: m.

Bougeon, an arrowe with a great 
head: m.

Se bouger, ou partir du lieu & place
où on est, to remoue or depart from
a place.

Ne se bouger d'vne place, & ne s'en
partir, to remayne, not to stirre.

Ne Bouge d'icy, stirre not from
hence.

Bougette de cuir, a budget.

Bougrerie, buggery: f.

Bougre, he that committed such a 
fact and sodomite villanie: a bug­
gerer: burne them all.

Bougironner, to commit buggery.

Vn Bougiron, a buggerer.

Le premier & second Bouhourdi, m:
 the first and second sunday in Lent.

Bouïs, ou arbre de bouïs, Boxe or
Boxe tree: see Bouys.

Vne Boule, a boule: f.

Vne Boviotte, f: the holes in a
doue-house: see Colomb.

Vne Bouloire, a bowling alley.

Vn arbre dit bouleau, a birch tree:
m.

Boulengier, a baker: m.

Boulengiére, a she baker: f.

Boulengerie, a bake-house: f.

Boulet d'artillerie, ou harquebuse,
 the bullet of a gunne or artillery: m.

Vn Boulevert, a bulwarke: m.

Boulie, gruell, pappe: f.

Bouillir, je bous, je boullu, j'ay boul­
lu, je boulliray, or boudray, to
boyle, to perboyle, to seeth.

Du bouilli, ou boullu, sodden meat:
m.

Bouillon, boyling or bubbling.

Humer vn Bouillon, to sup broth: m.

Bouillonner, to boile and cast vp sur­
ges.

Bouillonner, comme quand sur
l'eauë ou vrine se levent des bou­
teilles, bubbles such as rise in wa­
ter: to bubble like a soothing pot, or
like water at the bathes.

Vne Bouloire, a bowling alley: f.

Bouquet de fleurs, a nosegay: m.

Vn Bouquet de fleurs, ou pomme
de senteurs, a nosegay or pomander.

Vn Bouquet de laine, a flocke of 
wooll.

Bouquin, seeke Bouc.

Bourbe f: ou Bourbier, m: mudde,
or a muddy place, slough, a puddle.

Bourdes, tales made, inuentions, tri­
fles: f.

Ce sont Bourdes, these be but tales.

Bourder, to bourde, to ieste, to trifle.

Bourdon, ou mousche guespe, a
waspe, a droane: m.





Vn Bourdon enrre les aveilles, a
dorre-bee: a droane.

Bourdonner, to humme like a Bee:
to buzze in ones eare: to buzze.

Le Bourdon d'vn pelerin, a Pilgrims
staffe: m.

Vn Bourdon dedens lequel est vn
estoc caché, a staffe with a sworde
in it: m.

Vn Bourg & village estant en vne
plaine, a Borough, a Towne: m.

Bourgeois, a citizen, a burgesse: m.

La Bourgeoisie, the Citizens free­
dome: f.

Perdre le droict de bourgeoisie, to
lose the freedome.

Le bourgeon ou bouton de la vig­
ne, the budde of a Vine: m.

Bourgeon de laine, a flocke of wooll.

Bourgeon & bube que vient à la
face, a pimple in ones face.

Bourgeonner & jetter surgeons &
jettons, to budde out, to spring.

Bourgmaster, an high dutch name,
or dignitie, as the Maior of Lon­
don.

Vne Bourguignotte, a head-peece.

Bouringue, see Bourlingue.

Bourlet, or Bourrelet, a hoode such
as citizens doe vse, a roll that wo­
men set on their head: m.

Vn bournal & rayon de miel, a ho­
nie combe: m.

Bourre, flockes of wooll, hayres and
lockes wherewith they stuffe Sad­
dles, Balles, Collers, and such like: f.

Bourreau qui donne la gehenne &
torture, a hangman, an executio­
ner: m.

Vne bourrée, a bauen: f.

Bourrer, to stuffe with flockes and
haires, also to beate.

De la Bourre, f: flockes.

Bourrelier, qui fait les colliers des
chevaux, a maker of horses Col­
lers: m.

Bourrelerie, vexation, the office of a
hangman, crueltie: f.

Bourreler, to torment, to murther.

Bourrier, or poil, hayres or lockes of
wooll or bumbaste: m.

Bouroche, bourage: f.

Bourse de cuir, a leather purse, a
powch, a bagge: f.

Boursette, a little purse: f.

Bouse de vache, the dung of a cowe: f.

Bouscher, to stoppe, to shut vp.

Bousselle, or Buxole, or quadrant de 
mer, a mariners diall.

Lon ne peut Boucher la bouche
aux medisans, one cannot stop the 
mouth of euill speakers.

Tous les passages bouchez, all the
passages and wayes stopped.

Bouschement, m: a stopping.

Vn Bouscheron, a bill-man.

Bousfler, to puffe vp: to blow in, as
butchers doe, to flea the better an
oxe or sheepe.

Le fin bout de quelque chose que 
ce soit, the very poynt or ende of a 
thing: m.

Le fin bout de quelque chose, com­
me d'vne montaigne, & d'vn ba­
stiment, the top of a mountayne.

Le bout d'ne place & rue, the far­
ther ende of the streete.

Le bout de quelque baston soit ai­





gu, poinctu, trencheant, ou mous­
su, the poynt of a weapon: m.

Vne espée, vne dague sans bout, a
swoorde, a dagger without a chape: 
or vn fourreau sans bout, a scab­
bard without chape.

Les bouts, ou les poincts des co­
stez, the stiches of the sides.

Bouter & pousser, to put or push.

De la premiére boutée, at the first
push: f.

Vne Boute-feu, a match, he that set­
teth a house on fire, a kindler of
noyse and hatred betwixt men: m.

Iouër au Boute-hors, a kinde of play
where one thrusteth another out: 
m.

Bouteille, a bottle: f.

Boutellier & faiseur de bouteilles
 a bottle-maker: m.

Estre Bouteillier & eschason, to
be Butler: m.

Boutique, f: ou ouvroir, m: de mar­
chand, a Marchants shop.

Vn bouticlier, m: a shop-keeper: he
that keepeth the shop.

Boutonner, to budde, to spring out, to
claspe.

Bouton, de verolle, the signes or
markes of the french poxe.

Vn Bouton de soye, a silke button.

Le bouton ou bourgeon de la vig­
ne, the bud of the vine: m.

Bouvi Bouvillon, seeke Beuf.

Vn Bouyau, qu'on appelle le long
bouyau, a bowell or gutte: m.

Le Bouyau culier, the gutte next the
bottome of the stomacke.

Bouyau & intrailles, bowels and
entrailes.

Bouys, or arbre de bouys, Boxe or 
Boxe tree: m.

Braçats, armespeece: m.

Bracelet, seeke Brasselet.

Brachet, a kinde of hound: m.

Braconnier, a hunter: m.

Bragard, a bragge and dapper fellow.

Bragarder, to bragge, to be nimble.

Bragardement, braggingly, or nim­
bly.

Braguerie excessive, excessiue braue­
rie: f.

Braire, to braye, to roare, to groane.

Brayant, ou Brayart, a roarer: m.

Brayement, a roaring: m.

Brayement que font les petis en­
fants, the crying of children.

Brayement & escri qu'on fayt de 
douleur & d'ennuy qu'on a, the
groaning or roaring in sorrow.

Braise de feu, a burning coale, hoate
imbers: f.

Braizier, liue-coales: m.

Brasiller, to roste by quicke coales or
imbers.

Brame, a kinde of fish, a Breame: f.

Bramer, to crie, to roare.

Du Bran & son, branne, turd: m.

Et va, Bran pour toy, goe thy way, a
turde for thee.

Tu fais de l'asne pour avoir du bran,
 thou playest an asse play to haue and
eate branne: a kinde of speech vsed
towards him that sheweth as if he
were ignorant of such things as he
is demaunded.

Branc d'acier, a kinde of sworde: m.

Brancar, or Brancal, the arme of a 





Litter or Chariot: m.

Branche, a braunch: f.

Branche vrsine, vne sorte d'herbe,
 Beare-breeche, or beare-foote, an
herbe: f.

Branchette, a little bough: f.

Branchu, boughie.

Vn Branchage delié comme che­
veux, thick branched: m.

Esprevier branchier, a hawke flying
from branch to branch.

Branque vrsine, Beare-foote: an
hearb.

Brandir, to cast with force a darte, or
a speare: je brandis, je brandi, j'ay
brandi, je brandiray: to brandish
or shake.

Brandon de feu, a firebrand: m.

Bransler, to shake, to nod, to waue.

Le Bransle & maniement du corps
se rapportoit bien à la voix, his
gestures agree well with his voice:
m.

Danser vn bransle, to daunce: m.

Braquemar, braquemard, or vouge,
 a woodknife, a hanger: m.

Braque, a hound: m.

Braquer du chambre, to brake hemp.

Braquer l'artillerie contre vne for­
teresse, to set and appoynt the artil­
lerie against, &c.

Les bras, the arme.

Bras de mer, the arme of the sea: m.

Brasier, fire of coales: m.

Brasser & machiner à aucun quel­
que mal, to brewe or practise some
euill matter to another.

Qui à Brassé tout l'affaire, the brew­
er of all the mischiefe.

Brassée or brasse, a fadome: f.

Brassée de bois, foin, ou paille, an
armefull of wood, hay, or strawe.

Brasselet & ornement de bras, a
bracelet: m.

Brasselets & gantelets de fer, brace­
lets of a man of armes: m.

Brassiers, handicrafts-men in brasse
and copper: brasiers: m.

Bravade, brauery, f: a boasting: f.

Faire vne Bravade à aucun, to braue
one, that is to abuse one by wordes or
deeds, but in place of safety: & so
it may be termed a cowardly chal­
lenge.

Braver, to be braue: to boaste.

Bravement marcher, to goe neatly.

Vne braye ou museliere à chevaux,
 an instrument set on the nose of hor­
ses: f.

Brayer, to dresse a boate or ship with
pitch.

Des Brayes à luicter, breeches for 
wrastlers: f.

Brayes, breeches, sloppes, vpper­
stockes.

Faulse-braye, an out wall in a for­
tresse: f.

La brayette d'vne balance, the beam
of a balance: f.

Vne Braguette, or brayette, a cod­
pice: f.

Vn Breant, m: a bird called a siskin.

Vne Brebis, a sheepe: f.

Brebiette, a smal sheepe, f: an ewe
sheepe.

Brebiaille, a great flock of sheepe: f.

Breche en vn mur, a breach in a 
wall: f.





Breche-dent, a tooth gaper."tooth gaper" not found in OED.

Bredouiller, to stammer.

Vn bredouillard, m: a stammerer.

Bredaille, great panch or belly.

Bredailler, m: a gor-belly: a man ha­
uing a great fat belly.

Bref, see brief.

Brehaigne, the female of any kinde of
beast which is barren: the contra­
rie is portiére: f.

Brelan, or berlan, the place of dicing
and carding: m.

Tenir le Brelan, to keepe an open
house for whoremongers.

Hanter le Brelan, to frequent such
places.

Bren, m: turd.

Breneux, beshitten.

Bresil, brasill: m.

Bresil, biefe salted dried vp in the
chimney, Martlemas biefe: m.

Les Bretelles d'une hotte, the armes
of a basket or maunde carried vpon
ones shoulders.

Bresin, the hooke of a crane: m.

Breviaire, the seruice booke of priests
of the Church of Rome: m.

Il est clerc jusques aux dents, il à
mange son Breviaire, he is clarke
to the teeth-ward, he hath eaten his
seruice booke: spoken in mockage by
such as maketh shew of learning & 
be not learned.

Vn breulet, an engin to take birds: m.

Breuvage, seeke boire.

Breuet & toute autre recognoissance
par laquelle on confesse devoir, a­
voir reçeu, ou autrement quelque
chose d'aucun, a briefe, a handwri­
ting: m.

Brezo, see braise.

Briber, to begge, to loue bribes.

Bribe, a bribe: f.

Bribeur, a begger, that loueth bribes.

Briborions, mumbling wordes, as the
priests of the papists doe vse in their
prayers for the dead: m.

Bric, as pendre son adversaire au
bric, to take aduantage vpon the
word of his aduersary, or when a word
vnwarily spoken, is taken for a con­
fession: m.

Brichet, the breast, the brisket: m.

Bricoler, to play finely at tennis.

Bricole, as Il a fait vne bricole,  hee
hath plaied & made a brick wall: f.

Vne bride ou la rene d'vne bride, a
bridle, the raynes of a bridle: f.

Brider vn cheval, to bridle a horse.

Bride à veaux, lyes: f.

Brief, en Brief, briefe, to be short.

De brief, shortly.

Brifaut, a deuourer of meate: m.

Brievement, shortly, briefly, in fewe
wordes.

Brievete, shortnesse: f.

Brigade, a company: f.

Brigader, to keepe company.

Vne brigandine & cotte de maille,
 a Brigandine or coate of maile: f, a
coate of fence.

Vne Brigandine à double escaille,
 a Brigandine double plated.

Vn Brigantin, a ship called a brigan­
tine: m.

Brigue & course qu'on fait envers
les vns & les autres, quand on
brigue quelque office, running vp
and downe suing for an office: f.





Brigue pour estre Consul, sute for a 
Consulship.

Briguer, to sue or labour for.

Brigueur, ou brigand & destrosseur
de gents, a robber, a theefe: m.

Brigandage, briberie, theeuerie: m.

Brigander & destrosser, to robbe by
the high way.

Briganderie, robberie: f.

Brigandeau, a yong theefe: m.

Briller, to catch birds by night with a 
Lanterne.

Briller, to shine like a Diamond or
looking glasse at the beames of the
Sunne.

Chose Brillante, a shining or gli­
string thing.

Brin, as vn brin de sel, a corne of
salte: m.

Ie n'en ay brin, I haue neuer a whit.

Il n'est vn seul Brin estonné, he is ne­
uer a whit astonied.

Vn Brin de marjolaine, ou d'herbe,
 a slip of margerie or any hearb.

Brimballer, to shake like the flesh of
a foggie person or great dugge.

Tetin qui Brimballe à tous couts, a 
hanging filthie dugge, marot.

Brique, Bricke.

Briqueterie, bricke worke: f.

Briquetier, he that maketh bricks:
m.

Briser, to beate, to braie, to breake.

Brisure, breaking, brusing: f.

Brisans, be the breaking of the waues
of the Sea hitting at some rocke.

Bris, as courir au bris, shipwracke, to
runne to the wracke: m.

Vne Brisure, a bruse: f.

Vn grand brock, a great pot or stean,
a gallon: m.

Brocard & parolle de mocquerie,
a scoffe, a floute: m.

Brocarderie, idem.

Brocarder aucun, to flout one.

Vn brocart ou jeune cerf qui n'a
point encor les cornes forchées
ou forchues, a spitter.

Broche, a spit or broache: f.

Broches et defences d'un sanglier,
 the crotchet teeth of a wilde Bore,
the great teeth of a Bore.

Brocher vn cheval des esperons, to
spurre a Horse.

Vne robe toute Brochée d'or. a 
Gowne all sparkeled with golde or
aglets.

Brocher vn livre, to stitch a booke.

Ce livre n'est pas consu, ains seule­
ment broché, this booke is not sew­
ed, but onely stiched.

Couper broché, to cut off, to take a­
way the occasion.

Brochette soit de bois, ou de fer, a
pegge of wood or iron, a pricke: f.

Il a les Broches, he hath the piles.

Brochet, a Pike: m.

Vn Brocheton, a Pickrell: m.

Brochet marin, an Hadocke.

Brodequin, a buskinne, a startoppe:
m.

Brodeur, Brodure, seeke Bord.

Brodeures d'or, f. abiliments.

Broncher, seeke Bruncher.

Bronze, brasse: m.

Braguettes, little nailes called tacks.

Brosser du lin, ou chambre, to dresse
hempe, to brake hempe.





Brosse, to brake, or prichell: f."prichell" antedates earliest OED citation (1875).

Brosse, also a place full of wood, bu­
shes, thornes and brambles, a bushie
close.

Brosser à travers le bois, to runne
through woods as Hunters doo.

Brou, the huske or pill of greene nut
which blacketh ones fingers and
hands: m.

Brouët or Brouëd qui n'est point
exquis, broath: m.

Brouëtte, a wheelebarrowe: f.

Brouillars: m, & Brouées d'hyver: f,
 myst or fogge.

Vne Brouë: a little white cloude: f.

Brouiller, to confound, to mingle, to
tumble togither, to marre.

Brouillon, a marrer or confounder of
things.

Brouilleur, ou qui Brouille, a tum­
bler together, a slubberer, a marrer
or spoyler of things: m.

Brouilleries, toyes, confounded things:
f.

Broillis, or Brouillis en proces, de­
laies or petiefoggerie in Law: m.

Broussailles, a place full of bushes and
thornes.

Brouter & manger, to brouze to feed
like an Oxe or a Goate, to bruse.

Broier & casser bien menu, to braie,
to beate small, to powne.

Broyé, braied beaten small.

Brouy, or Bruy, burned.

Brouyr, to burne.

Vn Bruant, m: a kinde of little bird
counterfeiting neighing of horses.

Bru, daughter in law: f.

Ma bru, my sonnes wife.

Mon bruman, my daughters hus­
band: m.

Broyeur a beater small: m.

Vne Bruine qui gaste les arbres, a
blasting of trees: f.

Bruit, a brute, a noise: m.

Faire bruit, to make a noise.

Bruit de quelque chose nouvelle. 

Bremé entre le peuple, soit bon ou
mauvais, a fame or reporte among
people.

Petit bruit de ville & nouvelle, a 
tale or rumour, a talke.

Le bruit est, the brute is.

Semer vn bruit partout & espandre,
 to spread a tale abroad.

Bruire, to make a noise, to sound, to rum­
ble: je bruis, je brui, j'ay bruit, je
bruiray.

Bruiment, a rumbling: m.

Le bruiment des portes, the creaking
of doores.

Bruman seeke Bru.

Brume, the shortest day of the Win­
ter: f.

Brumal, wintrie.

Brun, browne: m.

Vne brune, a browne woman, f: a
louely browne.

Bruncher, to stumble.

Chevaux qui brunchent, stumbling
or tripping iades.

Brunet, brownish.

Aller soubz la Brune, to goe at twy­
light.

Brunette, a nutbrowne wench.

Brunir, to burnish, to furbish, je brunis
je bruny, j'ay bruny, je bruniray.

Se brunir, to burnish himselfe.





Bruse, ou meurte sauvage, wilde brush
butchers broome: f.

Brusler, to burne.

Bruslé, burned.

Bruslant, burning.

Bruslure, a burning: f.

Bruslement ou embrasement, a bur­
ning: m.

Brusque, quicke, liuely, hastie, wilde.

Brusquement, lustely, fiercely.

Ilz assailliruent or donnerent dans
les ennemis Brusquement, they did
set vpon their enemies lustely.

Mesure brusque, a swifte quicke mea­
sure in musicke.

Bruthler, a kinde of Hawke which can
neuer be tamed a carrein Kite: m.

Brutal, beastly, wilde or brutish.

Qui vit Brutallement, which liueth
beastly.

Brutalité, f: beastliness.

Qui parle brutif, which speaketh
thicke.

Bruvage, seeke Boire.

Des Bruyéres, furzes, briers, heath to
make broomes of.

Bruyereux, full of heath.

Bruoire, f: brionie or neppe.

Bube, ou Bubette, a wheale, a bli­
ster: f.

Vne Bube au visage, a bunch in the
face: f.

Vne Buche de Bois, a logge of wood, a 
backestocke: f."backestocke" not found in OED.

Droict de Buse, see Droict.

Petites Buchettes qui chéent des
arbres, feuilles ou fleurs, the flower
that falleth from trees: f.

Bucquer, seeke Buquer.

Buée, lye: f.

Faire la buée, to sette and washe a 
bucke.

Buandiére, a Launderer: f.

Buér les linceux draps, to washe a
bucke.

Vne buffe: f: ou soufflet, m: a buf­
fet, a blow on the eare.

Buffeter vn home, to boxe a man, to 
buffet with fists.

Buffeter les vins, to marre wines by
tasting them before they be set a
broach.

Vins Buffetez, wines spoyled in ta­
king winde through tasting of hire­
lings.

Buffeter les vins en vne cave ou na­
vire, to spoyle wines by often tasting
in sellars.

Vn Buffet & dressoir, a cubbard, a
dresser: m.

Vn Buffet d'or & d'argent, c'est à
dire, la vaisselle qu'il fault pour le 
service de la table, a cubbard of
plate.

Bufle, a beast called a Buffe: m.

Bugler comme font les bœufs, to
loow, to bellowe.

Le ventre me Bugle de faim, my bel­
lie crieth through hunger.

Buglement, a loowing: m.

De la Buglosse, Buglosse: f.

Bugnets, fritters: m.

Buïe, a pitcher, an oyle pot: f.

Vne buire à mettre l'huile, an oyle
glasse, a vyolle: f.

Vne buire, ou buirette, a cruet: f.

Buisart sorte d'oiseau, a Buzzard, a 
Bittour: m.





Vn Buscher, a pile of wood: m.

Buisson, a thorne or bryar: a bush.

Vne Buisine, f: a little pipe to play.

Buissonnier, qui hante les buissons:
 frequenting hedges and bushes.

Bulle, a Bull, such as come from the 
Pope: f.

Vn Buletin, pour estre franc du
port, a bill, a cocket: m.

Buquer à l'huis, to knocke at the 
doore.

Vn habillement de Bureau, ou autre 
drap meslangé de petit pris, dont
les serfs & menu peuple souloit
estre accoustré, a coate of change­
able colours for seruants, slight 
rugge, or pampilion: m.

Le Bureau ou comptoir, m: the 
place of payment or distribution.

Mettre vn proces sur le Bureau, a 
cause readie to be iudged.

Mettre l'afaire sur le bureau, to exa­
mine a matter.

Burette, a little oyle pot: f.

Vn Burin, a grauing sticke: m.

Buriner, to graue or carue in wood
stone, and such like: also to pierce.

Vn Buse, a buske, such as Gentlewo­
men doe weare.

Vn Bust, m: idem.

But, a scope, a but, a pray, or bootie: m.

Butiner, to bootie, or pray.

Herbe qui se nomme Butoesne, Be­
tonie.

Vn Butor, a bird called a Bitter.

Bavetter, buvotter buvette, buvage,
 seeke Boire.

Buyele, or Buxole, the Diall of Mar­
riners: m.

Buyzart, seeke Buisart.

Byble, see Bible.

Byrrasque, see Birrasque.


C ante A.

CA & là, hither and thither.

Courir ça & là, to runne hither
and thither.

Cabale, an instruction by word of
mouth giuen expressely by the fa­
ther to the sonne: f.

Cabane, a cotage: f: a cabin made of
boughes.

Cabaret, a victualling house: m.

Cabaretier, he that keepeth a victu­
alling house: a victualler: of some
an huckster: f.

Herbe qu'on appelle Cabaret, an
hearbe called Haselwort.

Vn Cabas de figues, a fraile of
figs: m.

Cabasset, a helmet or headpeece: m.

Cabinet, a Coffer, a Wardrope: m.

Le Cabinet d'vne femme, toutes
sortes d'ornements, joyaux & af­
fiquets qu'elle à pour s'accouïn­
ter, & attifer, a womans casket.

Caboche, the head: f.

Cabochon de pierre precieuse, quand
la pierre est taillée en bosse, the
bosse or rising of a pretious stone, the
hood of a foole: m.





Choux Cabus, Cabiges: m.

Laituës Cabuces, f: Letteise with a 
head like Cabiges.

Cacher, to hide, to conuey away.

Caché, hidden.

Cachenez, a muffler: m.

Vne Cachette, a corner, a close
place: f.

En Cachette, priuilie, closely hid­
denly: f.

Cercher les Cachettes, to seeke darke
corners.

Cachots, or cavernes, a couert for
Deere, or other beasts: m.

Cacasangue, the fretting of the guts,
the bloodie flixe: f.

Cachement, a hiding: m.

Cachet, a signet or seale: m.

Vn faulx Cachet, ou seau contre­
faict, a counterfaite seale.

Cacheter des lettres, to seale letters.

Calcidoine pierre precieuse, a pre­
tious stone so named: f.

Cad d'eauë, a storme: m.

La cadence des mots, the round vt­
tering of words: f.

Garder la Cadence en danfant, to
keepe measure in dancing.

Caduque, transitorie.

Cadaver, a carkasse, a dead body: m.

Cadeau, a great drawne letter: m.

Lettre cadelée, a letter drawne.

Cadenat, a padlocke: m.

Cadéne, a chaine of yron wherewith 
slaues in the galleis are bound: f.

Cadet, the younger brother among
Noble men: m.

Cafard, a flatterer, a glauerer: m.

Cafarder, to dissemble.

Cafardie, flattering, dissimulation: f.

Vne cage, a cage: f.

Cageois, a Countrey clowne: m.

Casois, or rather Cageois, Cotagers,
or men dwelling in countrie houses.

Cagot, an hypocrite, a dissembler: m.

Cahuër, Cahuöt, or Cahot, m:: the
iumppe or hoppe which a waggon or
coch giueth in an vneuen way.

Cahocer, or faire des cahots, to iump
or hoppe like a running or rowling
cart or waggon.

Vne Cahute, or Cahutelle, f: a little 
cotage.

Caignard, a micher, a hedgecreeper,
a common begger: m.

Caignardier, a chimney creeper, a
sluggish one: m.

Caignarder, to play the part of a slug­
gard and micher.

Cailler le Laict, to turne, or curde
Milke.

Caillette: f: the codde of a sheepe: we
call a foole Caillette: m.

Cailleboteux, full of flint stones.

Vne Caille, a Quaile: f.

Caillebottes, f: Milke full of small 
curds.

Vn Caillou, a bigge or flint stone: m.

Caïmander & amasser à la boiste, to
begge at the grate.

Caïmanderie, beggerlinesse or beg­
gerie: the art of begging: f.

Vn Cayon, m: a little hogge.

Vne Caisse, see Casse.

Cal, hardnes of the hands or feet: m.

Avoir des Calles es mains, ou aux
pieds de force travail, to haue hard
handes or feete with labour: also





cornes in the toes.

Calamar, a pennar: m.

Calamine, forger monnoye de cu­
yvre pur, sans calamine ny autre
mistion de metail, to coyne money
of pure copper, without Calamin, or
other mettall: f.

Calamité, miserie, wretchednesse.

Calamiteux, a poore wretch.

Calamite, or aimant, m: the Load­
stone.

Calanger, seeke Chalanger.

Calciner, to bring any mettall into 
powder: to purifie mettals.

Calcination, purifying of mettals: f.

Calcul, m: casting of accompt.

Calculateur, m: a reckoner, one that
taketh accompt, or caster of ac­
compt.

Calendes, f: the first day of each mo­
neth.

Vne Calendre, f: as Il chante comme
vne Calendre: he singeth like a
Larke: but our Calendre is bigger
and greater then a Larke.

Calculer, to compt, to reckon.No entry found for "compt" in OED as a verb.

Calendre ou Chatepeleuse, petite
beste qui ronge le froument, a little
beast that eateth corne called a
Mite or Weauill: f.

Calendrer vne toile, to slight a web,
or linnen.

Toile Calendrée, linnen cloth sligh­
ted: f.

Calendrier, par lequel ou pouvoit
cognoistre les jours festez & non
festez, a Kalendar: m.

Calenger, see Chalenger.

Caler les voiles, to strike down sailes.

Calfatin, m: the seruant of him which
hath the charge to trim a ship.

Calfat, he which hath the charge to
trimme a galley or ship: m.

Calfeutrer vn navire, to set a ship in
good order.

Calibre, or Qualibre, a qualitie, state
or degree.

Calibrer, as tu ne te dois calibrer à
moy, thou oughtest not to compare
thyselfe vnto me.

Calice, a Chalice: m.

Caliginosité, darknesse, dimnesse: f.

Caligineux, darke, dimme.

Caller & abaisser les voiles, to strike
sailes: see Caler.

Caller, or Chattonner, quand la
chatte fait ses petis chatons, when
the Cat bringeth forth her kitlings.

Vn Calmar & estuy, a case, a pen­
nar: m: also a kind of bird.

La mer Calme, & sans tormente,
 the calme sea.

Calmement, peaceably, softly: f.

Calomnie, quand falsement &
mauvaisement on allegue, ou met
on à fus quelque chose à quel­
qu'vn, a false accusation, a forged
crime: f.

Calomniateur, a false or malitious
accuser: m.

Home fort Calomnieux, m: a man
full of false accusation.

Calomnieusement, falsely.

Collops and egges, des œufs au lard.

Calotte, the paper or cloth wherewith
women doe wrappe their flaxe vpon
the distaffe, a burlet, or coiffe: f.

Calvaire, m: a mans skull.





Camall, m: a hoode against foule wea­
ther: also a coife or ribbon to trusse
the haires.

Tu es vn Camat, thou art a squall.

Calvanier, the hyred man which in
haruest doth carrie corne into ones
barnes: m.

Qui est cambré, ou courbé dehors
& contremont, bowed outward or
vpward: m: bowed backward and
vpward.

Cambrer, to vault or bow any thing
vpward: to build archwise.

Cambrure, f: such building like an
arch or vault.

Cameau, m: see Chameau.

Saulse Cameline, f: a certaine kinde
of saulce.

Habillement cameloté, a chamblet
coate: m.

Camelot, Chamblet: m.

Vn Camion, m: a little small pinne,
a post pinne: also a verie small
cart."post pinne" not found in OED.

Camisade, as donner vne camisade, 
to raise one in the morning and 
giue him a cleane shirt: to assault
a Campe, a Towne or Fort in the
morning betimes, a Camisadoe: to
giue a cold pye: f."to giue a cold pye" not found as a sense of "camisado" in the OED.

Camomille, Camomill: f.

Le camp, the Campe: m.

Camper, to set or place his Campe: to
pitch a Campe.

Campane, a Bell: f.

Vne campaigne, a voide field: f.

Campanette, an hearb or flowre cal­
led Canterbury belles: f.

Les escholiers ont Campos, schol­
lers haue leaue to play, or vacation
time.

Camphre, a gum called Camphire: m.

Camus, flat nosed, a camoise nose: m.

Elle est Camuse, she hath a camoise 
nose.

Petis chiens Camus, little flat nosed
dogges.

Camuset, m: little flat nosed.

Camusette, f: a woman a little ca­
moise nosed.

Ce ne sont que Canailles, f: they
are but rascals, scuruie knaues, of 
no estimation, dregges of the peo­
ple.

Canal, a conduite pipe, a chanell: m.

Le canal d'vne riviére, the chanell of
a riuer.

Canaille, dogges, a kennell of hounds,
rascals: m.

Canceler & mettre à neant quel­
ques lettres, to cancell a bill.

Vn Canard, m: a Drake.

Vne Cane, a Ducke: f.

Faire la Cane, to hide himselfe from
the battaile.

Candois, as if one would say Hun­
dreds in England, but they be soue­
raigne Lords, as among the Swit­
zers: m.

Caneler, to make rebates, chanels, a
chamfering in stone or timber.

Canelé,  chamfred: hauing creuises.

Caneleure, chamfring, chaneling: f.

Canceler & mettre à neant quel­
ques lettres, to cancell or bring to 
no effect certaine writings.

Cancre, a canker.

Candeur, whitenesse: m.





Canebasse, a little bottle to hang at
ones girdle: f.

Canelle à tirer du vin, a tap: f.

Canelle, a cinamon: f.

Canette, a little Ducke: f.

Caneter, to goe like a Ducke.

Caner, to squirt.

Du canevers, Canuasse: m.

Iours caniculaires, dogge daies.

La Canicule, or chaud mal: a hot fe­
uer or ague: f.

Canetille, an edging lace: f.

Canon, a lawe, a rule or direction in
law, as in the Canon law: m.

Docteur en droit Canon, a Doctor
in the Canon law.

Canon, a Canon: m.

Maistre Canonier, a master Cano­
ner: m."master cannoneer" not found in OED.

Vn Canepin bien delié qui est prins
du dedens de l'escorce du tillet
ou bouleau, en quoy les anciens
escrivoyent, the inner part of the
barke of a tree, which the men in
ancient time did write on.

Canepetiere, f: a bird as delicate as
a Fesant, some doe take it to be a 
Bustard or Bistard.

Les jour Caniculaires, dogge daies.

Vn Canevers, Canuasse.

Vn canivet, a penknife: m.

Canne: f: ou rouseau: m: a Reede,
or Cane.

Habillements couverts de Canne­
tilles, garded or purfled garments.

Canonizer, to canonise, to make a
Saint.

Canon musical, the sound boord in
Organes.

Le Canon d'vne harquebuse, the
barrell of a Gunne.

Vn Canon d'artillerie, a Canon.

Vn Canonier, m: a master gunner.

Les Canonnieres d'vne ville ou d'vn
chasteau, f: the loop-holes, the win­
dowes or round holes whereby the 
besieged in Townes or Castles doe
shoote vpon the enemies.

Par tous les Cantons des rues, m:
 by all the corners of the streetes.

Cantharide, vne sorte de ver veni­
meux & verd, qui s'engendre au
sommet des branches du fresne
& de l'olive, a kind of flye, or vene­
mous worme called Cantharides: f.

Canton, as les Cantons des Suisses,
 as if one would say, the Hundreds
among the Switzers: m.

Faire Cap à la mer, to take the maine
sea.

Capable, capable, receiuable.

Capacité, capacitie or receiueable­
nesse: f.

La capacité & portée d'aucun, the
capacitie or vnderstanding of any
man.

Pomme de capandu, ou carpendu,
quasi qui diroit court pendu, a 
pepine: m.

Capel, m: a little hat: from thence
commeth Capeline, f: a little flat
and broade hat which our Sheep­
heards doe vse, and men of warre
in time past, but of yron.

Capitation, poore men paying onely
for poling in time of subsidies: f.

Capitaine, a Captaine: m.

Capitainerie, a captainship: f.





Cappe, a cloake, a Spanish cape: f.

Cappéer, or cingler à la Cappe, to
saile yeelding vnto the tempest, and
yet to saile towards his iourney,
though it auaileth but a little.

Capendu, pepins: m.

Capituler, to agree by articles.

Capitulations, Articles of agree­
ment: f.

Capitulant, hauing a voyce in anie
Councell or assemblie.

Caprioles, or Sanguinaire, f: an
hearbe that stancheth blood.

Faire Capriots en dansant, to caper 
in dauncing.

Capriotant, capring.

Des Cappres, Capers: f.

Captif, a bondman.

Captivité, bondage: f.

Capuchon, a cowle or hood: m.

Caquesangue, the bloodie flixe: f.

Vne Caque de pouldre, f: a barrell
of powder.

Caquet, pratling, babling: m.

Caqueter, to prate, to babble.

Caquetoires, f: pratling places, where
women doe prattle togither.

Vn grand Caqueteur, Caquetard,
m: a pratler.

Vne Caquetarde, f: a woman prat­
ler.

Car, for.

Caractere, an impression, a marke or
signe, a letter: m.

Caracterer, to print.

Vn Carat, a caratte, a waight among
Goldsmiths: m.

Vne Caravelle, f: a kind of ship vsed
in Spayne and Portingale.

Caraque, or Carraque, a very strong
vessell vpon the sea.

Carchiophe, Artichault, an Arti­
choke: m.

Carder de la laine, to card wooll.

Cardeur de laine, a wooll carder: m.

Des Cardes à carder la laine, Wooll
combe cardes: f.

Caresse, chearing, welcomming, ma­
king much of: f.

Caresser, to cherish one, to welcome
one, to set much by one.

La Carine & fond de la naviere, the
keele of the ship: f.

Le Cariage, the cariage: m.

Carbonade, a Carbonadoe: f.

Carcois, m: a certaine part of the
top of the mast.

Carillon, a chiming of bels, courfew.

Ie te frotteray à double Carrillon, I
will beate thee like a stockefish: m.

Carizez, Kersies: f.

Carme, vne sorte d'arbre, a tree so
called.

Les Carmes, white friers: m.

Caresme, m: Lent.

Caresme prenant, Shrouetide.

Les Carneaux d'vne muraille, battle­
ments of walles: m.

Muraille Crevelée, f: or mur Cre­
velé, m: a wall of battlements.

Carnage, slaughter: m.

Vn Carolus, a peece of French money
worth somewhat aboue an English
penie: m.

Carolle, a kind of daunce: f.

Caroller, to daunce.

Carote, a Carret roote: f.

Vne Carpe, a Carpe: f.





Carpendu, see Capendu.

Carpie Charme, ou Carme, vne
sorte d'arbre, a certaine tree called
Carpi.

Vn Carquan, carkenet: m.

Carquois, a quiuer for arrowes: m.

Monstrer Carre de gens deliberez
et hardis, to shew a countenance of
stout men.

Carreau, seeke Quarreau.

Carrefour, seeke Quarrefour.

Carreler, to sole shooes.

Vne Carrelure, a sole of shooes: f.

Vne Carriere, f: as parfaire sa Carri­
ere, to run his Carrier or course.

Desloger et prendre sa Carriere, to
run at the tilt.

Carrillonner, to ring bels, and florish
therewith.

Carrillon, m: chyming of Bels.

l'arbre du Carobe, Carroube or Car­
roubier, the name of a certaine
tree.

Cartamus sylvestre, a tree so na­
med: m.

Cartilage, a gristle: m.

Cartilagineux, gristly.

Carte, a paper: f.

Carte blanche, as donner la carte
blanche, when the Prince giueth
vnto his Deputie a white paper
wherein is nothing written but the
Princes hand and seale.

Cartel, a bill or letter of defiance to 
fight in a close field: m.

Cartée, f: idem.

Carvy sauvage herbe, wilde cara­
waies: m.

Cas, a cause, a matter: m.

Vn Cas & meschant faict, a mischie­
uous matter.

Vn Cas aigre, & qui est trouvé fort
mauvais, a hainous matter.

Afin qu'on face Cas de toy, that
thou maiest be esteemed.

Mets le Cas que, &c. put the case
that.

Pren le Cas qu'il soit vaincu, put the
case he be ouercome.

Ceste cloche sonne Cas, this bell
ringeth as broken.

Voix Casse, a hollowe and broken
voice: f.

Casaque, f: or casaquin, m: a cas­
socke, a short garment, as men of
warre or Lackies do vse.

Case, an house: f.

Casanier, a sluggard, one that keepeth
the house, and house-doue.

Caseret: m, or esclises, f: à faire
fourmages, a cheese fatte, a cheese
presse.

Cassade, a deceit, a guile, a frumpe, a
floute, a mocke: f.

Donner vne Cassade, to deceiue, to
flowte.

Vne Casse en laquelle ou apporte
de la marchandise, a case: f.

Cassemuseaux, fine Cakes like buns:
m.

Casse-noix, a kinde of Bird, also a
crackenut: m.

Casquet, the visor of a headpeece: m.

Casuël, casuall, transitorie.

Deniers casuëls, reuenue or rent which
is vncertaine, as of toll, custome, &c.

De la Casse, Cassia, a fruite of In­
dia: f.





Casser, to breake, to crush in peeces.

Le Roy l'a Cassé, or il est Cassé, he
is crost out of wages.

Estre couché en estat, is the contra­
rie.

Casses, or Cassetis, little boxes wher­
in Marchants and Grocers doe put
their sundrie wares, also a Casket.

Casseure, battering, cracking, when
a vessell is battered or craked: f.

Casser les gents de guerre, to put
Souldiers out of wages, to crosse them
out of wages.

Cassé, fayled, put out of office.

Cassé & rompu, broken.

Cassant & aisé à Casser, easie to be
broken, frayle.

Castaing, as Il a les yeux roux et ca­
staings, he hath eyes of chestnut
colour.

Castadours, see Gastadours, m: pi­
oners.

Castagneux, m: a little bird.

Castalie, f: a fountaines name dedi­
cated vnto the Muses.

Caste, see Chaste.

Prendre la Castille pour aultruy, to
take the quarrell for an other: f.

Vn Castor, m: a beuer.

Casuël, as c'est vne chose Casuëlle,
 it is a casuall thing, it happeneth by
chaunce see Cas.

Catalogue, m: a rehearsall in words
or table in writing, of the number
of things, a role, a bill.

Cataplasme, m: a plaister.

La Cataracte en l'œil, f: the webbe
in the eye.

La Cataracte d'une montaigne, ou
quelque aultre lieu par où l'eauë
tombe avec grand bruit, a great
fall of water from on high broken
place making a great noise.

Catarrhe, m: & distillation d'hu­
meurs, f: the Catarre or falling
downe of humours.

Categoriquement, accusingly, or
things spoken before.

On le somma de respondre Cate­
goriquement & sans tergiverser,
 he was sommoned to answere to his
accusation without wrangling, or
delay.

Cathechiser, to cathechise one, to in­
struct one in the Christian faith.

Caterolle, the little hole where the
Cunnie keepeth her yong ones: f.

Cathedrale, eglise cathedralle, a ca­
thedrall Church.

Catholique, vniuersall.

Catonien, seuere as Cato.

Cavallier, a platforme, a rumpire: m.

Cavallerie, horsemen: f.

Vn Cavalin, a little horse: m.

Cavain, m: see Caver.

Cauchemare, the disease called the
Mare, whereby one thinketh he
hath a great waight vpon him stop­
ping his breath: f.

Caudatere, he or she that beareth a
noble womans traine.

Cavechure, in Picardie, is that we
call vn Chevestre, a halter.

Caver, to dig in, or make hollowe.

Cavé, made hollowe.

Cave à vin, a wine Celler, or vaut.

Cavette, a little caue or seller: f.

Cavain, or Cavité, a hole or hollowe





place: m.

Cavement, a making hollowe: m.

Caverne, f: a denne.

Caverneux, hollow.

Cavenne de berger, a Shepheards
arbour: f.

Caviller, to iest, to cauill, to reason
ouerthwartly.

Cavillateur, a cauillour: m.

Cavillation, a trifling cauill: f.

Le Caule de quelque herbe, the
stalke of any herbe: m.

Cauquemare, seeke Cauchemarre.

Caverne, a denne, a caue, or priuie
corner: f.

Cause qui faict faire quelque chose,
 the cause of any thing: f.

A cause, for because.

Dire la Cause, to giue a reason.

Avoir Cause & occasion, to haue
cause or occasion.

Vne Cause, f: & proces, m: a mat­
ter or processe.

Plaider sa cause, to pleade his mat­
ter.

Cause & avoir noise l'vn à l'autre,
 to contend, to striue together.

Vn Causeur, m: a pratler, a wrang­
ler.

Cault & fin, subtile, craftie, deceit­
full, warie.

Cauteleux, m: idem.

Cautelle, f: craft, guile, deceit.

Caustique, burning: as vnguent
Caustique, a burning salue or plai­
ster, a medicine burning the skin or
flesh.

Cautement, subtilly.

Cauteleusement, subtilly, craftily.

Cautérisation, the searing vp of a
wound, called by the Surgions Cau­
tering: f.

Vn Cautere, searing with a hot iron.

Cauterizer, to burne with an hotte
iron.

Pleige, m: & Caution, f: pledge sure­
tie.

Caution bourgeoise, a Citizen sure­
tie.

Cautionner quelcun, to baile one.

Cayer, a quier of any written paper, 
when a whole writing booke is deui­
ded into equall partes: m.

Caymander, or Caïmander, to beg.

Caïmanderie, f: begging.

Ce, that.

Et ce dés long temps, and that long
agone.

Ce-pendant, see Pendant.

C'est, is written in stead of ce est, that
is.

Ce, signifie que tu es vne beste, this,
doth signifie that thou art a beast.

Ceans, here within.

Est-il ceans? Is he within?

N'est-il pas ceans? Is he not heere
within?

Cecy, this heere.

Cecy mesme, this very thing.

Ceder à aucun, to graunt or giue
place to one.

Ceder & transporter quelque heri­
tage, to graunt or make ouer an he­
ritage.

Ie te Cede, I giue place to thee.

Vn Cedre, a Ceder tree: m.

Cé a sedule, a briefe, a hande
writing: f.





Ceindre, to girde: je ceins, je ceigni,
j'ay ceint, je ceindray.

Ceinct, girt.

Ceinct, m: ou ceincture, f: a girdle,
a girth.

Ceincturette, a little girdle: f.

Ceinturier, a girdeler: m.

Cela, that.

Celebre, famous, renowmed.

Celebrer, to extoll, to prayse.

Celebrer vne feste, to celebrate a 
holy day.

Celebration, celebrating.

Celebrité, renowme, haunting.

Celerité, swiftnesse.

Celsitude, the highnes of a prince: f.

Celer, to hide, to dissemble, to couer.

Celément, priuily.

Celerin, a little fish, otherwise called,
Harengade.

Celibat, m: single life: the state of
vnmaried men.

Vn Celercier, or Despencier, m: a
butler.

Celier, vn lieu soubs terre, comme
cave, & semblables, the Celler or
any place vnder the earth: m.

Celeste, qui est du ciel, heauenly, of
heauen.

Celestes, habitans au ciel, heauenly,
dwelling in heauen.

Celle, she.

Celuy, he.

Celuy là, the same man.

Cemetiere, ou dortoir, que les chre­
stiens  appellent ainsi, à cause de
l'esperance de la resurrection, a
Churchyarde: m.

Cencer, to reckon or account among
his reuenue: as cela est cencé entre
ses biens, this is accounted among
his rent, goods, or reuenue.

Cendre, ashes.

Cendrée sauvage, Sauory, Merio­
ram, Penniriall: f.

Des Cendrées, siluer put into small
balles: f.

Couleur Cendrée, ashe colour.

Le jour, or mescredi des Cendres,
 Ashwednesday.

Vn Cendrier, hee that keepeth the
chimney corner, a sluggard: m.

Cene, as Celebrer la sainte Cene du
seigneur, f: to celebrate the Lords
supper.

Vne Cengle, a girth: f.

Cengler vn cheval, to girt a horse.

Censer, see Cencer.

Cens, m: cense & rente: f: a rent, a
yearely reuenew.

Cense, ferme, ou metairie, a farme: f.

Censier, a fermer: m.

Censeur, a Cesser, a high Coonstable: m.

Censure, the value and estimation of
any mans goods: f.

Papiers Censiers, registers of ones
reuenewes.

Censurer & noter la vie d'un cha­
cun, to controll the life and actions
of each person.

Cent, a hundred.

Mettre par Centeines, to put by hun­
dreds.

Centenaire, com: continuing the
number of an hundred.

Centenier, a Centurion or captaine
of an hundred men: m.

La Centauria majeur, herbe, an hearb





called Centurie the greater: f.

la Centauria mineur, the lesser Cen­
turie: f.

Centidonia & corrigiole, herbe,
 knot-grasse: f.

Centre, poinct du milieu de toutes
choses, the centre or middle point:
m.

Cep, vne sorte de tourment de bois,
dedens lequel on met le col & les
pieds des malfaicteurs, an instru­
ment of torment made of wood, a 
timbrell, a pillorie, a paire of
stockes: m.

Ceper vne muraille, to beate downe
a wall by the foote.

Vn Cepier, he which keepeth, or hath
charge ouer the stockes: m.

Cerceau, a circle: m.

Cercelé, enuironed with a circle.

Cercelle, f: a water bird like a duck:
some take it to be a pochard: other
a teale.

Cercher diligemment, to seek out, to
boult out, to search diligently.

En cerchant, in seeking diligently.

Cercheur, a seeker, a searcher: m.

Cercheresse, a she seeker: f.

Cerchement, a seeking, a boulting
out, an inquisition: m.

La Cerche a esté faite, f: a serch hath
been made.

Apres diligente Cerche, after a di­
ligent search, or enquirie.

Cercelé, compassed about with a cir­
cle, hooped.

Cercle, a circle, a compasse: m.

Cercueil, a beere, a coffin: m.

Cerf, an Hart, a Stagge: m.

Le giste du cerf, the brake of the
Hart: m.

Cerfueil, Charuel: m.

Cerimonies, ceremonies: f.

Livre ceremonial, the booke where­
in the ceremonies of the court are
written.

Vne Cerise, a Cherry: f.

Cerisier, a cherrie tree: m.

Cerisée, f: the reuenewe rising by che­
ries.

Vne cherisaye, f: a place planted with
Cherry-trees.

Estre mis au rang des Cerites et tribu­
taires: to be put in the range or or­
der of those that pay tribute, or sub­
sidie: m.

Cerne, est autant à dire comme cir­
cle, a circle: m.

Faire cerne en terre, to close a ground
in.

Cerner & enciser les arbres, to cut
trees round about.

Cerner des noix, to crack nuttes.

Vn Cerneau, cela qui est bon à man­
ger d'vne noix, amende, & sem­
blables, the kernel of a nut, almond,
or any like thing: m.

Cerot, a seare-cloth: m.

Cerres, a kinde of peason: m.

Certes, certainely, truely, verily.

Certain & asseuré, certaine, sure,
without doubt.

Il est Certain, it is certaine, it is
doubtlesse.

Certainement, certainely, verily,
truely, surely.

Vne Certification qu'escrivent ceux
qui sont francs des imposts, & l'­





envoyent aux fermiers, a Certifi­
cate: f.

Sauoir quelque certitude & asseu­
rance de quelque chose, to be assu­
red of any thing.

Cervelle ou Cerveau, m: the braine.

Tenir son ennemy, son subiect, or
quelcun en cervelle, to keepe one
in feare or awe, to cause him to bee
circumspect, or looke to himselfe.

De la cervoise, beere: f.

De la Ceruse, f: ou fard, m: white 
leade.

Ces, ou ceux là, these or those.

Cesser & s'arrester, to cease, to stay,
to forbeare.

Cesser & se deporter de faire quel­
que chose, to stay from doing any
thing.

Les Ces, a ceasing, a forbearing, a 
forbidding: m.

Cesse, a ceasing, a forbearing.

Estudier sans Cesse, to study without
intermission.

Declairer Cessation des plaids, to
stay a matter in law: f.

Faire Cession de biens, to giue goods
ouer, when one for debt giueth o­
uer his goods, and so is free from al
his creditors.

Cessionaire, m: he which doth such
acte: a bankerupt.

C'est, it is, that is, seeke Ce.

Ceste-cy, Le feminin de cest, ou ce­
stuy, this woman.

Cestuy-cy mesme, this same man.

Cestuy-cy qui est aupres de moy,
 this fellowe by me.

Cestuy-là qui est aupres de toy, that
fellow by thee.

Cestuy-là Chrysippus, the very same
Chrysippus.

Ceves ou cevotes, Onions: f.

Vn Chabot, a little smal fish hauing
a great head: m.

Vn Chable, a cable: m.

Chacer, chace, seeke Chasser.

Chacieux, qui à de nature les yeux
pleurants, bleare eyed, or running
eyed."running eyed" not found in OED.

Chacieuseté, or Chacie, f: bleared­
nesse of the eyes.

Chafourré, disfigured, disguised: m.

Chagrin & soucy, griefe, care, way­
wardnesse: m.

Chagrin, soing & solicitude pour
autruy, carefulnesse.

Chagrigner, or Chagriner, to grieue,
to trouble a man.

Chagrigner, quelqu'vn, & le met­
tre en soucy, to fill one with care.

Ne vous chagrignez point, become
not wayward, be not pensiue or care­
full.

Chahüant, an Owle: m.

Le chainon du col, the hinder parte
of the necke: the nape: m.

Vne Chaine, a chayne: f.

Les chainons d'vne Chaine, the
likes of a chayne: m.

Chair, flesh: f.

Chaircutier, a Cooke which selleth
meate: m.

Chair-cuicterie, the place or market
where one may buy all kind of meat
ready dressed, f.

Charnier, le lieu où on met les os
des trespassez, a charnell house, a





great poudring tubbe: m.

Charnu, fleshie.

La Charnure d'vne personne, the 
flesh or brawne of one: f.

Vne Charongne, a carrion, a corse: f.

Vne Chaire, a chayre: f.

Chalant. or chalon, a wherry: m.

Chalant, or chaland, which Mer­
chants doe call a customer: m.

Chalande, a woman customer, which
is wont to buy in a place or shop.

Chalandise, f: the common or vsuall
comming or buying in a shoppe, ta­
uerne, or such like place.

Chalanger, to clayme.

Chalemie, a little pipe.

Chalemeler, to sing with a little pipe
made with the stalke of Oates.

Chalict, seeke Chaslit.

Chaleur, heete: f.

Ne se Chaloir plus de quelque
chose, not to passe for any thing.

Ne se Chaloir de rien, to care for no­
thing: il me chault, il me chaloit,
il me chalut, il m'a chalu, il me
chauldra: a verb impersonall.

Chalumeau, a reede, a pipe, stemmes
of hearbs: m.

Vne Chamarre, a shepheards pelt: f.

 a garment poudered with purple
studdes: m.

Chamailler, to strike with a sworde
vpon an armed man.

Chamaillis, the fight and striking of
armed men: m.

Chambriére, a mayd seruant: f.

mir, a bed chamber: f.

Innes.

certaine men dwelling in a cham­

D'une mesine Chambrée, which be
of one chamber.

iakeses: f.

hempe.

Chan: m.

Sur le Champ, immediately, at that
instant.

Champart, field rent: m.

Champarter: to diuide a field by e­
quall portions or partes.

countrey.

Faulcon Champestre, a Faulcon
which feedeth by pray, and not at
the fist.

shire, a bastard or base borne: m.

told-stoole, a mushrome: m.

Chance, chaunce: f.

Chanceller, to stagger, to reele, to wa­

Il va chancelant soubz le fardeau,
m: hee goeth faultring vnder the 
burthen.

Il chancelle en parlant, he faultreth
in his tale.

Chancellement, a staggering, a stut­

dle.

Chanfrain creux, ce sont comme

scorse.

Changer quelque chose avec au­
cun to scorse with one.

renue.

Change, a change: m.

his talke.

newed.

vinewed.

Chanter, to sing.

Les Chanteaux d'un habillement,
 the quarters of any apparell.

Chantonner, to chaunt.

Chant, song: m.

Chanson, a song: f.

Chansonnette, a litle Song: f.

 the singing string, the cord or string,

watering pot, the cocke of a Ce­
sterne, a tap: f.

Chantier, a stake, a canteling: m.

Chantier de bois, a pile of wood, a
stalder.Antedates earliest OED citation for "stalder" (1611).

fielde where they sowe Hempe: f.

Du Chanuré, Hempe: m.

Vne Chapeau ou bonnet à couvrir la 
teste, a hat or cap: m.





Chape, a Cope, also the lock of a dag­
ger: f.

Chapeau faict d'espics de blé, a gar­
land of Corne eares: m.

Vn Chapeau de fleurs, ou bouquet,
 a garland of floures: m.

Petit Chapeau de fleurs, a little gar­
land of floures.

Chapalier, m: ou chapeliére, f: a
garland maker, a hat maker.

Vne Chapeline, f: a broad hat such 
as haruest folkes weare.

Chappelle, a Chappell, a stiller: f.Antedates earliest OED citation for "chappell" (as alembic; 1708).

Chapeler du pain, to chip bread.

Chapelures, chippings: f.

Chapelet, m: or patenostres, f:
 beades.

Chapelet, a circle made with willows,
or brasse to set dishes vpon the ta­
