Chapelet de fleurs, m: a willowe
wreath.

Danser en chapellet, to daunce in a 
circle.

Ouvrager chapelets, to make Gar­
lands of flowers.

Chaperon, m: ou vne chappe, f: que
les femmes portent par temps de
pluye, a hoode: m.

Vn chaperon de veloux, a French
hoode.

Chaperonner aucun, to crouch to
one, to put of his cap, often suing
vpon one.

Chappe, the hoode which the Iudges
do vse, also a Cope: m.

La chappe d'vne dague, la chappe
d'un fourreau, the locket of a dag­
ger, or scabbard.

Chapplis, or chamaillis, the noyse
which men of armes do make fight­
ing and striking one an other, also
an haggasse pudding.

Le chapetiau d'vn pilier & colon­
ne the toppe or chapter of a piller:
m.

Vn chapitre de livre, the chapter of 
a booke: m.

Pain de Chapitre fine bread.

Chapon, a Capon: m.

Charette.

 dead or quick coales.

pour faire quelque chose, the

businesse.

to any.

ble.

Chargé, charged, burthened.

Home Charitable, com: a charita­

Charmer, to exchange, to charme.

En Charnage, in the time of flesh.

Charnier, a place where the corpses
are laid a churchyard, a powdring
tub, also a little pale or prop.

bones are kept.

on Vines doe holde.

Charnu, charnure, charongne, seeke
Chair.

pentrie, also to strike.

of: f.

Charruë, a plough: f.

Cherté, seeke Cher.

Vne chartre, ou prison, a prison: f.

Venir ou estre en Chartre, & tout
sec, to wither away.

Chartres, all writings & monuments
touching peace, truce, and like a­
greement betweene Princes or 
comminalties: f.

where all the ancient monumentes
are kept, the rolles.

Chacune, eche woman: f.

slit, a bedstead: m.

Chasse qu'on porte sus les espaules
és processions, a shrine: f.





I'ay gagné la Chasse, I haue gained
the chase at the tenise.

Chassebosse, vne herbe nommée
Corneole, aucunefos Soulcie a­
quatique, an hearbe called in La­
tin Acesis.

Chass-mal, a driuer away of all euils
as Hercules did.

Chasse-nuë, a driver away of cloudes,
as the Northwind.

Chasse-marée, m: a rippier.

Chasse-peine, as gold & wine, which 
doe driue away all paines and care.

Vne Chasse, a chase at tenise: f.

Chasser hors, ou arriére de soy, to
driue out, to cast out, to exclude.

Chassé & jecté hors, cast out.

Chasse, chase or hunting: f.

Chasser aux bestes sauvages, courir
aux Cerfs, to hunt wilde beasts, to
hunt the Stagge.

Chasseret, m: a little hunter.

Chastement, chastly.

Chasteau, a castle: m.

stise.

rection: m.

Chastré, gelded.

Ietter le Chataux jambes, to lay all
the faults vpon ones necke.

re precieuse enchassée, the broad

Le Coq chauche la poulle, the cocke

marmite, ou vne chaudiére, f: a

Chausse-cires, sealers of patents: m.

Chaussette, or Chausserette, a cha­
fer: f.

Chau-fournier, a lime kill: m.

Chauld, hote.

Vn fer Chaud, an yron glowing red.

Tenir Chaudement quelque chose,
& l'entretenir en sa chaleur, to 
keepe hote, or to maintaine a thing
in heate.

Chaut see Challoir.

Chaulde, as faire quelque chose à
la chaulde, f: to doe some thing in
a chafe or heate.

Conseil prins chaudement, counsell
taken vpon a sodaine.

Chaulme, strawe: f: the stemme of
corne: see Couvrir: f.

De la Chaulx, lime: f.

Chaulmer, to gather.

Chausser, to hose one.

Chaussure, hosing or shooing: f.

Chassée, levée d'vn estang, the
causey of a pond or riuer: f.

Chausse-pied, a shooing horne: m.

Des Chausses, hosen: f.

Chaussetier, an hosier: m.

Chaussions, little linnen sockes: m.

Chausse-trappe, a Caltrop for war,
made like tree yron prickes, so ioy­
ned, that being throwen, one al­
waies standeth vpright, also a trap
doore.

Vne herbe qu'on appelle Chausse­
trappe: c'est aussi vn fruit qu'on
appelle Chastaigne de riviére ou
truffes, ou saligots, a kind of fruite
growing in riuers or still waters af­
ter the sort of a caltrop with three
pikes: after it is sode in water it ea­
teth like a Chestnut.

Chauve par devant, baldheaded.

Chauveté, baldnesse: f.

Chauve-souris, a Backe, some calle it
a Bat: Flitter-mouse, or Rere­
mouse: f.

Cheau, or Chuat, a whelpe: m.

Le Chef, the head: m.

Mettre à Chef quelque haulte en­
treprise, to bring some great enter­
prise to passe.

Venir à Chef de ses besongnes &
entreprises, to bring the worke &
enterprise to an end.

Faire vn Chef d'œuvre, to make a
principall piece of worke, to make a 
masters peece.

Chegros, a shoothred: m.

Chelidoine ou esclaire, or esclere, an
hearbe cealled Clarie.

Se Chemer, to take care, to waxe hea­
uie.

Chemin, a way, a path, a streete: m.

Chemin, ou rue, a way, or streete.

Cheminer,  to walke, to iourney, to goe.

Cheminée, a chimney: f.

Vne Chemise, a shirt: f.

Chemise de fame, a smocke: f.

Vne chemise de drap, or chemisol­
le, a wastcoate.

Chenall, a chanell: 

Pierres cavées en





façon de Chenaux, stones curued
hollow.

Chenets, ou Landiers, Andirons: m.

Chenevi, hempseede: m.

Chenevotte, the shailes or stalkes of
hempe: f.

Chenille, a worme with many feete
that eateth vines, also a snaile, a 
caterpiller: f.

Chenille de vigine, idem.

Chenil, or chenin, a kenell of dogs: m.

Chenu, horehaired, grayhaired: m.

Cheoir, je chais, je cheu, je suy cheu,
je cherray, to fall.

Cheant ou tombant, falling or de­
caying.

Cheu, fallen.

Cheute, a fall: f.

Cher & fort aimé, deare and welbe­
loued.

Vne chose chere, a deare thing.

Cherté, dearth: f.

Chercher, seeke cercher.

Chercuïter, seeke Chair.

Chere, Trongne, Mino, cheere, coun­
tenance: f.

Faire grand chere, to make good
cheere to be merie.

Cherir, je cheris, je chery, j'ay chery,
je cheriray, to cheare, to welcome
one.

Des Chervis, a roote called Skir­
wike: m.

Chervis savages, wild Skirwike.

Vn Chesne, an Oke: m.

Chestif, or chetif, wretched, poore, mi­
serable.

Chetive, a she wretch miserable.

Vn Cheval, a horse: m.

Medecin à Chevaux, a horseleach.

Chevaucher, to ride.

Vn Chevaucheur, a rider: m.

Chevauchement, riding: m.

Chevauchées, riding, or trauailing on
horsebacke: f.

Chevauchon, as passer vne eaue à
chevauchon sur vn bois, to passe o­
uer a water on a peece of wood.

Chevalerie, Knighthood, cheualrie: f.

Vn Chevalet, a little horse: also a
parke, or a viol, harpe, or other in­
strument, of musike: m.

Chevaler aucun, to dog one.

Chevalier, ou homme d'armes, a
Knight, or man at armes: m.

Chevalier de l'ordre, a Knight of the 
Order.

Faire Chevalier, or donner l'accolée,
 to dubbe a Knight, to make one a
Knight.

La Chevance d'aucun, riches, goods,
or substance: f.

Vne Cheveche, a shrich Owle: f.

Chevestre, m: an halter.

Cheveul, ou poil, ou perruque, a
haire: m.

Chevelu, hairie, rough with haires: m.

Comette cheveluë a hairie Comet: f.

Chevelure, the hairebush: f.

Chevet, ou traversin d'vn lict, a bol­
ster: m.

Chevetain, a leader, a captaine: m.

Cheville, a peg, a woodden pinne: f.

Cheviller, to pinne with pins of wood.

Chevilles des pieds, the ankle bone.

Chevir avec aucun, to make an ende
with one.

Chevir, je chevis, je chevy, j'ay che­





vy, je cheviray, to bring any thing
to passe.

Ie n'ay sceu Chevir de c'est home
revesché, cheval farouche, I was
not able to bring that stiffenecked
man to any reason, to tame that
wild horse.

I'en Cheviray bien, I will bring him 
to reason.

Chevissance, the order and composi­
tion taken betweene the Creditor
and Debitor: f.

Vne Chevre, a she Goate: f.

Chevreau, a Kid: m.

Chevrette, a little Goate: f: also a 
fish called a shrimpe.

Vn Chevreul, m: a wilde Goate: I
suppose to bee your fallowe Deere
roe.

Chevreter, to bring forth Kids.

Chevre-pied, m: a Satyr.

Esguillettes de Chevrotin, Cheue­
rell poynts: m.

Vn Chevron, a Chevron, a giest, a 
rafter in the house that beareth vp
the roofe: m.

Cheut, fell, it commeth from Cheoir.

Chez moi, with me at my house.

De Chez moy, from me.

Chicaneus, chicaneur, or chicanous,
 a petifogger: m.

Chicanerie, petifogging: f.

Chicaner, to wrangle, to play the pe­
tifoggers tricke.

Chiche, a niggard, a pinch peny.

Chichement, niggardly.

Chicheté, niggardlinesse: f.

Chiches, a kind of pulse, cich pease: m.

Chicotin, an hearbe very bitter, by
some called Orpine: m.

Chichorée, an hearbe called Sucko­
rie, seeke Cichorée.

Vn Chien: m: ou vne chienne, f: a 
dogge or bitch.

Vn Chuat, a whelpe.

Chienner, or chienneter, to whelpe.

Chier, to goe to the stoole, or doe our
ease, to shite.

Vn Chiard, m: a shiting one.

Vn  Chigro, m: shoomakers waxe.

Chiliarque, the Captaine or head of 
a thousand men: m.

Avoir le Chifre d'un prince pour
entendre ses secrets, to haue the
bill, scrole, or memorandum of a
Prince, to know his secrets.

Chifrer, to cipher.

Chimere, a darke or subtile imagina­
tion: f.

Chirotonie, the order to allow or dis­
allow a Magistrate or officer, by
the lifting vp of the handes and
voyce: f.

Chirurgien, a Surgeon: m.

Le Choc de gents de guerre, a shock
or brunt of warriours: m.

Chocquer, to strike or knocke togi­
ther: to slay.

S'entrechoquer, to knocke one ano­
ther, or among themselues, to prease
one vpon another.

La chiorme de la galere ou sont les
forsats, the place of the Gallie where
the slaues doe rowe: f.

Chiquenaude, a fillip: f.

Chiquenauder, to fillip.

Chiqueter, to cut, as a doublet is cut,
vn pourpoint chiqueté.





Chiqueture, or déchiqueture, a cut­
ting: f: a gash, a cut.

Choëur, as les religieux sont assem­
blez en leur Choëur, the Monkes 
are gathered togither in their quire
or priuate place of prayers: or ve­
strie: m.

Chois, choise: m.

Choisir, he choisis, he choisis, j'ay
choisi, je choisiray, to chuse.

Cholere, choler, anger: f.

Il est en sa Chole, he is in his choler.

Cholerique, cholerike, angrie, testie.

Chommer, to tarie for, to make holy­
day for lacke of worke.

Dieu a commandé à son peuple sur
peine de mort, le septiesme jour
estre chommé & sanctifié, GOD
hath commanded to his people vpon
paine of death, that the seuenth day
should be ceased and sanctified, that
is, one should cease from his worke.

Chomable, com: daye or time of
rest.

Choper, to stumble, to offend.

Vne Chopine, a measure contayning
about a pint: f.

Chopiner, to quaffe.

Chocquer, to shocke, to cope, to fight.

Choc, coping, fighting: m.

Chordé, seeke Corde.

Chose, a thing: f.

Chosette, a little thing.

Faire la Chosette, to do a thing which
I dare not say, name or tell.

Des Choux, coleworts: m.

Choux cabus, cabiges.

Chou pour Chou, like for like.

Chouëtte, an Howlet: f.

Chouquet, a blocke: m.

Choyer ou contregarder, to spare.

dome: f.

ken.

le Ciel, the heauens, the skie, some­

desoubs & dessus en les clignant,

Clef, a key: f.

Apporte moy la clef de mon cofre, 
 bring thou vnto me the key of my
coffer.

Les Clefz de l'Eglize, the keyes of
the Church.

On apporta au Roy les Clefs de la
ville, they brought the King the
keyes of the towne.

Lon a contrefait les Clefs, they made
false kayes.

La Clef ou piece du milien, au quel
s'assemblent toutes les courbes
d'une voulte, a scutchen in the
middest of the vaute, where all the
course of the carued stones or tim­
ber doth resort.

Clemence, f: gentlenes.

Cler, cleere.

Cler, manifeste & évident, de quoy
on n'a point de doubte, cleare,
manifest, euident.

Clerement, cleerely, openly, mani­
festly.

clarifie.

Il est bon Clerc, he is learned, he is
a good clarke

Il est né coiffé, hee is borne rich and

Cognoistre, to know, to perceiue, to
discerne, to vnderstand: je cognoy,
je cogneu, je cognoystray: cog­
noistre pertayneth to the eyes, and
Sçavoir, to the minde.

Cailler ou donner à cognoistre & à
entendre manifestement, to giue
to vnderstand, to declare.

Cognoistre parfaictement ou vraye­
ment vne chose d'entre vne autre,
 to know one thing from another.

Cognoissant, knowledging, vnder­
standing.

Cogneu, knowne.

La chose est sceuë & cogneuë, that
which is knowne and come to light.

Collateralle, for the feminine.

Collation & taille, a ioyning toge­

one with another.

Collationné à l'original, conferred 
with the originall, that is, with the

Collaudation, a praysing: f.

Colle, glew, paste: f.

Colle de bouche, mouth-glew.

Vu Colleur, m: a glewer.

Coller, to glew.

Collement, a glewing, or coupling to­
gether: m.

La collée, as donner la collée, to make
one knight: f.

Collection, a collection, a gathering
together: f.

Collectif, as commander à la plus
grande partie ou nombre en nom
collectif, & à chacun en particu­
lier, to commaund to the greater
number altogether, and to each one
particularly.

College, a colledge: m.

Collerettere de fame, a night-kert­
chef: f.

Colline, a little hill: f.

Colloquer, to place together.

Colluder, & faire semblant de plai­
der contre aucun, & neantmoins
s'entendre avec luy, to make sem­





blant to doe a thing, and do cleane
contrarie.

Collusion, collusion, couen, sometime
deceite: f.

Colomb, a Pigeon: m.

Vne Colombe, a Doue: f.

Colombelle, idem.

Vne Colomne, f: a pillar.

Vn colombier, a Doue-cote: m.

Colonnel d'vne armée, the generall
or Captaine of an army: m.

Colonie, is a number of citizens sent
to dwell to some other place or
towne: f.

Colosse, m: an huge image made for
the honor of any person.

Colostre, m: the first milke called of
some beestings.

Coloquinte, ou courge sauvage,
 Colloquintida: f.

Colporter, porter sur le col, to carrie
a coarse to buriall, because he is ca­
ried aboue ones neck.

Le combat, m: ou bataille, f: ou
debat, m: the combat or battaile,
the strife.

Presenter ou donner le combat, to
bid the combat.

Combatte & batailler, to fight togi­
ther, to battaile.

Combatre en quelque maniere que
ce soit, to fight.

Vne combe, a valley betweene two
mountaines: f.

Combien que, although that.

Combien estes vous? how many are ye?

Combien de fois? how often?

Combien penses tu avoir tost faict?
 how soon thinkst thou to haue done?

Combien y a il? how long is it a­
gone?

Comble, a heape: m.

Le comble, ce qui est adjousté oul­
tre la juste mesure, aboundance, or
that which is more then the iust
measure, sometime fulnesse.

Combler, to fill full, to ouer-heape.

Comblé d'ennui, heaped or filled with
heauinesse.

Comblement, m: a heaping.

Combourgeoisie, when two diuers
townes are citizens, and free one of
the other: f.

Combustion, f: burning.

Combustible, easie to be burned, fu­
ell: com.

Il n'est pas combustible, it is not fuell.

Comedie & farce, a comedy, a play,
an enterlude:

Comete ou estoile cheveluë, a Co­
met or blazing starre: f.

Comin, vne sorte d'herbe, Comin an
hearbe: m.

Comique, a plaier of comedies: m.

Comestible, com: which may be ea­
ten, eatable.

A Dieu vous Command, I commit
you to God.

Commander & ordonner, to com­
maund, to appoint, to establish,

Commander de faire, to commaund,
to enioyne.

Commandé & publié, commanded
proclaimed.

Commandement, m: & ordon­
nance, f: a commandement, an or­
dinance.

Command as a dieu vous command,





 farewell: m.

Tous mes biens sont à vostre com­
mand, all my goods be at your com­
maundement.

Comme, euen as.

Comme j'espére, as I hope.

Comme on dit, as men say, as it is
reported.

Comme si je y eusse estë, euen as or
though I had beene there.

Comme s'il estoict faict, as if it were
done.

Commémorer, to mention or speake
of.

Commémorable, a thing worthie to
be remembred, to be spoken of: com.

Commemoration, a remembrance: f.

Commencer à faire quelque cho­
se, to begin a thing, to take a thing
in hand.

Commencé, begun.

Commençant, beginning.

Commencement, a beginning: m.

Les commendaces, f: the verses or
orations made to the praise of any
deceased, also praiers for the dead.

Commendataire, an officer in the
Popes Court: m.

Commensal, qui voit & menge or­
dinairement avec nous, a dayly
companion at table, a soiourner: m.

Il a beaucoup de Commensauls, he 
hath many boorders.

Commensalité, f: the companie or
association of boorders, or that doe
eate together.

Comment, or vn Commentaire, m:
 a commentarie or exposition.

Commment? how?

Comment cela? how so?

Comment te portes tu? how dooest
thou? how farest thou?

Commerce, traffick.

Il est dangereux quand en vne re­
publique les estats et offices tom­
bent en commerce, it is dangerous
when in a common-wealth the offices
are bought and sold.

Commere, Commerage, seeke
Comperage.

Commettre, je commets, je commy
j'ay commis, je commettray, quel­
que chose à aucun, le commette
sus quelque affaire, to commit a 
businesse to one.

Commettre quelque vilain ou mes­
chants cas, to commit a wicked crime.

Commination, threatening: f.

Parolles Comminatoires, threat­
nings words, speech full of threat­
ning.

Commis sus quelque affaire, appoin­
ted to some businesse.

Comminuër et mettre en petites
pieces, to breake or put in peeces.

Droit de commise, the right which
the Lord hath vpon his subiect
through felonie, disauowing his
Lord, or lye giuen vnto the same: f.

Commission, a commission: f.

Le Commissaire donné parle Ma­
gistrat pour cognoistre & juger
d'vne cause, a Commissioner ap­
pointed by the Magistrate to heare
and iudge a matter: m.

Donner commissaire, to appoint a 
Commissioner.

Commistion, a mixing or mingling: f.





Commiseration, f: as Il est digne
De Commiseration, he is worthie to
be pittied of compassion.

Lettres de Committimus, speciall
letters pattents of the Prince to a
Iudge, to heare and decide a matter.

Commode, apt, fit, conuenient.

Commodement, commodiously.

Commodité, commoditie, profite: f.

Commovoir, to moue, f: see mou­
voir, for the declining.

Commuër, to change.

Commutation, f: exchange.

Commune, common, vulgar, also the 
whole communaltie, the rascall peo­
ple: f.

Commun & appartenant à tous,
 common to all.

Vn commun dict du temps passé, a
common saying of olde time.

La commune, the common people: f.

Communauté, the Comminaltie: f.

Communion, communion, a fellow­
ship or knitting togither: f.

Communiquer, to communicate, to
make partaker, to conferre.

Communication, f: a communica­
tion.

Communicatif, easie to be spoken to,
as Cest vn roy, vn home, vne fame
fort communicative, she is a wo­
man easie to be spoken to.

Compaignon à apprendre, ou d'ap­
prentissage, a schoolefellowe, or fel­
low in house: m.

Compaignon de table, a table fel­
low.

Compaignon à cheminer, a wal­
king mate.

Compaignon de table à boire & à
manger, & à jouër, a companion
both at meat and at play.

Compaignon en tous labeurs &
peines, a fellow in all troubles.

Elle est ma bonne Compaigne, she is
my fellowe.

Cest vne bonne Compaigne, she is 
a good companion, a good merrie
wench: f.

Compaignie, compannie, fellowship, a 
company of souldiers.

Compaignable, one whose companie
is easie to be gotten, which lightly
will be found in honest company: com.

Il n'est nullement Compagnable,
 one cannot get him in company.

Se comparer à vn autre, to compare,
to liken.

Comparaison, a comparison, a like­
ning.

Comparer vne faulte, et payer bien
cher, to punish a fault.

Comparoir, je comparoy, je com­
paru, j'ay comparu, je comparoi­
stray au iour de la monstre, to ap­
peare at the muster day.

Comparoistre en jugement, to ap­
peare to iudgement.

Ne comparoistre point au jour de
l'assignation donné par devant le
Magistrat, not to appeare at the day
appointed by the Magistrate.

Comparoistre vne faulte, to pay deer­
ly for a fault.

Compartir, to deuide.

Compas, a compasse: m.

Compasser, to compasse.

Compassion, compassion, pitie, mer­





cie: f.

Compatible, which can abide, or a­
gree togither: com.

Ne se pouvoir compatir, that can
not abide one another.

Compatir l'vn avec l'autre, to beare
one with another, to suffer togither:
je compattis, je compaty, j'ay com­
paty, je compatiray.

Compenser, to recompence, to make
amende.

Compensé, recompenced.

Comperage, m: & commerage: f.
 the first acquaintance and fellowship
which gossips doe take in christening
of a childe, gossipship.

Compere, a gossip: m.

Commere, a she gossip: f.

Aller Commerer, to goe a gossipping.

Faire cher comperre l'offence, to pay
for the offence deerely.

Competer & appertenir, to belong
or appertaine.

Cela me Compete et appertient,
 the same doth appertaine vnto me.

Competiteur, a suter for a thing that
another sueth for: m.

Se complaindre, to complaine, to finde
him selfe agreeued: see Plaindre
for the declining.

Se complaindre à son amy, to com­
plaine to his friend.

Complainte, a complaint or moane­
making, or bewailing: f.

Complainte qu'on fait à auncun, d'­
vn autre, a complaint of an other, a 
telltale.

Complaire, je play, je pleu, j'ay pleu
je plairay, to please, to like.

Vn complant, a yong vineyard: m.

La complexion d'aucun, the com­
plexion, the nature or disposition of
one: f.

Mal complexionné, euill mannered, 
of euill behauiour.

Complice, a companion in wicked­
nesse: m.

Il est d'aage convenable & Compe­
tent, he is of a sufficient age.

Iuge Competent, a sufficient, conue­
nient or competent Iudge.

Competence, f: sufficiencie.

Competemment, sufficiently.

Compisser, to bepisse all things.

Complor: m: & intelligence: f:
qu'on a l'vn avec l'autre, agree­
ment, intelligence, conspiracie.

Accord & complot faict entre plu­
sieur, agreement betweene many,
confederacie: m.

Par complot, vpon agreement.

Comporter, to suffer, to maintaine
himselfe in state.

Se bien Comporter, to behaue him­
selfe honestly.

Comportement, a behauiour: m.

Composer quelque livre, to make a
booke.

Composer & escrire des vers, to
make verses.

Composer avec aucun, to compound
with one.

Composé & fact de deux natures,
 compound and made of two natures.

La Composition de quelque livre,
 the making of my booke: f.

Composition & confection, a com­
pound, a confection.





Composition & accord, a composi­
tion and agreement.

Compositeurs, or Composeurs en
musique ou imprimerie, m: com­
positors in musicke or printing.

Comprendre, to comprehend, to per­
ceiue, to compasse, to vnderstand: see
Prendre, for the declining.

Estre comprins au nombre des bien 
heureux, to bee comprised in the 
number of the happie.

Compromettre & se rapportter au
jugement de quelque arbitre sus
quelque different, to put the diffe­
rence in arbitrement.

Compromis, put in arbitrement: m.

Compter, to compt, to reckon, to num­
ber.

Tout comptant, readie told.

Vn compte, a compte, a reckoning, a
tale: m.

Compte & payement, a reckoning, a 
payment.

Abbreger son compte, to cut off his
reckoning, to make the matter short

Qui tient le compte, that keepeth the 
reckoning.

Dresseur de compte, an accompt ca­
ster.

Compteur, a reckoner: m.

Comptoir & table où anciennement
les argentiers comptoyent, a coun­
ter or table to cast accompt on: m.

Comptable, he which must giue or
make his accompt: com.

Comptement, a telling: m.

Compunction: f: ou remors: m: de
conscience, a remorse of conscience.

Conceder, to graunt.

Cela concerne l'vtilité publique,
 that concerneth the publique weale.

Concevoir en son esprit, to conceiue
with himselfe: je conçois, je con­
ceu, j'ay conceu, je concevray.

Ce qui est conceu, that which is con­
ceiued.

Conception, a conceite: f.

La conception de nostre entende­
ment, the sense, feeling, or percei­
uing.

Mon Conchambrier ou compag­
non de chambre, my chamber fel­
low: m.

Se Conchier, to beshite himselfe.

Vn concierge, to warden, a porter: m.

Conciergerie, a Warde, a Prison: f.

Concile, the Councell: m.

Concilier, to make friends one with
another, to reconcile.

Conciliation & vnion, reconcilia­
tion and vnitie: f.

Conciliateur, m: a reconciler: he that
maketh peace and agreement be­
tweene men at variance.

Conciliatrice, f: the woman taking
such charge vpon her.

Concion & assemblée, an assem­
blie: f.

Concitation & esmeute de peuple,
 a commotion of people, a rebellion: f.

Conciter & esmouvoir le peuple, to
moue the people to rebellion.

Concitateur & esmouveur de menu
peuple, the stirrer of the common
people.

Coaclave, m: an inner parlour: the
secret chamber where the Cardi­
nals doe meete to chuse the Pope.





Concitoyen, a fellow Citizen: m.

Conclure, je conclus, je conclu, j'ay
conclu, je concluray, to conclude.

Conclusion, a conclusion: f.

Faire bonne concoction, to make
good digestion: f.

Vn Concombre, a Cowcumber: m.

Concorde, concorde, agreement: f.

Vn Concordat, an agreement: m.

Concréer, as deux petites pelicules
se concréent, two small skinnes are
ingendred.

Concubine, a concubine: f.

Concubinage, a concubinage, the
keeping of a concubine: m.

Enfans Concubinaires, children
borne of a concubine: m.

Conculquer, or Conculcer, to tread
vnder the feete.

Conculcation, f: treading vnder the
feete.

Concupiscence, concupiscence, fer­
uent desire or appetite: f.

Concurrence, a running togither, or
agreement, when many chances run
togither, whereby we iudge the mat­
ter to be true: f.

Concussion, estre accusé de con­
cussions & deniers mal prins du­
rant le temps de son magistrat, to
be accused of extortion, and money
vniustly taken while he was a Ma­
gistrate: f.

Concussionaire, he which vseth ex­
tortion: m.

Condemner, to damne, to condemne.

Condemnation, a condemnation: f.

cing or putting to fine.

Sentence condemnatoire, or Con­
damnatoire, à l'amende, a sentence
condemning to a fine.

Condescendre & s'accorder à quel­
que chose, to condescend or agree
to a thing.

Condigne, worthie: com.

Condignement, worthily.

Condition, a condition, a couenant: f.

De Basse condition, of a base stocke.

Soubs & partelle condition, on this
condition.

Conditions d'vn homme bonnes &
mauvaises, the conditions or quali­
ties of a good or euill man.

Conditionellement, conditionally,
vnder a condition.

Conditionel, m: vnder a condition.

Condoloir, to moane with another.

Conduire, to conduct, to gouerne, to
leade, to traine: je conduis, je con­
dui, j'ay conduit, je conduiray.

Conduit à mener l'eauë en quel­
que lieu, a Conduite.

Conduite, leading, trayning, conduc­
ting: f.

Conducteur de la dance, the leader
of the daunce: m.

Tu es le conducteur de cest affaire,
 thou art the master of all this mis­
chiefe, or this worke.

Conductrice, she leader: f.

Condyle, the roundnesse or knots
in the knee, anckle, elbowe, and
knuckles: m.

Confederez, that are ioyned togither
in a conspiracie: m: confederate.

Confederation, a confederacie, or
conspiracie: f.





Confiction ou confiture, a confic­
tion, or confiting: f."confiction" not found in the OED except in this quotation under "confit," v.

Conferer ensemble, to conferre to­
gither.

Ie Confereray & bailleray avec vous,
 I will disburse, pay, beare the char­
ges with you.

Confermer, to confirme, to establish,
to auouch.

Confermer son opinion, to confirme
his opinion.

Confirmé, confirmed, sealed, or rati­
fied.

Confirmation, a confirmation, an e­
stablishing: f, bishopping.

Confesser, to confesse, to acknowledge.

Confesser franchement &  sans con­
trainte, to confesse freely, & with­
out constraint.

On Confesse bien qu'il est vray, it is
confessed to be true.

Confession, confession: f.

Par la Confession d'vn chascun, ilz
sont deshonnestes, they are vnho­
nest by the confession of all men.

Confession auriculaire, the confession
at the eare of the Priest: shriuing.

Docteurs Confessionnaires, Doc­
tors setting forth the forme to con­
fesse sinnes when one is shriued

Aller à confesse, to goe to shriuing: f.

Confesseur, he that heareth anothers
confession: m: our ghostly father.

Se confier, to trust, to put confidence
in.

Confiance & asseurance, confidence
and assurance: f.

Confiner aulcun en quelque lieu &
le bannir, to limite one within cer­
taine bounds.

Confiner, to assigne bounds and li­
mites in field and countrey: also to
leade and end his life in a place.

Se Confiner en vn desert, to ende his
life in a desert.

Confire, to confite, to drie, to wane for
sorowe: je confis, je confi, j'ay
confit, je confiray.

Confit ene amertume, soaked in bit­
ternesse.

Confiture, confiting: f.

Confitures, or draggées, confites: f.

Qui fait & vend Confitures, a Con­
fite maker.

Confisquer les biens d'aucun, to con­
fiscate ones goods, to sease or forfeite
them vnto the Prince.

Confiscation, ou biens confisquez,
& publication des biens d'auncun,
ou de plusieurs, a confiscation: f.

Seigneur Confiscataire, the Lord
which hath obtained the confisca­
tion of anothers Lordship: m.

Conflagration, a consuming with fire,
a burning: f.

Vn conflant, où deux rivieres s'as­
semblent, a place where two riuers 
meete together: m.

Conflict & combat, a conflict or com­
bat: m.

Confondre, mesler ensemble, &
brouiller, to confound, to mingle, to
tumble together: je confons, je
confondi, j'ay confondu, je con­
fondray.

Se conformer & accorder à aucun,
 to conforme him selfe or to become
agreeable to another.





Conformité, f: a conformitie.

Conformément, accordingly.

Confort, comfort, solace, encoura­
ging: m.

Conforter, & confermer les gents
de guerre, to comfort and encou­
rage warriours.

Confrairie, a fraternitie, a brother­
hood, a fellowship, the companie of a­
ny Hall: f.

Confreres, the fellowes of that fellow­
ship: m.

Confronter l'vn à l'autre, pour en
voir la comparaison, to compare
one by another, to see the difference.

Confronter tesmoins, to set witnesses
together.

Recolement & Confrontation de
tesmoins, when witnesses newly ex­
amined are set face to face to trie
their deposition.

Confus qui n'est point divis­
ne se­
paré, confused not distinct.

Estre confus, to be confused or ama­
zed.

Confusément, confusedly, indistinctly.

Confusion & trouble, ou desordre
de toutes choses, confusion, trouble
or disorder in all things: f.

Confuter, to confute.

Congé, leaue, licence, permission,
graunt: m.

Sans mon Congé, without my leaue.

Congedier vne armée, to breake vp
an armie, to giue leaue to returne.

Congeler, to congeale.

Congelation, a congealing or free­
zing: f.

Conglutiner & joindre ensemble, to
glew and ioyne together.

Conglutination, f: a glewing & ioy­
ning together.

Congnoistre, seeke Cognoistre.

Congratuler, to testifie by words the
ioy which one hath for the prosperi­
tie of another.

Congratulation, f: a reioycing with
one for his good fortune.

Congréer, to congeale.

Laict Congrée & caillé, curded
milke: m.

Congre, poisson, a Conger: m.

Il se Congrége en pierre precieuse,
 it groweth to a pretious stone.

Congréger, to gather togither.

Congregation, an assemblie: f.

Conjecturer, to coniecture.

Conjecture, a coniecture.

Conjoindre, to ioyne together, to glew
together, to paste together, to fasten:
see joindre for the decl.

Conjoinct, ioyned together.

Conjunction, a ioyning together, a
coniunction: f.

Conjoinctement, ioyntly, wholly.

Se Conjouïr du bien d'autruy, to be
glad of another mans good successe.

Conjouïssement, m: a reioycing to­
gether.

Amour Conjugalle, the loue between
a man and his wife: f: some do take
this word in the masculine gender,
and some in the feminine.

Conjurer & adjurer aucun le prier
pour l'amitié, ou autres choses, to
entreate one of all friendship to vt­
ter some thing.

Conjurer, Iurer ensemble pour mal





faire à aucun, Faire conspiration,
 to conspire.

Connestablie, a Constableship: f.

 a knitting or ioyning together.

Vn connin, ou connil, a Cunnie, a
Rabbet: m.

Vne Conniniere, f: a Cunnigrie.

cunnie.

Conquester, or conquerir, to con­
quer, to win.

Conquereur, or Conquerant, a Con­
querour: m.

Ville Conquerable, a towne which
may be conquered.

Conquis vaincu & gagné, conque­
red, ouercommed, gotten.

Conquester, to ioyne to his dominion.

Il s'est Conquesté & acquis gloire
& credit, he hath gotten to himselfe
honour and credite.

Il a fait vne belle Conqueste, he hath
made or done a faire conquest.

Conquest & acquest, m: the pur­
chase which a man purchaseth with 
his owne money.

Conroyer du bois, to chippe wood: to
square.

Conroyer du cuir, to currie leather.

Conroyeur, a Currier: m.

to hallow.

hallowed.

 to make conscience of a matter, to
stick at a matter.

Conscientieusement, done in good
conscience.

Consultative, see in Deliberative.

Consulter, to consult, to take aduise.

Consequemment, consequently, by
the sequell.

Chose grave & de consequence, a

Conserve de Roses, conserue of Ro­
ses: f.

Considerer quelque chose, to con­
sider, to weigh, to ponder.

Consideration, consideration, mar­
king, pondering: f.

Considerable, to be considered, com.

Consigner, to appoynt, to exhibite,
to present.

Consigner argent, to disburse money,
to lay a wager who shall haue the
vperhand in the law.

Consignation, such disbursing of mo­
ney: f.

Consister, to consist, or to be.

Cecy consiste à chercher la verité,
 this consisteth in searching the
trueth.

Consistoire, the Consistorie: m.

Consoler, to comfort, to cherish, to
solace, to cheare.

Consolation, consolation or com­
fort: f.

Consolateur, a comforter: m.

Consolider vne playe, to strengthen
or ioyne together a wound.

Consolidation, f: a strengthening.

Consommer & parfaire, to make
perfect, to ende, to fulfill.

Consoner, as sa parolle consone &
s'accorde à sa vie, his worde and
his life doe agree well together.

Consors, those whose lands doe ioyne
together: fellowes as man & wife.

Monsieur, recommendez moy à
madmoiselle votre consorte, Sir,
haue me recommended to the gen­
tlewoman your bed-fellow: f.

Consors & complices, fellowes in
wickednesse.

Conspirer & estre de commun ac­
cord, se venir allier ensemble
pour faire quelque chose, soit
bonne ou mauvaise, to conspire, to
consent, to agree.

Conspiration, a conspiracie: f.

Constant, constant, firme, stable,
setled.

Estre constant, to be constant.

Constance, constancy, perseuerance,
settlednesse: f.

Constamment, constantly.

Constellation & assemblée d'estoi­
les ensembe en quelque signe, a
gathering together of starres into
some signe: f.

Constituer aucun consul sus le peu­
ple, to choose or appoynt Consull o­
uer the people.

Constitu, arrest & determinance
de quelque chose, laquelle apres
avoir esté disceptée debatué est
mise à fin, a constitution, an ordi­
nance: m.

Rente constituée, reuenew, liuing, or
money put to vse.

La Rente constituée, & sonsiere dif­
ferent beaucoup, car celle là s'en vn
en fumée, & cestecy demeure, re­
uenew or liuing rising by money,
and by land, doe differ much, for
that vanisheth away like smoke, and
this remaineth fast.

Des la constitution du monde, euen
from the foundation of the world: f.

Selon les Constitutions & ordenan­
ces de la ville, according to the
lawes of the towne.

Constituëur de loy, m: a law-maker.





Construit & basti, builded.

Construction, f: a building, a constru­
ction or exposition in writing, or
words.

Construire, to build, to construe a 
text, to expound.

Consulter, seeke Conseil.

Consumer, to consume, to waste, to
weare away.

Consumption, a consumption: f.

Consuivre & atteindre, to follow, to
ouertake, to get, to obtaine.

Contagieux, as fievre contagieuse,
 a contagious ague.

Contaminer, to spot, to stayne, to de­
file, to corrupt.

Conte, an Earle: m.

Contesse, a Countesse: f.

Vn conte, a tale: m.

Vn conte, devis & propos, soit vray
ou faux qu'on fait à plaisir, a fa­
ble: m.

Contes de choses veritables, a sto­
rie.

Conter, to tell.

Vn conteur de contes, fables & sor­
nettes, a tale-teller: m.

Contemner, to despise, to disdaine,
to neglect.

Contemnement, a contempt or dis­
daine: m.

Contemneur, m: a despiser.

Contempler, to view, to beholde.

Comtemplement quand on pense
soigneusement à vne chose, to muse
on a matter: m.

Contemplation, f: deep consideration.

Contemplatif, m: hee that museth
vpon heauenly things.

Contemporains, borne at one time
of equall age.

Contenir & comprendre, to contain,
to comprehend.

Contenir & garder de faire oultre,
 to restrayne, to with-holde.

Se contenir & moderer, to forbeare,
to moderate.

Contenu, contayned.

Vn home continent, m: a chaste
man.

Cela contient peu, that holdeth or
conteineth but a little.

Continence, continence: f.

La contenance, the gesture, counte­
nance, or behauiour: f.

Contendre & debatre, to striue.

Contention, f: & estrif, m: a strife.

Contentieux, m: full of strife.

Disputer contentieusement, dis­
pute with contention.

Contenir, conprendre, to holde & 
keepe in, to containe.

Les Annales & Chroniques d'An­
gleterre Contiennent plusieurs
aultres choses: the Chronicles of
England doe contayne many other 
things.

Content, content, well pleased.

Estre content de ce qu'on a, to bee
content with that one hath.

Ie suy content, I am content.

I'en suy content, I am content of
it.

Mal-content, not content, displea­
sed, offended, euill contented.

Contenter aucun, to please or satis­
fie one.





Contentement de peu & abstinen­
ce de voluptez, to be content with
a little: m.

Pendre contentement, to delight in.

Contester la cause sus quelque dif­
ferent, to make protestation of suite
before the Iudge.

Ah Paillard vous contestez encores,
 what knaue, you prattle, you striue
yet, you find fault.

Par vn contexte, Tout d'vn train
sans rien mesler, continually, to­
gether, without interruption.

Contigu, adioyning, touching one an­
other.

Continence, seeke contenir.

Continu & entier, continuall, for e­
uer, whole.

Continu à faire quelque chose com­
me s'il estoit tousjours soubs le
joug, the continuance of a thing.

Continuër, to continue, to goe forward,
to last.

Continuël, continuall.

Continuëllement, continually.

Continuëttion, a continuing: f.

Contour, as estendre vne armée sur
le contour de la ville, to place an
armie vpon the soyle or compasse
round about the towne.

Contract, a contract, a couenant, a
bargaine: m.

Contracts & conventions redigées
par escript, an agreement or coue­
nant put in writing.

Contracter, to contract, to bargaine,
to agree.

Contraction de nerfz, a convulsion or
shrinking of the sinews: the cramp: f.

Contradiction, a gaynsaying: f.

Contraindre aucun, to constraine, to
enforce, to compell: je contrains, je
contrain, j'ay contraint, je con­
traindray.

Estre constrainct, to be constrayned.

Estre constrainct par necessité,
 to bee constrayned or driuen by ne­
cessitie.

Contrainct, a constraint.

Sans constrainct, without constraint,
freely, willingly: f.

Contraire & nuisant, contrary, hurt­
full.

Au contraire, contrariwise.

Contrarieté, contrarietie, difference: f.

Contrarier à aulcun, to withstand one.

Contravention, disobedience: f.

Contre, agaynst.

Faire le contre, & seconder aucun
pour faire quelque finesse, to help
another to do subtilty, to be the second.

Contr'escarpe, to rampier to the wall,
a countermure: f.

Contrechanger, to change one for
another.

Contr'estre, to withstand.

Contre balancer, to counterpoise, to
esteeme otherwise.

Contrecarre, as faire contre-carre à
l'opinion d'aultruy, to contrary o­
ther mens opinion: to withstand an­
otherm.

Contre-cedule, the counterpane of a
writing: f.

Il me vient à cöntre-cueur, it goeth
against my minde, or my heart.

Contre-dire, to gaynsay, to murmure,
to withstand, to decline it as Dire.





Contre-disant, ou qul contredit
tousjours, a gaynsayer: m.

Contrée & pays, a Lande or Coun­
trey.

Contre-faire, to counterfeit, to
make like: see Faire to decline
it.

Contre-faire quelqu'vn, to counter­
feit a man.

Se contre-faire, to disguise himselfe.

Contre-faict, counterfeit.

Contre-garder, to keepe, to preserue.

Se Contre-garder, to keepe himselfe,
to spare himselfe, to looke to him­
selfe.

Contre-mander, to sende letters
or wordes contrarie to the first sent 
before.

Contremettre, to lay agaynst.

Contre-miner, to countermine.

A contre poil, against the wooll,
cleane contrary.

Contremont, vpward.

Pourpoint contre-pointé, a quilte
doublet.

Vn Contre-point, a counterpoynt, a
couering: f.

Contre-poids, a counterpease: m.

Contre-poison, a counterpoison: f.

Contre-porteur, a carrier about of
letters or other things.

Contrerolleur, a Comptroller: m.

Contre-ruse, a countersleight, or a
guile agaynst another guile: f."countersleight" antedates earliest OED citation (1611).

Tomber contre val, to fall downe­
warde.

En contrevenant, in withstand­
ing.

Contrevenir au droict, to with­
stand the right: decline it as Ve­
nir.

Contribuer, to contribute.

Contrister aucun, to make one sor­
rowfull.

Se Contrister, to be sorrowfull, to bee
carefull.

Controuversie, f: ou debat, m: contre­
uersie or strife.

Controuver, & feindre, to inuent
or faine.

Controver quelque chose en son
esprit, to imagine out of our owne
brayne.

Chose controvée, a thing fayned or
inuented: f.

Controuveur de mots ou menson­
ges, an inuenter of words or lies: m.

Controuveur de parolles & men­
teur, a fayner, a lyar.

Controuvement, m: & fiction, f: fai­
ning, lying.

Contumace, rebellion, stubbornnes: f.

Contumacer, to iudge one to haue
disobeyed his superiour in colledges
and like communalties.

Contumelie, f: & outrage, m: out­
ragiousnesse.

Convaincre, to conuince, to ouercome:
decline it as Vaincre.

Convalescence, health: f.

Convenir & s'assembler, to gather
together, to couple and wiue.

Convenir & apointer de quelque
affaire qui estoit en doubte, to a­
gree on things in controuersie.

Faire bien convenir, to make them
well agree.

Vien convenant, fit apte, handsome.





Convenant à quelque affaire, fit for
a thing.

Il convient, it behoueth, it is conue­
nient: a verbe impersonall, il con­
vient, il convint, il a convenu, il
conviendra.

Convenant, seemely, apt, fit.

Convenable, Propre ou sortable à
quelque chose, conuenient, apt,
meete for a thing.

Convenablement, conueniently.

Convenance, agreement, consent: f.

Convenancer, to promise, to make co­
uenant.

Convention, a bargaine, an agree­
ment: f.

Peines Conventionelles, penalties
agreed vpon: f.

Vn convent, a couent, a Cloister of
Monkes or Nunnes: m.

Conventicule, a little assemblie: m.

Vn convers, nouveau à la foy, a con­
uert, one new come to the faith: m.

Couverser, avec quelqu'vn, to be con­
uersant with one, to keepe company.

Conversation & familiarité, conuer­
sation and familiaritie: f.

Se convertir, to be conuerted, to turn,
je convertis, je converti, j'ay con­
verti, je convertiray.

Convertir inimitiez en amitiez, to
turne enmitie into freendship.

Se couvertir en liqueur, to be conuer­
ted into liquour.

Se Convertir en sel, to be conuerted
into salte.

Converti, conuerted: m.

Convertie, she conuerted.

Convier, Semondre à souper, to bid
to supper or dinner.

Convindrent, as apres que les filz de
Dieu convindrent avec les filles
des homes, after that the Sonne of
God came, ioyned or coupled.

Convoiter, to desire, to couet.

Convoitant, coueting, greedily desi­
ring: m.

Convoitise qu'on a tant de bonnes
choses, que de mauvaises, concu­
piscence, desire.

Convoler en secondes nopces, to
marrie for the second time.

Convoquer, to call togither.

Convoy, a following or waiting on:
m.

Convoy des obseques d'vn trespas­
sé, to follow the dead corpes, or to
bring him home.

Convoyer, to beare companie.

Convoyer aucun par honneur, to
beare one companie home.

Convultion, fretting of the guts,
seeke Contraction.

Cophin, ou panier d'osier, a bas­

Abondant & copieux en sçavoir de

 an ouer-measure, that which is gi­

Correctement, diligently, or without
fault.

Correction, a correction, an amen­
ding: f.

Correlaire, surplus, or surcroist, that
which is giuen beside the measure,
the ouerplus: m.

Correspondre, to answere when one
thing or matter answereth to an o­
ther.

Correspendence d'amité, a mutuall
loue, when one loueth and is loued
againe: f.

De la corrigole, autrement dicte
Sanguinaria, qui croit és mon­
taignes, waygrasse, knot grasse: f.

Wardes.

Bon Courage, good hope, cheereful­

Courageux & hardy, hardie, coura­
gious: m.

Courageusement, couragiouslie,
stoutly.

Couramment, vistement, prompte­
ment, sans faillir, runningly, swift­
ly, readily.

Courbes d'une voute, the middle of
a vault where all the corners of the 
same doe meete together.

Courbé, crooked.

Courber, Plier, Affaisser, to crooke, to
plye, to bend, to bowe.

Courbé, bowed, bended.

Courbement, bending, bowing: m.

Vne Courge, a Gourd, a Pompion: f.

Courdouännier, see Cordannier.

Vne Courge, a coulestaffe, a say­
slang.

Vne Courée de motion, f: a sheeps­
gather.

Courre, je cours, je couru, j'ay cou­
ru, je courray, courir, to run.

Courir les bestes sauvages & chas­
ser, to hunt wild beasts.

Courir quelque chose legiérement,
 to run ouer a thing sleightly.

Courant, running.

Coureur, a runner: m.

Coureurs & chevaucheurs d'escui­
rie, horse coursers, riders.

Courement ou course, a coursing, a
running: m.

Courement ça & là, a running hi­
ther and thither.

Saillir sans prendre sa Course, to
leape without fetching his feese or
race: f.

Prendre sa Course pour myeux faul­
ter, or faillir, to fetch his race or
feese to leape the better.

Cours, a course: m.

Course, a small Wagon, a course, a 
flight: f.

Couronne d'or, a crowne of gold: f.

Couronner, to crowne.

Courretier, or Courtier, a broker: m.

Courroye grande & longue, a lea­
therne thong: f.

Lier quelcun de Courroye, to blinde
one with thongs.

La courroye d'vn soulier, the latchet
of a shooe.

Courroucer fort aucun, to anger one,
to displease one.

Courroucé, angred, displeased.

Courroux, anger, wrath, stomack: m.

Coursaire de mer, a rouer, a pyrate,
a sea theefe: m.

Coursier, a horse to runne at the Tilt.

Coursey, or Courson, m: the stock
of a Vine: f.

Court, short.

Pour le faire court, to be short.

Tenir de court, to keepe one short.

Vn Courtault, a curtall: m.

Courtement, shortly.

Vne cour de maison, a court: f.

La Cour d'vne metairie, ou autre
grande maison, the court of a farme
or great house.

Vne cour souveraigne, the high
Court.

La cour du prince, the Princes court.

Faire la cour à fille ou fame, to court
a maiden or wife, to be a suter to
some bodie.

Vn Courtizan, a Courteour: m.





Vne Courtisanne, a Courtisane, a
whore: f.

Courtisanner, to play the Courtier.

Courtois, courteous, gentle, louing,
tractable, meeke: m.

Courtoisie, curtesie, gentlenesse: f.

Courtoisement, curteously.

Vn Courtier, & faiseur de messa­
ges, qui va & vient à la poste &
volunté d'autruy, a currier, a mes­
senger: m.

Vn Courretier, or couratier de quel­
que chose que ce soit, qui moy­
enne & va & vien d'vne partie à 
l'autre pour faire quelque mar­
ché, a curretter, a broaker, a can­
uasser: m."canvasser" antedates earliest OED citation (1599).

Courretier de chevaux, a horse coar­
ser.

Courvée, ou Corvée, a quiting of
gentlenesse, a thanking, a dayes
worke due by the subiect vnto his
Lord: f.

Vn Courtil, a garden, a back-yard: m.

Courtine, a curtaine, a vayle: f.

Deux cousins gemains fils de 
deux freres, ou de deux sœurs, co­
sine germaines: m.

Vn coussin ou coussinet, a cushin: m.

Coust, cost, charge: m.

Il Couste la moitié moins, it cost
half lesse.

Qui Couste beaucoup, that costeth
much, deare.

Costageux, a costly thing.

Coustange, cost: m.

Costeau: m: ou espée: f: a knife or
a sword.

Coustelet, a little knife: m.

Coustillier ou escuyer, an esquire, the 
armour bearer: m.

Vne Coustume ou maniére de faire
qu'on a: a custome or maner: f.

Les Coustumes particulieres de 
chasque ville & cité, the priuate
custome of euery citie.

Les loix & Coustumes qui sont pro­
pres à vn chacun peuple, the lawes
and customes of a people.

Selon la coustume, according to the 
custome.

Comme il est de coustume, as it is 
commonly seene, as it commonly fal­
leth out.

Avoir de coustume, to vse or to bee
woont.

Lever vne coustume, to begin or 
raise vp a custome.

Prendre vne coustume, to take a cu­
stome.

Chose coustumiére, a common thing.

Coustumiérement, commonly.

Vne Cousture, a seame: f.

Cousturier, a taylor: m.

Cousturiére, a she taylor: f.

Coutaux, hillocks, little hils: m.

Vn Coutelas, a sworde of men of
armes: m.

Vne Coutelasse sur le visage, a blow
giuen by such a sworde vpon the 
face: f.

Vn coutil: m: ou coistre: f: a mat­
tresse, a pallet, a fether bed or flocke
bed.

Couture, see Coulture.

Couver, to keepe warme, to hatch, to
breede.

Couvé, kept warme, hatched.





Couvée de poulsins, hatching of
chickens, a broode of chickens: f.

Faire la couvade, to keepe the Campe 
for feare: f.

Couvement, a sitting, or hatching: m.

Couvrir, to couer, to hide, to ouer­
spread, to close: je couvre, je cou­
vri, j'ay couvert, je couvriray.

Couvert, couered, hidden.

Couverture, a couering: f.

Couverture de lict, a couerlet of a 
bed.

Couverture faite de liverses laines
ou pieces amassées ensemble, an
hapharlat, a course couering made
with diuers shreds.

Couvercle, a couer, a lid: m.

Vn couvre-chef: a kerchief: m.

Couvrement, a couering: m.

Couvertement, couertlie, secretlie,
wisely, closely.

Maison Couverte de pailile, or
chaulme, a house couered with
straw: thatched.

Couvoiter, seeke Convoiter.

Coy, still, quiet, as tenez vous coy,
be still, stand still.

Vn home coy, a still man, a quiet man.

Coyement, quietly, stilly.

Coyté, stilnesse: f.

Cracher, to spet.

Cracheur, a spetter: m.

Crachat, spettle: m.

Crachement, spetting: m.

Craindre, je crains, je crain, j'ay
crain, je craindray, to feare, to
dread.

Craignant, fearing, dreading.

Craintif, fearefull, dreadfull.

Crainte, feare, dread: f.

Avec Crainte, fearefully.

Craintivement, fearefully.

Sans crainte, without feare: f.

Cramaillere, the pot hanger: f.

Velours Cramoisi, Crimosin vel­
uet: m.

Les gouttes Crampes, the gowtish
crampe: f.

La Crampe, the crampe.

Crampon, a crampe of yron: m.

Cramponner, to fasten with barres
or crampes of yron.

Crane, the scull: f.

Crapaudine, a pretious stone: f.

Vn Crapaud, m: a Tode.

Crapaudeau, m: a little Tode.

Crapuler, to play the dronkard, the 
vse of too much drinking.

Crapaudaille, f: filthie knaues, men
of no value.

Crapule, drunkenesse: f.

Craquelin, a cracknell: m.

Craquer, to cracke.

Craquetis, a cracking, a noise: m.

Crasse & grand amas d'ordure sus
quelque chose, sluttishnesse, filthi­
nesse, greasinesse, baudinesse: f.

Crasseux, filthie, slutish, greasie, bau­
die.

Crassitude, grossenesse, lumpishnesse,
thickning: f.

Cravanter, to ouerpresse one, either
with blowes or labour.

Crayon, or Craïon, m: a pattern or
example.

Cray, seeke Croy.

Vne Creance, credite or trust: f.

La Creance, or croyance, the belief: f.





Lettres de Creanace, Letters of cre­
dance.

Vn creancier, a creditor, a truster: m.

Creancer, to make a promise.

Createur, seeke Créer: m.

Crecerelle, a Tymbrell, a Rattle: f:
a clacke.

Le credit d'aucun, the credite or au­
thoritie of a man: m.

Chose credible, croyable, or crea­
ble, f: to be beleeued.

Vn Crediteur, m: a creditor.

Credule, light to beleeue, com.

Credulité, light beleefe: f.

Createur de toutes choses, the crea­
tor of all things: m.

Créer, & donner estre à quelque
chose, & mettre premierement en 
nature, to create, to make, to giue
the first being.

Il fut Crée consul pour la seconde
fois, he was created Maior or Con­
sull for the second time.

La fame fut Créée ou plus tost for­
mée de l'home, the woman was crea­
ted, or rather formed of the man: f.

Creation: f: & establissement: m:
 the creation of a Magistrate.

La Creiche, auge, ou mangeoire
d'vne estable, a Crach, or Crib: f.

Cresme, creame: f.

Cremailliere, ou cremillére, a hooke
to hang any thing on: f.

Cremeur, m: feare.

Cremir, to feare.

Vn Cren: m: ou crenne: f: a notch,
a nocke in a bowe or shaft.

Creneaux,  the loops or spikes of a wal,
the battlements of a wall or castle: m.

Frangé & crené, fringed.

Crepets, wafer cakes, Fritters: m.

Cresmeau, qu'on met sur la teste
des enfants qu'on baptize, a Cri­
some: m.

Crespe, Sendall, Cipres: m.

Crespu, sliked, curled.

Crépuscule du soleil levant, the brea­
king out or rising of the Sunne.

Cheveux crespus, curled haire.

Crépir, to parget, to curle also.

Crepisseure: f: or Blanchissement:
m: pargetting.

Cresson, Water-cresses: m.

Cresson alenois: kerse, or cresses: 
hearbe: m.

Cresté, ou qui a vne Creste: copped: 
which hath a crest or combe.

Creté, or miste, gay, fine, gawdie.

Vne Creuë, f: a fifteene.

Vne Creste des oyseaux, a birdes
combe or crest: f: the cop of a birds
head.

Se crever & rompre, to burst.

Crever les yeux à aucun, to put out
or digge ones eyes.

Crever de despit qu'on à, to burst
with anger.

Vne crevasse, a chinke, a cleft, a cre­
uise: f.

Se cravasser, or crevasser, to cleaue, to
chap, to parch.

Crevassé, chapped.

Creux, hollowe.

Le Creu des mains, the basse of ones
hands.

Creuser, to make hollowe, to digge.





Vn Crible ou sas, a Cribble, a
Sieue: m.

Cribler & sasser, to sift.

Criblure, a sifting f.

Cri, a crie, a shoute, a shricke: m.

Crier, je crie, je criay, j'ay crié, je 
crieray, to crye, to shoote, to shricke,
to hallowe.

Vn Crieur, a cryer: m.

Vn Crieur public, a common cryer.

Crieurs de trespassez, cryers at a fu­
nerall arayed in blacke.

La Criée du Crieur, the Cryers 
crie: f.

Par leur fascherie & crierie, with
their griefe and crying: f.

Vn Criard, an out-cryer or braw­
ler: m.

Criarde, an vnquiet woman, a scold: f.

Criement, a crying: m.

Criement à l'encontre de quelque
chose, a reclaiming, a crying a­
gainst: m.

Crime, a fault: m.

Criminel, a Sherife, or an accuser, or
Clearke of the Assise: m.

Criminatoire, of finding fault, or re­
prehending: com.

Crimination, a finding of fault or re­
prehension: f.

Crimineux, or malfacteur, m: an e­
uill liuer.

Les crins d'vn cheval, qui luy pen­
dent sus le col, ou d'vn Lion, the
mane of a horse or lyon.

Crinon des cheminées, a cricket in
the chimnies: m.

Criqueter, or criquer, to creake, to
crackle with the fingeres.

Criquement de fueilles seiches, a
rusling of drie leaues.

Ieux Critiques, Playes which had
iudges to giue iudgement of those
which had done well.

Croailler, to croake like a Rauen.

Croailleric, or croaillement, the 
croaking of a Rauen, Tode or
Frogge: m.

Vn grand Croc, a Grapple, a hooke.

Croc à accrocher navires, a grapple
of a ship: m.

Vn Crochet, a fish hooke: m.

Crochet à houër la terre, a pick­
axe: m.

Donner le crochet à aucun, & le ru­
er par terre, to trip one: m.

Crocheteur, a common porter, a bur­
then bearer: m.

Crocheter, to fasten vp.

Crocheter vne ferrure, to picke a 
locke.

Crochu, crooked, hooked.

Crochure, crookednesse: f.

Crochement des dents, crookednesse
of teeth: m.

Vne Croce, see Crosse.

Vn Crocodile, beste d'Egypte, a
Crocodile: m.

Croire, je croy, je creu, j'ay creu,
je croyray, to beleeue, to thinke, to
trust.

Croire aucun,  to beleeue one.

Qui Croit de legier, light of be­
leefe.

Croire quelque chose, to beleeue a
thing.





Vne ferme Croyance, or Creance
qu'on a de quelque chose, a firme
beleefe, or sure perswasion: f.

Croyable, credible, worthy to bee be­
leeued, com.

Croyablement, credibly.

La Croisade, f: the expedition of the
Christians against the infidels, wher
each knight of Malta beareth a 
white crosse.

La Croisée d'une fenestre, f: the 
crosses or barre which crosseth or de­
uideth a window.

Croiser, to cutte ouerthwart or crosse­
wise.

Croiser les bras, les jambes, to crosse
the legges as Taylors do.

Croiser vne obligacion, to cancel an
obligation.

Croistre, je croy, je cru, j'ay cru, je
croystray, to grow, to increase, to
waxe bigge.

Croissant, growing.

A l'enseigne du Croissant, at the signe
of the halfe Moone: m.

Croissance, increase: f.

Vne Croix, a crosse: f.

La Croisade, the expedition when
the Christians take a white crosse a­
gainst the Turke: f.

Croisée, as la croisée de la fene­
stre, the crosse of the window.

Croisette, a little crosse.

Croupir, to bow downe, to come down,
to stoupe: je croupis, je croupi, j'ay
croupi je croupiray.

Croque-lardon, a lickrish, a pucker
of the larde when meate is rosted: m.

Croupir an coing du foyer, to
crouch in the chimney corner.

Crucifier, to crucifie or hang on the 
crosse.

Le Cropion, the rumpe: m.

Crosler, ou crouler, to brandish, to
shake, to wagge.

Croslé & ébranslé, shaken, wagged.

Vne Crosse, a Crosiers staffe, such
as Bishops vse among papists: f.

Crottes, daglings: f.

Crotté, bedagled.

Croté, crote, the dung of cunnies,
sheepe, goates, and such like: f.

Vne croupiére de cheval, a Crou­
per: f.

La croupe, or crope d'vne monta­
gne, the top of an hill: f.

Porter en crope, to haue one behinde
him on horse-backe, to beare in 
the croupe: f.

Eauë Croupie, standing water which
hath no course.

Croussiller entres les dens, to eate a­
ny thing that cracketh between the 
teeth, as a nut-shell or such like.

Crouste, a crust: f.

Crousteux, crustie.

De la croy, ou cray, chalke: f.

Croyé, or blanchi de croye, chalked,
or whited with chalke.

Cru, rawe.

Cruauté, seeke Cruel.

Crueté, rawnesse.

Crudité, vnripenesse, or when the
stomacke doth not digest.

Cruche à porter eauë, a pitcher, a 
water crocke, a steane: f."water crock" not found in OED.

Crucier, to torment, to vexe one.

Crucifier, seeke Croix.





Cruel, cruell, fierce, vngentle, vn­
tractable.

Cruauté, crueltie, vnmercifulnesse: f.

Vne Creuë, a kinde of subsidie in
France.

Vne creuë d'eauë, the rising or incre­
sing of the water through rayne.

La riviére est fort Creuë, the water
is very much increased and risen.

Cruellement, cruelly, tyrannously,
horribly.

Crystal, Christall: m.

Cube, a figure of Geometrie so cal­
led: m.

Cubiculaire, a Groome in the cham­
ber: m.

Cueiller, je cu, je cueilly, j'ay cue­
illy, je cueilliray, to gather toge­
ther.

Cueilleur ou vendangeur, a gathe­
rer of grapes: m.

Cueillette, a collection, a gathering
together: f.

Le Cueillement, the gathering to­
gether: m.

Vn Cueillier, a bird called a shouell.

Cueur, ou Cœur, a hart: m.

Mon petit Cueur, my little heart, my
sweet hart.

Par Cueur, by heart, by rote, without
booke.

Apprendre par cueur, to cunne by
heart.

Dire ce qu'on a sus le cueur, to vt­
ter a mans minde, to discharge his
stomacke.

Grand cueur & honneste, a noble
heart.

Gros cueur, a stout stomacke.

Contre son cueur, dissemblingly, or
agaynst his heart.

Au fin cueur d'yver, in the heart or 
middest of winter.

Cuider, to thinke, to weene.

Cuidereau, a prety hardy fellow, spo­
ken in mockage: m.

Vn cuilier, a spoone: m.

Le Cœur, or Cueur d'une eglise, m:
 the quier of a church.

Vne cuiliére, a ladle :f.

Cuillir, je cus, je cuilli, j'ay cuilli, je
cuilliray, to gather together.

Cuict, see Cuire.

Cuin, ou couïn à fendre bois, a
wedge to cleaue wood: m.

Cuirasse, as vn corps de cuirasse a
brestplate: f.

Du Cuir, a hide, leather: m.

Le Cuir luy tient aux costes, hee is
clung or hide-bound.

Ceste vache a le cuir qui luy tient,
 this cowe is hide-bound.

Cuire, je cui, je cuisi, j'ay cuit, je cui­
ray, ou faire cuire, to seeth, to bake.

Cuict en eauë, sodde in water.

Ce pain n'est pas bien cuict, this
bread is not well baked.

Lot cuisit des pains sans levain,
 Lot did bake vnleauened bread for
the Angels.

Cuisson, a seething, a smarting: f.

Cuisse-né, borne in the thigh as Bac­
chus.

Cuisine, kitchen: f.

Cuisinier, a Cooke: m.

La cuisse, the thigh: f.

Cuissinet, seeke Cuissin.

Cul, an arse: sound Cu: m.





Cullbuter, topsie turuie.

Culace, as appuyer son harquebus
sur la culace, to stay his gunne vpon
a prop or stay to shoote better: f.

Cumuler, to ioyne, to heape together.

Cumin, Cummin, an hearb: m.

Qui font la culbute, tumblers: f.

Cultiver, to till.

Cultiveur, m: a tiller.

Cultivement, tillage: m.

Culeter, to sturre the buttocks.

Culetis, m: Culetage, f: that action.

Cupidité, couetousnesse, greedie de­
sire: f.

Cupide, com: couetous.

Curage, an hearbe called in English,
Arse-smart: f.

Curailles de maison, rubbish: f.

Vne cure ou paroisse, a cure or pa­
rish: f.

Vn curé d'vne paroisse, the Curate
of a parish: m.

Cure ou garison, a cure or restoring
to health: f.

Ce cirurgian ne feit jamais Cure
qui vaille le parler, that surgeon
neuer made cure worth speaking: f.

Il à fait plusieurs belles cures, hee
hath made diuers fayre cures.

Curée, all such purtenances that
hunters giue to their hounds hauing
gotten the praye: f.

Vne curette à nettoyer le coultre de
la charruë, the yron wherewith the
Plough-man clenseth the Coul­
ter: f.

Vn curedent, a tooth-picke: m.

Vn cure oreille, an eare picker.

Cure, f: & soing, m: care, thought,
study, diligence, worke, labour.

Curer, to clense.

Cureurs de retraits, clensers of iake­
ses and priuies: dung-farmers: m.

Curateurs, such as haue charge of a­
ny thing: m.

Mettre en curatelle comme furi­
eux, f: to lay one in hold as a foole.

Curiosité, curiositie: f.

Curieusement, curiously.

Curialiste, ou courtisan, a Courti­
er: m.

Cuver son vin, to worke downe this
wine and meate: this is spoken of
drunkards.

Cuves dedens lesquelles on porte
la vendange au pressoir, olives, &
semblables, tubs, such as they car­
rie grapes to the winepresse.

Vne Cuve à cuver la vendange, a
tubbe, a fatte as dyers doe vse.

la Cuve dedens laquelle le vin du
pressoir se recueille, a receiuing
tubbe: f.

Vne grande Cuve: a great fatte, a 
great tunne or pipe: f.

Vn Cuvier, ou vne cuve à se baigner, 
 a bathing tubbe.

Cuyvre, copper: m.

Cy ou je suis, here in this place.

Ci devant, heretofore.

Cygne, seeke Cigne.

Cylindre, a round and long thing: m.

Cymaises, a great stone which vp­
holdeth the beame of the house in
the wall: f.

Cymbale, a Cymball: f.

Cymettes, f: the tender buds which
the stalke of Colewortes casteth





out in the spring time.

Du Cypres, Cypresse: m.

Cyre, see Syre.


D ante A.

DA, for Dea, a word affirmatiue,
as ouy da, yea forsooth, yes ve­
rily.

Dablée, or Cueillette, as nous au­
rons stannée bonne dablée de
bleds, de vins, & autres choses, 
wee shall haue this yeare great a­
boundance of corne, wines, and o­
ther things: f.

Daces, a kind of custome or toll in
France: f.

Davantage, furthermore.

Dactes, le fruit de la Palme, Dates,
the fruit of the palme tree: m.

Dadée: dandling: as souffrir vn en­
fant en ses Dadées, to dandle a
childe, to suffer his toyes.

Vne Dague, f: vn poignard, m: a
dagger.

Ne Daigner regarder aucun, not to
vouchsafe, to beholde one, to daine.

Vn Dain, a Fallow Deere: a Doe: m.

Vn Dainteau, or dainceau, a pricket,
or young bucke: m.

Daintiers, a word vsed among Hun­
ters, signifying the stones of a 
deere: m.

Dam, ou dommage, losse, hinderance,
dammage: m.

S'il le fait, ce sera son Dam, if he do it,
it will be his harme: m.

Du Damas, damaske.

ouvrage à la Damasquine: worke­
manship wrought after the damask
fashion.

Damasquiné, wrought so.

Damsquiner, to graue or carue any
thing in damaskine.

Habillement damassé, a damaske
coate or garment.

Dame, ou maistresse, Dame or mi­
stresse: f.

Vn Dameret, an effeminate man
which is alwayes at a womans tayle,
& studieth onely to please them: m.

Dames, as jouër aux dames to play
on the outside of the Tables: f.

Vn Damier, a payre of tables, a chesse
boord: m.

Damner, ou condamner, to condemne.

Damnable, com: as c'est vn fait, or
chose damnable, damnable, a deed 
to be blamed or condemned.

Damnation, f: damnation.

Damoisel, a young Gentleman not
made knight yet: m.

Damoiseau, idem.

Damoiselle, a Gentleman: f.

Teinct Damoisesau, or Damoiselet,
 the colour or complexion which she­
weth rather a woman then a man.

Dandiner, to doe fondly, nicely.

Vn dandin, a nice, like a foole: m.

Danger, or dangier, danger, perill: m.

Sans danger, without danger.

Mettre quelqu'vn en danger, to put
one in ieopardie.

Se mettre en danger, to ieopard a
ioynt, to aduenture, to hazzard.

Il y a danger que, &c. it is to be fea­
red least.

Dangereux, dangerous, perilous.





Dangereusement, daungerously, pe­
rilously.

Danse, a dance: qui meine la danse,
the ringleader: f.

Danser, to daunce, to hop, to leape.

Danseur, a dauncer: m.

Danseresse, a woman dancer: f.

Dansement, a dancing, a hopping, a
mouing: m.

Toute sorte de Dard, a Gleaue, a 
Dart: m.

Darder, to throw a Dart.

Dardeur, a thrower of a Dart: m.

Darderesse, f: a woman casting a
Dart.

Dardanier, an huckster, he that kee­
peth corne till it be deare: m.

Dartre, ou Feu voulage, a Tetter or 
Ring-worme: f.

D'adventure, perchance.

Dater des lettres, to date letters.

Daté le premier jour de Mars, da­
ted the first of March.

Datte, seeke Dactes.

D'avantage, seeke Avantage.

Vn Davier de barbier servant à ar­
racher les dents, the instrument of
a Barber seruing to pull out teeth.

Vn Dauphin, a Dolphin: m.

Dé, seeke Det.

Vn Dé à couldre, a thimble: m.

Ouy dea, yea verily, yea mary.

Debatre de parolles avec aucun &
noiser, to cauil, to brabble, to quarel.

Debatre quelque propos, to debate
a thing.

Debat & different de quelque cho­
se, a debate, a strife, a contention: m.

Debeller, to ouerthrow in the warre.

Debiffé, torne in peeces, ragged.

Fort debile & foible, very weake, ve­
rie feeble.

Debilité, weakenesse: f.

Debiliter, to weaken.

Debilitation de veuë, short sighted,
weake sight: f.

Debiter de la merchandise, to sell
merchandise by parcell.

Debonaire, meeke, gentle.

Debonaireté, meekenesse: f.

Debonnairement recevoir aulcun,
 to receiue and entertaine one gently
or friendly.

Estre, ou se tenir debout sus les pi­
eds, to stand vpright.

Tenez vous Debout, stand vp.

Debouter, to depose, to put out, to de­
nie a request.

Debouter loing des siens, to sepa­
rate farre from acquaintance.

Debriser, to breake.

Debris, a breaking: m.

Debrisé, m: broken.

Debrisement, m: breaking.

Debvoir, duetie: leaue, b, vnsounded,
as followeth: m.

Le devoir, duetie, office.

Ne faire plus son devoir, Laisser ou
delaisser à faire son devoir, to leaue
his businesse, to neglect his duetie.

Devoir quelque chose, to owe.

Ie ne sçay comme je me doy gou­
verner en cela, I knowe not how to
behaue my selfe in that.

Deu, due, debt.

Vne dette, a debt: f.

Payer ses debtes, to pay debts, to dis­
charge the due.





Remettre vne debte à quelqu'vn,
Luy quicter & donner la debte, to
forgiue a debt: f.

Vn debteur, a debter: m.

Deça le Rheim, on this side the 
Rhine.

Deça, delà, from hence, from thence.

Deça & Delà, hither and thither.

Par Deça, par Dela, on this side, on
that side.

Par de là, on the other side.

Decapiter, to behead

Decadence, decay, as venir en deca­
dence, to decay: f.

Decéder, to dye.

Deces & trespas, a departing out of
the worlde: m.

Deceler, to discouer a conspiracie, to
accuse.

Deceleur de secret, m: a discloser of
secrecie, a traitor.

Decelement, m: disclosing.

Decent, becomming, conuenient,
seemelie.

Decence & bien-séence, comelinesse,
handsomenesse: f.

Decentement, as it is conuenient,
seemely.

Deceptif, m: deceitfull, seeke Dece­
voir.

Decerner, to decree.

Ie feray comme il en sera decerné
par les juges, I will doe as it shall be
decreed by the Iudges.

Vne prinse de Corps Decernée, an
attachement vpon ones body graun­
ted.

Decret, a decree: m.

Decevoir ou abuser quelqu'vn, to
deceiue, to beguile, to disappoint.

Deceu, deceiued, beguiled, betray­
ed.

Vn deceveur, a deceiuer, a beguy­
ler, a craftie fellowe, a subtile fel­
lowe: m.

Deception, deceit, subtilty, craft, wi­
linesse: f.

Deceptif, deceitfull.

Parolle Deceptive, f: a deceitfull
worde or speech.

Decevable, idem, com.

Decez, see Deceder.

Dechasser, to driue awaye, to expulse.

Dechassé, driuen away, expulsed.

Dechassement, a driuing away: m.

Dechiqueter, seeke Deschiqueter.

Dechirer, seeke Deschirer.

Decheoir petit à petit, venir à de­
cadence, to fall away, to decay, to les­
sen: decline it as Cheoire.

Cela est Decheu de la moitié, it is
lessened by the halfe.

Dechet, the waste or decay, whether
it be in golde, siluer, wine , oyle, and
such like: m.

Estre de cheu de droit que lon pre­
tend en quelque royaume ou sei­
gneurie, to haue lost the right pre­
tended, &c.

Decider & mettre fin, to decide, to 
end.

Decision, f: deciding, a composition
of a matter in debate.

Decimes, tenths: m.

Declamateur, a Declaimer, a moter.

Declairer, to mote.

Declamation, f: an oration made of 
a matter fained.





Declamatoire, com: pertaining to
such exercise or vse.

Declarer, & exposer, to declare, to 
set forth, to expound.

Declaration, f: a declaration.

Declarer son courage, to declare or
shew his courage.

Declarer vne accusation & délation
faicte d'auncun à l'encontre d'au­
cun non recevable, to declare a­
gainst one.

Estre declaré, to be declared.

Decliner, to decline, to bow from.

Declin de l'aage, in decaying age.

Decoction, a decoction, a seething: f.

Decorer, to decke.

Decoration, a decking: f.

Découler, to flowe, to runne downe­
ward.

Decoulement, m: flowing or running.

Decoulourer, to staine, to loose co­
lour.

Decoulourement, a stayning: m.

Le Decours de la Lune, the wane of
the Moone: m.

Decouper, to cut or slice.

Decoupure, a cutting or slicing: f.

Décrépité, very olde.

Aage décrépité, very olde age.

Decroistre, to decrease, to weare a­
way, to waxe lesse, decline it as
Croistre.

Decroter, Decrotoire, seeke Descro­
ter.

Dedens, within.

Dedier, to consecrate, to dedicate.

Dedié, dedicated.

Dedication, or Dedicate, f: the con­
secration of a thing.

Deduite, f: & rabat, m: d'vne som­
me, an abating, a diminishing.

Deduit & plaisir qu'on prend à
quelque chose, delight: pleasure:
m.

Se deduire, to take his pleasure de­
light: je me deduis, je me deduy,
je me suy deduit, je me dedui­
ray.

Deduire, see Desduire.

Déesse, a she God, a Goddesse: f.

Defaillir, to languish, to waxe feeble.

Defaillir, je defaux, je defailly, j'ay
defailly, je defaudray, & se passer,
 to weare away, to wither away.

Vn default, want of appearance be­
fore the Iudge.

Rien ne me deffault, I lacke no­
thing.

Defaulte de quelque chose, want,
lack, penury, scarcenesse: m.

Defaillance de courage, want of
courage, faint hartednesse: f.

Defalquer, to cut out of a portion, to
seuer from the whole.

Defaroucher, see Deffaroucher.

Deffaveur, Diffavorir, m: see deffa­
veur.

Defectuëux, wanting, lacking, may­
med.

Defectuosité, f: lacke, mayming.

Defendre, je defens, je defendy, j'ay
defendu, je defendeay, to forbid, to
defend.

Defendre quelque chose à au­
cun, to forbidde the dooing of a
thing.





Defensive, as ligue offensive de­
fensive, a league to offend or assault
the common enemie, and defend our 
freends in league.

Ville defensable, a towne which may
be defende and kept.

Defendeur, a defendant, a defender: m.

Defence de ne faire quelque chose,
 forbidding, defence: f.

Default, a default of apperance at the
day or tearme appointed, that one is
summoned to appeare on: m.

Deferer aucun d'avoir faict aucun
crime & forfaict, to accuse one, to
lay to ones charge.

Delateur ou denonciateur, a priuie
accuser, a tale teller, a promo­

Delation, a tale told priuily to put one
to displeasure.

Deffavoriser, contrarie of fauour, to
shew no fauour, to deny and take from
one all fauour.

Deffaveur, m: disfauour.

Deffortune, misfortune: f.

Deffortuné, m: vnfortunate.

Deflorer, see Desflourer.

Deffuler, see desfuler.

Deffaire, seeke Desfaire.

Deffier, seeke Desfier.

Deffier aucun, to defie, to prouoke, to
chalenge.

Vn Deffi, a chalenge or prouoking.

Deffiance, f: a defying.

Defigurer aucun, to disfigure, to mis­
shape, to diffame.

Defiguré, mis-shapen.

Défigurement, a mis-shaping: m.

Deffinir, je definis, je defini, j'ay de­
fini, je definiray, to define, to de­
clare or shew.

Definition, a defining, an exposition: f.

Definer, to fall away and pine.

Definement, pyning: m.

Le Definement du monde, the lat­
ter end of the worlde: m.

Defleurer, to defloure.

Defluxion ou catharre, a rheume, a

Deformation, a disfiguring: f.

Deformée, deformed or disfigured.

Deformer, to disfigure.

Defrauder, to deceiue, to defraude.

uer.

Defrayer toute la viande, to prouide
cates.

Si vous me voulez defrayer, j'yray
avec vous: if you will beare thy
charges, I will goe with you.

Tout defrayé, all charges borne.

Defroy, al such charges rising of tra­
uailing by the way: m.

Vn defrayeur qui nous fournit de 
tout ce qu'il nous fault par les
chemins, a Cater, a Steward: m.

of the ground, a grubbing or shrub­

Defrichée, plowed or fallowed, grub­
bed.

Defricher la terre, to worke and till
ground, to make it fertile, to grub.

Se defriper, to rubbe on the shoul­
ders.

Deffraisser, to crush in peeces.

Vn defunct, a deceased and dead 
person.





Degasouiller, see Cazouiller.

Degast, waste, losse: m.

Degastement, wasting: m.

Degeler, to thawe, il degele, il dege­
la, il a degelé, il degelera.

Degel, m: thawing weather.

Degencrer, to degenerate.

Les oiseaux se desgoisent, birds chat­
ter or chirpe.

Degoisement, a chattering, a chir­
ping: m.

Degouter, To droppe out, to di­
still.

Degout, m: the dropping of house.

Degoutement, a distilling: m.

Degragder, to put one out of his office
and estate.

Degradation, f: a degrading or put­
ting out of office.

Degré, m: ou marche, f: a steppe, a 
starre.

Dedegré en degré parvenir à hon­
neur, from degree to degree, to come
to honour.

Eslever en hault degré d'honneur,
 to aduaunce to high degree in ho­
nour.

Deguerpir, as deguerpir le païs to
forsake his Countrie.

Deguerpir vn fief, to forgoe his fee to
the Lord.

Dehacher, to cut small.

Dehalé, leane and disfigured.

Estre deshonté, to be shamelesse.

Dehors, a broade, without.

Dejecter & debouter, to reiect, to cast
away, to shake off.

Dejecté & mis au bas, cast off, for­
saken.

Deïettement, m: a casting off.

Deïfier, to extoll one like a God.

Deïté, diuinitie of the godhead: f.

Delà, beyond.

Delà la mer, beyond the sea.

to leaue one off.

Delaisse, de qui on ne tient compte,

off: m.

Delateur, seeke Deferer.

Delayer, to delay, to deferre.

off: m.

lace.

chose, delight, pastime, pleasure: f.

Deleguer, to appoint one ouer some
thing or affaire.

Delegation, f: the charge laid vpon
another.

Deliberer, to determine, to pour­
pose.

Delibere toy, determine to make thy 
selfe ready.

Deliberation & propos de mou­
rir, determination or purpose to
dye: f.

Avoir voix deliberative au Senat, to 
haue authoritie and power in the 
Senate house to determine of mat­
ters propounded.

Voix consultative, when some of





the Senate giueth his voice, opinion
and aduice in the matter propoun­
ded, but concludeth or determineth
nothing.

Ie cognoy la deliberation de Clodi­
us, I know Clodius purpose.

Homme delicat & de petite com­
plexion, a daintie man, a tender 
man.

Delicate, delicatesse, quand on fuit
les laveurs, fascheries, & ennuïs,
 daintinesse, tendernesse: f.

Delices & ébats, delights, sportes,

Delicieux, delicious, pleasant.

Delicieusement, deliceously, pleasant­

Delier & menuïser, to make thinne.

Delié, thinne, slender.

Deliément, thinly, slenderly, scant­
lye.

Il a Delinqué, he hath done amisse.

Punir les delinquans, to punishe the

Delire, to choose, to picke out, to

Delivrer au plus offrant, to deliuer to

Delivrance, a deliuerie: f.

Deluge, a floud.

Demina, tomorrow: m.

Le Demaine, ou Domaiue & reve­
nu du peuple & de la ville, lande,
toll or custome, due to any people or
towne: m.

Vne Demande, a demaund, a questi­
on, a petition: f.

Demandé, asked.

stice, the Plaintife, the demaun­
