Se Demanger fort, to itch.

Demangement, itching.

Demangeure, Demangeson, f: I­
dem.

Demarer, to loose ancker, to set vp
sailes.

Demener vne cause, to pleade or o­
pen a cause.

Demener, Tempéster, Esmouvoir, to
tosse, to turmoile, to tumble, to wal­
lowe, to carry about.

Domener joye, to leade great ioy.

Se Dementer, to complaine.

Se Dementer de quelque chose, to
meddle in some matter.

Dementir, to giue a lie, to shewe a 
thing otherwise then it is, as les
filles bien souvent dementent le­
ur cœur, maidens must often doe or
shew otherwise then they do thinke.

Démerite, deseruing: m.

Il a esté puni selon ses démérites, he
hath beene punished according to
his deserts.

Demesler, seeke Desmesler.

Demettre, seeke Desmettre.

Lieu de Demeure, dwelling, abiding
place.

Longue demure, long tarying: f.





Demurer en quelque lieu, to dwell in
a place, to remaine.

ner, the remnant of dinner or sup­
per: m.

Au Demeurant, as touching the 
rest.

Demeurance, or demoure, remai­
ning: f.

Demi, halfe.

Vn Demicinct de fame, a womans
girdle halfe siluer: m.

Demi-ceintier, m: the maker of such

uerned by the people: f.

Demoniaque, possessed by the Di­
uell.

Demonstrer & faire bien entendre
quelque chose, to declare, to shew
at large.

monstration: f.

Demonstrateur, one that sheweth or 
declareth: m.

Demonstratif, that sheweth or is meet
to be shewed.

Demourer, Demourant, Demou­
rance, seeke Demeure.

Vn Denier ancien vallant six livres
d'argent, an ancient peece of mo­
ney beeing in value sixe pound of
siluer: m.

Denier vallant quatre petis sester­
ces, c'est à dire trois sols six deni­
ers, an ancient Romaine peny: m.

Les Deniers communs d'vne ville,
 the towne treaseure.

Le Denier à Dieu, the earnest pe­
ny: m.

Denier quelque chose, a deniall.

Déniement, a denying.

Denigrer, to make blacke, to defame
and report euill of one.

Denombrement, quand ancienne­
ment chascun bailloit aux Cen­
seurs le nombre de ses biens, an
inuentorie of goods, a numbring: m.

Denommer, to giue the names of o­
ther men.

Denoncer par attaches affichées és
lieux publiques, to declare, to pub­
lish, to proclaime.

Denoncer & faire à scavoir à vne
femme qu'on la quicte, to signifie
or declare diuorsement.

Denoncement, a signifiyng, a decla­
ring: m.

Denonciation de guerre, a denoun­
cing of open warre: f.

Denoter, to signifie, to note.

Ceste excuse denote qu'il y a faul­
te en son cas, this excuse sheweth
that his matter is not cleere.

Denrée, ware, marchandise.

Vne Dent, a tooth: f.

Le mal des Dens, the tooth ache.

Vn Dentateur or arracheur de dens:
 a barber which draweth teeth, a
tooth-drawer.

Dentelé, any thing made like teeth.

Se Departir & s'en aller de la mai­
son, to departe from home: decline
it as Partir.

Se departir de quelque lieu, to de­





parte from a place.

Departir & deviser, to parte, to de­
uide.

Qui Departit, a deuider, a distribu­
ter.

Depart ou departie, & estongne­
ment, departure.

Departement, a departing: m.

Departissement, a distribution, a par­
tition: m.

Dependre d'ailleurs, to depend of an
other, seeke Despendre.

Dependre, to take downe any thing
which was hanged.

Il a esté dependu par arrest de la 
cour, he is taken downe from the 
gollowes by the aduice and iudge­
ment of the Court.

Deperir, that is, perir du tout, to be
vndone.

Depesche, see Despescher.

Depestrer, seeke Despestrer.

Depilatoire, a thing causing the
haire to fall.

Depiteux, Depitonné, seeke De­
spiter.

Depilatoire, com: causing the fal­
ling of haires.

Deplayer aucun & le navrer, to
plague, to wound one.

Il est fort Deplayé & navré, he is
much wounded.

Deplorer aucun, to moue one.

Santé Deplorée, health without hope,
that is, there is no hope of health, re­
medilesse.

Deport, m: Les Deports des bene­
fices, the fruits of a benefice being
vacant.

Mourir sans aucun Deport, to dye
without any delay.

Deport, also is taken for pastime.

S'aller Deporter, to goe and passe a­
way the time.

Se Deporter, to forbeare, to leaue off,
to sport, to passe away the time.

Deposer & porter tesmoignage par
devant vn juge, & examinateur, to
depose, to beare witnes.

Deposer & priver de la couronne
imperialle, to depose or put beside
the Crowne.

Tenir en Depost, to holde or keepe a
thing to restore it againe.

Denier vn depost, to denie a feoffe­
ment of tenth, to deny a gage.

Deposition de tesmoings, a deposing
of witnesses.

Depositaire, the keeper of any thing
put in his custodie, m: a feoffer of
trust.

Deposséder, to put out of possession.

Deprier, to pray earnestly.

Deprimer, to bring one lowe.

Depuceler, to defloure a virgine, to
take her maidenhead.

Depuis, since.

Depuis ce temps là, since that time.

Deputer Iuge pour cognoistre de
quelque matiére, to ordaine or ap­
point a Iudge in a matter.

Avoir Dequoy, to haue wherewith­
all to helpe ourselues.

Dequoy me serr cela? where to doth
that serue me?

Derechef, againe.

Derider, to stretch a thing which
hath wrinckles, to vnwrinckle.





Derision, derision, mocking, flouting: f.

Deriver, to driue from one to another.

Tout le Dernier & le plus reculé de
nous, the vttermost, the last, the
farthest of vs: m.

Pour le Dernier, for the last, or last of
all.

Au Dernier, at the last.

Derniérement & le plus fresche­
ment, lastly, lately.

Deroger, to derogate, to minish.

Derogation, diminishing of a lawe or
dignitie: f.

Déroguer, to diminish, or abrogate.

Derogation, diminishing, abroga­
ting: f.

Dérogatoire, the law, the thing, the
priuiledge diminished, com.

Derompre, to breake, to bust, to riue

Mur Derompu, a riuen wall.

Derompement, a breaking, a ri­
uing: m.

Derriére, behinde, backward.

Par derriére, behinde, on the backe
part.

Dertre, seeke Dartre.

Vn Ders, a Canopie, but properly that
which hangeth ouer a Princes
table: m.

Dersolet, a little Canopie: m.

Dés le commencement de ma jeu­
nesse, from my youth hitherward.

Des le fin point du jour, euen from
the dawning of the day.

Desaccointer quelcun, to leaue a
mans acquaintaunce and familia­
ritie.

Desaccointer deux homes, to breake
friendship betweene two.

Desaccorder, to disagree, to iarre.

Desaccordance, disagreement: f.

Desaccoupler, ou descoupler les
bœufs, to vncouple, to vnyoke.

Desaccoustumer, to vnaccustome, to
disuse.

Se Desaccoustumer, to vnwoont.

Desaccoustumé, vnaccustomed, vn­
wonted.

Desaccoustumance, disuse: f.

Desadventure, misfortune: f.

Se Desagenouiller, to rise vp from
kneeling.

Desagreable, which pleaseth not, the
contrarie is Agreable.

Desaigrir sa colere, to asswage his
choler.

Desaise, a disease: f.

Desalterer, to slake thirst.

Desancrer & partir du port, to hoise
ancker, to depart the hauen.

Desapetissance, as ces herbes o­
stent la desapetissance, these herbs
doe put away lothsomnesse of the
stomacke: f.

Appetisser, to procure a good appe­
tite to meate.

Desappetisser is the contrarie.

Desapointer, to disappoint one.

Desapresent, euen from this present
time.

Desapprendre autruy, l'enseigner
tout au rebours qu'il n'a apprins,
 to new teach, to teach otherwise
then one was taught before.

Desapprendre & oublier ce qu'on a
apprins, to forget to vnlearne.

Desarçonner, to cast one out of his 
saddle.





Se Desarmer,e to vnarme himselfe.

Desarmé, vnarmed.

Desarnacher vn cheval, to vnhar­
nesse a horse.

Desarroy, as mettre l'armée en de­
sarroy, to put an armie out of order,
to ouerthrow an armie: m.

Desarroyer, to put out of order.

Desroyer, idem.

Gens desroyez, souldiers out of or­
der.

Desasseurer vn home qui se tenoit
bien asseuré, to put a man in feare
which iudged to be well assured: to
disappoynt him.

Desassembler, to scatter, to disperse.

Desavouër, to disallow.

Desastre, an hard chance: m.

Desastré, or infortuné, infortunate.

Desavancer, to goe afore one, to pre­
uent one.

Desavantager, to hinder one.

Desavantage, à mon grand desa­
vantage, to my great hinderance: m.

Desballer, to vnpacke, to vndoe packs
of ware.

Desbarbouiller, to make cleane, to
take away spots: the contrarie is,
Barbouiller, to foule any thing ei­
ther with soute of the chimney, with
lees, dirt, or such like thing.

Desbarder, to vnload a ship.

Desbardeur, a Liter man, or those
which doe vnlade the ship: m.

Desbarder vn cheval, to take off
bardes from an horse.

Desbarquer, the contrarie is, Embar­
quer, to vnloade a ship.

Desbarrer vn huys, to vnbarre a
dore, to open a dore.

Desbater vn asne, to take of the pack­
saddle of an asse.

Desbaucher aucun, to bring one to
wickednesse, or to loose life.

Home Desbauché, fame Desbau­
chée, a man or woman without
frame or good rule: disordered or
leading a dissolute life: a dissolute
one.

Desbender vn arc, to vnbend, to loose
a bow.

Desbender vne playe, to loose a
wound.

Desbattonner, to spoyle one from his
armour, to take away from him his
staues or armour: the contrarie is
Embattonner.

Desbauger vn sanglier, to raise a 
wild Bore from his lying place.

Desbléer, or Desblayer, to take away
any impediment which letteth or
combreth vs.

Desboité, out of ioynt.

Desbonder, or Desbondonner, to
take away the stopple of an hogges
head of wine, or of a sluce.

Desboucher, to vnstoppe, to set a
broach.

Desboucher, to disparke.

Desbouchement, disparking: m.

Desboucler, to vndoe a buckle.

Desbourber, to drawe out of the
mud.

Desbourser argent, to disburse mo­
ney.

Grand Desboursement d'argent, m:
 a great disbursing of money.

Desboutonner, to vndoe a button.





Desbraillé, whose garments are loose
before the breast.

Desbrider vn cheval, to vnbridle a
horse.

Desbrodequiner, to pull off ones bus­
kins.

Desbrouiller, to deliuer or vndoe a
thing that is intangled.

Se Desborder, to ouerflowe, to runne
ouer, to be out of frame.

Desbordement, misrule: m.

Desbordé, out of order or rule.

Desbusquer, to depart or stirre from
his standing place.

Desbuter, to throwe right to the but
or marke: also to make a match at
bowles.

Desacher sa face, to discouer his
face.

Desacheter lettres, to open or break
the seale of a Letter.

Descamper, to raise the siege: to de­
part from the campe.

Desboitement des os, bones out of ioynt.

Descapiter quelqu'vn, to behead
one.

Desceindre, to vngird.

Desceinct, vngirt.

Desceler, to discouer, disclose, or to
betray.

Descendre, to descend, to goe downe:
je descends, je descendi, je suy
descendu, je descendray.

Descendus de la ligne des Alba­
nois, descended of the line of Al­
banois.

Descente, a goyng downe, a descen­
ding: f.

La Descenduë & genealogie d'au­
cun, the descent and genealogie of
one: f.

Descengler vn cheval, to vngirth a
horse.

Desceu, as on a fait cela à mon des­
ceu, that hath been done without
my knoledge: m.

Deschainer, to loose out of chaines.

Deschalander, to driue away his cu­
stomers.

Deschant, descant, sometime a recan­
tation: m.

Deschanter, to descant.

Deschapperonner, to take ones hood
off his head.

Descharger aucun, to discharge, to 
vnburthen.

Deschargé & delivré de beaucoup
de soing, discharged of much
care.

Descharmer, to vnbewitch.

Descharner les os, to teare or loose
the flesh from the bones.

Descharpir, as je ne me peux des­
charpir de luy, I cannot bee ridde
from him.

Descharongner, to teare in pee­
ces.

Descharongnement, tearing of the 
flesh: m.

Deschausser, to pull off ones shooes or
hosen, to vnshooe.

Dechaussement, an vnshooing: m.

Descheance, f: decaying.

Deschevaucher vn home, to throwe
a man out of his horse.

Descombrer, to deliuer one of any
encomberance.





Deschevelée, a woman with her haire
about her eares.

Descheveler, to plucke a womans at­
tire from her head, and so spread her
haires abroad.

Deschevestrer vn cheval, to take the
halter from a horse, also to be rid
from one.

Deschiqueter, to pincke, to cut full of
holes, to mangle, to shread in pieces.

Deschiquetement, a mangling: m.

Deschirer & mettre en piéces, to
rent, to teare in peeces.

Deschiré, rent, torne.

Deschirure, a rent: f.

Deschirement, renting, tearing in
peeces: m.

Desclore, to pull downe hedges, to di­
sparke.

Desclouër, to loose and pull off a naile.

Descocher vne fleche, to shoote an 
arrowe.

Cest fort bien Descoché, it is verie
well shot: he looseth his bowe verie
handsomely.

Descoiffer, to pull of a womans attire
from her head.

Descognoistre, or Mescognoistre, 
see Cognoistre, his contrarie.

Descombrer, to deliuer one from en­
combrance, or incomber.

Descoler, to vnglew.

Ma table est toute Descolée, my ta­
ble is all vnglewed.

Descoller, to behead one.

Se Descombrer de quelcun, to be
ridde of one.

Desconsire vn exercite, to discomfite
or ouerthrow an armie.

Desconfiture de guerre, an ouer­
throw in warres.

Faire Desconfiture de gents de 
guerre, to discomfite Souldiers.

Se Descomforter & desoler, to dis­
comfort, to lament.

Descomfort, m: discomfort.

Descomforté, discomforted.

Desconseiller, to disswade, to counsell
the contrarie.

Desconseillé, disswaded.

Descontenance, out of countenance: f.

Descorder, to vntwist a corde.

Dire sa Desconvenuë à quelqu'vn,
 to shewe his griefe or misfortune to
one: f.

Descouldre, to rip, to vnsewe: de­
cline it like Couldre.

Descousu, ripped: vnsewed.

Descoulourer, to take away the co­
lour.

Descoulper, or Desencoulper, to dis­
charge one of his fault.

Descoupler les chiens, to loose or vn­
couple dogges.

Se Descourager, to be discouraged, to
distrust.

Descourager quelqu'vn, to discou­
rage one.

Descouragé, discouraged, out of
hart.

Descouronner, to take awaye the
crowne.

Descoulourer, to take away the co­
lour, as visage descoulouré par
maladie.

Descouvrir, to vncouer, to vnheale,
to make naked: see Couvrir, to de­
cline it.





Descouvert, euident, manifest, vnco­
uered, descried.

A Descouvert, openly, manifestly.

La Descouverte de quelques gents
ayants commis quelque malefi­
ce, the disclosing or finding out of
malefactors.

Descrier quelque chose, & faire
trouver mauvaise, to discredite a
thing.

Descrié, as les angelots sont descri­
ez, old angels are called in.

Monnoye Descriée, money called in.

Descrire quelque chose, to describe,
to declare at large.

Description, a description: f.

Descroistre, to decrease, to dimi­
nish.

Descrocher, or descrocheter, to vn­
doe or loose a hook.

Descroter sa robbe avec des de­
scrottoires, to rub with a rubbing
brush, to take off dirt.

Vne Decrottoire, a rubbing brush: f.

Desdaigner quelqu'vn, to disdaine,
to despise.

Desdaing, disdaine, despite, squea­
mishnesse: m.

Desdaigneux, squemish, coy, disdain­
full.

Desdaignement, a disdayning: m.

Desdier, seeke Dedier.

Se Desdire de ce qu'on a dict, to vn­
say, to recant: decline as Dire.

Sans se Desdire, without vnsaying it.

Desdommager, to make amends: to
saue harmelesse.

Desdommagement, a repayring, an
amends making: harmelesnesse: m.

Si je vous cautionne, si je suy vo­
stre plege, vous me desdommage­
rez, vous me rendrez indemne:
 if I be your suretie, you shall saue me
harmelesse.

Desdorer, to vngilt.

Desduire, to handle a matter: je des­
duis, je desduy, j'ay desduit, je
desduiray.

Il a fort bien Desduit ce poinct, he
hath handled that poynt or that
matter very well.

Desduit, delight, pastime, seeke De­
duit: m.

Desembarquer, to take lande, to vn­
loade a ship.

Desemparer, to depriue one of his
Hold, Fort, or office wherewith he 
was ceased, to force the field or place
afore occupied.

Desempener, to take away the fea­
thers, as of an arrow or bolt.

Se Desembucher, to rush out of an
ambush, or laying in waite.

Desempestrer, to rid himselfe of a 
thing: to vntangle.

Desemplir, to emptie, to lade out.

Desendormir, seeke Endormir.

Se Desenfler, to vnswell to asswage.

Se Desenfrongner & faire bonne
chere, to leaue frowning, to locke
cheerefully.

Desenger, to plucke vp by the roote:
to destroy an euill ympe.

Desenhorter, to disswade.

Desennuyer, to driue away weari­
nesse, to passe the time.

Desenroulé, put out of wages, or out
of the roule or number.





Desensevelir, the contrarie is, Ense­
velir, to burie one.

Desensorceler, to vnwitch.

Desenyvrer, to make sober againe,
contrarie to, Enyvrer, to make one
dronke.

Desert, a desart, a wildernesse: m.

Elle est Deserte, she is forsaken.

Desertion de cause, the leauing of
his action to fall: the forsaking of
his action.

Deservir, je desers, je deservi, j'ay
deservi, je deserviray, to deserue,
to earne.

Deservir sus table, to take vp the ta­
ble, looke Desservir.

Se Desesperer, to despaire.

Desespoir, desperation: m.

Iouër à la Despérade, to doe despe­
rately: f.

Desesperément, desperatly.

Desestimer, not to esteeme a thing.

Desestourdir, to come of a great mase
or astonishment.

Desfaire & rompre ce qui estoit faict,
 to breake or vndoe that which is
done.

Se Desfaire soymesme, to make him
selfe away, to kill himselfe.

Desfaicte, ou perte de battaille, the
defeat or ouerthrow of a battaile: f.

Desfascher, to take away griefe, to put
away anger.

Desfaroucher, to make tame.

Desfavorisé, out of fauour.

Desfaveur, m: disfauour.

Desfermer, to open.

Desferrer vn cheval, to take of a hor­
ses shooes.

Se Desfier, to mistrust.

Desfiance, ou diffidence, mistrust,
diffidence: f.

Desfiement, m: idem.

Vn Desfi, m: a defying.

Desfigurer, seeke Défigurer.

Desfiler, to vntwist, to vnweaue.

Desfleurer, to defloure.

Desfonser vn vaisseau, to knocke the
head of a vessell.

Desfortune, f: a misfortune.

Desfortuné, vnlooked.

Desfouïr, to dig out.

Desfrayer, seeke Défrayer.

Desfricher, to rid a ground of rootes
and thistles, to make it arable: to
grub: to shrub: to rid it from bus­
shes.

Lieu Desfriché, an arable ground.

Desfroncer, or Desfrongner, to shew
a merie countenance.

Desfroy, see Défrayer.

Soy Desfuler, to put off his cap, to
make obeysance.

Desgager, to fetch out of pledge.

Lon nele put Desgager, he could not 
be loose.

Desgainer vn glaive, to vnsheath, to
draw a sword.

Se Desgarnir de son armée, & la ba­
iller à vn autre, to vnfurnish.

Desgarni & descouvert, vnfurnisht,
or lying open: see Garnir, for the
declining.

Se Desgeler, to thawe.

Desgluer, to vnglew, to loose.

se Desgorger, to vomite, to spue out
his venime.

Desgourdir, je desgourdis, je des­





gourdi, j'ay desgourdi, je des­
gourdiray, when our hands or feete
being as it were a sleepe or numbd
through cold, doe waxe warme: or
when one doth carrie fish aliue, for
feare he should die by the way, he
putteth the same into the water to
reuiue it, wee say, Desgourdir le
poisson.

Desgourmer vn cheval, to vncurbe
a horse.

Aisé Degouster, & pour peu de
chose, one that will easilie lothe a 
thing: a nice or daintie person.

Voz parolles m'ont tout Desgous­
té, your speech hath put me out of
taste, hath discouraged me.

Desgoutement de viandes, lothsom­
nesse of meates: m.

Desgrader, to degrade, to vnhallow.

Desgrapher deux navires, to vn­
claspe two ships.

Desguiser, to disguise, to alter.

Feincts & Desguisez, fained, coun­
terfeite, disguised.

Desguisement de marchandise, coun­
terfeit or vntrue wares: m.

Deshabiller, to make himselfe vn­
readie, to put off his clothes.

Deshair, sadnesse, strife, disorder: m.

Tu m'as deshaité, thou turnest my
mirth into sadnesse.

Deshanché, he that hath his hippes
broken, or out of ioynt.

Desharnacher vn cheval, to take off
the trappings or harneis and fea­
thers of a horse.

Deshériter, to disherite.

Deshérité & privé de la succession,
 disherited, put from possession.

Desheritement, a disheriting: m.

Deshonnorer, to dishonour.

Deshonneur, dishonour shame: m.

Deshonneste, vnhonest, vnseemely,
vnfitting.

Deshonnesteté, dishonestie: f.

Deshonnestement, vnhonestly.

Deshonté, without shame.

Deshouser, to plucke off ones bootes.

Deshouser vne mule, to take off the
foote cloth from the mule.

Il est Desja tard, it is late.

Avez vous Desja fait? haue you
done alreadie?

Desjanter vne rouë, to take away the 
circle of yron which is about a cart
wheele.

Desjeccatif, m: any thing hauing the
vertue to die.

Desjeuner, seeke Desjuner.

Designer les limites, to prescribe the
limites and bounds.

Ces choses designenet & signifient
quelque meschanceté, these things
doe signifie or prognosticate some
mischiefe.

Desjoindre & separer, to seuer, to
separate: see Ioindre, to decline
it.

Desjoingnement, a separating: m.

Desjoinct, desjoincte, asunder seue­
red, separated.

Desir, desire, affection, appetite, lust: m.

Desirer, to desire.

Fort desiré, much desired, in good esti­
mation.

Desireux, m: one that desireth greatly.

Desirant, desiring.





Desirable, a thing to be desired, com.

Desister, to leaue off.

Deshucher vn oiseau, to beate downe
a birde from the rouste or pearch.

Desjuner, to breake ones fast.

Le Desjuner, a breakefast.

Ie ne me suy point encor desiuné de 
cela, that is, I haue not taste yet of
that, I haue heard yet nothing of
that.

Tout deslabré, m: al ragged, full of
ragges.

Deslater vne maison, to vnlath a
house, to take away the laths.

Se delasser, to vnwearie himselfe.

Desléer & destramper, to soake, to
delay.

Deslier, to vnbinde, to loose.

Deslié, loose, vnbound.

Desloger, to departe from home, to
vnlodge.

Deslogement, departing from home,
changing of lodging: m.

Ie ne l'ay onques peu faire Deslo­
ger, I was not able to driue him
from his place.

Desloyal, vnfaithfull, vntrustie: m.

Desloyauté, vnfaithfulnesse, treche­
rie, falshood: f.

Desloyalement, or desloyaument,
 falsely, vnfaithfully.

Deslouër, to blame, to dispraise.

Desmailler, to vndoe or breake a coate
of male.

Desmaillotter, to vnswaddle.

Desmailloté, vnswadled.

Desmaillottement, m: vnswad­
ling.

Des-maintenant, yea presently.

Desmancher, to take off the helue of 
an axe, or like instrument.

Desmanteler, to take ones Cloake,
also to beate downe the walles of a 
towne.

Desmarcher, to goe backe, to stir from
a place.

Desmarer, to set sailes, and to goe to
Sea.

Desmasquer, to take off the maske.

Desmaintenant je vous mets en li­
berté, euen now I set you at libertie.

Desmaintenant, from henceforth.

Se Desmarier, to vnwed, to diuorce.

Desmembrer, to dismember, to teare
in peeces.

Desmembré, rent, torne in peeces.

Desmembrement, a tearing in pee­
ces.

Desmenter, see Dementer.

Il l'a Dementi, he told him he lied.

Desmesler, to rid, not to meddle with
a thing, to cleere matters intang­
led.

Desmésuré, immeasurable.

Licence desmesurée, disordred with­
out order or measure.

Vne grande Demesure, without all
measure: f.

Demesurément, vnmeasurably, with
out all reason.

Desmettre quelque membre hors
de son lieu, to put out of ioynt, to
misplace.

Desmettez vous de telles entrepri­
ses, giue ouer such enterprises.

Membres Desmis de leur lieu &
desnouëz, members put out of 
ioynt or place.





Demission de roy, f: acknowled­
ging by tenaunt to holde his lande
of his Lord.

Desmeubler, to take away the hous­
hold stuffe from a place.

Desmoëler, to take away the mar­
row, to weaken.

Desmonter, to take from his horse, to
take off the Artillery from his frame.

Se Desmouvoir de sa constance, to 
change or remoue from his constan­
cie, to change opinion.

Desmunir, or Desgarnir, to vnfur­
nish.

Desnaturé, vnnaturall, which hath
changed his owne nature, a weake
person through the diminishing of
his nature.

Desnerver, to weaken.

Desnicher, to driue a bird out of
his neast, also to driue a man from
his place.

Desnigrer, to diffame ones name, to 
speake euill of one.

Desnigration, f: diffaming.

Desnouër, to vnknitte, vntie.

Se desnouër quelque membre, to
vnknit a bone, to put out of ioynt.

Desnuër, to make naked, to spoyle.

Desnué d'amis, voyde of friends.

Desobeïr à son mastre, to disobey, to
be stubborne.

Desobeïssant, disobedient, stubborne.

Desobeïssance, disobedience: f.

Desobliger, to release of his obliga­
tion or band.

Desolation, f: ou desolement, m:
 desolation, ouerthrowe.

Desolément, comfortlesse, desolately.

Povre fame desolée, without solace.

Desoler, to leaue or make desolate: 
to ruine.

Desordonné, disordinate, without
measure or order.

Desordonnément, aymer, to loue
without measure.

Desordre de toutes choses, confusi­
on, disorder: m.

Desormais, yet, for all that, hence­
forth: a worde compound of des,
ores, and mais.

Desourdir, to vnreaue, to vndoe that
which is wouen.

Despecer, to cutte in peeces, to break 
in sunder.

Despecé à grans coups d'injures,
 shaken vp with reuilings: railed.

Despecement, a renting in pieces: m.

Despendre, to spende, to consume, to
waste away: je despens, je despen­
di, j'ay despendu, je despendray.

Despendre, dissiper, gaster, & con­
sommer ses biens ou son patri­
moine, to spende away all his in­
heritance.

La république despend de Brutus,
 the publique weale dependeth on
Brutus.

Despens, expenses, cost, charges: m.

A ses Despens, at his owne charge
or perill.

Despense, expense, charge: f.

Despence, a butery: also small wine
mingled with much water: f.

Despencerie, butterie: f.

Despenaillé, ragged, torne.

Despeindre, to paynt, to drawe with
a pen or pencill: see Peindre for





the declining.

Despenser, to spend, to bestowe.

Il a Despensé à ce bastiment tant &
plus: he hath bestowe on that buil­
ding mountaines.

De la Despence: small wine for the 
household: f.

Vn Despensier, a cater: he that bui­
eth cates.

Despense & perte, cost, or losse: f.

Despensier, qui a la garde de la vi­
ande, a steward, hee which keepeth
the butterie.

Faire bonne despesche & se haster,
 to dispatch, to make haste: f.

Se Despescher, to make short.

Ie a heu sa Despesche: hee is dis­
patched: he hath his discharge: f.

Desespessir, esclarcir vne chose
trop espesse, to make thinne, to
clarifie: see Espessir, for the de­
clining.

Despestrer aucun & delivrer, to rid
one out of troubles

Despeupler, to vnpeople, to waste, to
spoyle.

Despiécer, to rent, to put the peeces
a sunder, to teare.

Despit, or despiteux, qui se cour­
rouce aisement, a spitefull fel­
low.

Se Despiter, to spite, to anger, to take a
matter in snuffe.

Se Despiter contre quelcun, to doe
a thing spitefully against another,
to anger him.

Despitonné, squemish, as les femmes
sont, de nature, Despitonnées, wo­
men be of nature squemish.

Despiteusement, for spite, spiteful­
ly.

Despité, spited, angred, vexed.

Despiteux, angry, wayward.

Desplacer, to displace.

Desplaire, to displease.

Ie me Desplay, it greeueth or dis­
pleaseth me: I am weary of my selfe,
or of my life.

Estre Desplaisant de quelque cho­
se, to be displeased with a thing.

Faire Desplaisir, to doe one a displea­
sure, to offend one.

Desplaisance, displeasure, griefe of
minde: f.

Recevoir Desplaisance pour l'a­
mour d'aulcun, to receiue displea­
sure for another mans sake.

Mais qu'il ne vous Desplaise, by
your leaue: that it may not displease
you.

Desplanter, to pull vp by the roote.

Desplier, to vnfolde, sometime to
make manifest.

Desplié & estendu, vnfolden, spread
abroade.

Despliement et maniement de jam­
bes, the folding or turning of the 
legges: m: nimblenes of legges.

Desplumé, to be without feathers.

Desplumer, to pull of the feathers.

Desposseder, to put one out of his pos­
sessions.

Despouiller, to spoyle, to vnclothe, to
put off.

Despouilleé, vnclothed, spoyled.

La Despouille des ennemis, the
spoyle of enemies: f.





Despouillement, a spoyle: m.

Despourpré, which hath lost his pur­
ple colour.

Despourveu, seeke Desprouveu.

Despravé, on dépravé, depraued,
marred, corrupted.

Déprier, to call our praier or suite
backe.

Despriser, to dispraise, to blame, to
contemne, to despise.

Desprisé, dispraised, despised.

Despriseur, a despiser: m.

Despris, or mespris, contempt, despi­
sing: m.

Desprisable, dequoy on ne doit
faire compte, dispraisable, com.

Desprisement, a dispraising, a con­
temning, a setting at naught: m.

Desprisonner, to deliuer one out of 
prison.

Desprisonné, absolued, set out of prison.

Desprouveu, vnprouided for, vn­
wares.

Il m'a prins à Desprouveu, hee tooke
me vnwares, vpon a sodaine.

Ceste fame est Desprouveuë de sens 
& entendement this woman is be­
reft of sence and vnderstanding.

Despuceler vne vierge, to defloure a 
maiden.

Desraciner, to roote out.

Desracinement, rooting out: m.

Desraisonnable, vnreasonable.

Se Desranger, to goe out of the ranke
or order.

Desrangé, out of order.

Desreiglé, vnruly, vnmannerly, ma­
lapert.

Desreiglement, m: vnrulinesse.

Desrester, to deliuer out of the nets:
Enrester, is the contrarie.

Desridement, the vnwrinkling of the
skinne: m.

Desrider, to take away wrinckles.

Desriver vne chose rivée, to take a
naile or such like out of his due and 
right place.

Desrobber, to steale.

Chose Desrobbée, stollen goods.

Desrobbeur & pilleur, a theefe, a 
robber, a picker, a pilferer: m.

Desrobement, stealth: m.

A la desrobbée, priuely, secretly, by
stealth: f.

Desroy, as faire quelque desroy to
worke mischiefe: m.

Estre en Desroy: to bee out of order,
as when souldiours be broken.

Desrocher vne maison, to take down
to destroy a house.

Desrompre, seeke Dérompre.

Desrondir quelque chose, to bring
out of compasse.

Desroquer vn home, when in wrast­
ling he is cast downe.

Desrougir, to lose his red colour.

Desrouiller, to scoure, to furbush, to 
get out rust.

Desrouler, to rolle out, to declare.

Desrouter, to put one out of his way.

Desroute, a putting to flight: f.

Desrumé, that hath put away his
rheume or cold.

Desrumer, to put away the rheume.

Desruné, out of order, taken downe,
taken in peeces.

Desruner, to set out of order.





Se dessaisir, to forgoe, to let loose.

Desséeler, to take away the seale.

Desseler vn cheval, to take the sad­
dle from the horse.

Dessengler, to loose the girthes of a 
horse.

Desserrer, to release, to vnshut, to
open, to loose.

Desservir sus table, to take vp the 
table.

Desserte, or dessert de table, the ban­
quet or after course: f.

Vous me faites tort sans desserte,
 you doe mee wrong without deser­
uing.

Desseurer, despartir, or Desmesler, to
put asunder, to part two men fighting.

Dessiller, to vnwrappe his eyes, to re­
store the sight, to vnseele, to vn­
blindfield.

Desseings, the purpose and determi­
nation of one: m.

Se dessoiver, to quench his thirst.

Dessoler vn cheval, to take away the
hoofe of a horse.

Dessorseler, to deliuer one from en­
chantment, to vnwitch one.

Dessoubs, beneath, belowe.

Dessoulder, to dissolue, to loose.

Dessus, aboue, aloft.

Le dessus de toutes choses, & com­
me la face, the vpper parte of a 
thing.

Destacher, to vntie: also to take away
a spot.

Desteler les chevaux, to loose horses,
or vnspang them from the carte.

Destendre, to stretch out, to spreade: 
see Iendre for the declining.

Destendu, stretched or retched forth:
but rather loosened, as the string of
a lute.

Destiltre, to vnweaue.

Destin, destiny: m.

Destiner or dessegner choses en soy­
mesme & proposer, to appoint, to
purpose.

Destiné à la mort, appointed to death.

Vne année destinée & féée à la de­
struction de la ville, a yeare appoin­
ted to the destruction of the towne.

Cest ma Destinée, f: it is my destiny.

Destituer & delaisser vne chose 
commencée, to disappointe or make
destitute, to forsake.

Destitution: f: & delaissement: m:
 destituting or disappointing, forsa­
king.

Dostombir ses mains, to vnnumbe
his hands when they be numbe with
colde."unnumb" not found in OED.

Vne destourtoire, or Destournoire,
 a little rod or sticke wherewith one
doth driue aside boughs and bran­
ches riding in a wood.

Destouper, to vnstoppe: f.

Destordre, to wring or wreith.

Destourse, f: ou destordement: m.
 wroong or wreithed.

Destorse: f: & fourvoyement: m.
 a straying or winding out of the way.

I'ay Destors, ou je me suy Destors
le pied, I haue wrinched my foote.

Destorse, is taken for misfortune, hin­
drance, or encombrance.

Destour, lieu entre les montaignes où
on se retire, a place betweene hils,
where men may hide themselues: m.





Lieu où il y a beaucoup de De­
stours, a place with many crooked
wayes: m.

Destourber, to trouble, to disturbe,
to hinder.

Estourbier, ou destourbement, a 
trouble, let, hinderance, m.

Vn destourbeur, qui par son ca­
quet empesche & destourbe au­
cune chose, a troublesome man, a
prating fellow: m.

Destourner aucun, to disswade a man
from his purpose, to bring him out
of the way.

Destourner aucun chose, & la des­
robber, to conuey a thing away.

Se destourner d'aucun, to forbeare
ones company, to withdraw his fa­
uour from him.

Destourné, disswaded, turned from
his purpose, out of his way.

Lieux destournez, by-places.

Qui destourne par parolles, a dis­
swader.

Destourner l'eauë par petits ca­
naux & ruisseeaux, to dryue or
turne water by little furrowes or 
brookes.

Destournement d'eauës, a turning
of the course of water an other way,
a drawing or turning of water ano­
ther way.

Destrancher à coups de langue, to
rebuke one sharpely, to rattle vp.

Destranché despecé à grans coups
d'injures, ratled vp with reuilings.

Destraindre, je destrains, je de­
straint, j'ay destraint, je destrain­
dray, to strayne or presse.

Destrainte & angoisse d'amours, f:
 distresse in loue, one ouerpassioned
by loue."overpassioned" (and "overpassion") not found in OED.

Destraver, to loose one out of shackles
or giues: the contrary is Entraver.

Destremper & mesler ensemble, &
ramollir, to soften, to mollifie, to al­
lay as wine with water, to soake.

Destrempé & meslé parmy d'autre,
 soaken, softned, or allayed.

Destremper du poisson salé, to steepe
or water saltfish.

Destresse, distresse, griefe, anguish: f.

Vn destroict, a straight, a narrowe
place: m.

Le destroict des chemins, a straight
in the way.

Vn destrier, a horse of armes: m."horse of arms not found in OED.

Destrousser, to spoyle, to robbe.

Destrousseur de gents, a robber: m.

Destroussement de gents, a robbing
of men by the high way: m.

Destruire, to destroy, to waste, to o­
uerthrow.

Destruction, destruction, waste: f.

Destruict & gasté, destroyed, wasted.

Destruiseur, a destroyer: m.

Desvalizer, to robbe one by the high
way.

Desveiner, to take away the veines &
the face.

Desveloper, to vnwrappe, to shewe
forth, to vnfolde.

Desvelopé, vnfolden.

Desvelopement, an vnfolding.

Desverrouiller vn huis, to vnlocke a
doore, to vnbolt.

Desvestir, to vnclothe: see Vestir.

Desvier, to put one out of his way, to





goe out of this life, to dye.

Desvisager aucun, to disfigure one.

Desvailer, to discouer, to take off the
veile.

Desunier, je desunis, je desuny, j'ay
desuni, je desuniray, to disioyne, to 
put a sunder.

Se desvoyer, or desvier, to erre, to
stray, to wander.

Desvoyement d'estomach, weaknes
of the stomacke: m.

Vn Det à jouër, a Die, or a paire of
Dice: pronounce Dé: m.

Detail, as acheter en gros, et vendre
en detail, to buy by great, and sell by
retaile: m.

Merchante en detail, a marchant sel­
ling by retaile.

Detailler & mettre en piéces, to hew
in peeces.

Detenir, to holde, to detaine, to occu­
pie, see Tenir for the declining.

Detenteur, m: he that holdeth any
thing from one wrongfully.

Deteriorer & empirer quelque cho­
se, to make any thing worse.

Determiner, to determine, to conclude.

Determinance de quelque chose,
laquelle apres avoir esté disputée
& detatuë, est mise à fin, the deter­
mining or ending of a thing: f.

Deterrer, to bring out of the ground.

Deterrer vn home, to put one out of
his land

En temps de guerre lon voit tant de
povres gens deterrez, in time of 
warre men do see so many poor folke
disherited.

Detester, to detest to abhorre.

Detestable & abhominable, detesta­
ble, abhominable.

Se détordre les bras, to wreith his
armes, see Destordre.

Détracter & mesdire d'autruy, to 
backbite, to speak euill behinde ones
backe.

Detracteur, a backbiter, a slanderer: m.

Par Detraction, slaunderously: f.

Se detraquer, to goe out of his way.

Detraqué, hors du trac, out of the 
path way.

Detriment hurt, hindrance: m.

Deu, debt, due, seeke Devoir.

Deuëment, duly, rightly.

Deuë, see Induë.

Devaller, to let downe, to tumble
downe.

Devancer, to excell, to goe before.

Devancer aucun à courir, to outrun
one.

Devanciers, our predecessours: m.

Devant quelque vn, before one.

Devant & derriere, before and bee­
hind.

Aller au devant, to go to meet one.

Devant que, before that.

Vn devantier, devantal, devanteau
or Tablier, an apron: m.

Devenir, de devien, je devins, je suy
devenu, je deviendray corps, to
waxe a body, to become.

Devenir riche, to become rich.

Que Devindrent tous ces gens?
 what became of those men?

Devers, towards.

Regarde devers moy, looke towardes 
me.

De devers Orient, towards the East.





Devider du fil par pelotons, to
winde vp threed in bottomes.

Vn devidet, on devidoir, a reele to
winde threed on: m.

Devier, looke Desvier.

Vn devin, a southsayer, a gesser: m.

Deviner, to soothsay, to gesse, to di­
uine.

ning.

Devineresle, a woman soothsayer: f.

Devinement, coniecturing, diuinati­
on, soothsaying: m.

Devint, became, see Devenir.

Devisager, seeke Desvisager.

Deviser, to talke, to deuise, to com­
forte.

Vn devis & ordonnance, a deuise or

Vne Devise, a posie, a colisance."colisance" antedates earliest OED citation (1641).

Devise, f: as il porte pour sa devise 
le croissant, he hath for his deuise.

Devoir, seeke Debvoir.

Devolu, a benefice, Lordship or like
fall into the Lords hands: m.

Devorer, to deuoure, to swallow vp.

Devotion, deuotion, religion: f.

Devot, deuoute: m.

Fame fort Devote, a very deuout wo­

Devotement, deuoutly.

Devoué, as brebis devouées à la
boucherie, sheepe appointed for
the slaughter.

Deux, two.

Deux à deux, two by two, by couples.

Tous deux, both.

D'eulx, pour de eux, of them, or from
them.

A dextre, on the right hand.

Dexterité, nimblenesse, handsome­

Dextrement, nimbly, properly, aptly.

Diademe, a Kings Crowne: m.

Diafané, shining, glistering.

Dialectique c'est à dire, l'art de bi­
en disputer, Logicke or good order
of disputation: f.

Dialecticien, m: a Logician.

Dialectiquement, Logically, as good
Logician ought to doe, after the arte 
of Logicke.

Dialogue, a dialogue: m.

Vn Diamant, a Diamond: m.

Cœur Diamantin, m: a hearte as
hard as a diamond.

Diaphane, shining like a starre, dia­
mond, or looking glasse.

Diapré, les champs diaprez, fieldes
and medowes diuersified through 
diuers flowres, diuersly wrought.

Dict, diction, dicter, seeke Dire.

Dict or dit, mon-dit pere, my said fa­
ther, son-dict frere, his said brother.

Dictamon, or Gingenbre de jardin,
 an herbe growing in Candie called
ginger, hauing the property to draw





out any thing fastened in the bo­
die: m.

D'icy, ou des icy, from hence.

D'icy à quel temps? Howe long? in
what time? how long hence?

D'icy en avant, from hence forward.

Diéte & regime de vivre, Diet, day­
lie fare: also a parliament & assem­
blie of the states of the Empire: f.

Dieu, God: m.

Dieu-donné, a mans name.

Diffame, euill name, euil reporte: m.

Diffamer quelqu'vn, to defame one,
to slaunder one, to take away ones
good name.

Estre diffamé, to be defamed.

Diffamation, a slaunder: f.

Differer & delayer, to deferre, to de­
lay, to driue off.

Differer de jour en jour, to deferre
from day to day.

Dilation & dilayement, deferring,
delaying: f.

Vn Different & debat, a debate, a
strife, a contention: m.

Estre en different & discord, to bee
at variance, to disagree.

Difference, difference, diuersitie: f.

Differemment, distinctly.

Difficile, hard, difficile.

Difficulté difficultie, hardnesse: f.

Difficilement, hardly, scantly, with
much adoe.

Difforme, vnseemely, filthy, out of
fashion.

Defformité, or difformité, vnseeme­
linesse: f.

Digerer, quand l'estomach cuit 
bien la viande qu'il a receuë, to
digest.

Digue de loyer, worthy of reward.

Dilaté, inlarged.

Dilation, a delay: f.

que chose, diligent, carefull, studi­

carefully.

Dinanderie, a place where copper
wares are solde: it is taken also for
any thing made of brasse, f.

Dipsade, a venemous serpent, whose
biting casteth one to such drinesse,
that through drinking (falling into
dropsie) dieth: m.

Dire, to say, to speak, to shew, to talk:
je dis, je di, j'ay dit, je diray.

On dit, it is sayd abroad.

Dict commun, a worde, a common
talke: m.

Mon dire touche plusieur, my talke





toucheth many: m.

sentence: m.

Vne diction, a saying: f.

Dicter & nommer à vn autre quel­
que chose qu'il escrive, to endite
letters.

Dictateur, m: a Magistrate among
the Romanes which had royall au­
thoritie for the time.

Directement, directly.

Ligne directe, a straite and direct
line.

Directeur, a leader: m.

Diriger, to order or direct.

Discepter, to dispute, to debate.

Discerner, separer l'vn d'avec l'au­
tre, to discerne, to separate the one
from the other.

Discretion ou seperation, difference
or separating: f.

Disecret, discreete, wise, aduised.

Discretement, discreetely.

Disciple, a scholler.

Les Disciplines liberalles, liberall
sciences.

La Discipline de l'Eglise ancienne
est fort diminuée, the discipline of
the auncient Church is much de­
cayed.

Discordant, disagreeing.

Discours d'esprit de tous costez, 
quand il pense à quelque cho­
se, to consider well, to cast euery

Discourir, to discourse, to examine a
matter, to make a discourse vpon

Discrucier, to vexe one.

Faire discussion sus les biens du
debteur, assavoir s'il est solva­

to pay: f.

or light man.

Divers, diuers, vnlike.

Divin, holy, godly.

Divretique, which hath the facultie
to make one pisse.
