Chose divulguée & semée par tout,
 spread abroad.

Dix, ten.

Dix ans, ten yeeres.

Dixiesme, tenth.

Pour la Dixiesme fois, for the tenth
time.

Dixsept, seuenteene.

Dixhuit, eighteene.

Dixhuitiesme, eighteenth.

Disneuf, nineteene.

Dixneufiesme, nineteenth.

Dizain, that containeth the number
of ten.

Vn dizain, a tenth, a Dittie of ten
verses: m.

Vne disaine, as you say, vne dou­
saine, a dosen.

Dober quelcun, to beate one.

Il a esté bien dobé, he hath beene
throughly beaten.

Docte & sçavant, a learned man, a
man of knowledge.

Estre docile, easie to be taught, com.

Docilité, aptnesse to learn, docilitie: f.

Doctement, learnedly.

Document, a precept: m.

Docteur en droit, a Doctor of the ci­
uill law: m.

Doctorie, the degree of a Doctor: f.

Dodeliner, to bring vp want only, as a
cockney, to lull.

Dodeliner, idem: also to becke.

Dogue d'Angleterre, a mastie Dog
of England: m.

Doctrine & enseignement, doc­
trine, instruction: f.

Doctrinal, the paterne of learning: 
Marot.

Doit, as grand peuple doit sortir d'­
Abraham, great people must or 
ought to issue of Abraham.

Vn doigt, a finger: m.

Vn doigtier, a thimble, a finger­
lyng: m.

Vn doisil, a faucet: m.

Dol, deceit: m.

Doler du bois, to bowe or square tim­
ber.

Vne doloire, f: a litle axe or hatchet.

Dolet, sorowfull, heauie, painfull,
greeuous.

Doleur de corps et d'esprit, sorrowe 
of minde, paine of body: f.

Avoir doleur, to haue paine.

Faire douleur, to greeue.

Appaiser la douleur d'aucun, to as­
swage ones greefe.

Se dolouser, to mone, to bewaile.

Doleance, greefe: f.





Doloir: je me deulx, je me doulu, je 
me suy doulu, to mone & sorrow.

Doloureux, m: full of sorrow.

La teste me deult, my head doth ake.

Dolentement, mourningly.

Domestiquer, to tame.

Domestique, homely, of our houshold.

Domicile, a house, an abiding place.

Dominer, to gouerne, to rule.

Dominateur, a ruler: m.

Domination, rule, power, gouerne­
ment: f.

Dominorier, like dominer.

Dommage, losse, hinderance, da­
mage: m.

Dommageable, hurtfull.

Dommageablement, with damage.

Dommaine, ou Doumaine, seeke
Demaine.

Domaniaux, as expoits domaniaux,
 iudgements put to execution within
a Lords Libertie: m.

Dompter, seeke Donter.

Dompte-venim, f: an hearb whose
vertue and strength is to abate poy­
son.

Dompte-vilain,  a good cudgell or like
toole to tame a stubborne knaue.

Don, m: a gift, see Donner.

Donq, Donc, or Donques: then, there­
fore, Ergo.

Que feray je Donques? what shall 
I doe them?

Dongeon, a dungeon: m.

Donner, to giue, to deliuer, to graunt.

Donné le premier de Ianvier, giuen
the first of Ianuarie.

Don, a gift, a graunt: m.

Donaison, a donation, a donaizon: f."donaizon" not found in OED.

Donation, a gift: f.

Donnement, a giuing: m.

Donne-vie, the giuer of life.

Dont, whence, or whereby.

Donter, to subdue, to ouercome, to
rule, to tame, to daunt.

Donté, tamed, daunted.

Dontement, a taming: m.

Donzelle, a fish like a Cunger: f.

Dorade poisson, a fish, of some thoght
to be called a Gilthead: f.

Dorer, to gilde.

Doré, or Dorée, gilt, faire, as venus
la Dorée, the faire Venus.

Dorure or Doreure, a iewell of two
peeces, gilting, bilyments: f.

Dores-en-avant, from hence forward,
hereafter.

Dormir, je dors, je dormi, j'ay dor­
mi, je dormiray, to sleep, to slumber.

Dormilleux, a drousie, sleepie one, a
sluggish one.

Dormitorie, a medicine prouoking
or casting one into a sleepe.

Dortoir, a Chamber or place where
many doe sleepe, also a churchyard.

Le Dos, the backe: m.

Dose, that quantity of drinke or me­
dicine which the Phisition appoin­
teth the Apothecarie to giue to the
sicke person.

Dosserasse, f: any thing vpholding
the great beame vpon a wall.

Dossier, any thing that stayeth the
back: as vn banc à dossier, a forme
with railes to stay the backe.

Dost qu'vne femme baille à son
mari pour son mariage, the dowry
that the wife giueth her husband





in mariage.

Dotal, as apenage dotal the portion
giuen for a dowrie.

Elle a vn bon Douäire: she is well in­
dowed, or shee hath a good dow­
rie.

Douäire que le mari baille à la fa­
me, The dowrie or ioynter that the
husband giueth vnto the wife: m.

Douäriére, a widdowe which hath a 
ioynter: f.

Douäne, the custome house at Lyons
in France: m.

Double, double: m: also a kinde of 
money in Fraunce woorth a far­
thing.

Le double de quelque escripture,
 the copie of a writing.

Le Double, the double: m.

Doubler, to double.

Doublement, doubly.

Vn Doublement, a doubling.

Doublement d'escripture, a copying
out of a writing.

Vn Doublet, m: a dublet.

Dela Doublure, f: lyning for any
garment.

Doublier, a long and large table, ha­
uing a cloth hanging on euery side
to the ground.

Doubte, doubte, suspition, feare: f.

Mettre quelque chose en doubte, to 
put a thing in doubt, to bring a mat­
ter in controuersie.

Doubtement, a doubting: m.

Doubter, to doubt, to feare.

Doubteux, doubtfullie, vncer­
taine.

Vne chose Doubteuse, a doubtefull
thing.

Doubtance, f: doubting.

Doubteusement, doubtfully.

Douër, to endue, or endowe one.

Doué de Beaucoup de vertus, enri­
ched with many vertues.

Vne Douille, f: the canon or yron of
a iauelin.

Douillet, delicate, dainetinesse: dein­
tie, m.

Faire bien de la Douillette: a very
fine, nice, or daintie dame.

Vn Douït, douët, or doet: m: a
brooke: a spring.

Doux, gentle, louing, sweet, tractable,
smoothe.

La main, la peau Doulce, a smoothe
hand, skinne.

Doucet, somewhat sweete.

Douceastre, sweetish.

Douceur, sweetnesse, gentlenesse, cour­
tesie, mildenesse: f.

Doucement, sweetely, gently, louing­
ly, mildely.

Douleur, seeke Dolent.

Dousil, a faucet: m.

Douves, the ditches of a castle: f.

Douze, twelve.

Vn Douzain, a shilling, in France a
soulz.

Douzaine, a dozen.

Vn Doyen, a Deane.

Doyenné, a Deaneship.

Dragée, dredge, iunkets, comfites.

Dragée aux chevaux, Prouender for
horses.

Drageon, or Bourgeon pampier,
 a braunch of the vine which bea­
reth no fruit.





Dragon, m: a dragon.

Drame, or Dragme, a Dramme, a
waight with the Apothicaries.

Dramer quelque chose, & en vser
par mesure, to vse any thing by 
measure.

Drap, woollen cloth.

Petit Drapeau ou Drapelet, a clout: 
an ensigne.

Draperie, a draperie.

Drapier, a Draper.

Drappier drappant, a clothwor­
ker: m.

Drap bien Drappé, clothe well
wrought.

Dresser, to direct, to set vp.

Se dresser, to stand vp.

Dressoir ou buffet, dresser, a cup­
bord.

Drillante flamme, a glistring, or shi­
ning flame.

Toute drougue bonne ou mauvaise,
 drugs, Apothicarie ware.

Drogueur, hee that selleth such
ware.

Vin or boisson drogué, wine or drink
mixt, brued with sugar, spices and
such like: also a poysoned drinke: m.

Drogueman, that is, Trucheman, an
interpreter: m.

Droict, right: m.

Droit d'obeine: see Aubain.

Droit de buche, such fees as officers
of the woodyard haue, or allowance
of wood in euery office at the princes
court.

Droit de verre, fees of those of the
ewerie, and so of the rest.

Tout Droict, right forth.

Droictement, directly.

Droictement à l'heure,  iust at that
houre.

Droict & raison, right and reason: m.

Bon Droict, good right.

Droicture & raison, right and rea­
son.

Droiturier, vpright.

A bon Droict, rightly.

Conseil Droicturier, & qui va à 
la rigueur de raison, straight coun­
sell.

Droictement, rightly iustly.

A tort ou à droit, by hooke or crooke,
by right or wrong.

Drole, m: a good fellow, which careth
little how the world goeth: a wag.

Cest vn Drole, he is a wag.

Droler, to play the wag.

Drolerie, f: waging.

Dromant, or Dromon, a kind of ves­
sell vpon the sea: m.

Dru & espez, thicke, as the falling
downe of raine: liuely, lustie.

Oiseau Dru, m: a bird readie to flie
from the nest.

Dryades, the Nymphes of the
woodes: f.

Du milieu, from the middest.

Du chemin, from the way.

Dinarchie, where the souerainetie is in
two princes hands: f.

Duc, a Duke: m.

Ducal, belonging vnto a Duke.

Duché, a Dukedome: m.

Duel, the combat betweene two: m.

Dueil, dole, sorrowe, heauinesse,
griefe: m.

Avec Dueil, with griefe.





Se duire & façonner, to accustome,
to frame himselfe, to enure.

Duire ses subjects aux armes, to ac­
custome his people to warre.

Il est Duit & façonné à cela, he is
trained vp, &c.

Cela me duit & convient, that fit­
teth me very well.

Il est bien duisant & convenable,
 the same is seemely, proper, or con­
uenient.

Vne Dune, the Dounes: f.

Dunette, little Dounes: f.

Duplique, as Repliques, Dupli­
ques, Tripliques, & Quadru­
pliques, all kinde of replies in the
lawe.

Duquel j'avoye acheté ceste mai­
son, of whome I bought his house.

Dur, hard.

Home Dur & rude, a hard man.

Coucher sur la Dure, to lye on the
ground.

Duret, hardish: m.

La cuisse Durette, the things some­
what hard: f. stiffe: f.

Dureté, hardnesse: f.

Durement, hardly, straightly.

Durcir, to waxe hard.

Durer, to harden, to continue, to last
long.

Durant ces iours là, during that
time, or those dayes.

Longue Durée, of long during or 
lasting.

Qui est de Durée, durable.

Se Duire & accoustumer, to be enu­
red with a thing.

Duire quelqu'vn à quelque chose
par accoustumance, to enure one
by custome.

Duict à rendre l'equité, brought to
yeeld right.

Duisant & convenable, fit, conueni­
ent.

Duisable, fitly, profitablie, com.

Duisson, an accustoming: f.

Duvet, doune, soft fethers: m.

Vn lict de Duvet: a bed of doune fe­
thers: m.

Trouver la Duyere du connil, to
finde the cunnie hole.

Dysenterie, ou flux de ventre a­
vec la sang, que les Italiens appel­
lent Caque-sangue, a bloodie
flixe: f.

Dy senterique, com: of the bloodie
flixe.


E ante A.

EAge, seeke Aage: m.

Eauë, water: f.

Eauë de depart, les frais de l'affine­
ment en mart, se fait par voye de
ciment royal, ou eauë de depart,
 water to fine mettals.

Ebaucher, seeke Esbaucher.

Ebene, seeke Hebene: m.

Eboulu, seeke Esboulu.

Ebrieté, drunkennesse: f.

Ebulicion, boyling or bubling vp: f.

Ecailler, seeke Escailler.

Ecamotée, see Escamoter.

Echelle, f: a ladder.

Echelon, the step of a ladder: m.

Vn Echelette, in chirurgerie, it is
called a skelton, or anatomie.





Eclypse de Lune, Eclipse of the
Moone: f.

Eclypser, to vanish away.

Ecloy, vrine.

Ecolleté, see Escouleté.

Edenter, to dash out ones teeth.

Edenté, toothlesse.

Edict, ordonnance, ou comman­
dement faict par le prince ou
magistrat, an ordinance, a com­
maundement, a proclamation, an
iniunction.

Edifier, to build, to edifie.

L'edifice que fait le masson & char­
pentier, the Mason and Carpentere
building: m.

Edification, building: f.

Edificatuer, a builder: m.

Education, f: a bringing vp.

Effacer, to blot out, to deface.

Effacement, a defacing or blotting: m.

Effassure, a blot, a blurre: f.

Effaroucher, to make fierce, to make
wilde.

Effect que l'art faict, the effect of the
workemanship: m.

Effect & pouvoir, effect and power.

Mettre en effect, to bring to effect.

Effectuër ce qu'on a deliberé, to 
bring to passe his determination.

Effectrice de quelque chose, shee
which is the cause that a thing is
done: f.

Esprouver par effect, to proue in ef­
fect: or indeede.

Effeminer, to effeminate, to make wo­
mannish.

Home Effeminé, an effeminate man,
a weakling.

Effemination, effeminating, making
one like a woman: f.

Efficace, force, strength, vertue, effi­
cacie.

Efficacement, strongly, with vertue
and efficacie, effectually.

Efficient, la cause efficiente, the
cause whereby any thing is finished,
or brought to passe.

Effigie, an image or likenesse: f.

Effigier, to drawe any thing with the 
pen or pensell.

Effleurer, to defloure.

Effundrer, ou esventrer, to vnbowel, 
to drawe a fish, or capon.

L'effort qu'on met à faire quelque
chose, the endeuour or good wil that
one hath to doe a thing: m.

Faire Effort à quelcun, to offer vio­
lence to any.

Le grand Effort: with great inde­
uour, inforcement or violence.

Efforcement, m: endeuor, violence.

Efforcément faire quelque chose, to
doe a thing with great endeuour or
might.

S'Efforcer, & travailler à faire quel­
que chose, to enforce or labor to do
a thing, to inforce or endeuour.

Effray or effroy, feare, astonishing, a­
bashing, amazing: m.

Effrayer, or effroyer, to feare, to a­
maze.

Effrayant, fearefull.

Effrayable or effroyable, dreadfull.

Effrayablement, with amazednes,
after a fearefull sorte.

Effreintes, f: see Espaves.

Effrené, vnbridled, vnruled.





Effrenémen, without order or rule: m.

Effrenation, f: an vnbridled maner.

Effronté, m: shamelesse.

Effrontément, shameleslie.

Elle est toute effrontée & eshontée,
 she is altogether shamelesse: she
hath a brasen face.

Effrouër, or esmier, to crumble in
small peeces.

Effroy, seeke Effray.

Effeuiller, to take off the superfluous
leaues of the Vine, trees, and such
like.

Effeuilleur, m: a Pruner, he that ta­
keth superfluous leaues of the vine.

Effeuillement, m: that action, that
is, pruning or nipping of the super­
fluous leaues.

Effusion d'eauë, purging out of wa­
ter, shedding: as Effusion de sang,
shedding of blood: f.

Egal, equall, like, paire.

Egaler, to make equall.

Egalement, equally.

Egalizer, to make euen.

Egalizement, a making equall.

Egestions, as l'engant n'a point en­
cor les Egestions par le fondement,
 the child casteth nothing by the fun­
dement, or downward.

Eglise, Church.

Egousser des pois, to shale peason.

Egoziller, to cut ones throte.

Egratigner, to scratch.

Eguillon, a pricke or sting: m.

Eguillonner, to pricke, to prouoke
one.

Eguïser, to sharpen.

Il luy perca l'Eine d'un seul coup, at
one stroke he pearced him through.

L'Eine, qui est vne partie du corps,
 the grine: f: the part about the pri­
uie parts.

Elabouré, wrought.

Elancer, to pricke with a Lancet.

Elarger, seeke Eslargir.

Elation & hautesse de cœur, stout­
nesse of mind: f.

Electeur, a choser: m.

Electif, subiect to election, as the king­
dome of Poland and Denmarke,
where the Kings are chosen by the 
Estates.

Election, a choise: m.

Le droict d'Electorat, m: the right
and power to choose: as the seuen
Electors of Almaine.

Electuäire, m: an electuarie.

Elegamment, eloquently, handsome­
ly, trimly.

Elegance, f: finenesse.

Element, the Element: com.

Elementaire, of the Element: com.

Element, ordinances of this world, or
first beginnings.

Vn Elephant, an Elephant: m.

Elevation, a heauing vp: f.

Elider, or Escacher, to burst or squise
out.

Elle, f: she.

Ellebore blanc, m: Lingwort, an
hearbe.

Ellebore noir, Beares foote.

Elle, c'est le feminin de Luy, she, the
feminine of he.

Ellée, as, Bailler les ellées à vn che­
val, to giue a horse the head: f.





Ellend, m: a wild beast in Prussia like
a fallowe Deere, which neuer lieth
for want of ioynts in his legges, ve­
rie good venison.

Eloquent, eloquent, well speaking: m.

Eloquence, eloquence: f.

Elucider quelque chose, to make 
bright, to declare or expound a thing.

Emaillures d'or ou d'argent, bullions
or riuets of gold or siluer: f.

Email, Amell: m.

Emailler, enamell.

Emanciper, to giue ouer, or set at free­
dome.

Emancipé, giuen ouer: made free.

Emanées, as Ordonnances emanées
du roy, decrees made by the King,
or comming from the King.

Embabouïner, to deceiue, to bring
into fooles paradise, to moufle one.

Emballer de la marchandise, to pack
vp marchandise.

Emballeur, he that doth packe vp
ware: m.

S'embarquer, to embarke, to take
ship.

Embarquement, a shipping: m.

Embarrer son espée en vn arbre, to
fasten his sword in a tree.

Heaume embarré, the Helmet faste­
ned to the head through blowes.

Embas, ou en bas, below.

Embassade, a message: f.

Embassadeur, an Embassadour, a
messenger: m.

Embaster, to lay on the packe saddle.

Embattonner, to arme one with
staues.

Embatre, to ariue, to rush in.

Il luy embatit l'espee jusques au
foye, he thrust his sword into the
liuer.

Embattes, windes blowing out of the 
East orderly about the Canicular
dayes.

Embaucher, to set one to worke.

Embaumer des corps morts, to em­
baulme dead corpses.

Embellir, to decke, to trim, to furnish,
to set forth, to beautifie: j'embellis,
j'embelli, j'ay embelli, j'embelli­
ray.

Embellissement, m: beautifying.

Embellissage, or embellissement, m:
 beautifying, setting forth.

Embesongné, occupied.

Emblaver, to sowe a peece of lande
with corne.

Champ emblavé, or terre embla­
vée, a field sowen and the corne be­
ing alreadie growne.

Emblemes, fine sentences with pic­
tures, and posies.

Emboire, to staine, to moyst or wet.

Embu, distained.

Terre embuëde sang, earth wet with
blood: embrued with blood.

Embler, to steale.

A l'Emblée, stealingly, priuilie.

Embompoint, m: the good disposi­
tion or liking of the bodie in a man
or woman.

Emboucher quelqu'vn, to instruct
one before hand, to tell him his les­
son.

Home bien Embouché, one which
had his lesson well told.

Mal Embouché, euill instructed, who





speaketh lyes by another mans tale.

Emboucler, to buckle, to claspe to­
gether.

Embouchoir, as mettez mes bottez
à l'Embouchoir, car elles sont
trop estroites, set my bootes on the
last, for they be too strait: m.

Embouër, or embourber, to bedirt,
or bemud one.

L'embouchure d'vne riviére, the 
entrie or issue of a riuer into the
sea: f.

L'embompoint d'vn home ou d'­
vne fame, the good bodily state of
one: m.

Embourrer, to bombase: to foist in: f.

Embourser, to lay vp in his purse.

Embraser, to set on fire, to enflame: to
glow like a coale.

S'embraser, to bee kindled, or all on
fire.

Embrasé, kindled, set on fire, glowing.

Embrasement, glowing, firing, en­
flaming: m.

Embrasser, to coll, to clippe, to em­
brace.

Embrassement, m: or Embrassade, f.
 a colling, a clipping.

Embrener, to beshite one.

Embrocher de la chair, to spit meate.

S'Embrouiller en quelque affaire,
 to cumber himselfe with a matter.

Embrouillé en proces, wrapped in
the law.

Cause, or Chose fort embrouillée, an
intricate matter.

Embroncher, to bowe downe the 
necke and head through some great
blow.

Embronché, m: bowed, astonied tho­
rowe a blow.

Embuches & espies, priuy waytings,
snares: f.

S'Embucher, to lye in waite or am­
bush.

Embuscade, ambushment: f.

Emendation, an amending, a correc­
ting: f.

Emender, to amend a thing.

Emeute, a stirre, a rebellion: f.

Emerillon, a Merlin, Hawke.

Eminant & surparsant les autres, to
bee hier than other, to excell an
other.

Eminence, passing aboue other: f.

Emmaigrir, j'emmaigris, j'emmai­
gry, je suy emmaigri, j'emmai­
griray, to waxe leane: to make a 
thing leane.

Emaillotter, to wrap in swathling
bands.

Emmaillotté, wrapped, swathled.

Emmancher, to helue, to set a hilt 
or handle, to a weapon or toole.

Emmanné, full of Manna.

Emmantelé, couered with a cloake.

Emmarteler, to bewitch, to intrappe,
to poison one with loue or like allure­
ments

Emmartelé des furieus assaults d'a­
mour, intrapped, caught, bewitched
with the furious assaults of loue: 
also to bee hoarse, or haue the
reume.

Emmatrieuler quelcun en la ma­
tricule de l'vniversité, to receiue
one as if it were in the bosome of the
Vniuersitie.





Emmener avec soy, to lead with
him, to carrie abroad.

Emmener par force, to lead away by 
force.

Emmeubler & ammesnager sa mai­
son, to furnish a house with stuffe.

Emmi le palais, in the middest of the
hall, or pallace.

Courir Emmi, or avau les rues, les
champs, to run about the streetes,
or fields like a mad man.

Emmieller & amadouër, to allure, to
intise, to tolle.

Emmiellé, intised, tolled.

Emmiellure, honey-sweete.

Emmitrer vn Evesque, to put the
Miter on a Bishop.

Emmonceler, to heape togither.

Emmurer, to wall about.

Emmuseler, to mousell.

Emmusquer, to perfume.

Emologuer, to admit a law, Patents,
or like.

Lois Emologuées, lawes admitted.

Emonctoire, m: the emunctorie, that
is, purging issues or places of the bo­
die, as from the braines to the eares,
from the heart to the armepit, out
of the liuer to the grines.

Emmont, vpward.

Emolument & profit, profit graine: m.

Emonder, seeke Esmonder.

Emoucer, to make dull or blunt.

Emoucher, seeke Esmoucher.

Empainte, or Emprainte, as à la pre­
miére empainte ilz abatîrent tous
ceux qu'ils rencontrêrent, at the
first onset they ouerthrew all such as
they met: f.

Il l'empaint tellement que le glaive
vola en pieces, he stroke him in
such a sort that his sword fell in pie­
ces.

Empaler vn home, to spit one vpon
a stake and so put him to death.

Empanaché, set with fethers: as vn
armet bien empanaché c'est à di­
re qui à vn beau panache, penna­
che, ou plumas, an helmet well set
with fethers.

Empan, or Empalin, m:: a span, the
breadth of ones hand.

Empaqueter, to packe vp.

Emparer, or saisir, to sease, to take
possession: the contrarie is Desem­
parer.

Les enemis se sont emparez & 
fait maistres de la ville, the ene­
mies haue occupied and seased the
towne.

S'Empatronner de quelque chose,
 to make himselfe master and Lord
of any thing.

Emparfumer, to parfume one, or any 
thing or place.

Empaulmer, to take in the palme of
the hand, to sease.

Empenné, fethered.

Empereur, m: the Emperour.

Emperiere, f: or imperatrice, the
Emperatrix, that is an Emperours
wife.

Emperler & orner de perles, to deck
with pearles.

Empescher de faire quelque chose,
 to hinder, to let, to withstand.

Empesché, hindered.

Empeschement, a hinderance, a let: m.





Empeser, to starch.

Empois, m: starch.

Empestrer quelqu'vn, to pester, to
trouble, to let, to hinder one.

Emphiteose, f: the making of a thing
better then it was when it was ta­
ken or receiued.

Heritage baille en emphyteose, land
giuen on a condition that the tenant
shall make it better.

Emphyteosien, he which taketh any
thing conditionally to make it be­
ter.

Empienne de soulier, f: the vpper
leather of ones shooes.

Empierrer aulcun, to transforme or
change any person into a stone.

Empiégé, or prins au piege, taken
in a snare.

Empire, empire, rule, gouernment: m.

Empereur, an Emperour, an head
commaunder. m.

Empieter, to holde with his foote.

Empirer, to make worse, to decay, to
compare.

S'Empirer, to waxe worse and worse.

Empirance, the decay, the laying
which is made in gold or siluer done
by Goldesmiths in mingling copper
or any other mettall with golde or
siluer: f.

Empirique, Phisitions going from
place to place to set out their ware, a
Phisition by practise: m.

Emplaider vn home, to thrust a
man and intangle him in the law.

Emplastracion, or enture en escus­
son, when two diuers armes be as it
were graffed and ioyned together in
the scutchion: f.

Vn Emplastre, a plaister: m.

Emplir, to fill: j'emplis, j'emply, j'­
ay emply, j'empliray.

Empli, filled.

Vn emply journel, quand on se sert
tous les jours d'vne chose, a dayly
businesse or occupation: m.

Employer & despendre à quelque
chose, to bestowe, to lay out on a 
thing.

S'Employer à faire quelque cho­
se, to giue him selfe to doe some
thing.

Ne s'Employer point, not to doe his
endeuour.

Employer tout le jour, to bestowe all
the day.

Employé, bestowed.

Employement & despence, a be­
stowing or charge: m.

Envoyer à l'Emplette, trafiquer ça
& là, to send about his businesse and
traffique, to send to buy ware.

Marchandise d'Emplette or d'em­
ploite, a ware or marchandise of
good sale, which may bee well vt­
tered, of a good vtterance: m.

Femme qui est encore de bonne
Emploite, a woman which is not
olde, but may be, &c.

Emplumer, to garnishe with fea­
thers.

Empoigner, to lay hands vpon one, to
catch.

Mal-Empoint, in ill plight.

Empoisonner, to poyson, to venime.

Empoysonneur, a poysonner: m.

Emoisonnement a poysoning: m.





Empoisser, to couer with pitch.

Empoissé, pitched.

Empoissonner, to furnish his Ponde
with fishes: as riviére, ou table bien
empoisonnée, a riuer or table
full, or well garnished with fishes.

Emporter, to carie away, to take a­
way.

Emportement, m: a carying away.

Empoule, a wheale, a blister, a push,
a bubble: f.

Empoule, a viole: f.

Empouper, to haue a prosperous and
good winde blowing at the Sterne,
and driuing the ship forward: as vn
vent gratieux empoupoit nostre
navire, a sweet and gratious winde
did driue our ship.

Enpourprer, to enriche a Tapestrie
with colour of purple.

Vn traict Empourpré de sang, an
arrowe dyed with bloud.

Empreindre, to print in, to presse in.

Empreinct, printed, signed.

Empreincte & marque, a print or
marke: f.

Emprendre, or entreprendre, to take
in hand.

Empris, taken in hand.

Empresser, to presse out, to thrust to­
gether, to squise.

Empreut, the first word of our num­
ber: as Empreut, deux: one, two.

Emprisonner, to imprison, to lay in
prison.

Emprunter, to borrow.

Emprunt, borrowing: m.

Aller aux Empruns, to go aborrowing

Emption, f: buying.

Empuäntir, or Empunaisir, to cause
a great stinke, to fill with stinking
smell.

Empuänti, Empunaisi, filled with
filthy or stinking smell.

Emputer, to dilate or dryue off the
time.

Vn emputeur, or delateur, a secret
accuser, a pick-thanke: m.

Emulateur qui à envie sur aucun,
 an enuious person.

Emulation, enuie: f.

En apres, afterward.

En ce, in that.

En chemin, in the way.

En jouänt, in iest, in play.

En oultre, furthermore.

Enamérer, to make bitter.

Enamourer, as s'Enamourer de
quelcun, to fall in loue with one.

Enaser, to cut off ones nose.

Ençant, comme vendre à l'ençant,
 portsale: m.

Encadener, to tie one in a chaine.

Encarrer et tirer à aulcun, to leuell
and shoote at one.

Encaver, to make hollowe.

Encaver des vins, to take wines into
the seller.

Encaver les nids des poules, to make 
hennes nestes in a wall.

Enceindre & entourer, to girt in,
to compasse about: decline it as
Ceindre.

Encens, frankensence: m.

Encenser, to sence.

Encensoir, a censor: m.





Encensiére, herbe, f: flebaine or co­
niza.

Encerné, as Alexandre le grand sem­
bloit estre tellement Encerné de
flammes de feu que &c. Alex­
ander the great seemed so enuiro­
ned with flames of fier, that &c.

Enchainer, to enchaine.

Estre enchainé, to be tied in a chaine.

Elle est Enchainée attourée d'af­
fiquets, comme si elle tenoit bou­
tique d'orsevre, she is with her
chaines and Iewels as &c.

Enchanteler, or mettre sur le chan­
tier, to stay vpon a stake as Vines be
in France.

Enchanteler du bois, to set wood in
piles.

Et qui t'a ainsi Enchanté? who hath
bewitched thee so?

Enchantement, enchanting: m.

Enchanter, to enchant, to bewitch, to
charme.

Les enchanteries sont descouver­
tes, the enchantementes are disclo­
sed.

Enchapeler, to set a hatte vpon ones
head.

Enchapeler des chapeaux de fleurs,
 to set garlands of flowers vpon ones
head.

Enchappé, clothed, or couered with a
Coape.

Encharger quelque chose à aucun,
 to charge, to enioyne one the doing
of a thing.

Encharneler or enchalasser vne vig­
ne, to prop a vine.

Enchasser en or, to chace in golde.

Mettre à L'Enchere, to raise the
price, to make deare.

Encherir les vivres d'vne armée, to 
raise the victualles in an armie.

Encherisseur, a raiser of price.

Les vivres sont encheris, victuals
are waxed deerer.

Encheper, to set one in the stocks.

Enchevestrer, to halter, to muzell.

Enchevestré, muzled, snarled, en­
tangled.

Encirer, to waxen.

Enchiser les arbres, to cut trees a­
bout.

Enclaver dedens, to close in, as when
two peeces of timber are inclosed
one with another, to morteise.

Enclaveure, when a peece of ground
goeth or entreth into another mans
ground, morteising: f.

Enclin, enclined, giuen, bent.

Encliner, to encline, to bend to.

Encliner, to incline to.

Encliné veres terre, bent to the ground­
ward.

Enclore, j'enclos, j'ay enclos,
j'enclorray, to enclose and parke
in.

Enclos, enclosed, emparked.

Dedans cest Enclos, m: within this
inclosing.

Enclosture, f: ou Clos, m: a close.

Enclotir, j'enclotis, j'encloti, j'ay
encloti, j'enclotiray, to driue a 
cunny, Foe or like into their clap­
per.

Enclouër vn Cheval, to naile or
pricke a horse.

Vne Enclume, an Anuile: f.





Les Encoigneures des parois, when
the corners of two diuers walls meet
togither: f.

Encocher vn vireton, or vne fleche,
 to nocke an arrowe.

Estre encombré de dueil & d'en­
nuy, to be compassed with sorrow
and care.

Encombriers, troubles, combers: m.

Encommencer, to begin.

Encommencement, beginning: m.

Encontre, a chaunce: f.

De bonne Encontre, with a good
lucke.

Encontrer, to meete, to encounter
one.

Enconvenancé, promised, as vous
m'avez enconvenancé, that is
promise: you haue promised vnto 
me.

Encordeler, to intrap.

Encordeler vn arc, to string a
bowe.

Encorner vn arc, to nock a bowe.

Encorneter, to put in a horne.

Encotonner, to bombase any thing.

Encotonner de barbe le menton,
 when the beard beginneth to spring
out in a yong man.

Encoulper aulcun, to lay the fault v­
pon one, to accuse one.

Encoulpeur, an informer.

Encourager, to encourage one.

Encouragement, encouragement: m.

Encourir grand deshonneur, to run
to a discredit, deshonestie.

Il est encouru es peines de la loy,
 he is run within the danger of the
law.

I'ay encouru la male grace du Roy,
pour l'amour de vous, I haue gotten
the kings displeasure for your sake.

Encre, m: incke.

Cornet à encre, an inckehorne.

Encrouster or Crespir, to plaster or
daube, to parget.

Encuict, hardened through heate.

Matiere fecale encuicte, mans dung
hardned, by too great heate of the
bodye.

Encourtiner, to shadowe.

Encourtiner vn lict, to garde a bed 
with curtaines.

Encuïrasser, to harden, when a softe
thing becommeth hard.

Encore, yet.

Encore d'avantage, yet further.

Encuser, to disclose, to appeache, to be­
wray.

Encusé, disclosed, a bewraying: m.

Endazé, indented.

S'Endebter, to become indebted.

Estre endebté, to be indebted, to en­
ioy other mens goods, to be in other
mens danger.

Endementé, m: wanton.

Vous estes fort Endemené, you play
the wanton.

Endementiers, in the meane while,
in the meane season.

Endenter vne herse ou rateau, to set
teeth in an harrowe or rake.

Endiablé, to be possessed with the
diuell.

Enditer, encuser, ou emputer au­
cun, to indite one.

Enditement ou delation, m: indite­
ment.





Il esté endité ou attaint, & convain­
cu du fait, he hath been endited &
conuicted in the fact.

Endive, vne sorte de Cicorée qu'on
appelle Endive, Endiue: f.

Endiveler les gerbes, to set sheaues
in heapes by tenne.

Endoctriner, to instruct.

Endesver, to be mad, to rage.

I'endesve, or desire de te voir, I doe
earnestly desire to see thee.

Ie Endesve de s'enfuïr, he burneth
through earnest desire to runne a­
way.

Endoctriner, to instruct, to bring
one vp in good nurture.

Bien Endoctriné, well brought vp.

Endommager, to hurt, to hinder, to
dammage.

Endommagement, hinderance, m.

Endormir, to lull asleepe: see dor­
mir.

Endormi, sleepy, drousie.

Se desendormir, to rise from sleepe.

Endormissement, sleepinesse, slug­
gishnesse: m.

Endormisson & estonnement de
membres, the sleeping or benum­
nesse of the members: f.

Andosser vn harnois, to put on har­
nesse vpon his backe, to be armed.

Endouille, a Sausage or chitter­
ling: f.

Vendeur d'endoilles, or Saulcices,
 hee that selleth chitterlings or such
like.

Endouiller, or entouiller, m: the first
branch of a Harts horne nexte the
head: the second is called Sur-en-
douiller: from the same to the top,
are called Chevilleures, or Cors:
those of the top, we call, Espois: ac­
cording to their proportion, we call
them, Fourché, Trocheure, Pau­
mure, Coronneure.

Quant à mon endroit, as for me, as
touching my parte: m.

Robbe à deux endroits, a coat made
for both sides.

Endroit la maison, aboute the
house.

Enduire, to dawbe, to annoynt, to be­
smere.

Enduict & frotté, annointed, rubbed.

Enduisson & frottement de quel­
que liqueur, an ointment: f.

Endui, ou enduisson, soit de plastre
ou de chaux, & sable, the dawbing,
plastring of a house: the plastring
or casting of a wall.

Endurcir, to harden: j'endurcis, j'en­
durci, j'ay endurci, j'endurciray.

Endurer & souffrir, to endure, to suf­
fer, to beare.

Endurement, a suffering, a bea­
ring: m.

Endurant, suffering or bearing.

Enerver, to weaken, to diminish.

Euneuque, or chastré, one that is
gelded: m.

Enfant, a childe: m.

Enfance, childhood: f.

Des son Enfance, from his childe­
hoode.

Enfanter, to bring foorth childe.

Enfanté, brought foorth.

Enfantement, a childing, a bringing
forth a childe: m.





Enfantiller, to play as little children
doo.

Enfançon, or enfanson, a little child:
m.

Enfantile, as raisons enfantiles chil­
dish reasons.

Enfantin, or raisons d'enfant, chil­
dish reasons, or of a childe.

Enfardeler, to pack vp.

Enfariner, to white with meale or flower.

Enfelonir, or devenir felon, to waxe
fierce or cruell: j'enfelonis, j'enfe­
loni, je suy enfeloné, j'enfeloni­
ray.

Enfer, Hell: m.

Enfestau, or festiére, a roofe tile: m.

Enfieller, the contrary, Emmieller,
to make bitter as gall.

Enfermer, to shut vp.

Estre enfermé à la clef, vnder locke 
and key.

Vne Enfermerie, a closet, a lodging
for a sicke man: f.

Vn Enfermier, m: he that hath the
ouersight of sicke persons.

Enfermement, a closing, a shutting
vp: m.

Enferrer, to lay in yrons.

Les Enfers, Hell.

S'enfierir & s'enorguillir, to waxe
proude, to waxe lofty: je m'enfie­
ris, je m'enfieri, je me suy enfieri,
je m'enfieriray.

Enfiler vne aiguille, to threede a
needle.

Enflamber, to enflame, to kindle.

Estre enflambé, to be enflamed.

Enflambement, an inflamation: m.

Enfler, to swell.

Enflecheures, the Ladders of cordes
to goe to the mast top.

Enflé, swollen.

Enflure, a swelling: f.

Enflement, swellingly: m.

Enfleurir, to spread with flowers.

Enfolastré, to be in loue, as je suy tant
enfolastré de moy-mesme, I am
so farre in loue of my selfe.

Enfondrer les navieres, to sinke ships,
to drowne.

S'enfondrer, to bee sunke to be drow­
ned.

Enfondré, sunke.

S'enfonser, to be sunke, to the bottome.

Enfonser vn huis, to beate in a
doore.

Enforcir, to inforce, to strengthen.

s'Enforcir, to waxe strong, to take a 
good heart.

Enformer, to giue forme or shape.

Enfouïr dedans terre, to digge vn­
der the ground: j'enfouïs, j'enfouï,
j'ay enfouï, j'enfouïrray.

Enfouï & enterré, digged and bu­
ried.

Enfourner, to take in an ouen.

Enfraindre, to breake: j'enfrains,
j'enfrain, j'ay enfrain, j'enfrain­
dray.

Enfroiduré, as je suy enfroiduré, I
am troubled with colde.

S'enfeuiller, to hide himselfe amonge
leaues.

S'enfuïr, to flee, to runne away, to
shunne: je m'enfuis, je m'enfui, je





me suy enfui, je m'enfuiray.

Enfumer, to smoake, to smother with
smoake.

Enfumé, smoaked.

Engager, to gage, or to laye to
gage.

Engagement, m: a laying to
pawne.

Engainer, the contrarie is Desgai­
ner, to draw his sworde.

Engelé, frozen.

Engarder & empescher que quel­
que chose ne se face, to withholde
the doing of a thing.

Garder l'Engeance, to keep the race
or seede of any thing for the en­
crease.

Enge, as l'Enge en est faillie, the of­
spring is fayled or lost: m.

Engeance, the seede or race of any
thing: f.

Engendrer, to engender, to beget.

Qui engendre, which engendreth.

Engendreur, an engendrer: m.

Engendrement, a begetting: m.

Engendrure, f: engendring.

Engeoler aucun, to caste into a 
Gayle.

Enger, to people, to garnish or fur­
nish any thing, that it may increase:
also to growe or encrease, la peste
ange fort, the plague encreaseth
much.

Engin & instrument, an engine or
instrument: m.

Engin & entendement, vnderstan­
ding, witte.

Mal-engin, deceitfull dealing: m.

Enginer, or engigner, to bewitch
to enchant: also to deceiue.

Engigneur, a deceiuer.

Estes vous Engigné? are ye so angry,
displeased or taken the snoffe, that
you will not eate your meate?

Englacer, je m'englace, I waxe as
colde as ice.

Engle, Engler, seeke Anglet.

Engloutir, or senglouter, to haue
the hecock.

Engloutir, to swallow vp, to deuour.

Englué, byrdlimed.

Engorger, to rauine gluttonously.

Engorgement, rauening: also the
place where a riuer falleth into the
sea: m.

Engouër, as S'engouër mangeant
trop goulement, to choake him­
selfe by eating too greedily: seeke
Anouër.

Le vent s'engouffre en ce lieu là, &
s'entonne, the winde whirleth in
that place.

Engouler, to deuoure.

Engeuleur, a sweller or deuourer of
any thing: m.

Engourdi de froid, benumbd with
colde.

Engourdissement, m: a benum­
ming for colde.

Engraisser, to fatten, to cramme, to
graze: to frank.

Engraisser, amender ou fumer vn
champ, to make fertill or battell a
fielde.

Engraisser vne beste, to fatten a beast,
to franke.

Engraissement de bestes, to graze or
fatten cattell: fatning: m.





Engraissé, fatned.

Engranger les bleds & les foins, to
bring into the barne corne and hay.

Engrener, to put corne into the hop­
per of the Mill to grinde.

Engraver, to graue, to cut.

S'engreger, to waxe sore.

S'engrossir, to waxe grosse, to waxe
thick: je m'engrossis, je m'engros­
si, je me suy engrossi, je m'en­
grossiray.

Engrossi, growne.

Engrossissement de femelles, to be
with childe, to be with young: m.

Faire enhaïr & trouver mauvais
quelque chose aux citoyens, to
bring the people in hatred with a
thing.

Enhanner, to sweate much about a
thing, to take much payne: see A­
hanner.

Enhancer vne pique, to set the iron of
a pike to his staffe.

Enhardir, to harten, to bolden, to en­
courage: j'enhardis, j'enhardi, j'ay
enhardi, j'enhardiray.

S'enhardir, to waxe hardy, to trust.

Enharnacher vn cheval, to dresse a
horse, & make him ready to battell.

Enhaster, to put to the spite.

En-hault, aboue, aloft.

D'en-hault, from aboue.

Enhazé, entangled with many and
diuers affayres.

Enherber, to bewitch one with hearbs.

Enherbement, poisoning with hearbs.

Enheriter aucun, to make one heire
of all his lande.

Enhorner, seeke Encorner.

Enhorter, to exhort, to perswade, to
require.

Enhorté & incité, moued, exhorted,
stirred.

Enhorteur, a perswader, an exhor­
ter: m.

Enhortement, an exhortation, a per­
swasion: m.

Enhui, ou aujourd'huy, today.

Nous ne pourrons estre En-huy là,
 we cannot be there today.

Enhuiler, to annoint with oyle, to put
oyle into any thing, to grease with
oyle.

Enjabler, to rigol a tunne, hogshead, or
barrell, and to put the heade vnto
it.

Enjamber, to put his legge ouer some
thing: it is taken for to encroche.

Enjaveller, seeke Iavelles.

Enjaveliner vn home, to arme a man
with a Iaueline: also to kill one with
a Iaueline.

Enigme, a riddle.

Enjoindre quelque chose à faire, to
appoynt any thing to be done, to in­
ioyne, to commaunde: see joindre
for the declining.

Enjouë, wanton, full of toyes.

Enjoncher, to strowe with flowers.

Enlacer, to snarle, to entrap.

Enlaider, to make foule, to make fil­
thy, to ray, to waxe hard fauoured.

Enlaidissement, a dishonestie, a di­
stayning, a defiling: m.

Enlanguagé, as home bien enlanguagé,
 a wel speaking man, which is eloquent.

Enlever, to rayse vp, to heaue vp, to
take away by force.





Petite Enleveure, & comme enffeu­
re qui se leve sus le pain en cui­
sant, a little bladder that riseth on
bread while it is baking: f.

Enlever vne fille, to conuey, or carrie
away a maiden.

Enlignagé, vn home bien enligna­
gé, a man of a great kindred.

Enluminer vn lieu obscur, to make
light or cleere a darke place.

Enlumineur de livres, a burnisher of
bookes: m.

Ennemy, m: an enemie.

Elle est ma grand ennemie, f: she is 
my great enemie.

Ennoblir, j'ennoblis, j'ennobly, j'ay
ennobly, j'ennoblirary, to make 
noble.

Ennoblissement, m: nobilitating, or
making noble.

Ennouër, to make a knot.

Ennombrer, seeke Annombrer.

Ennuy & fascherie, heauinesse, sor­
row, trouble, anger, grieuousnes: m.

Ennuyer, to molest, to trouble, to wea­
rie one.

S'ennuyer & fascher, to be wearie of
a thing.

Ennuyé & fasché, heauie, sorrowfull,
yrked.

Ennuyé de vivre, wearie of life.

Ennuyeaux, tedious, wearisome, yrk­
some: m.

Enombrager, to shadowe, to cloake.

S'Enordir, to defile himselfe.

S'Enorguillir, je m'enorguillis, je
m'enorguilly, je me suy enorgu­
illi, je m'enorguilliray, to waxe
proude.

Estre ennossé, to haue bones taken out,
to haue a bone sticking in the throat.

Ie suy enossé, I haue a bone sticking
in my throate.

Enorme, without measure: vn cas
enorme, a hainous deede.

Enormité, f: an enormitie, that is a
thing most odious.

Enormément, odiouslie, or beyond all
bounds or measure.

Enquerir, to enquire to aske, to de­
maund.

s'Enquester, to make enquirie.

Enqueste, a quest, an enquirie: f.

Monsieur l'enquesteur, m: the in­
quisitour, inquirer or examiner of
witnesses or any matter.

Estre fort enraciné, to be rooted in.

Enraciner, to roote in.

Enraciné, rooted in.

Enrager, to rage, to waxe mad.

Enragé, raging mad: m.

Estre enragé, to be starke mad.

Enrayer vne rouë, to set spokes to the
naue or stocke of a wheele.

Enrégistrer, to enroll, to register, to
Chronicle.

Enrégistrer ce qu'on a receu, & en
tenir compte au chapitre des re­
ceptes, to keepe a reckoning in wri­
ting.

Enrégistré, enrolled, enregistred.

Enrégistrement, an enregistring: m.

Enréter, to entrap in a net.

Enrheumé, vexed with the reume,
which hath the murre or pose.

Enrichir, j'enrichis, j'enrichy, j'ay en­
richi, j'enricheray, to enrich, to
make wealthie.





Enroller, or Enrotuler, to enroll.

S'enrouër, to be hoarse.

Enroué, hoarse.

Enrouëment, hoarsenesse: m.

S'enrouiller, to rust, to cancker.

Enrouillé, rustie, canckred.

Enrouillure, cancker: f.

Enrouler aux bandes, to be entred in
the roll of the bande.

Enroulez, enrolled.

Enroupié, see Roupie.

Enrouser, to water ground.

S'Enruisseler, s'escouler par ruisse­
aux, to run out in little chanels.

Ens, pour Dedens, within.

Cyens, here within, or Ceans.

Ensablonner, to fill with sand.

Ensafranner, to mingle with Safron.

Ensaisiner, to put one in possession.

Ensanglanter, to beblood: to embrew
with blood.

Ensanglanté, gore bloodie.

Vne Enseigne qu'on pend és mai­
sons, a signe.

Enseigne de recognoissance, a token
of remembrance.

Apparence & enseigne restant de
quelque chose, a marke or signe.

Ie vous diray les enseignes, I wil tell
ye the tokens.

Donner enseignes, to giue markes.

Enseignes, signes, tokens, markes,
notes: f.

Enseigne & estendart, a standart, an
Ensigne: f.

Enseigner, to teach, to instruct.

Enseigné, taught.

Vn enseigneur qui en a vn autre par
dessus luy, an Vsher of a schoole.

Enseignement, instruction, doctrine,
teaching: m.

Enseignemens & papiers, instruc­
tions.

Enseler vn cheval, to saddle a horse.

Ensemble, likewise, also together.

Ensemblément, togither.

Ensemencer vn champ, to sowe a
field.

Ensevelir, or ensepulturer, to burie:
j'ensevelys, j'ensevely, j'ay ense­
vely, j'enseveliray.

Enserrer quelqu'vn, to close one in, to
keepe one fast.

Enserrement, a closing: m.

Ensorceler, to bewitch.

Vn Ensorceleur, a witch: m.

Ensorcelement, a bewitching: m.

Ensorcelerie, witcherie: f.

Ensoulfrer, to fill with brimstone.

Eauës ensoulfrées, waters smelling
of brimstone.

Ce vin est ensoulfré, this wine is
brimestoned: that is, there is brim­
stone in this wine."brimstoned" not found in OED.

Ensuyvre, to followe, to doe the like.

Entablement, setting in a table, boar­
ding: m.

Entaché, or Entiché, to be spotted.

Ie ne suy point Entaché de cela, I
am not giltie with that.

Entailler & graver, to graue, to
carue.

Entaillé, carued, grauen.

Entailleur, a caruer of Images: m.

Entaillure, a grauing, a caruing: f.

Entalenté, as je suy entalenté, I haue
a great desire: I doe long.

Entalenter quelcun, to print in one a





great will and desire.

Entamer, to breake vp meate.

Entamez ceste espaule de mouton,
 cut vp, or begin to cut the first piece
of this shoulder of mutton.

Entamure de peau, a breaking of
skinne.

Entant que, in as much as.

Entasser, to gather into heapes, to pile,
to packe.

Entassé, piled, packed.

Entassement, heaping, a piling: m.

Vne Ente, a graffe: f.

Enter les arbres, to graffe trees.

Entement, a graffing: m.

Enteléchie, perfection, the cause
which causeth in vs all mouement
as well naturall, as willing.

Entendre, to heare, to vnderstand: j'­
entens, j'entendi, j'ay entendu,
j'entendray.

Entendre diligemment, to marke di­
ligently.

I'entens, I vnderstand.

Entendu & cognoissant, of vnder­
standing, wittie.

Entendement ou esprit que l'hom­
me a de nature, wit or vnderstan­
ding, conceit: m.

Perdre l'entendement, to leese his
vnderstanding.

Mettre son entente à faire quelque
chose, to intend to doe a thing: f.

Entendiblement, vnderstandingly,
learnedly.

Ententivement faire quelque cho­
se, to doe a thing intentiuely.

Entenne, the sayle yard: f.

Enter, to grafe: see Ente.

Enteriner des lettres royaux, to ad­
mit or allow letters patents.

Enterrer, to burie, to lay in earth.

Enterré, buried, couered with earth.

Enterrement, a buriall: m.

Entester, as ce vin m'enteste this
wine troubleth my head.

Entiché, seeke Entaché.

Entiché & corrompu, corrupt.

Entier, whole, vnbroken.

Vn home Entier, an vpright man.

Entiereté, wholenesse, sinceritie: f.

Entierement, wholie, faithfullie, sin­
cerely.

Entoiser vn arc, to bend a bow.

Entoiser vne espée, to lift vp a sword,
to strike one.

Entomber, to bring one to his graue.

On l'a aujourd'huy entombé, buried.

Entombi, or engordi, benummed: as
les membres Entombis, the mem­
bors benummed through cold: a
sleepe.

Entonnoir, a funnell: m.

Entonner, to tunne wine, or powre it
into tunnes.

Vne Entorce, a wrinching: f.

Il m'a baillé vne mauvaise entorce,
 he hath giuen me a sore ouerthwar­
ting.

Entortiller, to writh about, to wrig­
gle, to wind about.

Entortillé, writhed, winded about.

Entortillement comme d'vn serpent
qui se plie en rond, a writhing like
a snake: f.

Entouiller, to snarle, to comber, to en­
tangle.

Entour & circuit, about, round





about, compassing about: m.

Entourer, to compasse about.

Entourement, a compassing: m.

Entournure, a roundel, or circle: f.

Entrailles, the intrailes, the guts, the
inwards: f.

Entrainer, to draw away.

Entraver, to shackle: destraver is the
contrarie.

Entraves, gieues, shackles: f.

Iouöns entre nous, let vs play a­
mongst vs.

Il a tout entre ses mains, he hath all
in his hands.

S'entr'accointer, to become acquain­
ted.

S'entr'accoller, to coll, or embrace
one another.

S'entr'acompaigner, to keepe com­
panie one with another.

S'entr'accuser, to accuse one ano­
ther.

S'entr'advertir, to aduertise one an
other.

S'entr'affoller, to molest or hinder one
another.

S'entr'aider, to helpe one another.

S'entr'aimer, to loue one another.

S'entrappeler, to call one, &c.

S'entr'approcher, to drawe neere
one, &c.

Entrarracher, to plucke heere and
there.

S'entrassener des espées, to strike
one another with swords.

Entr'attacher, to tye one thing with
another.

S'entr'attandre, to tarrie and looke
one for the other.

Entre les gens de bien, among good
men, betweene good men.

Entrebaaillé, chapped or chinked, clo­
uen togither.

S'entr'embrasser, to embrace one a­
nother.

S'entrebaiser, to kisse one another.

Entrebastir, to build betwixt.

Entrebeu, as il est vn peu entrebeu,
that is, demy yvre, he hath drunke
a little more than needeth, he is
halfe drunke.

S'entreblecer, to hurt one another.

S'entrebrouiller, to intangle one, &c.

Entrebruire, to make a noyse among
other, to heare some noyse or ru­
mour.

S'entrebruler, to burne one, &c.

S'entrecaresser, to cherish one, &c.

Entrecasser, to breake by halfe.

S'entreceler, to hide or couer one, &c.

S'entrecercher, to seeke one, &c.

S'entrechamailler, to strike one ano­
ther, as men of armes doe.

Entrecharger, as la veuë m'entre­
charge, my sight diminisheth, dark­
neth, or waxeth darke.

S'entrecherir, to cherish one, &c.

S'entrechocquer, when two Armies,
or two enemies rush one against an
other.

Entre-cosser as les beliers s'entre­
cossent,  the Rammes doe but.

Entrecouler, to flow & run betweene,
as water or some other licour.





Entrecouper, to cut betweene, and as
if it were the halfe.

S'entrecourir sus, to run one vpon an
other in fight.

S'entrecraindre, to feare one, &c.

Entrecueillir, to plucke or gather be­
tweene.

S'entredemander des nouvelles, to
aske newes one of another.

Entredebvoir, as par la soy que nou
nous entre-devous, by the faith 
which we owe one vnto another.

Vn entredeux de murailles, a space
betweene two wales: m.

L'entredeux de quelque chose, the
space or partition between any two
things.

Vn entre-deux, m: a partition.

S'entrediffamer, to deface or discre­
dite one, &c.

S'entredire injures, to speake iniuries
one to another.

S'entredommager, to hinder one.

S'entredonner courage, to incourage

Entredormir, to slumber.

S'entr'ébrasser, to embrace one, &c.

S'entrepoigner bras à bras, to clasp
one another armes to armes as wre­
stlers.

Ils s'entr'entendent, they vnderstand
one another by collusion.

Sus ces entrefaictes, in this meane
while, while this was in doing.

Entr'esclos, halfe hatched.

S'entr'essayer à la jouste, to try one an
other at iustling.

S'entrefaire grand festé, to feaste one
an other through ioy.

Entrefendu, halfe clouen.

S'entreferir, to strike one another.

S'entreflatter, to flatter one, &c.

S'entrefouëtter, to whip one, &c.

S'entrefrapper, to strike one, &c.

S'entrefrotter, to rub one another, to
beate.

S'entregrater, or s'entregaller, to
rubb or scratch one another as hor­
ses doe.

Qui sçait bien son entregent, one of
god behauiour, that knoweth good
fashions.

Ils s'entrehayent fort, they hate one
another to the death.

Les moutons S'entrehurtent, the
rammes butte together.

Entrejecter, to cast betweene, to inter­
line.

Entreject, a putting or casting be­
tweene, but cheefely in words: m.

S'escarter, that is, se separer & s'e­

Escarteler, to cut in quarters.

Escerner au tour, to scrape or clense
round about.

Escervelé, harebrayned, cockbray­

Vn eschaffault, ou sont ceux qui re­

Eschafauder, to build scaffoldes, to
imagine some mischiefe.

Membres escachez, members squised.

Eschalas, a proppe for a vine, common­
