stayes in the vine.

Eschalotte, a Scallion: f.

Eschancrer, to indent, to dent.

Eschancrure, an indenting, a dent, a
notch: f.

Eschandole de bois pour couvrir
les maisons, an instrument of wood
wherwith they make euen the straw
when theye couer houses, therewith:
Some do think it to bee a shingle or
tile of wood: f.

Eschanger, to exchaunge, to chop, to
scorse, to barter.

Eschange, see troquer.

Eschanson, qui fait l'essay du boire
& du manger, a taster of meates
to kings or other: m.

Eschansonner, to make a say of meat,
drinke, or other things.

Eschantillon & monstre de quel­
que marchandise, a scantlin.

Eschantillonner, to cut and take off
a scantlin.

Eschapper, to escape, to slip away.

Eschappé, slipt away, escaped, saued.

Vn eschappatoire, a starting hole, a
by-rath, a scape: m."by-rath" not found in OED; possibly "a side-rath [earthen enclosure by]."

Escharde, a splint: f.

Escharpe, a scarffe: f.

Porter le bras en escharpe, to beare
his arme in a scarffe.

Donner vne grande escharpe, to
giue a great blow with a sword vpon





ones shoulder.

Escharcement vivre, to liue barely, to
liue hardly, niggishly, niggardly.

Escharde, a thorne, or stumpes or a
splint: f.

Aller sur Eschasses en temps de 
baultes neiges, to go vpon stilts in
time of high snowe.

Eschasses, crutches, stilts: f.

Eschabouillure, a push, a blaine, a 
blister, a wheale: f.

Vn Eschaudé, a wigge: m.

Eschauder, to scalde.

Eschausser, to warme, to heate, to
chafe, to burne.

Estre eschausté, to be warmed, to bee
chafed, to be burnt in filthy lust.

Eschauffement, chasing, warming,
heating: m.

Eschaufeture, or Eschaufaison, f: idem.

Eschauguette, a beacon: f.

Eschauguetteur, a viewer, a behol­
der whilest they fight in battell, a 
spie, an espiall in warres, a scoute­
watch.

Eschec, seeke Eschez: m.

Vne eschelle, a ladder: f.

L'eschelle d'vn navire, a ladder in a 
ship.

Escheller les murs, to scale the walles.

Vn Eschelette, a skeleton: a word of
surgerie: an anatomie.

Vn Eschelon d'eschele, the round or
stale of a ladder: m.

Il a este mis à l'eschelle & mitré, he 
was set on the pillorie, and a paper 
about his necke.

Eschemer, comme les mouches
à miel eschemen, sont leurs pe­
tites mouches, to swarm like Bees.

Escheoir, to happen, to chance, to fall 
out: see cheoir, to decline it.

Escheoir comme par sort, to fall by
lot, or by inheritance.

Successsion Escheuë, a succession fal­
len to ones hands.

Escheute de cent libres par an, a li­
uing of an hundred pounds a yeere
fallen to one.

Bien Escheans par faulte d'heri­
tier: aubain or droit d'aubaine:
 goods fallen into Escheate, an Es­
cheate.

Eschequier, seeke Eschez.

Escheveau, a skayne, a loope of silke, 
or thread.

Eschevelée, when a woman hath her
hayres all spred.

Eschever, to shunne.

Eschevin, a Sheriffe: m.

Les Eschevins & conseillieres de la 
ville sont assemblez, the sheriffes
and Aldermen of the towne are as­
sembled.

Eschevissement de dommage, a
harmelesse sauing: that is, the fact
whereby we saue one harmelesse, a 
scape from hurt.

Des Eschez, the Chessemen.

Eschequier, a Checker, a Chesse­
bourd.

Donner vn eschec, to giue a checke.

Eschif, as il est fort eschif he is very
greedy at his meate.

Eschiffler vne branche d'arbre, to
breake halfe the braunch of a tree,
as by the winde, or when it is too
much laden with fruit.





Tenir l'eschiquier & grans jours,
 to holde the Assises.

Eschiquier, le lieu où les commissa­
ires font justice, the court of the es­
chequer.

Eschoëte, or eschoite, a piece of land
or heritage happening by the death
of some of our kindred.

L'eschine, soit de l'homme ou be­
stes irraisonables, the chine bone,
the backe bone, the ridge.

Les os de l'eschine du dos & sem­
blables, the bones in the chine.

Eschiner, rompre l'eschine, to chine,
to breake the backe.

Eschoite, f: a piece of land fallen to
one.

Eschouër, to touch vpon a bancke or
sand sayling vpon the sea, to make a 
shipwracke.

A bon escient, in good earnest, in
good fayth: m.

A mon escient, with my consent, or
I knowing and willing.

Mentir à son escient, to lye willingly,
for the nonce.

Esclabocher, or esclaboter, to sprin­
kle one with dirt or water.

Esclair, Esclairir, Esclaircir, seeke
Escler.

Esclaire herbe, Selandine, Clarie.

Esclamme, f: a trauaileres cloake.

Esclanche de moutton, f: a legge of
mutton.

Esclandrir, j'esclandris, j'esclandri,
j'ay esclandri, j'esclandriray, to de­
fame, to dishonour.

Esclandre, a thunderclap, a slaunder,
slaughter.

Esclat ou latte, shiuers, chippes, a 
shingle, a lath: m.

Les esclats volerent en l'air, the shi­
uers flew into the ayre.

Son esclatant, a ratling noyse: m.

Esclave, a slaue: m.

Esclaver aulcun, to bring one to sla­
uerie.

Esclavine, or Esclamme, a pilgrims
mantle.

Escler que fait le tonnerre, the ligh­
tening of the thunder: fire breaking 
out of the cloudes: m.

Esclercissement & reparement,
 clearing, plaine shewing forth.

Esclisse où on met le fourmage
pour prendre sa forme, a cheespresse:
a little round circle made with wil­
lowes to set dishes vpon the bourd:
also splintes vsed about broken
legs: f.

Esclisser, to sparkle with ones mouth
or a squirt.

Esclissoire, f: a squirt.

Esclistre, the thunder-bolte in some
countrey of Fraunce, as Alexan­
dre estoit peint ayant l'Esclistre
en sa main: Alexander was pain­
ted hauing the thunderbolte or 
lightening in his hand.

Esclopé, maymed.

Esclorre des œufs, to clocke, to hatch
egges.

Vne Escluse, f: a floudgate, a waer.

Escoffray, a shoemakers shop: f.

Esconser, to hide.

Escole ou Colledge, a Schoole, a 
Colledge: f.





Maistre d'escolle, a Schoolemaster.

Vn escolier, a scholler: f.

Escolage, a schollers scholing, the wa­
ges of a scholler for his learning: m.

Escolleté, see Escouleté.

Escolastre, the superintendent ouer 
schooles, schoolemaster, & schollers.

Estre esconduict, to be denyed a re­
quest, to haue repulse.

Esconduire, j'esconduys, j'escon­
duy, j'ay esconduy, j'esconduiray,
 to denie ones request.

Escopette, escopetterie, a hote skir­
mish with gunshot: f.

Escores, all such stayes whereupon
the ship standeth while it is buil­
ding: f.

L'escorce de l'arbre, the barke of a 
tree, the rinde: f.

Escorcer, to barke trees, or rather
to vnbarke, to pill: to pull off the 
rinde.

Escorcement, a barking of trees, a 
pilling, a rinding: m.

Escorcher, to slay, to barke, to pill, to
parch.

Escorcheure du siege, the pieldnesse
of the seate: f.

Escorchement, a slaying: m: a parch­
ing.

Escorché, slayed: parched.

Escorner, as se laisser escorner to
suffer to be made a foole or idiot.

Escornisleur, m: a parasite or smell
feast.

Escornisler, to sit with those that be
drinking or banquetting, and goe
scotfree.

Escorte, guide and assistance of men
of warre for the safetie of victuals,
as je vous feray, or tiendray escor­
te, I will assist you in your way that 
you may passe in safetie: f.

Escort, dapper, handsome, trim, furni­
shed, aduised, circumspect: m.

L'escosse ou gousse de Febves, pois
& semblables, the codde of pease,
beanes, or other pulse: the hull or
huske of &c. f.

Escot, a shot: m.

Si vous vous attachez à moy, vous
payerez l'escot, if you deale with
me, you shall pay for it.

Escouër, to cut off the taile.

Chien escouë, a dogge which hath
lost his taile.

Escouffle, a kind of kitte: m.

Escouiller, to geld one, to strike one on
the cods, and so spoyle him.

S'escouler, to slide downe, to glide.

Escouleté, as des souliers escoule­
tez, shooes opened vpon the foot, and
tied with a buckle and a lachet.

Escoulement d'eauë, a sliding down,
or soft running of water: m.

Escourgée, a thong of leather, a lat­
chet or scourge: f.

Escourre, to thrash, to seuer the corne
from the chaffe.

Escourter, to shorten.

Chose escourtée, a thing shortened.

Escousse, vne grande escousse, a
great shaking: f.

Escouter, to harken, to listen, to giue
eare.

Escouteur, m: ou vne escoute, f: a
harkner, a scout, an eauesdropper: f.

Escoutement, harkening: m.





Escouër, to shake off, to fanne out, to
brush.

Escoutilles, the windowes or open
places whereby they let downe mer­
chandise or victuals into the shippe,
the hatches: f.

Escouvette, a brush: f.

Escouillon, an Ouen sweeper, a daf­
lin: m."daflin" not found in OED.

Faire escran contre le vent, to set the 
nose against the wind, to keepe ano­
ther from the winde.

Vn escran, a Skreene to keepe one
from the heate of the fire: m.

Escraser, to crouch or smuther.

S'escravanter de rire, to burst with
laughing.

Escresmer, to take away the creame.

S'escrever, to burst.

Vne Escrevisse, a Crab, a Creuise: f.

Vn escrin, coffret ou cabinet, a cas­
ket, a little chest, a drawer: m.

S'escrier, to cry, to rore out.

Escri, ou escriement, a crying out: m.

Escrimer, to play at fence.

Escrimeur, one playing with a sword,
a fencer: or master of fence: m.

Escrin, see Escran: a Skreene: also a
drawer.

Escrire, to write: j'escris, j'escrivi, j'ay
escript, j'escriray.

Escripture, writte, scripture, wri­
ting: f.

Escripteau, a writing, a scrole, a
bill: m.

Vne Escriptoire, a pennar: f.

Escrouë, the piece of wood wherein
the vice of a presse, or any other in­
strument hauing a vice doth turne:
also the booke of a Iaylor wherein
he writeth the name, day, moneth,
and yere that his prisoner commeth
in, and goeth out of prison.

Escrouler, or esbranler to shake.

Les Escrouëlles, the Kings euill: f.

Escru, new, fresh: as lon ne met point
vne piece de drap escru en vn viel
vestement, one soweth not a peece
of new cloth to an old garment.

Vn Escu, a crowne of gold in money, a
scutchion, a shield.

Escuëlle à oreillons, or oreilles, por­
rengers hauing eares.

Vn Escuiel plein de rochers, a rockie
place: m.

Esculer vne aiguille, to breake the
eye of a needle.

Esculer vn soulier, to beate downe the 
heeles of his shooe.

Escume, scumme, drosse, fome: f.

Escumer, jecter escume, to fome, to
scumme.

Escumeur de mer, a Pirate, a sea
thiefe: m.

Vn Escurieu, a Squirrell: m.

Vn court escusson ou bouclier, a
scutchion or buckler: m.

Escuyer ou coustiler, an Esquier, an
armour bearer.

Escuyer ou eschanson, an Esquier to
the mouth: m."esquire to the mouth" antedates earliest OED citation (1611; see "squire," n., 3b.

L'escurie du Roy, the Kings stable: f.

Esgard qu'on a de faire quelque chose,
 the regard, warinesse & aduise that
we haue to do a thing, a respect: m.





Esgaronner, estalonner, or aculer vn
soulier, to tread downe the heele of
a shooe.

Esgail, le soleil a essuyé l'esgail de la
rosée, the Sunne hath dried vp the 
wet of the dewe: m.

Esgargaté de crier, wearie of crying,
as if ones throate were burst or bro­
ken by too much crying.

S'esgarer, to stray, to wander.

Esgaucer vn cheval en la riviére, to
wash a horse at the riuer.

S'esgayer, to be merie, to sport proper­
ly when geese, duckes, or fishes doe
play in the water.

Vn Esglantier, eglantine, sweete
Brier: m.

Esglise ou Temple, a Church, a
Temple: f.

Esgorger, to cut ones throte.

Esgorgement, a cutting of ones
throte: m.

Esgual, equall: m.

Esgousser des pois ou febves, to pill
peason or beanes: to shale pea­
son, &c.

Vn Esgout qui chet de hault, a
drop: m.

L'esgout d'vne ville, the sincke of a 
towne.

Esgratigner, to scratch like a Cat.

Esgueuler, that is, couper la gueule,
 to cut ones throte.

S'esgueuler de crier, to bee wearie
through crying.

Esguiére, an Ewer: f.

Esguille, seeke Aguille: f.

Des Esguilles, a kind of fish called of
some Hornebeake.

Vn esguillon, a pricke, a stirrer, a
goade: m.

Esguillonner, to stirre, to moue, to pro­
uoke.

Esguillonné, stirred, prouoked.

Esguillonnement, a stirring: m.

Esguillonneur, a prouoker, a setter
on: m.

Vne esguillette, a poynt: f.

Esguïser, to sharpen, to whet a knife.

Eshanché, when ones hip is out of ioint,
and so halteth.

S'enhonter, to be shamefast.

Eshonté, to be shamelesse, to set a good
face on it.

Eshonté, shamelesse, impudent: m.

Eshontement, shamelesnesse, sausi­
nesse: m.

S'esiouïr, je m'esjouïs, je m'esjouï
je me suy esjouï, je m'esjouïray,
 to reioyce, to be glad, to be merie.

Qui s'esjouïst, ioyfull.

S'esjouïssant, reioycing.

Esjouïssance, ioy, gladnesse: f.

Esjouïssance qu'on fait du bien &
prosperité qui nous est venuë, ou
à autruy, the ioye that wee haue in
prosperitie.

Eslancé, as chevaux eslancez carren
horses, pricked with a Lancet.

Eslancement, m: glancing.

Eslancer son corps pour saillir, or
saulter, to shake his body for to leape
the better: to glance.

S'Eslancer sur son ennemy, to fall, or
set fiercely vpon his enemie.

Eslargir, to enlarge, to stretch out.

Eslargi & plein, à qui le ventre tire,
 stretched out, full.





Eslargir de ses biens, to giue of his
goods: j'eslargis, j'eslargi, j'ay es­
largi, j'eslargiray.

Eslay, faire vn eslay, to make a course
on horsebacke.

Esle d'oiseau, f: a wing: see Aile.

Eslever, to take away, to carrie away,
to lift.

Eslevé en hault, heaued vp, lifted vp.

Eslever ou nourrir, to bring vp, to
reare.

Eslire, to choose, to cull, to picke out:
j'eslis, j'esleu, j'ay esleu, j'esliray.

Esleu entre les autres, picked out,
chosen.

Eslite, choise, election: f.

Eslocher & esbransler, to shake, to
wagge, to waue: but properly in
things nailed.

Esloigner, to send aloofe, to conuey a­
way, to keepe off.

Esloigné, kept aloofe.

Esloignement, a conueying away, a
setting farre off: m.

S'eslourdir, j'eslourdis, j'eslourdi, j'ay
eslourdi, j'eslourdiray, to be astoni­
ed, to be amazed, to make one blunt.

Esmay, esmayer, seeke Esmoy.

Esmailler, to enamell.

Bague Esmaillée, a ring enamelled.

Esmaillure, f: enamelling.

Esmail, m: Amell.

Esmarmeler, or escacher, to burst: to
crush: to tread vnder the feete.

Esme, as j'ay failly à mon esme I
haue missed my purpose, determina­
tion or intention.

Prendre son Esme, to take his aime
as Archers doe.

Vne Esmeraude, an Emeraude.

Esmerauldé, bright, shining like an
Emeraude.

Esmerillonné, fort vif d'esprit, 
liuely, quicke.

Esmery, Vermilion.

S'esmerveiller, to maruell, to wonder.

Esmerveillable, wonderfull: to bee
wondred at, com.

Esmerveillement, a wondring, a ga­
zing: m.

L'esmeut d'vn corbeau & fiente
 the muting of a Rauen: m.

Esmeute, seeke Esmouvoir.

Esmier, to crumble or breake small.

Esmoëller, to take out the marrow, to
weaken.

Esmonder, to clense, to sweep, to make
cleane: to lop.

Esmondement d'arbres, & taille­
ment de vignes, a pruning of trees,
cutting of vines: m.

Esmotter, to breake clods in a field
eared.

Esmoucer, to make blunt the edge or
point of any sharpe yron.

Esmousser, to take away the mosse.

Esmoucer & refouler vn trenchant,
 to make blunt that which is sharpe.

Esmouchette de fenoil & sembla­
bles herbes, the round tuft or head
of fenell, or other hearbes wherein
the seede is.

Esmoudre vn cousteau, to grinde a
knife.

Esmoulu, sharpened, grinded.

Gentilhome fraiz esmoulu, a Gen­
tleman newly forged.

Esmouleur, m: a grinder.





Esmoulure, f: grinding.

Esmoulendier, a sheare-grinder: m.Antedates earliest OED citation (1688).

Esmoucher, to driue away flies.

Vn Esmouchoir, a fanne to driue a­
way flies: m.

Esmouvoir, to moue, to prouoke, to
stirre.

Esmu, stirred prouoked, moued.

Esmeute, a commotion, a tumult, a ri­
sing, insurrection, stir, or concourse
of people: f.

Esmotion, a motion, a stirring of the
minde: f.

Esmouvement, a mouing, a tos­
sing: m.

Esmoy ou soulci, care, sorrow, pen­
siuenesse.

S'esmayer, to be sad, astonied, care­
full.

Esnasé, without nose.

Esnaser, to cut ones nose, to breake his
nose, je me suy enasé, I haue dash­
ed my nose againe, &c.

Vn faux-nez, a nose made in steade of 
his owne.

Cache-nez, a muffler, a vizard, such
as Gentlewoman do vse: m.

Esnerver, or enerver, to weaken, to
make womanlike.

Toute espace & distance, space, 
distance.

Espace de temps, space of time.

L'espace & certaine mesure de ter­
re, comme vingt ou trente pas, &
semblables, a space or measure of
ground.

Vn Espagnol, a Spaniard: m.

Vne Espagnolle, a Spanish woman: f.

Espagnolle, as vne cape à l'espag­
nolle, a Spanish cape, after the spa­
nish fashion.

Vn espagneul, a spaniell, dogge: m.

Espais, seeke Espessir.

Espaller, to scatter with a shouell.

Espan, a spanne.

Espancher, to scatter abroad, to
poure.

Espandre, to shead, to spill, to poure
out: j'espands, j'espandi, j'ay espan­
du, j'espandray.

Espandu, spilled, poured out.

Espandement, a shedding, a pouring
out: m.

La Rose s'espanit, ou desploye, ou
s'estend, to blowe out like a Rose or
other floure.

Les aimans ayons receu vn bon re­
gard de la chose aimée, vous les
verrez Espanis comme vne Rose,
 set foorth like a Rose.

Espardre ça & là, to scatter.

Espars, scattered, dispersed.

Espardement, a scattering: m.

Choses dictes esparsement, wordes
spoken scatteringly.

Espargner, to spare, to saue.

Espargner la despense, to saue char­
ges.

N'espargner personne, to spare no
man.

Espargnant & qui a cure d'ar­
gent, & aussi s'abstient des autres
voluptez, a neere fellowe, a warie
man.

Espargne, scarcitie: f.

Couper du formage à l'espargne, to
cut cheese sparingly, niggardly.

De l'ospargoutte ou apparitoire,





 Pellitorie, an herbe.

Esparpiller, to scatter, to disparkle.

Esparpiller les yeux, les jambes ou
les doits, to set wide open the eyes,
legs, or fingers.

Le vent Esparpille les feuilles ça &
là, the winde scattereth the leaues
heere and there.

Esparvains, m: a diseased beast in the
houx or pasterns, or that hath the
scratches.

Vne Espatule ou Spatule, a slice: f.

Espave, he which is subiect to no
man: m.

Espaves, bien vacans goods without
owner.

S'en aller de l'espave et effreinte des
chiens, to departe from hunting
dogs after they haue lost the sent.

Espauler vn home, to put the shoul­
der out of ioynt.

Home espaulu, broad shouldred.

Espauliere, f: the peece of harnes co­
uering the shoulder.

L'espaule, the shoulder.

Espeautre. Espece de blé ainsi ap­
pelé, a kinde of barley as some
thinke: m.

Espece, vne espece de maladie, a
kinde of disesase: f.

Par especial, especially.

Espée, a sword: f.

Espeler, to spell as Children doe.

Espelement des syllabes, a spelling of
sillables: m.

Espennaillé, Il est venu tout espen­
naillé, he is come all ragged.

Vieille harde toute Espennaillée, f: 
 an olde cloute or peece of cloth al­
togither torne and ragged.

Esperdu, lost, a forgone man, amazed
astonied, dismaied.

Povre fame Esperduë: a poore dis­
maied woman.

Esperer, to hope, to trust.

Esperance de bien, hope of goods: f.

Esperlucat, an olde french word sig­
nifying curled haires.

Esplan, eperlan, smelte: as nous a­
vons heu à disner vn quarteron d'­
Esplan, we haue had at dinner a
quartern of smelts: m.

Espoir, hope, trust.

Esprit & entendement que l'homme
a de nature, wit and vnderstanding
that a man hath of nature: m.

Esprit sans repos, a restlesse minde.

Vn Esperon, a spurre: m.

Esperonner, a spurre.

Esperonade, a spurring: f.

Esperonnement, m: idem.

S'esperonner, to set on his spurres.

Espessir, to thicken: j'espessis, j'espes­
si, j'ay espessi, j'espessiray.

Espessi, thickened.

Espez, thicke.

Espesseur, thickenesse: f.

Espessement, thickely.

Espessissement, thickening: m.

Espi de blé, an eare of corne: m.

Les arestes ou barbe de l'espi, the
awnes or beards of the eare of corn.

Chose espiée, made like a corne eare.

Espices on espicerie, spice, the fees of
a Iudge for to viewe the bookes of
suters in lawe: f.

Espier & guetter, to espie, to watch, to
marke, to search out.





Vn Espie ou espion, a spie, m: an
espiall.

Ceux de la ville ont envoyé vn E­
spion pour descouvrir la mer, those
of the towne sent a swifte boate or
brigantine to discouer the Sea.

Espies, snares: f.

En espiant, espyingly.

Espieur, a spier, a prier: m.

Espiement, a spying: m.

Espinars, Spinages: m.

Espine, a thorne, a brier: f.

Espinaye, a thornie place, f: a bram­
ble or brier, or full of briers.

Espineux, thorny, briery.

Espinée, or eschinée, the backe bone
of a hog: f.

Espinette, a paire of Virginals: f.

Espinette organisée, a Bandora.

Espingle, a pinne: f.

Espinglier, a pinne maker, a pinne­
pillowe: m.

Espinoche, a little fish hauing thorns
or prickes vpon his backe for his
defence: f.

L'espinon, or Hardillon, the thong of
a buckle: m.

Esplanade, faire des esplanades, to
planish and make euen the way.

Vn espion & Brigandin, a Brigan­
dine: see Espier.

Esplouré, beblubbered with weeping,
bewayled.

Esplucher, to cull out, to picke wooll.

Esplucher chasque lettre d'vne loy,
 to search euery clause of the law, to
sifte out.

Espointer vne aiguille, espée ou cou­
teau, to breake or cut off the pointe
an needle, sword, knife, or such like.

Espoindre, to pricke, to stirre, to pro­
uoke: see Poindre, to decli.

Espoir, hope: m.

Espois, thicke: seeke Espais.

Esponge, a spunge: f.

Epouvanter, to make afraide, to
feare.

Espouventé, feared.

Vn espouventail, chose espouven­
tant, a thing to make afraid, a scar
crowe: m.

Espouventable, fearefull.

Espouvantement, a feare, a dread: m.

Espouiller, to lowse one, to kill his
lice.

Espouser vne femme,  to marrie a 
woman.

Espouser vn homme, to marrie a
man.

L'esposée, ou l'espousée, the bride: f.

Espousailles, bridall, mariage: f.

Espousseter, to brush.

Espoys, & endouiller, or entouiller,
 are contraries: for Espois, is the vt­
termost branch of the hornes of a
Hart, and Endouiller the first next
the head: see Endouiller.

Espreindre, to presse out, to wring.
j'espreins, j'espreint, j'ay espreint,
j'espreindray.

Espreindre le just, to wring out the 
iuice.

Espreint, pressed out.

Tout à Espreu, for the nonce.

L'esprevier s'sleve ou volle en haut
pour myeux surprendre le gibier,
 the hauke houereth or soreth high.





Vn Esprevier, a Hauke.

Estre Espris de folie, & estre com­
me insensé, to be taken with
follie.

Espris d'amour, to be in loue.

Esprit, spirite: see Espoir.

Esprouver, to proue, to assay.

Espreuve a proofe: f.

Harnois à l'espreuve, an harneis at
proofe.

Vne petite Esprouvette, a small in­
strument wherewith Surgions doe
search wounds, a probe: f.

Espuiser, to drawe out, as out of a
well

Espuiser vn thresor, or ses coffres, to
spend all his money.

Espulser, to flea one, to take away or kil
fleas.

Espurge, herbe, an herbe called
Spurge: f.

Espurger & oster les nœuds des
arbres, to prune trees, to cut away
knots.

Vn Esquadron, a company of men
of warre set in the order of a 
square: m.

Esqualler, or esquailler.  seeke Escai­
ler, to scale, to pull off the barke, as
esqualler des noix.

Esquarquiller, or esparpiller les
jambes, or les yeux, to set open the
legges.

Esquarrir, to square.

Esquarteler, to quarter.

Il a este esquartelé, he was cut into
foure quarters, quartered.

Faire esquarter & espandre ça & là,
 to shed, to throwe about, to scatter.

Vn esquif or bachot, a shipboat: m.

Esquifon, m: a little ship boate.

Esquignon, m: a fescue.

Esquilles et petits esclats d'os rom­
pus, little small bones: f.

Esquilles, as oster des esquilles de la
teste, to take scales out of ones head.

Esquierre, a squire, f: a rule.

Coin fait à l'esquiere, a corner made
right by the squire or rule.

Esquinancie, the squinancie: f.

Ecquipper, seeke Equiper.

Qui est Essardé & alteré, which is al­
waies dry.

Vn Essain, a swarme of Bees.

Essarter vn bois, to make a glade in a
wood.

Essayer, to assaye, to proue, to at­
tempt.

Essay, an assay or proofe.

Coup d'Essay, the first assay or triall
which a prentice dooth out of his
prentiship.

Faites en l'essay quand il vous plai­
ra, make a trial thereof, try it when
it shall please you.

Essulez, cast off, giuen ouer, lefte
alone.

Vn Esseau, or Essette de tonnelier, a
Coopers chipping axe: m.

Vn nouveau Essein d'abeilles, a 
yong swarme of Bees.

Essence, the being of any thing: f.

Il n'est plus en essence, he is no more
in force or being.

Essentielle, as divisions essentiel­
les entre les Magistrats, diuisions
shewing the property, nature & po­
wer among all kind of Magistrates.





Vn Essieu, an axiltree: m.

Essimer, to take away fatte.

Essorer, to drie vp.

Essoré, dried vp: as ma plume est es­
sorée, my penne is wearie, weake,
and drie.

Essorillé, hee which hath his eares
cut off.

Effort, as si le vin nouveau n'a ef­
fort, il rompra les vaisseaux, ex­
cept new wine hath vent, it break­
eth the vessels: m.

Essoyné, maymed, essoyned, seeke Ex­
onnier.

Essueil, m: se seoir à l'essueil de
l'huis, to sit at the threshall of the 
doore.

Essuyer, to wipe, to drie vp.

Il Est, seeke Estre.

Estable à chevaux & autres bestes
semblables, a stable, a stall, a fold: f.

Establage, m: stabling.

Establer les chevaux, to bring hor­
ses to the stable.

Establie, or establir de cousturier,
 the stall of a Taylor: m.

Establier, or estal à bouchier, the
stall of a Butcher.

Establir vn Roy, to establish a King:
j'establis, j'establi, j'ay establi, j'e­
stabliray.

Establissement, an establishing: m.

Vn estage de maison, a lofte of a 
house: m.

Il tomba du troisiesme Estage, hee
fell from the third lofte.

De l'estain, Tinne: m.

Estaimmer, to leade or tinne.

Estaimmé, leaded, as they lead pots.

Estain de laine, wollen yarne: m.

Estaler, to stall out, to shew wares.

Vne estale, a stall or booth.

Les marchants bastissent leurs
Estaux, the Marchaunts do build
their boothes.

Faire Estaler en hault & mettre en
veuë, to set hie for a shew.

Estalier, he that keepeth the stall and
selleth wares: m.

Vn Estalon, a Stallion, a horse to co­
uer Mares: m.

Estamine, a strayner: f.

Estampe, printing: f.

Estampeaux, tressels.

Estancher la soif, le sang, to slake
thirst, to stanch bloud.

Estanchement de soif, slaking of
thirst: m.

Estandart, a Stander: m.

Estang & vivier, a ponde: m.

Vn estanson, a proppe, a forke, a
shore: m.

Estansonner, to stay, to prop.

Estant, as se dresset en estant, to rise
vpon his feete, to stand vp.

L'estape, the wine market, the Sta­
ple: f.

Estaphisagrie, ou herbe aux poulx:
 staue sacre, or, stauesagre: f.

Estarnuër, seeke Esternuër.

Estat & condition des hommes,
 the state and condition of men.

Bailler vn estat & office, to giue an
office.

Tenir les estats, to hold a parliament.

Vne estaye, f: a proppe, a butteresse,
a shore.





Estayer, to shore vp: to shore.

Estayement, a shoring: m.

L'Esté, midsummer: f.

Esteindre, to quench, to slake fire.

Esteignement, a quenching: m.

Estelé, starred.

Estelé au fron, hauing a starre in
the forehead.

Esteler les chevaux, to spang in hor­
ses to the Carte: the contrarie is,
d'esteler.

Estendart & enseigne, a standart, an
ensigne: m.

Estendre, to set forth, to shew forth,
to stretch forth, to spread abroad:
see tendre, for the decl.

Estendu, stretched forth, spread a­
broad.

L'estenduë du ciel, the largenesse of
the heauen.

Estendement, a stretching forth: m.

Ester, as il ne peult estet en jugement,
 he cannot sue one in the lawe.

Personne capable d'ester en juge­
ment, one that lawfully may sue or
defend in the hal or any other court.

Esternir, to spread, to strawe: j'ester­
nis, j'esterni, j'ay esterni, j'ester­
niray.

Esterni, spread, layd vnder.

Esternissement, m: a laying vnder.

Esternuër, to sneeze.

Esternuëment, a sneezing: m.

Vne Esteule ou estouble, strawe,
stubble, f.

Esteuf, estœuf, or pile, a Tennise
ball: m.

Estimer, to esteeme, to value.

Peser ou estimer & juger, to thinke,
to esteeme, to iudge.

Estimer, priser & louër, to esteeme,
to praise, to allow, to regarde.

Estre estimé, to be esteemed.

Estimable, that which may be va­
lued, com.

L'estime qu'on a de vertu, the esti­
mation of vertue: f.

Estimation, estimation: f.

Iuge & estimateur de quelque cho­
se, a Iudge, an esteemer of a thing,
a prayzer: m.

Estinceler, to sparkle, to twinkle.

Estincelle, a sparkle: f.

Estincellement, a sparkling: m.

Estiomené, Saint Antonies fire: when
the member of ones body is meruai­
lously enflamed.

Estiomener, to cut off such member
so enflamed.

Estiver, to Summer, to rest in the 
Summer time.

Estival, belonging to Summer.

Estiveler, see Etiveler.

L'estoc & le tronc d'vn arbre, the
stubbe of a tree, the stocke: m.

Estoc, a sword for the prick or foine
onely: m.

Vn coup d'estoc, a pricke cast.

Eraper d'estoc & de taille, to strike
both foyning and edgeling.

Estoc, is taken for all sorte of stuffe:
as il y a des contes en ce livre de
tous estocs, you haue taile in this 
booke of all sorte.

Estoffer, to engraue.

Estoffeur, an engrauer: m.

Estoffe, as de bonne estoffe & ma­





tiére, good stuffe or ware: f.

Home de bas estoffe, a base estate
or birth: f.

Bien garnir & estoffer vne ville, to 
furnish and garnish a town of all ne­
cessarie things agaynst the enemie.

Estoile, a starre: f.

Vne estole, a Stole as Priests haue
about their neckes in the Romish
Church: f.

Estomach, the stomacke, the bel­
lie: m.

Estonner, to astonish, to amaze.

Estonné, amazed, astonied, agaste.

Estonnement du corps, ou des par­
ties d'iceluy, provenant d'vn ca­
tarrhe, benumnesse of the body to be
taken: m."benumbness" not found in OED.

Estordre, as on ne me sçauroit estor­
dre cela, one cannot take awaye
that from me: to wrinch; see Tor­
dre, to decline it.

Estorer, to build, to garnish or reare.

Boutique bien estorée de toute sor­
te de marchandise, a shop well fur­
nished with all sorte of ware.

Estorsement, a wresting or writhing.

Estorse, idem: f.

Estousser quelqu'vn, to smother, to
stifle, to strangle one.

Estouffement, smothering: m.

Estoupe de lin, ou de chanuré, towe: 
linnen or hempe towe: hards, or
hirds of hemp.

Vn estour, a fight: m.

L'estour fut grand & aspre, the fight
was great and sharpe.

Estouper, to stop vp.

Vn estoupillon, a stopple: m.

Vn estourbillon, a whirlewind: m.

Estourdir, j'estourdis, j'estourdi, j'ay
estourdi, j'estourdiray, to astonish,
to trouble ones head, to amaze, to dul.

Estourdy, blunt, blockish, dullwitted,
foolish, giddie.

Estourdissement, amazednesse, gid­
dinesse: m.

Estourdir ses morceaux, to turne
but once his meate in his mouth, &c
then to swallow it downe.

Vn estourgeon, a Sturgeon: m.

Estourneau, a bird called a Stare: m.

Estradiot, a horseman of Albanie: m.

Chevaucher à la stradiote, that is, to
ride with long stirrops: the contra­
rie is, à la ginette, that is, shorte
after the Morrisk fashion: the stir­
rop lether short.

Estrain, ou foarre, strawe: m.

Estranger, to make strange, to alie­
nate.

S'estranger de quelqu'vn, & oster
sa fantasie, ou amour, to become
straunge, to drawe away his heart
from one.

Estrangé, estranged, alienated.

Moult estrang, very strange.

Vn estranger, a stranger, a forrein: m.

Estrangement des autres, quand on
se met à part, to waxe strange, to
shun company: m.

La nouveauté & estrangeté du cas,
 the straungenesse of the deed or 
fact.

Il crie Estrangement, hee cryeth af­
ter a strange manner.

Estrangler, to strangle, to choake.

Estranglé, strangled.





Estranglement, a strangling: m.

Estraver or Destraver, to deliuer out
of shackles.

Donner estre à quelque chose, to
giue being to a thing, to create.

Estre, je suy, je fu, j'ay esté, je seray,
 to be.

Il fust iadis vn Roy, there was in
time past a king.

Fust que aucun racontast que, &c.
 whether it was that one shoulde
tell, &c.

Tu es, thou art.

Il est, he is.

Se maintenir en son estre, to main­
taine his owne estate.

Estrecir, j'estrecis, j'estreci, j'ay e­
streci, j'estreciray, to make narrow
or streight.

Estrecisson, f: a streightning.

Estreindre, to strain, to make streight,
to make narrow, to thrust together:
j'estrins, j'estrint, j'ay estrint, j'e­
streindray.

Estreignement, a strayning: m.

Estreines, presents, newe-yeares
giftes: f.

Va en mal estreine, goe with a mis­
chiefe.

Estrier, in Lorraine, Estrieu, a stir­
rop: m.

Il luy bailla tel coup d'espée sur la
teste, qu'il luy feit perdre les E­
striers: he gaue him, &c. that he
caused him to forgo or lose the stir­
rop.

Estriller chevaux, to currie horses,
also to beate one.

Vne Estrille, a curry-combe: f."curry-combe" antedates earliest OED citation (1708).

Estreiller chevaux, to currie Hor­
ses.

Estriver & debatre contre quel­
qu'vn, to striue, to contende, to
brawle.

Estriveur, a brawler, a scolder.

Prenre Estrif & debat à l'encon­
tre d'aucun, to bee at strife with
one? m.

Estriviéres, the stirrop leather: f.

Bailler les estriviéres, to whippe one
with a stirrop leather.

Estroict, streight, narrow.

Estoictement, streightly, narrow­
ly.

Le Destroict, or Estroict des monta­
gnes, the streight of the moun­
taynes.

Estron, a turde: m.

Estropiat, maymed: m.

Estudier, to Studye, to plye ones
booke.

Vne estude, a studie: f.

Estudes de lettres, studie of lear­
ning.

Metre tout son estude à appren­
dre, to set all his minde on lear­
ning.

Estude de Sapience, Philosophie,
study of wisdome.

Vn Estudiant qui ne se mesle point 
des affaires publiques, a Schol­
ler: m.

Esturgeon, m: a Sturgeon.

Estuver vne playe, to bathe or soake
a wound.

Estuver ses yeux, to soake the eyes.

Estuves, stewes, hote houses: f.

Estuvement, a soking, bathing: m.





Estuy de quelque chose que ce soit,
 a case, a sheath: m.

Estuyer, to set vp, or shut vp a thing.

Vn Estuy d'escriptoire, a pennar: m.

S'esvanouïr, to vanish, to fade away, to
swoune: je m'esvanouïs, je je m'esva­
nouï, je me suy esvanouï, je m'es­
vanouïray.

Esvanouï, vanished, swouned.

Esvanouissement & pasmoison, va­
nishing, swouning: m.

Esveiller, to waken, to raise vp.

S'esveiller, to wake.

Estre esveillé, to be wakened.

Esveilleur, m: one that awaketh ano­
ther.

Esventer, to fan, to winnow.

Vn Esventoir, ou Esventoire, a 
fanne: m.

Vn Esventé, a boasting and bragging
fellow: m.

Vn esventoir à chasser les mou­
ches, a flap for flyes: f.

Esventement, fanning, winnowing: m.

Vin qui sent l'event, Wine which 
hath taken vent: m.

Esvier, a sincke, a place to voyde wa­
ter: m.

Esvisager, to scratch one by the face.

Esvolé & eshonté, shamelesse.

Inconstant & esvolé, that is, Esven­
té, a wauering fellowe, which can
keepe no secret, but bloweth all out
to the winde.

Et, and, without sounding t.

Et aussi, and also.

Eternel, euerlasting, ayduring.

Eternité, f: ayduring.

Eternellement, euerlastingly.

Eternizer, to make eternall.

Etesies, see Embattes.

Devenir étique, to growe into a con­
sumption: to be lame, withered.

Etiqueter, to set an inscription or a
bill for a token or remembrance, as
vpon sackes of Euidences, or bagges
of money: also to haue lodging ap­
poynted by harbingers.

Etiquettes, such bils: f.

Etiquetiers, fourriers: harbingers: m.

Etiveler, to whisle: to hoope as Hun­
ters doe.

Ettaier, Ettaie, seeke Estayer.

Evacuër, to voyd, to emptie.

Evacuätion de mauvaises humeurs,
 voyding of euill humours: f.

Evacuätif: purgatiue: which hath
the propertie to purge.

Evader, Eschapper, to escape, to slip a­
way.

Evaguer, to roue abroad.

Evagation, f: rouing.

Evangile, the Gospell.

La lumiere Evangelique, the light
of the Gospell.

Evangeliste, an Euangelist: m.

Evangeliser, to preach the Gospell.

Evantes, women celebrating the feast
of Bacchus.

Evaporer, to breathe out, to let goe out
all the vapour of any hote thing.

Evaporation, a breathing out, an e­
uaporation, a steeming: f.

Evénement, a happe, a chance, a com­
ming to passe: m.

A tout Evénement je feray cela: at
all chances I will doe it.

Eventer, to let a thing take wind: as





ce vin est éventé, this wine hath ta­
ken winde.

Eventer le secret du conseil, to spread
abroad, to discouer the secret, &c.

Eventrer poissons, to draw or vnbo­
well fish: to garbish fish.

Evertuëment il besongne à cecy, he
worketh lustily.

S'esvertuer, to endeuour himselfe.

Evertir & ruiner, to ouerthrowe or 
bring to ruine any thing.

Eversion, an ouerthrowing: f.

Vn Evesque, vn Prelat, a Bishop: m.

Evesché, a Bishopricke: f.

Euf, seeke Oeuf, m: an Egge.

Evident, plaine, euident, manifest.

Evidence, an Euidence: f.

Evidemment, cleerely, apparantly,
manifestly.

Evier, seeke Esvier.

Evincer, to conuict by law.

Apres avoir esté evincé, j'ay eu re­
cours à mon garant, after I haue
been ouerthrowne by the law, I had
recourse to my warrant.

Il a esté Evincé d'avoir commis vn
meurtre, he was conuicted of mur­
ther.

Eviter, to auoyde, to shun, to shrinke
from.

Evitement, a shunning, an eschu­
ing: m.

Euneuque, or chastré, a gelded man.

Evoquer au peuple vne chose estant
par devant certains Iuges, to bring
triall of the matter from certaine
Iudges to the people.

Le peuple Evoqué par les tribuns,
 the people called together by &c.

Evocation, a calling backe againe: f.

Euphorbe, a kind of hearbe called in
Latin, Euphorbium.

Eupatoire, herbe, an hearbe called
Agrimonie.

Euphraise, or Euphrosine, a pretious
stone refreshing the eyes dazeled:
but rather an hearbe called Eye­
bright: f.

Eur, Eureux, seeke Heureux.

Princes Europoix, the Princes of Eu­
rope.

Si tu n'eusses esté, ou si ce n'eust esté
toy, if thou hadst not been, if it had
not been for thee.

Sans toy, without thee.

Euvre, seeke Oeuvre, m: worke.

Exacter, to vse tyrannie by exaction
vpon the people.

Exactement, exactly, perfectly.

Exacteur, an extortioner, a gatherer
of subsidies, a seuere corrector: m.

Exaction, extortion: f.

Exaggerer, to aggrauate.

Exaggeration, f: aggrauating.

Exagiter, to vexe, to tosse or torment.

Exagitation, a tossing: f.

Exalter, to praise aboue measure, to
exalt.

Exaltation, an extolling: f.

Examiner quelque chose, to exa­
mine, to wey, to ponder.

Examination, an examination: f.

Exasperer, to make angrie, to make
sharpe, to prouoke & exasperate one.

Exaulcer, to heare gently, to graunt.

Exaulser & eslever, to exalt, to praise
aboue measure.

Excéder, to exceede.





Exceder les termes de raison, to passe
the bounds of reason.

Excellent, surmounting, excelling,
passing.

Excellemment, excellently, passing
well.

Excellence, excellency, worthinesse: f.

Excepter, to except.

L'exception d'vne generalité, the
exception of a generalitie.

Excez, excesse, superfluitie, ryot.

Vn Exces de fiévre, a fitte of an A­
gue.

Excessif, passing measure, exces­
siue: m.

Excessivement, excessiuely.

Exciter, to stirre vp, to awake.

Excitation, f: awaking.

Exclamer, to cry out.

Exclamation, f: an exclamation.

Exclus, shut out, put out, excluded.

Exclure, j'exclus, j'exclu, j'ay ex­
clu, j'excluray, to shut out, to ex­
clude.

Exclusivement, out of the compasse: 
which is not comprehended or con­
tained in.

Excogiter, to imagine.

Excommunier, to excommunicate.

Excoriation, that is, escorchure, a
flaying when the skinnes is off, and 
the wound raw: f.

Excremens, the purgings of a mans
bodie.

Excrementeux, full of filth.

Excroissance de chair vicieuse, the
swelling of a corrupted flesh, a chil­
blaine: f.

Excuser, to excuse.

Vne excuse, an excuse: f.

Excusation, making an excuse: f.

Excuseur, qui excuse quelqu'vn, an
excuser: m.

Cela est excusable, that is to be ex­
cused, com.

Exécrable & détestable, hatefull, to
be abhorred, com.

Exécration, blasphemie, cursing be­
yond measure.

Excrémens, the dregs or excrements
of the bodie: m.

Exécuter, to distreine for debt.

Mettre en exécution ce qu'on nous
a enchargé, to execute our charge.

Il a esté exécuté, he hath been put to
death.

Exemple, an example: m.

Exemplaire plein de faultes, a false
sampler: m.

Avoir l'exemplaire & patron, to haue
a sample.

Punition servant d'exemplaire, pu­
nishment seruing for an example.

Exempter, to exempt.

Exempt, qui n'a nulle part, exempt,
he that hath no part.

Exempt de faire aucune charge, ex­
empt, free from any charge.

Exemption, libertie, freedome.

Exercer quelque art, to exercise an 
Art.

S'exercer, to exercise himselfe, to
enure.

S'exerciter à escrire, to vse to write.

Exercice, exercise, vse: m.

Exercitation, exercising: f.

Exhalation de la terre, the dampe or
vapour of the earth.





Exaler, to cast out vapours.

Exeréder, to disinherite, to put one
out of his inheritance.

Exhiber, to exhibite, to shewe.

Exhibition, a shewing: f.

Exhorter, to exhort, to animate and
incourage one.

Exiger ou demander, to demaund or
exact a thing.

Nous serons selon l'exigence du
cas, we will as the matter requi­
reth.

Exil, banishment, exile: m.

Exiler, to banish one.

Exigence, necessitie, and extremi­
tie: m.

L'exigence le requiert, necessitie re­
quireth it.

Selon l'exigence, according to the ne­
cessitie.

Exiler vn païs, to make a countrey de­
solate of people.

Eximer, to discharge one, to exempt.

Exomnier, to essoine: to sweare that
the partie cannot appeare in iudge­
ment for some lawfull excuse.

Exomnié: assoined: excused law­
fullie.

Exoines, patents, or letters of dis­
charge.

Exonniez par maladie, ou autre en­
combrier, discharged souldiers be­
ing maimed or weake through a
long sicknesse.

Exorbitans, dons exorbitans, or maux
exorbitans, exceeding great gifts,
enormous euils.

Exorcisme, coniuring, coniuration.

Exorciste, a Coniurer: m.

Expectation, a tarying: f.

Expédier quelque affaire, to hasten
or dispatch a matter.

Expédition & achevement, an ex­
pedition, a riddance: f.

Experimenter, to proue, to trie, to ex­
amine, to assay.

Vn homme expérimenté, a man of
experience.

Expert & sçavant, expert, cunning.

Expérience, experience, knowledge,
cunning: f.

Expier ou purger, to purge our sinnes.

Expiation, purging: f.

Expirer, to breathe out, to yeeld vp the
ghost, to ende.

Expiation, a sacrifice of purging, or
reconciliation: f.

Le temps est expiré, the time is en­
ded or expired.

Expliquer, to expound, to vnfold.

Expliqué, expounded, interpreted.

Faire exploiter besongne, to rid bu­
sinesse.

Qui n'exploite guere, slacke in busi­
nesse.

Exploit, deede, worke, affaires, busines
atchiued.

Exploits domaniaux, executions, or
iudgement, put to execution with­
in a Lordes Domaine or iurisdic­
tion.

Explorateur, a spye: m.

Explorer, to spye.

Exposer quelque chose aux enfantz,
 to bequeath or giue ouer to his chil­
dren: also to expound.

Vn lieu exposé & tourné au soleil,
 placed directly against the sunne.





Exposé a toute moquerie, put to
shame and mockerie.

Exposition, an exposition, a declara­
tion: f.

Dire par expres, chiefely, or expresse­
ly to tell.

Expressement, expressely, namelye.

Expression, a straining or squising
out: f.

Exprimer par escrit, to demaund or 
exact by writing.

Exprobation or reproche, a reproch,
a twiting: f.

Expugner & prendre vne ville par
force,  to take a towne by force.

Expugnable, that may be taken: the
contrarie, is inexpugnable, com.

Expulcer & getter hors par force,
 to driue out by force.

Expulsé, expelled thrust out.

Expulseur, m: one that driueth out.

Expulsion, an expelling.

Exquis, exquisite, singular, fine, per­
fect.

Exquisement, exactly.

Extase, or extasie, traunce, as estre en
extase, to be in a traunce: m.

Extatique, which is in a traunce.

Extenuër, to minishe, to extenuate, to
make leane

Il est fort extenuë de maladie, he is
very leane through sickenesse.

Extérieur, outward, intérieur the
contrarie.

Extérieureté, outwardnesse: f.

Exterminer, to vndoe vtterlie, to ba­
nishe.

Extirper & desraciner, to root out.

Extirpationk, a rooting out: f.

Extorsion, pour tor, wrong, extor­
tion: f.

Extorquer, to take away by force, to
wrest away.

Extraordinaire, extraordinarie, vn­
wonted.

Extraordinairement, extraordinari­
lye.

Extraict de noble lignée, comming
of a noble stocke.

Extrait de l'original, an abstract, a 
copie taken out of any writing.

Extraire & trascrire, to drawe out, to
write out.

Extravaguer bien loing, to wander 
farre.

Extravagation, f: wandring.

Extremement, without measure.

L'extremité & bord ou bout de
quelque chose, the brinke or top of
any thing.

Exuberant, abounding.

Exulcerer, to make sore, to eate
the skinne.

Exulceration, an eating of the skin: f.

Explastre exulceratoire, a plaister
eating the skinne, com.

Exultation, mirth and ioy: f.


F ante A.

FAble, a tale, a fable: f.

Fabloyer, a fable.

Fabriquer, to builde, to inuent.

La Fabrique de l'Eglise, the mainte­
nance of the Temple or Church.

Fabuleux, as c'est vn conte fabuleux
 it is a reporte or talke full of lies or
fables.





Cerches des oreilles fabuleuses
pour ouïr voz contes, seeke eares
delighting in tales, to heare your
lies, tales, or fables.

La Face, f: the face.

Facetieux, merie, pleasant, full of me­
ry conceits.

Facécie, merie conceites: f.

Facétieusement, pleasantly.

Facendes, or Faciendes, an Italian
worde, as Allez à voz facendes,
goe to your businesses and affaires.

Durant ces facendes, while this was
dooing.

Facile, easie.

Facilement, easily, readily, quickely.

Facilité, easinesse: f.

Faciliter vne chose, to bring a thing
to easinesse, to make it a sleight.

Façon, fashion, form, making, work­
menship: f.

Façonner, to fashion.

Vn Façonnier, a cloth-worker.

Iehan N. est le meilleur Façonnier
de Londres, Iohn N. is the best
cloth-worker in London.

Faconde, f: elegancie, eloquencie.

Facond, eloquent.

Facondement, eloquently.

Facteur, a Factor, an Agent: m.

Le Facteur d'vn Marchand, a Mer­
chants Factour.

Factieux, & faiseur de menées, a fac­
tious, a seditious person: m.

Faction, a sect or bande deuided the
one from the other: a mutinie, a se­
ditious company: f.

Facture, see Faire, to doe.

Vn Factiste, m: a commedian, a co­
micke Poet.

Facutlé, licence, power, facultie, a­
bilitie: f.

Il a de grands facultez, he hath great
riches.

Il a les facultez basses, the contrarie.

A grand peine ay-je heu faculté ou
congé de l'aller voir, with much a­
doe had I leaue to goe see him.

Fade,  vnsauery, without any taste.

Fruicts qui sont fades, vnsauerye
fruites.

Ce sont fadeses, f: they are toyes, fol­
lies, trifles.

Vn Fagot, a fagot: m.

Fagoter, to make fagots.

Fagouë, the necke peece of a Bore, the 
fag peece. m: also a wart."fag piece" not found in OED.

Faictiz, forged, made, as vn corps bi­
en faictis, a body well made.

Vne damoiselle bien & faictisse­
ment parée, a gentlewoman fine­
ly trimmed.

Faillir, je faulx, je failly, j'ay failli, je
fauldray, to faile, to erre, to slacke,
to lacke.

Faille, as sans faille, without faulte: f.

Home failli & recreu, a tired man,
wearie.

Cœur failli, a faint hart.

Faillites, as payer ses creanciers or
crediteurs en faillites, to pay his
creditors in papers, &c.

Fameilleux, hungrie, starued.

Famelique, idem, com.

Faim, hunger, famine, desire: f.

Il a faim de combatre, he disireth
to fight.

Faindre, Faintise, seeke Feindre.





Faine, a Beech tree: m.

De la Faine, Beeche maste: f.

Fai-neant, an idle person, a doer of no­
thing, seeke Neant.

Fai-neantise, idlenesse, faint-hart­
nesse: f."faint-hartnesse" not found in OED.

Faire, to doe, to goe about, je fay, je fei,
j'ay fait, je feray.

Faire quelque chose, to doe a thing.

Faict, a deed.

Cest vn home qui faict bien son pe­
tit faict, such one they call in Eng­
land, wise, which by subtiltie of the
law enriched himselfe.

Il faict bien de son Hercules, he
counterfeiteth Hercules, he stan­
deth vpon his pantoples, as if it were 
one as valiant as Hercules.

Cest fait de moy, I am vndone.

Faiseur, a doer.

C'en est fait, it is done of it.

Faicture, workemanship, f.

Faisable, which may be done, com.

Vn Faisant, a Phesant.

Vn Faisceau de quelque chose, que
ce soit liée ensemble, a bunche, a
bundle: m.

Faiste de maison, the top of an house.

Thuile festiere, a tile couering the
top.

Faitardise & paresse, slothfulnes,
sluggishnes, drousines: f.

Faitifs, see Faictiz.

Vn faix, a burthen: m.

Fallace, a guile: f.

Fallacieux, deceitfull.

Il falloit vser de plus long exemples,
 it behoued to vse longer examples.

Il fault, il falloit, il fallut, il a fallu, il
avoit fallu, il faudra, it behoueth, it
did behoue, it behoued, it hath beho­
ued, it had behoued, it shall behoue,
or it shall be needfull.

Il fault, it must, it behoueth.

Tant s'en fault qu'il me volust tra­
hir, que plus tost, &c. so farre vn­
like it is that hee would betray me,
that rather he would, &c.

Fallot, a cresset light, a paper Lan­
terne.

Vn gentil fallot, a trimme fellowe, a
fine companion, this is spoken by
mockerie

Falordiez, as Prestres Falordiez,
 Priests hired, beggerly Priests.

Vne falourde, a heauy burthen.

Falsisier, to falsifie, to forge.

Fame, fame, renowne: f.

Fameux, famous, renowned.

Cité, or cille fameuse, a famous
towne.

Familier, domestique, familiar,
homely.

Familiarité, familiaritie: m.

Familiariser aucun, to be bolde with
one in communication, to speake and
vse with one familiaritie.

Familiariser, to become familiar.

Familiairement, familiarly.

La famille & race, the house, kinred,
the familie: f.

Famine, hunger, dearth: f.

Vn fan de biche ou autres bestes, a 
Faune: m.

Fanner, or faonner, when Does doe
bring forth, to Faune.

Le Fanal or fanon d'vne gallere,
m: the lanterne of a Gallie.





Se faner, to wither, to rot, to putrefie,
to corrupt.

Fané et pourri, rotten.

Fanfare, it is the sound of the trum­
pets when they runne at the Tilt, a
bragge.

Fanfarer & faire fanfares, to brag 
much.

Fanfreluches, riffe raffe, the leauings
or shreds of any thing: f.

Fange, mud, durt: f.

Fangeux, durtie, full of mud.

Le fanon d'vn bœuf, la peau qui luy
pend soubs le long du col, the
dewe lap of a rudder beast, hanging
down vnder his necke: m.

Fantasie & volonté d'vne per­
sonne, the fantasie and minde of a 
body: f.

Fantasier quelque chose en son e­
sprit, to imagine, to cast fantastical­
ly in his minde.

Fantassins, footemen in warres.

Fantastiquer, to imagine, to inuent, to
cast in his fantasie.

Fantastique, fantasticall, inuentiue.

Fantasme, or fantosme, a vaine vi­
sion:m.

Faon, seeke Fan.

Faonner, to faune as Does do.

Vn Faquin, a Porter, a packebea­
rer."packebearer" antedates earliest OED citation (1656).

Far, or Fare, m: an high Tower or
Beacon.

Vne Farce, a niggard: m. a playe, an
Enterlude: f.

Farceur, a player of such plaies: m.

Iouëur de Farces, qui represente
contenances selon l'estat des per­
sonnes, a plaier, a counterfeiter of
personages.

Farcerie, f: a pleasant guest.

Farcereau, a maker of such Enter­
ludes: an inuenter of lies, a false
knaue: m.

Farce, or vne mulette, f: an haggasse
pudding.

Vn Farci, idem.

De la Farce, a liuering, a pudding: f.

Farcin, scurffe: m.

Farcineux, scurffie, scabbed.

Farcir & remplir, to stuffe, to franke,
to feede.

Il est tout farci d'escus, he is altoge­
ther stuffed with crownes, a money
man.

Fard, white lead painting colours.

Fardé, painted, as some women do vse
to paint themselues.

Fardement de vieilles choses pour
les mieux vendre, a painting or set­
ting forth olde things to the shew: m.

Vn Fardeau, a fardell, a trusse, a bur­
then: m.

Fardeler, to binde in little fardels.

Farfadets, little sprites.

Fariboles, trifles, tales, or like trash: f.

Farine, meale: f.

Farineux, white with meale.

Farine folle, such meale or floure as
is round about the mill, meale dust.

Farouche, fierce, outragious, cruell.

Farre, or Foarre, strawe: m.

Farse, see Farce.

Fascher ou ennuyer quelqu'vn, to
anger or displease, to irke one.

Tu me fasches & ennuyes, thou
troublest me, I am irked by thee.





Fasché, troubled, angred, yrked.

Fascheux & ennuyeux, troublesome,
grieuous, tedious: m.

C'est chose Fascheuse, it is an irke­
some thing.

Fascherie, anger, griefe, trouble, vex­
ation: f.

Fassines, fagots, or bauens: f.

Faseoles, a kinde of small pulse: f.

Fat, as c'est vn fat, he is a foole: m.

Fatal & féé, appointed by destiny, fatal.

Fatalizer, to iudge and appoynt any
thing to a destinie.

Fatalement, & par féérie, by desti­
nie.

Fatiguer, to wearie or trouble one.

Grande fatigue, great wearinesse: f.

Fatigation, trauaile: f.

Vn fatiste, a player, a Poet.

Fatras, trifles, toyes, stuffe, trash.

Fatrouiller, to inuent trifles, to be oc­
cupied about toyes, and workes of
none effect.

Fatrouilleur, a trifler, a botcher in
his trade: m.

Faval, or favas, seeke Febve: m.

Fau-bourgs, seeke Faulxbourgs.

Fau, vn arbre, a beech tree: m.

Faucher, to mowe the ground.

Faucheur de prez, a mower: m.

Faulcon, a Faulcon: m.

Faulconneau, a kinde of artillery: m.

Faudeteul, the kings seate when he is
at the table: m.

Faveur & support, sauour, support: f.

Il m'a monstré toutes les faveurs du
monde, he hath shewed me all the
fauours in the world.

Favoriser, to fauour.

Favori, ou favourisé, in fauour, fa­
uoured: m.

La Favorite de quelque grand seig­
neur, the Paramour of some great
Lord: she whom one loueth and fa­
uoureth about all: f.

Favorablement, fauourably.

Vne faucille ou crochet, a Sicle, a
hooke: f.

Faucon, oysesau de proye, a Faul­

Faulconnier, a Faulconer, one that

Faudra, seeke Falloir.

Faulsaire, a falsifier, a counterfeiter,

Faulser des lettres, to counterfeit
letters.

A faulses enseignes, to doe vnder a
false title, or token.

Qui fait faulseté, he that committeth

Fault, seeke Falloir.

Faultif, m: faultie, which hath done
amisse.

Faulte ou disette, wante, lacke, scar­

Faulx, homme Faulx, a false man.

Faulse monnoye, counterfeite mo­
ney.

Les plus Fauls de tous les homes,
 the falsest among all men.

Feal, faithfull, trustie.

Fébricitant, qui à la fiévre, which
hath an ague.

Vne petite chose noire qui est au

La faiture de quelque chose par la­
quelle on la met à estre, the ma­

Febvre, or feure, a Smith.

Fealle, as la sagesse fealle de ce grand

Fecondité, fruitfulnesse.

Feconder, to make fruitfull.

Vne fée, a fairie: Il ne fait pas bon

uoke the Phairies: marot: f.

Les fées l'on ainsi déterminé, such
is the determination of the Fai­
ries.

Féé, destinate, appoynted.

Féé, & qui doibt advenir par neces­
sité, appoynted, that must needes
come to passe.

Par féérie & destinée, by destinie,
by the Phairies appoyntment.

Se feindre, to fayne himselfe.

De la feine or foine, beech mast: f.

Felin, a small kind of weight among
stampers of money and goldsmiths.

Felle & desprit, angry, eger, fierce.

lée des louänges de noz devanciers.

veines in a precious stone: f.

Felon, fell, testie, outragious, cruell.

Ayant le regard felon, hauing a fell,
cruell, or mischieuous looke.

thing: f.

Femelin, made womanish.

nounce, fame: f.

j'ay fendu, je fendray.

fendu, chopped, cleaft.

cleftes or chinkes.

Fenestré & percé, windowed or pier­
ced through.

Fenestrelle, a little windowe.

Le fenestrage d'vne maison, the
windowes of a house: m.

Vn fenil ou on garde foin, a hayloft,
an hay mowe, an hay house, a

Du fenoil, or fenouil, Fenell: pro­
nounce, fenou: m.

Fenugrec, m: an hearbe.

Feodal, as le Seigneur feodal, the
Soueraign Lord of any lordship, out

Fer, iron: m.

Vn fer chaud, an yron glowing
redde.

Feriale, as les reliques feriales de
Saint Laurens, the reliques of S.
Laurence for holy and high dayes.

Chose fériale, a thing for high holy
dayes.
