Ferrailles, olde yron: f.

Ferrer mules & chevaux, to shooe
horses or mules.

Ferré, shod.

Vne fére, a wilde beast: f.

Feries & jours de cessation, holy
dayes, wakes, vacation time."vacation time" antedates earliest OED citation (1721).

Ferir: je fiers, je feru, j'ay feru, je
feriray, to strike.

Feru, stroken, hitte, wounded.

Vn fermaillet qui se pend au col
pour preserver de poyson, a pre­
seruatiue to hang about ones necke
against poyson.

La ferme ou demaine du prince, the
kings reuenue.

Vne Ferme, a Farme, a Man­
nour: f.

Les fermiers du prince, the Kings
Farmers.

Ferme, firme, stable, sure.

Estre ferme & constant, to be stable,
to be constant.

Fermeté, stablenesse, constancie, sted­
fastnesse: f.

Fermement, constantly, stedfastly.

Fermeillet, the carkenet, which gen­
tlewomen doth weare about their
beads enriched with pearles or am­
mell, a border, it is also a claspe: m.

Fermer, to shut vp, to close vp.

Fermé, shut, closed.

Fermement & closture de bouche,
 stopping ones mouth: m.

Feroce, cruell, com.

Ferrer, seeke fer.

Ferrumination, a mingling, or ra­
ther ioyning and couering a piece
of yron with golde, siluer, or other
mettall.

Fertile, fruitful, wel yeelding, fertile.

Fertilité, fruitfulnesse.

Fertilizer, to make fruitfull.

Fertilement fruitfully.

Feru, see ferir,  stroken, wounded.

Fervent, earnest, feruent.

Fervemment, earnestly.

Vne ferule, a sticke, or a paulme: f.

Feslée, see fellée.





Les Fesses, the Buttockes, the
breech: f.

Fesser, to breech boyes, to scourge
them.

Fessiffier, to doe the office of buttocks,
to play with his buttocks.

Fessiffiant, &c. 

Fessu, well buttocked, well breeched.

Feme fessue, a woman with great
buttockes.

Le feste d'vn edifice, the ridge of an
house, the top: m.

Feste, holyday: f.

Fester, to keepe holyday, to feast.

Iours Festez, dayes being made holy,
holydayes.

Festin, a feast, a banquet: m.

Fetisse, as liqueurs fetisses qu'on 
brasse de palmiers & aultres fruits
singuliers: strong drinke brewed
with dates and other dainty fruits.

Festoyer, or fester aucun, to feast one,
to cleare one: also to celebrate a 
holyday.

Vn festu, a strawe, or rush, a mote: m.

Le feu, fire: m.

Feu volage, a tetter, a ringworme: m.

Mettre tout à feu, & à sang, to put al
to fire and sworde.

Feu mon pere, my father deceased,
which is departed out of his life.

Feu ma mere, my deceased mother.

Fouchiere, ou Foyguere, Ferne
Brakes: f.

Feuille, Feuillée, see fueille.

Vn Fevre, or feure, a Smith.

Feudataire, the Lord, Lordshippe, or
land holding of another Lord.

Feve, seeke Febve.

Feurre, see Foarre.

Feultre, a Felt: m.

Feur, all the labour, costs and char­
ges which a labourer bestoweth in
the fruits rising by tillage: m.

A feur de cinq folz piece, that is, af­
ter the rate of fiue shillings a piece.

Vn feure, a Smith.

Fiance & asseurance, trust, affiance,
troth: f.

Fiancer vne fille, ou vne femme, to 
betroth, to make sure, to handfast.

Vne Fiancée, betrothed, handfa­
sted: f.

Fiansailles, f: betrothing.

Ficher, to fasten, to sticke in, to set
fast.

Le fic, a sore or scabbe hard to bee
healed: m.

Ficelle, packethread: f."packet thread" not found in OED.

Fiché & arresté, stedfast, stably­
shed.

Fiction & controuvement, a thing
fayned, an imagination: f.

Fort fidele & seur, faithfull, stable.

Fidelité, faythfulnesse: f.

Fidelement, faithfully, vnfaynedly.

Fiebvre, ou Fiévre, an Ague, a Fe­
uer: f.

Fievrette, f: a little Ague.

Acces de Fievre, the fitte of an A­
gue.

Fiebvreux, subiect to an ague: which
causeth an ague.

Fief, a fee: m.

Sergenterie Fiefée, the office of cer­
taine Sergeants holden in fee.

Fiel, Gall: m.

Fielleux, or felleux, as bitter as gall.





Fiens, dung: m.

Fiens à fumer la terre, dung to dung
the earth.

La fiente & ordure d'vne beste, the
dung of a beast: f.

Fienter, to shite.

Fiert-humble, a stout heart humbled.

Soy fier à quelqu'vn de quelque se­
cret, to trust one with some secret
talke.

Fier, with one syllable, is arrogant,
proud, loftie, high minded, fierce.

Fiéret, somewhat loftie.

Fiérement, loftily, fiercely.

Fiéreté, hautinesse, loftinesse, pride: f.

Vne fierte, or chasse, a coffin where
the bones of Saints are inclosed: f.

Fiert, as ce courage fiert bien a vn
Espagnol, this courage agreeth wel
with a Spanish nature.

Vn Fifre, a fife, a flute playing with a
drumme: m.

Fiévre, seeke Fiebvre.

Sang Figé, blood cluttered: m.

Figer, to fasten.

Vne Figue, a figge: f.

Vn Figuier, a figge tree: m.

Vne Figuiére, a Figge-yard.

Figure, a figure, an image: f.

Figurer, to figure, to paint.

Figurement, a figuring: m.

Fil, ou Filet, a threed: m.

Fil d'espine, sister threed.

Vn Filé & verveu à prendre poissons,
 an angle or bait to catch fish: m.

Filet à filet, threed by threed.

Filer, to spin, to twist.

Filure & tissure de layne ou de soye,
 shining: f.

La Filace qu'on met en la quenoil­
le, the flaxe that is put on the Di­
staffe: f.

Les Silames des veines, the strings on
vaines: m.Obscure.

Filandieres, a kind of small boates: f.

Filandres, are certaine strings sharpe
as needles growing in Hawkes that
are fed with euill meate, and cau­
seth them to dye, tallants.

Filliastre, a sonne in lawe: m.

Filiére, a long threed tyed at the line
of the Hawke when the Faulconer
doth lure him: also a net: f.

Filleul, or fillol, a godsonne: m.

Filleule, a goddaughter: f.

Fils, a sonne, a boy: m.

Vne Fille, a daughter, a wench: f.

Fillette, a girle, a wench: f.

Filoselle, creuell: f.

La fin de quelque chose que ce soit,
 the end of a thing: f.

A fin que je ne, &c. to the ende that,
&c.

En fin, in the ende.

Finer, to ende, to determine, to con­
clude.

Finé, ended.

Finablement, ou finalement, finally,
in summe.

Fin finalle, the last end, an end with­
out any more delay.

Fin homme, a subtile, craftie, or be­
guiling man.

Cest vne fine mouche, he or she is a 
subtill peece of flesh.

Fin drap, fine cloth: m.

Fine toile, fine linnen cloth: f.

Finesse, subtiltie, craft, deceit, guile: f.





Ce petit finet, that little craftie fel­
lowe: m.

Finement, subtilly, craftily, deceit­
fully.

Finer ses jours, to end his daies.

Ie ne peux finer de luy, I cannot go­
uerne him, or haue him at will.

Finage, m: all the small cordes of a ship.

Fiscal, pertaining to the Eschequer.

Le Roy a espuisé toutes ses finances,
 the King hath spent out all his trea­
sure.

Payer finance pour vn office de ju­
dicature, to pay a fine for an office of
a Iudge.

Finances, treasure, goods: f.

Financiers, the Treasurers of the 
Kings reuenues: m.

Fins & limites, bounds, limites, bor­
ders: m.

Fiole, a viole: f.

Fiquer, or fischer, to adorne: from
thence came Affiquets.

Le firmament, m: the firmament.

Fiscelle, f: packthred.

Fistule, a pipe, a disease called an is­
sue: f.

Fixe, as estoiles fixes fastened, vn­
moueable starres.

Vn Flacon, ou bouteille, a flagon, a 
bottle: m.

Flac, as de grand vilain, grand flac,
 a great lobbish knaue, a great sot: m.

Flache, flagging, faded.

Flaterau, a little flatterer: m.

Flacquer, to cast a thing to the wall or
the ground, which flappeth or doth
make a sound, as an egge or any li­
cour cast against a wall.

Flageler, to scourge.

Flagellation, a scourging: f.

Flageolet, a whistle, a pipe: m.

Flagorner, to dallie, to flatter, to tell
tailes.

Flagorneur & rapporteur, a blab, a
dallier, a tale teller, a tale carier: m.

Flairer, to smell, to sent.

Flaireur, a smeller: m.

Flairement, smelling, senting: m.

Flaistrir, as faire flaistrir & puis de­
capiter vn home, to whippe, to cor­
rect, &c.

Flambe, ou flamme de feu, a flame
of fire: f.

Flambeau, ou torche, a torche, a 
linke: m.

Flamboyer & reluire, to flame, to
shine.

Flammeche ou estincelle, a sparkle: f.

Flammerolles, flambars, fruirolles,
or Ardans, Fire-drakes.

Flancé, linge delié ou graisle, flanke
or thinne.Unclear.

Des flans, m: custards, flawnes.

Vn Flannet, m: a little custard.

Les flancs, the flankes: m.

Flanquer quelcun, or vne muraille,
 to garnish with flankes, to be at ones
side or elbowe for a rampier.

Flaque, or flache, vnlustie, feeble, a
flagging body.

Flascon, or flasque, a flagon: also a
flaske or boxe where souldiers doe
put their gunpouder: m.

Flasquet, m: a little flaske.

Flater, qui est vn mot propre quand
les chiens blandissent de la queuë, 





to flatter, to faune as a dog doth.

Flateur, a flatterer, a glauerer: m: a 
fauner.

Flatterie, flatterie, fauning: f.

Flateresse, a she flatterer: f.

Flatereau, a little flatterer: m.

Flatrer au front d'vne lettre chaul­
de, to marke a thing in the forehead
with a hot yron.

Flatré, marked for a naughtie packe.

Il a esté pilorié & flatri, fletri, or
fleutri, burned through the eare af­
ter the pillorie.

Flatrissement, or fleutrissement, m:
 burning through the eare.

Le Fleau & tendon ou ville de la
vigne dont elle s'attache, the
branch or shooting out of a vine: m.

Vn Fleau, a flale to thresh corne: m.

Fleau, a great balance hanging at the
Grocers shop: m.

Fleble, feble, or foible, weake.

Vne fleche & vn traict, a shaft, an
arrowe: f.

Vne fleiche, or fliche de Lard, a flich
of Bacon: f.

Flechir & ployer quelque chose, to
bend, to bow a thing.

Flechi & ployé, bent, bowed.

Flechissement, bowing, a ben­
ding: m.

Flechissure, bought, or bowingnesse: f:
bending.

Flegme, ou fleume, fleame: m.

Flegmatique, flegmatike.

Vn Phlegmon, m: an impostume of
inflamed blood.

Se flestrir, to wither away, to drye vp,
je me flestris, je me flestri.

Flestri, withered.

Flestrissure, withering: f.

Vne flette, a lyter, a small boate: also
a Flounder: f.

Fleume, seeke Flegme.

Fleur, a floure: f.

La fleur-de lis, the floure-de luce: f.

Fleurdeliser, to burne one with an hot
floure-de luce betweene the shoul­
ders, as theeues or roges are burned 
in the hand here in England.

Les fleurs d'vne fame, the flowers of
a woman: f.

Fleurette, ou Fleuron, a little floure: f.

Fleurir, je fleuris, je fleuri, j'ay fleu­
ri, je fleuriray, to floure.

Fleurissant, flourishing, or flowering.

Fleute, ou flute, flageol, or flageo­
let, a flute, a whistle, a pipe: f.

Fleuteur, ou fluteur, a piper, a flu­
ter: m.

Fleutrir, see Flatrer.

Fleuve ou riviére a flood or a riuer: m.

Fletz, a kind of fish like a Sole.

Flic, it is the sound or noyse which ri­
seth by casting any licour against a 
wall: m.

Fliche de lard, a flich of Bacon: f.

Flin, or pierre de foudre, a thunder
stone, Armourers and Cutlers doe
vse it in scouring their swords: m.

Vn flis, a shaft or an arrowe to shoote
farre: m.

Vn floc & bouton de laine, a stocke
of wooll: m.

Flocon, idem.

Flon, seeke Felon.

Flot, a flood: m.

Le Flot de la mer, the flowing of the





sea, the waues.

Chasque flot a son reflot: or chaque
flux a son reflux, each flowing hath
his ebbe.

La mer flotte & reflotte, the sea
doth flowe and ebbe.

Flotter, to flote, to swim.

Flottement, a floting.

Flotte de gens, a companie and mul­
titude of people: f.

Flour, Fleurir, seeke Fleur.

Fluctueux, full of waues.

Fluer, to run like water.

Fleuëurs de fame, the flowers of a
woman: f.

Flute, Fluteur, seeke Fleute.

Fluviatiles, of the riuer, or pertaining
to the riuer, com.

Flux, ou fluxion, a flood: m.

Flux de ventre, the flixe, the laske.

Flux de sang, or cacasangue, bloody
flixe.

Flux & reflux: see Flot.

Foarre, strawe: m.

Focile, the arme from the elbow to the
wrest, likewise from the knee to the
ankle bone: f.

Foible, weake, feeble, com.

Foiblesse, weaknesse, feeblenesse: f.

Foiblement, weakely, feebly.

Fœu, seeke Feu.

Foie, seeke Foye: m.

Foine, seeke Fouïnne.

Moulon de foin, a cocke of hay: m:
an haycocke.

Foin d'arriére saison, ou regain:
 lateward hay: late math: fogge.

Foin de pré, grasse of the pasture: m.

Foires d'vne ville, the Faire or mar­
ket of a towne: f.

Foire, thin dung, squirt.

Foireux, beshitten: m.

Petite foireuse, thou little shitten
girle.

Vne fois, once: f.

Quelque fois, sometime.

Par fois, by times.

Le fois or foix du corps, the middle 
of the bodie: m.

Foison, plentie, aboundance: f.

Foisonner, to abound.

Fol, a foole, an idiot, sound fou: m.

Folatre, a wanton.

Folatrer, to play the wanton.

Folatrement, ragement, wanton­
nesse, folly: m.

Folatreries, wantonnes, foolishnes: f.

Folie, folly, vnaduisednesse: f.

Folement, foolishly, fondly, childish­
lie.

Folet, a little foole: m.

Poil Folet, a yong mossie beard: the
first downe of yong birds.

Folier, to play the foole.

Fomentation, a plaister that asswa­
geth heate: f.

Foncer vn tonneau, the contrarie is,
deffoncer, to knocke out an hogs­
head.

Foncé, garnished, as il est bien foncé
d'argent, he is well furnished with
money.

Vn planchier foncé de fleurs, the 
floore of a chamber strawed with
flowers.

Foncier, as Seigneur foncier the
Lord of the soyle: m.

Rente fonciere, the yearely rent ri­





sing by ones ground: f.

Le fond de quelque chose que ce
soit, the ground of a thing, the bot­
tome: m.

Vn fond, champ & pié de terre,
 soile, a peece of ground.

Iurisdiction foncierie, the power and
iurisdiction to sease the land & not
the body.

Fonder, to ground.

Fondé par dessoubs, founded vnder­
neath.

Faire fonds aux finances, to giue bot­
tome, foundation or ground to the 
kings reuenue, such as are annexed
to the crowne.

Trafique de marchandise est vn
fonds de finances inespuisable tra­
fique is a spring of a kings treasure,
which cannot be dried vp.

Il plora moult abondamment, he
wept abundantly.

Vn fondement, a ground, a foundation.

La piere fondamentale, the chiefest
stone of the foundation.

Fondateur, a builder, a founder: m.

Vne fonde, a sling: f.

Fondre, je fonds, je fondi, j'ay fondu,
je fondray, to melt, to cast.

Se fondre, to melt away, to consume,
to sinke.

Fondeur, a melter or a trier: m.

Fondant, melting.

Fondement, a melting, also ones fun­
dament: m.

Fondriére, a quagmire, a bog, also a
great and deep valley among moun­
tains and hils: f.

Fondrilles, the dregs of any liquor.

De fons en comble, as ruiner vne
ville de fons en comble, to destroy
the whole towne.

Les fons, the Font where they chri­
sten children: m.

Tenir vn enfant sur les fons, to name
or holde a childe vpon the Font.

Fonte, casting, or melting: f.

Vne Fontaine, a spring, a fountain: f.

Vn fontenier, a digger of Welles, a 
seeker of springs: m.

For, with his Compounds signifieth
out, as for-clos, shut out: sometime
euill, as for-conseiller, to giue euill
counsaile.

Forain, a forraine, a stranger: m.

Forbannir, to banish one.

Vn cheval forbeu, a horse which
hath dronke being too hote.

Home Forbeu, a man which hath 
drunke more then measure, ouer­
seene in drinke.

Il se forboit, he ouerseeth himself in
drinke.

Force, strength, force, power, vertue: f.

Force & puissance, might and pow­
er.

Force & Verru, strength and vertue.

Qui a force escus, one which hath
plentie of crownes.

De toute ma force, with all my pow­
er.

Par force, by force, violently.

Ie ne fay point force de cela, I am 
nothing moued by that, I make no
reckoning of that, the same mo­
ueth me not at all.

Forceur, a conquerour, an enforcer, 
enforced.





Forcener, or estre forcené, to become
mad.

Forcené, madde, furious, out of his
wit.

Forcenement, or Forcenerie, mad­
nesse: m.

Forcer, to compell, to force one, also to
rauishe and force a woman, also to
break: as il a forcé la porte, he hath
broken the dore open: also to bring 
one to extremitie: as voilà vn cerf
forcé des chiens, that is, a Hart o­
uercome and without breath by the 
Hounds: Finally, to passe through,
as Il a forcé les gardes du chaste­
au, he is gone through the gardes of
the Fortresse.

Fortial, as cœur invincible et Fortial
 an inuincible and stout hart.

Forces, ou ciseaux, sheares or sis­
sers: f.

Forcette, small sheares: f.

Forclorre, to exclude.

Forchasser, to driue, cast, or shut more
of one side then of the other, as when
a bowe is stronger in one side then in
the other: as mon arc forchasse, &
forjecte, my bow shooteth not right.

For-conseiller, seeke For.

Forer, ou percer, to bore a hole.

Foret, an auger, a percer: m.

Vne Forest, a Forrest, a Wilder­
nesse: f.

Lieu forestier & sauvage, a wooddye
and wilde place.

Vn Forrestier, the keeper of a parke
or Forrest, sometime a stranger or
forraine: m.

Arbres Forestiers, trees growing in
Forrests.

Lieux forestiers et espais, ou les be­
stes se cachent en temps d'esté,
 lawnd in woods.

Forest Barbarique, a strange or vn­
acquainted Forrest.

Forfaict, fault, crime, forfeite: m.

Avoir forfaict contre quelque loy
imposant peine, to forfeite against
the law.

Forfaire sa terre, to forfeit his land.

Forfaire, to commit a fault.

Forfaiture, forfeiting: f.

Forfan, a knaue: m.

Forge à fer, a Smiths forge: f.

Forger & marteler, to forg or frame.

Estre forgé, to be forged.

Forgement, a forging: m.

Forgeron, a forger, a Smith: m.

Forgeur, a forger, a framer: m.

Forjectures, f: the coping or water ta­
ble of a wall.

For-juger vn home, to condemne and 
iudge a man wrongefully: also to
disinherite one.

For-juger vn Royaume, to renounce
or giue ouer a kingdome.

For-jurer son mestier, to giue ouer
his trade.

Forligner, to degenerate.

Forlignant, degenerating.

For-longer, or fortlonger, to goe far
before.

Forlonge, f: as les chiens chassent de
forlonge, the Hounds doe hunt the 
beast farre behinde.

Formage, seeke Fourmage.

Formalitez, order or proceeding in 
the lawe: f.





Se formalizer pour aucun, to take a 
quarrell for another, to be stubborne
or stiffe one against another.

For-mariage a mariage against the 
custome and lawe.

La forme, façon & traict de quel­
que chose, the forme, fashion, or 
draught of a thing.

Former, to frame, to fashion.

Vne forme, a Shoemakers last: f.

Vn formelier, he which maketh lasts
for shoemakers: m.

Vne forme & longue selle, a fourme
or long stoole.

Formener vn home, to vexe or tor­
ment a man.

Forment, Formentée, see Froment.

Forment, almost, as il est forment
guéri, he is almost healed, it is taken
also for very greatly, as il est for­
ment malade, he is very sicke.

Formilliere, ants hill: Formiere, idem
see Fourmis: f.

Formosité, fairenesse, welfauoured­
nesse: f.

Formule, a stile in writing, a prescri­
bed forme to proceed in the lawe: f.

Formulaire, as cest vn practicien
qui entend bien son formulaire,
 he is a practiser which vnderstan­
deth well his stile.

Fors toy, but onely thee.

Fornaise, a fornace, seeke Fournaise.

Forniquer, to commit fornication.

Fornication, fornication: f.

Fornicateur, a fornicator: m.

Forpaïser, to erre or wander out of
his countrey, to be out of his coun­
trey.

Se forpasser d'vn pas, to goe apace, or
step more then needeth.

Fort robuste & puissant, very strong
and mighty.

Fortelet, somewhat strong, increa­
sing strength.

Vn fort latron, a strong theefe: m.

Cela est fort bon, that is very good.

Ie me fais fort de cela, I take this v­
pon me.

Du fort,aluine or absince, Worme­
wood: m.

Fortifier, to fortifie, to strengthen.

Fortification, fortification: f.

Fortifiement, a fortifiying: m.

Fortifiable, a place that may be for­
tified, com.

Forteresse, a fortresse, a holde: f.

Vn fort & camp arresté, a Forte or
setled campe: m.

Fort, pour beaucoup, very much.

Chose fort vtile, a very profitable
thing.

Fort bien, very well.

Fortiall, see Force.

Fortuit, as cela est advenu par
cas fortuit, the same is happened
by chaunce.

Fortuitement, idem.

Fortraire, to withdraw from his neigh­
bor any thing of his, either his goods
or his seruants.

Fortunal, as tel estoit son fortunal,
 such was his hap or chaunce: m.

Fortune, fortune, hap, chaunce: f.

Fortunément, happily.

Vne fosse, a pit, a ditch, a graue.

Forvoyer, to goe out of the way, seeke
Fourvoyer.





Fosselu, as menton fosselu, the chin
hauing a little pit.

Fouäille, the garbage which hunters
do giue to their dogs, at the taking
of the wilde bore, as la Curée, at the
killing of the Hart.

Fossette, a little pit: as jouër à la fos­
sette, to play at nine holes: f.

Fossoyeur, a graue maker: m.

Fouäge, a leuie or subsidie taken vpon
eche fier or housholde: m.

Fouët, ou escourgée, a whippe or
scourge: m.

Fouëtter, to whip, to scourge.

Fougiere or Feuchiere, ferne, brake.

Vne Fougeray, f: a ferne ground.

Fouiller & cercher soigneusement,
 to searche diligently, to dig as hogs 
doe.

Fouiller vn home, to search a man.

Fouilleurs, searchers: m.

Fouillement, a searching: m.

Fouïnne, ou chat, selon aucuns, a
beast called a Foyne: f.

Fouïr la terre, & creuser, to digge or
delue the earth.

Fouïsseur, a digger: m.

Fouïssement, digging, deluing: m.

Fouldre, lightening: f.

Fouldroyer, to lighten, to thunder, to
destroy, to strike with lightening.

Fouldroyé, striken with lightning.

Foule de peuple, a throng of peo­
ple: f.

Fortir à la foule, to come out by a 
throng.

Fouler aux pieds, to tread vnder the 
feete.

Vne Foulerie, or Foulicre, the place
where they presse the grapes in time
of vintage.

Foulé, the path or trace of the
Harte vpon grasse, leaues, or dust,
which cannot be well discerned or
knowne: f.

Foulque, a birde called a Coote, and
because of the blacknesse is called a diuell:
m.

Foulon, a Fuller: m.

Vn four, an Ouen: m.

Vne fournée de pain, a batch: f.

Fournier, one that keepeth an Ouen
for folke to bake in: m.

Vne fourbe, stuffe, or smokehole: f.

On peult facilement juger de ceste 
fourbe, we may easily iudge of this
stuffe, or smoke hole, or guile.

Ce n'est qu'vne fourbe, it is but a lie
or counterfeited matter.

Fourbir, to fourbish, to pollish: je four­
bis, je fourbi, j'ay fourbi, je four­
biray, to burnish, to scoure.

Vn Fourbisseur, a Cutler: f.

Vne Fourche, a forke: f.

Fourché, forked.

Vne fourche-fiere, a fire fork, a trout
speare.

Fourchons, vne fourche à quatre
fourchons, as a forke with foure teeth
or forkets.

Fourcher, quand la langue four­
che, to stutte, to trippe with the
toung.

Fourchette, a little forke, a forket: f.

Fourchu, forked, as bestes à pied for­
cheu ou fourchu, cloue footed beasts.

Vn fourgon, a makron, an ouen rake:
m: patrouille rouäble.





Fourgonner, to stirre with an Ouen
rake.

Fourmage, cheese: m.

Vne Fourmagiere, or Formageres,
 a cheesepresse.

Fourment, seeke froment.

Fourmy, an Ante, an Emmot, a Pis­
mire: m.

Vne fourmilliére, pismires bankes or
nestes: f.

Fourmiller, to abound as Antes in
their nests or caues.

Vne fournaise, a furnace: f.

Fournir de quelque chose, to fur­
nish, to make vp that wanteth, je
fournis, je fourni, j'ay fourni, je
fourniray.

Fournir à l'appointement charnel
d'une fame, to fill the carnal lust of 
a woman

Founissement, furnishing: m.

Fourniture, furniture: f.

Fourrage, forrage for horses: m.

Fourrageur, qui va aux fourrages,
 a forrager: m.

Fourrager, to goe to forrage: to
fodder.

Fourreau, a scabbered: m.

Le bout d'un Fourreau, the chape of 
the scabbered.

Fourrer, ou jecter dedens, to thrust
in, to throw in.

Fourrer robbes, to furre gownes.

Fourreur, a furrier, a skinner: m.

Fourriers qui ordonnent les quar­
tiers, they that appoynt lodgings in
the princes court: Harbingers.

Fourser, comme font les carpes en
vn estang, to spawne, to cast the 
spawne as Carpes doe in a ponde: 
to burnish, to scoure.

Fourbi, furbushed.

Fourbir son harnois, to furbushe his
harnesse.

Fourbissure, furbushing: f.

Se fourvoir, to stray, to erre.

Fourvoyement, a straying: m.

Fouteau, fayant, or hestre, a Beech
tree: m.

Le foyer, or fouyer de la maison, the
harth: m.

Vne Fouyasse, a kinde of cake vsed at
Christmas holydayes in Bourbon­
nois shire: f.

Foy, quand on tient sa promesse,
 fayth: f.

Faire la foy & homage, to make ho­
mage to his Lord.

Le foye, the liuer: m.

Foyes, the traces and steps of redde
wilde beasts: f.

Fracasser, to bruse, breake, to teare.

Fraction, or fracture, a breaking, or
bursting: f.

Fragate, or fragats, f: a swift vessell
vpon the sea.

Fragile, frayle, com.

Fragilité, bricklenesse.

Fragment, a piece or gobbet of any
broken thing: m.

Fraesle, or fresle, fraile, brickle.

Fraislure, frailenesse, frailty, brickle­
nesse.

Freislusement, bricklely, fraylely.Neither "bricklely" nor "frailily" was found in the OED.



Frain & mords d'vne bride, the bit
of a bridle: m.

Frais, fraischement, seeke Frez.

Fraiz & despens, charge, cost: m.





Des fraises, strawberies: f.

Vn fraisier, the hearb bearing straw­
beries: m.

Vne fraise de veau, a Calues chaul­
derne.Only one citation for "chawdron" in the OED (c1440).

Vne fraise de chemise, ruffes.

La fraise de ma chemise est trop lon­
gue, my ruffes are too deepe.

Fralater du vin, to drawe wine out of
a tunne or hogshead, and put it into
another vessell.

Fralatement, or tralatement, the 
drawing of wine without his lee: m.

Fraisne, seeke freisne.

Framboises, red-corrantes: some do
call them hurtle-beries: f.

France, France.

Franc, qui ne doibt point de tribut,
 free at libertie, francke: m.

Franc & liberal, liberall, francke,
free.

Ville franche, a free towne.

Franchir, je franchis, je franchi, j'ay
franchi, je franchiray, as franchir
vne muraille, to leape ouer a
wall.

Franchir le sault, ouerleape.

Franchement & sans crainte, freely,
without feare.

Franchise, freedome.

Franchise, f: a iagge: purfle.

Frange, a fringe: f.

Les franges d'un lict, the valens of 
a bedde.

Franger, to croumpell or iagge.

Feuilles frangées ou deschiquetées,
 leaues croumpled and iagged on the
edges.

Frangé & crené, fringed that hath a 
fringe.

Frapper, to strike, to knocke, to
beate.

Frappé, striken, knockt, rapt.

Frappement, a striking: m.

Frere frapart, a name giuen to monks
and fryers, because they suppose
that such fellowes doe strike well:
m.

Fratrisseau, m: a little vnexperte
young Frier.

Fraternel, seeke frere.

Fraude, deceit, guile: f.

Frauder quelqu'vn, to deceiue one.

Fraudulent, or fraudeur, deceitful: m.

Frauduleux, or fraudateur, a decei­
uer: m.

Frauduleusement, deceitfully.

Frayer, & heurter contre la rive, to
rap agaynst the shore.

Frayer, or froyer, to rubbe, also to
spawne in fishes, also when serpents,
frogs and such like doe couple to­
gether: to beare cost and charges.

Frayement d'vne chose contre vne
autre, a rubbing of one thing a­
gainst another.

Chemin frayé, a beaten way.

Frayeur, feare, frighting: m.

Fredaine, a lye or tale, a guile, de­
ceitfull trickes: f.

Fredons, warbling of voyce in mu­
sicke: m.

Fredonner, to warble or quauer.

Fregate, or fragate, a kinde of vessell
vpon the sea: pinnases: f.

Frelan, m: an hornet.

Frelan, or murt sauvage, or els Bruse,
m: I take to be holy.





Fremir, to quake for feare.

Fremir de courroux, to quake tho­
rough anger.

Frenaisie, f: frensie.

Frenatique, a franticke person.

Frequenter, ou hanter quelque 
lieu, to frequent, to haunt, to vse
a place.

Frere, a brother: m.

Fraternel, belonging to a brother.

Fraternellement, brotherly.

Fraternité, f: brotherhood.

Fresaye ou cheveche, a shrich-Owle.

Freschement, seeke frez.

Fresle ou fragile, frayle, brickle.

Estre trop excessif ou trop fresle au
deduict d'Amour, & ainsi finir 
sa vie, to bee earnest, hoate, or
weake in fleshly lust or venerie,
and so to end his dayes through too
great pleasure.

Fresler, among mariners is to folde.

Fresne arbre, an Ashe tree: m.

Fressure, ou fresure, the inwardes or
intrailes, a geather, as vne fresu­
re, or corée de pourceau, or de
mouton, a hogges haslet or sheepes
geather: f.

Payer le fret, to pay for the fraught
or fraight.

Ceste marchandise passe sans fret,
 that merchandise doth pay no cu­
stome or toll.

Freter vne navire, to straight a ship.

Fretiller, to waue, to moue, to wagge,
to wauer.

Home fretillant, or fretillard, a tick­
lish, a sturring man.

Desir ou envie fretillard, a tickling
or prouoking desire.

Freze, see fraise.

Frez & nouvellement faict, fresh, newe
done.

Du pain frez, new bread: m.

La chose est fresche, the matter is
recent.

Se reposer au frez du bocage, the rest
at the coole of a groue.

Se poumener à la fescheur, to walke 
in the coole: f.

Tout freschement, freshly.

vn friand, friolet, a licorish fellow,
a sweet-lips: m.

Friander, to feede licorishly.

Friandise, licorish thinges licorish­
nesse: f.

Fricasser, or frire, to frie.

Vne fricassée, any meate fried in a 
panne.

Fricassé, fried.

Friche, comme, terre delaissée en
friche, fallowe grounde that lieth
fallow.

Frilleux, chill, colde of nature: m.

Frima, or frimats, mist: m.

Fringoter, to quauer in singing.

Fringuer, to bee minion, fine and 
trimme.

Faire la fringue, to go finely in app­
rell, and other wanton trickes: f.

Vn frelan, a butchers broome.

Frioler, to be gaye, to playe the fine
fellow.

Comme le feu friole la paille, as fire
consumeth strawe.

Vestements fripez, clothes that haue
been worne, and newe trimmed to
be solde.





Vn fripier, a seller of olde clothes, an
vpholdster: m.

Vne Fripiére, a woman seller of olde
things: f.

Vne friperie, the place where they sell
such olde garments: m.

Vn friquet, a little scummer to turne
fish in a frying panne, also a licko­
rous sticke: m.

Frire, to frie: je fris, j'ay frit, je fri­
ray.

Il à frit le bon home, ah, the good
man hath spent all.

Des Friteaux, Fraize, Fritters: m.

Friture, frying: f.

Frisque & gay, fine, and liuely.

Frisson, quaking for colde, shiuering.

Frissonner, to quake for colde, to shi­
uer.

Frize, spanish friese: f.

De la grosse frize, rough friese.

Frizer les cheveux, to curle the hairs,
to frizle.

Frizoter les cheveux, or la barbe de  
mille nœuds, to curle the hayres
or beard with a thousand knottes.

Perruque frizée, the hayre bushe 
frizeled.

Frizes, frize cloth.

Frivole, vaine trifling of no value,
friuolous, com.

Froc de moine, the hoode of a 
Monke: m.

Getter le froc aux orties, to cast his
hood to the nettles, that is, when a 
monke doth cast off his monkish ap­
parell, and run away.

Froid, colde.

Froidement, coldely.

Froidure, coldnesse: f.

Froidureus, a chillie person that is 
euer acolde, that cannot bee from
the fire.

Avoir froid, to be colde.

Froilon, ou frelon, a hornet.

Froisser, to breake in pieces, to quash
in sunder, to dash.

Froissement, a dashing, a crushing
in pieces: m.

Froissis, m: knocking together: bur­
sting.

Froment, wheate: m.

Fromentée, furmentie: f.

Vn clou, ou froncle, a bile, a white­
flaw: m.

Fronser vne chemise, to gather a 
shirte bande, also to frowne, as fron­
ser le front.

Fronsure, a gathering, frowning: f.

Le front, the forehead: m.

Vn fronteau, a frontlet, a forehead
cloth, a fillet: m.	

Le frontiere d'vne bride, the face
parte of the bridle: a headstall: f.

Les frontieres d'vn païs, the fron­
tiers of a countrey: the front or 
marches.

Frotter de quelque liqueur, to rubbe
with water, to chafe, to soke, also
to beate one.

Frottement, a rubbing, a cha­
fing: m.

Frouelle, an agnaile, a pinne, a war­
nell in ones toe.

Frouër, or effrouër, to crumme.

Froument, wheate: m.

Fourmentée, Fourmentie: f.

Froumenté, a kinde of white grape





very pleasant to eate: m.

Froyer, seeke Frayer.

Frugale, as tenir vne façon de vivre
frugale, to keepe or followe a sober
life, sparing, thriftie.

Frugalité, thriftines, sparing: f.

Fruict, fruit: m.

Fruictier, that beareth fruit, an Or­
chard: a costermonger: a fruite­
rer: m.

Vne fruictiere, a woman selling fruit.

Fructueux, fruitfull.

Fructuosité, fruitfulnesse: f.

Fruition, as avoir fruition de quel­
que chose, to haue the fruition of 
some thing that is to enjoy: f.

Fruistrer & priver aucun de quelque
chose, to frustrate or disappoint
one.

Estre Frustré de son esperance, to be
frustrate of the hope conceiued.

Frustaroire, hauing the power to fru­
state, com.

Frustration, defrauding: f.

La Feuille des arbres, the leaues of
trees: f.

Fueille, tant d'arbres que d'herbes,
 the leaues of trees or hearbes.

Vne Feuille de papier, a sheete of pa­
per.

Feuillars de Chesne, the boughes of
an Oke.

Feuillée, or Fueillade, the shadowe of
leaues and trees: f: an arbour.

Fueillu, full of leaues.

Feuillage, such pictures of leaues and
trees which be wrought in tapestrie,
or painting: m.

Fueillet, a leafe of a booke: m.

Fueiller, ou iecter fueilles, to bring
forth leaues.

Fueilleux, full of leaues.

Les fueillets d'vn livre, the leaues of
a booke.

Fueilletter les livres, to turne ouer
bookes, to search, or reade.

Fugitif, ou Fuitif, fugitiue, runa­
way: m.

Fuir, to flee, to runne away.

Fuir & eviter, to flee, to shunne, to a­
uoyde: je fuis, je fui, j'ay fui, je fui­
ray.

Fuyant, flying.

Les Fuyars, those that runne away
from the battell: m.

Ombre Fuyarde, a running or pas­
sing shadowe.

Fuyeur, a runaway: m.

Fuite, a flight: f.

Fumée, smoake: f.

Vn Fumeau, a brand, a smoaking
sticke: m.

Fumiéres, m: the dung of a Hart,
Hind, Roe, and such like.

Fumer, to smoake.

Fuirolles, Cressets: m: also Fire­
drakes.

Fumier, a dunghill: m.

Fumer les Oliviers, to dung Oliue
trees.

Fumement de terre, dunging of
ground.

Fume-terre, herbe, Fumitorie: f.

Functions, as le cerveau est le siege
de toutes les functions, the braines
is the seate of all the doings: f.

Funeste, a lamentable thing.

Funerailles, burials, funerals: f.





Vn Furet, a Ferret: m.

Fureter & cercher par tout, to search
euery where like a Ferret.

Fureur, furie, rage: f.

Furieux, furious, raging, wrathful: m.

Furieusement, furiously.

Furgon, seeke Fourgon.

Furole, that flash of fire which is seen
vpon the sea in the Sayles yarde,
which the Mariners doe call Saint
Hermes fire: f."Saint Hermes fire" antedates earliest OED entry (1611).

Furt, stealth, theft: m.

Furtivement, by stealth, priuely.

Fusées avec ses pesons, the quill of
threed, or the spindle & threed with
the werble: f.

Achever sa fusée, when a woman hath
spun her full quill.

Vne Fusée, a squib.

Vn Fusil, a Fusil to strike fire in a tin­
der boxe: also the steele of a butcher
wherewith he whetteth or sharpe­
neth his kniues: m.

Fusiller, or Fureter, to search in euery
corner.

Fust, a Frame whereon Artillerie is
set: the carriage of an Artillerie: 
so we say Affuster, and Desaffuter,
to set vp, or set downe off the frame: 
also the great beame of a wine
presse: also a speare staff.

Fustaille à mettre vin, the vessels 
whereinto we vse to put wine: f.

Fustaye, is a general word for groues
or high trees of the Forrest, as Ar­
bres de haulte Fustaye, great, high
and old trees f.

Vn Fust, a staffe, a stake: m.

Vne Fuste legére, a Foist or light
ship: f.

Fustaine, ou bombasin, toute au­
tre chose faicte de Cotton, Fu­
stian: f.

Fustiguer, to whippe one about the 
towne.

Futur, as au tans futur, in the time to
come.

Fut, seeke Estre.

Il fut, he was.

Fuzain, the tree whereof they make
spindles: m.


G ante A.

GAban, or Caban, a cloake made
of Felt against the raine: m.

Gabarre, a kind of ship or boate: f.

Gabelle, toll, tribute: f.

Sel Gabelé, or marchandise Gabe­
lée, salt or marchandise customed:
whose custome or toll is payed.

Gaber, to mocke, to floute.

Gaberies, or gabes, tales, mockes: f.

Gabeur, a mocker, a flouter: m.

Gabeller, to flout and mocke.

Gabion, a basket of earth, such as
they vse for defence in warre: m.

Gabionner, to fortifie himselfe with
such defence of baskets full of
earth.

Gabie, as la gabie d'vn navire, the
vpper part of the mast, wherein the
cords or shroudes are fastened: f.

Gage, loyer & salaire qu'on donne
pour la desongne, wages, rewarde
in respect of worke: m.

Le gage qu'on met en jeu, a gage, a
pawne, the stake in play: m.





Les gages des gens-darmes, Soul­
diours wages.

Gager contre aucun, to lay a wager,
to gage.

Gager aulcun, to streine ones goods.

Simple Gagerie, f: a streining of
goods.

Faire gageure & mettre en jeu, to 
wage, to pawne: f.

Gage de combat, when two fighters
cast their Gauntlets for a paune of
the fight to come.

Gai, or gay, merie, light hearted, liue­
ly, seeke Gay.

Gageure, the wager.

Quitter la Gageure, to giue ouer the 
wager.

Gaigner, to winne, to gaine, to profite.

Gaigner vn mal, to get a disease.

Gagnage, or gain, gaine: m.

Terres gagnables, or labourables,
 land which may be tilled, com.

Gaigne-denier, a porter, a winne­
penny.

Gaigne-pain: as cest vn bon gaigne-­
pain, he playeth the good husband:
a good painfull iourneyman.

Gaillard, lustie, frolicke, gallant.

Gaillardement, gallantly: liuely.

Gaing, gaine, getting: m.

Gaine, a sheath: f.

Gayole, or Cage, a cage: f.

Gayoler, to prattle as a bird doth in
a cage.

Gajure, ou Gageure, seeke Gage.

Galland, a fine, craftie, subtile, wittie
fellowe: m.

Gallantise, fine and merie deede or
counsell: f.

Du Galbanon, a kind of gumme issu­
ing out of an hearbe: m.

Galle, a galling, a fretting, a rubbing
of the skinne: f.

Vne Galeace, a kind of ship: f.

Vn Galerand, or Butor, a kinde of
bird called a Bittour: m.

Galerne, a colde winde making the
vines to freese: f.

Vn Galafre, or Galifre: m: a cormo­
rant, or greedie deuourer of meate.

Vn Galetas, a garret: m.

Vn povre Gale-frotier: m: a poore
scabbie knaue.

Vne Galete, f: a broad thinne cake:
see Gasteau.

Galler, to gall, to chafe, to scratch
when it itcheth.

Galleux, scabbed, itchie: m.

Gallée de trois rames pour bane, a
galley with three rowes of ores: f.

Gallée de cinq rames pour banc,
 a galley with fiue rowes of ores.

Galleres, Galleys.

Condemner aulcun aux Galleres
perpétuelles, to condemne one to
the Galleys for euer.

Gallion, ou Brigantin, vne sorte de
naviére anisi nommée, a Galliot, a
Brigandine: m.

Vn Galiot, the master of a ship.

Vne galiote, a swift vessell betweene
a Galley and a Brigandine: f.

Gallerie, où on se pourmene, a gal­
lerie, a walking place: f.

Galloches, a kinde of shooe, a pat­
tin: f.





Galloches, m: be schollers in the V­
niuersitie going from colledge to col­
ledge to hear & take their lectures.

Gallonner & frotter fort en amig­
notant, to clap on the backe, to che­
rish.

Galloper, to gallop.

Aller le grand gallop, to runne in
hast: m.

Gambades, gamboles: f.

Gangrene, son bras est tombé en
gangrene, his arme wounded is
cankred: f.

Vn Gantier, a Glouer: m.

Vn gant, a gloue: m.

Les gans nostre dame, an herbe cal­
led our ladies gloues.

Gantelets de fer, gantlets: m.

Gantes, or rather Iantes, the circles of
a cart wheele: f.

Garance, herbe, Madder which
Diers vse: f.

Drap garancé, cloath dyed with that
colour of Madder.

Garant, a graunt: a warrant: m.

Gare, gare, beware, beware: a word
spoken when we warne one to auoyde
a perill.

Garantie, f: warrant.

Gaquiére, land that lieth lay: seeke
jachere.

La garantie, warrantise, authoritie: f.

Garbouil, hurly burly, murmuring.

Garçon, see Garson.

Garçonner, to play the boy.

Garçonner vne fille, to defloure or
defile a maide.

La garde, ward, custodie: f.

La garde du corps d'vn prince, a
Kings gard.

La garde du corps d'vn capitaine, a
Captaines warde.

Les gens de la Garde ont mis leurs
hoquetons argentez, the yeomen
of the Gard haue put on their
best coates.

Garder, to warde, to keepe, to defend,
to shield.

Bailler en garde, to giue in warde, to
commit, to giue in custodie.

Se prendre garde, to take heed.

Donne toy garde, take thou heed.

Ce fruit n'est pas de garde, this fruit
is not of long custodie.

Garde que, &c. take heede that, be­
ware least, &c.

Gardeur de bestial, a Heard, a Pa­
stour: m.

Gardien, ou gardienne, a Warden, a 
keeper: m.

Le pere gardien, the head and chie­
fest among the Friers.

La Garde d'un malade: a keeper, he
or she that keepeth a sicke person.

Garde gardienne, he that is put in
trust of land or other thing to ano­
ther vse, and so to yeeld it vp a­
gaine.

Gardien d'aucune chose, he which
hath any thing in keeping.

Vn garde-bras, the bracelets of an
armour, that piece of armour coue­
ring the armes: m.

Vn Garde-manger, cupboorde, an
ambrie, a buttrie: m.

Garde-robbe, a wardrope: f.

Garderobbe, or Avronne, Southern­
wood.





Gardon, poisson, a Goodgion: m.

Garée, a peece of ground not newly
wrought or trimmed, but tilled of
olde: f.

Garet, the earth tilled: m.

Garence, seeke garance.

Garanne, a warren of Cunnies: f.

Gargarizer, to gargill or washe the
mouth.

La gargouille ou siflet, the pipe: f.

Gargouiller, to gargle.

Gargouillement, a gargling: m.

Le Garignon ou osselet de quoy jo­
uënt les petis enfans, the huckle­
bone: m.

Garite, or fuite, flight, running away,
as gagner la garite, to flie & run
away, to saue himselfe by flight: f.

Prendre la garite, & fuir a vau de
route. idem.

Garite, as dresser des garites au
hault d'un chasteau pour y faire
courir la ronde aux Soldats, au be­
soing d'un siege, to build on the top
of a castle galeries of defence to &c.

Garnement, or Pendart, a naughtie
packe, a vile gallowes: m.

C'est le fait d'vn mauvais garne­
ment, it is the deede of a naughty
packe.

Garnir d'or, to garnish with golde.

Garnir sa maison, to furnishe or
trim a house: je garnis, je garni, j'­
ay garni, je garniray.

Garny, garnished.

Qui garnit, which garnisheth.

Garnison, store, preparation: f.

Le Garnison qu'on met en vne vil­
le, the garrison of a towne.

Ganiture, la ganiture d'vn lict,
d'vne espée, ou quelque chose,
 the garniture or furniture of a bed,
sword, or any other thing: f.

Lier & Gartoter vn home, to
binde a man with cordes like a
theefe.

Garrer vn Bateau, to trimme his
boate.

Le Garrot d'un cheval: 

Garrulité, f: cackling.

Vn garrot, the bolt of a crossebow: m.

Garson, a boy: m.

Garson-fillette, both boy and wench.

Vn gars, m: a Lad, a yong strip­
ling.

Vne jeune garse, a yong wench: f.

Garsette, f: a very yong wench.

Garsonner la femme d'autruy, to
haue to do with another mans wife.

Vne gasche, an ore, a skull: f.

Gascher, to rowe.

Gascher du plastre, to spread a plai­
ster, to make a water.

Gaschement, a rowing: m.

Gaschis d'eau, when the waterman in
rowing doth washe or sprinckle one
with water: m.

Gaspiller son propre & despendre
follement, to waste and spend away
his goods, to lash or lauishe out
wastely his money.

Gaspilleur d'argent & gaudisseur, a
spender, a prodigall person: m.

Gastadours, or pionniers, diggers in
Mines: m.

Gaste-bois, an euill Carpenter which
marreth such stuffe as is put in his
hands: f.





Gaste-pavé, a trotter vpon the paue­
ment, a walker by the streets: m.

Gate, a bowle, seeke Iate: f.

Vn Gasteau, ou galete, a cake: m.

Donnes moy de votre Galete, giue 
me of your thinne Cake.

Gaster, to marre, to spill, to waste, to
consume.

Gastement, or Gast, a marring: m.

La gauche ou main senestre, the left
hand: f.

Gauchier, a left handed: m.

Oster vne Gauche opinion, to take
away an euill opinion conceiued in
ones minde.

Gauche, com: le costé gauche, la
main gauche, the left side, the left
hand.

Gauchir, je gauchis, je gauchi, j'ay
gauchi, je gauchiray, ou tordre, to
wring or bend, to goe aside.

Gauchi, ou gauché, wrong.

Gauchirson cheval, to turn his horse
aside, to shun the blowe.

Gauchir au coup, to giue or turne a­
side for feare of a blowe.

Gaudir & faire grosse chere, to be
frolike, to be liuely.

Se gaudir d'aucun, to iest with one, to
floute, je me gaudis, je me gaudi,
je me suy gaudi, je me gaudiray.

Gaudisseur, a iester: m.

Par gaudisserie, in iest or floutingly: f.

Gauffre, seeke Goffre.

Gauffrure, a kinde of embrodering, an
embossing: f.

Vne riche Gaufreure, a rich embro­
dering.

Le Gaujon, the throte boll: m: the
gullet.

Vne gaule, a staffe, a long slender
pole: f.

Gauler quelcun, to cudgell one, also
to rob or spoyle one.

La Gaule celtique, the farthest part
of Fraunce.

Vn Gausseur or Gaudisseur, a scof­
fer: m.

Vn Gay, or Geay, a Iaye: m.

Gay & joyeux, mery, lusty.

Couleur gaye & resjouïssante, a 
liuely colour delighting the eye.

Gayement & joyeusement, cheer­
fully.

Gayeté, mirth, liuelynesse: f.

Gave, that kinde of cloth which wo­
men drawe the patternes of their 
worke by: m.

Gazon de terre, a greene turfe: m.

Gazouiller, to whistle, sing, chirpe, or
warble as birds do.

Gazouillis de fontaine, the noyse
which the water causeth falling out
of the cocke of a Fountaine: m.

Geant, or Giant, a Giant: m.

Gect, ou Iect, a throwe or cast at
dice, the draught with a nette in
waters, the Shippe-mans sounding
leade: m.

Vn Gect ou bende large, a purfle, a 
garde, a welt: m.

Gectons, seeke Getter.

Genne, ou Gehenne, torture ou
question, a racke, a place of tor­
ment: f.

Geindre, to crocke like a doue or pi­
geon, also to bewaile or complaine
vnder an heauie burthen.





Geiner, ou Geheinner quelqu'vn, to
racke one.

Gelée, frost, gellie: f.

De la Gelée, f: gellie.

Vne Gelée blanche, a hoarie frost.

Il y avoit vne Gelée blanche à ce
matin, there was a white frost this 
morning.

Geler, to freese.

Gelement, a freesing: m.

Gelure, Ice, f: frost.

Geline ou poulle, a hen: f.

Les Gelines pondent par le bec, the
hennes doe lay their Egges by the 
hill.

Gelinette, f: a little henne.

Gelinier, a hen house, a roust: m.

Gemeau, a twin: m.

ay gemi, je gemiray.

Gemissement, a sighing: m.

Gemme, a pearle: f.

Gemmeux, full of pearles.

Gendarme, a man of armes: m.

souldiours: f.

La Gencive, the Gummes: f.

Gendre, my sonne in law, my daugh­
ters husband: m.

Genealogie, f: the genealogie, the de­
grees of kinred or petigrees of one.

General, generall.

Le General d'vne armée, the gene­
rall ouer an armie: m.

Les Generauls des monnoyes, the
ouerseers of mints and money.

Generalement, generally, compre­
hending all.

Generation, begetting, ingendring: f.

Generer, to ingender.

humour, f.

Generosité, gentlemanlinesse, cou­
rage: f.

Du Genest, greene broome: m.

Fait de genest, made of that where­
with they make greene broomes.

Genevre, genevrier, Iuniper: m.

Genisse, a Heafer: f.

Genitoires, the priuy parts: m.

Geniture royalle, a royall proge­
nie: f.

La genie d'un chacun, the good or e­
uill spirit or angel of ech one.

Genial, m: pertaining to good or euil 
lucke or chaunce.

Genne, Genner, racking, to racke.
see Geine.

Genouil, a knee, sound Genou: m.

Genouillet, a little knee: m.

Genouille, hauing many knots: as la­
tige du fenoil est nouëuse et Ge­
noillée, the stalke of the Fenell is
knottie.

Genouillée, f: an hearbe called of
some Stichworte.

Genrehumain, mankinde: m.

Vne Gent & nation, a nation a
kinred: f.

Gens de mestier, handiecrafte men:
m.

Gens d'eglise, Church men: m.

Il y a gens & gens, there is no choise
in men.





Gens de robbe longue, men of law.

Gent, miste & propre, a proper man,
a hansome fellowe: m.

Gentement, seeke gentil.

Gentienne herbe, an herbe called
Gentian: f.

Gentil, feate, proper, comely, gentle,
tractable.

C'est vn gentil personage, vn gentil
esprit, a proper man, a fine wit, a gen­
tle person.

Chose gentille, belle, plaisante &
de bonne grace, a plesant & hand­
some thing.

chamber.

scante worthie the name of a Gen­

in Latin, Semipaganus.

Gentillement, gentiment, ou gen­

thens: m.

nishe: f.

Gentilizer, to liue like an Heathen.

Gerbe de blé, a sheafe of corne.

Vne Gerbée, a great number of

Gerber des javeles, to binde corne of
swath in sheafes.

Gerbiers, a stacke of corn, also a place
to keep salt, as a great garner: m.

Gercer, gersure, seeke jarcer.

Gerfault, a kind of Hauke, the biggest
and greatest of all: m.

Germain, engendré de mesme ger­
me, come of the same stocke that I

mander: f.

Gemence & semence des arbres,
 the sprigs or sprouts of trees: f.

 the little spring of an egge: m."spring" antedates earliest OED citation (1600).

Germer, to bud, to sprout.

ting: m.

Le Germe soit d'arbres, herbes ou
semence, a branch either of trees,
herbe or seede: m.

Gersure, or fente, a clefte, also the
nebbe of a pen.

Gesir aupres, je gis, je jeu, j'ay jesy,
or jeu je gesiray, to lye by.

Sa fame gist, his wife lyeth in.

Apres que les fames ont jeu vn
mois, elle se relevent, when women
haue lyen in a moneth, they rise.

Cy gist, here lyeth.

Gisant, lying.

Gesine, a lying in.

 gesture, behauiour, demeanour, acts

summe.

Faire glissant & grillant, to be very
slipperie.

Gloire & louänge par bien faire,
 glorie, prayse: f.

Angleterre, shee is the proudest in

hearb called crowfoote: some doe

Vn godet & tout autre vaisseau de

Goës, a kinde of grapes.

Goffe, an Italian worde, it signifieth
foule, hard fauoured, lumpish, a sot.

Goffre & semblable qu'on baille aux

Gogo, as dormir à gogo, to sleepe at
his full.

Estre en ses Gogues, or else avoir v­
ne Dame en ses goguettes, to haue 
his ladie at his own wanton or flesh­
ly will.

Gogue, as tu es en tes gogues, nowe
thou art vpon thy pantofles: f.

Se goguer, or goguager, to make 
good cheere, to haue the worlde at
will: to sport.

throte, a lump of flesh swollen vnder

Devenir gourd & roide de force de

Grabat, a little bedde, a strawebed, a
poore mans couch: M.

Grace, bien & plaisir qu'on fait à
celuy qui ne l'a deservi, grace, plea­
sure done to one that hath not de­
serued it, fauour: f.

Bonne grace, good grace, handsom­
nesse.

Ie me recommande à toutes voz 
bonnes graces, I recommend mee
to your good fauour.

Avec grace, with good grace.

Obtenir sa grace, to get his pardon.

Gracieusetez, liberalitie, gentlenesse.

Gracieus, gracious, gentle, liberall.

Se mettre en la male-grace de quel­
cun, to incurre, to gette ones dis­
pleasure.

Graffigner, or esgratigner, to scratch
one.

Grailler, to blow a horne, to trumpet
hoarsely, with a hoarse noyse, also
to speake hoarse.

Graille, slender, thinne, small.

Grailleren chantant, to sing vntu­
nably.

Grains, all manner of corne: as il y
a peu de grains dedans la ville,
there is small store of corne in the
towne.

seede: m.

De la graine de Choux, de Laituës,
ou d'espinars, Colewortes, Let­

 graine wherewith Scarlet cloth is
grayned.

Teinct en graine, dyed in graine.

Grain, a graine: m.





Graisse, fat grease: f.

Vn Graissier, a Grasier: m.

Les rouës grailloyent, croyent, bru­
yoyent ou faisoyent bruit, acause
qu'elles, &c. the wheeles crackt, or
made a noyse or cracking, because
they were not greased.

Graisser les bottes, to grease bootes.

Vn graisset, a greene Toade: m.

Vn gramen, it is taken for all kind of
grasse: m.

Grammaire, Grammar: f.

Grand, great, big, large.

Grandelet, somewhat big.

Grandement, greatly.

Grandeur, greatnesse: f.

Grandeur de lieu, greatnesse of
roume.

Grandeur de corps, bignesse of bo­
die.

Grange, a barne: f.

Grangette, a little barne: f.

Passer Grangeage d'vn champ ou
terre, to let out for yeares a field: m.

Vne grangée, a good haruest: f.

Vn grangier, a Farmer: m.

La grangiére, the Farmers wife: f.

Graphigner, to scratch as cats doe.

Grapir, je grapis, je grapi, j'ay gra­
pi, je grapiray, to creep vp, to climbe
vp hardly.

Grappe de raisin, Grapes: f: a clu­
ster: a plaister of grapes.

Grappage, grape gathering, wine
haruest: m: Vintage.

Grapillage, idem: it is also the gathe­
ring which poore men doe after that
the master of the Vineyard hath ga­
thered his Grapes, as a glening in
Haruest.

Grappes, a certaine disease in horses.

Gras, fat: grosse: quarrie: pursie: m.

Vne fame Grasse: a fat woman: f.

Dormir la grasse matinée, to sleepe
till noone day.

Grasset, or grasselet, fattish, some­
what fat.

Grasseur, fatnesse: f.

Grater, to scratche, to clawe, to
scrape.

Gratelle, itch: f.

Grateleux, itchie, skuruie.

Grateron, a kinde of grasse sticking
at ones garments as they goe in the
fields, called Cliuers, or goosegrasse,
it is also called du Riéble: m.

Gratia dei, or falouze, an hearbe
which Harts vse against venemous
beasts.

Gratieux, gratious, courteous, gentle.

Gratieusement, gratiouslie, courte­
ously.

Gratieuseté, gentlenesse, gratious­
nesse.

Gratin, the remnant of the little Babes
pappe which sticketh on the bottome
of the skillet: m.

Dons Gratuits, free gifts: m.

Gratuité, as presens faits par Gra­
tuité, gifts of recompence, or for re­
compence: f.

Gratuitement, freely, sadde, se­
uere.

Gravement, grauely, aduisedly.

Gravité authorité, grauitie, au­
thoritie: f.





Gravelle, ou pierre, maladie, the dis­
ease called the stone: f.

Graveleux, a man full of grauell.

Cendre gravelée, ashes burned and
made with lees of Wine.

Graver, to graue.

Graveur, a grauer: m.

Graveure, grauing: f.

Gravier, grauell: m.

Gravir, je gravis, je gravi, j'ay gravi,
je graviray, to creepe to, to climbe
vp.

Gravité, seeke Grave.

Du gravois, grauell: m.

Gré, comme à mon gré, willing, as I
wish: m.

Il a confessé de son bon gré que, &c
 he hath confessed of his owne free
will, that, &c.

Bon gré, mal gré, nilling, willing, or
vnwillingly, against my will.

Tresmal en gré, most displeasantly or
in most euill part.

Degré à degré, from degree to de­
gree, or orderly togither.

Faire au gré d'aucun, to please one, to
gratifie.

Tout de gré, willingly, wittingly.

Prendre en gré, to take in good part.

Ie l'ay fait malgré, or maugré moy, I
haue done it against my will.

Ie ne vous sçay ne gré, ne grace de
cela, I giue you no thankes for that.

Ie vous en sçay bon gré, I like you
for that, I giue you thankes.

Il a plaidé ma cause à mon gré, he 
hath pleaded my matter at mine
owne liking.

Grebonde, as l'estœuf a grebondé, a
fait vne grebonde, the ball hath
turned a side vpon the house, when 
he that serueth at the tenise ser­
ueth well, so that the ball doth not
roule vpon the house: f.

Grecs, are the vppermost teeth of the
wilde Bore, which doe sharpen the
vndermost, called in French Armes,
limes & deffences: m.

Grec, a Greeke.

Grediller, to stroke ones head, to giue 
smooth words.

Grediller, to curle the haires with a 
hot yron: we say, entortiller, cres­
per, or grediller les cheveux.

Vn fer à grediller les cheveux, an y­
ron or pinne of wood or Iuorie, to
frisle the haire.

Gref, seeke Grief.

Vne Greffe, a graffe, a slip, a yong set,
a shrubbe: f.

Greffer ou enter, to graffe.

Greffé ou enté, graffed.

Greffe, the court of Register: m.

Mettre au Greffe, to put into the
Court.

Enrégistrer au greffe, to put in regi­
ster of the Court.

Greigneur, or gregneur, the greater,
as we say Segneur, elder.

Grelle, seeke Gresle, haile: f.

Vn Greffe de quoy on ente, a 
graffe.

Greffier, Secretarie, the Register, a
towne Clarke: m.

Gremeler, seeke Grommeler.

Gremil, or Grenil, m: otherwise her­
be aux perles, grummell, or gray­
mill, an hearbe.





Grenade, a Pomgranade: f.

Vn Grenadier, a Pomgranad tree: m.

Grenouiller, or buvotter aux ta­
vernes, to play the drunkard in a 
tauerne.

Grenouilliere, f: a froggie place.

Vn Grenat, a pretious stone: m.

Grener, when herbes come to seede, or
eares like corne.

Grenu, full of graines, grained.

Grenier, a garner, a corne loft, a gar­
ret: m.Antedates earliest OED citation for "corn-loft" (1611).

Les Grenetiers, the Kings officers
keeping the garners of salt in al his
countrey, to make an accompt of
that which is sold: m.

Grenouille, a Frog: f.

Grenouillette, a little Frog: f.

Vn Gresil, hailes stones, also the white
frost vpon trees in the winter time:
reeme.

Gresle & menu, slender, thin, small.

Gresle, haile: f.

Gresler, to haile.

Gresleux, stormie weather full of
hailestones.

Gresse, seeke Graisse.

Gretiller, to crackle.

Grevance, griefe: f.

Greve, grauell, as estendre sur la
greve, to straw vpon the grauell: f.

La Greve de la jambe, the calfe of
the leg: f.

Grever, to grieue, to hurt.

Grevé ou chargé, grieued, burthe­
ned.

Grevez & rompus, crackt, broken.

Greveure, the bursting of the cods: f.

Des Greves, bootes: also the armour
for the legs: f.

Les greux, m: in Picardie it is the
nayles.

Grever, to scratch with clawes or 
nayles.

Gribouri, it is a nicke name, as if one
would call another Shrimpe: m.

Grief, ou Gref, griefe.

Cela m'est bien grief, that grieueth
me: is grieuous to me.

Grievement, grieuously.

Griesche, pricking or sharpe, as ortie
griesche, a kind of pricking nettle
longer and slenderer than the com­
mon nettle.

Perfrix griesche, a Partridge of the
colour of a Woodcocke.

Grifes, clawes, tallants: f.

Vne griffade, or vn coup de griffe, a
clawing, a marke of a clawe: f.

Vn Griffon, a Griffon: m.

Vn Grignon de pain, a crustie peece
of bread: m.

Grignoter, to eate like a Cunny, Squir­
rell, or such like: also to gnaw.

Gril, a gridyron: m.

Estre vn peu grillé, & atteint de la
flamme, to be Sunneburnt and in­
flamed with the flame, to be withe­
red.

Griller, to slip, to slide.

Faire grillant, to make slipperie.

Grillon des champs, a creket, or cric­
ket: m.

Grillon, or grillet de cheminée, a
cricket in the chimney.

Grillons, or grezillons, a kind of tor­
ment whereby they presse ones fin­
gers to extort & know the truth: m.





Donner les grezillons, or mettre vn
criminelaux grillons, to racke one
by the fingers, and to wring ones
hands with manacles.

Grimacer, or faire la grimace, to coun­
terfeit an Apes face.

Laide grimace, a writhed mouth: f.

Grimper, ou gravir, to craspe, to
catch: to climbe: to get vp.

Grimpereau, a little bird making
warre against the Egle, as Robin
red breast: some doe call that birde
a nut iobber: m.

Grimpure, or grimpement, a ram­
ping or grasping: f.

Grincer les dents, to gnash the teeth.

Gringoter, ou Gringuenoter, to
chaunt, to sing as birds doe, to qua­
uer.

Gringuenotis, or gringotis, quaue­
ring or deliuering of the voyce: m.

Gringuenotant, quauering, warb­
ling.

Aller Grioter, or cueillir des griotes,
 to goe to gather sweete Cherries.

Griotes, sweete Cherries: there bee
none in England: we haue of diuers
sorts in France: f.

Griotes seiches, dried Cherries.

Grinon, see Gryllon: m.

Gripper, to gripe, to graspe, to snatch.

Gris, grey, russet.

Griser & devenir chenu & blanc,
 to waxe hoare haired.

Grizonner, idem.

Grive, vne sorte d'oiseau, a thrustle,
a Mauys: f: a feldfare.

Graile, slender, seeke Gresle.

Grivelé, to be of the colour blacke and
white, like a Snayle vnder the belly.

Vne Grivelée, a bill or scroule, be­
cause it is blacke and white: f.

Grizonner, to waxe grey.

Groiselles, gooseberries: f.

Groiselier, a gooseberrie shrub: m.

Grole, Graye, or Freux, the Cornish
Chough, the Chough or Dawe.

Groin de porceau, a Hogs snout: m.

Grommeler entre ses dents, & se
pleindre comme ses dents, & se
pleindre comme ceux qu'on bat, 
to mumble, to mutter.

Choses Grommeleuses, rough things,
as turfes in a field.

Groin, the snout of a hog or dog: as
faire mines de groings & d'yeux:
to looke on one with a lowring or
frowning countenance: Marot.

Gronder, to snarle, to grone.

Grogner comme font les pour­
ceaux, to grunt or groyle like swine."groyle" was not found in OED except in 1667 ("growl," v.3; cf. "gurl," v.).
	
Grongnement, a grunting: m.

Gros, grose, big, thicke.

Acheter en gros, to buy by great.

Grossoyer vne obligation: to ingrosse
an obligation.

La Grosse d'une letre, the ingrossing
of a letter.

Vn Grossoyeur, an ingrosser: m.

Grosseur, bignesse, thicknesse: f.

Grossement & lourdement, grosly,
dully, blockishly.

Grossir, je grossis, je grossi, j'ay gros­
si je grossiray, to waxe thicke.

Vn groselier, a Goosberie shrub: m.

Groselles, Goosberies: f.

Gros-bec, or pinson royal, m: a kind
of bird not much differing from a
Plouer.





Femme grosse d'enfant, a woman
with childe.

Grossesse de femme, womans being
with childe: f.

Grossiers, Grocers in the Countrey,
Mercers, marchants selling by the 
great.

Grotte, f: a denne, a caue,

Grotesque, idem.

Gruau, or gruyau, m: oatemeale.

Groulard, see Traquet, the bird cal­
led a Bunting.

La rouë d'vne grue, a crane wherewith
they lift vp burthens: f.

Vne Grue, a Crane: f.

Gruir, to creake like a Crane.

Grumeleux, full of knots or clutters.

Grumeler, seeke grommeler.

Gruper, ou Gripper, to gripe, to
snatch.

Gruyau, oate meale: m.

Gruyer, on forestier, verdier, or
garde-bois, a woodeward, a keeper of
a Forest.

Guaire, seeke Guere, little.

Guare, guare, see gare.

Guay, liuely, disposde, merrie.

Guarir, je garis, je gari, j'ay guari, je
guariray, to heale.

Se Guarir, to waxe hole.

Ie vous guariray tout à net, I will
heale you cleane out.

Ie suy guari de ma fiebvre, I am
whole of my Ague.

Ceste herbe guarist les mules aux
talons, this herbe healeth the kibes.

Guarison, health: f.

Vn gué, a fourde: m.

La riviere est Gueable, the riuer is
fourdie.

Ilz n'on sceu trouver le Gué à
passer la riviere, they could not finde
the fourde, to passe ouer the riuer.

Guéer, to wade.

Guéer vn cheval, to water a horse, to
 wash him.

Guéer du linge, to washe slenderly, or
rince linnen.

Guedde, or guesde, otherwise Pastel,
an herbe called Wad: m.

Il est bien guedé, when a man is
stuffed with meate and drinke, or is
drunke, to strout or fill with meate.

Elle est guedée, she is stroute or filled 
with meate and drinke, she is tip­
led.

Vne guenon, a Monkie: f.

Guepillou, a holly water sprinckle.

Guerdon, rewarde, meede, recom­
pence, m.

Guerdonnement, a rewarding: m.

Guére, little, small.

Il n'advient guere souvent, it happe­
neth but seldome.

Il ne demeurera guére, he wil tarrie
but a little.

Il ne s'en fault guere, it wanteth but a
little.

Nagueres, or il n'y a gueres, not long
agone.

Il n'en y a gueres de sisçavans que
luy, there be fewe as learned as he.

Guerir, seeke Guarir.

Se Guementer, To lamente, to
grone.

Guernette, f: a shrimp a fishe.

Guernier, seeke Grenier.

Guerpir son païs, & s'en aller habi­





ter en terre estrange, to forsake his
Countrey.

Guerpir vne terre à cause de la rente,
 to giue ouer a peece of ground.

Guerre, warre: f.

Guerroyer, to make warre.

Guerroyant & noysif, warring, figh­
ting.

Guerroyeur, a warriour, a frayma­
ker: m.

Vn grand guerrier, m: a great war­
riour.

Faicts Guerriers, deeds in warres.

Nation Guerriere, f: a warlike na­
tion.

Guespe, f: a waspe.

Guespier m: a little birde eating
waspes or bees.

Guesde, Woad, such as Diers vse.

Des guestres, high shooes, startops: f.

Guestré, hauing on startops.

Le Guet de nuict, The nighte
watche: m.

Vne guette ou espie, a watchman, a 
spiall: f.

Guetter, to watch, to marke, to spie, to
prie.

Guetteur, a watcher: m.

Guetteur de chemins, a robber by
the highway.

Faire quelque chose de guet à pen­
sé, to doe a thing aduisedly: of his
owne free will.

Commettre vn meurtre de guet à
pensé, de guet apens, ou de guet
appensé & de propos deliberé, to
lye in wait, to commit a murder wit­
tingly.

Gever, or gesver vne terre, to restore
land to the right Lord or owner, to
deliuer it again into his hands, and
be no longer his tenant.

La gueule, a beastes mouth, the gul­
let: f.

Gueule béée, with open mouth.

Gueus, vn gros gueus, a roge.

Gueux, as gueux de loustiere roge
as bolde as, &c.

Vne Gueuse, a she roge: f.

Gueuse, also, is a great lumpe of mol­
ten iron.

Du guy, miseltoe: m.

Guichet, a wicket, a hatch: m.

Vne Guide qui meine autruy, a lea­
der, a guide, a loadsman: f.

Guider, to guide.

Vn Guidon, a man of armes bearing
the Ensigne or Guidon: m.

Guiéres or guaire,  see Guéres: little.

Guigner, to winke, to becken.

Guignement, beckning or wincking.

Guilhedin, ou hacquenée, a gel­
ding: m.

Vne Guilée, a shower of raine: f.

Vn Guillemot, a yong Plouer: m.

Vne Guimple, or guimpe, the wier
or like attire which women vse a­
bout their head: f.

Des guimauves, wilde Mallowes: f.

Guise, as vivre à la guise d'autruy, to
liue after another mans fashion.

Ie feray cela à ma guise. I will doe
that after mine owne minde and
liking.

Guinder en hault, to lifte vp by in­
struements proper to that.

Estre guindé en lair, to be lifted vp
as those which be racked.





Guinder les cieux, to bow downe the
heauens: a power of God.

Guinder les voiles, to lifte vp the
sailes.

Guindelles, barkes or hulkes: f.

Vn Guindol, an instrument of Car­
penters, Masons or like, to lift vp
pieces of timber or stones.

Polie guinderesse, the pullie lifting
vp the sailes of the mast: f.

Guirlande, or ghirlande, a garland
of flowers: f.

Guisnes, or guines, a kinde of sweete
Cheries: f.

Guines noires, blacke cheries.

Vn Guinier, a Cherie tree bearing
such sweete Cheries: m.

Guiroët, see Gyrouëtte.

Guiterne, jouër sur la guiterne, or de
la guiterne, a Gitterne: f.

Gynocratie, when the crowne of a 
kingdome or gouernement doth fall
into a womans hand: f.

Gyroflée, or giroflée, violet: f

Gyrouët, or gyrouëtte, the weather
cocke: f.


H ante A.

HA, ha, A ha.

Qui Ha, seeke Avoir.

Habarres, a little boate carried in the
ship to take land: f.

Habile, able, handsome, nimble, cun­
ning.

Habile du corps, light of the body.

Mal habile à faire quelque chose,
 vnapt, vnfit, vnhandsome to do any
thing.

Habilité & aptitude, nimblenesse: f.

Habilement, handsomely, cunningly,
nimbely.

Habiller, to cloathe, to trimme, to
furnish.

Mal-habillé, euill clothed.

Habillement, cloathing: m.

Habit, idem.

Reprendre ses premiers habits, to
take againe his first apparell.

Habiter, to remaine, to dwell, to in­
habite

Habité, inhabited.

Les habitans d'vn païs, the inhabi­
tants of a countrey.

Habitation, a dwelling place: f.

Habitable, which may be inhabited.

Habitude, acquaintance, custome: f.

L'habitude des choses vertueuses
s'acquiert par vne longue coustu­
me de faire, the plight of vertuous
things is gotten by a long wel doing.

S'habituer, to settle.

S'habituer & accoustumer, to set­
tle, to enrich himselfe.

Habituation, f, custome or plight.

Habitué, accustomed.

Hable, an Hauen of the Sea: m.

De l'hache, herbe, f: smallage.

Vn hache d'armes, a masse of armes,
an axe of armes: f.

Hache, an axe: f.

Hache, a certaine measure in suruey­
ing land or ground.

Hacher menu, to coppe in peeces, to
shred.

Hacher en pieces, to hew in peeces.

Haché, coupé, abbatu, hewed.

Ilz ont esté tous Haches en pieces,





 they haue beene all cut or hewed in­
to peeces.

Hachette, an Hatchet: f.

Hachis, a Gallimaufrey, m: mince­
meate.

Hagard, a word of Fauconrie, as
Faulcon Haggard, that Hawke
which is not of one yeere, but hath
mewed more then once: m.

Hagard, wilde, strange, contrarie: m: as
Fortune m'a esté fort hagarde &
estrange, Fortune hath not fauou­
red me.

C'est vn home hagard, hee is a
strange man, and such as will not
frame himselfe after other mens
conditions.

Hait, or haict, actiue, ready, liuely,
wiling: as faire quelque chose de
haict, to doe some thing with speed,
actiuitie, liuelynesse, and with a good
will.

Saulter & danser de hait, to leap and 
daunce liuely.

Ce que vous faites, faites le de hait,
 that which you doe, doe it frankely.

Hai-droit, he which hateth all equity
and right.

Vne haie, a hedge, seeke haye: f.

Haillier, or hallier, a great thick bush,
a place full of bushes or brambles, a
bush of thornes, a brier bush: m.

Haillon, a clout or rag: m.

Vn haim, ou hamesson, a hooke: m.

Haine hatred, malice: f.

Haï, je haïs, je haï, j'ay haï, je haïray,
 to hate.

Haï, hated.

Haï de Dieu & des homes, hated
both of God and men.

Haineux, m: that beareth hatred.

C'est vne chose Haineuse, it is an
hatefull thing.

Haire, as porter la haire, to weare a
sacke cloth: f.

Hairon, or Heron, a Herne, or Heron­
sewe: m.

Heronnier, he which holdeth of the
nature of an Herne, that is to be
slender and leane, as avoir la cuisse.

Heronniére, to haue a leane and
slender thigh: Marot.

Faulcon Heronnier, a Falcon for the
Herne: m.

Le Faulcon gentil est bon Gruyer,
 the Faulcon Gentill is good for the
Crane.

Haitié, vn home bien haitié, an
healthfull and sound man, the con­
trary is Dehaitié, sickely.

Haiter, or avoir à gré, to like well a
thing: as cela me haite bien, that
liketh me very well.

Il a fait cela de bon hait, he hath done
that with a good will, that is without
compulsion, but cheerefully.

Il est bien de hait, he is merie & well
disposed, lustie.

Halbarques, a kinde of boates with
buckles: f.

Il est tout Halbrené, he is all beshitten.

Halbrené, as ce Faulcon est halbre­
né, that Falcon hath many feathers
broken

Vne Hale, a Hall, properlye where
victuals are solde.

Les hales, halles as il est allé aux
hales, hee is gone to the Hall or





market to buy victualles.

Hale, seeke Hastle.

Vne halebarde, an Halbardf.

Halbardier, he that carrieth an hal­
berd: m.

Halebrent, seeke Albrent: m.

Haleine, breath: f.

Halecret, & toute armure de corps,
 a Corslet: m.

Se vestir d'vn halecret, to putte on
harnesse.

Tout d'vne Halenée, all with
one breath.

Halener, to breathe.

Haler pour tirer en mont, to pull vp,
to hale.

Haleter, to gaspe, drawe the
breath.

Halmyrach, seeke Admiral.

Hamesson, or hameçon, a hooke,
seeke haim:m.

Hameau, sixe or seuen houses toge­
ther in the countrey, without forme
of village: m.

Hampe, the brest of the Hart: f.

Hanap, ou tasse à boire, a  tankard,
a iacke, a platter: m.

Hamessonné, full of hookes to fish.

La hanche, the hanch, the hip: f.

Hanchu ou qui à grosses hanches, hip­
pie, which hath a great hip, hanch
or hucklebone."hippie" antedates earliest OED citation (1919).

Hanebane, herbe, Henbane: f.

Hannons, petoucles, or petoncles:
 flookes or flounders-fish.

Hanser vn home, to make one free of
a towne.

La hante ou fuste d'vne javeline ou
autre baston, the staffe of a Iaue­
line or other weapon: f.

Chemin fort hanté, a frequented
way.

Hantise, frequentation, or frequen­
ting: familiaritie: f.

Hantement, m: conuersation.

Happer, to catch.

Hape-lourde, a counterfeite iew­
ell: f.

Hanter, to haunt, to frequent.

Haquebutiers, ou harquebuziers,
 harquebuzers, gunners: m.

Haquenée, an ambling gelding: f.

Haquet, m: a little carte or charret,
such as brewers doe vse.

Haquetier, hee that leadeth such
carte: a Carre-man.

Vne har, harselle, ou hart, a Withe
made of greene stickes, the bande
of a Fagot: f.

Defendre sur peine de la har, to for­
bid, to commaund vpon payne of the
halter, or hanging.

Cela sent la har, that smelleth the
halter.

Haran, a herring: m: see Harenc.

Harangue, a declaration, an orati­
on, a tale: f.

Haranguer, to declare, to make an
oration.

Harangueur, an oration: m.

Vn haras, a herd of horses & mares.

Harasser, by a continuall vexation
and trauel, to weaken one, and make 
him weary and tyred.

Il est tant harassé, qu'il n'en peult
plus, hee is so tyred that he can doe
no more.

Harander, to vexe, to weary one.





Harceler, to vexe, to trouble, to an­
noy.

Se harceler l'vn l'autre, to prouoke
one another.

Vous me harassez trop, you are too
importunate vpon me.

Harassé, tiered.

Harse, seeke herse.

Harceleurs, m: sturrers of suites in
lawe: fire-brandes that set men by
the eares.

Harde, a number of wilde beasts to­
gether: wee say also, Vne harde
d'oyseaux, a great company of birds.

Vn hardeau, a young boy: m.

Vne hardelle, a young mayden: f.

Hardes, stuffe, implements: f.

Trousser ses hardes, & s'en aller, to
packe vp all his geare, and goe his
way: see Bagage.

Hardement, m: audacitie, stoutenes.

Hardi, bolde, couragious, stout, hardy.

Hardiesse, boldenesse: f.

Hardiment, boldely, stoutely, cou­
ragiously.

Hardillon, the thong of a buckle: m.

Harenc, or Harang, a herring: m.

Harenc sor, soret, a red Herring.

Harengiére, a woman selling Her­
rings: f.

Harengeoison, the time of fishing
for Herrings: m.

Harer les chiens, to cherish dogges, to
set them together by the eares, to
clap their backes.

Hargneux, wayward, froward, pee­
uish: also he which is burste in the
coddes.

Harier & importuner, to moleste &
be importunate vpon one.

Harmonie, Harmonie, melodie: f.

Chant harmonieus, a sweete melo­
dy: m.

Harnacher vn cheval, to set foorth
a horse with trappings and all his
furniture.

Harnois d'hommes d'armes, a har­
nesse.

Harondelle, seeke Arondelle: f.

Haro, as crier le grand haro, or ha­
rol sur aulcun, to lay and crie vp­
on one all the euill and mischiefe
that can be imagined: to crie out
at one.

Harper, or jouër sur la harpe, to play 
vpon the harpe.

Harpeur, m: an harper or player vp­
on the harpe.

Se harper l'un l'autre, to ioyne, claspe,
or embrace one another.

Vne harpe, a Harpe: f.

Hars, or hare, seeke Har.

Hasard, hazarde, venture: m.

Hasarder, to venture.

Hasardeur, m: one that ventureth.

Hasardeusement, venturously.

Vne hase, an olde Female Cunnie: f.

Hasle, sunne-burning: f.

Vn home tout haslé, a man all to be
sunne-burned.

Vn haste, a spitte, or broach: m.

Haste, haste, speede, swiftnesse: f.

A la Haste, in haste.

Haster, to hasten, quicken.

Se haster d'aller, to make haste, to
make speede.

Hastif & soudain, hastie, sodaine: m.

Hastiveté, hastinesse, sodaynenesse: f.





Hastivement, hastily, swiftly, speedily.

Hasterel, or les hastereaux, the haslet
of a hogge: m.

Hau, a manner of calling, hawe.

Hau, c'est tres bien fait, Hawe, well
done.

Hau mon pere, haw, father, heare ye?

Haubert, a coat of maile with sleeues
and gorget.

Haubergeon, Idem, or a little ar­
mour of maile.

Havée, a handfull of any thing: as
j'ay emporté ma havée, I haue
snatched & caried away my parte.

Povres amans Havez, poore louers,
withered, spent, disfigured as spirits.

Il a les yeux haves & affreux, hee
hath a wilde and dreadfull eyes or
looke.

Havement, greedily.

Haveron, seeke Aveneron, wilde
Otes or Cockle: m.

Havet, a hooke: m.

Havi & tout bruslé, parched.

Hault, high.

Ie suy tout havi de froid, I am be­
nummed for colde.

Hautain, loftie, high in the insteppe.

Hautaineté, loftinesse: f.

Hautainement, loftily.

Haultement prononcer quelque
vers, to pronounce a verse aloude.

Haulte-contre, the contrary is, Bas­
se-contre: the base in musicke.

Haulteur, height: f.

Haultesse, f: highnesse.

Haulser, to set vp, to set aloft.

Hausser le prix, to raise the price of
any thing.

Vne haulse, the vnder-lyning of a 
shooe: f.

Haulsebec, or vn niquet, a nodding
of the head: m.

Haulse-pied, a trap or snare to in­
trap wolues, foxes, or grayes: m.

Havoir, seeke Avoir, to haue.

Vn havre, a Hauen, an harbour for
a shippe: m.

Vn home havre, or auffreux, a dread­
full man: m.

Vne haye, a hedge, a mound.

Vn champ vien hayé: vne vigne
bien hayée ou environée de hayes,

red with hedges.

Hayeson, le temps ou sayson qu'on
refait les hayes, hedging time: f.

Hayer, Hay, seeke Haïr.

Hazar, seeke Hasard.

Vn heaulme, an helmet: m.

Heaulmier, m: he which forgeth hel­
mets, or all kinde of armours.

Heaumiere, f: the hole where the
handle of the sterne passeth thorow.

Hebenin, m: made of hebenie.

De l'hebene, a wood called Heben.

Harberger, seeke Erberger.

Hebeté, dull, blockish: m.

Hebeter, to make one dull and bloc­
kishe.

Gens hebetez, without wit, dulled.

Helas, alas.

Hennir, je hennis, je henni, j'ay
henni, je henniray, to neigh like a
horse.

Hennissement, a neighing: m.

Hepathique, a kinde of herbe proper
for ringwormes: f.





Heraux d'armes, Heraulds: m.

ner: m.

Vne herbiére, a woman selling of

Herber, to feede of grasse as beastes
doe feede, also to put at grasse.

Herberge, a lodging: f.

Herberger, to lodge.

Herce, or harse, see Harse.

Toute sorte d'herbe, all sortes of
hearbes.

Herbistes, or herboristes, the Phisi­

Herbu, full of grasse.

Herbage, m: a pasture.

Hereditaires, as vne maladie héré­

Chiens herigotez, dogges dew claw­

Heroïque, noble.

La herse de la porte d'vne ville, a 
Port-cullies,

Herser, rompre les mottes & ga­
zons de la terre, & couvrir la se­
mence, to harrowe the ground, and
to breake the clods.

Hersement, a harrowing: m.

Hersoir, yesternight.

Se heruper, to set vp the bristles.

Hestoudeau, a cockrell, a caponet: m.

Hetique, wythered, lame, which is
in a consumption.

Heudrir, to set together foule clothes
or linnen, and so becommeth musty
and spotted, which cannot after­
ward be made cleane: as ce linge
est tout heurdri, this linnen is all
musty.

Heur, fortune, happe, chaunce: m.

Bon-heur, good hap, good fortune.
