Heureux, happie, fortunate, chee­
uing: m.

Hereusement, happylie, fortunately.

Heureuseté, happinesse, blessednesse: f.

Heure, houre: f.





De bonne-heure, in good time, or be­
times.

A ceste heure, at this time.

A l'heure, at that houre.

Le Heurt & sommet de la mon­
tagne, m: the top of the hill.

Heurt, a blow, a dash, a stroke: m.

La heurt & chec de la bataille, the
charge and incounter of the bat­
tell.

Heurter contre quelque chose, to
dash against some thing.

Heurter ou frapper à la porte, to
knocke at the doore.

Heurter & trebucher, to hit against
any thing, and so fall downe.

Hertant, striking, knocking.

Heurté, striken, dasht.

Heurtement, a dashing, a striking: m.

Heurtis, m: idem.

ouglie.

Qui est hié, stamped downe.

Hier, yesterday.

Ne hobez de là, stir not from thence.

zen: f.

by: we call Hobreau, a halfe gentle­

thers side: a mongrell: m.

Hodé, c'est à dire, las ou lassé, wea­

Ho, ho, si tost, what, so soone?

Honneste homme, louäble, de ver­

rence.

Honorable, honourable, reuerend,
worshipfull, com.

Honorablement & ornément, hono­
rably, worthily.

Honorer, to honour, to reuerence.

Home fort Honoré & prisé: a man
honored and praised.

Honnir, je honnis, je honni, j'ay
honni, je honniray, to dishonour
one, to shame, to curse, to defame
one, to defile.

Honni soit qui mal y pense, asha­
med, or cursed be he which thinketh
euill in it.

Estre honni & à deshonneur, to be
defamed, to haue his honestie stai­
ned.

Honte, shame: f.

C'est chose Honteuse à dire, it is a
shame to speake of it.

Honteux, m: shamefast.

Honteusement, shamefully.

La partie honteuse d'une personne,
 the shamefast part of a man.

Hoquetons argentez, the best coates

Horion, a blow, as je te bailleray vn

such a punch, that, &c.

Horloge de sablon, an houre glasse.

Hormis vn tel, excepting such a one.

Ie feray tout ce que vous vouldrez,
hormis cela, I will doe all that you
will, sauing that onely.

tiuitie: m.

Horreur, horrour, feare with trem­

licour.

cap, also the crest of any bird: f.

I ante A.

IA, comme, Il y a Ia deux Ans que,
&c. already: it is already two
yeers, &c. ja, not: as je n'iray ja, I
will not goe.

Il n'est ja necessité de ce faire, it is
not need to doe that.

Iasojt que, although that.

Iable, the chime of the Hoggeshead
in the which the rigoll is indented.

Iabler, to dresse the chime of any ves­
sell, and to indent in it the rigoll, to
put in the head of the tun, hogges­
head, barell, pale, or such like.

Iabot, the crawe or gorge of a
Birde: m.

Vne Iachere, terre qu'on laisse repo­
ser en friche, Fallowe ground, f: the
fallowe fielde which is to be sowen
the next yeere, or that laie.

Vne Iacincte, a precious stone called
a Iacinct: m.

Les Iacopins, the white Friers: m.

Iactance, craking, boasting: f.

Iacture, a casting away, a laste: f.

Iadis, ou le remps Iadis, heretofore.

Iayet, or jaet, the stone that is called
Ieate: m.

Iallet, a little bowle to cast and boule
farre: m.

Iain, m: a gibrige word, which signi­
fieth as much as wine.

Ialoux, qui craint que ce qu'il aime
ne soit commun à autruy, iea­
lous: m.

Ialousie, iealousie, it is also a flower
called of some Maudlenwoort, of
others Flower gentill: f."maudlinwort" (after Mary Madalene) not found in the OED.

Ialousement, ielouslie.

Iamais, neuer.

A Iamais, for euer.

Iambes or jambages d'un huis
ou porte, the iaumbes, also the posts
on euery side of the doore: f.

La jambe depuis le genouil jusques
en bas, the leg from the knee down­
ward: f.

Iambette, a little leg: f.

Donner la Iambette, to giue a legge,





to giue one a fall.

La jambiere d'vn gendarme, greues
or armour of the legge of a man of
armes: f.

Vn Iambon, a pestle of Porke, a
gammon of Bacon: m.

Ian le blanc, or l'oiseau Saint Mar­
tin, a rauening birde or a kinde of 
hauke killing hennes in the coun­
trey houses: the Protestants doe call
the God of the papists made of paste,
Ian le blanc.

Iangler, to Iangle.

Ianglerie, f: Iangling.

Iannette, herbe, great S. Iohns-wort,
also a womans name: f.

Iannot or Ianequin, m: a mans
name: m.

Les Iantes d'vne rouë: the spokes of a 
wheele: f.

Le mois de Ianvier, the month of Ia­
nuarie: m.

Iapper, to barke.

Vn Iaque de maille, a Iacke made of
maile: m.

Tu n'es qu'un Iaquet, thou art but a 
iacke.

Iarcer, Se Iarcer, to cleaue, to rent.

Iarcé, cleft.

Iarsure, a cleauing or clefte: the neb
of a penne: f.

Iardin, a gardin: m.

Iardin à herbes & arbres, a kitchin
garden.

Iardinet ou petit verger, a little gar­
den or orchard: m.

Iardinier, a Gardiner: m.

Iardiner, to trim the garden.

Iardinage, the trimming of gardens.

Iargon, a counterfeit speeche, Pedlers'
French, chirping, gibbrige: m.

Le Iarret, the houghes, the hammes.

Iaretier, vn home, or vn cheval jar­
retier, a man or horse which in go­
ing ioyneth his knees or legges togi­
ther, an enterfeiring horse, a crump
footed man."crump-footed" antedates earliest OED citation (1599).

Les Chevaliers de la jartiére, the
knights of the garter: m.

Iartier ou Iartiére, a garter: f.

Vn Iars or Iar, m: a gander.

Iaser, to talke, to chat, to prate.

Iaseur, a prater, a babler: m.

Iaserie, pratling: f.

Iasement, a babling: m.

Iasard, a pratler: m.

Vne jasarde, a she pratler: f.

Vn jaseran, a cote of maile: m.

Iasmin, a tree, and a little flower cal­
led Iasemine: m.

Iaspe, a Iasper stone: m.

Iasper, to painte after the Iasper co­
lour.

Vne jatte, a bowle: f.

Iaver, a kinde of disease comming to
horses: m.

Iau, ou roussette, a Barbell: m.

Iaveline, ou pique, a gleaue, a Ia­
ueline: f.

Vn javelot à darder, a dare: m.

Iavelle, ou boteau, a bottle, a trusse, a 
bundle, the swathe.

Iaveleurs, the gatherers of tenths in
sheaues or swathe: m.

Enjaveler, to set corne in swath, as
reapers doe in reaping corne.

Iauge, as poinsoon de jauge, an hogshed
of gage: m.





Iauger, to gage a peece of wine.

Iaulne, yellowe.

Devenir jaulne, to become yellowe.

Iaulnir, to waxe yellowe, je saunis je
jauni, j'ay jauni, je iauniray.

Iaulnisse, the disease called the iaun­
dise: f.

Iaulnastre, somewhat yellowe.

I'ay, pour je ay, I haue.

Iaser, see Iasere.

Iceluy, the same man: m.

Icelle, the same she woman.

Icy, où je suis, here, where I am.

D'Icy en avant, hence forward.

Idiot, an Idiote, a simple person: m.

Vne Idole, an Idole: f.

Idolatre, which worshippeth an I­
doll.

Idolatrer, to worship Idols.

Idolatrie, f: the worshipping of Idols.

Idées, imaginations in the minde of 
men, also the Images of things prin­
ted in our soule, the paterne or simi­
litude of any maner of thing: f.

Ie comme, Ie seray cela, I, I will
doe it.

Iean je le vous nie, but by your leaue,
I deny it flatly.

Iecter, to throwe, to cast, to sling.

Ietter le chat aux jambes, to lay the 
fault vpon one.

Iectement par dessus, a throwing
ouer.

Faire Iectées, to fling.

Iectement, a throwing, a casting.

Vn Iecton & scion d'arbre, a twig or
science of a tree: m.

Vn Iecton de mousches à miel pen­
dant à vn arbre, a swarme of Bees
hanging on a tree.

Vne Ienice, a Hayfer, a young
Cowe: f.

Iesier d'vn Chapon, the croppe of a 
Capon: m.

Ieu, play, game: m.

Faire ou dire quelque chose par
Ieu, to doe or speake any thing in
sporte.

La Ieune, ou Iune, fast: f.

A Ieun, ou Iun, fasting.

Ieuner, ou Iuner, to fast.

Vne Ienne fille, fame, personne, a

Ieunesse, youth, yong age: f.

If, a kinde of tree called Yew, m, an
Ewe-tree.

Ignominieux, reprochefull, disho­
nourable.

Ignominieusement, shamefully.

Ignorer, not to knowe, to be igno­
rant.

Ignorant, ignoraunt, rude, vnlear­
ned: m.

Ignoramment, ignorantly.

Il, he: m.

Il est ainsi, it is so.

Il fault, it behoueth.

Illia que passion, Maladie quand vn
patient rend ses excréments par
la bouche, a disease which causeth
the Patient to void his excrementes
at the mouth: f.

Illec, there, in that place, thither.

Par illec, that way.





Illicite, vnlawfull.

Illégitime, not lawfull.

Illuminer, to giue light.

Illusion, deceite, fantasie, beguyling.

a laughing stocke, com.

nowne.

Illustrer, to make light or cleare, to

faict sus le vif, an image, a likenesse

 an imagined souldier, a counterfeit,

Imitation, following: f.

Imitateur, a follower, a counterfeiter.

Imitatrice, a she follower or counter­
feiter: as L'art est Imitatrice de
la nature, arte counterfeiteth or
imitateth nature.

Imitable, a thing which may be fol­
lowed, com.

Immaculé, vnspotted.

Immarcessible, which cannot vade.

Immaterielle, as chose immaterielle,
comme les anges et esprits, a thing
without matter, as Angels and spi­
rits, without a tangible body.

or incorporate one in a commonalty.

Immediatement, immediatly, forth­
with.

Immédicable, that which cannot be
healed by any salue or medicaments.

Immémoriale possession, a possession
without memory.

Immense, as dieu est d'vne clemence
immense, God is of an exceeding
great mercy.

Immensité, exceeding greatnesse: f.

Immeubles, goods that are immoua­
ble: m.

Immisericorde, vnmercifulnesse: f.

Immisericordieux, vnmercifull.

Il s'y est porté fort immodestement,
 he did behaue himselfe therin very
saucily, malepertly.

Immolé, offered.

Immolation, f: offring, sacrificing.

Il est Immune de toutes charges, he
is free from all charges.

Il entre de grand impétuosité, hee

lence.

Impetuëusement, violently, forci­
blie, vehemently, also rashly.

Impiteuse fame, a woman without

Indissolublement, vnseparately.

Individu, compter les Individus, n'­

which cannot be deuided or put a­
sunder.





Par Indivis, as not diuided: which
cannot be deuided.

diuision.

Indivisiblement, indiuisiblie, not to

Indubitablement, vndoubtedly.

Induction, an alluring, a perswasion.

our giueth his inferiour, cockering.

gences, such pardons as the Pope

Indulgent, a cockering man, which is

Innocenter, or donner les Innocens,
 It is vpon Childermas day, when lo­
uers or wel-willers do get into their
beloueds chamber, and with some
rods or twigs doe strike them.

which cannot bee numbred, com.

Innumerable, innumerable, beyond

Inouï, as cest chose inouïe, that is,

fore.

Inunder, to ouerflow.

Inopiné, sodayne, vnlooked for, vna­
wares.

Inopinément, vnthought on, at vna­
wares.

Inopinément, as se rencontrer ino­
pinément, to meet vnlooked for, at
vnwares.

Inquiétation, disquieting: f.

Inquieter, to trouble, to molest, to dis­
quiet.

Si on sçavoit combien la vie des
marchants est inquietée, if one
should know how marchants life is 
disquieted, or troublesome.





Inquiéter, to disquiet.

vnquietnesse, vnrest: f.

tif, and Louägier.

of ones beliefe: m.

Insatiablement, insatiably.

ones knowledge.

Inscrutable, that which cannot bee

Insensé, mad, witlesse.

Insensible, insensible, that cannot be

Inserer au registre, to enter into a re­

Inseré, written, enregistred, graffed in.

Insidieux, that lyeth in waite, full of
guile and deceitfulnesse.

Insigne & notable, a notable thing, a 
thing to be marked, com.

Se insinuër en la bonne grace d'au­
cun, to creepe in ones bosome, to get
his goodwill and fauour.

Inscipience, foolishnes.

Insister, to stand vpon a matter, to la­
bour earnestly, to persist.

Insociable, where there is no fellow­
ship: the contrarie is, sociable, ciuil,
louing, fellowship.

Insolent & arrogant, presumptuous,
arrogant, vnrulie.

Insolens soldats, vnruled souldiers.

Insolens, too much licence or liber­
tie, arrogancie: f.

Insolence, carelesnesse.

Insolu, vnpayed.

Insoluble, that cannot be dissolued.

Inspection, a looking in: f.

Estre Inspiré de l'Esprit divin, to be
inspired with the holy Ghost.

Inspiration, inspiring: f.

Instable, vnstable, fickle, changeable.

Instabilité, vnstablenesse: f.

Installer, to place or set one in his be­
nefice or prebend.

Instamment, instantly.

Vne petite Instance, a little poynt de­
pending on the principall.

En vn Instant, in a moment, in an in­
stant.

Instaurer, or restaurer, to restore one.

Instauration, a repayring, a renew­
ing: f.

Instinct & inspiration, instinct, or in­
spiration, inward motion: m.

Instigation, stirring, a prouoking: f.

Par ton instigation je l'ay fait, I haue 
done it through thy procurement or 
stirring.

Instiguer, to pricke one forward, to
intise.

Instigateur, a stirrer or prouoker: m.

Instiller, to powre or let in by drop
meale.

Instillation, a powring in by little 
and little: f.

Instituer, to ordaine, to appoynt, to
teach.





Choses nouvellement instituées,
 matters newly ordained, or set vp.

Instruire, to instruct, to teach.

Instruict & enseigné, taught, instru­
cted.

Instruction, an instruction, a teach­
ing, a learning: f.

Instructions qu'on baille aux am­
bassadeurs, instructions or memo­
rials giuen to ambassadours.

Instrument à faire quelque chose
que ce soit, an instrument or toole: m.

Instruments, obligations, lettres, til­
tres & enseignemens serons de­
livrez, the instruments and euiden­
ces shall be deliuered.

Instrumental, m: which serueth for 
an instrument.

Insulaire, dwelling in an Iland.

Insulter, to rise against one, to de­
spise.

Insuperable, that cannot bee ouer­
commed, com.

Insupportable à cause de sa puis­
sance, he that is not to bee borne
with, com.

Peine insupportable, which cannot 
be borne with.

Intégrité, innocencie, purenesse: f.

Intégrité de vie, sinceritie of life.

Intelligence, knowledge, vnderstan­
ding: f.

Intelligible, easie to be vnderstoode,
cleere, com.

Il y a grandes intelligences entre
eux, there is a great intelligence
betwixt them.

Intelligiblement, intelligiblye.

Intellect, the vnderstanding, the ver­
tue whereby we vnderstand things.

Intemperance, intemperance, ex­
cesse: f.

Intemperé, intemperate, without
measure or moderation.

Intemperément, vntemperately, vn­
modestly.

Intemperature de l'air, the disorder
of the aire or weather, f: the gros­
nesse of the aire when the aire is out
of temper.

Intendit, the principall proceedings by
writings in the law: m.

Intenter & mouvoit vn proces fort
doubteux, to intend or begin a sute
very doubtfull.

Payer les despens d'vn proces mal
intenté, to paye the charges for a
sute in the law euill begun.

Intenter action de bonne foy, to at­
tempt vprightly: to proceede in lawe
without guile.

L'intention, fantasie, & volonté d'­
vne personne, the intent, minde,
purpose: f.

Interceder pour aulcun, to make in­
tercession for another.

Intercepter les letres d'aulcun, to 
stay and take by the way letters sent 
from one to the other.

Intercesseur, a mediatour: m.

Intercession, an intercession: f.

Interdire, to forbid, to prohibite.

Interdict, an iniunction, a defence, or
forbidding.

Interest, interest, exchange.

Prendre à interest, to take money at
interest, to receiue at exchange.

Tu y as interest, thou hast title to it,





thou hast interest.

Estre condemné à tous les despens,
dommages & interestz, to be con­
demned, to pay all cost and char­
ges.

Ie me sens interessé par cela, I finde
my selfe hindred or hurted by that,

La matrice se sentant interessée, the
matrix or womans wombe feeling
paine.

Interest, m: hinderance, dammage.

Interjetter, to cast betweene, as inte­
rjetter vn appel, to appeale at the
iudgement giuen by the Iudge, not
for the principall, but for some other
incident of the matter tried by the
law.

Ilz interjettêrent quelque oppo­
sition, mais ilz n'y perseverê,
rent pas, they brought in some op­
position, but they did not stand to it.

Interieur, inward.

Intérieurement, inwardly.

Interloquer, to speake betweene.

Interlocution, a certaine sentence gi­
uen by the iudge in a mans case
whilest it is pleading, a sparckeling
betweene: f.

Interlocutoires, reasons alleadged
whereby the course of the case is
stayed for a time: f.

Intermettre, discontinue, to leaue
for a time, sans intermission ou
intervale de temps, without cea­
sing: f.

Faire intermission d'escrire, to leaue
of writing for a time.

Intermine, m: vndetermined.

Internel: m: inward.

Interpeller, to interrupt.

Interpelation, f: an interruption.

Interpellateur, m: he that interrupt­
teth.

Interposer son jugement, to giue his
iudgement, to allowe.

Interposement, a putting or setting
betweene, a pause: m.

Personnes interposées, mediateurs,
 a third betweene partie and partie,
broakers.

Interposition de temps, space be­
tweene time and time.

Interpreter & donner à cognoistre,
 to interprete, to expound.

Interpretation, f: an exposition.

Interprete, com: an interpreter or
expositor.

Vous l'Interpretez mal, you take it
in ill sence or euill part.

Vn fin Interrogateur, m: a subtile
enquirer or examiner.

Interroguer, to question, to de­
maund.

Interrogation, a questioning.

Interruption, interruption, a brea­
king one of his tale.

Interrompre la parolle, or le pro­
pos d'aucun, to interrupt the talke 
of one.

Intervalle, distance, a space betweene,
a space of time: m.

Sans intervale, without ceasing.

Intervenir l'arrest ou jugement, to
preuent the finall iudgement of a 
case.

Vn intestin qui va depuis le roi­
non dextre jusque au fenesetre, en
passant sus le fond de l'estomach,





 a gut that passeth from the right
kidney to the left, an inward: m.

Les intestins, the inwardes, the
bowels.

Dissentions Intestines, ciuill or do­
mesticall strife or warre.

Inthronizer, to bring and place one in
a throne.

Inthronization, the setting or pla­
cing of a Prince in his throne, to 
put one in possession: f.

Intime, as mon intime amy, my
deare and inward friend.

Intimement prier aucun, innerlye to
pray one.

Ie l'aime Intimement ou entiere­
ment, I loue him innerly or intire­
lye.

Intimer la guerre à vn Prince, to 
declare or denounce Warre in a 
Prince.

Intimer, as faire adjourner le juge
en cas d'appel, & faire intimer
partie, to serue proces on a Iudge
for wrong iudgement giuen, and to
summon the aduerse partie in the
fauour of whome iudgement was 
giuen, to appeare in a higher court.

L'Intimé, he which is cited or cal­
led by the processe at the sute of him
that did appeale.

Congé à l'intimé contre l'appe­
lant, par faulte de venir plaider sa
cause d'appel, when the defendant
is dismissed from the Courte, for
that the plaintife did not pleade the
cause of his appeale.

L'appelant porte visage d'intimé, he
which was condemned, and therfore
did appeale, beareth as stout a coun­
tenance, as he in whose fauour iudg­
ment was giuen, and is called by pro­
cesse to an higher courte.

L'heure à sonné sur les defences de
l'intimé, the clocke did strike when 
the partie cited did alleadge his rea­
sons.

Intimider, to make one afraide.

Intituler, to name, to title.

Intitulation, f: ascribing of a title, a
denomination.

Intollerable, intollerable, that cannot
be borne, com.

Intractable & farouche, vntracta­
ble, outragious, wilde, com.

Intruz, as Il est Intruz en son bene­

ded with equalitie and similitude.

Ie ne suy ton justiciable, I am not

L ante A.

LA, this article La, is a signe of 
the feminine gender, as La fem­
me, the woman.

Là, so noted, is an aduerb of place, as
là ou tu es, there where thou art, in
that place.

La, is also a relatiue, rehearsing the
thing before spoken, as où est ma 
fame? where is my wife? ne la voyez
vous pas? do you not see her?

Labeur, labour, toyle, worke: m.

Labeur & travail, labour, dili­
gence.

Laborieux, diligent, paynefull: m.

Labeur ou labourage, tylth: m.

Labourer, to labour, to worke, to toyle.

Labourer la terre, to till the ground.

Laboreur, m: an husband man, a
hinde.

Vn Lac, or lacet, a snare, a gin: m.

Tomber aux lacs, to fall into the
snares.

Le lac de Geneve, the lake of Gene­
ua: m.

Lacerer, to teare in pieces.

Laceracion, a tearing: f.

Laceron, ou laicteron, herbe, a Sow­
thistle: m.

Ladite, or ladicte, the aforesayd or
spoken, the relatiue of the feminine
gender.

Ladrerie, leaprie, measeldnesse: f."measeldnesse" antedates earliest OED citation (1611).

Ladrerie, the dwelling of the leprous.

Porc Ladre, or Sursemé, an hogge
meselled: m.

Vn Ladre, a leprous, a lazarous.

Lai, a laye man: m.

Les gens laiz, laicall persons, those
that are not of the clergie: m.

Du Laict, milke: m.

Laict caillé, curded milke.

Du Laict clair, whaye.

Laict esburré, fleeted milke.Phrase not found in OED.

Il me porte vne dent de laict, hee
beareth me a priuie grudge.

Laictages, or toute viande de laict,
 white meates, all kinde of meates
wherein milke is mingled: m.

Laictée, the farrowe of a bitch, deli­
uered of her whelpes: f.

Laicterie, the dairie, where milke &
cheese is kept or made: f.

Laictiére, qui de soy rend du laict:
 an hearb that hath milke in it: f.

Laicte, or laictance, the softe roe of
 a fish: f.

Laicteron, m: a kinde of hearbe, a
Sowthistle.

Laictuë, Lettuce: f.

Laictuë pommée, Cabbige, lettuce.

Laid & difforme, mishapen, ill fauou­
red, foule, filthy: m.

Laideron, somewhat ill fauoured: f.

Laidement, ill fauouredly.





Laideur or laidure, ilfauourednesse,
filthinesse, dishonestie: f.

Laidoyer, ou laidanger aucun, to 
raile and to staine ones honestie, to
dishonest.

Vn laignier, a pile of wood, a wood
yarde: m.

Laigs or laiz, as laigs testamentaires,
 Legacies left by a last will: m.

La laine, wooll: f.

Laine avec le suin, washed wooll.

Lainé, full of wooll, woollie.

Laine facture f: well spinning or wor­
king.

Lairray, lairras, comming from the
verbe Laisser, to forsake.

Laisarde, a Lizard, a Nute: f.

Vn Laisard, m: idem, a houet, a Li­
zart."houet" not found in OED.

Lezatdin, or Laisardin, like a Li­
zard: m.

Laisser, to leaue off, to forsake.

Toutes choses laissées, al things left
a side.

Vne laisse, a leash of hounds: f.

Laisses, among Hunters is the dung
of a wilde Bore, Beare, or Wolues, m.

Laiton, or leton, latten, brasse: m.

Vn laiz, or leis, a legacie: m.

Lampe, a great waue in the Sea ri­
sing after some great storme, seeke
Oule: f.

Lame, is a plate of brasse, copper, tin,
lead, or like mettall.

Vne lame de tisseran, the rame of a 
Weauer: all which words be short in
pronunciation, but l'ame, so written
is long: the soule.

Le lambeau d'vne robe, a purfle or
garde, the skirtes of a garment: m.

Ceste opinion ne se trouve point es
lambeaux des Iurisconsultes, this o­
pinion is not found in the papers or
writings of Ciuillians.

Lambiquer, to still water.

Lambris, a seeling, wainscotting: m.

Le lambris du comble ou plancher
d'vne maison, the roofe of a chamber,
embowed or fretted, the seeling of a 
house.

Lambrisser, to wainscot walles.

Maisons Lambrissées, houses waint­
scotted, f: embowed or carued.

Lambrunche, f: a wilde vine.

Lamen, m: or Lamentation, f: a
complaint or lamentation.

Lamentation & deuil, wailing or la­
menting: f.

Lamenter, to waile, to lament.

Lamentable, a lamentable thing, to
be lamented, com.

Lampas or Lampast, a disease and
swelling rising in the mouth of hor­
ses, being holpen by letting them bloud
& pricking the same with an horne,
the rampone: m.

Lampe ou Luminaire, a lampe, a
light: f.

Lamproye, a Lamprie: f.

Lance, a speare: f.

Vn Lancier, as les Lanciers firent
la premiere charge, speare-men
gaue the first onset: m.

Lancette, f: a Lancet, an instrument
to make incision.

Lancelée, f: an hearbe.

Lancer ou darder, to launch forth, to
throw forth.

asswage a sore: m.

Qui est lent de nature, slowe of na­

suming one by little and little.

Lentement marcher, to goe slowly.

Lenteur & tardiveté, slownesse.

L'envers de la robe, the inside of a

droit: m.

on & d'vne Panthere, a Libert: m.

Lequel, the which.

Lequel des deux, qui que ce soit,
 which of the two soeuer it be.

Lesquels deux, which two.

Lequel est plus digne, which is the
worthier.

Lerre, ou larron, as tu es vn faux ler­
re, thou art a false theefe: m.

Lesard, see Lezard.

goeth, also a leish: f.

Condemné de Lese majesté, con­
demned of treason.

Du Leton, a mettall called Latten: m.

Lettres missives, letters, epistles.
