letters patents.

Lettres royaulx, Letters patents from
the high power.

Lettré, learned.

Levain, leauen.

Pain sans levain, vnleauened bread.

Leu, ou Lu, read, or perused.

Vne Levée d'vn estang, the banke
of a pond, the pits brinke: f.

Levée qu'on faict pour garder que
la riviére ne desborde, a banke or
a causie.

Faire vne levée de gens, to raise vp
souldiers.

Faire vne levée de bouclier, to make
a shewe.

Lever, to heaue vp, to lift vp.

Faire Lever la paste, to cause the dow
or paste to rise and be leauened.

Lever boutique, to set vp a shop.

Levé, lifted vp.

Levement de deniers, a leuying of 
money: m.

Levesche, ou levesse, herbe, an herbe
called Lombardy louage: m.

Vn Levier, a leauer: m.

Vn Levrault, a Leueret, a young
Hare: m.

Les levres & boliévres , the lips: f.





Levreteau, a little Hare: m.

Levreter, when the Hare is deliuered
of her yong ones.

Leurre, a lure to call the Hawke: m.

Oyseau de leurre, a Hawke of the 
lure.

Il y a sept maniere de Faulcons, ou
oyseaux de leurre, Faulcon gentil,
Pellerin, Tartaire, Gerfaut, Sacre,
Lasnier, Tunicien, there be seuen
sorts of Hawkes comming to the
lure, that is, the Faulcon gentil, &c.

Acharner le leurre, to fasten flesh vpon
the lure, to cause the Hawke to
come better to the fist.

Oyseau de poing, a Hawke co­
ming to the fist without lure.

Leurrer, to teach and accustome a 
hauke to come to the fist by the lure.

Leurrer vn home, or desniaiser, to
make a new man which is grose and
plaine, to be wittie or acquainted
with worldly matters: also to al­
lure.

Vn Levrier, a Greyhound, a hound
for the nonce: m.

Vne Levriere, a grey-bitch, a graie-­
bitch.

Hare levrier, stirring words of Hun­
ters.

Vn Levreton: m: a young Grey­
hound.

Pain de Levriers, a chesse-lofe.

Lexive, lye, such as they wash buckes
with: f: pronounce Lessive.

Lez, c'est à dire pres, ou aupres,
 nigh to.

Lezard, a Neute.

Plume Lezarde, a blaming or hurt­
ing pen: a man applying his pen to
the diffaming of honest persons.

L'hom, seeke L'on.

Liaison, a band: f.

Vn lien, a band: m.

Vn Liard, a piece of French money
containing in value somewhat lesse
than the English halfepeny: m: a
dodkin.

Du Liarre, Iuie: m.

Liasse, as vne liasse d'alumettes a
bundell of matches: f.

Vne Liasse de lates, a bundle of
lathes.

Libelle diffamatoire, a Libell of de­
famation: m.

Liberal, liberall, free-harted, franke.

Dame fort Liberalle, euery liberall
Ladie.

Liberalement, franklie, liberally.

Liberalité, liberalitie, bountiful­
nesse: f.

Liberté & franchise de parler & vivre
comme on veult, libertie, freedom, 
to liue as one will: f.

Libraire, a Booke seller: m.

Librairie, a Booke sellers shop, a Li­
brarie: f.

Librement, freely, without control­
ment.

Licantrope, the disease causing a man
to thinke that he is become a wolfe,
and goeth wandring in the wilder­
nesse and forrest all the night, o­
therwise we call them Loups-ga­
rous: m.

Vne Lice, a Lists for men to ride hor­
ses in: f.

Entrer en lice, to come to the combat.





Fuir la Lice, to goe from the fight.

Licence & permission, licence, li­
bertie: f.

Licencié, that hath taken a degree in
the Vniuersitie.

Licencier vne armée, to dismisse an
armie.

Lice, or Lyce, or chienne, a bitch:
also a whore, as cest vne faulse lice,
faulse louve, or faulse chienne, she
is a false whore: f.

Chose de plus grand'estoffe & plus
haulte lice, a matter, or stuffe of
great estimation.

Tapis de haulte lice, tapistrie of high
stuffe and price.

Licher, to licke.

Lichement, a licking: m.

Licharder, to licke daintily.

Il est Licite & permis, it is lawfull &
sufferable.

Licol, chevestre, or museliére de
cheval, a halter: m: say Licon.

Vne Licorne, an Vnicorne: f.

Vn Lict, ou autre lieu à se coucher, 
 a bed or other place to lye in: m.

Lict de camp, a field bed: m.

Les Licts, or assiettes de massonne­
rie, a row or course of stones or brick
in masonrie.

Lictiere aux chevaux, litter for hor­
ses: f.

Vne Lictiere, a horslitter: f.

La lie, bourbe & Limon, lees, drosse,
scumme, or grounds: f.

La Lie de L'huile qui est par dessus,
 oyle lees.

Du Liege, corke: m.

Lieger des pantoufles, to corke slip­
pers.

Souliers Liegez, corked shooes.

Vn Lien, a line, a band, a leash: m.

Lier, to binde, to tye, to make fast.

Lié & attaché, bound, or fastned.

Liement, a binding, a making fast, an
vnion: m.

Vn Lien & bride qu'on attach à
vn dard pour le jecter plus roide,
 that which is bound to the middest
of a Dart to throwe it, a slope or
loope.

Lientérie, or flux de ventre ou d'est­
homac, the flixe of the stomacke: 
that is, when the stomacke through
weakenes doth not digest the meate,
and so goeth downe in the man as it
is taken or eaten: f.

Lientérieux, sicke of that flixe or dis­
ease.

Liepard, see Leopard.

Lieüre, relieüre, or liaison, a binding,
a ioyning togither: f.

Liesse, ioye, mirth: f.

Liément, ioyfully.

Liette, or layette, the drawer of a 
cubbord, or chest: f.

Liet, m: all merie.

Lieu, a place: m.

Petit Lieu, a little place.

Au Lieu, in steede, or in place of.

Dire en Lieu, to speake in place.

Lieuë, vne Lieuë, a league surmoun­
ting two english miles: f.

Vn Lievre, a Hare: m.

Tuer vn Lievre au giste, to kil a hare
in her forme.

Vn Lieutenant, a Lieutenant, a De­
putie: m.





Lieutenant civil, a Iudge of towne
matters.

Lieutenant criminel, a Iudge of
crimes, for life and death.

Lieutrin, a pulpit: m.

Ligature, a binding: f.

Lige, or vassal, a subiect: m.

Mon prince Lige & naturel seigne­
ur, my naturall Prince and Lord.

Ligeaulté, loyaltie, that is, the fide­
litie which a subiect oweth to his
Prince.

Lignagier, see Retraict.

Lignage, linnage, kinred, ofspring: m.

De grand Lignage & parenté, of
great kinred, of noble parentage.

Ligne ou traict, a line, a draught: f.

Ligne partissant quelque figure
que ce soit tout au travers, an o­
uerthwart line.

Vne ligne d'escripture, a line, a verse
of writing.

Fait à la ligne ou cordeau, made by
line and leuell, perfectly done.

Ligne à prendre poisson, an angle
rod.

Lignée, linnage, kinred: f.

Ligner, is when the Wolfe couereth
the she Wolfe.

Ligneul, Shomakers threed: m.

Lignier & tas de bois, a pile of wood:
masc.

Vne ligue ou bande, a faction, or
companie deuided, a league: f.

Estre ligué avec vn aultre, that is,
Allié & conféderé, to be in league
togither as Switzers be.

Faire & instituer ligues ofensives &
defensives, to make confederacies
both to offend our enemies, and to be
defended from them.

Limace, ou Limaçon, a Snayle: f.

Estre plus tardif qu'vn limaçon, to
be more slow then a snayle: m.

Faire le limaçon, to go round as soul­
diers doe in mustring.

Limaille, the dust that commeth of
filing: f.

Limande, a kind of fish: f.

Vne Limande, a libet, a short cogel: f.

Faire la Lime sourde, to giue no eare
to, to shewe as one that heareth not.

Limbe de tissu, wouen fringes.

Vne Lime, a file: f.

Limer, to file yron or any other thing.

Le lievre lime son levreteau, the
Hare licketh her yong ones.

Limes, be the two vnder teeth of the
wilde Bore wherewith he fighteth:
masc.

Limé & poli, polished.

Limure, file dust: f.

Limures, be all those things clipped
out of gold, siluer, or any mettall.

Vn Limier, a blood hound: m.

Limiter & borner, to limit, to bound.

Limité, determined, bound.

Les limites & bornes, the limites &
bounds.

Limitrofe & voisin, he whose ground
lieth next to mine: see Lymitrophe.

Limoine, a kind of herbe: m.

Le Limon d'vn chariot, charrette, &
autres, the beame whereon the yron
hangeth in a Waine, the draught
tree of a wagon, coach, or cart: m.

Limonier, as Cerfs limoniers, Harts
bearing most great hornes.





Limon & ordure, drosse, filthynesse
of all earth, slime: m.

Eauë limonneuse, puddle water.

Du lin, linnen, flaxe: m.

Fin lin, fine linnen.

Linier, he that dresseth fine flaxe: m.

Liniére, a woman dressing flaxe: m.

Se linder par terre, to creep as snakes
and like wormes.

Lineature de mains, the lines of
ones handes: f.

Lineaments du visage, the draughts
of the face: m.

Vn linge fort delié, a verye fine lin­
nen cloth: m.

Vn petit linge, a linnen cloute.

Home, fame ou cheval linge ou flan­
cé, which is flancke or thinne.

Vestu de linge, clothed with linnen.

Liniment, annoynting, smearing: m.

Lingiére, a Semester: f.

Linsueil, a sheete: m.

Vn lingot, an ingot, a lump, a masse.

Linotte, a bird called a Linnet, or a
Goldfinch: f.

Le linteau de dessus l'huys, the tran­
some or lintell ouer a doore: m.

Vn Lion, a Lion: m.

Lionne, a Lionesse: f.

Lionin, of Lion: m.

Vn Lionnier, m: a keeper of Ly­
ons.

Il fait de liperquem, that is, se mon­
strer le grand gouverneur, to shew
himselfe to be a great ruler or go­
uernour in a mans house.

Lippe, a lip: f.

Lippu, thicke lipped: m.

Lippée, as flater pour la lippée, to
flatter one onely for the belly sake: f.

Faire ce qu'on voudra pour la lip­
pée, to doe any thing if he may fill
his belly.

Liqueur, liquor: f.

Liqueur espreincte, pressed liquor,
iuyce.

Liquide, thinne, euident, com.

Liquider, to examine a matter, to
make thinne when any liquor is too
thicke.

Vne Lire, a Citterne or instrument
of musicke.

Lire, je lis, je leu, j'ay leu, je liray,
 to reade.

Légible, or lisible, easie to be read.

Lecteur, a reader: m.

Lecture, a lecture: f.

Liseur, one that readeth: m.

Liron, a Dormouse: m.

Vn Lis, a Lilly, a flower-delice: m.

Liseron, an hearbe of which there
are two kindes, the one is called Pe­
rywinckle: m.

Liset qui ronge la vigne, a worme 
that eateth vines: m.

Liser, to liste or border any thing.

Lisiéres, bounds, borders: f.

La lisiére & limite du monde, the
boundes of the world.

Sur les lisiéres de France, vpon the
borders of France.

Lisse, seeke Lice, the lists for iustlers: f.Antedates earliest citation in OED for "juster" (1599).

Lisser, or Calendrer de la toile, to
slike linnen.

Liste, f: as églize, or chapelle entou­
rée d'vne liste de dueil, a Church
or chappell girdeled with a blacke
paynting like a girdle, also the liste





of a cloth: it is also taken for a pre­
cinct or compasse: finally for a num­
ber, as avoir vne liste des plus
dignes personages d'vne ville ou
province, to haue a numberly wri­
ting or otherwise of the most nota­
ble persons of, &c.

Litharge, litage, or white lead.

Litige, strife, debate: f.

Litigieux, full of strife, contentious: 
also a matter which is in controuer­
sie, as Heritage litigieus, a piece of
ground which is in controuersie.

Litorne, a bird of the bignesse of a 
black bird, called a wing thrushe.

Liveau, seeke Niveau.

Livide, swarfe.Antedates first citation of "swarf" as an adjective in OED (1619).

Vne Livre de poids, a pound weight: f.

Vn Livre, a booke: m.

Livret, a pamphlet: m.

Livre, a liuery: f.

Livrer, to deliuer, to giue.

Les lobes du foy, the napes of the li­
uer.This sense of "nape" was not found in the OED.

Locatif, ou louägier, he that soiour­
neth, or that doth hire a chamber
or two: m.

Locataire, he that hireth a house, &c.

Localement, in a place.

Locher, to shake, to be loose: as il y a
tous-jours vn fer, or clou qui lo­
che, there is alwayes some naile
which clinketh, some thing behind.

Loches, fish called millers thumbes: f.

Locution, a speech, or kinde of spea­
king: f.

Locution figurée, a figuratiue speech.

Vn Lodier, m: a quilte, a counter­
point.

Lof, seeke Loo.

Vne Loge, a lodge, a cabine of a 
shippe: f.

Logette, a little Lodge, a small co­
tage: f.

Les petites logettes es gousses des
febves & autres où sont les grains,
 the litle holes in coddes of beanes,
peason, or such like, where the
graines are.

Logis, a lodging, an abiding place, a
dwelling: m.

Loger, to lodge in a place, to hoste,
to Inne.

Ie suy bien Logé, I am very well lod­
ged.

Loing, farre off.

Chemin loinguet or longuet, a
meetely long way.

Fort loingtain, very long.

Lieux loingtains, farre places.

Loingtaineté, great distance, far­
nesse off: f.

Loinseay de fil, m: a bottome of
threede.

Vn Loir, a dormouse, a batte: m.

Il est Loisible, it is lawfull, com.

Qui nest pas Loisible de faire,
 that is vnlawfull to be done.

Loisir, m: leysure or time to doe a
thing.

Loisir, quand on cesse de la be­
songne, leysure, when one resteth
from worke.

Qui loist, & n'est point deplaisant à
Dieu, pleaser.

Il me loist, it is lawfull for me.

Lon, in steade of l'home, as londit,
for l'home dit, the man sayth.





Long, long.

Longuement, of long time.

Assez longuement, of meetely long time.

Logueur, length: f.

Vn longard, a delayer or prolonger of
time: m.

Longe de veau, a loyne of veale: f.

Longes ou lanieres à tenir les oise­
aux sur le poing, Labels or iesses
that doe hang at a hawkes legs.

Longis, as c'est vn grand longis, he
is a great loubie: m.

A la longue, at length: f.

Longitude, f: length.

Longuet, somewhat long.

Loo, or lof, a terme that is vsed a­
mong Mariners for the length from
the mast to both sides of the ship.

Lopin, m: a lumpe, a gobbet, a lun­
cheon.

Qui suit les lopins, a smell-feast.

Vn lopin de laine, a locke of wooll.

Loquacité, pratling: f.

Loque, or loquette, a cloute: f.

Vn povre Loqueteux, m: a poore
wretch.

Loquet d'un huis, the hatche of a 
doore: m.

Lorion, or Loriot, a bird which if a
man see when he is sick of the Iaun­
dise, the man shall waxe whole, and 
the birde shall immediately dye: a
witwall, or hickwall.

Lors, then, at that time.

Lors qu'il luy plaisoit, when it did
please him.

Lods, lots, or loz & ventes, m:
 the Kings Siluer, the Fine which
the buyers of Landes doth paye vnto
the Prince.

Vne losenge deverre, a quarrell of
glasse: f.

Forme de losange, the forme of a 
quarrell.

Vn lonsengier, m: a tale-bearer, a
flatterer.

Lossec, le lieu, de la navire, où se
retire toute l'eauë & toutes im­
mondices, that place of the shippe
whither al the filth draweth, a sinke.

Lot, a lot: also a measure of wine con­
taining a pottel.

Mon lot, my lot.

Lottir, to cast lottes: je lotis, je loti,
j'ay loti, je lotiray.

Vne Lote, a kinde of fish much like a 
Lamprell.

Lots, or lods & ventes, see Lods.

Louäble, louägier, seeke Louër
Maison.

Louche & bigle, he that looketh a
squint, goggle eyed: m. pronounce 
it long.

Vne louche, lousse, or cuiliere, a
ladle: pronounce it shorte.

Louchet, a mattock with two bits: m.

Loudier, seeke Lodier.

Vn gros loudier, or els Vn gros pail­
lard, a great knaue: m.

Vne grosse loudiére, f: a filthy
queane.

Louër vne maison, to hire a house.

Louër & marchander la peine d'­
aucun, to hire ones labour by the
day or otherwise.

Qui est loué, he that is hired.

Louäge, hiring: m.

Louägier, a hireling, a soiourner: m.





Louër aucun, to prayse, to commend,
to allowe.

Louée, praysed, commended.

Louänge, praise, commendation, glo­
rie.

Louänger, to prayse.

Louäble, prayse worthy, allowable,
laudable, com.

Louäblement, laudably, prayse wor­
thyly.

Louëur, a praiser: m.

Louëresse, a she prayser: f.

Vn Loup, a Woolfe: m.

Lou-garou, seeke Loupgarou.

Tenir le loup par les oreilles, to hold
the Woolfe by the eares, that is, to
be in danger on euery side.

Loup servier, a wilde Cat like a Leo­
pard, whose skinne is very preci­
ous: m.

Loup-garou, Wolues which do eate
children, and sometime men: abu­
siuely wee call Lou-garou, a man
which onely goeth by night, dread­
full, and disfigured, also a craftie
and subtile knaue: m.

Louve, a she woolfe: f.

Louveteau, a wolues whelpe: m.

Loupe, the roll of a weauers loome,
a kernell growing in the face, a wen
vnder ones throte: f.

Lourd, blockish, lumpish, vnhand­
some, lowtish: m.

Lourdault, a loute, a lob, a grout­
noll: m.

Lourdin, a little lobbe: m.

Lourdement, loutishlye, vnhand­
somely.

Lourderie, f: blockishnesse.

Vne loutre, vne beste, qui vit en
l'eauë, & en terre, an Otter f.

Louve, seeke Loup.

Louvette, a vermine called a tike,
annoying beastes, as dogges, oxen,
sheepe, &c.

Louvetier, an officer of the King in
euery forrest to take Wolues, least
they eate the young Faunes of Does
and such like: m.

Louvich, which eateth greedily like
a Woolfe.

Manger Louvichement, to eate
Woolfe like.

Loy, Lawe: f.

Selon la loy, lawfully, according to
the lawe.

Loix, Lawes and ordinances.

Loyal, faythfull, trustie.

Loyalement, or loyaulment, faith­
fully, trustily.

Loyauté, faithfulnes, trustinesse: f.

Loyer, hire or rewarde: m.

Loz qu'on attend, qui est desja
quasi deu, prayse looked for: m.

Emporter le loz, to carry away the
prayse.

Lozenge, any square thing, as a
Dye or such like: f.

Lu, ou leu, Il ny a ne Feu ne leu,
 light, there is neither fire nor light.

Lubin, or Lupin, a kinde of fish, also
a nicke name, as frere lubin: m.

Lubricité, Lecherie: f.

Lubrique, lecherous.

Vivre lubriquement, to liue vici­
ously.

Luc, a Lute: m.

Mastre jouëur de Luc, a Master





that teacheth to playe vpon the
lute: m.

Lucs marins, m, an haddocke.

Lucarne, a garret windowe: f.

Lucratif, as labeur Lucratif, a la­
bour full of gaine and profite: m.

Suivre la lucrative, to be toward the
law, because it bringeth gaine: f.

La Luëtte, the pallet of the mouth: f.

Luëur, light, brightnesse: m.

Iecter grande luëur & clarté, to cast
a great light.

Lugubre, pertaining to mourning.
vn chant lugubre, a sorrowfull
singing, com.

Deuil lugubre, sorrowfull mour­
ning.

Honneurs lugubres, a such mour­
ning apparell as is vsed in burials.

Luicte, a wrestling place: f.

Luicter, to wrestle, to struggle.

Luicteur, a wrestler: m.

Luictement, wrestling: m.

Luire, to shine, to glimpse.

Luisant, shining, bright.

Luiton, or lyton, Gobelin, or follet,
 a sprite which cannot be seen in his
or any other forme, taking his pa­
stime in mocking of men, a bugge.

Lumer, to shine, as ceste chandelle
lume mal, this candle burneth ve­
ry euill.

Lumiére, a light, a brightnes: f.

La lumiére du jour, the light of the
day.

Luminaire, a lampe or other light.

Lumineux, giuing great light.

Lumillette, f: eye-bright.

Lundi, Munday: m.

lune, the Moone: f.

Lunatique or lunet, lunaticke, mad.

Lune fort resplendissante, a bright
shining moone.

Lunaison, some do take it for the shi­
ning of the Moone.

Lunettes, spectakles: f.

L'vn & l'autre, both the one and the
other.

Lupin, a kinde of pulse or corne called
lupins: m.

Lus, or brochet, a Pike: m.

Vne Luserne, a globerd or gloworme.

Lustre, as ce drap a beau lustre this
cloth hath a faire glasse, colour, or
shewe.

Donner lustre à quelque chose, 
 to giue a glasse and colour to any
thing.

Donner lustre à son dire, to giue co­
lour to his saying.

Lustre, also is the viewe ouer the Ci­
tizens aswel for the manners, as for
goods.

Vn Lut, or luth, a Lute: m.

Lut, durte, or clay: m.

Luter, to lay on clay, to spot or beraye,
to smeere.

Vn Lutin, a baudy slaue, a sprite: m.

Luxure, lust: f.

Luxurieus, lustfull, giuen all to vo­
luptuousnes.

Luy, he the same man.

Lymitrophe, adioyning, bordering
to.

Lyrique, as le poete lyrique, we
meane Horace, because he hath
written verses fit to be played vpon
the harpe or other instrumentes of





musicke.

Lyre, an harpe: f.

Lyce, seeke Lice, a bitch, a whore.


M ante A.

MAcault, or Magault, a scrip: m.

Macerer, macerer son corps,
 to make leane, to punish ones body, to
bring to nothing, to ouercome and 
maister.

Maceré, tamed, ouercommed, brought
to nothing or to dust, as le poulse
de Pyrrhus ne peut estre maceré
par le feu; Pyrrhus thombe could 
not be endomaged or ouercomed by
the fire.

Mache-coulis, com: a great eater of
consumies."consumies" not found in OED.

Mache-fer, ou escume de fer, the
drosse of yron: m.

Dent Macheliere, the eye tooth: f.

Machiner quelque finesse, to deuise
or goe about some subtiltie.

Machiner à aucun quelque mal,
 to practise some mischeefe against
one.

Machinateur, a maister of mis­
cheefe: m.

Machination & tromperie, circum­
uention or subtiltie: f.

Machine, engine, f.

Du macis, m: masticke.

Machurer, to black, to spot, to smeare: 
as il est tout machuré, he is spot­
ted like a colier, smith, or oriers of
blacke: he is all smeared.

Macquereau, seeke Maquereau.

Macque, all that light which is seen
through a net, or through a quarrell
broken in a glasse window.

Macroule, or diable de mer, a very 
blacke birde in the riuers or marsh,
a Moore-henne: m.

Macule, a spot, a blot: f.

Maculer, to spot, to blot.

Maculatures & meschants papiers, 
 foule or waste papers: f.

Tables de bois Madré, speckled wod­
den tables.

Magazin, or arriére boutique, a 
ware house or inner shop: m.

Magdaleons, a langate, a rowler, lit­
tle round stones like a rowler: m.

Magicien, a Magician, a wise man.

Magie, f: the arte of enchaunting.

Art Magique & d'enchanterie, the
arte Magicke, or enchanting: f.

Magistrat, qui a jurisdiction & em­
pire, a Magistrate, a ruler.

Magistrales conclusions, conclusions
made not by common consent, but
by the aduise of particular Magi­
strates.

Magistralement, as il escrit magi­
stralement, he writeth like a master,
he writeth Doctor-like, spoken in
mockerie.

Magnificence, magnificence, brin­
ging of great things to passe: f.

Magnanime, a stout harted man, 
couragious, com.

Magnanimité, greatnes of minde,
stoutnes: f.

Magnanimement, stoutly, couragi­
ously, with a bolde stomacke.

Magnifique, great, honorable, sump­
tuous, com.





Magnifiquement, honourably, bounti­
fully.

Magnifier, to extoll, to praise, or
commend.

Magnitude, greatnes, largenes, big­
nes: f.

Mai, see May.

Vne Maict, a kneading trough: f.

Majesté, maiestie or power: f.

Majeur, a Mayor, also a proposition
in Logicke: f.

Majorité, the contrarie is minority or
vnder age, as wards be: f.

Noz Majeurs, our forefathers, our
auncestours.

Maignen ou Chaudronnier, a tin­
ker, a copper-smith: m.

Maigre, leane, thin, slender.

Maigret, somwhat leane or slender.

Maigrelet, m: yed leaner, thinner or
slenderer.

Maigrelette, f: a leane thinne or slen­
der woman.

Maigreur, or maigreté, leannesse: f.

Maigrement, leanely.

Maigue, fleeted milke or whay: m.

Mail, a great beetle to cleaue wood.

La Maille en l'œil, a webbe in the
eye: f.

La maille d'vn filé, the mash of a net,
or hole betweene the tredes: f.

Cotte de maille, a cote of maile.

Maillé, hauing a priuie coate.

Mailleton, or crocette, a young twig
growing at the foote of the Vine,
which Gardiners doe cut to plant
in some other place: m.

Vn Maillon, when a Gardiner bin­
deth with willowes an Arbour and
the vine togither: m.

Maillet, a mallet, a beetle: m.

Malleable, com: which can endure or
suffer the hammer.

Vn maillon, m: a knot which Gar­
deners do vse in tying the Vine to
the stocke.

Le Maillot des petits enfants, a
childes swathell band.

La Main, the hand: f.

De Main en main, from hand to
hand.

Faire main mise, to sease a thing.

Avoir main Mise, the magistrate ha­
uing power to sease body and goods.

Bailler main-levée, to release, dis­
mise, to deliuer that which was sea­
sed, imprisoned, &c.

Demander main levée, when two
striue for a benefice, and one aske
possession of the same by the death of
the other.

Vne main de papier, a quier of pa­
per: f.

Mainsné or puisné, the yonger: m.

Maint homme, Maintes gents, many
men, diuers people.

Maintenant, now, at this present.

Maintenir, je maintiens, je main­
tins, j'ay maintenu, je mainti­
endray, to maintaine, to holde, to
keepe.

Maintenance, as sans la mainte­
nance & governement de Dieu,
tout seroit reduit à neant, without
the assistance of God, all in a moment
shall be ouerthrowne: f.

Maintenuë, vne pleine maintenue, a
iust possession: f.





Maintenir aucun estre de franche
condition, to maintain, or beare one
out to be free.

Maintenir son opinion, to maintaine
or defend his opinion.

Estre maintenu en son ordre, to be
maintained in his order.

Maintes-fois, often or diuers times.

Maintien, gesture, countenance, be­
hauiour: m.

Maire, Majeur, a Mayor: m.

Mais, but.

Ie n'en puis mais, I cannot doe with­
all.

Il a mais de quarante ans, he is more
then fortie yeeres of age.

Mais huy, as je ne m'en iray mes­
huy d'ici, I will not depart this day
from hence.

Maisné, or mainsné, the yonger bro­
ther: m.

Vne Maison, a house: f.

Maisonette, a little house, a cottage.

Maisonner, to build houses.

Maisonnement, building of houses.

Maistre, a Maister: m.

Maistresse, a mistresse, a dame: f.

Maistrier, ou Maistriser, to rule, to go­
uerne, to maister.

Maistrise, maistrie: f.

Toutte sorte de Mal, all kinde of
euill.

Mal gratieux, vnpleasant, without
grace: m.

Faire Maux, to do euill, to doe shrewde
turnes.

Malement tormenté, sorehandled
or vexed.

Il me va malement, it goeth euil with
me.

Malade, sicke, euill at ease.

Maladif, sickely, accrased, crased: m.

Si la nourice est maladive, elle fera
l'enfant maladie, if the nurse be
sickely, she will cause the childe to
be sickely or crased.

Maladie, sicknesse of the bodye, di­
sease: f.

Maladerie, the house and mansion of
leprosie, a spittle, or hospitall: f.

Homme mal adroit, a fond man, an
vnhandsome man, vnfit for any
thing.

Maladventure, misfortune, mishap,
mischeefe, mischaunce: f.

Maladvis, vnaduisednesse, indiscre­
tion: m.

Mal-advisé, not circumspect, which
hath taken euill counsell.

Malaisé à faire, hard to be done.

Malaisément, very hardly, very pain­
fully.

Mon malaise procede d'ailleurs, my
sore and disease proceedeth some
where els.

Ie suy mal-aise, I am diseased, cra­
sed, or ill at ease.

Malaisance, hardnes, difficultie: f.

Malandres de chevaulx, m: horse di­
sease, as glaunders.

Malart, m: a Malard.

Malavenant, vnseemely, vncomely,
vnfitting.

Malavisé, m: indiscreet, following ill
counsell.

Estre mal-content de quelque cho­
se, to be angry or displeased with a
thing.





Avec malcontentement, in displea­
sure, vnwillingly.

Malcus, a foutch, a kind of sword: m.

Male, a male: f.

Malette, a budget, satchell, or wallet: f.

Vn Malier, a horse that carrieth a
male or trunke: m.

Maledicence, euill speech, euil report,
backbiting: f.

Malediction, a curse: f.

Les malefaçons de proces, faults
committed in a sute of law: f.

Malefice, a mischieuous act: m.

Maleficié, inchaunted, deformed, ha­
uing not all his members.

Maleficié de nature, & ne pourvant
point engendrer, a man not apt to
generation.

Mal-encontreux, which bringeth e­
uill lucke: m.

Mal-encontre, misfortune, mishap, e­
uill lucke: m.

Malengin, fraud, craft, subtiltie, de­
ceit, trecherie: m.

Sans fraude ne Malengin, without
deceit, in good faith.

Mal-toste, a kind of custome or toll
in France.

Mal-faisant, a wicked or hurtfull per­
son.

Malfaicteur, a malefactour, a guiltie
person: m.

Vn Malfaict, a shrewd turne, a mis­
chiefe: m.

Malgrace, displeasure, out of fa­
uour: f.

Estre en la Malgrace d'aucun, to bee
out of ones fauour.

Mettre en la malgrace & haine, to
bring one out of fauor, or to displea­
sure.

Malhabile à faire quelque chose,
 vnfit to doe any thing, the contrarie
is, bien-habile, com.

Mal-hardi, cowardly, fearefull.

Malheur, mischiefe, misfortune: m.

A la Malheure, vnhappily, in an ill
houre: vnluckely.

Grande malheureté, great miserie,
great mishap: f.

Malheureux, vnhappie, vnfortunate,
wretched.

La plus malheureuse, she is the most 
vnluckiest, &c.

Malheureusement, vnhappily, vn­
luckily, mischieuously.

Malice, malice, subtiltie, deceit: f.

Malicieux, malicious.

Malicieusement, maliciously, hurt­
fully.

Maling & mauvais, wicked, mischie­
uous, hurtfull.

Malignité, mischieuousnesse: f.

Malignement, malitiously, froward­
lie.

Malle, seeke Male.

Mal-mener aulcun, to handle ones
sore.

Malleable, plyant to the hammer.

Malette, f: a wallet: also an hearbe.

Malotru, c'est vn povre malotru, a
poore miserable person, a pitifull &
wretched one.

Mal-plaisant, or Mau-plaisant, vn­
gracious, rude, without grace or be­
hauiour.

Mal-talent, euill will, anger, spite:
mase.





Mal-enthalenté, m: wicked minded.

Maltaulte, the toll: f.

Maltaultier, a toll gatherer: m.

Maltais, a man of the Ile of Malta.

Mal traictement d'hoste, an host
that maketh his gests ill cheare, ill
entreating: m.

Malvaisie, or malvoisie, f: Malmesie.

Malveuillant, an ill willer.

Malveuillance, ill willingnesse: f.

M'amie, my loue, my she friend: the
Masculine is, Mon amy, my lo­
uer, or my friend: f.

Mal-verser en son office, to behaue
himselfe ill in his office.

Malversation, commettre plusieurs
abus & malversations, to commit
diuers abuses and euill deedes: f.

Mammelle & tette, a dugge, pap or
breast: f.

Fame Mammeluë, a woman hauing
great dugs: f.

Mammelus, seruants or souldiers a­
mong the Ægyptians.

Manans & habitans, dwellers or in­
habiters.

Manables, com: which may be in­
habited, habitable.

Le Manche de quelque outil que
ce soit, the haft of a toole, a helue:
masc.

La Manche d'vn habillement, the 
sleeue of a garment: f.

Mancherons, bracelets, halfe sleeues,
a bracer: m.

Manchot, benummed, taken, maimed,
or that lacketh one hande, vnper­
fect: m.

Mand, or Mandement, m: a congre­
gation, or conuocation.

Mande, f: a liuerie basket.

De la mande gloire, an hearbe called
Mandragon: f.

Mander quelqu'vn, to send one on an
errand.

Qui est Mandé à venir, he that is
sent for.

Mandement, a sending for, a com­
mandement: m.

Ie feray ce que tu me mandes, I will
doe as you send me word.

Mandez moy si, &c. send me worde
if, &c.

Manequin, seeke Manne.

Manequinages, are such Images,
marmosets, mouthes and faces as
are carued in wood, in building or
wainscotting, and such like: m.

Manger, to eate, to feede.

Manger à coup, to eate greedily.

Vn grand mangeur, a great eater, a 
glutton, a deuourer: m.

Mangeson, the itch: f.

Mangeur, m: a great eater.

Mangeaillle pour les pourceaux, f:
 meate for hogs.

Mangeville, meate, food: f.

Mangeves, Akornes or Beech mast,
such as the wilde Bore feedeth on:
but Viandis, is such meate as the
Hart vseth: f.

Mangonneau, as jetter pierres &
mangonneaux contre ceux qui
veulent de force entrer en vn cha­
steau, to hurle stones & such things
comming first to ones hands against 
such as will enter by force into a 
Castle: m.





Manicles, splents, giues: f.

Manicordion, or Epinettes, a paire
of Virginals: m.

Manie, madnesse: f.

Maniaque, or Maniacle, a furious, a 
mad man.

Manier, to handle, to vse.

Endurer d'estre Manié, to suffer to
be handled.

Maniable, tractable, that will bee
handled, com.

Maniement, a handling, a vsing, an
intreating: m.

Maniére, a manner, a way, a guise: f.

La Maniére de parler, a manner of
speech.

Ceste Maniére de gents est tresmes­
chante, this manner of people is ve­
ry wicked.

La Maniére d'escrire, a stile, forme,
or manner of writing.

Maniére & façon de faire, a manner
of behauiour.

A la Maniére, after that sort.

Par Maniére de faire, after a fashion.

Manifacture, or manufacture, a work
that is done with ones hands: f.

Manifeste, manifest, playne, open,
cleare, com.

Manifester, to manifest, to shewe a­
broad, to declare.

Manifestement, manifestly, plainly,
openly.

Manigances, toyes, trifles, trashes.

La Manne du ciel, Manna or hea­
uenly foode: f.

Vne Manne, ou banne, ou panier, a
basket, a maund: f.

Mannequin, a tankard or pot made
with bull rushes, a little maund.

Manoir, a dwelling place, a mansion,
a Manor: m.

Manottes, or menottes, giues or ma­
nacles: f.

Mannouvrier, a handicrafts man: 
masc.

Manque, maimed.

Manquer, to want, to lacke, as Il ne
nous manque rien, wee want no­
thing.

Mansuëtude, gentlenes, meekenes: f.

Masuët, meeke, gentle: m.

Vne Mante veluë, a rugge, a rough
mantle, an Irish mantle: f: a frize.

Manteau, a cloake: m.

Mantel, or manteau qui a vn coclu­
chon, a cloake with a cape or hood:
masc.

Les blancs Manteaux, Nunnes in
Paris so called.

Vn porte-manteau, a cloakebagge.

Manteau de cheminée, the mantle
of the chimney.

Manuël, as Argent manuël, readie
money: m.

Sain Manuël, ones signe or hand.

Manuëllement bailler, to giue in
hand, to deliuer presently.

Oeuvres Manuëlles, handy worke: f.

Manufacture, f: idem.

Manumission, an infranchising, or
setting his bondman at libertie: f.

Maquereaux aux jambes de ceux
qui se chauffent par trop en hi­
ver, scorchings comming in the legs
through too much warming or set­
ting by the fire in winter.

Maquereau, a man baud: a makrel: m.





Maquerelle, a woman baud: f.

Maquerelage, bauderie: m.

Maquignon, a horse courser: m.

Maris, or marez, a fen or marris: m.

Maraud, a begger: m.

Grosse Maraude: f: a she begger.

Maurauder, to beg.

Mauraudise, beggerie: f.

Marastre, a stepmother, a mother
in law: f.

Marbre, Marble.

Dur & froid comme marbre, as
hard and cold as marble.

Marbrin, ou de marbre, of Marble,
marble like: m.

Marbrier, a woorker or caruer in
marble: m.

Vn Marc de pois, a weight contay­
ning eight ounces: m.

Le marc de toutes choses, the lees or
grounds of any licour: m.

Le Marc des raisins, the mother of
the wine, or grapes: m.

Marcassin, a Weather among the
sheepe: some take it for a weaned
pigge: m.

Marcasites, as entre la terre & les
metaux sont les marcasites & au­
tres mineraux, f: a stone like brasse.

Marchand, a merchant, a chapman,
a copesman: m.

Marchant en detail, a marchant sel­
ling by great.

Marchander, to cheapen, to bid mo­
ney for any thing.

La Marchandise, Marchandise,
commodities, ware: f.

Marché, a market place, a faire: m.

Bon & gand Marché de toutes cho­
ses, good cheape ware.

Faire quelque marché, ou contract
avec vn autre, to contract with an
other.

Marche, or els, païs: as il est venu
habiter en ces marches, he is come
to dwell in this countrey: in these
quarters: f.

Marche, frontiére, fins, lisiéres & li­
mites d'vn païs, the bounds and li­
mites of a countrey.

Marches, is also the footing or trace
of an Otter, as le pied & foyes d'vn
cerf, the track of an Hart.

La Marche d'un degré, vis ou escal­
lier, the step, grises, or degree of a
paire of staires: f.

Vn Marche-pied, a footpace, a thre­
shold, a groundsil: m.

Marcher, to walke, to goe, to steppe, to
pase, to march.

Le Marcher d'aucun, a mans pase:
masc.

Marchement plus oultre, a stepping
forward: m.

Marchure, a going, a marching: f.

Vn Marchis, a thicke trace of men
or beasts: m.

Marcotte, seeke Marquotte.

Mardelle, or Margelle d'vn puis, the
brimme of a Well: f.

Mardi, Tuesday: m.

Le Mardi gras, Shrouetuesday.

Vne Mare, a still water, a marrish: f.

Marez & Marescage, Marshes, or
Fennes: m.

Lieu marescageux, marshy ground.

Marée, sea fish: also the flowing of the
sea: f.





Vn Mareschal, or feure, a blacke­
smith.

Vn mareschal, a horse-smith: also a
horseleacher, a ferrour: m."horse-leecher" was not found in the OED.

Mareschal ou Connestable, a Mar­
shall or Constable.

Les Mareschaux, the marshals.

Le mareschal du Camp, the Mar­
shall of the fielde.

La marge d'vn livre, the margent of
a booke: f.

Margelle, as la margelle d'un puis,
 the brim of a well.

Marguerite, a womans name, a pre­
tious stone, also a Daisie: f.

Marguillier, qui à la chage des cho­
ses qui sont dedens quelque li­
eu, comme temple, ou autres, one
that hath the costodie of any thing,
a Churchwarden: m.

Vn mari, a husband: m.

La Mari de ma mere, my mothers
husband.

Mariage, marriage, wedlocke: m.

Marier, to marrie, to wed, to giue to
wife.

Se Marier, to be married.

Mariable, marriageable, com.

Avoir faim d'estre marié, one that
would fayne be marryed, to long to
be married.

Nouveau marié, the bridegrome, the
new married man.

Mariée, the bride, the spouse.

Mariement, m: marriage, a wed­
ding.

Marin, of the sea.

La Marine, the sea, or belonging
to the sea.

Marinier, a mariner, a shipman: m.

Marjolaine, an hearbe called Mar­
ioram: f.

Vn Marjolet, as c'est vn petit mar­
jolet, he is a fine darling: m.

Marisque, f: a great figge, without
sauour.

Maritime, nigh the sea, of the sea
coast.

Marmaille, rascall people, hobberde­
hoy, halfe a man halfe a boy.

Vne Marmite, a great potte to seeth
meate in, a cauldron: the beefe
potte: f.

Marmiteux, seeke Peneux: m.

Marmoter entre ses dents, to mum­
ble betweene the teeth, to mutter, to
murmure.

Vn Marmot, a Marmoset, a Mon­
key: m.

Marmouset faict en façon d'vne
mammelle en vne fontaine, par
lequel l'eau sort, the cocke of a
Cesterne or fountaine made like a
dugge, out of which the water run­
neth: m.

Marmousets tels qu'on voit és fon­
taines jectans l'eauë, the cockes of
fountaines: Idols.

Marne, sorte de pierre blanche, a 
kinde of earth called Marne, such
as husbandmen vse to dung their
ground with: m."marn" not found in OED (presumably French but not noted as such by Hollyband).

Marner vne terre, or vn champ, to
dung a ground.

Maronnier, seeke marine.

Marque, marlze, or marquis, as la
Marque de'Ancone, the countrey
about Ancone in Italie: f.





Marque, as donner lettre de mar­
que, to giue letters of Marte.

Marque, a marke, a signe, a note, a
token: f.

Marque faicte en vn livre, a note, an
annotation in a booke.

Marque & enseigne, a marke or a 
spotte.

Marquer, to marke, to note, to signe.

Marqué, comme d'vn fer chauld,
 marked, as with a hote yron.

Marqueter, tacheter & mouche­
ter, to marke out, to deuide, to be­
spotte, to make checker worke, or o­
ther like, with small peeces colou­
red, as in tables, bourdes, paue­
ments, &c.

Marqueterie, a worke with small
pieces of diuers colours, represen­
ting sundry pictures, as we see in ta­
bles, bedsteds, or such like: checker
worke: f.

Marquetage, idem, m.

Vne Marre, a mattocke or like instru­
ment to plucke vp weedes: f.

Marreau, a token; such as is giuen to
those that goe to receiue the Com­
munion: m.

Marqueté d'estoiles, bespotted with
starres.

Marquote & rossette, the twigge or
branch of a vine: f.

Marrein de quoy on bastit, timber
wood: tunnes, hogsheads, and such
vessels of wood.

Marrine, a godmother: f.

Se Marrir & couroucer, to bee grie­
ued or angry: je me marris, je me
mari, je me suy marri, je me
marriray.

Estre Marry & dolent de quelque
chose, to bee grieued with any
thing, to take the matter heauylie,
to be sorie.

Marrisson, griefe, sorrowe: f.

Marolle, the name of a village, see
Pucelle.

Vn Marron, m: a kinde of rounde
chestnut.

Marroquin, Spanish lether: m.

Vn gros Marroufle, a great big cat,
an ougly man: m.

Marrobe, m: an Herbe called Hore­
hound.

Marteau, l'herbe à masses, or Mate­
raz, an hearbe growing in pondes or
fennes, with a longe and smoothe
stalke, hauing at the top a Flower
which flieth away like the doune of
a thistle: some call it a flag: m.

Le mois de Mars, m: the Moneth of
March: m.

Marsouïn, a sea hog: m.

Vne Marte, a beast that is called a
Marten, a Fulmer or Polcat.

Vne robe fourrée de martes, a gown
furred with Martens.

Pennes de martes, skinnes of Mar­
tens.

Marteau, a hammer: m.

Marteler, all to be beaten or payed
with a hammer.

Martelé, beaten with a hammer.

Martelet, a little hammer: m.

Marteleur, m: a hammer man, or v­
sing the hammer.

Home martial, m: a man giuen to
wares.





Martinet, a bird called a Martlet: m.

Vn Martinet, a thing seruing for a 
candle sticke: m.

Martinet, a water mill causing to
rise the great hammer in the forge
where blades and barres of yron are
made: also schollers in Paris.

Martres, seeke marte.

Martyr, a martyr: m.

Martyrer, or Martyrizer, to torment
one.

Martyre, Martyrdome: m.

Martirément, Martyrlike: m.

Mas de navire, seeke Matz: f.

Mascher, to chawe or chew.

La Maschoire, the chappe, or iawe: f.

Les dens mascheliéres, the eye teeth,
or the cheeke teeth.

Masculin, of the masculine kinde.

Masle, the he of any beast or foule.

Vn masque, a maske, a vizard: m.

Masqué, masked, disguised.

Vne masquerade, or masquerie, a 
mummerie: f.

Masqueure, a masking: f.

Massacre, a murther: m.

Estre au massacre du cerf, to bee at
the death of the Harte.

Massacrer, to murther.

Massacreur, a murtherer: m.

Masse de quelque chose que ce soit, 
faicte en forme de pain, a masse of
any thing, a lumpe, a loafe: f.

Massif, massiue, sound.

Massiveté, massiuenesse: f.

Vn Masson, a Mason, a bricklayer.

Maistre Masson ou charpentier, the
maister Mason, or chiefe master
of the workes.

Massonner, to dawbe, to make a wall.

L'art & science de Massonnerie &
charpenterie, de deviser edifices
& bastimens, the arte of Mason­
rie, or Carpenterie, in deuising
buildings.

Tout l'édifice est de Massonnerie,
 the whole building is of Masons
worke.

Vne Massuë, or masse, a club: f.

Vn Massier, a mase-bearer.

Vn Massoret, as vous avez l'ame
d'vn massoret traversée au corps,
 you haue the soule of some sprite
cast ouerthwart into your body.

Vn Mast de naviére, the Maste of a
shippe: m.

Masterel, or petit Mast, m: a small
maste.

Master vn navire, to furnish a shippe
with mastes.

Du Mastic, a gum called Mastick: m.

Mastic dont les faiseurs d'images de 
pierre collent les pierres ensem­
ble, Masticke wherewith the car­
uers of Images doe glue the sayde
stones together: m.

Mastin, a mastife, a great curre: m.

Nous appelons vn home Mastin,
quand il est de villaines & ordes
complexions & cruel, wee call a 
man a Mastie, when hee is spotted
with foule and filthy qualities or
manners, or when he is cruell.

Mastine, a she mastife, also a dishonest
woman, or cruell, wee doe call Vil­
laine Mastine: f.

Mastiner, to cause a mastife to line
a bitch, also to reuile one and vse





him mastife like, brutishly, foulie.

Vne masure, a Mazer: f.

Vn mat, m: a sot, a foole.

Matassiner, to iest with his handes
like a iester or tumbler.

Iouër aux matassins, to play a mor­
ris daunce, at matachine, or the an­
tique: m.

Matelot, a shipman: m.

Materaz d'arbaleste, the quarrell of
a crossebowe: m.

Materas desenpenné, a quarrell
without fethers: it is taken for a 
light headed person.

Materaz à coucher, a Mattrice bed,
also a kinde of weede growing in the
fennes, hauing doune like a thistle: 
flagges.

Toute sorte de Matiére, all sortes of
stuffe, matter, or mettall: f.

Matériel, materiall.

Maternel, of the mothers side.

Mathematique, Mathematicall.

Mathematicien, a skilful man in the
Mathematicall sciences: m.

Le Matin, the morning, the dawning
or twilight: m.

Soir & matin, euening and morning.

Homme qui est matineux, an early
riser.

Des le fin matin, at the very brea­
king of the day, very early.

Belle Matinée, a fayre morning
tide.

I'ay esté empesché toute la Mati­
née, I haue been busie all the mor­
ning or the forenoone.

La Matrice d'vne femme, seeke A­
marry.

Matricale, the register, seeke Em­
matriculer.

Matrone, femme d'honneur, A ma­
trone, a woman vertuous, and praise
worthy: f.

Matronal, m: belonging to an honest
matrone.

Mat, or matté, m: ouercomed, which
hath check-mate.

Matter, to ouercome, to giue a check-
mate at Chesse.

Maturité, ripenesse in all things, good
season, time conuenient: f.

Maturation, pruning of trees: f.

Maturatif, as medicamens Matu­
ratifs, m: ripening salues or plai­
sters.

Matz, or matereau d'vn navire, the
maste of a shippe: m.

A mau chat, mau rat, a crafty cat,
a crafty ratte: a common saying
when two subtile felowes encounter
together either in law or any other 
dealing: m.

Mau-dire seeke Mauldire.

Mau-disné, that hath not well dined,
that hath an ill dinner.

Maudolé, ill fauoured, mishapen,
which is not smooth.

Mauduict, & mal conditionné, mis­
chieuous, vnhappy, euill conditio­
ned.

Mau-gratieux, rude, without grace,
froward.

Mau-joint, ill set and ioyned toge­
ther.

Mau-lavé, ill washed.

Mauldire aucun, to curse one, to
werrie, to forespeake, to banne.





Mauldisson, blasphemie, cursing: f.

Chose mauldite, a cursed thing.

Maulgré que j'en aye, in spite of my
teeth, against my will.

Maulgré eux, in despite of their
teeth, whether they wil or no, against
their willes.

Il feit cela Mau-gré soy, he did that
against his will.

Maulve, herbe, an herbe called Mal­
lowes: f.

Maulx, seeke Mal.

Mau-marié, ill matched by mari­
age.

Mau-net, slouingly, filthy, vnclean­
lye.

Maupiteux, cruell, vnmercifull,

Mauplaisant, lumpishe, vnpleasant,
without grace.

Maulplaisance, lumpishnesse, heaui­
nesse: f.

Maulplaisamment, vnhandsomely.

Maul prest, vnreadie, vnhandsome.

Mau-sade, loutish, rude, vnmannerly,
vnproperly, without fauour.

Mausadement, ilfauouredly, rudely,
without salt.

Mausadete, rudenesse, barbarous­
nesse: f.

Mau-soigneux, carelesse, negli­
gent.

Vn Mausole, sepulchre magnifi­
que d'vn Roy, ou quelque grand
seigneur, the tombe of a King, or
some great Lord.

Mau-soupé, that hath ill supped, or
had an ill supper.

Mauvais, euill, wicked, hurtfull, per­
uerse, vnhappy, mischeeuous, naught.

Sentir Mauvais, to smell of a stinking
sauour.

Il y a tant de mauvaises gens, there
be many wicked men.

Mauvaisement, wickedly, naugh­
tily.

Mauvaistié, wickednes, vnhappines,
maliciousnes: f.

Mauve, seeke Maulve.

Vne Mauvis nom d'oiseau, there be
three kindes: la Traye, that fee­
deth on Misselden, which is called
a Thrush: the other la Mauvis, a
Thrussell or Mauis, the third, la
Calende, awling Thrushe f."awling Thrushe" was not found in the OED.

Vne Maxime, a proposition, a max­
ime: f.

Vne May à pestrir pain, a kneading
trough: f.

Le mois de May, the Moneth of
May: m.

Vn May, a bough or Maypole: m.

Planter le May, to plant the May­
pole.

Le Maz d'vne navire, the Mast of a
ship: m.

Vn Meat or passage, a way like a lit­
tle pipe, or passage.

Meche, seeke Meiche.

Méchine, a maid seruant: f.

Médalle, or medaille, a picture cast
either in golde, siluer, lead, or plai­
ster: f.

Mediateur & moyen en quelque
affaire, Moyenneut, a moderator,
an vmpire, a stickler: m.

Medicamen, a Medicine: m.

Medicamenter, to plie one with good
phisicke, or surgerie.





Medecin, a he Phisition: m.

Medecin à chevaux, m: a horse-lea­
cher, a ferrour.

Medecine, a she Phisition: f.

Medecinal, medicinable, healthfull,

Medeciner, to heale, to cure, to re­
medie.

Medicinement, a healing, a cu­
ring: m.

Mediocrement, moderately, mean­
lye.

Medicament, a medicine: m.

Medicament qui entame la peau &
fait sortir l'ordure, a Medicine or
plaister breaking the skin, & draw­
ing out the matter.

Medieu, or Medieus, a manner of
swearing among women, and name­
ly in Paris, if one would say, by the
faith of my body: some in anger doe
adde to it this participle ce, or se, as
Cemedieu meschant, &c. Gods bo­
dekin knaue, &c.

Il a la Fortune mediocre, hee hath
a mean fortune, he is of a mean state.

Mediocrement, meanly, with measure.

Medique, f: horned clauergrasse, an
herbe.

Mediocrité attrempée, a moderati­
on, a temperature: f.

Meditation, a thinking or deuising in
thought, a musing or studying, a me­
ditation: f.

Mediter, to muse, to studye, to thinke
deepely.

Medulaire, as vn os medulaire, a
bone full of mary, com.

Meffaict, a misdeede, a shrewd turne,
a fault: m.

Meffaire à aucun, to misuse one, to do
one a shrewde turne.

Meffaire en vers son mary, that is,
ne luy point tenir loyaulté matri­
moniale, when a wife keepeth not
loyaltie in Matrimony towards her
husband.

Que t'ay-je Maffait? wherein haue
I offended thee?

Se Meffier d'aulcun, to mistrust.

Megissier, a white tawyer, or tawer.

Megisserie, a tawer or tawyeres house.

Megue, or Maigue, whay: m.

Mehaigné, torne, as one killed by a 
Lyon or Beare.

Mehaigner vn home, to cut a man
with a sword.

Mehain, wounding, hurt: m.

Meiche de lampe, ou chandelle, the 
match of a lampe or candle: f.

Meignie, the whole housholde: f.

Meilleur, better, worthier.

Le Meilleur de tous les autres, the
best of all other, the cheefest.

Prendre quelque chose en la bonne
part, to take a thing in good part.

Il est en Meilleur poinct qu'il ne
souloit, he is in better taking then
he was wont.

Il a eu du Meilleur, he had of the best
that is, he vanquished, &c.

Faire trouver Meilleur, to cause
or procure one to like any thing the
better.

Le mal Saint Mein, the Scuruie dis­
ease: m.

Melancholie, Melancholy, blacke
colour: f.

Melancholique, com: Melan­





cholicke, peeuish, wayward.

Mélancholier, to make one sad.

Pourquoy vous mélancholiez vous?
 why waxe you sad?

Melilot, an herbe called Melilot: m.

De la Melisse, an herbe taken to be
sweete Baulme: f.

Mélodie, melodie, sweete tunes: f.

Melodieux, full of melodie.

Melodieusement chanter, to sing
sweetely, with great melodie.

Melons, fruite growing as Cucum­
bers doe, but hauing a very pleasant
and sweet taste, sugred or musked,
a melon.

Membre, a member or parte of any
thing: m.

Vn Membre de veau, de mouton, a 
legge of veale, of mutton.

Le membre viril, a mans yarde.

Avoir les membres endormis, & 
gourds, to haue ones members a sleep,
either with colde or otherwise.

Home membru, a man hauing
strong limmes.

Perclus de ses membres, taken of his
limmes.

Vne embrure de bois, a shingle of
wood, a clouen boord: f.

Mémoire, memory, remembrance: f.

Faire memoire d'aulcun, to haue
talke of one.

Rediger vn memoire par escrit, to
put in writing an acte or deed for a 
perpetuall remembrance.

Chose digne de memoire, worthy of
memorie.

Feu de bonne mémoire N, the de­
ceased of famous memorie, N.

Mettre en mémoire, to put in remem­
brance.

Faire selon les mémoires & instruc­
tions qui nous sont baillez, to
do according to the instructions gi­
uen vs.

Vos memoires ne portent point ce­
la, your charge is not such.

Vn memorial, a booke for memorie: 
a memoriall, a booke of remem­
brances: m.

Ie vous envoye cest anneau pour vn
memorial, I doe send vnto you this
ring for a token: m.

Mémorable & digne de memoire,
 worthy of remembrance, com.

Menace, threatning, menacing: f.

Menacer, to threaten, to menace,

Menaçant, full of threatning.

Menacement, a threatning: m.

Menaceur, a threatner: m.

Manades, mad-women celebrating
the feast of Bacchus: f.

Mendier, to beg, to aske for Gods
sake.

Mendiant, a begger: m.

Mendicité, beggerie: f.

Mener, to lead, to guide.

Tout est mené & gouverné par
le vouloir de Dieu, all thing is
ledde and gouerned by the will of
God.

Mené & induit, ledde and perswa­
ded.

Vn faiseur de Menées, a busiebodie,
a sedicious person: f.

Il a tant fait par ses menées, &c. he
hath done so much by his traines &
subtilties, &c.





Ie suy mal mené, I am euill hand­
led.

Menage, cariage: m.

Menestrier, a minstrell: m.

Menotes, manacles: f.

Mensnoge, an vntruth, a lye, a fa­
ble: m.

Mensonger, to lye.

Mensonger & faulx, full of lyes: m.

Choses mensongiéres, lying mat­
teres.

Plein de mensonges, full of lyes.

De la mente, an herbe that is called
Mint: f.

Menterie, a lye, a tale, an vn­
truth: f.

Menteur, a lyer, a fabler: m.

Menthe, f: Mynt, herbe.

Mentir, je mens, je menti, j'ay men­
ti, je mentirray, to lye, to tell a false
tale.

Mention, mention or remembrance 
of, &c: f.

Mentionner, to make mention.

Mentionné, rewarded, made menti­
on of.

Le menton, the chin: m.

Menu, small, thin, fine, slender.

Par le menu, by parcels, by retale.

Le Menu peuple, the rascall peo­
ple.

Menuët, little, pretie, thin, smallish.

Menuïser, to make, to cut small, to
crumble.

Fort brayer & menuïser, to breake
small, to pound and bray in a Mor­
ter.

Menuïsete, thinnesse, slendernesse: f.

Menuïsement, to breake small.

Menuïsier, a Ioyner.

Menuïserie, Ioyners worke: f.

La Mer, the Sea: f.

La Mer monte, or la mer se hausse,
 it doth flowe.

La Mer s'abbaisse, it doth ebbe, see
Flot.

La Mer d'vn pressoir, the holownesse
or chanell of a presse, wherein wine,
veriuice, or Cider doth run into a
bole or other vessell.

Vne mer de proces, an infinite or 
endlesse sute in law.

Mer & mermiste imper, an vmpier.

Mercadans, little Marchants, as
yong beginners: m.

Mercenaire, an hireling, lead by re­
ward: m.

Iuge Mercenàires, Iudges corrupted
with gifts and rewards.

Gend'armes Mercenaires, hired
Souldiers.

Mercerot or porte-panier, a Ped­
ler: m.

Mercerie, ware, Mercerie: f.

Mercier ou autre qui demeure en 
petites loges d'ais, Mercers of
small ware, or such as keepe boothes.

Mercy, pittie, mercie, softharted­
nesse. m.

Se rendre à la mercy d'aucun, to
stand to ones mercy.

Grand mercy, I thanke you.

Dieu mercy, God be thanked.

Merci-dieu vilain, &c, it is a man­
ner of swearing of french women in
their anger.

Mercier, with three syllables, but
most commonly we say, Remerci­





er, to thanke one.

Mercredi, Wednesday: m.

Mercurial, borne vnder the planet of
Mercurie.

Mercuriale, herbe, an hearbe called
Mercurie: f.

Merde, mans dung, a turd: f.

Merdaille, men of no value, rascals,
beshitten knaues: f.

Mere, a mother: f.

Des mereaux ou gettons, counters
to cast with: a token such as they
giue at the Church.

La mere goutte, vin qui provient
des raisins avant qu'il soyent fou­
lez, vnpressed wine.

Le jeu des Merelles, the playe of
dammes: or fiue penie morice: f."fiue penie morice" antedates earliest OED citation (1611; "Merels," n., 2a).

Mérianer, as the Normans do speake,
is to rest at the noone day.

Meriane, f: the resting at noone day.

Méridional, of the South side.

Mériter, to deserue, to earne.

Il a mérité le fouët, he hath deserued
the whip.

Selon ton Mérite, according to thy
desert: m.

Méritoire, meritorious, com.

Merlan, vne sorte de poisson, a Whi­
ting: m.

Vn Merle, a blacke bird: m.

Merlu, m: an hadocke: some doe call
it Haberdine.

Merveille, a meruaile, a wonder: f.

Merveilleux, or merveillable, a mer­
ueilous, wonderfull, passing.

Merveilleusement, merueilouslie,
wonderfully, passingly.

Merveille, or pome de merveille, or
pome de Ierusalem, a kind of apple.
fem: also a kinde of sporte.

Mes de table, a messe, a dish of meate.
masc.

Lon a servi le second mets, they haue
serued the second course.

Mesadvenance, vnseemelinesse, vn­
comelinesse, an vncomely behaui­
our: f.

Mesadvenir, to mishappen.

Il te mesadviendra de cela, ill chance
will happen to thee for that.

Mesadventure, ill chance.

Mesaise, misery, as oster à quelqu'un
son mesaise, to take away ones grief
or disease: m.

Mesange oyseau, a birde that doth
eate Bees: f.

Meschance, mischiefe.

Meschanceté, vnhappinesse, wicked­
nesse, mischieuousnesse, dishonestie.

Meschainment, wickedly.

Meschant, a wicked one, a naughtie
pack, an vngracious graffe, a hooke
vnhappie.

Meschef, mischiefe, m.

Tu porteras tout le meschef, thou
shalt beare all the burthen & fault.

Meschoir, a verbe Impersonall, to
chance euill, Il luy Meschoit tous 
les jours, some ill lucke doth fall
vpon him daily.

A qui jamas il ne Mescheut, to whom
neuer euill chaunce did happen.

Donnez vous garde quil ne vous
meschée pour cela, take heed least
it doe chaunce euill vnto you there­
fore.

Il luy Mescherra de ce, this will





chaunce to him vnhappily.

Vne Meschine, ou petite chambri­
ére a girle or wench: f.

Se mescognoistre, to forget himself:
decline it as Cognoistre.

Mescognoissant, an vnthankefull
person, a churle.

Mescholiere, f: in stead of Mon es­
choliere, a woman scholler.

Se Mesconter, to misreckon him­
self.

Mesconseiller aucun, to giue one e­
uill counsaile.

Se Mescontenter, to be discontent, to
be displeased.

Mescontentement, offence, displea­
sure: m.

Mescreant, a miscreant, a faithlesse
fellowe, an vnbeleeuer: m.

Mescroire aucun de larrecin, to sus­
spect one of theeuerie.

Mesdire & detracter de quelqu'vn,
 to missay of one, to backbite, to slan­
der, to misreport, to detract.

Mesdisant, an euil tongued man, a
slaunderer: m.

Langue Mesdisante, an euill-tongue.

Medisson, euill speech, slaunder: f.

Meseau, ou Mesel, a Leaper, a Lazar
man: m.

Meselerie, f: Leprosie.

Meselle, a leprous woman: f.

Mesfiance, or desfiance, a mistrust: f.

Mesgard, or Mesgarde, comme, Ie
l'ay faict par mesgard, ouersight,
vnwittingly to doe a thing.

Mesgnie, household, meynie: f.

La Mesgnie & la Famille des serfs,
 the household or meynie seruants.

Mesgue, whay: m.

Meshuy, to day, this day.

Mes-huy, is most commonly spoken
from noone to the euening tide: as
je ne bougeray mes-huy d'icy, I
will not stirre out of this place or
this house till to morowe.

Meslange, a medley, a mixture, a
mingling: f.

Meslanger, to mingle and compound
togither.

Mesler, to mingle, to mixe, to meddle,
to occupie.

Meslé, or meslangé, mingled, mixed.

Se Mesler de médecine, to occupie
Phisicke.

Vne Mesle, merle, mesple, or Neffle,
 a Medlar: f.

Meslier, Nefflier, merlier, or mespli­
er arbre, a Medlar tree: m.

Ie ne me veux point mesler de cela,
n'en bien n'en mal, I will not deale 
with that matter, neither good nor
bad.

Meslée, a mingling of two, or many
things togither: Meslée also is ta­
ken for a combat: as A donc com­
mença la meslée dure & cruelle,
then began the fight to be fierce and 
cruell: f.

Se retirer de la meslée, to withdraw
himselfe out of the prease and
fight.

Venir à la meslée, & se combatre
main à main, to come to the com­
bate, and fight hand to hand.

Mesliers, vines mingled.

Ce mesme, the very same thing, the
same.





En ce lieu là mesme, in the very same
place.

Dire les mesmes parolles, to speake
the selfe same words.

Mesmement que la premiére chose,
&c. namely, or especially when the
first, &c.

Le Mesnage, housholde: m.

Bon Mesnagier, a good husband, one
that looketh well to his busines.

En bon mesnagier, like a good hus­
band.

Vne bonne mesnagiére, a good hus­
wife.

Mesnagement, huswiferie, thrifti­
nes: m.

Mauvais mesnagement, vnthriftines.

Cest bien mesnagé, it is plaied like a 
good husband or good huswife.

Mesoffrir, to offer lesse than the thing
is worth: decline it as Offrir.

Mesprendre, je mesprens, je mes­
pris, j'ay mesprins, je mespren­
dray, to doe amisse.

Mesprendre & faire contre son de­
bvoir, to mistake, to doe contrarie.

Ie me garderay de mesprendre, I 
will doe nothing but as I may doe.

Il a respondu qu'il se gardera de
mesprendre, he hath made answer
that he will consider better of the
matter.

Il ne mesprit jamais, he neuer did a­
misse.

Mesprison, dites luy qu'il se garde
de mesprison, that is, de mespren­
dre, to doe amisse: f.

Mespris, disdaine, contempt, squemish­
nesse, a dispising: m.

Par Mespris, disdainefully, squemish­
lie.

Mespriser, to despise, to disdaine.

Mesprisé, dequoy on ne tient comp­
te, disdained, nought set by.

Mesprisement, a despising, a con­
tempt: m.

Mespriseur, a disdayner, a despiser: m.

Mespriseresse, a coy dame, a squemish
mistresse: f.

Vn message, an errand: m.

Messager, a Messenger, a post, an A­
postle: m.

Messagére, a woman messenger: f.

Messagerie, the office of a Messen­
ger, a messengership: f."messengership" antedates earliest OED citation (1611).

La Messe, f: the masse.

Messiffier, to say or sing a masse.

Messiffiant, a massing Priest.

Messeant, vnseemely, vncomely, vn­
sitting.

Per messeance, through rudenesse: f.

Messeamment, vnmannerly, vnseem­
lie.

Cela messied, that is vnseemely.

Faites autrement a fin qu'il ne vous
messée, doe otherwise to the ende
that it doth seeme vncomely vnto
you.

Messier, celuy qui garde les vignes,
 hee which keepeth the vines when
grapes be ripe: m.

Le Messin, the countrey about Lor­
reine.

Messire, as if one would say, Mon Si­
re, my Lord, this word is attributed
to priests: Some doe say, me cyre, as
me cyre Iehan, me cyre Pierre,
Sir Iohn, Sir Peter: also the knights





of the order are called Messire.

Mestier, an occupation, a craft: m.

Gens de mestier, handicrafts men.

S'il en est mestier ou besoing, if he
be in need or want.

Mestif, see Metiz, a mungrell.

Mestives, Haruest: f.

En temps de mestives, in haruest
time.

Mestivier, a reaper, that doth reape
corne: m.

Mesvenir à quelcun, to chance ill to
one.

Mesure, a measure: f.

Mesurer, to measure, to meate.

Mesurant, meating and measuring.

Mesurage, measuring: m.

Mesurement, mesurage, a measu­
ring or meating out: m.

Mesureur & cordeur de terres, a
measure of lands: m.

Vne met, or mect, a kneading tub: f.

Du metail, all kind of mettall: m.

Matairie, a countrey house, a farme: f.

Metayer ou fermier, a farmer: f.

La metayse, or metayerie, the com­
modities that doth rise by a farme:
fem.

Vne metayere, f: a she farmer, the
farmers wife.

Metal, mettall: m.

Metal d'argent, siluer mettall.

Metes, or limites, the bounds or li­
mites: m.

Meteil, messeling, corne mingled.

Methode, a readie way to teach or
learne: f.

Methridat, Mithridate, Triacle: m.

Metin, the countrie about Lorreine.

Metope, f: a square space betwixt
two rafters in Carpenters worke.

Metiz, engendrez de divers genres
de bestes, mongrels: m.

Metre, a Meeter, a verse: m.

Mettre, to put, to place, to set.

Mettre à fin, to bring to end.

Se mettre à quelque chose, to fall to
some thing.

Se mettre à bien faire, to fall to doe
well.

Vn mets & viande qu'on porte &
met on sus la table, any kinde of 
meate set on the table: a course: m.

Meu, seeke Mouvoir.

Les meubles d'vn homme, moueables,
houshold stuffe: m.

Meubler vne maison, to garnish a
house with houshold stuffe.

Chambre bien meublée, a chamber
well garnished.

Biens mobiles, moueables, com.

Vne meule, a milstone.

La Meule d'un cerf, the roote of the
Harts hornes.

Meur, ripe.

Se meurir, to waxe ripe: je meuris,
je meuri, j'ay meuri, je meuriray.

Meureté, or meurison, ripenesse: f.

Vne meure, a Mulberie, or Black­
bery: f.

Vn meurier, a Mulberie tree: m.

Meugler, to bellowe like a Cowe or 
Bull.

Les meurs, ou mœurs, manners, be­
hauiour: f.

Meurte, arbre, a Mirtle tree: m.

Meurtir, or murtrir, je meurtris, je
meurtri, j'ay meurtri, je meurtri­





ray, to murther.

Meurtre, m: murther, or manslaugh­
ter.

Meurtrier, a murtherer: m.

Meurtrisseure, a brousing of the flesh,
the paine of a wound: f.

Sang Meurtri, blood blacke and 
blew.

Lettre meurtrissante, the dead letter,
letter killing.

Meurtriérement occis, killed cruelly.

Vn Meusnier, m: a Miller.

Vne Meusniére, a woman miller: f.

Meute, or esmeute, a number of
houndes running after a Hart: f.

Mezenge, a bird so called: f.

Mezereon, a kinde of hearbe hauing
the leafe like an Oliue tree.

Miauler, to crie like a catte.

Miaulement, m: meuing like a cat.

Vne miche, a worme that feedeth on
Bees, also a fine manchet: f.

Mi-cheval, m: a centaure, that is,
halfe a horse, and halfe a man.

Mi-courber, to bowe himselfe the
one halfe.

Le Midi, ou mijour, Middaye or
noone: m.

Mie de pain, the crumme of a loafe
of bread: f.

La Mi-esté, mid-summer.

Miel, honey: m.

Vn bournal, or rayon de miel, a ho­
nie combe: m.

Mon miel, a manner of flattering: 
my sweete honie.

Mielleux, sweete as honie.

Voix mielleuse, a sweete voice.

Mielleusement, sweetely.

Mien, mine: m.

Elle est mienne, she is mine.

Ce n'est pas la tienne, mais la mi­
enne, she is not thine, but mine.

Il est des miens, he is of my trayne.

Miettes & toutes telles choses qui
chéent de la table, crummes of
bread.

Mieulx, better best.

A qui Mieulx, mieulx, the best take
it: to striue who shall do best.

I'aime mieulx, I had rather.

Mignard en parolles, fine in speech,
eloquent.

Ma petite mignarde, my prety and
wanton: my darling: f.

Mignarder, to play the wanton.

Dire mignardement, to speake trim­
ly, finely, eloquently.

Mignardise, trimmenesse, featenesse,
wantonnesse, delicatenesse: f.

Mignon, m: minion, trimme, feate,
fine.

Cest son mignon, he is his minion.

Le mignon du Roy, the kings minion.

Ma mignonne, my minion, my trul,
my sweeting: my darling: f.

Mignonnement vestu, minionly
clad, gaylie, minikinly.

Fait bien mignonnement, done ve­
ry finely, gaylie, gallantly.

Mignotises, darlings: f.

Mignoter, to vse one as his darling,
to dandle.

Mignotement, to be vsed like a dar­
ling, dandling.

Mignonnetté, trimmenesse, neate­
nesse, finenesse: f.

Mignotise, nicenesse, dandling: f.





Migraine mal, the Megrim in the
head, also a colour in graine: f.

Vne Migraine, f: a pomegranate:
also a kinde of sea fish.

Mi-jour, the middest of the day: m.

Mil ou millet, a pulse that is called
Millet, or mill: m.

Vn milan, m: a Kite, a Puttocke, a
Gleade.

Milannois, a man of the towne of
Millaine, in Lombardie.

Vn miliart, as vn miliart d'escus d'­
homes, many millions of meny crowns.

Million, a million, tenne hundred
thousand.

Millenes, as vne millene d'années,
 many thousands of yeares.

Milliesme, as la milliesme partie the 
thousand parte.

Milieu, the midst: m.

Qui est au milieu, which is in the
middest.

Milieu de quelque chose, the mid­
dest or center.

Militer, to vse the feates of warres, to
be in warres.

Art, or industrie militaire, the Arte
of warefare.

Mille, a thousand.

Mille fois, a thousand times.

Mille fueille, herbe, an hearbe cal­
led Milfoyle, yarowe, or nose­
bleede: f.

Millepertuis, an hearbe called Saint
Iohns worte: m.

Mince & delié, fine and small.

Mincer, to mynce, to cutte in small
pieces.

Mincement, slenderly.

Mine, mesure, a measure containing
about two bushels: f.

Trois, or quatre minaux, or mines:
 idem.

La mine d'aucun, the countenance
of a body.

Faire bonne mine, to make a good
shewe.

Commander par mine, to command
by nodding, or some like countenance
or gesture.

Mine de metail, ou miniére, a mine
of mettall: f.

Mineral, mettall.

La variéte des mineraulx, the varie­
tie of mettals.

Mine qu'on fait soubs la tetre, a 
mine or caue vnder the earth: f.

Miner, to mine or digge vnder the
earth.

Miner & vser, to weare away, to vn­
dermine one, to weare and consume
him.

Vn mineur de douze ou quatorze
ans, a minor, or one in the age of
minoritie: m.

Mineur, as Prouver la mineur to
proue the Minor in termes of lod­
gicke.

Contrats faits avec mineurs tien­
ment, s'ilz sont à leur profit, con­
tractes made with minors are of ef­
fect, if they be made to their profit.

Minorité, the time whilest the minor
is vnder age, minoritie: f.

Minoratif, as medicine minorative,
a phisicke of gentle effect.

Miniére, a quarrie or mine: f.

Minime de tous, the least of all.





Vne minime, a minim in musicke: f.

Vn ministre & serviteur, a minister,
a seruant: m.

Ministrer & servir, to minister, to
serue, to deliuer.

Minuër le sang, to diminish the blood.

Minution de sang, drawing of blood.

La minuict, midnight: f.

Vne minute, a minute, a copie, an in­
grossing: f.

Minuter vn contract, to take a copy
of an euidence, to make a draught
of any writing, to ingrosse.

Minuter ses papiers de raisons, to
tosse, turne, and cast his bookes of
accounts.

Mi-panché, half bowing or hanging.

Mipartir, je mipars, je miparti, j'ay
miparti, je mipartiray, to part by
the middest, to deuide in two.

Mirabolans, a kinde of fruite: m.

Miracle, a miracle, a maruell, a won­
der: m.

Miracleurs, doers of miracles: m.

Chose miraculeuse, wonderfull.

Miraculeusement, miraculously.

Mire, a phisition, a surgeon: m.

Mirer drat au blanc, to take his le­
uell or shot right to the marke.

Vn miroir, a looking glasse: m.

Se mirer, to looke in a glasse.
Qui bien se mire, bien se voit:
Qui bien se voit, bien se cognoist:
Qui bien se cognoist, peu se prise,
& sage est.

Dieu le vous mire, let God render it
to you.

Vn miroitier, or faiseur de miroirs,
 a maker of looking glasses: m.

Mi-rond, halfe round.

Missaille, or gageure, f: a pawne or 
wager.

Lamisaine, f: the middest sayle in a 
shippe.

Mise, expence, cost: as La mise exce­
de la recepte, the charges doth ex­
ceede the receipt.

Miserable, miserable, wretched, com.

Miserablement, en sorte qu'on fait
pitié à aucun, miserably, wret­
chedly.

Misere, miserie, wretchednesse: f.

Misere mei, as Iliaque passion,
 the wringing in the small guts.

Misericorde, f: mercie, pitie, com­
passion.

Misericordieux, mercifull, pitifull.

Misericordieusement, mercifully.

Missive, letters sent: f.

Miste & propre, neate, fine, gaye.

Mistement, finely, gaylie.

Mistere, mysterie: m.

Mistion, a mingling, a mixing: f.

Mistionner, to mingle, to meddle.

Mistionné, mingled, mixed.

Mistionnement, m: a mingling, a
mixing.

Mitaines, or mouffles, mittens, win­
ter gloues.

Mites, or mitons qui naissen és four­
mages & febves, Mites that doe
breede in cheese and beanes: f.

Mithridat, seeke Methridat.

Mitiguer, to asswage.

Mitigation, asswaging: f.

Mitigatif, m: which hath the force or
strength to ease or asswage.

Mi-tirer la langue, to draw out





halfe his tongue.

Mitré & crossé, hauing a Miter &
a Bishops staffe, as the popish Bi­
shops doe vse.

Mitre, a miter: f.

Mitrer quelqu'vn, & le mettre à l'­
eschelle, to make one weare a pa­
per, to miter one.

Mixtion, seeke mistion.

Mobile, seeke meuble.

Mobiliaire, moueables and chattels.

Mobilité, inconstancie: f.

Se mocquer de quelqu'vn, To
mocke, to floute, to laugh to scorne,
to disappoynt.

Mocqué, mocked, disappoynted.

Mocqueur, a mocker, a flouter, a de­
ceiuer: m.

Moquerie, a mocke, a floute, a scoffe,
a deceit: f.

Par mocquerie, mockinglye, Ie­
stingly.

La mode ancienne, the olde maner
or fashion: f.

A la novelle mode, after the newe
fashion.

Vn modelle, a moulde, a patterne: m.

Moderer les tributs, to moderate, or
to ease payments or toll.

Estre fort moderé & constant, to be
moderate and constant.

Moderément, moderately, tempe­
rately.

Sans moderation, f: immoderately,
rashly.

Moderation, as sans moderation ou
attrempence, without meane or
temperance.

Moderateur, a gouernour: m.

Moderatrice, a gouernesse: f.

Moderne, that which is of our age: 
as les Poetes modernes, the Poets 
of our time, com.

Modeste, com: as home modeste,
 a modest man, com.

Modesteté, or modestie, f: mode­
stye.

Modestement, modestly.

Modification, limitation, or restri­
ction, a qualifiyng, moderating, li­
miting, or releasing: f.

Modillon, see Corbeau.

Les gros moignons de chair & des
muscles, lumpes of flesh mixt with
sinewes and gristles, the brawne of
the armes and legges.

La grosse charnure, the brawne: f.

La mouëlle qui est dedens les os, the
marrowe that is within the bones: f.

Le suc, or moelle de quelque cho­
se, the iuyce of any manner of
thing.

Les moëttes, forerunners, those that
run before to bring tydings of ones 
comming: m.

Moette, or mouëtte, a sea Gull, a 
kinde of birde: m.

Mœurs, manners: seeke meurs: f.

Moien, Moienner, seeke Moyen.

Moilon, morter, cement, rubbish: m.

Pierre ou mur de Moilon, parget, a­
ny grosse matter whereof a wal is
made as rubbish, shards, ragged
stones, to bee short, a wall made of
that matter.

Moindre, least.

Il se courrousse pour la moindre
chose du monde, he will be angry





at the least thing in the world.

Eh, mon amy, je t'estime le moin­
dre de tous les homes, oh, good
friend or fellowe, I doe lesse set by
thee, then the least or most abiect
of all men.

moindre pris, with lesse price.

Moine, a Monke: m.

Moinerie, monkerie: f.

Moineau, a Sparow: m.

Moins, lesse.

Tout au moins, A tout le moins, as
A tout le moins escoutez moy, yet
at least, heare me.

Rien moins, nothing lesse.

Pour le moins, at the least.

Mois, a month: m.

Les mois des femmes, womens dis­
ease or sickenes.

Se moisir, je me moisis, je me moisi,
je me suy moisi, je me moisiray,
rancir, to waxe mouldy, or mustie,
to waxe rancke.

Moisi & ranci, mouldy, musty, ranck
foistie.

Moisissure, mouldines: f.

La moisson, ou le temps de la mois­
son, the time of Haruest: f.

Moissonner, to worke in Haruest, to
reape.

Moissonneur, a haruest man: m.

Vn moisson, m: a Sparow.

Moite, moist, soked, steeped.

Lieu moite & relant, a moiste or
dampish place.

Moiture, moisture: f.

Naturalle moiteur de la terre, the
moisture or fatnes of the earth.

La moitié, the one halfe, equall parte.

Moitoyen, as vn mur moitoyen the 
wall common betwixt two, or diuers
neighbours: m.

Mol, soft: pronounce mou: m.

Vne pome molle, a softe apple.

Mollement, softly.

Mollet, soft, tender, delicate.

Mollesse, or molleté, softnesse, ten­
dernesse: f.

Mollir, je mollis, je molli, j'ay molli,
je molliray, to waxe soft, to become
withered.

Moleste, troublesome, combersome.

Molester quelqu'vn, to trouble one,
to comber one, to be burdenous to
one.

Molestie, troublesomnesse: f.

Molin, seeke Mouldre, a mill: m.

Molinet, a little mill: argent coigné
ou fait au molin, or molinet, monie
coyned at the mil, also it is a parte of
a ship: m.

Molliffier, to make softer.

Mollification, softning: f.

Mollir, seeke mol.

Moluë, or moruë, greene fish: f.

Croyez vous que la moruë soit
bonne au beurre? doe you beleeue
that greene fishe is good with sweete
butter?

Molure the stone vpholding the great
beame in building: f.

Vn moment grand ou petit, a mo­
ment or space of time: m.

Mommerie, a Maske: f.

Mommeur, he that weareth a vizard.

Vn mommon, as donner vn mom­
mon, when Maskers doe offer to
play at dice: m.

ning of a fable.Word entry missing from the Henry E. Huntington copy in EEBO (STC 6737), supplied from the Leeds copy facsimile by Scolar Press.

ment, he speaketh by signes, mea­
ning otherwise then his wordes doe
declare.Word entry missing from the Henry E. Huntington copy in EEBO (STC 6737), supplied from the Leeds copy facsimile by Scolar Press.

Vn morceau de quelque chose, a 
morsell, a gobbet, a lumpe of any
thing: m.Word entry missing from the Henry E. Huntington copy in EEBO (STC 6737), supplied from the Leeds copy facsimile by Scolar Press.

re, to make colation with a bit of
