Mordre, to bite, to nip: je mords, je
mordi, j'ay mordu, je morderay.Word entry missing from the Henry E. Huntington copy in EEBO (STC 6737), supplied from the Leeds copy facsimile by Scolar Press.





Mordre en riant, to bite and laugh
when he hath done.

Qui est mords, which is bitten.

Mordacité, a biting, sharpenesse of
words, a nip: f.

Mordiquer, to bite, to nip.

Mords de bride, a bit of a bridle.

Morsure, a biting: f.

Vn more, a Morian: m.

Moreau, ou morel, a blacke horse, or
morell: f.

Morelle, herbe, an Herbe called
nightshade: f.

Le morfil d'vn couteau, the edge of a 
knife: m.

Se morfondre, to chatter for cold, to
catch colde: je me morfonds, je
me morfondi, je me suy morfon­
du, je me morfondray.

Monfondu, almost dead of colde,
which hath caught colde.

Morfondure or morfundement, cat­
ching a colde: f.

Morgeline, herbe, an herbe: f.

Morgue, comme, Qui fait la mor­
gue, he that maketh a countenance
or setteth a bolde face on the mat­
ter, that counterfeiteth a seuere or
graue philosopher: f.

Morille a kinde of todestoole: f.

Qui est bien moriginé, well mane­
red, manerly.

Morillon, a kinde of bird in riuers ve­
ry blacke: also morillon, is a kinde 
of blacke grape among the Parisi­
ans, which those of Orleans do call
Auvernas, wherewith the best wine
is made: m.

Vn morion, a sallet or helmet.

Morir, seeke Mourir.

Vn danseur de morisque, a morrice
daunser: m.

Morne, comme sot, & sans advise­
ment, amazed, or at ones wits end,
sometime pensiue, heauy.

Temps Morne, darke or lowring we­
ther.

Morne & pensif, full of pensiue­
nesse.

Mornement, dumpishly, pensiuely.

Mornifle, it is a certain fruite grow­
ing like a todstoole, but round, a
dainty dish among the Italians, it is
also a blow with ones hand, as Il luy
Bailla telle Mornifle qu'il le tourna
de l'autre costé, he gaue him such
a blowe, that &c: f.

Moron, herbe, an herbe called Pim­
pernell, some take it for Chicke­
weede.

Morosité, waiwardnesse, frowarde­
nesse: f.

C'est vn home for difficile à gover­
ner, he is a very froward ouer­
thwart man.

Mors, or morsure du diable, a kinde
of herbe: m.

Morsure, seeke Mordre.

La mort, Death: f.

Mort subite, sodaine death.

Il est impossible que la mort soit
honorable de celuy qui a mes­
chament vescu, it is vnpossible that
death be honourable of a naughtie
liuer.

Pourchasser la mort d'alcun, to seek
after ones death.

Mort aux vers, wormeseede.





Vne Mortaise, a buttresse, a shoul­
dring: f.

Mortel, deadly, mortall.

Coup mortel, a deadly blowe: m.

Mortellement, mortally, deadly.

Mortalité, death, mortalitie: f.

Mortifere, a bringing or causing of
death, com.

Appartenant à mortuäille, belong­
ing or pertaining to mortuaries, or
burials.

Vn drap Mortuaire, ou chevalet
mortuaille, an herse set vp at a bu­
riall.

Mortifier, to mortifie, vexe, and pu­
nish his bodie.

Mortification, mortifying, vexing,
mortification: f.

Fraper mortement, to strike slowlie
and faintly: the contrarie is, Cou­
rageusement.

Vne Mortaise, a shoulderer, or shoul­
dering piller vpholding the frame.

Mortepaye, are the ordinary & per­
petuall souldiers placed in Castels
and townes for time of life: m.

Vn Mortier, commonly is a vessell of
brasse, yron, stone or wood, to stampe
or bray any thing, a morter: it is a 
kinde of cap, hauing the brim tur­
ned vpward: also a kind of artille­
rie of yron short and hauing many
rings or circles onely vsed in ships
for nailes shot: finally, it is a Lampe
either of yron or other mettall: m.

Mort-né, a still borne: m"a still borne" antedates the earliest OED citation (1913).

Du mortier, morter to plaister with­
all: m.

Moruë, or Mouluë, poisson, a fish
called Codde, or greenefish: f.

Morve, ou Morveau, snot sniuell: m.

Morveau, snotty, sniuelly.

Mosaïque, or musaique, any worke
finely wrought with small peeces: o­
therwise called in French, ouvrage
de marqueterie.

Mosquettes, or mosquets, field pee­
ces: m.

Mosquette, the temple of the turkes.

Mosquée, f: idem.

Vn mot, a word, it is also the sound of
the horne among hunters: m.

A son mot, at his word.

Vn motet, a verse: m.

Moteur, or motoire, as l'esprit mo­
teur de l'univers, the spirit causing
the whole world to moue.

Motif, a motion, a cause, also the au­
thor of any mischiefe: m.

Motte ou glason, a clod of earth, a
turne: f.

Le pourceau leve les mottes de ter­
re avec le groin, the hogge raiseth
the clods of earth with his snoute.

Motte, a but to shoote at: f.

Mottelette, f: a little turfe.

La motte d'vn home ou d'vne fame, 
 the noddle.

Moucher, to wipe ones nose, to blowe
ones nose.

Mouchoir, an hankerchief: m.

Mouchet, a bird of praye, a Tierce­
let: also a kind of artillerie: a mus­
ket: m.

Moudure, or mousture, the rewarde
or fine which a miller taketh to
grind corne, a toll: f.

Moucheter, to sparkle, see Mousche,

Mue, properly a change: f.Word entry missing from the Henry E. Huntington copy in EEBO (STC 6737), supplied from the Leeds copy facsimile by Scolar Press.


Lu mu de cerf, when the Hart cast­
eth his hornes: also the muing of a
Faulcon, it is taken also for the
place where hee doth mue: so we
say, mettre en mue, mettre hors de
mue: also it is taken for a coupe or
stie where Capons or other beasts
are fatned: Finally, for a mockerie
we say, la mue d'vne fame, when
through Phisicke & drugs she hath
changed her wrinkled skinne into a
smooth and delicate hue.Word entry missing from the Henry E. Huntington copy in EEBO (STC 6737), supplied from the Leeds copy facsimile by Scolar Press.


Tuez moy le meilleur chappon de la





mue: kill me the best capon of the
coope or stie

La Muette, the house of the chiefest
woodward, where the keepers doe
bring the branches and hornes that
are cast by Hartes: also the place 
where a Hare doth farrow: f.

Home muable, an vnconstant man.

Muance, change: f.

Muableté, ficklenesse: f.

Muement de forme en aultre, al­
tring of one forme or shape to ano­
ther.

Mutation, chaunging, chopping, al­
tering: f.

Muet, dumbe, speechlesse: m.

Rendre muet, to make one dumbe, to
stop ones mouth.

Il desire que sa fame fust muette, ou
bien que luy mesme fust sourd:
 he wisheth his wife dumbe, or he
himselfe deaffe: m.

Mufle, or museau, the snout: m.

Mugereul, poisson, a fish so called by
the people dwelling at Narbone: m.

Muge, m: the swiftest of all the sca­
led fishes.

Mugir, to bellow like an oxe or a cowe.

Mugissement, bellowing of Kine or
Oxen: m.

Mugler, idem, as Mugir.

Muglement, properly is of an Oxe or
Cow, but it is said also of an Hinde:
as la blanche biche eslevoit ses
muglements jusques au ciel, the
white Hinde did raise her cry euen
vp to heauen: m.

Du Muguet, May lillies, or Prime­
roses: m.

Vn Muguet, a fine Courtier, an effe­
minate one lying in womens laps, a 
louer, a woer: m.

Muguetter, or faire l'amour à vne
fame, to court, to sue to a woman: m.

Muguette, ou muscade, a Nutmeg:
fem.

Vne Muguette de mouton, a mou­
get.

Mui, vn mui de forment, a bushell of
wheate: m.

Cent muis de bled, an hundred bu­
shels of corne.

Il va sur mule aussi bien que le pa­
pe, he rideth vpon a mule as the
Pope: this is spoken in mockerie by
those which haue kibes.

Marche devant povre mulard, thou
which art vexed with kibes, goe be­
fore.

As tu pansé ta mule? hast thou dres­
sed thy kibes? f.

Le laict d'vne pucelle est chose sou­
veraine pour la guarison des mu­
les, the milke of a Virgin is a soue­
raigne medecine to heale kibes.

Aportez moy mes mules, bring me
my moiles or pantofles: f.

Elle porte des mules de troys do­
igts d'espesseur, he vseth moiles of
three inches thicknesse.

Vne Mule, a mule: f.

Vne mule aux talons, a kibed heele.

Les mulets du Roy sont passez, the
Kings mules are passed: the vse of
the French court is to carrie the
Kings, Princes and Lords houshold
stuffe vpon great mule foales: m.

Il est chargé comme vn mulet, he is





laded like a Mule.

Il est fantastique comme vne vieille
mule, he is as fantasticall as an old
mule.

Il boit & mage à ses heures comme
la mule du pape, he doth all things
at this houre as the popes mule doth.

Cest vne mule, or elle est mule, that
is spoken of a barren woman, because
a mule neuer bringeth forth.

Vne mule vmbrageuse, a starting
mule.

Mulet, a mules foale: m.

Muletier, a mule keeper: m.

La mulette d'un veau, f: the chal­
dron of a calfe.

Vn moulon de foin, a hay-cocke: m.

Mulet, a field mouse: m.

Multiplier, to multiply, to increase.

Les ennemis se multiplient de jour
en jour, the enemies doe encrease
dayly.

Quant à moy j'entens myeux la di­
minution que la multiplication,
 as for me I am more skilfull in di­
minishing, than multiplying: f.

Cest vn vray multiplieur en l'art
d'alquemie, car il convertist le fin
or en beaux lingots d'arain, ou le­
ton, he is a true multiplier in the
Arte of Alcumie, for he turneth
fine gold into faire wedges of brasse
or latten: m.

Multipliement, or multiplication,
 an increasing, a multiplying: m.

Multiplieur, a multiplyer: m.

Multipliable, which may bee increa­
sed or multiplyed, com.

Multitude & assemblée de gents, 
 a multitude or assemblie of people.

Vne multitude confuse, a confused
multitude: f.

Multitude de plaisirs lesquelz tu
m'as faits, a great number of plea­
sures which thou hast done to me.

Et voyant que la multitude des en­
nemis estoit plus grande que la
sienne, il, &c. and seeing that the
multitude of the enemies was grea­
ter than his, he, &c.

Mumie, or chair humaine embaul­
mée, mans flesh embaulmed.

Vn munier, a miller: also a kinde of
fish: m.

Munificence & liberalité, liberality.

Munir, je munie, je muni, j'ay mu­
ni, je muniray, to fortify, to defend,
to garnish, to shield.

Munition & garnison, a garrison or
warde: f.

Munir & fortifier vne place premi­
er que l'ennemy vienne, to forti­
fie a towne before the comming of 
the enemie.

Munition de vivres, munition of vi­
ctuals: f.

Ville bien munie, a towne well furni­
shed both with strength and all ne­
cessarie things.

Munimens & deffences, m: forti­
fiyng.

Munitionner vn camp, or vne ville,
 to fortifie, victuall, or furnish of all
things a campe or towne.

Mur, a wall: m.

Viel mur, an olde wall.

Escheler vn mur, to clime vp the wal
by a ladder.

Naqueter, to stay or stop the ball at
tennice.

Narine, f: the nostrels.

Fandre les Narines à vn cheval,
pour myeux prendre son alei­
ne, to slitte the nostrelles of a
horse, to take his breathe the be­
ter.

Narration, f: a Narration, a decla­
ration

Narrer, to shew, to tell, to declare.

Narrateur, he that sheweth or telleth
any thing: m.

Narratif de letres, the contentes of
Letters.

Clauses narratives des mandements,
 the contentes of clauses of letters of
commandement.

Nasarde, as donner vne Nasarde to
giue one a phillip or rappe vpon the 
nose: f.

Nasarder, to phillip one vpon the
nose.

Ca ce nez, que je le Nazarde, let me
haue that nose, that I may phillip
the same at will: marot.

Naseaux, les trous & souspiraux du
nez, the breathing holes of the nose, 
the nostrels: m.

Nasitort, or cresson alenois, cresses,
an hearbe: m.

Nasquir, c'est à dire naistre, to bee
borne, to haue first being.

Il Nasquit a troys heures apres mi­
di, he was borne, &c.

Le Nassel d'un heaume, m: the band
vnder the chinne of an helmet.

Vne Nasse, a weyre for to catch fish
in: f.

Vne Nasselle, a small boate, a cocke­
boate: f.

Natif, m: borne: see Naistre.

Vne Nation, a nation, kindred, or
people: f.

Nativité, seeke Naistre.

Vne chambre nattée, a chamber
wel furnished or hanged about with
mattes.

Vn Nattier, a matmaker: m.

Natte, a mat: f.

Nature, nature: f.

La Nature & maniére de faire, qu'­
vn chacun a de nature, nature or
inclination.

La Nature & partie honteuse d'vne
personne, the priuie partes of any
person.

Naturel, naturall, kinde.

Chacun de nous est plus naturel au
mal que au bien, each man is more
bent naturally to, &c.

C'est vne chose Naturelle, it is a na­
turall thing, it stands by reason.

Naturellement, naturally, kindely.

Naturalizer, to make one Denison.

Lettres de Naturalité, f: letters of
Denison.

Naturalizé, which is made Denison.

Tous les naturels, all the naturall
Philosophers, that is, those which
haue searched out the secrets of
nature.

Nau, seeke Navire.

Vn Navet, a rape or turnep: m.

A fleuri sont les bons Naveaux, ma­
rot: at Fleuri be the best turneps:
but Naveaux properly are not
bigger then ones thombe, a verie





sweete and sauoured kinde of Tur­
nep.

Vne Navetiere, a Rape fielde: f.

De la Navette, turnep seede: f.

La Navette d'vn Tisserand, a Wea­
uers shittle: f.

Naufrage, a shipwracke: f.

Naufrageux orage, a storme decla­
ring shipwracke: m.

Naviger, to sayle, to fleete.

Navigation, nauigation, sayling: f.

Navigable, as riviére navigable a 
riuer where one may saile, com.

Navire, ou Nau, a Ship: some doe vse
it in the masculine gender, & some
in the feminine.

Naulage, the fraight or fare paied for
passage ouer the water: such mo­
ney as one doth pay to passe the Sea
in a Ship: m.

Naulager, to pay for the conduct of a
ship.

Navrer, to hurt, to wound.

Navré, hurt, wounded.

Elle a esté Navrée, pensant navrer
les aultres, she hath been wounded, 
c.

Vn Navreur de gens, a shifter, one
that borroweth of euery man, a co­
siner.

Navrure, a hurt, a wound: f.

Nautonnier, a Mariner, a ship-man,
a boat-man: m.

Nayer, seeke Noyer.

Nayf, see Naïf.

Qui est Né, seeke Naistre.

Ne cecy, ne cela, neither this, nor
that.

Ne à ceste heure mesme, not at this
present houre.

Ne aussi, nor also.

Ne cela aussi, nor that neither.

Neant, nothing.

Chose de rien, a thing of nothing.

Tout vint à neant, all came to no­
thing.

Neant moins, neuerthelesse.

Et neant moins vouz voyez mes
ans, and yet you see my yeeres.

Neble, a cloud: f.

Nébleux, cloudie.

Vn faitneant, an idle person: m.

Necessaire, necessary, needfull.

Necessairement, necessarily.

Necessité, necessitie, neede: f.

Les Necessitez de nature, the ne­
cessities of nature, the easing of ones
body.

Home necessiteux, a poore and nee­
dy man.

Nectar, le bruvage des dieux, the 
drinke of the Gods: f.

Liqueur nectare, sweet and pleasant
liquour: f.

Nef, a ship: f.

La Nef d'vne Eglise, the ridge or the
body of a Church.

Vne Neffle, Mesle, or Mesple, a fruit
called a Medlar.

Vn Nefflier, merlier, mesplier, ou
Meslier, a Medlartree: m.

Negation, a denying, a nay: f.

Negatoire, vne action negatoire, a
negatorie action.

Negatif, negative, that denieth.

Neglliger, to neglect, to haue little re­
gard to.

Negligence, carelesnes, rechlesnes.





Negligemment, negligently, care­
lesly.

Negligent, negligent, careles, retch­
lesse,

Negoce & affaire, businesse or af­
faires: m.

Negocier, to exercise marchandise,
to trafique, to be in businesse.

Negociateur, a factor, an occupier, a
merchant: m.

Negociation, a businesse, trade, or
trafike: f.

Negociation vsuraire, Vsurers trade 
or traffike.

Negriez & vigne sauvage, wylde
Vine: m.

Neige, snowe: f.

Neiger, to snowe.

Neigeux, full of snowe.

Nepenthe, without dolour or paine, it
is a drinke which causeth one to feel 
no dolour: m.

Neptune, m: the God of the Sea.

Neptunien, or neptunois, which is
of the nature of the Sea.

Neptunales, f: the holiedayes dedica­
ted to the God of the Sea.

Neveu, a Nephewe, or a brothers
sonne: m.

Nerte, as vn oiseau de Nerte a feld­
fare or thrush.

Nerf, a sinew: m.

Nerveux, full of sinewes, or strong.

Conjoint par Nerveure & liaisons,
 ioyned with sinewes and bands.

Nervins, certaine cordes about the
sailes of a Ship.

Nerte, f: the name of an herbe called
Mirtle.

Nes, seeke Nez.

Nettoyer, to clense, to make cleane,
to wype, to rubbe, to purge, to
scoure.

Net, cleane, neat.

Mettre au net, when we haue written
any thing first, and then write the
same faire, we say, Il est au net:
also when any sentence or matter
intricate is made plaine.

Nettoyable, that which may be made
cleane or cleansed, com.

Nettement, cleanly.

Netteté, cleanlynes, f: cleannes.

Neud, a knot: m.

Nouër, a knit, to tye.

Nouëuz, knitting togither, full of
knots.

Neuchu ou plein de neuds, full of
knots, knottie.

Neuëment, simply, without calling.

Nouëment, a knitting: m.

Neuf, nine.

Le Neufiesme jour, the ninth
day: la neufiesme heure, the ninth
houre.

Neufismement, by nine times, as we
say tiercement, thirdly: so neufies­
mement, ninthly.

La Neufaine, a vowe among the Pa­
pistes during nine dayes ceremo­
nies: where you must remember to
sound F. in these three last wordes,
like V, as Neuviesme, Neuvies­
mement, Neuvaine.

Neutre, fauouring none of both the
parts.

Neutralité neutralitie: f.

Se Neutralizer, that is, Ne se for­





malizer pour l'vn ne pour l'au­
tre, to make himselfe neutrall, hel­
ping neither part.

Le Nez, the nose: m.

Ni, For Ne, before the vowels, nei­
ther, nor.

Vn Ni, a nay.

Nais, seeke Niez, nice.

Nice & paresseux, slowe, fainte: m.

Niceté, slownesse, dulnesse: f.

Vn Nid d'oyseau, a birds nest: m.

Nicher, to nestle, to builde nests.

Vne Niée de poulsins, a broode of
chickins: f.

Niéce, or Niepce, a Niece, or my bro­
thers daughter: f.

Nielle, vne maladie qui vient aux
bleds par trop d'humeur, blasting
of corne: f.

Este Niellé & gasté du remps, to
be blasted.

Nier, to deny, to gainsay.

Niant, a denier.

Niement, denying: m.

Niez, an Idiote, a peke noddie, a simple
soule, a sneaksbie: m.

Niézer, to play the Idiote.

Niézeté, simplicitie, foolishnes: f.

Nifler, to swallow his sniuell.

Nigauld, as c'est le plus grand ni­
gauld que je vi jamais, he is the
greatest loubie, lumpishe, or doltish,
that euer I saw: m.

Nigaulde, is the feminine.

Nigelle an herbe, gitte: f.

Nigromance, necromancie, diuina­
tion by calling vp of sprites: f.

Nigromancien, a necromancer: m.

Nihil, as mettre nihil, or neant à
beaucoup d'articles, to blot out
articles: m.

Nimbot, a dwarfe, a little man: m.

Niquet, Ie n'en donneroye pas vn
niquet, a thing of no value, a knick
made with the thumbes, nailes and
teeth.

Faire la nique, or le Niquet, to mocke
one by nodding the head: f.

Niqueter, as Il n'y a que niqueter,
 there is no fault to be found, or to be
mocked at.

Vn niveau, ou plomb, a plummet: m.

Niveler, to sound with a plummet, al­
so to giue the weight, or weigh a
thing.

Nivellement, a sounding: m.

Niveleur, a weigher or he that kee­
peth or giueth waights, also a plommer.

Noble, Noble, of gentle bloud.

Noblement, nobly.

Noblesse, nobility: f.

Relever d'avoir fait chose dero­
gant à noblesse, to restore ones
bloud.

Nocher, a Mariner, the gouernour
of a ship: m.

Nocturne, as vne vision nocturne,
 visions by night: f.

Noël, or nouël, as if one would say, a
new thing, neuer seene before, it is 
Christmas: m.

Chanter Noël, to sing a Christmas
Caroll.

Noir, blacke colour: m.

Vne febve Noire, a blacke beane.

Noirastre, blackish.

Noiret, ou Noirault, swart, duskish.

Les meridionaux sort noiraux, those





the South are blackish, duskish.

Noirté, seeke Noirceur: f.

Noircir, to blacke: je noircis, je noir­
ci, j'ay noirci, je noirciray.

Noirci, blacked, made duskish.

Noicissure, blackishnes: f.

Noirceur or noireté, i idem.

Noise, contention, strife, braule, noise,
disagreement: f.

Noisette, a little small strife or noise,
also an hasell nut.

Noiser, to striue, to contend.

Gents Noiseux & malfaisans, trou­
blesome fellowes, brablers.

Noisif & quereleux, troublesome and
full of quarels: m.

Noix, a walnut: f.

La Noix d'vne harbaleste, the nut of
a crosbowe.

Noix muscade, or Muguette, a nut­
meg.

Noisette, ou noiselle, a filberde, or
hasell nut: f.

Noiselier, or noisetier, a Hasell nut
tree: m.

Vn noyer, a walnut tree: m.

Noyer en l'auë, to drowne.

Noyé, drowned.

Le Nom de quelque chose, the
name of a thing: m.

Les noms & debtes, the names and
debtes.

Nombles d'vn sanglier, m: the
clawes of a wilde bore.

Nommer aucun, to name or alleadge
a man.

Nommer & bailler nom à aucun, to
name or giue name to one.

Nommément, namely, especially.

Nominacion, a naming, or nomi­
nation: f.

Nombre, number.

Nombrer, to number, to tell, to compt,
to reckon.

Nombré, numbred, tolde.

Nombrement, numbring, a tale.

Nombreus, which containeth num­
bers.

Nombreuses loix, verses.

Le nombril, the nauill: m.

Le nombril de Venus, an herbe.

Nompareil, or nompair, which hath
not the like, peereles.

Nompareillement, that is, excel­
lently.

Non, not, nay.

Non seulement, not onely.

Nonain, see Nonnain, a Nunne.

Nonante fois, ninetie, or fourescore
and ten times.

Nonnain, a Nunne: f.

Nonante, ninetie.

Nonantiesme, the ninetieth.

Fame Nonchalente, a carelesse wo­
man.

Se Nonchaloir, to liue in securitie &
carelesnesse.

Ce Nonchaloir est grand, f: this se­
curitie or carelesnesse is too bad.

Nonchalant, carelesse, retchles, neg­
ligent: m.

Nonchalamment, negligently, care­
lessely,

Nonchalence, carelesnesse: f.

Noncer à quelcun, to bring newes
or word to one, to tell to one.

Nonnain, ou Nonne, a Nunne: f.

Heure de nonne, noone.





Nopces, or nopçages, mariages, wed­
dings: f.

Nore, or bru, my sonnes wife: f.

Nostre, ours.

Ilz sont des nostres, they be of our
side.

Notablement, singularlie, excellent­
lie.

Notamment, namely.

Notable, notable, worthie of mark­
ing, com.

Notaire, a Notary, a Scriuener: m.

Noter, to note, to marke, to signe.

Estre Noté, to bee noted, or of ill
name.

Notablement, notably.

Noté & marqué, noted, or mar­
ked.

Notice, cela est venu à sa notice,
 that is come to his knowledge: f.

Notoire, notorious, plaine, com.

Chose Notoire & certaine, a thing
manifest.

Notoirement, manifestly.

A Nou, as passer la mer à nou to passe
the sea swimming.

Novales, Vines newly planted.

Nouäilleux, full of knots.

Novembre, the moneth of Nouem­
ber: m.

Nouër, seeke Neud.

Nourir, je nourris, je nourri, j'ay
nourri, je nourriray, to reare vp, to
nourish, to feede, to bring vp, to finde
at bourd.

Qui est nourri, fed, nourished.

Nourrissier, a Nurse: spoken of the
man: m.

Nourrisse, a Nurse: f.

Vn Nourrisson, hee or shee that is
brought vp as a child: m.

Nourriture, meate, foode, Nurture: f.

Nourritures, bringing vp of hogs and 
swine.

Nourrissement, bringing vp, fin­
ding.

Nous, we.

Nous-aultres, see Vous.

Nousmesmees, we our selues.

Novalitez, nouelties: f.

Nouveau, new, fresh.

Nouvelle, newes: f.

Nouvellement, newly, of late.

Nouveauté, novelleté, noueltie, new­
nesse, of late: f.

Le noyau, the kernell of a nut, and
such like: m.

Vn noyau & viz par laquelle on
monte en quelque lieu, a payre of
winding staiers: m.

Noyer en leauë, seeke Noix.

Nuage, seeke Nuée.

Vn Nuage de corbeaux, c'est à dire
vne collée espesse obumbrant le
ciel comme font les nuées, a thick
flight of Rauens shadowing the skie
as a cloude: m.

Nuage, in painting, is the shewe and
representation of the Ayre and
cloudes.

Nud, naked.

A demi nud, halfe naked.

Mettre à nud, to strip starke naked, to
vnclothe.

Nuë, she naked.

Nudité, f: nakednes.

Nue, or Nuée, a cloude.

Mettre aulcun jusques aux nuées,





that is, le louër haultement, to
praise one euen to the skies.

Ne faire non plus de conte d'aulcun,
que des nuées, or neiges, d'antan,
 to set no more by one, then of the
cloudes or snow of the last yeare.

Temps nuageux, that is, couvert de
nues, or nuées, the heauen couered
with cloudes, the ayre cloudie.

Nuage, cloudie: m.

Montangne nuageuse, a mountaine
couered with cloudes.

Nuer, to ouershadow a picture or any
thing with a bright colour.

Blancheur nuée de vermeil, a white
ouershadowed with a reddish co­
lour.

La Nuict, the night: f.

Veiller les nuicts entiéres, to watch
whole nights.

Nuictées, f: the space of the whole
night.

Nuire, je nuis, je nui, j'ay nuit, je
nuiray, to hurt, to offend, to anoy.

Nuisant, hurtfull, full of shrewde
turnes.

Nuisance, hurt, annoyance: f.

Nuisible, which may hurt, hurtfull.

Nul, none, no man: m.

De nulle valeur, of no value, nothing
worth.

Nulle part. in no place, on no side.

Nullement, nothing at all, in no wise.

Nullité, as amener aucune chose à
nullité, to bring any thing to no­
thing: f.

Nuptial, pertaining to a wedding: m.

Ayant posé ses acoustremens nup­
tiaux, hauing laid off his wedding
garments.

Robe nuptialle, a wedding apparel: f.

Nyctalopes, beasts going in the night
time.

Nymphe, a Nymph: f.

Nymphal, belonging to a Nymph: m.


O ante B.

O Moy home perdu, O perdu que
je suis, O wretch that I am.

O la hardiesse, O what boldnesse, O
lustie courage.

Obeïr, j'obeïs, j'obeï, j'ay obeï, j'­
obeïray, to obey, to giue place, to be
subiect.

Obeïssant, obedient, seruiceable.

Obeïssance, obedience, subiection: f.

Obediemment, obediently.

Obeine, see Aubaine.

Obelisque, m: a great square stone
beneath, going sharpening to the
topward, like a pyramide.

Vn obice, or obstacle, a let, an impe­
diment: m.

Obiect, an obiect, the laying or setting
of a thing before ones eyes, or a­
gainst one: m.

Objecter, to lay to ones charge, to ob­
iect, seeke Obijcer, and Reprocher.

Obier, ou opier, arbre, a Wych hasel,
as some thinke: m.

Obijcer, ou Obiecter & reprocher,
 to lay to ones charge, to hit one in
the teeth, to set against.

Vn obit, as se trouver à l'obit de son
pere, to be at his fathers buriall: m.





Faire vn obit, to make a pompous bu­
riall.

Objurguer & reprendre, to rebuke
or reprehend one sharply.

Objurgation, a rebuke, a chiding: f.

Objurgateur, a rebuker: m.

Lettres objurgatoires, blaming, re­
buking or chiding letters: f.

Vn Oblat de religion, when one of­
fereth himselfe to be in a religious
house: m.

Oblation, an oblation, an offering: f.

Oblecter & esbastre, to sport.

Oblectation & esbat, a delight, a re­
creation, pastime, or sport: f.

Obliger, to binde one.

Estre obligé par promesse, to bee
bound by promise.

Obligation, an obligation, a bond: f.

Lettres Obligatoires, letters of bonds,
that is an obligation: f.

Obliquement, ouerthwartly, croo­
kedly.

Obliquité, crookednesse: f.

Oblivieux, forgetfull, also that cau­
seth to forget.

Obmettre, seeke Omettre.

Vn Obole, qui est vne piece de
monnoye vallant sept deniers
tournois, a three farthings english,
or thereabout: m.

Obscur, darke, obscure, duskish.

Obscurcir, j'obscurcis, j'obscurci,
j'ay obscurci, j'obscurciray, to dar­
ken.

Ombre Obscurcissant, a darke sha­
dow: m.

Obscurcissement, a darkening: m.

darknesse of speech.

 an earnest praier, a speciall desire: f.

rals: f.

Observance ancienne, an ancient
custome, an obseruation: f.

Observer, to obserue.

Obstacle, a let or impediment: m.

Obstant, letting, standing against.

Non-obstant oposition ou appel­
lation quelconque, all oppositions
or appeales preuailing nothing, or
notwithstanding.

S'obstiner à l'encontre de tous, to
stand stifly against all men.

Obstiné, obstinate, stiffenecked, selfe­
willed.

Obstinément, obstinately, stiffenec­
kedly.

Obstination & aheurtement, selfe-­
willednesse, stubbornnesse: f.

Obstination & fermeté de propos, 
 constancie in that they stand in.

Obsister, to withstande, to stande a­
gainst.

Obtemperer & obeïr, to obey, to yeeld
to.

Obtemperation, obedience, yeelding:
fem.

Obtenir & impetrer ce qu'on de­
mande, to obtaine or get that which
we demaund: j'obtiens, j'obtins,
j'ay obtenu, j'obtienndray.

Arrestz de la cour obtenuz par for­
ce, iudgement obtained, as if it were





by force from the high court: m.

Obtenuë, that which is gotten.

Obtrectation, ill report, disdayning,
backbiting, slaundering: f.

Obtrectateur & mesdisant, a back­
biter, an euill speaker: m.

Obvention testamentaire, a legacie
falne or made to one vnlooked for,
by chaunce.

Obvier que quelque chose ne se
face, to preuent the dooing of any 
thing.

Obumbrer, to shadow.

Occasion, occasion: f.

Occasionnellement, by occasion.

Occasionner la mort d'autruy, to be
the cause of another mans death.

Occident, the Sunne setting: m.

Occidental, of the West part.

Les occidentaux sont forts & robu­
stes, the Westerne men bee strong
and stiffe.

Occire, j'occis, j'occi, j'ay occis, j'­
occiray, to kill, to slay.

S'occire, to kill himselfe.

Il occioit, he did slay.

Vous vous occiez de dueil, you kill
your selfe through sorowe.

Occiant, slaying.

Occision, slaughter: f.

Occis, killed, slaine.

Chose occulte, hidden things, priuie
things: f.

Occulter, to hide.

Occultation, hiding: f.

Occultement, hiddenly, secretly, pri­
uilie.

Occuper & empescher, to let or hin­
der.

Occupé & addonné, giuen to any
thing.

Occupation, a letting, businesse, af­
faires: f.

Occurrent, as ce sont choses occur­
rentes, that is, qui occurrent & sur­
viennent, things which do happen,
chances.

Par plusieurs occurrences, through
many things happened: f.

Ocean, la mer Oceane, the Ocean
Sea: m.

Vne oche, vn cren, or crenne, a notch
in a skore, a nocke in a bow: f.

Ocher, or Crener, to indent.

Oché, or crenelé,  indented.

De l'Ocre, Okre, such as Painters
vse: m.

Octave, a mans name: Les Octaves
de Pasques, Easter holydaies: f.

Octante, eightie.

Octantiesme, the eightieth.

Le mois de Octobre, the moneth of
October: m.

Octroy, a grant, also a will, as il a fait
cela de son octroy, he hath done it
of his owne free will: m.

Octroyer, or ottroyer, to graunt, con­
sent, or agree to a demaund: as à la
requeste de N. je vous ottroye ce­
la, at the request of N. I doe graunt
you that.

Il ne veult rien ottroyer quelque pri­
ére qu'on luy face, he will giue or
graunt nothing, notwithstanding al
the prayers that one can vse.

La Rynne t'a ottroyé ta demande,
 the Queene hath graunted thee thy
demaund.





Il n'est pas donné ne ottroyé à l'ho­
me de pouvoir tout exprimer, it
is not giuen to man to be able to ex­
presse and vtter euery thing.

Ottroyer rabais, or rabbats, to abate
a fine or summe.

Choses données & Ottroyées, things
graunted.

Oculaire, ce que se voit, qu'on voit
à l'œil, that which is seene, eui­
dent.

Oculairement, euidently, at ones
eye-sight.

Odeur, sauour, sent, or smell: m.

Odorement, or Odorat, a smelling.

Odoriferant, or odoreux, a sweete
smelling.

Odieux, odious, hatefull.

C'est vn chose Odieuse, it is an hay­
nous thing.

Oeil, the eye: seeke Yeulx: m.

Oeconomie, the guiding and orde­
ring of things pertayning to hous­
holde, or husbandry: f.

Oeconome, a Steward: m.

Oeconomique, as ordre oeconomi­
que, a good order taken in husbandry.

Arracher & crever vn œil, to put out
ones eyes.

Avoir l'œil sur aulcun, to haue an
eye vpon one, to watch one.

La larme à l'œil, elle luy dit, hauing
a teare at her eye, that is, weeping,
she said to him.

Le coing de l'œil, the corner of the
eye.

Oeil de beuf, an hearbe called May
weede, it is also called in French,
Pisse ene lict, because it is thought
it causeth to pisse a bed.

Oeil de bouc, a fish with scales.

Oeillet, a gilliflower, œillets incar­
nats, Carnations, œillet blanc,
a white gilliflower: m.

Oeillades, wantons eyes, sheepes eies,
louing or louers lookes: f.

Oeillarder aulcun, to tye one, to cast
a wanton eye, to looke vpon one wan­
tonly, to askew."askew" not found as verb in OED.

Oeillader, or jetter Oeillades, idem.

Oeiller les vin, assavoir les remplir,
 to fill wines.

Payer pour l'Oeillage, remplage, or
remplissage des vins, to pay for the
leake of wines.

Les Oeillieres, the eye tooth: f.

Vn œuf, an egge: m.

Vn œuf frais, a new layed egge.

La cocque d'vn œuf, the shell of an
egge: f.

Le blanc ou l'aubin d'vn œuf, the
white of an egge: m.

Le moyeu d'vn œuf, the yolke of an
egge: m.

Oeuf-molette, see Omelette.

Oeuvre, seeke Oeuvrer.

Of, Mot que dient ceux qui sont
estonnez & espouvantez, Oh, a
worde that men doe vse that are a­
frayd or astonied.

Offendre, to endomage one, as Of­
fendre son ennemy, that is, l'en­
domager, luy porter dommage,
this is in martiall affayres.

Offencer, to offend one, to hurte in
wordes or deede.

Si je vous ay offencé ou abusé, pre­
nez en la revenche, If I haue





offended you, nowe reuenge your
selfe.

Offence, an offence, a hurte: f.

Faire cher comperre l'offence, to
cause one to pay deerly for his fault
committed.

Si j'ay commis offence, ce a esté par
mesgarde, if I haue committed a­
ny offence, it was vnawares, or a­
gainst my will.

Armes offencibles, com: hurtfull
weapons.

Cela est vn baston fort offencible,
 that as a dangerous weapon: m.

Offerte, as aller à l'offerte, f: to goe to
an offering.

Vn Official, m: a Bishops chaun­
cellour.

Office & charge qu'on faict, the of­
fice or charge that a man hath.

Officier & Sergent, m: an Officer, a 
Sergeant.

Officier, of foure sillables, is to doe
the diuine seruice at Church.

Offrir, to offer: j'offre, j'offri, j'ay
offert, j'offriray.

Offre qu'on a faict à aucun, an offer
made to one, a condition: m.

Vendre au plus offtant, to sell to him
that offreth most.

Offrende qu'on faict à Dieu, the
offering to God: f.

Offraye, or orfaye, a kinde of raue­
ning bird: an Eagle of the sea.

Offusquer, to darken.

Iugement offusqué d'ire, the iudg­
ment blinded through anger.

Ohier, to weaken one.

Vne ohie, a weakning: f.

Ohié, vn homme ohié de son corps,
 ill at ease, one whose body is out of
temper.

Ohe, is it so? is that true?

Oignon, an onion: m.

Ognonnette, Scalions: f.

Oignonnerie, the place where onions
are sowen, or growe.

Oindre, j'oins, j'oigni, j'ay oinct, j'­
oindray, to annoynt.

Oinct, annoynted.

De l'oing, Swines grease, or others.

Oignement de nard, oyle of spike: m.

Onction, an annoynting: f.

Onguent, an oyntment: m.

Oiseau, or oisel, a bird, foule: m.

Oiselet, or oissillon, a small bird: m.

Huppe & creste qui est sur la teste
d'aulcuns oiseaux, the tuffe which
certayne birdes haue vpon their
heads: f.

Plumer vn oiseau, to pull a birde.

Oiseler vn faulcon sur la grue, to
Lure a faulcon vpon the crane, to
flesh him.

Oiseau de masson, a hodde, a traye
wherein they carrie morter, m: a
bosse.

Oiseleur, a fouler or birdcatcher: m.

Oiselerie, fouling: f.

Oiseliére, a great cage where many
birdes be kept: f.

Oiseux, slothfull, slacke: lither.

Oisif, idem.

Oisiveté, slouthfulnesse, slackenesse,
lithernesse: f.

Oisivement, litherly, slouthfully.

Vn Oison, a greene goose: m.

Vne Olive, an oliue: f.





Vn Olivier, an oliue tree: m.

Oliviers, oliue trees: m.

Olivastre, a wilde oliue tree: m.

Olybrius, as faire l'olybrius, to playe
the parte of a cruell and drun­
kard.

Oligarchie, f: a common weale go­
uerned by fewe.

Ombre, a shadowe, a colour: m.

Soubs ombre d'aliance, vnder co­
lour or pretence of friendship.

Ombrager, to shadowe.

Ombrage, shadow, or couert: m.

Ombrageux, skittish as horses are,
suspicious, as ielous men be.

Ombragement, a shadowing: m.

Les ombragemens des peintres,
 shadowing of paynters.

Vne Omelette, a gallimaufrie of egs
in a frying panne: f.

Omettre quelque chose, to omit
any thing, to leaue any thing vn­
done: see Mettre for the decl.

Omis, left vndone.

Omission, leauing out: f.

Onc, seeke Oncques.

On dit, it is sayd, men saye: seeke
hom.

Vne Once, or lonce, f: an Ounce,
a beast.

Once à once, by ounces: f.

Pesant vne once, weighing an ounce.

Mon oncle, frere de mon pere, mine
vncle.

Mon oncle frere de ma mere, I­
dem.

Oncques, euer.

Oncques mais, or onques puis je ne
le vei, I neuer sawe him since.

Onde, a flood, a waue: f.

Ondé, made with waues.

Robe ondée, a gowne made with
waues.

Ondée, also a great and sodaine fall
of rayne, which otherwise wee call
Guilée: f.

Cheveux ondez, haires dressed like
waues.

Onder les cheveux, to set hayres by
waues.

Robe qui ondoye, a gowne which in
going seemeth to waue.

Ondoyer vn enfant nouveau né,
 a manner of speech among the pa­
pists, when the Midwife christe­
neth a childe new borne, when hee
is in danger of death.

Onereux, or chargeant, loding, char­
geable, which loadeth, which is
heauy.

Vne ongle, the nayle of ones finger: f.

Onglette, a small nayle: m.

L'onglée en l'œil, the Web in ones
eye, but properly in horses: f.

Vne onglade, a scratch with ones 
nayle: f.

L'onglée au bout des doigts pro­
venant de grand froid, the a­
king of ones fingers endes through 
very olde.

Onguent, seeke oindre.

Onyche, a precious stone called O­
nyx like a nayle: m.

Onze, eleuen.

Onzieme, the eleuenth.

Operations naturelles, naturall ope­
rations, or workings: f.

Operer, to worke.

 working, the power of facultie to

sit with the Iudge to giue their ad­
uice or opinion vpon matters in con­

La page d'vn livre, the page of a
booke: f.

Page ou serviteur, a page or ser­
uant: m.

Il est sorti de page, when a Page of 
honour is out of his waiting office,
also when a Leueret beginneth to
be a Hare.

Paier, ou payer, to pay.

Payement, a paying: m.

Paillace, a straw bed, also a wide ves­
sell like a bushell, but not so deepe,
made of like stuffe as Hiues be: f.

Paillard, a whorehunter, a brothel, a
knaue, a villaine: m.

Cest vn fin paillard, he is a craftie
knaue.

Vne paillarde, a whore, a harlot: f.

Cest vn fort paillard, hee is a stout
knaue.

Cest la plus forte paillarde de Lon­
dres, she is the strongest whore in
London.

Cest fait en façon de paillarde, it is
a whores tricke.

Paillarder, to commit whoredome.

Paillardise, whoredome: f.

La paille de l'orge, chaffe of Bar­
ley: f.

Paille, as maison couverte de paille,
 a house thatched or couered with
straw.

Pailles, paillettes, or papillottes, d'or
 spangles: f.

Pailles qui sortent du fer chaud
quand on le bat sur l'anclume, a
sparke issuing from yron when it is
taken out of the fire and beaten vp­
on the anuill.

Vn Paillier, a place where chaffe is 
kept: also the stalke of straw: m.

Faire vn grand paillier, to lay vp straw
in a rike or cocke.

Pain, bread: m.

Gros Pain, brown bread: cheat bread.

Du pain beneist, holy bread.

Chapler du pain, to chip bread.

Pain & pitance, both bread & meat,
seeke Pitance.

Fais maintenant de tel pain soupes, 
 hote sup, hote swallow.

Ou luy a fait de tel pain soupes, that
which he had procured for others,
he hath been serued with.

Pain de porceau, an hearbe.

Pain de cocu, or coucou, another
hearbe so called, because the Cuc­
cow eateth of it.

Vn Panetier, a Panter: m.

Eauë Panée, mises or water-bread: f."water-bread" not found in OED but cf. "water-sop," n.



La Paneterie, the pantrie: f.

La Panetiére d'un berger, the scrip
or bag wherein the shepheard doth
put his bread and victuals: f.

Paindre, paintre, paincture, seeke 
Peindre.

La Paneterie, le lieu où on serre &
garde on le pain, a pantrie: f.

Vne paire de quelque chose que ce
soit, a paire or couple of any thing: f:
some doe say, Vn Paire.

Vne paire de gans, a paire of gloues.

Vn Pair de france, a peece of France:
masc.

Pairrie, the Lordship of a peere: f.

Païs ou pays, a country or kingdom: m.

Païs de droict escrit, a countrey go­
uerned by the ciuill lawes.





Guerpir son païs, to giue ouer, to for­
sake his countrey.

Regreter son païs, to sigh after his
countrey, to desire to returne to his
countrey.

Vn païsant, ou paisant, a countrey
man, a husbandman: m.

Paisseau, pieu, ou eschallas, a prop, 
such as they stay vines by: m.

Paisseler, ou eschalasser, to stay or
prop vp.

Paistre, to feede as cattell doe, to goe
to pasture.

Le Paissage, ou paissement de be­
stes, feeding of beasts: m.

Paissage, or paysage, la gayeté en
paissage embelly de belles fon­
taines, bocages, prairies, &c. the 
beautie of pasture beautified with,
&c.

Paissu, eaten by beasts.

Paix fourrée, a cloaked or coloured
peace: f.

Paix, peace, rest.

Paisible & coy, qui ne se courrouce
point, peaceable, quiet, still, com.

Paisiblement, peaceibly, quietly.

Paisibleté, peaceablenesse, quietnesse,
tranquilitie: f.

Vn paladin, one of those auncient
knights of the round table: m.

Il fait bien de son Paladin, he brag­
geth and doth set himself forth ve­
ry much.

Le palais & la maison royale, a pal­
lace, a King or Emperors place: m.

Le palais de Paris, where the Iudges
doe sit, as in Westminster Hall by
London.

Les gens du palais, al the Iudges and 
Lawyers of the hall.

Iours de palais, court daies, when Iud­
ges doe sit.

Les Poursuivans au palaix, suters at 
the Hall.

Entendre le fait du palais & de plai­
derie, to be skilfull in pleading mat­
ters in the Hall.

Le palais de la bouche, the pallet or
rouffe of the mouth: m.

Il a le palais friand, he hath a sweete
lip, he can iudge whither the sauce
or meate be well seasoned or not.

Palet à iouër, a small beetle to play at
ball with: a quaite: as jouër au pa­
let, to play at quaites: m.

Paleter du chambre, or chanuré, to
pestle hempe.

Vn Palet, a pestling yron: m.

Vn pal, ou pali, ou pieu, the pale of a 
parke, a pale: m.

Palisser vn jardin, to compasse about
a garden with pales.

Vn palissade, a place enclosed with
pales for souldiers: f.

Pale, or cuellier, a fowle called a Sho­
ueler.

Palefroy, a riding horse for gentle­
women, ambling or not: it is called
Palefroy, because Espquiers in times
past did leade gentlewomens horses 
by the bridle, as if we could say, Par
le frein: m.

Palefrenier, or Parefrenier, a horse­
keeper: m.

Palemaille, as jouër à la palemaille,
 to play at long boules as Italians do
with a long thing like a hammer: f.





Palenc, m: a certaine rope in the
ship to hoyse ware in the same.

Palier ou farder vne cause, to cloke or
colour a matter.

Se Pallir, to become bleake: see Paslir.

Aucunement pasle, palish, wanne,
bleake, leane.

Vn Palletoc, a kind of garment like
a short cloake: m.

Vn Pallis, a pale: m.

Pallissade, a Fort compassed with pales:
a pale of defence vsed in warres.

Palme arbre, a Palme tree, or Date
tree: f.

La Palme de la main, the palme of
the hand.

Palumbe ou pigeon ramier, a wood­
culuer or Ringdoue: f.

Vn Palu & marescage, a Marsh or
quagmire: m.

Pampre ou pampe, fueille de vigne,
 the tender stalke of a Vine leafe: 
masc.

Pan ou Panneau dequoy on ence­
inct & on entoure vn bois pour 
prendre bestes sauvages, toyles, or
such nets as are set to catch Deere
in: m: an Haie.

Vn pan, or pand de muraille, a long
piece or stretching of a wall.

Panache, a great tuffe of feathers as
men of armes doe beare on their hel­
met, seeke Empanaché: m.

Panade, it is water brewed and tossed
with crummes of browne bread or
wheaten, in two glasses or like, to
drinke when one is very hote & dry,
or hauing the fit of an Ague.

Des panaiz, an herbe called Carot: f.

Pance, the maw, the panch: f.

Pançu, pansu, or pançard, a Gorbel­
lie, he that hath a great belly: m.

Pancher ou pencher, to hang as a 
building doth that is not vpright.

Penché sus le devant, to hang for­
ward: stiepe-downe.

Panchement, a hanging, a declining:
m: stieping.

Le Pand d'vn habillement & le plis,
 the hemme of a garment: m.

Pandectes, c'est à dire livres con­
tenants toutes choses, bookes con­
taining all things: f.

Pandore, a womans name: f.

Pandorin, as elle a le vase pandorin,
 she hath the boxe contayning all
mischiefe: m.

Paneaux olde ragges: and in Ioyners
worke bee certaine thinne peeces of
workmanship: m: a paine in wainscot.

Panée, seeke Pain.

Panetier, Panetiére, paneterie, seeke
Pain.

Du Panic, a graine like millet, panike: 
masc.

Panicaut, herbe, a kinde of thistle
called Huluer, or Seaholy: m.

Panicles, little loaues: f.

Vn Panier, a small chest: m.

Vn Panier d'osier, a hamper, a bas­
ket.

Vn Paneron, a little basket: m.

Vne Panerée de figues, a basket full
of figs: f.

Vn Porte-panier, a pedlar: m.

La Panilliére, the lower part of the
belly: f.

Du Paniz, semblable au millet, a





kinde of pulse like millet: m.

Faire Pannade & voltiger les che­
vaux, to make his horse to pranse,
or flourish.

Faire pannades, pransing: f.

Panne, peau, or pellices a skinne of
furre: f.

Panne, a skin, a fell, a hyde: m.

Paneau de menuïserie, a coffer of
ioyners worke, a trap: m.

Pannonceau, the crest of an Hel­
met, or the fethers of the same.

Pannicules, or membranes, little
skinne or bed wherein the childe ly­
eth in his mothers wombe.

Panoye, le jeu de la panoye, a game
of wrastling: f.

Panser vn malade, to attende on a 
sicke person, seeke penser.

Pansard, a gorbellyed man: m.

Panse, see Pance.

Pantes & coupeaux des montaigne,
 the sides and toppes of mountaines.

Panteler, to beate & pant as a paine­
full heart doth.

Le Roy tasta où son las cœur Pan­
teloit, the King feeling where his 
weary heart did beate.

Panthere beste, f: a beast called a 
Panther.

Pantoïment tormenter aucun, to
vexe one in such sorte, that hee be
not able to take his breath.

Pantois, m: he which cannot take his
breath.

Pantoyer, to be out of breath.

Vne Pantoufle, a slipper, a pantofle: f.

Panurge, that is, cault, astut, fin,
affété, rusé, a craftie one, also one
that medleth to doe all things: m.

Paour, seeke Peur.

Vn Paön, a Pecocke: m.

Paönnesse, f: the henne Pecocke.

Se Paönner, to bragge like a Pe­
cocke.

Paovre, seeke Povre.

Vn Papegay, or papegau, a Parret,
a Popingay: m.

Papefif, m: the great piece of the
sayles.

Papelard, an hypocrite, a pratler: m.

Papelarder, to play the hypocrite.

Papelardise, speaking fayre: f.

Papier, paper: m.

Vne main de papier, f: a quier of
paper.

Papiers de marchands, & autres se
meslans de trafique, all kinde of
writings of merchants or occupiers.

Papetier, hee that selleth or maketh
paper: m.

Vne papeterie, or moulin à papier,
 a paper mill: f.

Du papet, see papin.

Vn papillon, a butterflie: m.

Papillottes d'or ou d'argent, span­
gles.

Du papin, pappe for children: m.

Vn paquet, a packet, a bundle: m.

Paquette, nom d'herbe, honie-suc­
kle, woodbine: f.

Par moyen, ou par mon moyen, by
my meane.

Par où? which way?

Par cy par là, this way, that way.

Par derriére, behind, or backeward.

Par dessus, vpward.

Par fois, now and then.





Par là, that way, there.

Parabole, a parable, a similitude, a
comparison: f.

Parachever, to make an ende, to fi­
nish.

Parachevement, an ending, a fini­
shing: m.

Parade, a shewe, a boasting: f.

Paradis & jardin, m: a Paradise, a
garden.

Paradoxes, wonderful things against
the common opinion of men: f.

Dame de haut parage, a high noble
Ladie: m.

Paragon, ou parangon, an example,
a proofe, a comparison: m.

Paragonner & comparager, to com­
pare, to conferre.

T'oses tu paragonner à moy? darest
thou make thy selfe equall vnto 
me?

Ie m'ose paragonner à toy, en ma­
tiére d'escriture, in writing I dare
liken me vnto thee.

Paragraphe, as Alléguer force loix,
paragraphes, & opinions des
docteurs, to alleadge many titles of
lawes and opinions of Doctors: m.

Paralelle c'est à dire equallement
distant, f: a comparison of like
space.

Paralytique, one that hath the Pal­
sey.

Paralysie, f: palsey.

Paragon, the worthiest in his kinde:
seeke Parangon: m.

Paranniser, to make perpetuall or e­
uerlasting.

Paranymphe, the chiefest of a mans
parte in a wedding, hee that tooke 
the signe of good lucke or fortune
for the bridegroomes part: m.

Paraphrase, an exposition of a texte
not worde for worde, but keeping
the sense: f.

Parasite, that is, Qui suit les lopins,
vn Patelin, vn Iaquet, a flatterer,
a smell-feast, a belly-friend: m.

Parastre, ou beau pere, a father in
lawe, a stepfather: m.

Paravant, or Auparavant, before.

Vn Parc, a parke: m.

Parquer, to pitch a Campe, also to
place a folde as shepheards doe.

Parcelle, a parcell, a piece: f.

Oster quelque chose à Parcelles
& peu à peu, to take away by little
and little.

Parler par parcelles, to speake by 
parcelles.

Par petites parcelles, by small pie­
ces, by parcels.

Parcroistre, that is, achever de 
croistre & augmenter, to make an
ende of growing, as il est parcru,
he is full growne, or past growing:
decl. it as Croistre.

Parchemin, parchment: m.

Parcheminier, m: a parchment maker.

Pardon, pardon, forgiuenesse: m.

Pardonner, to pardon.

Pardonnement, a pardoning, a for­
giuing: m.

Ce cas n'est pas pardonnable, com: 
 this case is not to be pardoned or
forgiuen.

Pardurable, com: of continuance,
seeke Perdurable.





Parefrenier, m: an Ostler, a horse­
keeper.

Pareil, like, equall, paires.

Pareillement, likewise, also.

Pour la pareille, for the like good
turne againe: f.

Rendre le pareille, to render like
for like.

Parelle, ou patience, herbe, an hearb
called peniriall: f.

Perens & alliez, kinsfolke and alli­
ance.

Parenté, kinred, of one blood: f.

Qui est de noble parenté, which is
of noble blood.

Parentage du coste du pere, kinred
on the fathers side: m.

Parentelle, linnage, kinred: f.

Parenthese, a clause included with
in another sentence, which may be
left, and neuerthelesse, the sence to
be perfect: f.

Parer, to decke, to dresse, to trim.

Parer aux coups de son ennemy, to
warde the enemies blowes.

Parement, Arras, decking, trim­
ming: m.

Son lict estoit tout à lentour paré
fort richement, avoit vn beau pa­
rement, his bed was hanged with
very fayre arras.

Paresse, f: slouth, sluggishnesse, lazy­
nesse.

Paresseux, a slouthfull, lazie, or loi­
tering fellow.

Paresseusement, slouthfully, slowly.

Parfaire, to make perfect, to ende, to fi­
nish: see Faire, to decl.

Parfaict & achevé, fully ended.

Plus-parfaict, more perfect.

Tres-parfaict, most perfect.

Parfaictement, perfectly ended.

Parfaictement, perfectly, redily.

A la parfin, in the ende, at the last.

Par fois, sometime, now and then.

Parforcer, se parforcer de faire quel­
que chose, to enforce himselfe to
doe his vttermost.

Parfournir les legions, to performe
vp the number of the bandes.

Parfournir sa promesse, to fulfill his
promise.

Parfum, perfume, sweete odour: m.

Parfumer, to perfume, to sweeten.

Parier, to lay a wager, as in bowling
or shooting.

On parie, they lay a wager.

Ie parieray dix coutre vn, I will lay
tenne to one.

Parité, equalitie: f.

Se parjurer, to forsweare.

Parjure, com: a forsworne man, a 
Periurer.

Parjurement, forswearing, periu­
rie: m.

Parler, to say, to speake, to vtter.

Parler à quelqu'vn, to speake to one,
to talke with one.

Le parler de l'homme, mans speech.

Hola, hola, n'en parlons plus, ho, let
vs speake no more of it.

Parlant, speaking.

Vn beau parleur, a faire spoken man,
a smooth tongued fellowe: m.

Vn Parlement, ou vn plaide, a par­
liament, a court: m.

La cour de parlement l'a ainsi or­





donné, the high court of parliament
hath so iudged or ordayned.

Messieurs de parlement, the Iudges
of the high court of Paris.

Ville où il y a parlement, a towne
where a high courte is: the chiefest
is at Paris, then at Tolouse, at Gre­
noble, at Dyon.

Parlementer avec aucun & deviser, 
 to talke or commune with one.

Parole, a worde, a saying: f.

Par-lire, to reade through, to reade
ouer.

Vn parloir, a parlour: m.

Qui est à tout par luy, Qui se gou­
verne par soymesme, that is of
himselfe, which ruleth himselfe.

Vn Parmenter, m: in Picardy is a 
taylor.

Vn parmesan, a man borne in Par­
me in Italie, it may bee taken also
for cheese called Parmesan: m.

Parmy, amongst.

Parmy la fenestre, ou le guichet,
 out at the windowe, or wicket.

Parmy les rues, abroade in the 
streetes.

Paroccir, to kil one right out, to make
an ende of one in killing of him.

Paroice ou parroisse, a parish: f.

Les Parroissiens, the Parishioners: m.

Parolles, see parler.

Paroir, je parois, je parus, j'ay pa­
ru, je paroistray, to shewe himselfe,
to appeare.

A donc le jour parut bel & clair,
 then the day appeared fayre and
bright.

Parorides, as Plusieurs homes de
Septentrion cognoissans leur im­
puissance, se chastrent en se cou­
pant les veines parorides soubs
les oreilles, certaine veines be­
hinde the eares, and vnder the 
burres or kernels of them.

Les Parques, the three Goddesses
of destinie: that is, Clotho, Lache­
sis, Atropos.

Paroy, a wall :f.

Paroy moitoyenne, a wall betwixt
two neighbours.

Parpaigne, the stay to vpholde, the
great beame in a wall: f.

Parquer, to parke or hedge in.

Vn Parquet ou sale d'audience, a 
hall or place of hearing: m.

Le dedant du parquet de la cour, the
precinct where the Iudges doe sit,
and counsaylors doe pleade.

Le barreau & parquet de la cour,
 the barre: m.

Parquoy, therefore, or through the
which cause.

Ie ne t'ay fait ne dict le parquoy tu
me doives faire ce que tu me fais,
 I haue not deserued this at thy
handes.

Parrins & marrines, god-fathers &
god-mothers.

Parsonnier, a partner: a Coparte­
ner: m.

Ilz sont Parsonniers ensemble, they
be coparteners together.

Part ou portion, a portion, a part: f.

Quelque part, somewhere, or some
part.

A Part, a side.

Parler à part avec quelcun, to speake





a side with one.

Faites cela à Par vous, do that secret­
ly with your owne selfe.

Partant de la maison, &c. departing
out of the house, &c.

Par tant, vpon this condition, also it
signifieth Therfore.

Partage, seeke Partir.

Vn Parterre, a peece of ground, a plat
of ground, a close: m.

Iardins bien cultivez et façonnez
en Par-terres, gardens well digged
and cast with fine beds.

Le Parterre se fend, the floore cha­
peth.

Vn party & condition, a parte and
condition, a match: m.

Il m'a fait vn mauvais parti, he
hath dealt with me wickedly.

Fille qui ne peut trouver parti, a
maiden which can finde no husband
or match.

Partisans, that is, ceux qui tiennent
mon parti, my partakers: m.

Home partial, a man with whome 
there is no communication, also a
partiall man.

Partialitez, brigues, & faveurs, fac­
tions, rebellion, partialitie: f.

Participant, taking part.

Ie vous feray participant de mon
gain, I will make you a partaker of 
my gaine.

Participant du fait, an accessarie to
the fact.

Participer, to take parte of both the
sides.

Propre & particulier, proper, peculi­
ar, or that is a mans owne.

Particulierement, particularly, speci­
ally.

Particulier en ses opinions, singular
be his opinions.

Particulariser, to shewe particular­
lye.

Sans rien particularizer, without
particularitie, generally.

La partie est bien faite, the match is 
very well made: f.

Gagner la partie, to win the set.

Partie, a part, a peece: f.

Partie adverse, an aduerse partie, or
one that laweth against another.

Dresser vne partie avec vn autre,
 when Marchants become parte­
ners.

Dresser ses parties, to make his ac­
compts.

Partir, je pars, je parti, j'ay parti, je
partiray, to parte, to deuide.

Il son partis en deuz, they are par­
ted into two.

Party en trois, deuided into three.

Partage, a deuiding or parting: m.

Partiment, a diuiding: m.

Partissement & division, a distri­
bution: m.

Se partir de quelque lieu, to departe
out of some place.

Parvenir au port, to arriue at the
hauen.

Parvenir à son attente, to attaine to
his expectation or desires.

Parvis, the porch of a Church: m.

Parure, decking, apparell: f.

Pas, for point, as Pas trop mal, not
very ill.

Vn Pas, a pace, a step: m.





A chasque pas, at euery step.

Pas à pas, foote by foote.

Large environ de cinquante pas
or passées, large or wide, about a
fiftie paces.

On luy a fermé le pas, they stop the 
way vnto him.

Pascage, as Iacob par l'espace de
vingt ans, fut commis sur les pas­
cages et les troupeaux de son be­
au pere, Iacob by the space of twen­
tie yeeres was set ouer the feeding
and flock of his father in law: m.

Se pasmer, to fall in a swoune.

Pasmoison, a swoning: f.

Lagneau pascal, the Passeouer: m.

Pasquerages, pasture or pastur ground
also all kinde of food growing in Fo­
rests to fatten swine, as acornes, &c.

Pasques, Easter.

Pasquette vne herbe, an herbe cal­
led Hony-suckle, also a womans
name: f.

Pasquis, lieu ou les bestes paissent, 
 pasture ground: m.

Passer & cheminer, to passe, to goe.

Passer devant, to goe or passe before.

Passer la mer, to passe the Sea,

Passer tout oultre, to passe ouer, or
thorow.

Passer vne liqueur par vn linge, ou
estamine, to straine any kinde of
liquour.

Oultre-passer, to extoll, to passe any
other.

Passer qvelque chose, laisser quel­
que chose à dire ou faire, to passe o­
uer, to leaue to speake of any thing.

Passer aucun, & estre plus excel­
lent, to passe any other, to excell.

Passer aucun en cheminant, to ouer­
goe any other.

Passer le temps, to passe the time.

Le jour est passé, the day is past.

Il se passe à peu de chose, hee is
content with a little.

Passé, passed by.

Passée, as l'année passée, the last
yeere.

Prendre des oyseaux & geays à la
passée, to take birdes and Iayes as
they passe by: f.

Passées du cerf, the brake or trace of 
the hart: f."brake" or "break": this sense not found in OED.

Vn passant qui passe son chemin, a
wayfaring man: m.

Passeur, a ferrie man, or he that ca­
rieth folke from hauen to hauen, a 
passenger: m.

Passement, a passing ouer: m.

Passable, a thing that may be passed
ouer, tollerable: com.

Passablement, tollerably, that may be
borne withall.

Passage, a passage, sometime a place.

Passage de l'escriture, a text or place
of the scripture: m.

Passager ce cours de nostre vie, that
is, passer, to passe the course of our
life.

Nef passagére, a ship to cary people
ouer: f.

Choses, passagéres, transitory things.

Passager, a sea man which passeth o­
uer men: m.

Faulcon passager, a Falcon passa­
ger: m."passager" antedates earliest OED citation (1917; but cf. "passage hawk" 1828-).

Faire vn passe-droict, to giue ouer





his right: m.

Passefillons, curled or broidered
haires: m.

Iouëur de passe passe, a Iugler: m.

Passefleurs, herbe, an herbe which
some take to be Rose parsly: f.

Passemens, comme robbes cou­
vertes de passemens, all kinde of 
pasment lace: m.

Vn Passementier, he which maketh
lace: m.

Vn Passe-par-tout, a man going
through all, whom nothing can let
but he passeth through.

Danseur de Passe-pieds, he that dan­
ceth on tiptoe, or capers: m.

Vn Passe-port, a pasport, a salfe­
conduite: m.

Passe-porte, a bill of discharge for
any marchandise: f.

Passe-rage, see Raphanelle.

Passereau, a Sparowe: m.

Passe temps, a pastime: m.

Passevelours, herbe, a flower, some
call it Flower gentle: m.

Passeur or Passageur, m: a carier, a
boate or ferrie-man.

Passion & accident d'esprit, a passion
or motion of the minde: f.

Passionné, out of his witte through
sorrow.

Se Passionner, to torment himselfe, 
also through ioy to be as it were out
of his wit.

Paste, paste or dowe: f.

Vn Pasté, a Pastie, a Pie: m.

Vn pasté de venaison, a pastie of Ve­
nison.

Vn pasté de poires, a peare-pye.

Vn Pastis, a pasture ground: m.

Livre ou escriture plein de Pastez, a 
booke or writing full of blinde blots.

Vn Pasté en pot, chopped meate with
spices made with potage or broth, a
gallimaufrie, an hotch-pot, a minced
pie made in a pot.

Vn Pastissier, a pie-baker: m.

Pastisserie, all kinde of bakemeate, as
apportez nous la Patisserie, bring
vs the bakemeat: f.

Il besogne fort bien en toute sorte
de Patisserie, he worketh very well 
in all kinde of bake meat.

Allez voir qui est en la Patisserie,
 goe & see who is in the pastrie: f.

Pastel de Languedoc, woade of lan­
gouedocke: m.

Des Pastenades, parseneps, or carot
rootes: f.

Pasture & nourriture, qu'on baille
aux bestes, fodder that is giuen to
beastes: f.

Pasturer, to feede, to fodder.

Pasturage, pasture ground: m.

Pasture & nourriture, qu'on baille
aux bestes, fodder that is giuen to
beastes: f.

Pasturer, to feede, to fodder.

Pasturage, pasture ground: m.

Pasteur, pastre, or pastoreau, a shep­
heard, a pastor, he that hath the

Pastorat, belonging to a pastor: m.

Vie pastorale, a shepheards, or pastors
life: f.

Pate, seeke Patte.

Pateliner, to flatter.

Voyez comment il Pateline ce­
ste fame, marke I pray you how 
he entertaineth and flattereth that
woman.





Patene, or patine, the patine couering
the chalice of massing Priests: f.

Patent, euident, plaine.

Lettres patentes du roy, the kings

Dire la patenostre à l'envers, to

Vn patenostrier, a bead-maker: m.

Paternel, of the father, fatherly.

Paticier, a baker: m.

Patient, pacient, diseased.

Patience, patience, abiding: f.

Patienter, to stay with patience.

Ouïr Patiemment, to beare pati­
ently.

Porter patiemment, to beare pati­
ently, to suffer willingly, to abide
constantly.

Le Patin ou patte d'vne colonne, the
foote of a piller: m.

Des patins, a manner of shooes: m.

Patir, je patis, je pati, j'ay pati, je pa­
tiray, to suffer.

Tu en patiras, thou shalt pay, suffer
for it.

Patois, as Il parle son patois, he spea­
keth his gibrish: m.

Patrie, the countrie: f.

Il a trahi sa patrie, he hath betraied
his country.

Il est mon Patriote, hee is my country
man: m.

Vn Patriarche, a Patriarke: m.

Patriarchie, the dignitie of the Pa­
triarke: f.

Patrimoine, patrimonie, or that fal­
leth to one on his fathers side: m.

Le Patron de quelque chose, a pa­
terne, or example of any thing: m.

Vn patron de naviére, the patron of

Le Patron d'innocence, an example of innocencie.

Patron, a defender, a protector.

Droict de patronnage, the right of
presentation of a benefice: m.

Patronner quelque chose, to paterne
out a thing.

Vne patrouille, an ouen rake, or ouen
sweeper, a makron: see Fourgon.

Patrouiller, to beray, to smeare.

Tout patrouillé, all besmeered.

Patrouilleur, a carper at euery mans
worke: m.

Patte de beste, a beastes paw: f.

Coulon, or pigeon pattu, featherfoo­
ted doues or pigeons, rough footed
with feathers: m.

Paturon de cheval, the shankemaine
of a horse: m.

Les chevaux estoyent au sang jus­
ques aux paturons, the horses were
in blood ouer the hoofe.

Vn Pau, m: a stake.

Paucher, paulcer, but commonly
Pocher les yeux, to put out ones
eyes.

Paucité, scarsenes, fewnesse.

Le Pavé d'vne place, the pauement
of any place: m.

Paver, to paue with stone.

Pavement, a pauing: m.

Vn Pavillon & tente, a pauillion, a
tent: m.

Pavigeade, see Pavisade, in pavois.

Paulmelle, a kinde of barly: f.





La mesure d'vne Paulme, a hande
breadth: f.

La Paulme de la main, the palme of
the hand.

Le jeu de la paume, the Tennise
play: f.

Paumeure, f: the hornes of a Hart.

Les paupiéres des yeux, the eye lids:
fem.

Vn Pavois, a buckler: m.

La pavoisade, pavesade, or pavigea­
de d'vne galere, the defence of the
Galley to couer the slaues or rowers
from the shot: f.

Vn pavois en façon de croissant, a
shield: f.

Du pavot, an hearbe called Poppie:
masc.

Pautonnier, a knaue: m.

Pautonnerie, knauerie: f.

Payer, to pay.

Payement, a paying: m.

Les mortes payes, dead payes: f.

Payen, a heathen: m.

Payenneté, or payennie, Heathen­
nish: f.
