Vn Peagier, a toll gatherer: m.

Peau, a skinne: f.

Peau de parchemin, a skinne of 
parchement.

Il n'a que la peau & les os, hee hath
but the skinne and bones.

A qui la peau tient aux costes, hyde­
bound or clung.

Peaucier, a skinner: m.

Peautre, the sterne of a ship: f.

Peché, sinne: m.

Peché mortel, a deadly sinne.

Peché veniel, a veniall sinne, a light
sinne.

Pecher, to sinne.

Pecheur, a sinner: m.

Pecheresse, a woman sinner: f.

Pécore, a sheepe: f.

Et va va, grosse pécore, goe thy way
dolt.

Péculier & propre, peculliar, a mans
owne.

Pécune, money: f.

Home pécunieux, a well-monyed
man.

Amande Pécuniaire, a fine.

Iuges pedanées, Iudges inferiours,
as villages and countrie.

Vn pegnerre, pignard, or peignar­
re, a Comb-maker: m.

Vn peigne, a combe: m.

Peigné, combed.

Peigner, to combe.

Iuges Pédanées, inferiour Iudges.

Pedagogue, an instructer: m.

Pedagogie, the office of an instruc­
ter or teacher: f.

Vn pedante, one that hath the ouer­
sight of children, and doth conduct 
them to schoole: m.

Pédiculaire, maladie pédiculaire, the
lousie sicknesse, full of lice: com.

Pegase, or cheval volant, a flying 
horse, hauing wings: m.

Pege, pitch: f.

Peindre, to paint, to set forth in co­
lours: je peins, je pein, j'ay peint,
je peindray.

Peinct, painted.

Peintre, a painter: m.

Peincture en tapis ou broderie, such





pictures as be in tapistrie or em­
brodering: f.

Peincturer, to paint.

Mettre peine, to take paine in a
thing.

Peine perduë, lost labour: f.

A peine que je die, scantly can I
say.

A peine peut-il parler, scantly can
he speake.

Sur peine de la hart, vpon paine of
the rope.

Perdre sa peine, to loose labour, to la­
bour in vaine.

Peiner, or pener, to enforce to doe a
thing, seeke Mettre peine.

Chose penible, a painfull thing, a la­
boursome worke: com.

Home penible, a painfull man.

Loy penale, a law of penaltie: f.

La Pelade, f: the falling of the haire.

Pel, or peau, a skinne: f.

Pelasse, the piles, the barke of a tree:
fem.

Pelanide, a fish called Tuny: f.

Pelauder, to handle one sore either in
words or deedes: to hoyse one.

Peler, to pill, to pull off the haire, to
scald.

Pelé, pield, or bald.

Pelerin, a stranger or pilgrime: m.

Pelerinage, ou Peregrination, a pil­
grimage: f.

Pelure de quelque fruict, the pill or
skinne of any fruit: f.

Vn Pelican, a bird called a Pellican:
masc.

Pelle, seeke Paelle.

Pelletier, a Skinner: m.

Pelote à jouër, a ball for to play with:
fem.

Peloter, to play at ball.

Peloton, a bottome of threed, seeke
Ploton: m.

Pelu, ou velu, hairie, or full of small
haire.

Il a les mains peluës, he hath haired
hands, that is scratching.

Penancier, he that appointeth a pe­
nance or penaltie to those that haue
sinned: m.

Pencher, seeke Pancher.

Pendre & estrangler, to hang and 
strangle: je pens, je pendi, j'ay
pendu, je pendray.

Pendant cela, in that meane while.

Pendant de clefs, a pendant or thing
that hangeth: a key clogge: m.

Cas pendable, hanging matters, wor­
thie of hanging: com.

Estre pendu, to be hanged.

Pendement au gibet, hanging on
the gibbet, or gallowes: m.

Vn pendereau, or pendart, a crack­
rope, a gallowclapper: m."gallowclapper" not found in OED (but see under "crack-rope," n. in 1708).



Penderie, a hanging: f.

Pendant que j'iray & viendray, whi­
lest I goe and come.

Ce-pendant que nous disnerons,
vous ferez cela, whilest wee bee at
dinner, you shall doe that.

Nous vous constituons governeur
en ces quartiers, Ce-pendant nous
n'entendons pas que vous vsiez 
de cruaulté, wee doe appoynt you,
&c. yet for all that we do not meane
that you, &c.

Pendiller, to hang.





Pendillant, hanging as it were by the 
halfe.

Les Pendans d'vne bourse, the strings
of a purse: m.

Pendras, meschans, meurtriers, dig­
nes de mort, ou de quelque autre
griéve punition, that haue deser­
ued hanging: m.

La Pente d'vne montagne, the side
of a mountaine: f: the steepe place
of a rocke.

Les Pentes d'vn lict, the side of a 
bed: m.

Penencier, or Penitencier, he that
appoynteth a punishment for offen­
ces committed towards God appoin­
ted by the Pope in Churches at 
Rome, as in Santa Maria majore,
and others: m.

Pener, penible, see Peine.

Penetrer, entrer bien avant, to pierce
in, to enter deepe in.

Penetratif, piercing: m.

Peneux & piteux, out of hart, out of
courage: dismayed.

Penil d'homme, ou de femme, la
motte, the noddle of a man or wo­
man: m.

L'os Penillier, the sharbone.

Peninsule, a house in a towne that
one may goe about as an Iland: f.

Penitence, as demander penitence
à son confesseur, to aske his ghostly
father a penance: f.

Faire penitence, to punish himself for
his sinne committed.

Iune enjoint par penitence, a fast­
ing appointed for a satisfaction or
punishment for his sinnes, as is vsed 
among Papists.

Pennache, or plumas, fethers vsed
in hats, caps, or helmets of men of
armes: m.

Pennage, be the fethers of a Hawke,
so we say, Oiseau de beau penna­
ge, a hawke with haire coloured fe­
thers: m.

Pennage blond, rous, noir, haglé,
fleuri, chevané, these be the colours
of Hawkes: to call the fethers par­
ticularly, we say, Pennes longues,
the long one, Pennes menuës, the
meane ones, between the downe and 
great long fethers.

Penne, or Pennache, as aboue in
Pennache.

Penne, or aisleron, the fethers of an
arrow or bolt: as vn traict, empen­
né, a bolt with fethers.

Pennon, the standard of a Gentle­
man vnder a Baron, which hath a
long taile, and the same of a Baron
is without taile, called Banniére, a
banner: m.

Penser, to thinke, to imagine.

A quoy pensez vous, quand vous
ne pensez en rien, whereon doe you
thinke, when you thinke on no­
thing?

Pensée, a thought: f: also a flower
called Harts ease, or pensiue."pensive" in the OED is not a name for a herb.

Pensement, idem.

Pensif, a man full of heauinesse: pen­
siuenesse.

Elle est toute pensive, she is pensiue,
full of thought; or heauinesse.

Pensant & repansant sur cest af­
faire, je ne sçay que j'en doy dire, 





thinking, and thinking agayne on
this matter, I cannot tell what to 
say to it.

Penser vn cheval, vne playe, to dresse
a horse, a wounde.

Penseur, m: one that thinketh.

Penseresse, or penseuse, f: a woman
thinking or imagining.

Pension, a pension: f.

Pension annuëlle, a yearely pension.

Pensionnaire, Pensioners, also bour­
ders: m.

Prendre des enfans en pension, to
take bourders.

Pente, seek Pendre.

Penteur, the name of a rope passing o­
uer the top of a mast: m.

Penurie, or indigence, lacke, penu­
rie: f.

La pepie, the pip as hennes and chic­
kens haue: f.

Pepins, kernels or seede: m.

Pepinerie, a Nurserie in an Or­
chard where they doe sowe ker­
nels: f.

Les pepins des raisins, the stone or
kernell of the grape: m.

Pepon, seeke Pompon.

Per ou non per, vne sorte de jeu,
 paire or not paire, a play called euen
or odde: m.

Le sans per en bonté, en beauté, en
vertu, the peerelesse in goodnesse,
in beautie, in vertue.

Per de France, seeke Pers.

Per à compaignon, a peere, one like,
or fellow.

Il entend bien son per, or pair, he
vnderstandeth well the value of
the money by exchaunge from one 
towne or place to another: it is spo­
ken of a wise man, and well accoun­
ted in matters & affaires of a com­
mon weale or state.

Percer, to pierce, to thrust thorowe: to
gore.

Percé tout oultre, thrust thorow: go­
red or sticked thorow.

Percher ou jucher sur vn arbre, to
pearch as Foules do on trees.

Percement, a percing, a thrusting
thorow: m.

Perc'oreille, such blackish wormes 
as be found in Apples, or in Fil­
berds: m.

Perce-fueille, herbe: f.

Perce-pierre, seeke Persepierre.

Vn perche, a pearch, a long poll
or rodde: f: also the hornes of a 
Hart.

Vn poisson qu'on appelle perche, a
fish called a Pearch: f.

Percher, when a Faulcon doth sit vp­
on a branch or poll.

Perclus de ses membres, hee that
hath not the vse of his members, or 
as we say he is taken.

Perclusions, as il a acquis en la
guerre des maladies, des gou­
tes, & des perclusions pour l'­
advenir: hee hath gotten at the
warres sicknesses, gowtes, and to
be taken of his members in time
to come.

Perdre, je pers, je perdi, j'ay per­
du, je perdray, to loose, or for­
goe.

Perdu, lost, forgone, cast away.





Perdition, loosing, forgoing: f.

Perte, f: losse, dammage, or detri­
ment.

Vne perdris, or perdrix, f: a Par­
tridge.

Perdrix griesche, or becasse, a wood­
cocke.

Pérdreau, a young Partridge: m.

Perdurable, euerlasting, ayduring.

Perdurablement, euerlastingly.

Pere, a father: m.

Pere grand, a grandfather.

Peré, breuvage faict de poires,
 Perry, a drinke made of the iuyce
of Peares: m.

Peregrin, rather Pelerin, a Pilgrim,
a stranger: m.

Peregriner, to goe a voyage, to goe on
pilgrimage.

Peregrination, a pilgrimage: f.

Peremption dinstance, an olde mat­
ter or suite in the lawe, left for a 
long time or season.

Defence perentoire, a sufficient de­
fence: f.

Respondre Perentoirement, to
answere presently without further
delay.

Lappel à vigueur & force devant la
peremption on desertion, the ap­
pellation is in force before the day
appointed be past, before it bee let 
fall.

Perennel, eternall.

Perenniser, to make euerlasting.

Perfection, f: perfection.

Perfectioner, to make perfect.

Biens perissables, goods subiect to
perill, com.

Perilleusement, with perill.

Vne perle, a pearle: f.

Perlette, a little or small perle.

La perle des advocats, the perle of
Counsaylours or Lawyers.

Permanable, or permanent, during
for euer, com.

Perfums, perfumes, sweete smelles: 
masc.

Perfumer, to perfume.

Perfumé, perfumed.

Perfumement, a perfuming: m.

Perfumeur, a perfumer: m.

Peril, perill, daunger.

Perilleux, perillous, dangerous.

Perir & estre gasté, to perish, to bee
marred: je peris, je peri, je suy pe­
ri, je periray.

Permettre, to permitte, or to suffer:
see mettre to decline it.

Permis, permitted, suffered.

Il est permis, it is permitted, it is
lycensed.

Chose permise, a thing permit­
ted.

Permission & congé, permission or
leaue: f.

Permuter, to exchange.

Permutation, f: exchange.

Pernicieux dommageable, hurtful,
pernicious.

Pernicieusement, perniciously, hurt­
fully.

Perpendiculaire, directly, downe
right, which is straight downe by a 
line: com.

Perpendiculairement, strayghtlie
downe.

Pierre de pernis, or pierre de quoy





lon fait les Perpins es murailles,
 stones that are putte thorough a 
wall for the strength of it, or to
beare the burthen.

Perpetrer vn meurtre, to commit a
murther.

Perpetuel, perpetuall, for euer.

Perpetuer, to leaue to perpetuall me­
morie.

Perpetuité, euerlastingnesse, perpetui­
tie: f.

Perpetuellement, euerlastingly, per­
petually.

Perplex & doubteux, in a doubt.

Perplexité, perplexitie, doubtful­
nesse: f.

Perquisition, an inquirie, a search: f.

Vn perron, a monument erected for
a remembrance: m.

Vn perroquet, a Parrat: m.

Vne pertuque ou chevelure, the
tresses, long hayre.

Vne fausse perruque, Periwin­
cle.

Perruquet, one that doth frisell his
haires: m.

Perruquier, hee that maketh Peri­
wincles: m.

Perruquiere, f: a woman making the
like.

Pers, ou Couleur perse, m: Skie co­
lour.

Les Pers de France, the Peeres of
France: m.

Il a esté fait per de France, he hath
been made Peere of France.

Tenir en perrie, to holde a Lordship
after the sorte of a Peere: f.

Persceuter, to vex, to afflict, persecute.

Persecuteur, a persecuter: m.

Persepierre, herbe, f: an hearb cal­
led Sampier.

Perser, seeke Percer.

Perseverer, to perseuere, to conti­
nue.

Perseverant en son propos, perseue­
ring in his tale, in his opinion.

Perseveramment, stoutely, constant­
lye.

Perseverance, perseuerance, paci­
ence, continuance: f.

Persevéremment, constantly.

Persil, m: an hearbe that is called 
Persely.

Persil bastard, bastard Persely.

Persister, to persist, to continue.

Persister tous-jours en son opinion,
 to persist in his opinion.

Grand ou excellent personnage,
 an excellent personage, or highe e­
state: m.

Personnage d'vne farce, a personage
in a play.

Personat, an office in the clergie: 
masc.

Personnellement, personally or bo­
dylie.

Adjournement personnel, when one
is summoned to appeare personally.

La personne d'vn chacun, f: euery
person.

Perspective, f: the Arte of perspe­
ctiue.

Perspicuité, cleerenesse in speech: f.

Persuader, to perswade.

Perolles persuasibles, wordes fitte to
perswade, com.

Persuasif, m: a perswading thing.





Sentence persuasive, f: a sentence
full of perswasion.

Persuadeur, m: a perswader, a coun­
saylor, an inducer.

Persuasible, easie to be perswaded, com.

Persuasoire, com: that induceth or
perswadeth.

Parler persuasiblement, to speake in
such a sorte that one may perswade
or induce.

Perte, f: a lost: see Perdre.

Pertinent, Ce que tu dis n'est point
pertinent, belonging, that which
thou speakest belongeth not to the 
matter.

Pertinemment, to the purpose, fit­
lye.

Vn Pertuis, a hole: m.

Pertuisane, f: a staffe called a Perti­
sane.

Perturber aucun, to trouble one, to
disturbe.

Perturbation d'esprit, troublous af­
fections of the minde: f.

Perturbateur du repos public, a dis­
quieter of ones ease and rest: m.

Pervenche, herbe, an hearbe called
Periwincle: f.

Pervers, ouerthwart, peruerse.

Pervertir, je pervirtis, je perverti,
j'ay perverti, je pervertiray, to
peruerte.

Perversité, f: ouerthwartnesse, per­
uersitie.

Perversement interpreté, peruersly
expounded.

Pescher, to fish.

Pescheur, a fisher: m.

La pesche, the draught of the net: f.

Pescherie, a fishing, also a little ponde 
to keepe fish: f.

Peschement, fishing: m.

Vne Pesche, f: a fruite that is called 
a Peach.

Peschier, a Peach tree: m.

Pesche-noix, a Peach stone: f.

Peser, pesant, pesanteur, pesé, peson: 
 seeke poix.

Pesle mesle, confusément, all on a 
heape, one with an other, confused­
ly, mingle mangle.

Vn pessaire, a kinde of suppositories
to prouoke a womans flowers: m.

La peste, the pestilence, that which
we call the plague.

Pestifere, qui a la peste, pestilent in­
fected with the plague, or causing
the plague.

Lieu pestiferé, pestiferous place: m.

Pestilentieux, plaguie.

Pestilenciel, idem.

Pestrir la paste, to kneade dough: 
je pestris, je pestri, j'ay pestri, je
pestriray.

Pestrisseur, a kneader, a baker: m.

Pestrissement, m: kneading.

Vn pet, a fart, a scape: m.

Peter, to fart, to let a scape.

Petarasse, or patarasse, a striking
vpon ones buttockes: also when a 
lusty horse leapeth and farteth alto­
gether: f.

Petiller, to stampe, to trample: to
quake.

Petiller de despit, to stampe for spite
or anger.

Petiller soubs les pieds, to tread vn­
der the feete.





Petillement, m: stamping, quaking
or trembling, treading vnder the
feete.

Feu petillant, when the fire sparkleth,
sparkling: m.

Petit, small, little: m.

Le plus petit, the least.

La plus Petite de toutes les fa­
mes, the lesse or smallest of all wo­
men.

Les petits de quelque beste que ce
soit, the little or young ones of any
beast.

Petit à petit, by little and little, faire
and softly.

Petiteur, smalnesse, littlenesse: f.

Petitesse, idem.

Petitement, scantly, smally.

Petition, ou demande, a request, a
petition: f.

Petitoire, com: clayming, belong­
ing to a request, clayme, or peti­
tion.

Action Petitoire, an action, or suite
concerning tytle or right.

Peton, seeke Pied.

Petonde, petoucle, petoncle, or han­
nons, m: fish, flounders, flookes,
see Hannons.

Petrarquiser, to be in loue like Pe­
trarke.

Petrir, petrisseur, seeke Pestrir.

Petteler & fouler aux pieds, to tram­
ple, to stampe with ones feete.

Peteliz, or peteslement, stamping
vnder the feete: m.

Peu, very little, scant any, small.

Peu s'en fault, ou à peu pres, scarce 
enough, almost.

Peu, agrave; peu, by little and little.

Peult, as il peult, he may or can.

Pevoesne, herbe, an hearbe called,
our Lady-rose.Not found in OED; refers probably a peony.

Peuplade, a people sent from one place
to another to dwell: f.

Vn peuple & nation, a people and
nation.

Le menu Peuple d'vne ville, the
Commons of a Towne or of a City.

Se Peupler, to increase with peo­
ple.

Ville fort peuplée, a populous towne
or Citie.

Peupler vne Cité, to inhabit a towne,
to furnish it with people.

Peuplement de vigne, an increase
of vines.

Populace, the rascall people: f.

Populaire, the common people: m.

Home fort Populaire, a man addi­
cted to the common people, fauou­
ring the commons.

Peuplier, arbre, a poplar tree: m.

Peur, ou paour, feare, terrour: f.

Faire peur, to feare, to be afrayd, to
fright.

Poureux, fearefull, timerous.

Fille fort Poureuse, a fearefull may­
den.

Poureusement, fearefully, time­
rously.

Phagedaine, a cankred wound: m.

Phalange, a kinde of venemous spi­
der or like, a little Neute, which
the Italians do call, Tarantola: f.

Phalerer, to paynte, to couer with a 
maske.

Phantasie, phantasie, imagination: f.





A la Pharisienne, after the fashion of
an hypocrite: f.

Phasiole, espece de pois, a kinde of
pease, an herbe: f.

Philacteres, philacteries, as if one
should say a garder or keeper, a litle
scroll wherein the ten commaunde­
ments were written & caried a­
bout the Iewes garments: m.

Philomesses, the louers of the masse.

Philosophe, a louer of wisedome, a 
Philosopher: m.

Vn Phillippus, a piece of golde so
called: m.

Estudier en Philosophie, to studie
Philosophie: f.

Philtre, amorous potions making men
mad for loue: m.

Phiole, a viole, a small glasse: f.

Phlébotomie, letting of bloud: f.

Phlebotomer, to let bloud.

Phlegme, fleume: f.

Phlegmatique, flegmatike.

Vn petit Phlegmon, m: a warte in
the vpper lid of the eye like a barly
corne.

Vn phlegmon, m: an apostum of
blood enflamed.

Physicion, a Phisicion, a natural phi­
losopher: m.

Philacte, a goaler: m.

Picmart or pimart, see Pic, because
it is all one name.

Pic nom d'oyseau, pivert, a bird cal­
led a Speicht or Hicwaw, also a mat­
tocke, a pickaxe: m.

Picotin, a pecke: m.

Vne Picque, seeke Pique.

Vne Pie, a bird called a Pie: f.

Vn Cheval Pie, a Horse blacke 
and white, after the similitude of a 
Pie: m.

Croque la pie, a name which we giue
to a good drinker : as also we say by
him, c'est vn bon pion, c'est vn Pi­
ailleur, he is a gossip pintepot, & Pi­
ailler, to drinke at large: m.

Pieça, a good while agoe.

Cela se faisoit piéça, that was done in
time past.

Vne piéce de toile, de veloux, de sa­
tin, de drap, &c. a peece of linnen,
veluet, satin of cloth, &c.

En piéces & morceaux, ou par par­
ties, in peeces, morcels, or partes.

Il y a longue piéce, it is a good while
since.

La haute piéce, the shoulder peece of
an harneis.

Piecette, f: a little peece.

Le pied, the foote: m.

A pied coy, with soft foote, with soft
pace.

Le petit pied, a measure which car­
penters and masons doe vse.

Edifice fait au pied, a house builded
with measure and compasse.

Perdre le pied, when a fighter doth
slide or fall.

Perdre pied, when in passing the fourd
one looseth ground.

Gagner au pied, to run away.

Prendre au pied levé, to snappe one
in wordes, to take him at aduaun­
tage.

Le pied de la montaigne, the foot or
bottome of a hill.

Pied de milan, herbe, an herbe cal­





led Kites foote.

Hausser ou rabaisser la valeur & pi­
ed de la monnoye, to rise or bring
lowe the valewe of the coyne or mon­
ney.

Pied rond, all kinde of beasts hauing
a round foote or hoofe.

Pied forchu or forché, a beast hauing
a clouen foote.

Piedstal d'vne colomne, the foote of
a piller, a piestall.

Vn peton, a little foote: m.

Vn pieton, a footeman: m.

C'est vn pied viste, a swifte footed
man.

Vn piége, a snare or grin, a pitfall: m.

Vne pierre, a stone: f.

Pierre précieuse, a precious stone.

La pierre, ou gravelle, maladie, the
disease of the stone: f.

La pierre est eschappée, when the
stone is cast, a prouerbe, for it is pas­
sed recouerie.

Pierrette, or pierrote, a small stone: f.

Pierreux, stony, rockie.

Il est bien piétre le bon home, the
good man is very poore.

Pietrement, poorely.

Pietrer, to trample vnder foot, to tread
downe.

Vn pieu, a stake or poste: m.

Pigeon ou coulon, a pigeon, a doue:
masc.

Pigeon ramier, a stocke doue: m.

pigeonneau, a young doue or Pige­
on: m.

Pigeonnier, or colombier, a doue
house: m.

Pignolat, see Pin.

Vne pile, pelote, ou esteuf, à jouër,
 a ball to play with: f.

Vne pile de draps, de toile, a pile of
cloth.

Ie n'ay croix ne pile, I haue nor crosse
nor pile, I am monilesse.

Piler, to pile, to beat.

Vn pilon, a pestle :m.

Piler en vn mortier, to stampe in a 
morter.

Pilement, m: a stamping.

Pileur, a stamper: m.

Vn pillier, a piller or collumne: m.

Gaster & piler tout & faire degast,
 to waste, spill, and spoyle all.

Pilleur, a piller, a poller, a spoyler: m.

Pillage, praye or pillage: m.

Pillars, filchers, pilferers, rouers: m.

Pillerie & ravissement, pilling or ra­
pine: f.

Pillement, a pilling, or polling: m.

Le pilori, a pillorie: m.

Pilorié & fléutri, that hath beene on
the pillorie and burned in the eare
or band.

Piloriement & fleutremen, standing
at the Pillorie and burning: m.

Mis et tourné au pilori, or els, qui 
a fait la mouë aux harengieres, set
at the pillorie.

Pilot & patron d'vne navire, a Pilot
or guider of a Ship: m.

Piloter quelcun, to robbe and spoyle
one.

Pilotis, a pyling with timber in water
workes.

Pilules pillules, or as we call them pilles.

Pimpernelle, an herbe called Pim­
pernell: f.





Vn Pin, a Pine tree: m.

Vne Pinasse, f: an other kinde of
Pine tree.

Vn Pinier, m: trees bearing apples, as
cypres.

Du piniolat, or pignolat, the kir­
nell of a Pine apple that is preser­
ued: m.

Vn pinacle, a steeple: m.

Vn pinceau, a pensill: m.

Vn pinse-maille, qui n'a esgard
que à amaisser argent, a pinch­
peny: m.

Pinces, or pinsettes, pinsers: f.

Pinser, to pinch.

Des pinsettes, pinsers: f.

L'argent des princes est subject à la
pince, Princes money is subiect to
the nippe, that is, to polling or rob­
bing: f.

Pinceter, to pinch thicke, to play swift
and fine vpon a lute.OED does not record a sense of "pinch" that specifically applies to lute-playing.

le printens d'yver, et pincetant sur
les chanterelles de son luth obeï­
ssant, &c. playing vpon the singing
cords of her obedient Lute, &c.

Pindarizer, to speake finely, or cu­
riously.

Pinson, a bird, a Spinke: m.

Pinte de vin, a pinte of wine: f.

Piocher, to digge.

Piocheur, a digger: m.

Vne pioche, a spade, a pickaxe: f.

Pioler or gazouiller, to chirpe like a
Sparow.

Piolement, or gazouillis, chir­
ping: m.

Piole Riole, diuers in colours, seeke
Riolé.

Pionnier, a Pioner, a digger in
warres: m.

Vne pippe, a little pipe which the
bird catchers doe vse in taking of 
birds, also a certaine vessell of wine
and corne: f.

Piper, to beguile one, to deceiue one, to
cog at dice or cardes.

Pipeur, a deceiuer, a beguiler, a cog­
ger: m.

Pippée, is a worde counterfaited of
birds pieping or chirping, as also Pi­
pe, Pipeur, & Pipper, and signifieth
the voice which a bird catcher doth
vse, either with a leafe, his knife,
or reede, or any other like thing, to 
haue the birdes to resorte to the
bushe where he is hidden with his
twigs of birdlime: So we say Pren­
dre les oyseaux à la pipée, to catch
birdes after that sort: f

Pipée, is taken for a countenance or
counterfaited behauiour, as Il fait
la bonne pipée, he sheweth a dissem
bling face or countenance.

Pipée, is a Participle of the Passiue
signification: as Elle a esté pipée,
she was caught craftily, deceitfully.
I'ay esté pipé, I haue beene cogged
with, that is, I haue beene deceiued
by craft.

Piperie,  the arte of cogging: f.

La pipette & petite queuë de laine 
qui est au sommet d'vn bonnet,
 the knop on a mans cap: f.

Pique ou javeline, a pike or iaue­
line: f.

Avoir pique or rancune contre au­
cun to beare rancor against one.





Piquer & ficher, to fasten a thing to
the ground.

Piquer, to pricke, to launce, to spurre,
sometime to quilt, to sting.

Piquer aucun de parolles, to nip one
in words.

Le Piquant d'vn fer, the pointe or
pricke of any iron.

Piqueure, sting, pricking: f.

Picoter, to peckle, to pricke thicke, to
specke.

Picoter & tacheter de diverses
couleurs, to spotte with diuers co­
lours.

Picoté, tacheté, spotted, speckeled.

Picoteure de bran de judas, red
pimples rising in the face.

Vne Piramide, a pillar made after the 
fashion of a Pyramide, that is foure
square and sharpe towards the top:
fem.

Figure Piramidale, a forme or figure
after the fashion of the hart: f.

Pirate, ou larron & escumeur de
mer, a Sea theefe, a Pirate: m.

Art Piratique, the arte and trade of
a Rouer.

Pire, worse.

Il n'est pas des pires, he is not of the
worst.

Pirouëtte, a whirle gigge: f.

Pirouëtter, to turne about swiftlye, to
turne round like a whirle gigge.

Vn Pirou, a greene goose in the coun­
try of Poitiers: m.

Pis, sometime is the dugge of a cow,
goate or sheepe, now the cod of a dog:
and most often an aduerbe, then it
signifieth worst: as Ou pis, ou mi­
eux, or worst, or better.

Au Pis aller, or els Au fort, at the 
worst.

La chose ne sçauroit pis aller, qu'el­
le va, the matter cannot goe worst
then it goeth now.

Vn Pis de bœuf, the brisket of beefe: 
masc.

Piscine, a poole or pond to water hor­
ses, keepe geese or duckes: f.

Pirouëtter, to turne round, or to goe
about like a whirle gigge.

Pisser, to pisse.

Pisse en lict, a kinde of herbe: m.

Pissat, pisse, vrine, stale: m.

Pistolet, or Pistole, a dagge, also a 
peece of golde, m: a pistole: f.

Pistolier, a man of warre vsing
dagges: m.

Pitance, Toute viande oultre le pa­
in & le vin, all meate besides bread
and drinke, a pittance: f.

Pitault, a clowne: m.

Vne Pite, a kinde of money vnder a
halfe farthing: f.

Pitié & compassion qu'on a de la
misere d'aucun, pitie and compas­
sion: f.

Chose pitoyable à voir, a pitifull
thing to beholde: com.

Piteux, one that is to bee pitied, a
wretch.

Faire le piteux, to make a shew to bee
in a poore estate, to counterfaite the
poore and miserable: m.

Piverd, oyseau, a bird called a spiecht,
masc.Not found in OED.

Pivoine, a planet, also a birde, it is
also called Pevoisne: f.





Piuler, to doe after the crye of little
chickens following the henne.

Le Pivot d'vn huis, ou porte, the
hinges of a dore: m.

Le Pivot, support & appuy d'vne
race, the stay of a kinred, familie
or race.

Pivotter vn huis, to set hinges on a 
dore.

Placars, seeke Plaquars.

Vne grande place sans maisons, a
great place: f.

Vne place où le peuple s'assemble, 
place where the people doe meete.

Vne forte place, a Fortresse.

Faire place, to make roome, to giue
place.

Mettre aucun en sa place pour faire
son office, to put another in his
stead or place to execute his office.

Ie vous quitte ma place, I giue you
my roome, my office or authori­
tie.

Se placer en lieu convenable, to
take his roume in a fit place.

Vn placet, a bill of remembrance to
an Officer from the Prince, a bill of
processe: also a request: m.

Plage, a compasse vpon the sea side,
hauing no hauen: f.

Plaid, debat, question & procez, 
 pleading, strife, debate: m.

Plaider, to pleade, to declare the mat­
ter.

Plaider, avoir proces, to goe to the
Law.

Vn Plaideur, a pleader of the Law, a
Lawyer: m.

Cest vn fin & ruzé plaideur, hee is
a craftie Lawyer.

Plaidereau, a contentious fellowe, one
that will goe to Lawe for euery
thing: m.

Vn pladoyé, ou playdoyer, a plea or
Oration made to the Iudges: m.

Plaidoiries, idem.

Vn Playdoyeur criard, a pratling
Lawyer, an importunate prater: m.

Iours plaidoyables, court daies.

Iours non plaidoyables, daies when
it is not lawfull to pleade, when it is 
not court day.

Plaie, a wound, see Playe.

Plain & vni, plaine, smooth, euen.

Vne plaine, a plaine field or leuell
ground: f.

Vne Plaine de grande estendue, a 
great and wide plaine.

Plaindre, je me plainds, je me plai­
ny, je me suy plaint, je me plain­
dray, ou complaindre, to plaine or
complaine.

Chose à complaindre, a thing of
complaint.

Qui plaind sa peine, he that grud­
geth his paine.

Il plaint ce qu'il boit & mange, a
Miser which grudgeth at his owne
meate and drinke.

Plainte, ou Complainte, a com­
plaint: f.

Il a esté grandement plaint, he was
greatly sorrowed after: they did
moane for him greatly.

Plainte, ou plaintif, a plaintife or ac­
cuser.

Plaintives douleurs, moanefull do­
lours.





Entens, Seigneur ma voix Plain­
tive, O Lord heare my moanefull
voyce.

Plaire, je plais, je pleu, j'ay pleu, je 
plairay, to please.

Il se plait fort, he taketh a great pride
in himselfe.

A Dieu ne plaise que cela advien­
ne, God forbid this should happen.

Il a ainsi Pleu à Dieu, so it pleased
God: such was the will of God.

Plaisant homme, a pleasant or mery
fellow.

Mal-plaisant, is the contrary.

Plaisance, pleasure, delite: f.

Plaisanter, to iest, to scoffe.

Plaisanteur, a iester, a scoffer: m.

Vn Plaisantin, idem.

Il est Plaisant, he is a pleasant fellow,
a iester, a bourder.

Plaisanterie, iests, scoffes: f.

Plaisamment, pleasantly, merily, io­
cundly.

Plaisir mondain & charnel, worldlie
pleasure or lust.

Plaisir qu'on prend à quelque cho­
se, pleasure or delight.

Plaisir desordonné, disordinate plea­
sure.

Plaisir & service qu'on a faict, the
pleasure and seruice that one hath
done.

Plaisir qu'on faict les vns aux autres,
 the pleasure which one doth to 
another.

Avoir plaisir & esbat, to haue plea­
sure, ioy, or sport.

Au plaisir de Dieu, and it please 
God.

Faire plaisir à aucun, to doe one a
pleasure, to doe one a good turne, to
gratifie one.

Prendre plaisir à l'estude, to delight
or to haue a pleasure in studying.

Prendre plaisir à lire vne lettre, to
take a pleasure in the reading of a
letter.

Vne Plameuse, a blow on the eare: f.

Plan, the draught of a Forrest or buil­
ding: m.

Vne Planche, a planke, a thicke
bourd: f.

Plancher, a floure of bourds: m.

Plancher ou paver d'ais, to floure or
planke with bourds.

Vn Planchier: see Lambris.

Vn plançon, a little planke: m.

Plane, nom d'arbre, a Plane tree: f.

Vne Plane, or rabot, the Ioyners
plaine, or Carpenters: f.

Planer, to make smooth & euen with
a plaine.

Planer, to goe cleane, and without any
wauering.

Planer, to blot out.

Planer de la memoire, to blot or put 
out of our memorie.

Cest oiseau plane mignardement,
 that bird, that Hawke cutteth the
ayre, or flieth swift, gingerly, and
without flittering with his wings.

Faulcon qui plane, when a Hawke
flieth cutting the ayre without wa­
uering or shaking eyther of his
wings.

Planette, a Planet: f.

Planir & vnir quelque lieu, to plaine
or make euen a place: je planis, je





plani, j'ay plani, je planiray.

Vn lieu Plani, an euen place.

Du Plantain, an hearbe called Plan­
tine: m.

Vn plantal, vn sion & iecton d'ar­
bre, ou d'herbe qu'on plante en
terre, a plant or syon: m: the blade
of an herbe.

Plantars, that is, the great branches or
poles of willowes kept for to plant: m.

Vne plante d'herbe, ou d'arbre, a
plant of any tree or herbe, a set, also
a yong vine: f.

La plante du pied, the sole of ones
foote: f.

Planté & abondance, plentie, aboun­
dance: f.

Planter, to plant, to set.

Plante, a graffe: f.

Plantage, a graffing, a setting: m.

Plantement, graffing, setting: m.

Planteur, a grafter, a setter: m.

Plantureaux, plentifull, aboundant.

Plantureusement, plentifully, aboun­
dantly.

Planure, a plaine field: f.

Plaquars, placardes, writings from
higher powers: m: also bils set vp:
libels.

Plaques, or Plaquars, pargetting a­
gainst a wall.

Plaquer contre vne paroy, to dawbe
against a wall: also to fasten against
it.

Plasmateur, m: God is so called, be­
cause he made vs, as worker of I­
mages, or of any other thing in
earth.

Plasmation, f: such workmanship.

Le Plastron d'vn home armé, a cer­
taine peece of an armour.

Plastras, rubbish: m.

Plastre, plaster or morter: m.

Plastrer, the plaster.

Plastriére, the place where they dig
plaster: f.

Plat ou escuëlle, a platter, a dish: m.

Plat & bien vni par dessus, flat and 
smooth, also a plaine.

Ietter quelque chose tout Plat à
terre, to cast flat to the ground.

Ie le vous nie tout à Piat, I denie it
flatly.

Frapper du plat de l'espée, to strike
with a sword flatling.

Plate-forme, the mould of a house,
also a bulwarke or platforme: f.

Plauder, or Pelauder, to beate one, as
je te plauderay bien, I will currie
and trim thee handsomely.

Il a esté bien pelaudé, he was dressed
finely.

Vne playe, a wound: f.

Refreschir & renouveler la playe, to
renue the wound.

Estuver vne playe, to bathe a wound.

Vne carpe à l'estuvée, a stude Carpe.

Playe faite à justice, when iustice
hath not such power and force as it
should haue.

Plein de playes et vlceres, ful of sores.

Player & navrer, to plague or wound
one.

Playé & navré, wounded.

Pleige ou respondant, a Suretie: m.

Vous plait-il estre mon pleige, pour
la pareille? will it please you to bee
my suretie, for the like turne?





Pleiger aucun, to be suretie for one.

Ie le plegeray corps pour corps, I
will be his suretie body for body.

Plein, full.

Pleine, when a beast is with yong: as
ma jument, vache, chienne est
plaine, my Mare, Cowe, Bitch, is
with colt, with calfe, with whelpe or
yong: f.

Pleinement, plainlie, euidentlie, ful­
lie.

Plenté, seeke Planté, aboundance.

Plethoric, a fat man, corpulent, full
of humours: m.

Pleurer, to weepe, to wayle, to lament,
to shed teares.

Pleurant, weeping.

Pleuré & regretté, bewept, bewailed,
bemoned.

Pleureur, a weeper: m.

Pleur, a teare, a trickle: f.

Pleurement, a weeping, a wayling: m.

Pleuresie, a disease called the Plu­
rasie: f.

Pleuretique, one that hath the Plu­
resie.

Pleust à Dieu qu'il fust venu, I would 
it pleased God that he were come.

Pleuvi, as Serviteur qu'on a pleuvi
franc de tout larcin & crimes,
 a seruant discharged franke and
free from all kinde of thefte and 
crime: m.

Pleuvir, or fiancer vne fille, to be­
trothe a maiden.

Pleuvir vne marchandise bonne &
loyale, to warrent ware merchant­
able.

Pleuvine, bailler quelque chose en
pleuvine, to deliuer ware on trust
or vpon warrantise: f.

Vne plie, or plye, a fishe called a
Plaise: f.

Plier, to plait, to fold, to bowe.

Pliement, a plaiting, a bowing: m.

Plieure, folding or bowing: f.

Plis de robbes, the plaites or lap of 
garments: m.

Il a prins son pli, hee hath taken his 
plight: that is, he will neuer be o­
ther man than he is now, that is e­
uer taken in ill part.

Vne robbe plissée, a gowne that is
plaited.

Vne plinthe, f: a square and plaine
peece of wood or timber in Mason­
rie or Carpenterie worke: it is also
the first peece of a piller.

Plomb, leade: m.

Le Plomb d'vn masson ou charpen­
tier, a Carpenters plummet: m.

Vne chose à plomb, when it is right
cast, or drawne from foundation to
the top, as walles, houses, &c.

Plomber, to plumbe or sounde the
depth of a thing, to sounder.

Plombé ou estaimmé: comme,
poailon plombé, a Skillet leaded 
or tinned.

Plombé, vn esprit rude & plombé, a
dull spirit: m.

Fort plombeux, leadie: which hath
much leade.

Couleur plombée ou resemblant au 
plomb, leadie colour, or like leade.

Vne plombée, a plummet or pellet of
leade: f.

Vn plombier, a Plummer: f.





Plonger en l'eauë, to diue, to plunge
in the water.

Plongeon, oyseau, a foule called a 
Ducker, of others, a puffin: m.

Plote, Ploter, seeke Pelote.

Vn Ploton de fil, a bottome of threed,
a clue: m.

Plourer, see pleurer, to weepe.

Plouvoir, il pleut, il plouvoit, il plut,
il a plu, il avoit plu, il plorra, a 
Verbe Impersonal, to rayne.

Plouvier, or blouroir, seeke Cylin­
dre.

Plouviner, & faire vn petit vent, to
misle and blow.

Pluye, raine: f.

Pluvial, raynie, or like to rayne.

Pluvieux, raynie.

Plumes, fethers: f.

Vne Plume à escrire, a pen.

Vn plumart, or plumars, a plume of
fethers: m.

Vn plumassier, a fether maker: m.

Plumer, to plucke, or to plume.

Plus, more.

Au plus, at the most.

Plus de fois, oftener, or more times.

Plusieurs, many.

Plusieurs fois, many times.

Pluvier, a Plouer: m.

Pluye, Pluvieux, seeke Plouvoir.

Vne Plye, f: espece de poisson plat,
 a plaice.

Poacre, see Pouäcre.

Poale à frire, ou autre choses, seeke
Paelle.

Vn poale, or poille, & estuves, a hote­
house, a stoue: m.

Poalon, a skillet: m.

Vne Poche ou pouchette, a pocket,
also a great wide sacke to carrie
meale as Millers doe vse: f.

La poche d'vn oyseau, the crawe of 
a foule, the croppe.

Pocher, to thrust out with ones fin­
ger.

Pocher l'œil à quelqu'vn, to thrust
out ones eyes, to digge out ones
eyes.

Vn œuf Poché, a poched egge: m.

Podagre, the Goute: f.

Home podagre, or podagreux, gou­
tie.

Vn poelle & estuves, a stoue, a hote­
house: m.

Vn Poëte, a Poet: m.

Poëme, the worke of the Poets: m.

Des Poetrons, ou prunes jaunes,
 yellowe plummes: m.

Poictrail de Cheval, a Horse pe­
trell: m.

La poictrine, the brest: f.

Poitrinette, a litel brest.

Poictron, the siege: m.

Poignard, poigner, seeke Poing.

Poil, hayre.

Poil folet, pinne fethers of a young
birde, the first downe.Antedates earliest OED entry (?1680).

Corapei, such as hangeth ouer the
Princes seate, in the Chamber of
presence, called the cloth of estate.The headword is probably "canopy."

Poille, see poale.

Ceux qui portent le poille, when
the Papists doe carrie their sacra­
ment in the procession, foure men do
carrie with foure staues a cloth or
like fine cloth square, to shadow such 
as be vnder it, a Canapie.





Vn poilon, a little skillet where lit­
tle childrens pap is made: m.

Vn poinct, a poynt, a pricke: m.

Le poinct du jour, the dawning of
the day.

Le poinct de la matiére, the poynt of
the matter.

Vn poinct, a stitch, such a disease in
ones side: m.

Vn poinct d'esguille, the stitch of a
needle.

Elle est en bon poinct, shee is freshe
and in good taking.

Ce cheval est en bon poinct, this
horse is fat.

Estre bien en poinct & en ordre,
 to be well apparelled.

Se mettre en poinct, & s'apprester,
 to prepare himselfe.

Ie suy mal en poinct, I am in poore
order or estate.

Tout vien à poinct qui peut atten­
dre, a prouerbe: all will be well in
time: a threatning manner of
speech.

Pointu, sharpe poynted.

La Poincte & asprete d'vn Ro­
cher, the poynt or toppe of a rocke:
fem.

La poincte de l'œil, the corner of the
eye.

La poincte de quelque chose a­
guë, the poynt of any sharpe thing:
fem.

Fraper de poincte, to cast a pricke
at one.

Vin, or saulce qui a bonne poincte
au gouster, wine or sauce hauing a 
good quicke taste.

Poincte de France, the first onset of
the frenchmen.

En ce point, ou par ce poinct tu m'­
ostes toute esperance, in this point,
or through this poynte thou takest
all hope from me.

A poinct & convenablement, very
aptly and fitly.

Bien à poinct, in good time.

Bon poinct, ou mauvais poinct, good
plight, or ill plight.

Qui est en bon poinct & en or­
dre, that is handsome and in good
order.

Poincter, to pricke often.

Pointeler, to pricke often, to make
many poynts or prickes.

Poindre, to pricke, to sticke, to lanch:
je poins, je poigni, j'ay point, je
poindray.

Poesie, or Poëterie, Poetrie: f.

Poignant, pricking.

Poignement, a pricking: m.

Le poing, the fist: m.

Vne poignée ou javelle, f: a hand­
full.

Vne Poignée de N: a handfull, a
gripe of N.

La poignée, the handle of a sworde
or dagger.

Vne poignée de gens, a handfull of
men.

Vn poignard, a Poinadoe, a dag­
ger: m.

Le poignet de la main, the gras­
ping of the hande: m.

Poinson d'attorneresse, a bodkin to
frisell hayre withall: m.

Poinson , or poinçon de fer, an yron





bodkin or puncheon: also a marke,
stampe, or seale.

Le poinçon de la tour de Londres,
 the stampe or marke of the towre of
London set vpon any Goldsmithes
worke.

Vn poinson de Vin, a hoggeshead
of wine.

Point, ou nullement, not.

Point trop, not to much.

Point encore, not yet.

Vne poire, a peare: f.

Poires de Angoisse, choaking peares.Antedates earliest OED citation (1623; cf. "choking," adj. 1; but see also "choke-pear").

Vn poirier, a peare tree: m.

Vn poireau, ou verruë, a Warte:
masc.

Poireaux, Porrée, seeke porreau:
porrée.

Vn pois, a peise, a weight: see poix.

Il me poise de vostre mesadventure,
 it grieueth me of your ill chance.

Poison, poison, venim.

Poisonneux, venemous.

Poisser, seeke Poix.

Poisson, fish: m.

Poissonnet, a little fish: m.

Poissonnier, a fisher, a fishmonger: m.

La poissonnerie, the fishmarket: f.

Poissonneux, abounding in fish.

Poivre, seeke poyvre.

Poivrette, seeke poyvrette.

Poix, pois, & poids, differ thus: al­
though they haue one like pronun­
ciation: for Poix, is pitche: pois,
a peyse: poids, a weight.

Le poids d'vne livre, the weight of a
pounde: m.

Chose de grand poids & conse­
quence, a matter of great weight
and consequence.

Peser, to weygh, to peyse.

Peser & considerer diligemment
quelque chose l'examiner, to con­
sider a thing diligently, to ponder a
matter.

Ce me Poise, I am sorie for that, it
grieueth me.

Pesant, weighty, heauy, burthenous.

Pesanteur, weight, heauynesse: f.

Peseur, a weigher: m.

Peson, or vertoil, a wherle to put on
the ende of a spindle: m.

De la poix, pitch: f.

Poix-réfine, Rosen: f.

Poisser, to pitch.

Vaisseaux poissez, pitched vessels.

Poissement, a pitching with pitch: m.

Le pol artique, the North pole: m.

Polaque, a man of Poland.

Polaine, a peece of the ship: f.

Souliers faits à la polaine, open shooes
as olde men doe weare: see Polen­
ne.

Vne pole, a kind of flat fish: flounders.

Police, le faict & gouvernement d'­
vne republique, the gouernment of 
a common-wealth: f.

Citez bien policées, où il y a bon­
ne police, Cities well ordered or
gouerned.

Polir, je polis, je poli, j'ay poli, je
poliray, to polish, to clense, to make
cleane, to scoure.

Poli, polished.

Poliément & ornément, smoothly
and brightly.

Poligarchie, a Monarchie deuided 
into diuers partes: f.





Poligamie, the lawe of Matrimony
graunting many wiues: f.

Polipus chancreux, a disease in the 
nose like a canker: it is also a fish: see
pourpe: m.

Polypode, herbe, ferne vpon trees:
wall-ferne: polipodie: f.

Polissement, a polishing: m.

Polissure, polishing: f.

Polluer, to defile, to spotte, to pol­
lute.

Pollu, defiled.

Vn poltron, a nothing worth, a sloth­
full person, faynt-hearted: m.

Poltroniser, to play the slouthfull
person: it is an Italian worde.

Pomelée, ou patte de Lion, herbe, 
 an hearbe called Bearefoote: f.

Vne pomme, an Apple: f.

Pomme de capendu, a Pepin.

Pomme de renette, a renet.

Du pommé, or Cidre, Cider: m.

Tetin pomelu, a dugge rounde like
an Apple: m.

Pommeau d'espée, the pummell of a 
sworde: m.

Pomon, seeke poulmon.

Pommes de senteurs, sweete balles,
pomanders."sweet-ball" antedates earliest OED citation ("sweet," adj., 1617).

Pommiers, Apple trees: m.

Vne pommeraye, vn lieu planté d'­
arbres fructiers, an Orchard. f.

Vn cheval pomelé, a round horse.

Pompe & appareil solennel, a

Il marche pompeusemen, hee goeth
pompously.

Pompeux, pompous, magnificall.

Pompon, or pepon, a kinde of fruite
like a round pompion, but very plea­
sant to eate rawe with salte and
meate a muske Milion: m.

Ponent, du coste du ponant, of the 
West parte: m.

Pierre ponce, a pomise stone: f.

Poncer, to pounce.

Pondre, je ponds, je ponu, or j'ay
ponu, or pondu, je pondray, to
lay egges.

Vn œuf frais pondu tout mainte­
nant pour ton desjuner, to haue
an egge newe layd to ones break­
fast.

Vn pont-levis, a drawe bridge.

Vn ponceau, or poncel, m: a lit­

Vn Pontonnier, or pontonier, a 
Ferry-man.

Ponceau, or Coquelicoq, Chesboll,
or poppie: m.

Populaire, populace, seeke Peu­
ple.

Populeuse cité, a populous citie.

Pontificat, as la deuziesme année
de son pontificat, the second yeare
of his prelatship.

Pontifical, costlie, pontificall, sump­
tuous.

Pontificallement, sumptuously.

Vn popelin, a little babie: m.

Populeux, full of people.

Ville populeuse, a Citie abounding
in people.

Populosité, abundance of people.

Vn Porc, ou porceau, m: a hogge, a
swine.

heard: m.

Porcelaine, vne grande coquille de 
mer faicte comme vne corne,
 a great shell of a fish made like a
horne.

Porphire, a kinde of marble: m.

Vne porque, a Sowe: f.

Mener vne vie porque, to leade an 
hoggish life.

Vn porreau, a leeke: m.

Dela porrée, ou jotte, an hearbe cal­
led Beetes: all kinde of pot hearbs: f.

Porion, or oignon sauvage, m: a wild
onyon.

Vn Port, a hauen, a riuer, a porte to
take, and to ariue to the hauen: m.

Payer le port, to pay the custome, to 
pay the waterman his fare.

Le port & contenance d'vne per­
sonne, the behauiour or mainte­
nance of one: m.

Par port d'armes, by force of armes: 
when the subiect taketh armes a­
gainst his Lord.

Le port & saveur d'une personne
envers l'aute, the fauour, &c.

Homme qui a grand port, a manne
well
beloued.

Porte-chappes, m: Priestes bearing
coapes: m.

Porte-ciel, as Atlas, m: vpholding
the heauens.

Porte-celles, seeke Portecolles.

Porte-coulisse, a percolice: f.

Port-espée, a sworde bearer: m.

Porte-guidon, a standard bearer: m.

dlebowe to beare the cloake: m.

the trayne of the Prince or any
Lorde: m.

Vne Porte, a gate: f.

Portail, an entrie, a portall: m.

Portier, a porter: f.

Portiére, a she porter: f.

Porter, to beare, to carie.

Se porter bien, to be in good health.

Porter patiemment, to beare pati­
ently, to suffer.

Port-enseigne, an ensigne bearer: m.

Porte-faix, a porter, a burden bearer.

Porte-panier, a basket bearer: m.

Qui est porté, which is caried.

Porteur, a bearer, a carier: m.

Porteur de rogatons, a bearer of
bulles from the Pope.

Portage, a bearing: m.

Le fruit & portée d'vne beste, the 
fruit or burthen of any beast: f.

Portées, in the plurall number, be the
boughes of the forrest or thicket,
which the hart boweth or breaketh
trauersing the wood: f.

Vne portiére, femelle qu'on garde 
pour porter des petits, anie fe­
male kept to beare young: f.

Port, ou portement, a bearing, a ca­
rying: m.

La capacité & portée d'aucun, the
capacitie or vnderstanding of any:
the ability: f.





Ie feray selon ma portée, I will doe
according to my abilitie.

Portion, a parte, a portion, a deale: f.

La portion, a portion of any victu­
alles

Portionner, to deale, to parte, to de­
uide.

Portique, or promenoir, a walking
place, a porch: m.

Poser & asseoir, to stay on, or to set
downe.

Mis & posé, placed, or situate.

Homme posé & rassis, a sober or di­
screete man.

Posé le cas que, &c. put the case
that, &c.

Pose le cas qu'il soit vaincu, put the
case he be ouercome.

Pose & repos qu'on prend, rest, or
pause: f.

Faire vne pose, to make a pause.

Posement, a placing, setting or dis­
posing of any thing: m.

Position & situation, placing and si­
tuation: f.

Posseder, to possesse, to enioy.

Possesseur de quelque chose, an ow­
ner of any thing: m.

Possessoire, a matter holden in pos­
session.

Possession & héritage, possession or
heritage: f.

Possible, possible, that may be.

Autant qu'il est possible, as much as
is possible.

Selon ma possibilité, according to my
possibilitie: f.

Se resjouïr au possible, to reioyce as 
may be possible.

Poste, a post or messenger: m.

Cheval de poste, a post horse.

Courir la poste, to ride post: f.

Les postes & chevaucheurs d'escu­
rie, m: the kings postes or Mes­
sengers.

Cela est bien à ma poste, that is at
my lyking, it liketh me well.

Cela estoit fait à poste, that was
done on purpose, it was imagined
before,

Faire à la poste d'vn autre, to doe af­
ter an others minde or fantasie.

Mettre gens à la poste, to appoynt
or place men which will doe as one
liketh.

Le posteau d'vn huis, the poste of a 
doore: m.

Posteaux ornez de despouilles, posts
or pillers decked with the spoyles of
our enemies.

Postelé, seeke poupelé.

Postposer, to set behinde, to esteeme
lesse, to omit: as postposer ses af­
faires à celles de son amy, to neg­
lect or omit his owne businesse for
his friends sake.

Postérieur, the last: la partie poste­
rieure, the hinder parte.

Postérité, posteritie: f.

Posthume, which is borne after his
fathers decease.

Postidate, the day delayed, the date
after the true day.

Postuler, ou plaider, advocasser, to
pleade or to demaund a thing.

Interdire de postuler, or plaider, to
forbid one the barre.

Postulation & requeste, a demaund,





a request: f.

Postulé, admitted, ioyned to socie­
tie, company, office, or charge with
others.

Postules, or pustules, byles, wheales: f.

Vn pot à pisser, ou de chambre, a
chamber pot: m.

Pot à eauë, a water pot.

A pot, & à feu, as Il est leans à pot
& à feu, he haunteth that place so
much, that he is as one of the house.

Ilz ne font qu'vn pot & vn feu, they 
liue, eate and drinke together, they
set but one pot to the fire.

Vne pottée, f: a potte full of any
thing.

Vn potier de terre, a Potter: m.

Vne poterie, a pot market, the place
where pottes are made: f.

L'art de Poterie, the arte of a Pot­
ter or to make pottes.

Du potage, porrige, broth: m.

Manger son potage, to eate his
porrige.

C'est vn vilain pour tout potage,
que voulez vous que j'en die? he
is a villaine when all is done, what
shall I say by him?

Potage exquis, bien acoustré & as­
saisonné, porrige or broth very
well seasoned.

Grand potager, or mangeur de po­
tage, a porrige belly.

Herbes potagiéres, pot hearbes: f.

Vie potagére, a life sustayned with
porrige: f.

Potences, crouches of lame men: f.

Vne potence, a gibbet: f.

Vne poterne, a posterne or backe
doore of a towne or castell: f.

Potage commun qui n'est point
espez, potage or broth not thicke: 
masc.

Homme potieux, malaize à con­
tenter & difficile, a waywarde
man, a delicate man which casteth
for the least thing in the worlde: 
masc.

Potie sur vne robe, f: a spot vpon a
gowne.

Tu es trop potieux, thou art too
daintie.

Potion, or bruvage, a drinke: f.

Vn potiron, ou champignon, a tode­
stoole, a musherom: m.

Potié, seeke poupelé.

Potonnier, a knaue, a roge:m.

Pouäcre, that is, villain, pourry, oy­
sesau, fayneant, a filthy, foule, rot­
ten, copper nosed one.

Pouciniere, seeke poulsiniére.

Poulcins, seeke Poulsins.

Poulain, a colte: m.

Maladie es aines qu'on appelle les 
poulains, botches in ones grine.

Poulener, or poulainer, to colte, or
fole as Mares doe.

Large d'un poulce, a thombe
broade.

Vne poulcée, the breadth of a 
thombe.

Vn Poulcier, m: a measure as the
thombes breadth

Pouldre, dust: f.

Pouldrer, to dust.

Pouldrer de sel, to pouder with salte,
to season with salte.





Chair pouldrée, poudred flesh: f.

Pouldrette, fine pouder: f.

Pouldreux, dustie.

Pouldriére, or poussiére levée en l'­
air, dust raysed vp the ayre either
by the winde or horsemen: f.

Pouldre à canon, gunne pouder: f.

Pouldrette, f: very small dust.

Pouldrer, to turne into duste.

Pouldrer de sel, to salte or pouder
with salte.

Chair Pouldrée de sel, flesh or meate
powdred with salt.

Pouldroyer, to turne into pouder or
duste.

Pouldrement, m: filling with duste,
poudering.

Pouldreux, m: dustie.

Pouldroyer quelque chose, to put
any thing to dust.

La poule gloce, f: the Henne doth
clucke.

Poule d'Inde, a Turkie Henne.

Poule de la Guinée, a Henne of
Ginnie.

Poule d'eauë, a coote.

Vn Poulaillier, a Poulter, the hens
roust: m."poulter" lacks this sense in the OED.

victuallers: m.

Poulier, poulaillier, or gelinier, the
Hennes roust: m.

Poulenne, as souliers à poulenne,
 shooes opened aboue and tyed with
a latchet, hauing two hornes at the
toes.

Vn poulet, ou poulette, a younge
Henne: m.

Vn cochet, idem.

Poulie, a pulley: f.

Vn poulion, a little pulley: m.

Le poulmon, the lungs or lites: m.

Poulpe, or charnure, the brawne of
a man.

Poulpeux & charnu, fleshie, and
full of brawne.

pit: m.

Poulpitres, armaires, or armoires
à metre livres, a presse to set bookes
in: m.

Vn poul, a louse: m.

Maladie aux poux, a lousie dis­
ease.

Pouilleux, lousie.

Ce n'est que vne Puilleuse, shee is 
but a lousie baggage.

Pouiller, to wayte one, to picke out
lice.

Poulser, to push, to thrust, to iustle.

Poulsé, being thrust or enforced.

Le pouls, the pulse: m.

Poulsement, a pushing, a thrusting: m.

Poulsif, pursie, short winded: m.

Poulssive, she is short winded: f.

Poulsins, chickens: m.

La poulsiniére du ciel, f: the seuen
starres.

Poulsiner, to bring forth a broode of
chickens.

Niée, or couvée de poulsins, a brood
of chickens.

Poultre ou tref, f: the beame of a 
house.

Vne Poultre, or Iument, a Mare: f.





Poulx, lice: m.

Plein de Poulx, full of lice: m.

Poupe, the teate of a wilde beast, as
les poupes d'vne louve, d'vne our­
se, the teates of a she Wolfe or a 
Beare: f.

Poupée, or Poupette, a puppie, a ba­
ble, a babie: f."bable" may antedate OED ("babble," 3; 1667).

Poupelé, as cheval poupelé, pome­
lé, or postelé, a round fat horse, or
grey spots round like an apple.

Vn Poupon, as elle tenoit son petit
poupon, parlant de Pentagruël,
 she held her little babe: m.

Poupine, a woman fine, and coye with­
all: f.

Pouvoir, je peux, or puis, je pu, j'ay
peu, je pourray, to can, to bee
able.

Pleust à Dieu que je le peusse faire,
 would God I might doe it.

Il n'a peu, or pu faire que cela fust
ottroyé, he could not bring to passe
that this might be graunted.

Tant que je peu, as much as I could.

Ne povoir, that cannot.

Il peut estre, it may be.

Povoir & authorité, ou seigneu­
rie, power, authoritie, or gouern­
ment.

Bailler povoir & puissance, to giue
power and authoritie to one.

Ie ne l'ay pas peu envoyer plus tost, 
 I could not send it sooner.

Le povoir & puissance en biens, po­
wer or abilitie in goods.

Ie vous aideray de tout mon povoir,
 I will helpe you with all my power
and might.

Poupe, ou poulpe, maladie dedans
le nez, a disease in the nose.

Vne Poupée, a young wench, some­
times a puppet: also the flaxe of a 
distaffe: f.

Popelin, m: a rundell: a circle or
winding compasse.

Vn Poupetier, a maker of babies or
puppets

Poupelé, full of muscles, strong.

Poupe, polpe, or charnure, the most
fleshie parte in ones bodie.

La poupe, & derriére de la navire,
 the poope or hinder parte of a ship:
fem.

Pour, for.

Pour ma part, for my part.

Il a jugé pour toy, he hath giuen sen­
tence on thy side.

Pour autant, for as much.

Chacun pour soy & Dieu pour tout,
est vn mauvais proverbe, euerie
man for himselfe, and God for vs
all, is an euill prouerbe.

Pour si petite chose? for so small a
matter?

Pource, because, for that cause,
therefore.

Pour neant & sans rien bailler, for
nought, for nothing.

Pour vne parole, for one worde.

Porceau, seeke Porc, a hog.

Pourcelaine, seeke porcelaine.

Pourchaille, or pourpié, an hearbe
called purslaine: f.

Pourchasser quelque chose, to
seeke to get any thing, to desire to
compasse a thing, to sue to one for
a thing.





Purchasser sa vie d'huis en huis, to
get his liuing from doore to doore.

Pourchas, a purchasing, a getting, a 
soliciting, diligence.

Ie vous remercie, que à vostre
Pourchas, j'ay esté enrollé au ser­
vice du Roy, I thanke you, that at 
your suite I haue beene enrolled at
the Kings seruice.

Povre, poore, bare, needie.

Povret, a poore soule: m.

Pouvreté, pouertie, neede, necessitie,
barrenesse, want: f.

Mener ou mettre à povreté, to bring
one to pouertie, to vndoe one.

Povrement, poorely, simply.

Poureux, Poureusement, seeke peur.

Pour-fendre, to cleaue.

Pourfendu, cleft.

Le pourfil de l'homme, the shape & 
figure of a man.

Pourfiler d'or, to ouercast with gold,
to tinsel or weaue as cloth of tinsell,
or baudkin is.

Pourfilure, f: tinseld, wrought with
baudkin worke.

Pourfit, see proufit.

Pourfiterolle, f: a Cake baked vnder
hoate imbers: see Proufiterolle.

Se Pourmener, to walke.

Pourmenement, walking.

Pourmenoir, a walking place: m.

Pourpaler de quelque chose, to 
conferre and talke touching some
matter.

Pourpe, or polypus, a fish hauing
many feete chaunging colour of­
ten: m.

Pourpenser, to bethinke one, to de­
uise on a matter.

Pourpier, an hearbe that is called 
purselaine: m.

Pourplanter, to plante heere and
there.

Pourpoint, a doublet: m.

Mis en pourpoint, when one hath
spent all his goods and hath nothing 
left: also one spoyled and robbed by
theeues, which is left in nothing but
in his doublet and hose.

Pourpre, est le poisson dont se pre­
noit la teincture de pourpre, a shel
fish called a Purple: m.

Pourpré, of purple colour.

Pourprisant, making or giuing the
colour of Purple.

Pourprendre, as la racine de cest
arbre Pourprenoit vne grande
largeur, the roote of that tree
did occupie in compasse a great in­
closure.

Ilz ont Pour prinze la terre de gens 
de guerre, & assiegé la ville tout
au tour, they haue inclosed the land
with men of warre, and besieged the
towne round about.

Vn pourpris & closture, an inclo­
sure, a cloyster: m.

Pourquerre & pourchasser quel­
que chose, to sue for a thing.

Pourquis, purchased.

Pourquoy? why? wherefore?

Pourquoy non? why not?

Pourrir quelque chose, to rotte a 
thing.

Se Pourrir, to rotte, to waxe rotten.

Estre pourri & gasté, to be rotten
and marred.





Il sent le pourri, it smelleth of rot­
tennesse.

Pourriture, ou pourrissure, rotten­
nesse: f.

Poursemer, to sowe.

Poursemé, sowen.

Poursuivre, to pursue, to followe a 
matter: it is declined like Suyvre.

Poursuitte, ou pourchas, a pursuite
or following, an action in lawe: f.

Proces d'vne longue poursuitte, or
de long traict, a suite in the lawe
of a long tract of time.

Pourtant que, for asmuch as, because
that.

Pourtraire, to drawe out, to por­
tray.

Vn pourtraict, a draught or portrai­
ture: m.

Le pourtraict, patron & ordon­
nance d'vn edifice & autres cho­
ses, the portrayture or modell of a­
ny building.

Pourvoir, seeke prouvoir.

Pourveu que tu ne le puisses, so that
thou canst not doe it.

Pourveu qu'il soit vray, so that it be
true.

Pousser, see Poulser.

Prouïngner, seeke Prouïn.

Pourvoir, pourveu, pourvoyant,
pourvoyance, pourvision, seeke
Prouvoir.

Poussiere, seeke Poudre.

Poussif, seeke Poulsif.

Poutie, poutieux, seeke Potie.

Poutre, seeke Poultre.

Pouvoir, seeke povoir.

Poivrer, to pepper any meate, also to
giue pepper to a Faulcon to clense
him, or to make more tame when he
is wilde.

Poivré, peppered.

Poivreure, peppering: f.

Poivre, pepper: m.

Poyvrette, Nielle ou Nigelle, an
hearbe called Gyth: f.

Practiquer ce que nous enseig­
nons, to practise or put in vre that
which we teach.

Bons practiciens, gents qui sca­
vent bien les loix & les coustu­
mes, one of great practise in the
lawe.

Par practique, by practise or sub­
tiltie, f: by craft or deceitfull dea­
ling.

La practique the stile of Lawyers.

Prangeler, to chaw the cud in the af­
ter noone as cattell doth: in Nor­
mandy they terme it Merianer.

Prain, pleine, grosse, & enceincte,
 doe differ thus: for wilde cruell
beastes being with young, as a shee
Beare, we say elle est prain, of a ta­
med beaste, elle pleine: and of a
woman, elle est enceinte, or elle est
grosse, she is with childe: f.

Pré, and in some parte of Fraunce,vn
prat, or Prée,  a medowe: m.

Defendre les prez, to hedge medowes
round about.

Preau, or petit pré, a little medowe: 
masc.

Les belles prairies, the fayre me­
dowes: f.

Pre-alable, which ought to goe be­
fore, as regardons au prealable,





let vs consider on that which ought
to be discussed or determined the
first of all.

Prealablement, formost, or first.

Preallégué, alledged before.

Preambule, a preface: m.

Prebende, a Prebend, the portion of
Canons: f.

Prebender en vn tripot, to band in
the tenice.

Precaire, or prest, the deede of boro­
wing: m.

Précéder, to goe first, to excell.

Précédant, going before.

Précédence, the honour and preroga­
tiue to goe before: f.

En telles ceremonies il n'y a aulcun
lieu de précédence, in such cerimo­
nies they keepe no order in going be­
fore or behinde.

Précesseur, which goeth afore vs: m.

Préceller les autres en vertu, to ex­
cell others in vertue.

Précepte, a precept, a commaunde­
ment: m.

Précepteur, an instructer, a teacher.

Préceptrice, & celle qui enseigne,
 she which teacheth: f.

Precieux, precious, seeke pretieux.

Précipiter, to cast headlong, to doe a
thing rashly, or in haste.

Précipité, cast headlong.

Iugemens precipitez, iudgements
done in haste, or rashly.

Précipitation de jugement, iudge­
ment done too hastily: f.

Précipice, a downe right pitch, or fal:
a creeke: m.

Précis, precise.

Dire precisement son opinion, to
say preciselie his minde.

Précogiter, to thinke before what we 
should say.

Prédecesseur, our predecessour: m.

Noz prédecesseurs, or Ancestres,
 our forefathers, ancestors.

Prédestiné de Dieu, appointed by god.

Choses prédestinées, things orday­
ned or appoynted before, which must
come to passe.

Prédestination, predestination, ap­
poynting before what shall come: f.

Prédestinée fatale, a fatall destinie
which must needes happen: f.

Prédicateur, a preacher: m.

Prédication, a preaching, a Sermon: f.

Prédire, to foretell.

Ie le vous avoye prédit, I did tell it
you afore.

Prédiction, a foretelling: f.

Préminence, preeminence, preroga­
tiue: f.

Préface ou prologue d'vn livre pro­
pos iteratif de ce que nous vou­
lons dire puis apres, the Preface 
or Prologue of a booke, a short de­
claration before what wee will say
after: f.

Préferer & plus estimer, to preferre,
to esteeme aboue, to like better.

Préeferer son advis à celuy d'autruy,
 to preferre his owne iudgement to
another.

Preférable, to be preferred, com.

Préfiner, borner, & arrester, to de­
termine before, to appoint before
what shall be done after.

A jour prefix, at a day appoynted.





Prefixion de temps, an appoynting
of time: f.

Le demandeur produira ses tes­
moings dans troys jours, sans au­
tres préfixions & delaiz, the plain­
tife shall bring foorth his witnesses
within three dayes, without any o­
ther appoynting or delay.

Raisons Pregnantes, reasons ha­
uing force and strength, pressing
reasons.

Prejudice, preiudice, hinderance: m.

Ie le feray, mais que ce soit sans 
mon préjudice, I will doe it, if it be 
without any hinderance.

Cela me seroit prejudiciable, com: 
 that would be hurtefull to me.

Préjudicier à aucun, to bee a hinde­
rance to one.

Prelat, a prelate: m.

Prelature, a prelateship: f.

Prele or Asprele, f: an hearbe called
horse-tayle.

Premediter, to premeditate.

Premeditation, premeditating.

Premier, first, or primate: m.

Premier que je parle, &c. before I
talke, &c.

Premier & salarier, to rewarde.

Tout premierement, first of all.

Premis, set before: as la cour du
parlement de Paris est prémise
aux autres, the courte of the par­
liament of Paris is preferred and
set before any other.

De prime face, at the first shewe.

Primerain, that which hath none o­
ther beginning: m.

Prendre, to take, to catch, to appre­
hende: je prens, je prins, j'ay
prins, or pris, je prendray.

Prenez garde à ce que vous faites,
 take heede what you doe.

Vn Preneur, a taker: m.

Prins, caught, taken.

Prinse, or prise, a catching, a prize:
fem.

Preoccuper, to preuente.

Preoccupation, f: preuenting.

Preordonner, as Chose Preordonnée
de Dieu, preordinated, or a thing
before determined of god to be done.

Preparer, to prepare, to set in a rea­
dinesse.

Preparation, & appareil, preparati­
on, making ready: f.

Preparement, a preparation, a prepa­
ring: m.

Faire ses préparatifs de guerre, to
make his preparation for to goe to
warre.

Préposer, or préférer, to preferre.

Preposterer, to corrupt, to alter, to
change all good order.

Prépuce, c'est la peau du bout du
membre viril, the foreskinne of a 
mans yarde: m.

Prérogative, & avantage, preroga­
tiue, aduantage.

Pres ou apres, nigh.

Estre au pres, to be present.

Ie me suy de plus, que pres les au­
tres ne me sont, I am more nighe,
that is, more bound to my self, than
others be to me.

Cela me touche de pres, that tou­
cheth me very much.

A peu Pres, almost, within a little.





Presage, a perceiuing of a thing be­
fore it commeth: m.

Cecy m'est vn bon, ou mauvais pré­
sage, this is good or euill token to
me.

Présagieux, chose présagieuse, a
thing which doth foretell vs chaun­
ces to come.

Présagier, to gesse, to diuine, to per­
ceiue a thing which is towards.

Présagiant, south-saying, foretelling
a thing to come.

Presbtre, a Priest: m.

Presbitere, la maison ou le prebstre
demeure, the house by the Church
where the Curate dwelleth, seeke
prestre.

Prescher, to preach.

Allons au Presche, com: let vs goe
to the Sermon.

La Presche est finie, the Sermon is
done.

Prescheur, a preacher: m.

Prescience, foreknowledge: f.

Prescrire, to prescribe, to appoint.

Vn proces peri & prescrit, a suite pe­
rished and past suing.

Prescription, the time of prescripti­
on: f.

Prescription ne court point pendant
minorité, prescription of time ta­
keth no place while the pupill is vn­
der age.

Droits qui par aucun traict de temps
ne preuvent estre prescrits, right
which by no space of time can be a­
lienated or lost.

Qui est present, which is present or 
hard by.

Estre present, to be present.

Presence, presence: f.

En Presence, before or in presence.

Presentation, a setting foorth, a pre­
sentation: f.

Presentement & tout à l'heure, pre­
sently, at that  very instant.

Presenter, to present, to offer.

Se presenter devant quelqu'vn, to
present himselfe to any, to make a 
shewe.

Vn present, a present, a gifte: m.

Petit present, a little gift.

Preserver & garder quelqu'vn qu'­
il n'ait mal, to preserue, to defend
or keepe one from any harme.

Estre preservé, to be preserued or de­
fended.

Vn preservatif, a preseruatiue: m.

Presider à quelque affaire, to bee
chiefe in any businesse.

President, a President or chiefe Offi­
cer: m.

Le premier President de la cour de
Parlement, chiefest Iudge of the
high court of Parliament.

Le second President preside en l'­
absence du premier, the seconde
Iudge sitteth in the absence of the
first.

La Presidence, the office of a Pre­
sident or chiefest iudge: f.

Presomptions, or conjectures, suspi­
tions, likelyhood: f.

Presque, almost, welnigh.

Presque tous, almost all, the most
parte.

Le païs de France est Pres-que de­
struit par les guerres civiles, the





Countrey of Fraunce is almoste
destroyed through the great ciuill
warres.

Presser quelque chose, to presse a 
thing.

Presser aucun de faire quelque
chose, to presse or inforce one to
doe a thing.

Pressant: ou pressif, enforcing or vr­
gent.

Chose pressive, an earnest or vrgent
businesse: f.

Presseance, honneur & presseance,
 the honor & place of dignitie: f.

La presse, a prease of people: f.

Vne presse, a presse, to presse or print
any thing: f.

Pressement, a pressing: m.

Des presses fruicts, a fruit called a
Peach: f.

Vn pressoir, a presser: m.

Pressoirer, to presse out liquor.

Vn pressoireur, or pressurier, a pres­
ser: m.

Pressoirée, that which is pressed: f.

Prestation de foy, giuing of fayth
and loyalty of the subiect to the So­
ueraigne: f.

Prest & appareillé, ready or prest.

Prestement, readynesse, promptnesse.

Prester, to lend.

Prester l'oreille aux flatteurs, to giue
eare to flatterers.

Vn prest, a loane: m.

Presbitere: the vicarage, the church
house: m.

Prestre, a priest: m.

Prestresse, a she priest: f.

Prestrots, little Priestes or vnder
Priestes, or Chauntrie priestes, or
Curates: m.Postdates last OED citation (?c1200).

Prestraille, scurvie priestes.

Autorité Prestrale: Priestes autho­
ritie.

Presumer de soy, to presume, also to
thinke, to imagine.

Presomptuëux, presumptuous or ar­
rogant.

Presomption, presumption, mala­
partnesse: f.

Presomptuëusement, malapartly,
presumptuously.

Presupposer, presupposé qu'ainsi
soit, to presuppose, to weene.

Presure, the ruen of a beast to turne
milke: f: the curd or renning.

Prétendre, to shewe or pretend, to alal­
leadge, to signifie: see Tendre for
the declining.

Prétendre vne chose de son chef, to
deriue a thing from his spring.

Ilz sont deux qui pretendent vne
mesme debte, that is, chacun
d'eux dit la chose luy estre deuë,
 there be two which make a claime
for one debt.

Ie ne sçsay que tu prétens par tes pa­
rolles, I knowe not what thou mea­
nest by thy wordes.

Ie n'empesche rien en ton preten­
du, m: I doe hinder thee nothing in 
that which thou hopest or lookest
for.

Prétendant, clayming or preten­
ding.

Préterit, past, expired.

Prétermettre, or omettre, to leaue
and passe ouer, to omit, decline it





as Mettre.

Prétermission, or omission, f: omit­
ting or passing ouer any thing vn­
touched.

Préteur, a Iudge among the Romanes,
called a pretor: m.

Prétoire, the lodging of the sayde
Iudge, or the place where he sate in
iudgement: m.

Pretexte,  a colour, a shadowe or clo­
king of a matter: m.

Bailler quelque pretexte, cou­
leur, or couverture, to giue a co­
lour.

Soubz pretexte & couleur de re­
ligion, vnder the cloke or colour
of religion.

Il pretend à cela, his pretence is
thereto.

Prétieux, precious.

Précieusement, preciously.

Prétoire, a common Hall: see Pre­
teur.

Preu & vaillant chevalier, a vali­
ant or couragious knight.

Preudhome feal & loyal,  a faithfull
man, hardie, a valiant man: m.

Preudhomie, honestetè, true mea­
ning: to be short, we cal Preudhome,
such which hath all the qualities of
a perfect Gentleman, without guile
or deceit: f.

Preude fame, a wise, discreete, and
honest woman.

Prevaloir, to preuaile, to receiue aide,
succour or profite thereby: as vous
ne vous sçauriez prévaloir de
cela, you will neuer be the better
by that, you can take no benefite or
profite thereby.

Preudhomie, feauté, & loyauté,
 faythfulnesse, trustinesse, worthines:
see Preudhome.

Prevaricateur, a double dealer, or de­
ceiptfull person: m.

Prevariquer, to swarue from the
trueth, to deale craftily.

Prevenir, to preuent: see venir to de­
cline it.

Prevenu, preuented.

Prevenement, a preuenting: m.

Prevention, idem.

Prevoir, to foresee: see voir.

Tu as tout preveu, Thou foresaw­
est all.

Prévoyance, foresight: f.

Prevost de la ville, the provost or
chiefe of a towne: m.

Vn prevost des mareschaulx, a pro­
uoste Marshal, that hath in charge
to hang vp theeues.

Prevosté, the iurisdiction of the mar­
shall seate: f.

Preut, comme en preut, first, or first
of all.

En preut, deux, trois, one, two, three,
&c.

Preuve, seeke prouver.

Preux, hardi, sage, royal, chevale­
reux, preudhome, be all the names
of a valiaunt Knight: m.

Prier, to pray, to require, to desire, to
beseech.

Ie te prie, I pray thee.

Ie vous en prie, I heartily pray you.

Priant, praying.

Priére, a prayer: f.

Par Priére, by prayer.





Priement, m: praying.

Le Prieur, the Prior: m.

La Prieure, the Prioresse: f.

Vn Prieuré, m: a priorie.

Primace, as la primace de Lyon, an
ecclesiasticall dignitie aboue a Bi­
shop, or Archbishop: m.

Le primat d'Angleterre, the primate
of England: m.

Primauté, the primacie.

Prime, or premier des chevali­
ers, the firste or chiefest of the
knightes.

Le prime des philosophes, the flow­
er amongst the, &c: m.

Prime, thine.

Iouër à la prime, to play at Prime­
ro: f.

Prime-barbe, see Barbe.

Primerain, that commeth or sprin­
geth forth.

Rose Primeraine, a budding Rose,
tender.

Prime-vere, the spring time, also an
herbe called cowslippes: f.

Primitif, as la primitive Eglize, the
primitiue Church.

Primogeniture, the first birth: f.

Prince, ou princesse, a Prince or
princesse.

Estre principal ou plus excellent,
 to be principall and chiefe.

En prince, princelike.

Il parle en prince, he speaketh like a 
prince.

Principal de college, the principall of
a Colledge: m.

Tout le principal de l'affaire gist en
tesmoings, the chiefe of the matter
standeth vpon witnesses.

Principalement, chiefely, especially,
principally.

Principauté & seigneurie, princi­
palitie or lordship.

Principe, a principle, a maxime, or
chiefest ground of any Arte or
Science.

Prins, taken, seeke prendre.

Dire de plainsault or incontinent,
 to tell immediately, readily or at the
first chop.

Prinze, taking, f: a priese.

Printemps, Spring-time: m.

Pris & valeur, price and value: m.

Mettre pris, to set a price.

Mettre à pris, to bring to dearth.

Faire pris des tous, to set much by
good men, to esteeme the good.

Donner le pris à quelcun, to giue a
price to one.

Emporter le pris, to cary away the
price, praise and victorie.

Priser & estimer, to praise, to esteeme,
to like.

Prisé, prised.

La prizée, the praising or estimation
of a thing: f.

Priseur, a praiser, a price setter: m."price setter" antedates earliest OED citation (1620).

Vne prison, a prison: f.

Prisonnier, a prisonner: m.

Priuativement à tout aultres seig­
neurs, denied to all other Lords, be­
ing depriued of that benefite or
profit.

Vn privé & retraict, a priuie, or
Iakes: m.

Priué avec vn autre, familiar with
one.





Vivre en son privé, to liue at home
secretly and without medling with
any affaires.

Estre fort privé, to be gentle and fa­
miliar.

Vne personne privée qui n'a nulle
charge en la république, a priuate
person that hath no charge in a com­
mon wealth.

Pardonnez moy si je suy privé
ceans, pardon me if I be bold here
within.

Qui vous à fait si privé avec moy?
 who made you so bolde with me?

Madmoiselle, que je vous die vn
mot en privé, Gentlewoman, let 
me tell you a word in secret, or se­
cretly.

Parlez privémen, speake boldely.

Bestes privées & traictables, tame
and tractable beastes.

Privément, priuatelye, familiar­
lye.

Privoité, or privauté,  acquaintance,
familiaritie: f.

Priver aucun de son estat & offi­
ce, to depriue one from his office or
charge.

Privé de quelque chose, depriued or
bereaued of a thing.

Privation, a depriuing: f.

Privilege, c'est à dire vne loy parti­
culiere pour ou contre aucun, a
priuiledge.

N'estre point plus privilegié que
les autres, to haue no more Pri­
uiledge or Prerogatiue then an o­
ther.

Prix, see pris, --

Probable, com: seeke Prouver.

Probité de vie, honestie of life, good
behauiour in his liuing: f.

Probléme, a Probleme, a propositi­
on with a question or demaund an­
nexed: m.

Problématique, containing suche
questions: com.

Procéder & aller avant, to proceede
or goe forward.

On a jugé selon les Procedures,
 they haue iudged according to the
proceedings.

Processions, processions: f.

Proces, a strife or sute in law: m.

Vn proces criminel, a matter vpon
life and death.

Faire le proces à aucun, to sit vp­
pon a fellowe, or touching life and
death.

Son proces est fait, his matter is tri­
ed either by witnes, suspition, or any
other circumstances, & nothing re­
steth but iudgement.

Vn proces verbal, a sute or matter
in law, not by writing, but by report
or denouncing.

Gaigner son proces, to obtaine his
sute in the law.

Vuïder vn proces, to dispatche, to 
make an end in a sute.

Perdre son proces, to be cast in the
law.

Le proces est pendu au croc, the
sute hangeth for a time.

Home processif, that is, confit en
proces, quereleux, vn aheurté
plaideur, vn plaidereau, a wran­
gler, a couetous person, one that ta­





keth delight to vexe others in the
law.

Prochain, or proche parent, nigh
kinseman.

Aime ton prochain comme toy
mesme, loue thy neighbour as thy
selfe.

Mon prochain voisin, my next neigh­
bour.

La plus prochaine maison de la no­
stre, the next house to ours.

Prochaines terres, the next land or
ground.

Il est pres & prochain de nous, he is 
neere vs.

Prochainement, nighly, les six mois
prochainement passez, the sixe
monthes last past.

Dans huict jours prochainement
venans, within eight daies next
comming.

Prochaïneté, nighnes, or neerenes: f.

Prochasser, seeke pourchasser, to
sue.

Proche, as prochain nigh: com.

Proclamer, to proclaime.

Procréer, to procreate, to beget, to in­
gender.

Procreation, an ingendring: f.

Procreateur, he that begetteth or in­
gendreth: m.

Procreatrice, she that ingendreth: f.

Procurer la paix, to procure peace.

Procurer & avoir charge des af­
faires d'autruy, to procure and
