haue the charge of another mans
affaires.

Tu t'es procuré ce mal-heur, 
 thou hast procured to thy selfe this
mischiefe.

Procuration, a letter of attorney: f.

Passer procuration à aucun, to giue a
letter of attorney to one, to make one
his deputie.

Vn Procureur, an Attorney: m.

Le Procureur du Roy, the kings At­
torney.

Advocats & procureurs, the coun­
sailors and Attorneis.

Vn faux procureur, a false attorney.
which hath betraied the matter of
his Client.

Estre sustitu d'vn procureur, to
be vnder an Attorney, to be his de­
putie.

Procureurs d'hopitaux, deputies, re­
ceauers of rentes and almes of spi­
tles houses.

Prodige, a strange thing not accusto­
med to be seene, a monster: m.

Prodigieux, monstrous, strange, vn­
accustomed.

Prodigieusement, strangely, mon­
strously.

Prodigue, riotous, prodigall, lauish,
wastfull: com.

Prodigalement, prodigally, waste­
fully.

Prodigalité & degast de biens, con­
suming of goods: f.

Prodiger, to spoyle, to spill prodigal­
lye.

Proditeur ou traistre, a traitor, or
betrayer: m.

Produire, to bring forth, to alleage.

Prodition, or trahison, treason: f.

Produire & mettre hors son fruit, to
bring forth fruit.





Produire & metre en avant, to bring
forth or set before ones eyes, je pro­
duis, je produi, j'ay produit, je pro­
duiray.

Qui produit beaucoup, that brin­
geth forth much.

La production d'vne partie, that
which a partie bringeth forth to iu­
stifie his cause.

Sacs & productions eticquetées,
 the bookes or registers of a sute inre­
gistred or inrolled.

Proeme ou preface, a Prologue, or
preface: m.

Mon Proesme, m: that is, mon pro­
chain, my neighbour.

Profaner, se servir en commun v­
sage des choses consacrées, to pro­
fane, or put holy things to common
vses.

Chose profane, a filthy thing, vn­
seemely, prophane: com.

Profanation, f: profaning.

Prophané, m: defiled, profaned.

Profanement parler et faire, to
speake vngodly, prophanelike,"prophanelike" not found in OED.

Proferer & prononser, to pronounce,
or alledge.

Prolation, the pronouncing of let­
ters: f.

Professeur qui se mesle d'enseig­
ner, he that professeth to teach any
thing: m.

Faire profession de quelque chose
& s'en mesler publiquement, to
professe any thing, or to teach pub­
liquely.

Faire profession de religion, de
l'Evangile, to professe Religion,
the Gospell.

Vn profez, hee that hath made a 
vow of some sect or religion among
Papists.

Proffit, commoditie, profite.

Vne profiterolle, a gobbet wherewith
we cramme capons: f.

Profond, deepe.

Profondement, deepely.

Profoundeur, ou profundité, height
or depth: f.

Progenier, faire des petits, to bring
forth yong, or progenie.

Progeniteurs, our progenitors: m.

Pronostication, a prognostication: f.

Pronostiquer, to prophecie, to foretel,
to diuine or gesse.

Pronostiqueur, a foreteller, a diuine
which telleth things to come: m.

Progres, as faire de grands progres,
 to make a long discourse: m.

Prohiber & defendre, to forbid, to
prohibite.

Prohibé, prohibited, forbidden.

Prohibition, forbidding: f.

Interdict prohibitoire, a proclama­
tion forbidding, &c.

C'est vne chose projectée, it is a mat­
ter cast afore hand, a thing done for 
the nonce.

Projecter, or pourjecter, to describe
or draw a thing before, to cast in his 
minde, to purpose.

Il a fait ainsi son project, so he hath
cast in his minde, he hath so purpo­
sed, so he maketh his accompt.

Vn project, or pourtraict, the plat of
any building cast before: m.

Projects de maisons, when houses





haue a little forecast or wall before
the gate, the iutting or coping of a
wall: m.

Prolation, pronouncing or profering
of words: f.

Prolixe & long, tedious, long, com.

Il est trop prolixe, hee is too long, too
tedious.

Prolixement, at length, at large, te­
diously.

Prologue, preface, or preambule, a
Prologue or Preface: m.

Prolonger, to prolong, to detract time,
to deferre.

Prolongé, prolonged, deferred.

Prolongation: f: ou prolongement:
m: a prolonging, a deferring.

Prolongement de temps, delaying,
or deferring of time.

Promener, seeke pourmener, to
walke.

Promettre, je promes, je promi, j'ay
promis, je prometray, to promise.

Promettre mons & vaux, to promise
mountaines of gold.

Promis, promised.

Promesse, a promise: f.

Accomplir sa promesse, to fulfill a 
promise.

Tenir sa promesse, to keepe promise,
to stand to his word.

Grand prometeur, he that promi­
seth much, but performeth nothing:
masc.

Promeu, promotion, seeke promou­
voir.

Promontoire, or roche penchant
sur la mer, an hill lying or hanging
vpon the sea like an elbow of land,
a promontorie: m.

Promoteur en cour d'églize, a Pro­
ctor in the Spirituall court: m.

Promouvoir, to aduance, as Promou­
voir aucun à quelque estat, to ad­
uance one into some dignitie or e­
state: decline as Mouvoir.

Promeu aux estats, aduaunced, pro­
moted.

Prompt, prest & appareillé, prompt,
readie: m.

Promptitude, f: readinesse.

Promptement, readily.

Prone, as faire le prone when after
the Creed at the seruice vpon Sun­
daies, the Minister goeth vp into
the pulpit, then hauing done the ac­
customed prayers, he declareth vn­
to the people if there be any holy­
dayes or fasting dayes in the weeke
following, al which ceremonies done 
at that time, we comprehend vnder
this word Prone: m.

Prononcer, to pronounce.

Vne prononciation, a pronouncing: f.

Prophete, a Prophet: m.

Prophetie & annoncement des cho­
ses advenir, a Prophecie or fore­
shewing of things to come: f.

Prophetizer, to prophecie.

Propice, com: mercifull, also fit, pro­
per, as Cecy m'est bien propice,
that is, qui me convient, that is
very proper and fit for me.

Proportion, proportion: f.

Proportionner, to make a thing with
good proportion or measure.

Proportionellement, proportiona­
bly.





Propos & intention, a purpose and
intent: m.

Propos & devis, a speech, a talke.

Tout à propos, of purpose.

A quel propos dis-tu cecy? où tend
ce propos? to what end or purpose
speakest thou that?

Parler bien à propos, to speake very
aptly.

C'est argent m'est venu fort à pro­
pos, this money is come to me verie
fitly at the pinch.

I'ay ferme propos de, &c. I am de­
termined to, &c.

Qui demeure en son propos, which
is stedfast in his mind.

De propos deliberé, of a set purpose,
determinately.

Proposer en soymesme, to purpose
in himselfe.

Proposer & mettre au devant sa vie
aux jeunes enfans pour la suyvre,
 to set forth his life for others to fol­
low.

Proposition,: a proposition in Logick,
a question put forth.

Propre & appartenant à aucun, pro­
per or belonging to any.

De ma propre malice, of mine owne 
proper malice.

Propre & peculier, proper and pecu­
liar.

Fort propre & convenant, very pro­
per and fit, com.

Mal propre, vnhandsome.

Proprement, properly, aptly, decently,
comely.

Propreté & seance, neatnesse, fit­
nesse: f.

I'ay fait cela de ma propre main, I
haue done that with myne owne
hand.

Il est propre à toutes choses, is pro­
per and fit to do all things.

C'est vn home mal propre & ave­
nant, the contrarie.

Qui n'est point propre aux lettres, 
 vnfit to learning.

Proprieté & appertenance proprie­
tie or owning: f.

Proprietaire, an owner: m.

Le Seigneur proprietaire, the Land­
lord of any ground or land.

Proprieté de quelque chose acquise
par prescription, a proprietie got­
ten by prescription.

Propugnacle, a defence: m.

Proroguer, ou prolonger, to prorogue,
to prolong, to deferre.

Commission prorogée par le peu­
ple, a commission lengthened by the
people.

Prorogation ou prolongement, de­
ferring: f.

Proscrire & mettre en criée, ou en
vente, to put to port sale.

Proscrire aucun, that is, donner pu­
issance au premier qui le trou­
verra de le tuer, & ce avec loyer,
 to outlawe one, to giue power that
whosoeuer shall finde him, doe kill
him, and that with a reward.

Proscription, such a licence to kill: f.

Proscription, an attainder.

Prose, prose: f.

Prosperer, to prosper, to thriue.

Prosperité, quand les choses nous
viennent à souhait, prosperitie: f.





Prosperément, prosperously.

Prosterner & ruer par terre, to fall
flat to the ground: to cast one to the
ground.

Estre prosterné devant les pieds de
quelqu'vn, to lye prostrate at ones
feete.

Prostration, a prostrating, or falling
at ones feete: f.

Prostituër, to set open to euery man
that commeth: as il a prostitué sa
fille, sa fame, he hath abandoned
his daughter, his wife, to be abused
in her bodie by euery man.

Elle s'est prostituée à tous venans, 
 she hath giuen her selfe to be abused
of all commers.

Prostitution, that fact: f.

Demourer en la protection & sau­
vegarde de peuple, to remaine vn­
der the protection and sauegard of
the people: f.

Protecteur, a protector: m.

Protectrice, a she protector: f.

Proterve & arrogant, proude, mala­
part, arrogant, com.

Protervement, frowardly, arrogant­
ly, fiersly, knauishly, proudly.

Proterve, com: arrogant, proude,
knapish, saucie, malapert, knauish,
foolish."knapish" not found in OED; possibly a form like "(n)apish." 

Protervement, malapertly, proudly,
saucelie, arrogantly, &c.

Protervie, waywardnesse, arrogancie,
saucinesse: f.

Protester, to protest.

Prothocolles, protecooles, or porte­
colles: m: the first copies or origi­
nall of writings: also he which doth
prompt to players vpon the scaffold.

Prou, j'ay enduré prou de maux, I haue
suffered much sorrowe.

En avez vous prou? haue you e­
nough?

Bon prou leur face, much good may
it do vnto them.

La prouë, ou le devant d'vne navié
re, the forepart of a ship: the fore­
ship: f: the decke.

La Provende d'un cheval, the bread
or oates for horses: f.

Proverbe, a prouerbe, an adage: m.

Les prouësses & haults faicts de 
quelqu'vn, the prowesse or noble
acts of one: f.

Prouësse, valiantnesse: f.

Proufit, profit, gaine, commoditie: m.

Il y a du proufit en ces choses là,
 there is profite in those things.

proufiter, to profite, to gaine.

Proufiter en biens, to waxe rich.

Vtile & proufitable, com: profita­
ble, commodious.

Proufitablement, profitably, commo­
diously.

Proujecter, see Projecter.

Vn Prouïn, a yong braunch of a vine:
masc.

Prouigner vne vigne, to plant a vine.

Prouigner des proces, to procreate,
ingender, and as it were to cause to
rise ones sute or matter in lawe, of
another.

Prouignement, a planting: m.

Providence divine, the diuine proui­
dence: f.

Province, a Prouince: f.

Provision, a prouision, seeke Prouvoir.





Letres de Provision, letters of con­
firmation.

Confirmation d'un of­
fice, the confirmation of an office
ratified by the Prince.

Provisional, as edict provisional, a
law for a time: m.

Arrest provisional, a iudgement or 
sentence giuen for a season.

Proumouvoir, seeke promovoir.

Provoquer, to prouoke, to stirre, to
moue.

Provocation, a prouoking: f.

Provocatoires donnez à l'home de
guerre vainqueur, de celuy par
lequel il avoit esté deffié, the gift
giuen vnto the victor, for the vic­
torie gotten ouer him, that had cha­
lenged him to the fight.

Prouvende, see Provende.

Provoqué, prouoked.

Prouver, to proue, to approue.

Prouver faulsaire, to proue one false, a
forger.

Prouver nostre dire, to approue our
sayings.

Probable, which may be proued, com.

Probablement, probably, with likely
proofe.

Probableté, or probabilité, likenesse
of truth, probabilitie: f.

Probation, proofe: f.

Prouve, a proofe, a say, a triall: f.

Preuve, a triall, a temptation: f.

Faire preuve, or esprouver, to trye
one.

Faire preuve & l'essay du vin, to as­
say and tast the wine.

Il y a assez de preuve, thou bringest
much reason or proofe.

Preuvé par tesmoins, tiltres & en­
seignemens, a proofe either by wit­
nesses, title, or euidences.

Prouvoir à quelque chose, to pro­
uide for a thing, je prouvoy, je
prouveu, j'ay prouveu, je prou­
voirray.

Lon Prouvoirra à tout, it shall bee
prouided for all: order shall be ta­
ken, &c.

Prouvoir & se donner garde, to fore­
see and beware of, &c.

Tu t'est prouveu, thou wast ware of
it.

Prouvoyant à ses affaires, prouiding
for his businesse.

Prouvoyance, prouision: f.

La provision de la maison, the pro­
uision belonging to a house: f.

Faire provision d'argent, to prouide
money.

Proximité, nighnesse, the nighest de­
gree of kinred, neighbourhood: f.

Proye, a pray: f.

Prudence, quand quelqu'vn sçait
que c'est de bien & de mal, wise­
dome, prudence: f.

Prudent & sage, wise, sage.

Prudemmment, wisely.

Prune, a plum, a damson: f.

Prunes de damas, a damson.

Pruneaux, prunes: m.

Vn prunier, a damson tree: m.

Vne Prunelle,  a wild sloe: f.

La Prunelle de l'œil, the apple of the
eye.

Vn Prunelier, a sloe tree: m.

Vn Psalme, or pseaulme, a psalme: m.





Psalmodier, to sing songes to God, to
sing psalmes.

Psalmodie, the singing of psalmes: f.

Psaultier, a Psalter: m.

Ptisaine, seeke Tisane.

Puant, stinking, or he which stin­
keth: m.

Puante, she that stinketh: f.

Bestes puantes, stinking beastes a­
mong hunters are the wilde Bore,
Foxes, and such like.

Puanteur, stinke: as quelle puante­
ur est cecy? what stinke is this? f.

Puantise, idem.

Puir, to stinke: as Il put comme cha­
rongue, he stinketh like a caraine,
je pus, tu pus, il put, &c.

Publier, to publish.

Publier à son de trompe & cri pub­
lic, to make a proclamation.

Leu, Publié, & enregistré, read, publi­
shed, and inregistred.

Publieur, the crier, he that doth pub­
lishe: m.

Publié, published.

Public, publike, common.

Publication de livres, a publishing or
setting forth of bookes: f.

Publicain, a tole gatherer among the
Iewes.

Publiquement, publiquely, openly.

Pucelle, a maide, a virgin: f.

Pucelle de Marolle, a nicke name gi­
uen to corrupted or defiled maiden,
it is supposed that at that Village
named Marrolle, a virgine of fif­
teene yeeres of age is hard to be
found.

Pucellage, maidenhead, virginitie.

Pudique, com: chaste, vne fame
pudique, a chaste woman or wife.
impudique, com: is the contrary.

Pudicité, chastitie, shamefastnes,
honestie in liuing: f.

Pudiquement, chastly, honestly, shame­
fastly.

Puer la vigne, to cut the vine.

Puir, to stinke, je pus, je puiray, tu
puiras, il puira, for the future tense.

Puis apres, then after.

Puis que je, &c. seeing that I, &c.

Puis qu'ainsi est, je &c. seeing it is
so, &c.

Puis qu'il vous plait, je le feray, see­
ing that it pleaseth you so, I will
doe it.

Depuis, since, some doe say, Du de­
puis, in steed of Depuis, but it smel­
leth the Normans soyle.

Depuis le matin, since morning.

Et Puis, qu'en est-il? well, how goeth
the matter?

Puisné, the yonger borne: m.

Cest la puisnée, she is the younger.

Vn Puis, a well: m.

Puis qui ne tarist point, a well, which
is neuer dried vp.

Vn Puitier, he that diggeth welles: m.

Puiser de leauë, to draw vp water out
of a well.

Puisement, a drawing out: m.

Povoir & puissance, power and
might: m.

Force & puissance, strength: f.

Chacun selon sa puissance, eche one
according to his possibilitie.

Puissance & authorité, power and
authoritie.





Puissant, mighty, strong, valiant, 
rich.

Il est riche & puissant, he is rich and 
wealthy.

Combien qu'il soit puissant en terres
& tresors, si est-ce qu'il n'est pas
meilleur que moy, although he be
mighty in land and treasure, yet he
is not better then I.

C'est vn puissant home, hee is a
strong man.

Puissamment, mightily, strongly, va­
liantly.

Puitier, see puis.

Vne pulce, a flea: f.

Ce lict est plein de pulses, this bed is
full of fleas.

Pulcier, a man, place, dog full of Fleas.

Fame ou chambre pulciere, a woman
or chamber full of fleas.

Pulluler, & bourgeonner, to budde
out.

Poulpite, seeke poulpitre.

Pulveriser, to beate to pouder.

Poyvre pulverisé, peper beaten to
pouder.

Vn home punais, a man with a stin­
king breath.

Elle est punaise, she hath a stinking
breath.

Ostez moy este punaise de devant
moy, away with this stinking whore
out of my presence.

Punaisie, a stinche or stinking sa­
uour: f.

Vne punaise, a stinking kind of worm
breeding in wood, but specially in
the creuises of a bedsted, and in the
night doe disquiet one by their by­
ting: the Latins doe call it Cimex
the Italians Cimici.

L'herbe aux punaises, an herbe that
killeth such wormes.

Punction, a pricking: f.

Punctuër vne oraison, or vne let­
tre, to make an Oration or le­
ter with points, to obserue or keepe
the pointes.

Punctuätion, pointing, noting or
making with points.

Puir, je punis, je puni, j'ay pu­
ni, je puniray, to punishe, to cor­
rect.

Ie te puniray tellement, que les au­
tres y prendront exemple, I will
correct thee in that order, that all
others shall take example by thee.

Cas punissable, com: deed worthy of
punishment.

Punisseur, he which punisheth: m.

O cas digne de punition, a deed wor­
thy of punishment, punishing or cor­
rection.

Pupile ou mineur, an vnderling,
masc.

Biens pupilaires, pupils goods.

Pur, pure, cleane, neate.

Pur & entier, pure and whole, per­
fite.

Purement, purely.

Pureté & innocence, purenesse and
innocencie: f.

De la purée de poix, Pease strai­
ned: f.

Purer, quand vne apostume rend
de la bouë, to cast out matter as a
sore doth.

Purger, to purge, to clense.





Purgé, purged, clensed.

Purgation, purgation: f.

Purgation de quelque cas qu'on
met sus, when one maketh his pur­
gation of a fault or crime laid to his
charge.

Purgatoire, purgatorie: m.

Purifier, to purifie, to make cleane.

Purification, cleansing: f.

Purpurin, purple-like.

Pusillanimité, fainthartednesse, or
cowardise: f.

Pusillanime, com: a weake man, of lit­
tle courage, faintharted: m.

Vne pustule, a wheale or blister: f.

Pustuleux, full of wheales or blisters.

Vne Putain, a whore or harlot: f.

Se deffaire d'vne putain, to be rid of
a whore: of a strumpet.

Putier, a whoremunger, a whore-hun­
ter, a Ruffian: m.

Putasserie, a whorehunting: f.

Putatif, as pere putatif taken or estee­
med for a father.

Vn putoir, a stinke, euill sauour, a
whoremaister is also called Putoir,
for commonly such villains do stink
and smell strong.

Se putrifier, to waxe rotten or cor­
rupted.

Putrifié, rotten, corrupted.

Putréfaction, rottennesse: f.

Putréfactif, & corrosif, that hath the
strength to eate rotten flesh.

Pyramide, see Piramide.

Piralides, f: are certain fourefooted
beastes or wormes flying and found
in the Iland of Cyprus, of such na­
ture, that they liue in the fier, so that
being kept but a while from it, they
dye.

Pyrethre or pied d'Alexandre, a 
kinde of herbe kept in ones mouth,
causeth much water to come out.

Les monts Pyrénées, the moun­
taines that doe parte Fraunce from
Spaine: m.


Q ante V.

WHeresoeuer you find q, before
u, sound it as k, so in steed of
Quadragenaire, fortie yeeres of age,
pronounce it, as if it were written:
kadragenaire.

Quadran au soleil, m: a Sunne diall."sun-dial" antedates earliest OED citation (1599).

Quadrangulaire, or quadrangule,
com. gen: of foure-square, or cor­
ners.

Quadrer & convenir, to be iustly a­
greeing, to serue aptly in a place, to
agree, to be fit, to fit well.

Quadrin, vn Liard, a peece of 
French money little more worth
then a farthing: m.

Quadruple, quatrefois autant, foure
times as much, fourefolde.

Quadrupler, to folde, renue, or reite­
rate a matter foure times.

La quadruple du defendeur, the
fourth reply of the defendant.

Quadruplication, a repeating foure
times.

Quaisse, seeke Quesse.

Qualité, qualitie: f.

Les qualitez qui accompaignent
vne chacune chose, the qualities
which are annexed or ioyned in a­





nye thing, as time, place, breadth,
length, &c.

Les tiltres & qualitez de chasque
personne, the titles and qualities
of each person.

Selon la qualité de la cause, il fault
choisir vn advocat des plus grans,
des moyens, ou des moindres,
 as the matter is weightie, so it be­
houeth to choose a Counsaylour ei­
ther the best learned and of greatest
authority, meane sort, or of the low­
est estate and calling.

Prendre qualité de noblesse, de tu­
teur, d'exécuteur de testament, to
take vpon him the title, name or
qualitie of nobilitie, tutor or exe­
cutor of ones last will.

Estre qualifié prince de l'empire, to
be admitted to beare the title of a
prince of th' Empire.

Quand sera-ce? when shall it be?

Quand il me souvient, now when I
remember.

D'icy à quand? how long?

Quant à ce, &c. as for that.

Quant à mon regard, as touching
my selfe, &c.

Quant à ce que tu m'escris, tou­
ching that which thou doost write
to me.

Quant est de moy, as for me.

Quant ores tu me devrois tuer,
si ne le feray-je point, though
thou shouldst kill me, yet I wil not
doe it.

I'yray quant & quant vous, I will
goe altogether with you.

Quant & quant, forthwith, there­
with.

Quantes fois? how oft?

Ie ne sçay quantes ou combien de
fois, I know not how many times, 
or how often.

Toutes & Quantes fois, as often as.

Quantiesme? what number, order?

Di moy le quantiesme tu es, tell me
of what order or place thou art, that 
is, if thou be the firste, second, the
third, the ninth, &c.

Le quantiesme, or la quantiesme
est-ce? of what number, order, or
place is it?

Quantité, quantitie, muchnesse: f.

Quaquet, a pratling, babling, chat­
ting: m.

Ie rabbaisseray ton quaquet, I will
bring downe thy pratling.

Quaqueter, to prate, to chat.

C'est assez Quaqueté, thou hast pra­
ted enough.

Compagnon à quaqueter & plai­
santer, a mery companion that kee­
peth company in mery conceits and
pleasant deuises.

Quaquetement, a pratling: m.

Quaqueteur, a pratler: m.

Quarante, fortie.

Quarantiesme, the fortieth.

Quaresme, Lent: m.

Quaresme prenant, or le Mardigras
 Shroue-tuesday.

Qurantaine, Idem: also the time con­
taining fortie daies of praier for the
dead.

Quaresmer, to keep and obserue Lent
as the papists doe.

Vn Quarlet, m: a Plaice, or fish.





Vn Quarquan, ornement & ba­
gue qu'on pend au col, a Iew­
ell to hang about ones necke, a car­
kenet: m.

Quarquan à mettre le col des mal­
faicteurs, a pillory, a coller of iron to
put about the necke of prisoners.

Quarré, fouresquare.

Vn quarré, a square: m.

Quarrer, ou escarrir, to square
out.

Quatre pieds en quarreur, foure
foote square: f.

Le quarreau d'vne colonne, the 
square of a pillar: m.

Vn Quarreau d'arbaleste, the bolt of
a crosse-bowe.

Quarreaux de jardins, the beds of a 
garden.

Acoutrer les Quarreaux es jar­
dins, to dresse the beds in a Gar­
den.

Le quarreau a perdu ses herbes, the
bed of herbes is withered.

Apportez moy vn quarreau, bring
me a cushin: m.

Quarreau or brique, a bricke.

Quarreler or paver de quarreaux, to
paue a chamber or hall with bricks.

Quarre-four, a street or way hauing
foure corners, a foure cornerd street
or way: m.

Il a esté fouëtté par tous les quarre­
fours de Londres, hee hath beene
whipped through all the foure cor­
ners of London.

Quarlet, m: ou plye, f: a plaise fishe.

Quarlets, plaices.

Quarriéres, quaries of stone: f.

Quarrieur, or quarrier, a hewer of
stones: m.

Prendre quarriére, to take his course
in running at tilt.

Donner quarriére à vn cheual, to 
try a horse in running.

Finir sa quarriére, when a man of
armes hauing broken his speare
doth finish his course.

Donner quarriére, also it is to put his
enemies to flight.

Quarreler des souliers, to sole, to 
cobble shooes.

Carreleure de souliers, the soale of
ones shooes: f.

Quarreleur de souliers, a Cobler: 
masc.

Le quart ou quatriesme, the quarter
or fourth part.

Quartaux, a certaine measure of corn
or salte in Fraunce aboue the bushel
of London.

Quarte à vin, a quarte of wine: f.

La Quarte partie de la journée,
d'vn jour, the quarter of a dayes
worke.

Vn quartier, a quarter: m.

Les quartiers d'vne ville, the quar­
ters of a towne.

Vn quartenier de ville, the Alder­
man of the warde: m.

Quartenier or Commissaires des
quartiers, I take to be the iustices
of peace in the Countrey.

Quartement, fourthly.

Quasi, presque, almost.

Il l'a quasi tué almost he hath killed
him.

Ie suy quasi tombé, I did almost fall.





Quasser & briser, to breake, to quash
in peeces.

Quatorze, fourteene.

Quatre, foure.

Quatre fois, foure times.

Quatre fois autant, foure times as
much.

Les quatre temps, foure times in the
yeere appointed for to keepe fast,
imbrer dayes: m.

Le quatriesme, the fourth.

La Quatriesme foys, the fourth
time.

Quatroille, is a certaine readish spot
in dogges: as, les chiens gris sur l'­
eschine, quatroilles de ronge, et
comme la couleur de la jambe d'­
vn lievre, sont les meilleurs, dogges
gray vpon the backe, spotted with
red, and like haire and colour as a 
hares legge, be the best.

Vn quay, or perron, a piller of mar­
ble, or stone: m.

Sur le quay, vpon the keye on the ri­
uers side.

Que, that, which, but, sauing, ex­
cept.

Que fais tu? what doest thou?

Qu'est cela? what is that?

Qu'en est-il? what is thereby?

Que veux tu? what wilte thou
haue?

Quel? what maner of thing?

Quel home? what man?

En quelle maniére? in what ma­
ner?

Quelle, quelle soit qui a dit cela, je
dys, que c'est vne putain, what so­
euer she is that hath spoken that,
I say she is a whore.

Quelque, something.

Quelque prix que ce soit, que j'en
aye, what soeuer it cost, or what price
soeuer, &c.

Si je vous ay fait quelque chose qui
vous plaise, &c. if I haue done any
thing that pleaseth you, &c.

Ya-il quelcun qui se plaigne de moy,
 is there any body that complaineth
of me?

Quelconque, chacun, what soeuer.

Quelqu'vn entre le peuple, some
man amongst the people.

Vne quenouille, a distaffe: f.

Allez filer vostre quenouille, go spin
your distaffe.

Quenouille rustique, or safran ba­
stard, an hearbes name.

Quenouillée, or poupée de filace, a
distaffe full of flaxe: f.

Vne querelle, a quarell, a debate, a
strife: f.

Demesler vne Querelle à coups
d'espée, to end a quarell with the
sword.

Entrer en querelle, to enter into a
quarell.

Laisser toutes Querelles & de­
bats, to giue ouer all quarels and
strifes.

Quereller vn heritage, to pretend
right in a peece of ground.

Ie n'y querelle tien, I pretend no title 
therein.

Quereleux, a contentious fellowe, 
a wrangler, a common picker of
quarels: m.

Querir, je quiers, je quis, jay quis,





je querray, to seeke, to fetch, to cal
one.

I'ay quis cela dés le commancement, 
 I haue sought that from the be­
ginning.

Allez querir Iehan pour disner, goe
fetch Iohn to dinner.

Envoyez le querir je vous prie, 
 send for him I pray you.

Envoyons querir du secours, let vs
send for succour.

Querquois, carcois, trousse, or Car­
quois, estui àe segettes, traicts, fle­
ches & viretons, a quiuer: m.

Quesse, a square chest of wood to put
marchandise in, or to carry armour
or such like thing: f.

Queste, as se mettre en queste
pour trouver quelcun, to take
his iourney to see if hee can finde
one: f.

Lettre de queste, a licence to gather
for the almes of people as we see in
churches.

Questeurs, such as beg with authori­
tie or licence: m.

La queste ou enqueste que fait vn
Iuge en vne cause, the inquirie
that a Iudge doth cause to be made
vpon any matter.

Quester, to begge or to seeke ear­
nestly.

Quester et lever l'a proye au fond
d'aultruy, to search & raise a pray
in another mans ground.

Question ou doute, a question or
doubt: f.

Souldre vne question, to assoyle or
resolue a question.

Il est icy question de la vie, this is
touching ones life, here is a matter
of life and death.

Il n'est pas maintenant question
d'ont procede la maladie, mais
de quoy on la guarist, heere we
dispute not from whence procee­
deth the sickenesse, but how it may
be healed.

Il est question de quelque argent, 
 it is a money matter,

Il n'est pas question de cecy, we
passe not for this, it is not this that
doth trouble vs, it is not touching
this.

Il est la question de l'honneur &
crédit, this is already touching ones
honour and credit.

La chose dont est question, the
matter that we are about, the
matter that we haue in hande to
treate of.

Bailler la question, gehenne & tor­
ture pour sçavoir d'vn faict, to put
one on the racke or pinbanke.

Questionner aucun, to aske of one, to
enquire.

Questionnette, a little question: f.

Vne science or art questuaire, a sci­
ence or trade bringing profit.

Queu, queux or cuisinier, a cooke:
masc.

Le maistre queux, the maister cooke.

La queuë, the taile: f.

Queuë de aronde en matiéte de
charpenterie ou menuïserie, a fa­
stning of boords together in maner
of a doues taile: f.

La Queuë d'vne poire, & autres





fruits, the stalke of a peare or other
fruit.

Couper la Queuë au jeu, when one
hath gotten an other mans money
at dice, cutteth off or giueth ouer
play: to this effect Marot saith, vous
mavez coupé la queuë, feriez
vous bien aise qui la vous coupe­
roit? speech with a double meaning.

Donner sur la queuë d'vne armée,
 to fall vpon the backeward of an
army.

Mener la queuë d'vne armée, to lead
the rereward of an army.

Remuër la Queuë, to wagge the
tayle.

La difficulté sera à la queuë, the
hardest or most difficultest wil be at
the end.

Queuë de cheval, de regnard, de
porceau, descorpion, all those bee
the names of herbes.

Queué, qui a vne queuë, one that
hath a taile: m.

Queuë, queus, or queut à aguïser
ferrements, a whetstone: f.

Qui suis-je? who am I?

Qui que tu voudras, whomesoeuer
thou willest.

Qui que ce soit, qu'il entre, whosoe­
uer he be, let him come in.

Qui est ce qui est leans? who is it
which is there within?

Et qui plus est, and that which is
more.

Qui ça, qui là, now here, now there: or
ils estoyent cachez, qui ça, qui là,
they were hidden, this man here, &
this there.

Qui est-ce qui me demande? who
asketh after me?

Qui est tu? what art thou?

Il n'y a personne de nous, qui ne l'­
eust fait, there is not one amongst
vs, but had done it.

Cela a esté fait, voire et dedans la 
cour, qui plus est: that hath beene
done, yea within the courte, which is
more.

Quicunque, whatsoeuer.

Quicter, to acquite.

Quicter la place, to leaue the place,
seeke Quiter.

Quictance, a quittance: f.

Bailler quictance, to giue on a qui­
tance.

Quid, pro quo, to take one in stead of
the other, as when Apothecaries doe
take one drug for another.

Vn quignon de pain, a good peece of
bread: m.

Vn petit quignet, a little corner: m.

Maistre pierre du quignet, a mon­
strous Image of stone at our Ladies
Church in Paris.

Quilles, as jouër aux quilles, to play
at nine pins: f.

La quille d'un navire qui soustient
les costes, that peece of wood of a 
ship which vpholdeth the sides.

Quillevilles, a kinde of roote called
Cheruice: f."chervice" not found in OED; possibly it is an error for "chervil."

Quinaud, singe, or marmot, an Ape,
a Monkie: m.

Tu es vn laid quinaud, thou art a
foule Monkie.

Quinaude, a shee Ape or Monkie: f.

Ie l'ay rendu quinaud, ou je l'ay fait





quinaud, in disputing or arguing, I
haue set him to the wall, I haue
made him ashamed.

Quinconcé, as vergier & jardin quin­
concé, an Orchard and garden set
by line and leuell.

Quine, as faire la quine à quelcun,
 to make a mouth at one, to mocke
one: f.

Quinette, the staffe whereon a criple
doth stay or leane: f.

Vn quinquaillier, he that selleth all
kind of old yron, also a pedler: m.

Quinquailles, such old yron things:
fem.

Quinquennel, a time or terme of fiue
yeares: m.

Conceder vne Quinquenelle à vn
banqueroutier, to graunt a time of
payment to a banquerupt: f.

Quint, or cinquiesme, the fifth.

Quintaine, as jouster à la quin­
taine, a piece of wood whereon han­
geth the ring when yong gentlemen
begin to learne to run: f.

Quintefueille, herbe, an herbe called
Cinkefield: f.

Quintement, fiftly.

Quinze, fifteene.

Quinze fois, fifteene times.

Quis, or cerché, sought, as je l'ay tant
quis, qu'à la fin je l'ay trouvé, I
haue sought him so long, that at 
length I haue found him.

Que quiers-tu? what doest thou looke
or seeke for?

Nous querons ce que nous ne trou­
vons pas, we seeke that we finde
not.

Tant quist-il son pere, qu'il le trou­
va, he sought his father so long, that
he found him.

Où l'as tu quise? where hast thou
sought her?

Quiter, to acquite, to discharge one
of a debt.

Ie vous quite & remets la debte, le
serment, la peine, I do acquite and
remit vnto you the debt, the othe
made vnto me, the paine.

Quiter à quelcun sa dignité, to yeeld
to one his dignitie.

Quiter son droit, to giue ouer his 
right.

Faire quiter à l'ennemi son fort, la
place, la ville, le camp, to driue his 
enemie to voyde his Fort or Hold,
the place, the towne, the campe.

Renoncer & quiter son office, to
yeeld vp his office.

Quiter les plaidoiries, that is, ne
plaider plus, to giue ouer the law.

Ie vous quite la trosieme partie de
la debte, I remit you the third part
of the debt.

Ie luy ay quité le tout, I haue remit­
ted vnto him the whole, I haue yeel­
ded vp to him the matter, I haue 
giuen him the vpper hand.

Tu n'en demeureras pas quite si je
vis, thou shalt not remaine vnpuni­
shed if I liue.

Iouër à quite ou à double, to play
double or quit.

Quitance, a quittance: f.

Quitement, or paisiblement, peace­
ably, without let.

Ie te lairray aller quitement & fran­





chement, I will suffer thee to goe
quietly.

Vne quote, ou quelque partie, a
part, or portion: f.

Quoter & marquer l'article que on
veult impugner, to quote or marke
in the margent.

Quouät, m: see Couät.

Quoy? qu'est cela? what? what is
that?

Quotidien, daily.

Queuë, a taile: f.

Quoy qu'on l'achette, how deare so
euer it be bought.

Quoy qu'il en soit, whatsoeuer it be.

Quoy que luy mesmes le die, though
he himselfe saith it.

C'est quelque grand chose, quoy
qu'il en soit, it is some great mat­
ter whatsoeuer it be.

I'ay Dieu merci de quoy, paier
ce dont est question, I haue where­
with (God be thanked) to pay that
which is in controuersie.

Il n'a de quoy souper le povre ho­
me, the poore soule hath not to pay
for his supper.

De quoy me sert d'avoir tant d'es­
cus, si je n'en vse? what commodi­
tie is it to me to haue so many Freench
Crownes, if I take not the vse of
them?

I'ay heu de quoy, mais maintenant,
je n'ay plus rien, I haue been able
to liue, but now I am not.

Si tu as mieux de quoy que moy,
soupe deux fois, if thou be richer
than I, than sup twise.

Vierge, pucelle, fille, qui n'a de quoy
pour estre mariée, a virgin or mai­
den which hath nothing towards
her mariage.

Avoir bien de quoy, to haue some­
what to take to, to be rich.


R ante A.

RAbbaisser vne personne qui s'­
eslevoit trop, to pluck one down
that was too presumptuous.

Rabais, abatement: m.

Rabaisseur d'orgueil, m: one that
bringeth downe the pride of ano­
ther.

Rabaissement d'estat, m: the aba­
sing or decaying of another man
state.

Le rabat d'vn jeu de paulme, the
pent-house of the tennis: m.

Vn Rabat-joye, m: quasi qui rabat,
or rabaisse la ioye, a teller or brin­
ger of euill newes.

Rabalter, to rattle either at ones
dore, or in a chamber or garret, as
it was thought in the olde tyme by
sprites.

Rabbatre du pris, to abate the prise: 
decline it as Battre.

Rabbatre de la somme & diminuër,
 to abate of the summe.

Rabais, m: a bating or diminishing of
any thing or summe.

Rabavit, or Trique-madame, an
hearbe called Sengreene.

Rabe de Limosin, f: a Turnep: see
Rave.

Rabiller & racoustrer vn habille­
ment, to mend a garment.





Rabillement, mending: m.

Rabilleur, m: he that mendeth olde
things.

Rabiliter, ou reabiliter, to repaire, to
amend.

Vn rable, ou rabot à mesler l'arene
& le sable parmi la chaulx, a bea­
ter, such as Plasterers vse to beat
and mingle together their haire &
lime: m.

Le rable d'vn liévre, the loyne of a 
Hare.

Le rable d'vn sanglier, the loyne of a 
wild Bore: m.

Rabot, a Ioyners plane: m.

Raboter, to plane, to make smooth.

Raboteux, rough, as chemin rabo­
teux, a rough way.

Racines rabougries, rootes dried and
parched with heate.

Arbres Rabougries, trees burned
with the Sunne.

Rabroveur de petits enfans, a scour­
ger, a rebuker of children by the
way: m.

La Racaille du peuple, a rascallie
sort of people: f: cullers or robbers."culler" not found in OED in this sense.

Raccointer, see Accointer.

Raccoller, see Accoller.

Se racorder & rallier, to agree again
togither.

Racorder ceux qui sont en discord,
 to make an agreement betweene
those which be in strife.

Raccoupler, to couple againe.

Se racourcir, to shrinke togither, or
to stoupe: je racourcis, je racourci,
j'ay racourci, je racourciray: to
shorten.

Racourci, shrunke.

Raccourcissement, m: shortning.

Raccoustrer, to mende, to trimme a­
gaine.

Racoustreur, a mender or trimmer of
things: m.

Raccoustrement, a mending, a trim­
ming: m.

Raccoustumer, ou ramener quelque
coustume, to bring a custome a­
gaine, to bring in vre againe.

Les gens de ta Race sont bons me­
sangers & bien attrempez, those
that are sprong of thy race & blood,
doe play the good husbands, and are
altogether temperate.

Vne race, a race, an ofspring, a kin­
red, also a sort or kind, as il amena
vne race de chiens, qui, &c. hee 
brought such a kind or sort of dogs,
that, &c.

Rachais, carren leane.

Chevaux plus que rachais, most car­
ren leane Iades.

Rachalander, to call againe his olde
customers.

Rachasser, to driue away againe.

Racheter au poids de l'or, to redeeme
with the weight of gold.

Rachat, ou payement de rançon, a
redeeming or paying of ransome: m.

Raciociner, to reason, to discourse
with himselfe.

Racine, a roote: f.

Racinette, a little roote: f.

Radicalement, from the roote.

Racler, to rake, to scrape, or to grate.

Raclé, scraped, grated.

Vn racloir, a grater, a scraper: m.





Raclure, grating, or scouring: f.

Raconter, to tell, to declare.

Digne d'estre Raconté, worthie of
telling.

Raconteurs de nouvelles, tellers of
newes: m.

Racourir, to run againe.

Rade, the sea shore: f.

Navires en la Rade, in the arbor.

Vn Radeau, or raseau, peeces of tim­
ber pinned together vpon a riuer
seruing for a liter to carrie hay, or
such like thing.

Radicalement, see Racine.

Humeur radicale, speciall or radicall
humour.

Radieux, full of beames: m.

Radoter, to dote.

Radotement, doting: m: dotage.

Vn vieux Radoté, an old doting foole:
masc.

Radouber, to patch, to piece.

Radoubement, a mending: m.

Radresser ou redresser, to amende, to 
correct.

Radressement, a mending: m.

Radresseur, a Corrector: m.

Se Radviser, to take better aduisement,
to change aduise.

Rafflater, to flatter againe.

La raffle d'vne grappe de Raisin, the
stalke of a bunch of grapes, also a 
kind of gaming called Rifling: f.

Iouöns à la Raffle, let vs goe to rife­
ling.

Rafreschir, to refresh, to cheare vp
one.

Rafreschissement, refreshing, chea­
ring: m.

Se Ragaillardir, to waxe merie.

Ragalice, regalice, or riglice, rigo­
lice: m.

Ragats d'eauë, floods of water: m.

Rage, rage, furie: f.

Rager & folatrer, to play the wanton,
to ticke and toy.

Ragement, wantonnesse, or toying: m.

Rageux, a wanton, lasciuious.

Raggrandir, to enlarge, to make
great: see Aggrandir for the de­
clining.

Raie, raier, seeke Rayer.

Rajeunir, to waxe yong againe: je ra­
jeunis, je rajeuni, je suy rajeuni, je
rajeuniray.

Railler & se gaudir d'aucun, to iest
or to flout.

En raillant, iestingly.

Vn railleur ou raillard, a iester: m.

Ce n'est qu'vne Raillarde laissez-la
là, she is but a scold, a pratler, a iar­
ring woman, let her alone: f.

Raillerie, f: flouting, iesting.

Vne Raine, f: a Frog.

Rainette, f: a little Frog.

Rain de baston, m: a bough more
like a staffe which is giuen to those
that doe take, or are put in posses­
sion of any house or ground, to enioy
the same as their owne.

Rainseaux ou rameaux d'arbres,
 boughes of trees: m.

Raiponce, a kinde of hearbe vsed in
Sallets: f.

Raire, to shaue.

Ray ou rasé, shauen: m.

Raiz, seeke Rets.





Cité Rasée, a Citie beaten euen with 
the ground: f.

Vne grappe de Raisin, a bunch of
Grapes: f.

Les Raisins de lierre, the berries of
Iuie.

Raison, reason: f.

Raison pourquoy? a reason why?

A quelle raison? by what reason?

C'est la raison, it is reason.

Ce qui est raisonnable, that which is 
reasonable, com.

Ce n'est pas faict Raisonnablement
à toy, it is not reasonably done of
thee.

Raisonner, to reason, to argue.

Loix raisonnées, lawes hauing their
reasons after them, or annexed to
them.

Raisonnement, a reasoning: m.

Ralentir ses pas, to remit or slacke his
going: je ralentis, je ralenti, j'ay
ralenti, je ralentiray.

Se ralicter, to fall againe sicke.

Raller, to rattle in the throte, as if one
were a dying.

Raller en quelque lieu, to goe again: 
see Retourner.

Rallier, to ioyne togither that which
is scattered.

Ralliement, an attonement, a recon­
ciliation: m.

Rallumer, to kindle againe.

Ramadouër, to flatter againe, to
stroke.

Ramadoux, a Ratte of India of the 
bignes of a Cat, which creepeth into
the Crocodiles mouth when he ga­
peth, and eating his bowels, killeth
him: it is called Rat de pharaon.

Esprevier ramage, a hawke which
hath been among braunches and in
the Forrest: the contrarie is, Espre­
vier royal, a Hawke taken in the
nest: m.

Chant Ramage, a wild singing: m.

Ramaigrir, je ramaigris, je ramai­
gri, je suy ramaigri, je ramaigri­
ray, to waxe leane.

Ramage, les petits oiseaux oublient
leur ramage, the braunch song of
birds: m.

Vn chant Ramage, a wild song, a tune
vsed among the boughes and For­
rest: rusticall.

Ramas & meslange, a gathering to­
gither, a medley: m.

Ramasser, to gather togither.

Ramassé, gathered togither, assem­
bled.

Rambade, as se targer sur la ramba­
de des galleres, to couer himselfe
as with a target vpon the bend, or
the wale of a Galley: f.

Rame de papier, a reame of paper: f.

Rameau, a branch of a tree, a bough:
masc.

La feste des Rameaux, Palme-Son­
day.

Vn Ramaison ou rainceau, a little
bough cut off.

Ramée & fueillée, a shadowe: f.

Ramure ou branchage boughes: f.

La ramure d'vn cerf, the hornes of a 
Hart: f.

Vne Rame ou aviron, an Ore: f.

Ramer, tirer à l'aviron, to rowe.

Ramer des pois, to fasten boughes to





the end that peason may line, being
fastned vpon.

Ramener, to bring againe.

Ramentevoir, je ramentoy, je ra­
menteu, j'ay ramenteu, je ramen­
tevray, to bring to remembrance.

Ilz ramentoivent les arts & s'y exer­
cent, they call to remembrance the 
Artes and sciences, and take exer­
cise therein.

Ramer, see Rame.

Ramieller, to make againe as sweete
as honey: see Amieller.

Ramier, ou coulomb ramier, a stock
doue: m.

Ramilles, small stickes: f.

Raminagrobis, as il fait de son ra­
minagrobis, he counterfeited the
graue and wise person: it is a nicke
name: he goeth ietting.

Ramon, ou ballay, a broome, a be­
some: m.

Ramonner & nettoyre, to sweepe, to
make cleane.

Ramonneur de cheminée, m: a chim­
ney sweeper.

Ramoitir, to soake, to moisten.

Ramollir, to soften a thing: je ra­
mollis, je ramolli, j'ay ramolli, je
ramolliray.

Se ramollir, je me ramollis, je me
ramolli, je me suy ramolli, je me
ramolliray, I am become softer,
more gentle.

Rampar, seeke Rempar.

Ramper ou grimper, to rampe, or
climbe.

Rampement & trainement sur le
ventre ou pieds sur terre, a ram­
ping or creeping on the ground: m.

Rampable, which may be climbed or
gone vpon.

Ramponner vn home, to mocke a 
man.

Ramponne, f: a mockerie, a scoffe.

Ramu, ou branchu, full of boughes.

Ran, ou belier, a Ramme: m.

Ranci, relant, chansi, moisi, rustie,
mustie, fustie, ranke: m.

Rancissure, rustinesse, mustinesse: f.

Rancon, a hedging bill.

Rançon, Rançonner, seeke Rençon.

Rancœur: m: or rancune: f: hatred,
malice, rancour.

S'enfuir à grand randon, to runne a­
way in hast: see Fuir, for the decli­
ning.

Randonner, Idem: as Il s'ensuyoit
tant que le cheval pouvoit ran­
donner, he ran as fast as the horse
could goe.

Rang, an order, a ranke: m.

Ranger, ou Arranger, to sit in order,
to range.

Vne rangée de rames ou avirons, a
rowe of Ores: f.

Rangier, a wild beast betweene a Doe
and a Hart: m.

Ranimer, to reuiue.

Tu m'as Ranimé, thou hast restored
my life againe.

Raouler, seeke Rouler.

Rapacité, rauening: f.

Vne Rape, a raspe or rough file: f.

Raper, to scrape hard, to knock at ones
dore or windowe.

Raphanelle sauvage, Dittander:
Dittanie or Pepperwort: f.





Rapeau, as se venir payer au rapeau,
 to come to the paying place: m: see
Bureau.

Rapé, it is wine hauing the graine of
the Grapes not brused: m.

Rapetacer, & reamender, or ravau­
der, to patch, to peece, to cloute.

Rapiecer, to set a peece.

Rapine, rapine, robberie: f.

Rapiner, to rapine, to robbe, and
spoyle.

Rapineux, a rauener, a robber, a spoi­
ler: m.

Vne Rapiére, a rapier, a sword: f.

Rapoil, an instrument to shaue the
haire: m.

Rappeller, to call againe.

Rappel, a calling agayne, an appeale:
masc.

Rappointer vn home, to set vp again
in order a man in his first estate.

Rappointer vne aiguille, to make a
point to a needle.

Mon espée & dague sont fort bien
rappointées, my sword and dagger
be very well sharpened.

Rapporter, to bring againe.

Faire Rapporter vne chose à vn au­
tre, to make one thing agree with
another.

Ce champ Rapporte & rend beau­
coup, this field yeeldeth much fruit.

Se Rapporter à aucun, to report him
selfe to any man.

Rapporter tout à aucun, Mettre
tout entre les mains d'aucun, to re­
port all to one man, to put all into
his hands.

Rapport, report, or talke.

Grand Rapport de terre, great yeel­
ding of ground.

Rapporteurs de parolles, reporters
of words, whisperers: m.

Ne croyez point aux faulx Rap­
ports, beleeue not false tailes or re­
ports.

Faulx rapporteur, a false reporter, a 
backbiter: m.

Vn bon rapporteur de proces, when
a Iudge or Counsailor in the Lawe
doth rehearse faithfullie and cun­
ningly the whole matter of a suite
before the Iudges.

Rapprendre, to learne againe.

Rapsodie, the gathering or patching
of diuers sentences togither.

Rapt, ou ravissement, rauishing, or
taking away by violence: m.

Raptacer, to mend an old thing.

Vne Raquette, a racket: f.

Ie la Raquoiseray, s'il y a home qui
le puisse faire, I will still or asswage
her, if any man can doe it.

Raquoisé, m: asswaged.

Raquoiser, to still one.

Rare, qui ne se trouve, ou ne se void
point souvent, ne par tout, rare,
greason, daintie.

Ras, as drap d'or ras, & non frizé,
 cloth of gold not frizled: m.

Du Raseau, m: net-worke.

Raser, ou Raire, to shaue.

Rasé, shauen.

Rasement, a shauing: m.

Rasibus, leuell to the ground, euen
with the ground.

Rasibus du casteau, hard by the wal
of the Castle.





Rasoir, a raser: m.

Rasure & effaceure de lettres ou
mots, rasing out of words: f.

Raser vne ville, to make a towne e­
uen to the ground.

Rature de barbe, f: the shauing of
ones beard.

Vn bon Raturier, m: a good Barber
that handleth his rasor finely.

Rasle noir, la roine & comme mere
des cailles, the leader, as if it were
the mother of quailes: there is of
another sort of reddish colour cal­
led Rasle-rouge, ou de genest.

Rassaillir quelcun, to assault one a­
gaine.

Rassasier, to satisfie, to content ones
appetite.

Rassasiment, a satisfying: m.

Rassembler, rabiller, raccoustrer
quelque chose bien proprement,
 to set togither, to mende a thing
finely.

Rasseoir, to sit downe.

Rasseurer, to settle one, to confirme
him being afrayed.

Qui est posé & rassis, a setled man.

Vin Rassis, setled wine: m.

Sens Rassis, a setled mind or sense.

Du pain Rassis, stale bread.

Rassotter, to waxe doltish: to dote.

Vn vieil Rassotté, an old doting foole: 
masc.

Rassottement, dotage: m.

Vn rasteau, a little rake: m.

Rasteler le bled en herbe, to rake the
corne while it is greene.

Rastelier de chevaux, the racke
where they put hay for horses: m.

Rasure, seeke Raser.

Rat, a Rat: m.

Raton, a little mouse.

Ratueul, Raveul, or Loir, a dorme
mouse.

Rat de Pharaon, see Ramadoux.

La rate, the splene: f.

Vne ratiére, a mouse trap: f.

En die chacun sa ratelée, each one
saith his aduise: f.

I'en diray ma ratelée, aussi bien que
les autres, I will tell my sentence, o­
pinion, or minde as well as the rest.

Rateler, to make a noise like an Owle:
to houle.

Rate-penade, see chauve-souris.

Ratifier & approuver, to ratifie, to
approue.

Ratisser, to rake, to scrape, to grate.

Vne ratissoire, a scraper, a grater to
grate bread: f.

Ratteindre en cheminant, to ouer­
take in going.

Raton, see Rat.

Ratraper, to ouertake againe.

Rature, or Rasure, f: a strike.

Faire vn ravage, to make a rode on
the enemies.

Ravager, to spoyle.

Ravaller, rehumer, to swallowe downe 
againe.

Ravallement & amoindrissement, a
falling in price, as the falling of the
market: a debasing: m.

Les vsuriers se pendront, voyant
les bleds & les vins se Ravaller
en prix, Vsurers will hang them­
selues, seeing the price of corne and
wine doth fall.





Ravaller vne personne laquelle s'­
eslevoit par trop, to bring downe 
lowe one which did rise too hye, to
debase a thing.
exeme="sleep(n)" 
Ravasser en dormant, to tosse, and
to bee vnquiete in his sleepe, to
dreame.

Ie n'ay fait que ravasser toute la nu­
it, I haue slept much out of quiet all
the night.

Ravaudeur, qui refait les vieux ha­
billements, a botcher: m.

Ravauderesse, a woman that is a bot­
cher: f.

Vne rave, a rape, or turnep: f.

Vne raviére, the ground where tur­
neps are sowen: f.

Ravine, rage ou ravage d'eauë, great
flouds of water.

Rauir, je ravis, je ravi, j'ay ravi, je ra­
viray, to rauish, to take away by vio­
lence, to rob.

Ravi, rauished.

Ravissant, rauishing.

Ravissement, rauishing, robbing: m.

Ravisseur, m: a rauisher.

Raviser, seeke Radviser.

Se Ravoir, to come againe to him­
selfe.

Vne Ravoire, m: see Ravage.

Rause orgladiolus, herbe, segges or
shere grasse: f.

Ravoler, to flie to vs.

Vne Raye, f: a thornebacke.

Vn Ray ou rayon du Soleil, the
beame of the Sunne, m.

Vn Rayon pour escouler l'aue d'vn
champ, a drane to drawe the water
out of a fielde: m.

Vne Raye, ou Ligne, a row or a line. f.
also a fish called thornebacke.

Les Rayes, or rayons d'vne rouë, the
staues of a wheele: m.

Rayer, Effacer, to race, to crosse
out.

Rayé, crossed out.

Rayére, a long and narowe clefte in a 
Tower or prison for aire: f.

Rayolé, seeke Riolé.

Rayonner, to cast beames as the sun,
starre, or light.

Re, without composition, signifieth
nothing at all, but in composition, it
is taken diuerslie, as it appeareth in
these examples following, where you
shall note that it neuer taketh or ad­
mitteth any apostrophus at all.

Reachet, as le domaine d'vne repub­
lique est subiect à reachet, goods
of the common weale are subiect to
be bought againe if they were solde
before by the prince: m.

Reagal, a kinde of poyson: m.

Reaggravations, f: the second or
thirde excommunications against
the rebels in the Romish church.

Rebaille moy presentement ce que
tu as heu en mariage et va t'en,
 giue mee againe, or restore me that
which thou hadst at thy mariage,
and goe thy way.

Rebailler forme à quelque chose,
 to new make a thing, or giue vnto it
a new forme or shape.

Rabaiser, to kisse againe.

Rebaisotter, to kisse and kisse againe.

Reballier, to sweepe againe.

Rebannir vn home, see Bannir.





Rebanqueter, to make a banket a­
gaine.

Rebaptizer, to baptise againe.

Reaument & de faict, verily, indeed.

Rebarbatif, shrewde, sharpe, curst.

Rebarder vn cheval, to set newlye the
trappings vpon an horse.

Rebaster vn asne, to set againe the
packe-saddle vpon an asse.

Rebastir, to builde againe, see Bastir.

Rebattre vn clou, to driue backe a 
naile.

Rebaudi, merie, liuely: m.

Elle est toute rebaudie, she is all lu­
stie or frolike: f.

Vn Rubec, an instrument of musicke
a rebecke, a fiddle: m.

Qui jouë du rebec, a fidler.

Se rebecquer, to withstand one.

Il a Rebecqué contre moy, he stoode
with me face to face.

Rebeller, to rebell.

Rebelle, com: rebellious.

Rebellion, rebellion: f.

Rebender vn arc, to bend a bowe a­
gaine.

Rebenir, or
rebenistre quelque cho­
se, to blesse or make holy againe.

Rebineurs de choses accordées,
 deniers or gainst-saiers of all such
things as they had agreed vpon.

Reblanchir, to white againe.

Rebobeliner, to mende or newly cob­
ble any thing.

Rebondir, to rebound backe againe.

Reboucher ou Emousser vn tren­
chant ou pointe, to blunt the edge
or point of a thing.

Reboucher vn trou, to stop vp a hole,
to make blunt.

Rebouché, stopped vp.

Rebouchement, a stopping vp: m.

Rebourjonner, to bud againe.

A rebours, arsward, quite contrary,
backward.

Couler à rebours, to flow against the
streame.

Tourner à Rebours, to turne vpside
downe.

Rebouter ses ennemis, to repulse the
enemies.

Le Rebras d'vn bonnet ou chappe­
au, the eares or brimme of a cap or
hatte: m.

Se rebrasser jusques au coude, to
turne his sleeues vp to the elbowe.

Rebrunir, to new burnish, to furbish.

Rebut, casting out, leauings, cullers,
or robbers: m.

Ie n'ay eu que le rebut des autres, I
haue had but th' other leauings, the
cullers.

Ie rebut du peuple, the rascall peo­
ple, the drags of the people, the cul­
leres or robbers of the people.

Rebuté, which hath beene denied, or
had a repulse.

Récaner or rechaner, to bray like an
asse.

Récanement, braying: m.

Receler & cacher, to hide, to conceale.

Receleur, a receiuer: m.

Receleresse, a woman receiuer: f.

Recellement, a concealing: m.

Recellement sans faire semblant de
rien, a dissembling or hiding of a 
matter.

Recent, fresh, now of late.





Recentement, freshly.

or enquirie: f.

Recevoir, je recoy, je receu, j'ay

accept.

Estre receu d'aucun, to be receiued
of one.

receiuer: m.

Faire recepte, to make receipt.

Vn Récépissé, a letter by the which
wee confesse to haue receiued any

Receptacle, a sinke: m.

Reces or decrets, decrees.

Recevable, a thing to be receiued, com.

freshly, seeke Chamailler.

Rechaner, to bray like an Asse.

Rechanger, to change againe.

Rechamailler, to fight & charge one
freshlie.

 to charge againe his enemies.

Recharger par dessus, to ouercharge
one.

Rechasser, to driue away by force.

Rechatouiller, to tickle againe.

Rechauffer, to warme againe, also to
waxe hot.

Vn rechault, a chafing dish, a chafer,
also hote imbers: m.

Se rechausser, to put on againe his ho­
sen or shooes.

De rechef, againe, a fresh, a new.

Recheute, a falling againe: f.

Rechigner, to grudge at one, to grim.

Rechignement, frowning, grudging.

Rechignéement, waywardly, fro­
wardly, lowringly, grimly.

Rechoir, to fall againe, see Choir.

Rechigné & refrongné, a wayward
lowring fellow, a froward.

Faire quelque chose en rechignant,
 to doe a thing grudgingly.

Vn Rechignard, m: a waiward man,
a niggard, a pinch-penny.

Reciner, to go to drinking at after
noone.

Le reciné, the nonchion: m.

Vn recipé d'Apoticaire, m: a re­
cipe, the bill of the Phisition to the 
Apothecarie.

Reciproquement, mutually, one to­
ward another.

Réciproque, one for another.

Reciter, raconter, to recite, to tell a­
gaine, to rehearse.

Recit, a reciting, a declaration: m.

Recitateur, m: the speaker.

Reclain, m, calling for aide or assi­
stance to a superiour.

Reclamation & contredit, a gaine-­
saying.

Reclouër, to naile againe.

Recoiffer, to tier and dresse againe as
women do their heads.

Recognoistre, to acknowledge, to call
to remembrance ones or any things
fauour, shape or likenes.

Tu ne recognois point le bien, et plai­
sir que je t'ay fair, thou dost not ac­
knowledge the good turne that I
haue done to thee.

Ie l'ay recogneu à la fin, & apres





l'avoir bien regarde, I knew him at
length, and after that I behelde him
attentiuely.

Recognoissant le plaisir qu'on luy
a fait, acknowledging, &c.

Avec Recognoissance, f: with thanks
or acknowledge.

Recoigner, to knocke in againe.

Au Recoin, m: to the corner.

Reclamer aucun à son aide, to call
one to his aide, to gainsay.

Il ne cerche que les lieux reclus, he
seeketh but solitarie or hidden pla­
ces or holes.

Les Reclus, religious persons enclosed
in, which come not foorth or to the
sight of the worlde.

Les recluses, nuns so enclosed.

Recoler tesmoings, to call witnesses,
and to examine them againe.

Recoller, to glue againe.

Recolorer vne peinture décolorée,
 to refresh a picture with freshe co­
lour.

Recombatre, to fight againe.

Recombler les fossez, to fill againe
the dikes.

Se recommander à Dieu, to commend
himselfe to God.

Se Recommander à quelqu'vn,
 to commende himselfe to anye o­
ther.

Recommendation non point petite
mais fort affectueuse, most hartie
commendations: f.

Lettres recomandatoires, or recom­
mandatives, letters of commenda­
tions, com. gen.

Recomanderesses, women which com­
maund, and thereby doe get seruice
for maidseruants, praisers of maids
seruants, to get them to good mi­
stresse.

Les recommendaces, praises for
the dead: also praiers to God at a 
mans buriall, in the Romish church.

Recommencer, to begin againe.

Ce sera tousjours à recommencer,
 this will neuer be done, it will be re­
newed euery foote.

C'est à recommencer, les porceaux
y ont esté, a Prouerbe, hogges haue
beene at it, they haue marred all, we
must begin fresh againe.

Recompenser, to recompence, to re­
ward, meede.

Recompense, recompence, or reward:
fem.

Recompensement, a recompensing,
a rewarding: m.

Recompter, to tell money againe.

Se reconcilier avec aucun, to recon­
cile him to one, to attone.

Reconcilier aucun & mettre en
grace, to bring one in fauour a­
gaine.

Reconciliateur, m: a reconciler.

Reconciliation, a reconciling: f.

Reconduire, to bring one home a­
gaine.

Ie vous reconduiray, I will bring you
on your way againe.

Recomforter, to comforte one, to
cheere one vp.

Recomfort, comfort, solace, ease, re­
lease of griefe: m.





Recognoistre, to acknowledge, to be­
know, see cognoistre for the de­
clining.

Recognoissant, a thankefull man.

Recognaissance, acknowledging: f.

Reconsement, hiding: m.

Reconvoyer, to bring one againe.

Ie me recorde, I remember.

Recors, mindefull.

Ils n'ont point esté recors des œu­
vres de Dieu, they were not minde­
full of God his workes.

Recordation & souvenance, remem­
brance: f.

Recoquiller, as if it were to reuiue a­
gaine, to rise, as when a worme is
troden.

Il est tout recoquillé, he is lustie, me­
rie, or altogither liuely, considering
the state where hee was before, see
recroquiller.

Se recoucher, to lye downe againe.

Recouldre, to sowe againe, see coul­
dre.

Recourbé, bent backe.

Recourber, to bend backe.

Avoir recours à l'aide d'aucun, & à
son secours, to haue recourse to 
some man for succour.

Recourse, recourse: f.

Recousu, sowed againe.

Recousure, f: sowing againe.

againe.

Recouvrement, a recouering: m.

Estre à recoy, to be at rest, to be at
quiet.

Lieu où on est à recoy, a quiet
place.

Recracher, to spit out againe.

Recrant, recreant or recreu, tired,

Recreance, f: or lascheté de cœur,
 faintnes of hart.

fresh the minde.

Recreation, recreation: f.

Recreatif en paroles, mery or plea­
sant in words.

Fort recreativement, verye plea­
santly.

Recreance, f: sentence by prouision
deliuering.

Recreance soubz la main du Roy,
 possession giuen by prouision, whilest
the matter is tyred.

Recroistre, to growe againe, to in­
crease.

Recroquiller, to bend, to crooke,

Recroquillement, bending, crooking,

Recru, tired.

La bonne fame, elle est recruë, the
good woman she is tired, wearied: f.

Recréence, f: wearinesse.

Le recteur de l'vniversité, m: the
president of the vniuersitie for that
yeere.

euilir.

Recueil, a gathering togither: m.

Il m'a fait bon recueil, hee gaue me

the decli.

Recuict, sodden againe.

Se Reculer, to drawe backward,





to recule.

Reculer & ne vouloir point venir
au point, to draw backe, & to come
to noe end.

Reculée, a going backe: f.

Reculé, drawen apart.

Reculement, a drawing backewarde:
masc.

A reculons, ou en reculant, backe­
ward, afterward.

Il va à reculons comme les escre­
visses, hee goeth backewarde like a
Crab.

Il fait toutes choses à reculons, he
doth all things arsie versie.

Recuser vn juge, to appeale from a 
Iudge, to refuse him.

Redargution, redarguing, checking: f."redarguing" antedates the earliest OED citation (1635).

com.

Redemander, to aske againe.

Redemption, f: redemtion.

a man.

Rediger par bandes, to bring souldi­
ers into bandes.

Rediger par escript, to bring into
writing.

On m'a redigé en ces extremitez,
 they haue brought me into these ex­
tremities.

Redire & rapporter à quelqu'vn
quelque chose, to tell againe or
report.

Redire souvent vne mesme chose, to 
report a thing often.

Il n'y a que redire en ce fait icy,
 there is nothing to be found faultie
in this fact.

Redicte, a repetition.

Redition, a giuing ouer, or restoring.

Apres la redition de la ville, after
the surrendring of the towne.

Redonder, to redound.

Redorer, to gilt againe.

Redoubler, to double againe, to re­
double.

Redoublement, a redoubling: m.

Reboubter, to feare,

Chose redoubtable, a thing to be
feared: com.

Redresser vne chose bossue, to
set anye manner of crooked thing
streight.

Reduire à neant, to bring al to naught,
je reduis, je redui, j'ay reduit, je re­
duiray.

Reduire en pouldre, to bring to
dust.

Reduire vn enfant gasté, to bring
to goodnesse a childe that is spoy­
led.

Reduict, a secret place: m.

Réel, as prendre les oyseaux à la
cloche ou au réel, to catch birdes
at the bell in a thicket of wood or bu­
shes: m.

Réelle, as vne cause, charge, impost
réelle, & non personnelle, a sute,
charge, or subsidie reall & not per­
sonall: that is, extending vpon the
land, and not vpon the person or
ones body.

Réer, it is the crying of an Harte or 
Hinde.





Refaire les portes qui sont rompu­
es, to mend broken gates, to make
new.

Home bien refect, a fat man: m.

Refection, foode or refection: f.

Refaucher, to new mowe grasse.

Reffe, en Bourbonnois est ce que
les Anglois appellent, hard shell, as
vne noix resse, an hard shell nut.

Refermer, to shut againe.

Reflechir, to bow againe.

Reflourir, to flourish againe.

Reflotter et refleux, see Flotter.

Refociller, to refresh.

Refondre, to cast againe, see Fondre.

Reforger, to forge againe.

Reformer, to reforme.

Reformation, a reformation: f.

Reformateur, a reformer: m.

Vn refort or rave, a rape, a Ra­
dish: m.

Réfor sauvage, a wilde radish.

Refouler le trenchant de quelque
chose, to make blunt the edge of a 
thing.

Refoulé, made blunt.

Refoulement, an abating of the 
edge: m.

Refourbir, to polish againe.

Refrain des balades, the burthen of a 
song, the holding of a song or ballet,
the refret, the foote of a song, ballet
or dittie: the verse enterlaced or of­
ten repeated in a dittie, song or bal­
let.

Refranchir le sault, to ouerleape.

Refrapper, to strike againe.

Refrappé, striken againe.

Refrappement, to strike in againe.

Se refraindre or refreindre, & mode­
rer, to refraine, to forbeare: je re­
frains, je refraigni, j'ay refraint, je
refraindray.

Refrainte, a bridling.

Refrener la hardiesse d'aucun, to a­
bate the courage & boldenes of one,

Refreschir, je refreschis, je refreschi,
j'ay refreschi, je refreschiray, to re­
new or refresh the memorie.

Refreschir vne playe, to renue a 
wound.

Refreter vn naviere, to dresse or set vp
new againe after a shipwracke.

Refrigeratif, m: a cooling thing.

Refrigeration, f: cooling.

Refrigerer, &c. vses de refroidir, pro­
prement se dit d'vne chose qui
par avant boulloit, to coole.

Refriquer vne chose jugée, to renew
a sute in the law, to begin fresh the
sute.

Refroidi, cooled.

Refroidissement, cooling: m.

Se refrongner, to frowne vpon one.

Refrongnement, a frowning vpon
one, frowardnesse: m.

Refrongné, froward, diuers, peruers.

En refrongnant, or refrongnéement,
 frowardly, peruersly, stubbornly.

Refrotter, to rub againe.

Refuge, refuge, succour, helpe.

Faire cession de biens, pour le
dernier refuge, to become as
it were a Bankeroute, for his last
refuge.

Refugiez, all such persons which
haue resorted to a place for refuge
or succour.





Refuir, to flie againe, to shun, to saue.

Refuyant le labeur, flying from la­
bour.

Refuser, to refuse, to deny, to gainsay,
to forsake.

Estre refusé, to be refused or forsaken.

Refus qu'on fait d'aucun, the refu­
sing of any person: m.

Cecy n'est pas de refus, this is not to
bee refused.

Refuter, to refute.

Refutation, f: refuting,

Se Regaillardir, je me regaillardis,
je me regaillardi, je me suy regail­
lardi, je me regaillardiray, to be
merry.

Galler & regaller, to scratch his scabs
and scratch againe.

Regain, foin d'arriere saison, m: the
after gras or after crop of haie, late­
ward haie, fogge, the latter math.

Regale, as droit de regale the right
pertaining to the king.

Regal, or Royal, kingly, pertaining to
a King.

Regallement, or Royallement, roy­
allie.

Regarder, to regarde, to marke, to see,
to looke, to espie.

Regarder dedens, to looke into.

Se regarder & glorifier, to set much
by himselfe.

Regarder attentivement, to glorie.

Regard, m: on regardeure, f: re­
garde, respect.

Pour mon regard je n'en fay conte,
 as for my parte. I make no accompt
thereof.

Regardeure basse, to looke downe.

Regardeur, a looker: m.

Regardement, a looking: m.

Régent, a regent, a schoolemaister, a
gouernour: m.

Il Regele, it freeseth againe.

Il a Regelé ceste nuit, it did freese,

Regenter, to teach in Colleges, whe­
ther it be in the first, second or any
forme.

Il a Regenté troy ans à Oxenfort,
 he hath beene a reader at Oxford
the space of three yeeres.

Le Regent de France, the regent of
N. that is, which gouerneth the
kingdome whilest the king is absent
or vnder age.

Madame la Regente, f: the guberna­
trice or gouernesse of the Realme.

Regence, f: that office of gouernment.

Regermer, to spring againe.

Regimber, to winse, to kicke & fling,
to spurne.

Regimbeur, m: a winser, a kicker.

Regimbement, a winsing, or kicking:
masc.

Vn regime de vivre, an order of diet,
a gouernment.

Vn regiment de gendarmes, a com­
pany or band of Souldiers, or men of
armes: m.

Légion, a region, a realme, a coun­
trey: f.

Régir & gouverner, to rule and go­
uerne, je regis, je regi, j'ay regi, je
regiray.

Regi & gouverné, ruled and go­
uerned.

Vn Registre, a Register: m.

Le registre de la geole, the booke of





the gaile: the register of the Coun­
ter.

Escrire es Registres & chartres de
la ville, to write in the bookes, char­
ters or registers of the Citie, for a 
perpetuall remembrance.

Reglisse, or regalisse, riglice: m.

Vn Regnard, a Foxe: m.

D'vn Regnard, of a Foxe.

Cest vne fine regnarde, f: she is a 
subtill Foxe.

Regnardeau, a yong Foxe: m.

Regner, to raigne.

Regnicoles, dwellers in a kingdome.

Qui regne, that reigneth.

Regorger, to giue vp againe, to par­
breake.

Regorgement & trop grande abon­
dance, excesse, too great aboun­
dance: regorging or casting of the
gorge: m."regorging" antedates earliest OED citation (1733).

Regratter quelque vieille robbe, &
la faire comme neuve, to new dresse
an old gowne.

Regrateurs, ou regratiers, hucksters,
wiflers, dressers of old clothes: m.

Regratement de vieilles choses pour
les mieux vendre apres, the flouri­
shing vp of old things to make them
better to sale: m: wiflings.this sense of "whiffling" was not found in OED.

Regratier, of foure syllables, to thank
one.

Perruque regredillée, frizeled haire:
fem.

Regrediller les cheveux, to frizle the
haire.

Regret, sorrow, griefe: m.

Faire quelque chose à regret, to doe
a thing vnwilling against his mind.

Ie n'ay point de regret d'avoir fait
cela, I am not sorie, or I repent not
that I haue done that.

Regreter aucun, to bewaile one, to be
sorie or wish for one.

Reguinder, to turne sailes and come
backe againe.

Rehaiter vn home, to reuiue or re­
ioyce a man.

Rehaulser, to set hier.

Rehouër, to new dig.

Rehouëment, a new digging as they
doe yerely about the rootes of vines:
masc.

Rehumer, to sup vp againe.

Rejalir, je rejalis, je rejali, j'ay rejali,
je rejaliray, to rebound, to giue
backe: as, Mais quand il vid son
espée Rejalir en l'air si luisante &
claire, il s'esmerveilla, but when he
sawe his sword through the blow to
rebound toward the aire, he was, &c.

Rejecter, to reiect, to despise, to cast
off.

Rejecter tout vn affaire au mois
de Mars, to put off all businesse till
March.

Rejecté, cast off.

Rejectement, a casting off: m.

Vn rejecton, the young spring of a
vine, a swarme of Bees: m.

Reigle, a rule: f.

Reigler les choses, to rule things.

Republique reglée par bon ordre,
& bien devisée, a Common-weale
well ordered, and with a wittie de­
uise or inuention.

Reglure, f: or reglement, ruling by
lines.

Relais, when as Hunters doe place
houndes in a place where they doe
thinke that the beast will passe, and 
then doe let them goe, and refresh
those which be tired: also we do say,
Chevaux de relais, fresh horses ap­
poynted in a place for the better
speede: m: also seates and bankes
to sit vpon: m.Word entry missing from the Henry E. Huntington copy in EEBO (STC 6737), supplied from the Leeds copy facsimile by Scolar Press.
