Remediement, a healing: m.

Remembrance, a remembrance, a si­
militude: f.

Ie me remembre de l'avoir veu, I 
remember very well that I haue
seene him.

Tant plus la chose est remembrée,
tant plus elle plait, the more the
thing is called to remembrance, the
more it pleaseth.

Rememorant, calling to remem­
brance.

Remémorer quelque chose, to call
to remembrance.

Remenant, or Remanent, the lea­
uings of any thing: m.

Remener, ou ramener, to bring a­
gaine.

Reménement, a bringing againe: m.

Remercier, to thanke.

Remerciement, a thanking: m.

Remerquer, or remarquer, to note or
marke a thing.

Remesurer, to measure againe.

Remettre, to place aright, to restore
to the first estate: see Mettre.

Remettre la peine, to forgiue the
paine.

Remission & pardon, pardon, remis­
sion: f.

Il est fort Remis, & ne tient plus sa
rigueur, he is very much asswaged,
he is slacker in his anger.

Remissible, com: as ce cas & offence
n'est remissible: this fact is not to
be pardoned.

Remeubler, to furnish againe with
moueables.

Remis, see Remettre.

Remise, f: as prendre les perdrix à
la remise, to take Partridges at the 
second flight.

Remettre à autre temps, to delay the
matter to another time or season.

Remirer, to see, as le Soleil qui tou­
tes choses remire, the Sunne which
beholdeth all.

Remonstrer, to shewe, to rebuke, to
warne, or to set before ones eyes.

Remonstrer à aucun sa faulte, & l'en
reprendre aigrement, to reproue
one for his fault, to checke.

Remonstrances, f: admonitions, shew­
ing.

Remonter, to climbe vp againe, to
buy horses for to goe to the warres,
to bring one to his former estate.

Remordre, to bite againe, as remor­
dre celuy qui nous a mors.

Remors de conscience, a remorse of
conscience: m.

Remouvoir, to remoue.

Rempar, a rampier, a fort: m.

Rempener vne flesche desempen­
née, to feather againe an arrow.

Remplir, je remplis, je rempli, j'ay
rempli, je rempliray, to fill againe.

Rempli, stuffed, filled.

Remplissement, a filling: m.

Remplage, ou remplissage, furni­
ture: m: filling of any licour.

Payer pour le remplissage des vins,
 to pay for the leake of wines.

Remplission de chair qui vient au
lieu où l'os avoit esté rompu, that
filling of flesh where the bone was
broken before: f.

Remporter, as il a remporté grand





honneur de ceste enterprise, he
hath carried away great honour of
such enterprise.

Remporter, to carrie againe.

Remuër, to remoue, to stirre.

Remuëment, a remouing: m.

Cest vn home fort remuant, he is a
very stirring fellow.

Remugle, or relant, fustie, mouldie,
mustie.

Remunerer, to rewarde, to recom­
pence.

Remuneration, f: reward.

Renaistre, to bee borne againe: see 
Naistre for the declining.

Rencherir vne marchandise, to set
merchandise to a higher price: je
rencheris, je rencheri, j'ay ren­
cheri, je rencheriray.

Les vivres sont rencheris par vne
pluye & verglas, victuals are the
dearer because of raine and a little
frost.

Il fait du rencheri, he sheweth a croo­
ked and ill disposed nature or mind:
he is now of another mood.

Renchoir malade, to fall againe sick.

La Rencheute est pire que la mala­
die, the fall againe of a sicknesse is
worse then, &c.

Renard, or regnard, a Foxe: m.

De regnard, of a Foxe.

Renaviger, to sayle againe.

Reng, rengée, seeke rang.

Rencheoir en maladie, to fall sicke
againe: see Choir for the declining.

Rençon quasi redemption, raun­
some: f

Rençonner & piller aucun, to raun­
some or polle one.

Rençonnement, m: polling.

Rençonneurs, m: pollers, extortio­
ners.

Rencontrer, to meete with.

Rencontre, a meeting: m.

Rencontreur, qui se mocque d'au­
truy, mocqueur, a Scoffer: m.

Cest bien recontré, it is finely spoken,
it is merily sayd.

Cest home rencontre bien, this man
is full of merie conceits, he speaketh
merily, and to the purpose.

Rencuser, to bewray.

Renditer, to accuse one freshly, to en­
dite one againe: see Enditer.

Se Rendormir, to fall a sleep a­
gaine.

Rendormissement, a falling againe
on sleepe: m.

Rendre, to yeeld, to restore, je rends,
je rendi, j'ay rendu, je rendray.

Rendre la pareille, to requite or ren­
der the like.

Rendre ses comptes, to giue vp his 
accompts.

Rendre les abbais, or abbois, among
Hunters if a worde vsed when the
Hart tired taketh an high place to 
his owne aduantage, & there vpon
his taile abideth the barking of
hounds: the contrarie is of the wild
Bore: for when first he springeth
out, they say, Le sanglier rend les
abbais, grounding at the dogs.

Se rendre à aucun en sa sauvegarde
& puissance, to yeeld himselfe to
the sauegarde and power of an o­
ther.





Se Rendre prisonnier & serf de vo­
lupté, to yeeld himselfe a prisoner
and slaue to pleasure.

Se Rendre à la mercy d'autruy, to
yeeld himselfe to anothers mer­
cie.

A Paris est le rendez vouz, at Paris
is the place of meeting togither.

Rendement, a restoring: m.

Rendurcir, as ilz se sont rendurcis,
 they waxed worse, more stubborne
& stiffenecked.

Renforcir, or renforcer, to waxe
strong, to take a good courage.

Renforci, or renforcé, strengthened.

Renvoyer du renfort, to send aide: m.

Renfiler vne aguille, to threed again 
a needle.

Se renfrongner, to frowne, to skoule.

Reng, m: order: it is also taken for a
ranke or order of souldiers in a bat­
tell array.

Il se presenta sur les Rengs, pour
courir, pour commencer le com­
bat, he came to the place for to run
at the tilt: for the fight.

A la premiere charge, lon enfonça
jusques au troisiesme reng, at the
first brunt or charge, they ouer­
threw all, to the third ranke.

Rengainer son espée, to put vp his
sword into his sheath.

Rengendrer, to engender againe.

Renger, to set in order, to range: seeke
Ranger.

Rengreger vn mal, to make a thing
worse then it is.

Mon mal se rengrege, my disease 
waxeth sorer and sorer.

Rengregement, a waxing sorer: m.

Renier avec ferment, to denie with
othe.

Reniement de la chose deuë, deny­
ing of a due: m.

Renifler, to eate his sniuell, or spittell.

Rejoindre, to ioyne againe: as don­
nez vous garde que les ennemys
ne se rejoinent, see that the ene­
mies doe not ioyne againe togither.

Renoirsir, to make blacke againe: see
Noirsir for the declining.

Renfler, to puffe vp againe.

Renom: m: Renomée: f: renoume, 
good name.

Avocat fort renommé, a famous
Lawyer or Counsailor.

Gens renommez en guerre, famous
men in warres.

Estre fort mal renommé, to haue an
euill name.

Renoncer aucun à gendre, to for­
sake one for his sonne in law.

Renoncer à l'amitié d'aucun, to for­
sake friendship with one.

Renouër les choses delaissées &
rompuës, to knit vp things that are
asunder.

Renouveler, to renue.

Renouvelé, racoustré, & regratté,
 renewed, new trimmed.

Renouvellement, a renuing: m.

Sur le renouveau, towards the spring
time.

Rente, rent, custome, taxe: f.

Vivre de ses rentes, to haue a liuing,
to liue of his owne reuenews.

Home bien renté, a man of good li­
uing.





Renter vn home, to giue to a man a
liuing, or yearely rent.

Rentaire, to lay in a seame with ones
naile, to make a seame that it ap­
peare not.

Rentrer, to goe in againe.

Renverser, to ouerthrow.

Coup donné à la Renverse, a crosse
blow: f.

Tomber à la Renverse, to fall back­
ward.

Renversement, an ouerthrowing: 
masc.

Renversure, ouerthrowing: f.

Renvoyer, to send againe.

Renvoy, a sending againe: m.

Demander son renvoy, to aske to be
sent to his owne iudge.

Repaire & logis, a place to repaire
to, a lodging: m.

Repairer, to resort to a place, & there
take his lodging.

Repaistre & bailler à manger, to
feede: je repais, je repeu, j'ay re­
peu, je repaistray.

Repaistre le corps de viandes deli­
cieuses, & lesprit de parolles joy­
euses, to feede the bodie with deli­
cate meate, and the spirit with me­
rie talke.

Repeu, feede: m.

Apres la Repuë, f: after meale.

Reparer, to repaire, to mend.

Reparation, reparation: f.

Reparement, a repairing: m.

Réparable, which may be amended,
or repaired: irréparable, is the con­
trarie: com.

Repargner, seeke Respargner.

Repas, a meale, repast: m.

Repasser la mer, par où on estoit ve­
nu, to passe againe ouer sea,

Repatrier, to restore one to his owne
countrie.

Repeigner, to combe againe.

Perruque peignée & Repeignée,
 lockes combed and combed againe.

Penser & repenser en son esprit, to
thinke and thinke againe.

Repensement, a chewing of the cud,
a thinking againe: m.

Soy repentir d'avoir fait quelque
chose, to repent for the doing of
a thing, je me repens, je me re­
penti, je me suy repenti, je me re­
pentiray.

Repentance, repentance: f.

Repercuter, a word proper to Chirur­
gions, to driue back, as médicament
répercussif, a salue or oyntment
driuing backe humours, &c.

Repertoire, or inventoire, an Index,
a briefe description: a Kalender,
such as Marchants haue in their
bookes: a table: m.

Repeser, to waigh againe.

Repéter & redire vne mesme cho­
se, to repeate or say oft one thing, to
demaund.

Repeu, satisfied.

Repeuë, a refection: f: a bayte in the
Inne.

Apres la repeuë nous montasmes à
cheval, after wee had bayted, wee
tooke our horses.

Repigeonner, to bud out: to burgen.

Repigeonnement, budding: m.

Repétition de quelque chose, the re­





petition of any thing: f.

Replanter, to plant or set vp againe.

Replétion, a filling, when one hath fed
his bellie full: f.

Home replet, a fat or well filled man.

Replier, to bend againe, to fold.

Le Repli d'une letre, d'vne robe,
d'vn privilege, m: the folding, rol­
ling or turning of a letter, gowne or
priuiledge where the seale or the
hand of the Prince is.

Les Replis d'une riviére, the wind­
ings of a riuer.

Replicquer, to replye or answer.

Replicque, a replye: f.

Repliques, answers.

Repliques, Dupliques, Tripliques
& Quadrupliques, the replies for
the first, second, third and fourth
time in law.

Repoindre & repiquer, to pricke a­
gaine.

Repolir, to polish againe.

Reponce, an Hearbe vsed in Sal­
lets.

Reporter, to carrie againe.

Reportée, carried againe.

Repos, rest, quietnesse: m.

Repos d'esprit, quiet minde, peace of
conscience.

Reposer & dormir, to rest and sleepe.

Home bien reposé, a sad, graue, still
man.

Resposoir, a resting place: m.

Se reposer, to rest, to take ease.

Repoulser, to repulse, or to with­
stand.

Repoulsé, repulsed, or withstan­
ded.

Repoulsement, a repulsing: m.

Repoulsoir, that which repulseth: m.

Repous, m: pauing with rubbell: fil­
ling with rubbish: a field lying ley.

Reprendre, to receiue againe, to take
againe: see Prendre, to decline.

Faire reprendre les choses rompuës,
 to make broken things hold togither
againe.

Reprendre aulcun de quelque faul­
te, to reproue one of some faults com­
mitted.

Reprendre son chemin, to take his
way againe.

Reprins, taken againe, rebuked.

Reprinse & repétition, a petition.

Repreneur, a reprouer, a carper: m.

Repréhension, reprehension, re­
proofe, f.

Representer, to represent, to keepe the
place, to be like.

Representant, a shewing forth.

Representation, a representation: f.

Ie vous prie, & reprie, I pray & pray
you againe.

Reprimer, to represse and subdue.

Reprimende, a rebuke, a checke: f.

Il a heu ja deux fois la reprimende,
 he hath been already rebuked twise
by the Prince or Iudges.

Elle a esté reprise, she was taken a­
gaine: also rebuked.

Reprocher, to reproach.

Reproche, reproach, vpbraiding: m.

Reprochable, reproachfull: com.

Reprouver, to reproue, to checke.

Reprouvable, which may bee repro­
ued: com.

République, the publike weale: f.





Repudier sa femme, to forsake his
wife.

Repudiable, com: to be reiected.

Repuë, seeke repas.

Apres la repuë, after meale: f.

Qui cerche ses repuës franches,
 which seeketh to fill his belly franke
and free.

Il fait tout pour la repuë, f: he doth
any thing, so that he may fill his bel­
ly, euery thing for good cheere and 
free meales.

Repugner, contredire, aller à l'en­
contre, to repugne, to gainsay.

Repugnance & contrarieté, repug­
nance and contrarietie: f.

Repululer, to Burgen, to budde a­
gaine.

Reputer aucun pour tel: ou tel, to
repute or esteeme one for such.

Reputé, reputed or esteemed.

Bonne reputation, good reputation
and estimation: f.

Mauvaise reputation, ill reputation
or name.

Requerir, je requiers, je requis, j'ay
requis, je requerray, to require in­
stantly, to desire.

Faire selon que le cas ou là matiere
le requiert, to doe as the matter re­
quireth.

Ceci n'est pas Requis pout le temps
qui court: this is not requisite as
the time goeth now.

Racine fort requise pour faire on­
guent, an excellent roote for to
make an oyntment.

Requeste, a request: f.

Requestes escriptes, requests or sup­
plications.

Faire requeste à aucun, to make 
request to one.

Le maistre des requestes, the master
of requests.

Sonner la requeste, when Hunters
doe blowe to haue their houndes to
seeke out the trace lost of the wilde
beast.

Cela n'est plus en requeste, that is
no more sought or asked for.

Requint, the fifth penny due to the
lord, by the sale of any land holding
of his manor or like: m.

Payer les Quints & requints, to pay
such duties.

Requoy, see recoy.

Resaigner vn home, to let one blood
againe.

Resaillir, to start backe.

Resaluër, to salute againe.

Resarcler, to weede againe.

Reschapper d'vne maladie, to escape
or recouer of a sickenesse.

Resbaudir, to reioyce one, also to en­
courage hounds in hunting, as res­
baudir les chiens.

Reschauffer, to warme againe.

Reschauffoir ou reschault, a chafing
dish: m.

Rescinder vn contract, to breake a 
bargaine.

Rescision, as decrets subjets à resci­
sion, decrees subiects to be cut of or
abrogated.

Du reseau, m: net-worke.

Se recourse du danger où on estoit
d'estre mis en oubly, to seeke to
forget danger.

Retracter & revoir, to correct a thing,
to ouersee a thing.

Vn privé & retraict, a priuie or
house of office, a iakes: m.

Vn retraict public, a common pri­
uie.

Cureurs de retraits, dung farmers,
iakes farmers.

Retraicte & retour, retourning a­
gaine: f.

Sonner à la retraicte, to sounde the
retyre.

Retraire, to plucke out againe,

Retraire en servage, to bring to bon­
dage.

Se drap s'est retraict, this cloth is
shrunke.

Retrecir, to pull or drawe backe, to
make narrower, je retrecis, je re­
treci, j'ay retréci, je retreciray.

Retraicter vn arrest, to call backe a 
sentence giuen.

Retrencher, to cut off.

Retrencher les gages, to cut off
wages.

Les officiers ont esté Retranchez en
leur estat, the officers haue beene
cut off in their offices, that is, some
of their allowance hath beene cut
off.

Retribuer, to rewarde.

Rétribution, a reward: f.

Rétrograder, to goe backe, as when
the Sunne went backe in the dayes
of Ezechias.

Rétrogradation des astres, the going
backe of Planets: f.

Retrousser, to trusse vp.

Vne rets, a net.

Reu ou ru, a Brooke: m.

Vevalloir, to recompence, to be as
much worth to him as that com­
meth to.

Soy revancher or revencher, to wreak
himselfe.

Bailler la revanche, to be euen with
one: f.

Reveler, to reueale, to disclose, to be­
wray.

Revelation, reuelation; f.

Reveleux, a wanton, lasciuious:
masc.

Revendre vne chose à celuy qui l'a­
voit venduë, to sell a thing againe
to him that solde it.

Vn revendeur & regrateur, a retai­
ler or huckster: m.

Revenir en quelque lieu, to come a­
gaine into any place, je reviens, je
revins, je suy revenu, je revien­
dray.

Ce mal revient tous-jours, this
euill or mischeefe commeth backe
againe.

Revenir à soy, to come to himselfe.

Ie l'ay bien fait revenir de par De­
eu, on de par l'autre, I made him
to come againe in spite of the great
Turke.

Mon songe revient à cecy, my 
dreame agreeth very well to this
chance.

Qui revient bien aux gents, &
n'est point envieux, a fellowelike
man.

Ie suy revenu, I am come againe.

Ihanne est revenuë du marché,
 Iohn is come againe from market.





Revenuë, rent, reuenew: f.

Le revenu d'aucun, any mans rent
or reuenew.

Revoir & retracter vne chose , to cor­
rect and ouersee a thing.

Revision de proces, f: an ouerseeing
an examining of bookes and wri­
tings of an olde matter in law.

Reverberé, ou frappé, reflexe or re­
uerberation.

La reverberation du Soleil, the re­
flexe of the Sunne.

Reverdir, to waxe greene againe: je
reverdis, je reverdi, je suy reverdi,
je reverdiray.

Reverend, reuerende, or worship­
full.

Reverence qu'on porte à aucun,
 the reuerence that is borne to one:
fem.

Avoir en reverence, to haue in re­
uerence.

Reverément, reuerently.

Revers, a blow cast backe either with
the hand or sword: m.

Ie te bailleray vn tel Revers, que je 
te feray tourner de l'autre costé, I
will giue thee such a clicke, such a
wherit, that I shall make thee turne
to th'other side.

A Revers, backeward.

Reverser, to poure out againe.

Reversures, or reversailles des voir­
res, the leauings in glasses or cups
after one hath drunke: f.

Revesche, wilde, vntamed, crooked,
wayward, froward, stubborne.

Vn Revesche, sower wine, vnplea­
sant.

Revestir, to clothe one, to apparell one,
to put a man in possession: see Vestir
for the decl.

Revirer, as se revirer contre son en­
nemy, to turne againe against his
enemie.

Reveuë, f: as faire la reveuë d'vne 
armée, to viewe an armie, to mu­
ster.

Revisiter, to reuisite, to ouersee.

Revisitement, an ouerseeing: m.

Revivre, to liue againe: see Vivre for 
the decl.

Reume, seeke Rume.

Révocable, that may be called backe
againe, the contrary is, Irrévo­
cable, com.

Vne Reuppe, see router.

Reünir, Reünition, seeke Vnir.

Revoler, to flie againe.

Se revolter & rendre du party des
ennemis, to reuolte, to take the ene­
mies part.

Revoltement, m: ou revolte, f: a 
reuolting, a slipping away from an
army.

Il s'est revolté de l'Evangile, he is
fallen from the Gospell.

L'an revolu, the yeere being gone a­
bout: m.

Revolution, change or turning about.

Revoquer vn ambassadeur, to call
backe an Ambassadour.

Revoquer vne donation, to cal back
againe a gift or legacie,

Revocation, f: a calling back of such
things as were determined before.

Revoquer en doubte, to call in que­
stion or doubt.

Rime, Rime or Meeter: f.
Il n'y a ne rime ne raison en cela,
there is no equitie in that.Word entry missing from the Henry E. Huntington copy in EEBO (STC 6737), supplied from the Leeds copy facsimile by Scolar Press.

Perdre vn roc, to leese a rooke play­





ing at Chesse.

Vn Roc, in the countrie of Bourbon­
nois, a cradle: so they say, Rocquer,
or Roquer vn enfant, to rocke a 
little babie: m: also a peece of tim­
ber in a ship.

Rochet, or roquet, a linnen garment
of maidens keeping sheepe: m.

Roquette, a Fortresse: f.

Roder le païs, to make a roade in the
countrie, to roue or wander about.

Roder les rues, to play the ruffin by
night.

Vn rodeur ou coureur, a roder or
wayrider: m.

Rogations, rouaïsons, or roisons,
 Rogation daies: f.

Rogatons, vn porteur de rogatons,
 a bearer of the Popes Bulles, or
relickes of Martyrs to bee wor­
shipped, and so to gette money by
them: m.

Rogue, a presumptuous fellowe, arro­
gant: m.

Estre roide de froid, to be stiffe with
cold.

Roidi, contented: stiffened.

Roideur, roughnesse, sternenesse: f.

Roidement, roughly, strongly.

Le Roignon, the kidney: m.

Roisons, f: Rogation dayes.

Vn Roitelet, sorte d'oiseau, a bird
called a Wren or Robin red breast, a
king of small state: m.

Rolle, rollet, seeke Rouler.

Roman, as le Roman de la rose,  the
Roman of the rose: m.

Romarin, a braunch called Rosema­
rie.

Vivre à la Romanesque, to liue after
the Romanes fashion: f.

Rompierre, Persepierre, herbe Em­
petron, an herbe called Empetron,
or Sampier: f."empetron" not found in OED.

Rompre, je romps, je rompi, j'ay
rompu, je rompray, to breake, to
burst in sunder, to pash in peeces.

Rompu, broken.

Rompure, a bracke.

Rompement, breaking, bursting: m.

Vne Ronce, a bramble: f: a brier.

Ronceux, full of brambles or briers.

Vn Ronsoy, or lieu pourplanté de
ronces, a bushie close full of brambles.

Rond, round.

Rondace, ou rondelle, a target: f.

Rondement, roundly.

Vn Rondeau de patissier, a Cookes
rolling-pinne: m.

Vn rondeau de rime, a Meeter that
euer endeth as it beginneth.

Rondeur, roundnesse: f.

Vne petite rondelle de guerre, a
small target or buckler: f.

Rondelier, m: he that vseth or ma­
keth targets.

Ronfler, to snort, to snore, to rowte.

Ronger, to gnawe, to gnabble, or nib­
ble.

Rongé tout à l'entour, gnabled about:
nibbled.

Rongement, a gnawing: m.

Rongeur, m: a poler.

Rongner, to pare, to clip.

Rongné, pared, clipped, nibbled.

Rongnement, a paring, a clipping: m.

Rongnure, parings, clippings: f.

Rongne, scab: f.





Rongneux, scabbie.

Roquer, see Roc.

Roquet, habillement de fille ou fem­
me, a womans apparell made of lin­
nen, or such as shepherds doe vse a­
gainst the raine: m.

Roquette, herbe, an herbe called Roc­
ket: f.

Vn Rot, a belch: m.

Rotter, see router, to belch.

Rosageur rosagine, a shrub hauing
leaues like a bay tree.

Roseignol, a Nightingale, m: see
Rossignol.

Rose, a Rose: f.

Vinaigre, huile, sirop rosat, Vineger,
oyle, sirrope of Roses: m.

Vn Rosier, a Rose arbour: m.

Rosier muscat, a muske Rose tree.

Rosin, m: Rose like.

Herbes Rosoyantes, hearbes hauing
the colour of Roses.

Roseau, a reed: m.

Rosée, the dewe: f.

Il Rosine, the dewe falleth downe.

Rosinement, m: the falling of the
dewe.

De la rosette, a colour called russet: f:
ruddle.

Vn Rossignol, a Nightingale: m.

Rossignolet, a little Nightingale: m.

Rostir ou cuire à la braise, to roste, je
rostis, je rosti, j'ay rosti, je rosti­
ray.

Rosti, rostmeate.

Vne rostie, a toast: f.

Rostisserie, a Cookes row: f.

Vn Rotisseur, a Cooke which selleth
hote meate: m.

Rotine, as apprendre quelque cho­
se par rotine, to learne by rote.

Roturier, a carter or villaine: m.

Roture, the condition, state, or the
calling of one which is not noble: f.

Roturiére, a woman which is not ex­
tract of any noble stocke: f.

Roturiérement, carters like.

Rouäble, or Rable,  a cole rake: m: al­
so a beater wherewith Masons doe
beate their morter.

Rouärt, the Prouost of Marshals,
like the office of the Knight Mar­
shall: m.

Faire la rouë, to goe about.

Vne rouë, a wheele: f.

Vn Rouët, m: a wheele to spin.

Vn Rouët de harquebuse, the lock of
a gunne.

Cheval Rouën, a horse of roen or
chestnut colour.

Rouëtte, a little wheele: f.

Rouëlle d'oignon, a shiue of an Oni­
on: f.

Rouge, red colour.

Rogeur, rednesse: f.

Rougeastre, reddish, or claret colour.

Rougir de honte, to blush for shame,
je rougis, je rougi, j'ay rougi, je
rougiray.

Rouget, poisson, a fish called a Ro­
chet: m.

Rougeole, ou verole, the small pocks:
fem.

Rouille, ou rouillure, rustinesse: f.

Mon cousteau est tout Rouillé, m:
 my knife is all rustie.

Rouïr du chambre ou du lin, to wa­
ter hempe or flaxe.





Vn Rouïssoir, m: the pond where they
doe water flaxe.

Rouler, to roule or tumble.

Roulant, rolling.

En roulant, in or by rolling.

Roulement, a rolling: m.

Le rouleau & racloir des mesure­
urs, a striker: also a scroll: m.

Vn Roulier, ou Voicturier, a Carier:
m: also an hogs stie.

Roumarin, m: Rosemarie.

Roupeau, m: a kind of Herne.

Roupie, f: a bird called a Bulfinch.

Roupie, an Issicle, the nose dropping:
the murre or pose: f.

Nez enroupié, a dropping nose.

Roupieux, a man whose nose drop­
peth still.

Roupieuse, a woman with a dropping 
nose.

Vne roussette, a fish called a Barbell: 
fem.

Roussir, to waxe red.

Rous, a red man, which hath a red
beard: m.

Vne Rousse, a woman with red haires
and freckled face: f.

Vn Rousseau, a red haired man: one
full of freckles.

Bestes rousses, red wild beasts.

Rousselet, somewhat red.

Roussastre, com: idem.

Vne route, a belch: f.

Router, to belch or breake wind.

Vne Route, or reuppe, f: a belch.

Routant, belching.

Ta Route sent le vin que tu as beu, 
thy belching smelleth of the wine
which thou hast dronke.

La Route du Liévre, the hare forme:
fem.

Prendre la route d'Angleterre, to
take his way towards England.

Vne grande Route de gens, ou de
cerfs, a rout or multitude of &c.

Vn vieux Routier ou Roturier, qui
de long temps est vsité à finesses,
 an old deceiuer: or warriour.

Routier also is the direction of the
way, also a man well practised or ac­
quainted in some trade.

Routine, see Rotine.

Pommes Red ouveau, Queene Ap­
ples.

Roux, reddish colour.

Roy, a King: m.

Royne, a Queene: f.

Faire commendement depar le Roy,
 to command in the Kings name.

Le Roy de la febvre, the King chosen
by the beane.

Royalement, royally, princely.

Roye, ou Royon, seeke Ray.

Roytelet, a bird called a Wren: m.

Vn Ru, ou Reu, a Brooke: m.

Ruade, the kicking of a horse: f.

Ruben de teste, a headband, or a fil­

nish a garment with ribands.

Rubennier, or faiseur de rubens, a
maker of ribands: m.





Rubicunde, somewhat red, f.

Rubis, pierre précieuse, a stone cal­
led a Rubie: m.

Vne Ruche à miel, a Bee hiue: f.

Rude, rude, rusticall, lobbish and
blockish, com.

Rude & aspre à manier, rude and
hard to be broken or handled.

Rude & mau-piteux, rough & with­
out pitie.

Rudement, rudely, rustically, rough­
lie.

Rudesse, rudenesse, blockishnesse: f.

Rues d'vne ville, the streetes of a 
towne: f.

Par rues, by streetes.

Vne ruelle ou petite rue, a lane: f.

Rue mal-heureuse & maudite, a
cursed and vnluckie streete.

Batre les rues & le pavé, to rifle by
night in the streetes, to keepe euill
rule.

Vne Ruelle, f: a lane.

La Ruelle du lict, the space betweene
the bed and the wall.

De la Rue, an hearbe called Rue, or
Herbegrace: f.

Ruer, to throw.

Ruer du hault en bas, to throw downe
headlong.

Ruer par terre, to throw downe to the 
ground.

Il luy rua vn coup d'espée, he cast at
him a pricke or foyne with a sword.

Se ruer & getter sur aucun, to fall
vpon one, to rush vpon him violent­
lie.

Ruer des pieds, to strike with ones
heeles, to kicke.

Vne Ruade, f: a kicking.

Rueur, a kicker: m.

Rufien, or rufisque, a he baud: m: a
ruffian.

Rufienner, to play the baud.

Rugir, or ruir, as le Lion rugit, ou ru­
it, the Lyon rores, je rugis, je rugi,
j'ay rugi, je rugiray, to rore.

Rugissant, roring.

Rugissement, or Rugiment, a ro­
ring: m.

Ruine, ruine or ouerthrow: f.

Ruiner & destruire, to ouerthrowe, to
destroy.

Elle est ruinée, & ce par sa propre
faute, she is ruined and vndone, and
by her owne fault.

Ruineux, ruinous, in decay.

Ruir, to rore.

Ruissement, roaring, seeke Rugir.

Ruisseau, a chanell, a brooke or run­
ning water: m.

Ruisselet, a gutter, a spring: m.

Ruisseler, as le sang luy ruisseloit de
tous costez, the bloud did run on e­
uery side.

Ruit, or rut, when red wild beasts be
in heate, also the companie or num­
ber of Hindes, after whome the
Deere doe run: to rut.

Venaison ruitée, Venison which is 
killed at the time of rutte.

Rumatique, hee which is troubled
with the reume.

Rume, the reume: m.

Ruminer, comme quand les bestes
remaschent ce qu'elles ont ja man­
gé, propre aux bestes à pied four­
ché, to chaw the cud.





Ruminement, a chawing: m.

Rupture, a breaking: f: bursting.

Rupture, quand l'intestin descend,
 bursting of the cods.

Rural, rude, countrey like.

Ruse, subtiltie, craft, deceit: f.

Rusé, subtile, craftie.

Cest vne Rusée, she is a craftie
whore.

Rustault, ou rustique, a countrey
man: rude, m.

Rusticité, rudenesse: f.

Vn rustre, a Royster, a knauish fel­
low: m.

Ruyler ou mesler & destremper du
plastre ou terre avec de l'eauë,
pour faire du mortier, to mingle 
plaster or earth with water to make
morter withall.


S ante A.

SAble, ou sablon, grauell: m.

Sablon & menu gravois & greve,
 sand: also our Harolds doe call, in
blazing Armes or Scutchions, the
blacke colour Sable.

Sablonneux, m: full of grauell or
sand: sandie.

Terre Sablonneuse, f: sandie ground.

Vne Sablonniére, a grauelly plac: f.

Vn Sabot à se iouër, a top: m.

Sabots & souliers de bois, pattons,
woodden shooes: m.

Le Sabot d'vn cheval, the hoofe of a 
horse: m.

Saboter, to scourge a top.

Sabouler, to tread vnder the feete.

Saboulement, m: treading.

Saburre & grosse arene dequoy on
charge les navires, à fin d'estre
plus fermes, shingle, or pibble
stones: the balase or costage of ships:
lastage or balase of a ship to peise
euen: f.

Sacquer vne espée, to drawe his
sword: also thrust it into ones bel­
lie.

Vn Sac, a sacke: m.

Sachet, a bag or pocket: m.

Le sac d'vne ville, the sacke of a 
towne.

Saccager, to spoyle, to sacke.

Saccagement, a spoyling or sacking:
masc.

Saccouter à l'oreille, to whisper or 
prompe in ones eare.

Sacerdot, or prestre, a priest: m.

Sacerdotal, priesthood, as l'estat sa­
cerdotal: m.

Saches, see sçavoir, know thou.

Sacquer, seeke Sac.

Sacre, oyseau de proye, a kinde of
Hauke: also a kind of artillerie: m.

Vn Sacret, the tiercelet of a Saker:
masc.

Sacré à Dieu, consecrated to God.

Sacrer vn home, & tous ses biens, to
outlaw one, whereby it is lawful for
any man to kill him.

Sacrer vn Evesque, vn Roy, to conse­
crate a Bishop, a King.

Le Sacré du Roy, the Kings corona­
tion: m.

Sacraire, the place where they put ho­
ly things: m.

Sacremens de l'eglise, the Sacra­
ments of the Church: m.





Sacrements, qui sont tenus secrets
au peuple, Sacraments.

Sacrifier, to sacrifice.

Sacrifice, a sacrifice: m.

Sacrificateur, a sacrificer: m.

Sacrilege, larron des choses sacrées,
 a Sacrilege, theft of holie things:
masc.

Sacristain, or Secretain, the Sexton
of a Church: m.

Sacristie, the place where they keepe
holy things, the Vestrie: f.

Sadayer vne femme, to flatter a wo­
man or speake her faire.

Mais voyez, je vous prie, comment il
sadaye & pateline ceste fame, but
marke, I pray you, how hee gropeth
this woman.

Sade, ou sadinet, pretie, faire.

Safran, Saffron: m.

Aller au safran, to decay, of a ritch
man to become poore, when a Mer­
chant is bankerupte.

Vn Safranier, or Saffrenier, which
selleth Saffron: that is, which hath
spent all, a bankerupt: m.

Safrané, saffroned.

Safre, wanton: m.

Saffrette, remuänte, fretillante, a
wanton maiden or woman: f.

Safreté, wantonnesse: f.

Sage, wise.

Sagement, wisely, aduisedly, discreete­
lie."discretely" antedates earliest OED citation (1706).

Sagesse & cognoissance, wisedome,
knowledge, vnderstanding: f.

Le sagerault Vlysse, the wise man V­
lysses: m.

Saget, m: a pretie wise man.

Sagette, or Sayette, an arrowe: f.

Sagetter aucun, to loade one with ar­
rowes.

Sagitaire, ou archer, an archer, a
shooter: m.

Sais, seeke saye, a coate: m.

Saigner & jecter sang, to let bloud,
to bleede.

Saigner aucun, to let one bloud.

Saignée, a letting of bloud: f.

Saigneux, bloudie, or full of bloud.

Saillir, to leape, to skip, to hop, to dance
to goe or issue out.

Saillir, or couvrir vne femelle, to line
a femall, in beasts.

Saillie, ou sault, a leape: f.

Saillie avec impetuosité, comme de
gensdarmes sur les ennemis, an is­
suing out, as footemen doe on their
enemies.

Saillie de maison, the iutting out of
an house.

La Saillie & cabochon d'vne pierre
prétieuse taillée en bosse, the chase
wherein a precious stone is enclo­
sed: f.

Sain, healthfull.

Sain & entier, whole and sound.

Sain & sauve, safe and sound.

Elle est Saine, she is safe and sound: f.

Sain doulx, seame or fresh grease, al­
so the tallow of any wild beast: m.

Sainct & sans aucune tache de vice,
 holy, vnspotted.

Saincteté, holinesse: f.

Chose Saincte, f: an holy thing.

Sainctement, holylie.

Sainctuäire, the Sanctuarie.

Saisir les meubles d'aucun pour quel­





que contumace, to seaze or attach
the goods of any man, je saisis, je
saisi, j'ay saisi, je saisiray.

Saisie, as empescher la saisie & di­
straction des meubles à vil prix,
 to let that the goods of a man put to
paune be sold vnder price.

Saisine, possession: f.

Saisissement, a seazing, or attaching.

Saison & temps propre à faire quel­
que chose, season or fit time to doe
any thing.

Cela est hors de saison, that is out of
season.

Il a esté malade longue saison: hee
hath been sicke a long time.

Salace, as les melancholiques sont
plus Salaces que les aultres, men
abounding in melancholie are more
lustie or lasciuious, &c.

Vne Salade: f: ou heaulme: m: a
sallet or helmet,

Salades d'herbes ou autres choses,
 all kind of Sallades: f.

Salaire, reward, recompence: m.

Salarier, to reward one.

Salarié, rewarded.

Vn Saonier, a Salter: one that sel­
leth salt: m.

Sale & ord, see Sasle.

Salir, Sale, see Saslir.

Salissure, fouling, soyling: f.

Vne sale, a hall: f.

Saler, to salt, to season, to pouder.

Salé, salted.

Vne Saliére, a poudring house, a salt
seller: f.

La Saline, a salt house, where salt is
made: f.

Salins, or greniers à sel, where salt is
kept and sold: m.

Saligots ou truffes, a kind of herbe in
the water: m: see Charisse-­
trapes.

Salmure, brine.

Salmingondins: m: a kind of sauce
vpon mince meate.

Salmigondinois, louing such sauce.

Salure, poudring, or salting: f: brine.

Salette, Ozeille, or Vinette, Sorell: f.

Vn Saloir, a poudring tub.

Salure, or Saleure, poudring or sal­
ting: salt meate: f.

Salive, spittle: f.

Vne salle, a hall: f.

Salle d'audience, the chamber of
presence.

La grand salle du palais, the Hall, as
Westminster Hall.

Sallette, a little hall.

Salamandre, a Salamander: f.

Salpestre, Saltpeter: m.

Salubre, healthfull, com.

Salvations, be the purgations or iusti­
fications of false witnesses against
vs.

Saluër aucun, to salute or greete one,
je saluë, je saluay.

Salut, health, greeting: m.

Donner Salut, Saluër, to giue health
or greeting.

Saluëur, one that saluteth: m.

Salutation, salutation, greeting: f.

Salutaire, healthful, wholesome, com.

Samedy, Saterday: m.

Samoireau, a kind of great grape: m.

Samy, a kinde of cloth very fine like
vnto Satin: m.

Sandal, bois qu'on apporte d'Inde,





 a precious wood that is brought out
of India: m.

Saner, to heale.

Sanable, which may be healed: com.

Sang, m: bloud.

Sanglant, bloudy, full of bloud.

Sanguin, of a Sanguine complex­
ion.

Du Sanguin, a kinde of redde tree:
masc.

Vne Sanguine, f: a kinde of red stone
which armourers doe vse in gilting
their rapiers or daggers.

Sanglanter, to besmeare one with
blood.

Sanglantement, bloudie.

Sang-meslure, f: when through feare
the bloud is changed & we become
pale.

Home sang-neslé, a man troubled by
feare.

Vne sangle, a sengle or girth: f.

Sangler vn Cheval, to girthe a 
horse.

Vne robe sangle, a single gowne: 
fem.

Porc-sanglier, a wilde Bore: m.

Les crochets d'un porc-sanglier, the
crooked tuskes of a wilde Bore.

Sanglout, seeke Senglout.

Tuer un home de sang froid, to kill a
man aduisedlye, his choler being
past.

Sanguinaire, a bloudie man.

Sanguinité, f: affinitie, next blood.

Sanicle, a kinde of hearbe healing
wounds.

Sans, without, besides.

Sans toy, without thee.

Sans cause, without cause.

Sans fin, without end.

Vne sansuë, a horsleache, a kinde of
worme: f.

Santé, health, welfare: f.

Sanctimonie, holinesse: f.

Sanves, an herbe called wilde cole.

Saouler, to suffice, to satisfie, to fulfill,
to stroute or fill.

Saoul, but pronounce Sou, full, drunke,
strout: m.

Elle est soule, she is belly full, she is 
drunke: f.

Il n'a pas son saoul de pain, he hath
not his belly full of bread.

Il est saoul de sa fame, he is weary of
his wife.

Saoulé, full.

Saouleuré, fulnesse: f.

Sapin, a tree called a Firre tree: m.

Sapper vne muraille, to cut a wall by
the foot.

Saphir, pierre precieuse, a precious
stone called a Saphire.

Vne sarbataine, a long trunke, also
an instrument of musicke, some doe
call them Waites: f.

Sarcler, to rake, to weede.

Sarclement, a raking or weeding:
masc.

Vn sarclet, a rake: m.

Sarcleur, ou bineur, a weeder: m.

Vn Sarcueil, ou biére, a biere, or cof­
fin: m.

Sardelle, ou sardine, sorte de poisson,
 a kinde of fishe called a Sardine, or
anchois: f.

Sarfouïr, fouïr par dessoubs, to vn­
derdig or vndermine.





Sarmant, a vine branch, that which
Gardeners doe cut off: m.

Sarpe, ou Sarpette, seeke Serpe.

Vne sarpilliére or envelopoir, a brai­
ding or wrapping cloth or clouts, a­
ny thing to wrap marchandise in.

Sarrer, seeke Serrer.

Sarriette, an herbe called Sauorie: f.

Sartre, or cousturier, a tailor: m.

La sartie, a little boate: f.

Vn sas, a Sieue: m.

Sasle, foule, filthie, loathsome.

Saslir, je saslis, je sasly, j'ay sa­
sli, je sasliray, to beraye, soile, or
foule.

Sasser, to sifte.

Satin, Sattin: m.

Satisfactionnaires, preachers of sa­
tisfaction, com.

Satisfaire & payer, to satisfie, to
paye.

Satisfaction, a satisfaction: f.

Saturne, one of the seauen Planets;
masc.

Vn Satyre, a Satyre: m.

Vne satyre, a kinde of verse rebuking
vices: f.

Satiriquement, bitingly.

Satiriun, m: a roote.

Vne savatte, an olde shoe.

Savaterie, the place where olde shoes
be solde: f.

Savetier, a cobler, a souter: m.

Saveur, sauour or taste: f.

Saugrenuë or sogrenuës questions,
 vnsauoured questions: f.

Savourer, to taste.

Chose savoureuse, of good taste.

Sauf, safe.

Sauf vostre honneur, sauing your re­
uerence.

Sauf vostre grace, idem.

Saufconduict, a safe conduct: m.

Savinier, arbre, a tree called Sa­
uyn.

Saules-verds, greene willowes: m.

De la Saulge, an hearbe called sage: f.

Il n'y a ne sel ne sauge, it is an vnsa­
uorie thing.

Vn saugé, the sauce of a capon: m.

Vne saugrenée, f: a kind of porredge
made with peason and broth halfe
sodden, put in a dish with sops, salte,
sallet oyle, and some vineger.

Saulmon, a Salmon: m.

Saulmure, the brine of salte: f.

Saulnier, a Salter: m.

Saupicquet, any kinde of sauce, but
properly made with vineger, onions,
and mustard, or such as they dresse
for roasted porke: m.

Saulpoudrer la chair, to corne fleshe
with salte.

Vne saulsaye, a place where willowes
growe: f.

Saulse, sauce: f.

Saulser, to dip in the sauce.

Saulsisse, a sausige: f.

Vn sault, a leape: m.

Saulter, to leape.

Saulteler, to hoppe.

Saultement de l'vn à l'autre, leaping
from one to another: m.

Saulterelles, some cal them locusts, it is
a kinde of flie spoiling both grasse &
corne, in India they bee of great
bignes & length, the people do eate
them.





Sauterette, f: a shrimpe, fish.

Saulteur ou danseur, a leaper or daun­
ser: m.

Saultereau, petite beste, a grashop­
per: m.

Saulteresse, ou danseresse, a woman
daunser: f.

Vne saulx or saule, a willowe or wi­
thie: f.

Du savon, sope: m.

Sauoir, looke Sçavoir.

Savonner, to washe in Sope.

Savourer, seeke Saveur.

Savoureusement, as manger savou­
reusement, to eate with a good sto­
macke.

Sauroye, as je ne sauroye faire, boi­
re, souffrir cela, I cannot doe, drinke,
suffer that.

On ne luy sauroit persuader, one can
not perswade him.

Sauvage, wilde, vntamed.

Sauvageaux & plantes, yong plants:
mas.

Sauvageté, wildenesse: f.

Sauvagine, venson: f.

Sauvegarde, safegarde, suretie: f.

Se mettre en la sauvegarde d'aucun,
 to commit himselfe to the safegarde
of one.

Sauver, to saue.

Sauver la vie, to saue ones life.

Sauvé & eschappé, saued and esca­
ped.

Sauveur, a Sauiour: m.

Salutation, salutation, or greeting: f.

Sauveté, safetie, assurance: f.

Vn saye, ou sayon, a coate, a iacket: 
masc.

De la sayete, a kinde of cloth called
saye.

Sceu, see Sçavoir, knowen.

Scorne, as faire vn scorne à quelcun,
 to make or giue a mocke to one: m.

Scabelle, f: scabeau, m: petit banc,
 a Stoole, a fourme.

Scabreux, rough, knaggie.

Vn scalme or escome, the broad end
of an ore.

Scandale, offence: m.

Scandalizer, to slaunder, to giue an
occasion of offence.

Scandaleux, a slaunderous deed.

Scarifier, to raise the skin.

Scarification, the raising of the skin
either by salues or other instru­
ments: f.

Scariole, an herbe called Sicorie: f.

Scarvine, f: a pilgrims cloake.

Sçavoir, to know, to ken, to wotte, je
sçay, je sçeu, j'ay sçeu, je sçauray.

Sçavoir, pertaineth to the minde and
coignoistre, to the eyes.

Sçavoir bon gré, to giue one thankes.

C'est à sçavoir, that is to wit.

A sçavoir mon, whether or not.

Qui sçait, he that knoweth.

Sçavant, skilfull, learned, cunning.

Sçavamment , skilfully, learnedly,
cunningly.

Sçavoir & expérience, knowledge,
experience: m.

Home de grand sçavoir, a man of
great learning.

Science, skill, science: f.

Au veu & au sceu de tous, in the
presence of all men.

Au sceu et consentement de son





mary, with the knowledge of her
husband.

Home scientique, a very skilful man,
but most often it is taken in euill
part.

Scientifique, com: idem.

Faire quelque chose sciemment, to
doe a thing wittingly.

Scammonie, herbe, a daungerous
herbe so called: f.

Scédule & obligation an obligation,
a bill, seeke Cédule: f.

Septre royall, a Kingly Scepter:
masc.

Schisme ou division, schisme or di­
uision.

Chismatique, an heretike: com.

Scholastique, Schollarlike: com.

Sciatique, the Sciatica, the Goute of
the hip: f.

Vne scie, a sawe, f: see sie.

Sciemment, Science, see Sçavoir.

Scintelle ou estincelle, a Sparke: f.

Scintiler estinceler, to sparkle.

Scintillation, f: sparkling.

Scipoule ou oignon marin, a Sea
Onion.

Scopeterie, a thicke gunshot of Soul­
diers.

Scourgeon or secourgeon, a kinde of 
barlie: m.

Scrofulaire, an hearbe healing the
Queenes euill.

Scorpion, a Scorpion: m.

Scrupule de conscience, feare of con­
science: f.

Mettre quelq'vn en scrupule & cra­
inte de conscience, to bring one to
feare or doubt.

Scrupuleux, scrupulous, religious:
masc.

Fame fort Scrupuleuse, a very scru­
pulous woman: f.

Vn scrupule, a waight among the A­
pothecaries.

Scrupuleusement, religiously,

Seant, fitting, seemely, decent, come­
lye.

Cela vous seed fort bien, the same
doth become you very well.

Seance, comelines, seemelinesse: f.

Avoir seance en lieu royall, to haue
a sitting place, to sit in the royall
seate.

Ilz sont vis à vis l'un de l'autre en
seance, they are one right against
the other in sitting in their places.

Seamment, comely, decently.

Vn seau, m: ou seille, f, à porter ea­
uë, a water paile, a bucket."water paile" not found as a combination in the OED.

Vn seau ou seel de quoy on seelle, a
seale or signet: m.

Sec, seeke seicher.

Seiche, a kinde of fishe called of some
a Cuttle: f.

Second, second.

Vn second moymesme, an other my
selfe, my fellowe: m.

Secondement, secondly.

La secondine ou arriere-fais d'vne
fame, f: the second birth, the skinne
wherein the child or beast is wrap­
ped.

Seconder autruy, to practise to do as
well as an other, to followe an other
in order.

Seconder au combat, to ayde and 
helpe one in fight, to be at his





side for helpe.

Fame laquelle n'a seconde en
beauté, a peerelesse woman in beau­
tie.

Allez au choc, à la charge, orà la
cargue & je vous seconderay, 
goe to the chocke, charge, or onset,
and I will assist you, I will be your
second.

Secouër, to shake off.

Secousse, shaking off: f.

Son royaume a receu de grandes
secousses, his kingdome hath suf­
fred or receiued great blowes or sha­
kings.

Secourgeon, see Scourgeon.

Secouëment, a shaking: m.

Secourir & aider aucun, to succour
or helpe one, je secours, je secouru,
j'ay secouru, je secourray.

Secours, helpe, succour, aide: m.

Secours d'espagne, succour, which
commeth too late.

Aller au secours, to goe to helpe one.

Privé de tout secours, destitute of all
helpe.

Amy secourable, a comfortable or
helpefull freend: com.

Vn secret, a secret, a hidden thing:
masc.

Lieu secret, a secret or close place.

Estre secret, to be secret, to be close, to
keepe counsell.

Secrettement, secretly, closely.

Secretain, the Sexten of a Church:
masc.

Vn secretaire, a Secretarie or writer
of letters.

Vne secte & opinion suyvie par
beaucoup de gens, a sect or opi­
nion: f.

Vne secte & bande, a secte or com­
pany.

Seculier ou lay, non dedié à Dieu,
 Secular or Lay, not consecrated to
God.

Vn prestre séculier, a single priest, m:
that is, which is not a Monke or re­
ligious.

Sedentaire, as mestier sedentaire,  an
occupation or trade vsed in sitting,
as Shoemakers, Taylors, and such 
like.

Gens sedentaires, men occupied with
in the house sitting.

Séder & appaiser, to pacifie, to as­
swage.

Sédition, sedition: f.

Séditieux, seditious.

Séduire, je seduis, je sedui, j'ay sedu­
it, je seduiray, to seduce, to deceiue,
to misleade.

Séducteur, a deceiuer: m.

Séduction, deceiuing, seducing: f.

Sédulité & diligence, diligence: f.

Séel, ou seau à seeller, a seale to seale
with: pronounce Seler.

Séeler toutes choses que ce soit, to
seale all things.

Séellé, sealed.

Vn seelé, a couenant made and sealed
betweene partie and partie: m.

Séelleurs, the sealers: m.

Segle, Rie, seeke Seigle.

Ségreger & mettre à part, to put a
sunder.

Seguë, hemlockes: f.

Seiche, vne sorte de poisson, a fishe





called a Cuttle, some a Sounde:
fem."sound" antedates earliest OED citation (1611).

Seicher, to dry.

Seicher d'ennuï, to wither awaye
through heauinesse.

Seichement, drying: m.

Sec, dry.

Secheresse, drought: f.

Du Seigle, Rie: m.

Du pain de seigle, Rie bread.

Seigneur ou maistre, Lord, maister.
owner: m.

Seigneur foncier, or proprietaire,
 the landlord.

Seigneurie & maistrise, Lordship,
maistry: f.

La seigneurie de Geneve, de Venise
de Berne, &c. the segnory, that is the
soueraignty of Geneua, Venice, &c.

Droicts seigneuriaux, rights, rents,
or other seruice due vnto the Lord
of the soyle.

Seigneurier, to rule.

Vne seille, f: ou vn seau, m: a payle
or bucket.

Seillon, terre esleuée en vn champ
entre les rayons, the ridge
betweene the furrowes of Corne
masc.

Seillonner vne terre, to ridge a
ground.

Sillonner la mer, to saile vpon the 
Sea.

Sillonner vne presse de gens, to cut
a sunder or deuide a presse of people
to goe through.

Vne seime, grand filé à pescher
poisson, a great nette to take fish:
fem.

Le sein, the bosome: m.

Ceste fame a du sein, this woman
hath a bosome, a word spoken in moc­
kage, signifiyng that she hath great
dugges.

Mettre en son sein, to put in his bo­
some.

Seine, retz, filé, idem: as Seime, a 
net.

Seing, a marke, see Sing.

Sejourner en quelque lieu, to so­
iourne in a place, or remaine for a 
time.

Sejour, remaining, soiourning: m.

Sel, salte: m.

Sans sel, vnsauery, without tast, foo­
lish.

Vne selle, f: ou banc, m: a seate or
a fourme.

Selle ou autre couverture de che­
val, a saddle: f.

Seler les Chevaux, to saddle hor­
ses.

Vne selle percée pour aller à la sel­
le, a stoole of easement.

Aller à la selle, to goe to the stoole of
easement.

Vn selier, a Sadler: m.

Selon ce que je pense, according to
that I thinke.

Selon ce que je peux voir, as far as
I can see.

Ie prendray conseil selon le temps, I
will take counsaile as the time gi­
ueth or requireth.

Selon qu'il me semblera estre pro­
fitable, as it will seeme profitable.

Selon qu'il m'en peult souvenir, as
I can remember.





Semaille, sowing time, seeke Semer.

Il me semble que j'ay oui sa voix
maintenant devant la maison,
 me seemeth I heard his voice at the
doore.

Il me semble que j'ay memoire des­
puis qu'il a esté faict, me thinkes I 
remember since it was done.

Il te semble ainsi, thou thinkest
so.

Il semble à voir que tu dis la verité,
 it seemeth at the first shewe that
thou saiest truth.

Ainsi que bon te semblera, as thou
shalt thinke good.

Semblant couvert, Beau semblant,
 a cloked countenance, a faire shew:
masc.

Faulx semblant, a false or dissembling
countenance.

Ton faux semblant m'a deceu, thy
dissimulation hath deceiued me.

Semblable, com: & pareil, lyke.

Semblablement, likewise, also.

Semblance, shewe, likenes: f.

Semblance d'aucun, the likenesse of
one.

A la semblance, façon & maniére
de France, of or after the French
fashion.

Semelle or carlure de soulier, the sole
of a shoe: f.

Semelle de chausses, the sole of a pair
of hosen.

Semeler, or carler, to sole shoes.

Semer, to sowe seedes.

Semer quelque chose parmy le
peuple, to sowe or spread among
the people.

Semer guerre, to stirre warres.

Semé, ou planté, sowen or plan­
ted.

La place estoit semée d'armes de
leur chamaillis, the place was
spread with armour through their
fight: Amadis.

Elle a le visage semé de royolle, she 
hath her face couered with small
poxe.

Semé, or semencé, sowen.

Cler semé, as loyauté est cler se­
mée entre les humains, loyaltie is
scant among the humaine.

Semence, seede: f.

Cela n'est que semence, that is of no
estimation by his smallenes.

Semence de perles, small perles.

Semeur, a sower: m.

Semaille, or semaison, f: as temps de
semailles, sowing time.

Semestre, the space of sixe moneths.

Semillant & fretillant, m: a quicke
stirring or vnquiet fellowe.

Semondre quelqu'vn à souper, to
bid one to supper, je semonds, je
semondi, j'ay semond, or semon­
du, je semondray.

Semonce, a bidding, summoning: f.

Semondre aux nopces, to bid one to
a wedding.

Semonneur, a Sumner: m.

Sempiternel, qui dure tousjours,
 ayeduring, euerlasting, sempiter­
nall.

Le senat, la compaignie des Sena­
teurs & Conseilliers, the Senate
or company, Counsellours or Alder­
men: m.

I'y mettray tous mes cinq sens, I
will apply therunto all my fiue sen­
ses, that is, all my strength.Word entry missing from the Henry E. Huntington copy in EEBO (STC 6737), supplied from the Leeds copy facsimile by Scolar Press.

witte.Word entry missing from the Henry E. Huntington copy in EEBO (STC 6737), supplied from the Leeds copy facsimile by Scolar Press.

 what followes thereof? what ma­

Serain, or serein, beau temps, faire,
milde, and sweet weather, the mil­

Se garder du serain, to bee out of 
the mil-dewe, as in Summer time





at nine or tenne of the clocke in the
night.

Le Serein, the calme.

Sereiner la tempeste, to asswage the
tempest.

Sereiner les yeux, or la veuë, to
brighten the eyes or sight, to make
lightsome.

Serenité, fayrenesse of weather: f.

Serane, or Sereine, a mermayde: f.

Serancer du lin, to hetchell flaxe, to
hetchell hemp.

Seran, the combe to dresse flaxe: m:
a hetchell.

Vn serf, a seruant: m.

Servitude, ou subjection de ceux
qui sont serfs à quelque seigneur,
 seruitude, bondage, subiection.

Servilement, like a slaue.

Servilement & avec crainte, to
do a thing more through feare than
loue.

Servage, slauerie, bondage: m.

Enmener en servage, to carrie one
into captiuitie.

Delivrer de servage, to deliuer one
out of bondage.

Sergeant, a sergeant: m.

Vn sergeant tonnelier, an hooke
or 
tongues the which a Cooper vseth
about tunnes, hoggesheads, and
barrels.

Sergeantise, or sergeanterie, the of­
fice of a sergeant: f.

Seri, as temps doux & seri, m: fayre
weather.

La mer tranquille & serie, the calme
sea: f.

Il se tient coy & seri, he stirreth not,
he is quiet and still.

Serie, the eeuen, as à la serie de No­
el, at Christmas eeuen: f.

Temps serin, seeke Sereine.

Serin, a little birde feeding on thi­
stles, singing very sweetely: So we
say: Il chante comme vn serin, or
sereine, hee singeth as sweetely as
such a bird, or like a mermayde: m.

Seringue, or Syringue, a spoute, a 
Spring: f.

Le Serment & jurement qu'on fait,
 an othe: m.

Faire Serment, to take his othe.

Il est du serment, or ilz sont tous du
serment, when a company or hall do
all conspire together to maintaine
their liberty, commodity, &c. so
that a Forreiner leeseth time to seek
any redresse or helpe at their hands,
or of any of them.

Par mon serment, by my trueth, as
God helpe me.

Ie suy du serment de l'espée, I am
sworne a fencer: I am admitted at
fencing schoole.

Sermon, a sermon: m.

Sermonner au peuple, to preach and
make a sermon before the people.

Sermonneur, a preacher: m.

Seroit, should be, seeke Estre.

Seroit ce raison que, &c. were it rea­
son that, &c.

Seroit il possible? were it possible?

Serpe à esmondre les arbres, a hed­
ging bill: f.

Serpette, f: or serpillon, m: idem.

Vn serpent, a serpent, an adder: m.

Serpentin, of the nature of a serpent.





Serpentine, herbe, an hearbe called
Dragon, also a kinde of Artillery: f.

Serpenter, to goe like a Serpente, to
winde about.

Fleuve serpentant, a riuer winding
or turning about.

Serpeilliére, ou serpillére, a serpe-­
cloth: f.

Du serpolet, an hearbe like Sauorie,
and smelleth like Time: m.

Serrail de l'huis, the ringe of the
doore: also the palace of the Turke
where he keepeth his Concubines: 
masc.

Serrer, je serre, je serray, j'ay serré,
je serreray, to locke, to shut vp, to
put too, to close.

Serré, shut vp, thrust together.

Serre, as tenir aucun en serre, to hold
one in a streite: f.

Serrement, a thrusting together: m.

Serrément & à l'estroict, narrowly, or
streightly, or in a little roume.

Serres, f: the nayles or talents of a
Hawke.

Les Gruës tiennent d'vne des Ser­
res vn caillou pour ne s'endormir
au guet, the Cranes doe holde with
one of their clawes or talents a flint
lest they sleepe watching.

Serriette, f: Sauory: see Sarriette.

Serrure, a locke: f.

Serrurier, a locke-smith: m.

Servage, seruitude: seeke Serf.

Vne serviette, a napkin: f.

Servir, je sers, je servi, j'ay servi, je
serviray, to serue, to obey.

Aider & servir à aucun, to stand one
in some stead, or to be a help to one.

Se servir de quelque chose, to take
the vse of any manner of thing.

Cecy sert à cela, this serueth to that
vse.

Il sert beaucoup, &c. It is very good
to knowe, &c.

Tu ne sers icy de rien, thou doest no
good here.

Serviable, seruiceable, diligent, rea­
dy: com.

Serviteur, a seruant, a prentice: m.

Servante, a mayd seruant: f.

Service, seruice: m.

Servis, a kinde of duety due vnto the
Lord of the soyle in France.

Sestier, see Septier.

Seu, an elder tree: m.

Seu, see sçavoir.

Vin-aigre seurat, or surat, vinegar
made with elders: m.

Les arbres sont en seve, the trees cast
their leaues or sap: f.

La seve de la vigne, the bleeding of
the vine.

Vn homme severe, a cruell man.

Severement, seuerely.

Severité, cruelty, ouer streightnes: f.

La severonde, or sevronde du toict
d'vn edifice, the caues of a house,
that defendeth the wal from raine:
fem.this sense of "caves" appears not to be in the OED.

Seul, onely, singular: m.

Elle est seulle, shee is alone.

Seulette, a woman alone, as j'aime­
roye mieux dormir seulette, Que
d'avoir vn fascheus mary, I had
rather to sleepe alone, than to haue
an yrkesome husband: f.

Seulement, onely.





Ma seur, or sœur, my sister: f.

Ma belle sœur, my sister in law.

Qui est seur, surely, hee that is faith­
full.

En lieu seur, to be in a sure place.

Seur de la main, a man hauing a sure
hand, which doth not misse.

Estre à sureté, to be safe, or in sure­
tie: f.

Sureté & gage, suretie or pledge: f.

Surer, to weane from sucke

Qui est suré, that is weaned.

Sexe, a sexe or kinde: m.

Sextement, for the sixt time.

Sextier de bled, a measure of corne,
a quarter: leaue x."leaue x" may be a note to the lexicographer or the printer.

Si son pere estoit retourné, If his 
father were come home agayne.

Si tu le fais, if thou doe it.

Si comme, so as, euen as.

Si ferez vous cela, nilling, willing, you
shall doe that.

Il est sçavant, & si est vaillant aux
armes, he is learned, and besides va­
liant in armes.

Si faut-il faire cela, ribon ribaine,
 yet for all that this must be doone,
maugre our heartes, or in the
spite of all menne, or whether we
will or no.

Ie le feray, par tel si que, &c. I will
doe it, but vpon such condition
that, &c.

Si non que, sauing that.

Si que, in such sorte that.

Si fort, so strongly.

Sibler, see Siffler, to whistle.

Siboule, seeke Ciboule, a scallion: f.

Sybylle, a Sybel, a woman prophecying.

Carmes, or vers Sybillins, verses of
a Sybell.

Siccité, drinesse: f.

Sidre, Cidre: m.

Siche, seeke Chiches: m.

Vne Sie, a Sawe: f.

Sier, to sawe.

Sié, sawed.

Siement de blé, a cutting downe of
wheate: m.

Siette, f: a little sawe.

Siécle, age, & en ce nostre siecle, in
this our age.

Aux siécles à venir, m: in the time to
come.

Sied, setting becoming, seeke Seant.

Il luy sied bien àe parler, it becomes
him well to speake.

Cest habit te sied bien, this garment
becommeth thee well.

Le siége de l'homme, that part that
a man sitteth on, the arse: f.

Siége, ou chaire, a seat or chayre.

Le siége & parquet des grands ju­
ges, the seate of the Iudges.

Le siége royal, the kings throne.

Le siége & assault qu'on baille à
vne ville, the siege of a towne.

Lever le siége, to rayse the siege.

Sien, his.

Garder le sien, to keepe his owne.

Chacun y a baillé du sien, euery one
hath distributed towards it.

Elle est sienne, she is his.

Sieu, the tallow of red deere: m.

Des siens, of his.

Sier, see Sie.
