of the Lungs, the great pipe: m.

Sigale, or Cigale, a grashopper: f.

Signacle, or Caractere, m: a marke,
signe or token.

Signal, as vn signal de feu, a signe or
token, as when one lighteth fiers
vpon beacons: m.

Signamment, namely.

La signature d'vn Notaire, the sig­
nature or marke of a Notarie.

Vn signe au ciel, a signe in the heauen: m.

Signe manuël, a signe manuell: m.

Vn signe qui denote quelque cho­
se, a signe that signifieth something.

Signes d'amours, signes of loue.

Signer, to signe.

Signer de sa main, to signe with his
hande.

Vn signet, a signet: m.

Signifier, to signifie, to giue notice, to
shew.

Que signifie cecy? what doth this sig­
nifie? what meaneth this?

Signifiance, signifiyng, significati­
on: f.

En signifiance de quoy, &c. in to­
ken whereof, &c.

Silence, silence: f.

Siliquastre, Spanish pepper, or of In­
dia: m.

Siller les yeux, to blinde ones eyes, to
sowe the eye liddes of a Hawke to
carrie her farre.

Faire des Simagrées, to make sowre
and ill fauoured faces and counte­
nances.

Vn Simier de bœuf, m: an Oxe
pizel.

Similitude, similitude, likenesse: f.

Simme, the top of a tree, or mountain,
&c: f.

Simmonie, simonie: f.

Simoniaque, hee which selleth the
goods of the Church.

Simple, simple.

Simplement, simply.

Simplesse, ou simplicité, simplici­
tie: f.

Simplette bergere, a very simple
shepearing.

Simulachre, an Image or picture:
masc.

Simulation, simulation, hypocrisie: f.

Simulateur, a dissembler: m.

Vn sing-manuël, a handwriting.

Contre-faire vn sing-manuël, to
counterfeyte another mans signe or
hande.

Il a aporté ce sing du ventre de sa
mere, he hath brought this marke
foorth of his mothers wombe.

Sing, sometime is a bell, or the ring­
ing of belles: as les sings sonnent,
the belles doe ring.

Tu n'as pas fait sonner les sings pour
vn tel fait, that is, thou hast not
blowen abroade this thy facte, thou
diddest not boast of it.

On a sonné le toc-sing, they haue
sounded an alarme: sonner le toc­
sing, is when they will haue the
commons to rise, or when any house
is on fire, or to runne vpon their e­
nemies, they strike hard and thicke
the greatest bell of the Parish, then
all the people runne as it were to the
outcrye, or the firing of beacons





here in England.

Vn singe, an ape: m.

Singeot, a little ape: m.

Cest mon singe, hee goeth about to
counterfeit me, that is, to doe as I
haue done.

Singeries, Apish tricke, or doings of
an Ape: f.

Singeries, f & badinages, m: Vi­
ces, Iuglers, and Morishe trikes.

Singler sur mer, to saile, to cutte the
seas.

Singler aulcun d'vn fouët, or d'vne
verge, to swinge one with a rodde,
to ierke him so, that the rodde may
girth his buttocks or thighes round 
about.

Singulier, singuler, alone.

Par grand singularité, with great
singularitie: f.

Singuliére beauté, an excellent beau­
tie.

Singuliérement, singularly.

Personne ne me l'ostera, sinon la
mort, no man shall take her from
me, but onely death.

Il n'y a personne qui l'ait dit sinon
toy, no body hath spoken the same
sauing thou; except thou or but on­
ly thou.

Sinople, vne sorte de couleun, a kind
of greene colour, sinople: m.

Vn sion & jecton d'arbre long d'vn
pied, qu'on plante en terre, a scion
or plant of a tree: m.

Sire, that is, maister, but this worde
alone without addition is onely to
the King, but adding the proper
name, it is attributed to Marchants,
as Le sire Iehan N. le m'a vendu:
as for the compound which is Mes­
sire it is giuen onely to priestes, and
Knights of the order.

Du sisame ou jugeoline, a kinde of
white grayne so called: m.

Vn sistre, a Citterne: m.

Situer, to place, to set, to situate.

Situé, placed, situate.

La situation de quelque chose, the
situation of a place: f.

Du sivé, seame, or swines grease: m.

Sivé, is a kind of sauce or broth wher­
with wee doe dresse in France the
fore parte of an Hare: m.

Du sivé d'oistres, or d'huistres, Oi­
sters stued: m.

Sive, sivette, sivotte, Scallions, Ciuet
seeke Cives.

Six, sixe.

Six fois, sixe times.

Six ans, sixe yeare.

Le Siziesme aage, the sixt age.

Vn sixain, a piece of French money
worth somewhat more than a half­
penny: m.

Sobre, sober, continent: com.

Sobrement, soberly.

Sobrieté, sobrietie: f.

Sobriquet, a nip, a mock, a nick name.

Le soc d'vne charruë, the coulter of
a plough: m.

Societé, societie, fellowship: f.

Sociable, familiar, frequenting com­
panies, easie to be found in company.

Sodalité, brotherhood, communaltie,
a colledge.

Sodomie, the act of buggerie.

Sodomite, a buggerer.





Soef, ou souëf, sweete, smooth.

Soefveté, sweetnesse, smoothenesse: f.

Soefvement, sweetly, gently, smooth­
lye.

Sœur, seeke seur, sister.

Soie, or sée de porc, the bristle or 
the great hayre of a hogge, seeke
Soye: f.

Soif, thirst: f.

Avoir soif, to bee on thirst.

Solure & escorcheure faicte en la
peau, a breaking of the skinne, as
when one through riding hath his 
tayle sore: f.

Soimesme ou soymesme, himselfe.

Soin, care, diligence: m.

Avoir soing de quelque chose, to
care for some thing, to sette the
minde.

Soigner, to care.

Soigneux & diligent à faire quel­
que chose, carefull, diligent: m.

Soigneux en ses affaires, diligent in
his businesse.

Elle est fort Soigneuse, she is very
carefull: f.

Soigneusement, diligently, care­
fully.

Sur le Soir, vpon the euening: m.

La soirée, the euening tide: f.

Le soir , the euening.

Tous les soirs, euerey euening.

Sois, soit, il vient de estre, bee thou,
be it.

Ne sois plus courroucé contre luy,
 be no more angry with him.

Soit ainsi, be it so.

Soixante, sixtie, or three score.

Le Sol & fondement de toutes cho­
ses, the foundation of any thing: m.

Vn escu sol, a crowne of golde, of the
Sunne: m.

Se solacier, to take his pastime, to 
sporte, to be merrie.

Vn sold, seeke solz, a souse, a kinde of
French money.

Soldan, seeke Souldan.

Soldat, a souldier, seeke Souldart, in
Souldoyer.

La sole du pied, the plante of the
foote, also the sole of hosen or shooes:
as soler, or semeller des chausses,
or souliers: Sole, is taken for little
beames, bearing the flower in buil­
ding, called a ioyste: also a fish called
a Sole: finally hunters doe call the
vnder parte of the foote of the
wilde Boare, Sa sole du pied du
sanglier: f.

Soleil, the Sunne: m.

Soleil levant, the Sun rising.

Soleil couchant, the Sunne setting: 
the Sunne at glade.

Soleiller, to Sunne, or to sette in the 
Sunne.

Soleillé, warme or dryed at the
sunne.

Solenniser, to solemnize, or to cele­
brate.

Solemnisation & feste, solemnization.

Solennité, sound, tune: f.

Garder les solennitez requises &
accoustumées, to keepe the order,
custome, and solemnities accusto­
med.

Iuger selon les solennitez de la loy,
 to iudge according to prescription
or clauses of the lawe.





Solennel, qui se fait tous les ans, so­
lemnities that are vsed euery yeare.

Solennellement, solemnely.

Solerre, vent, the east winde: m.

Soliciter aucun, & le presser fort de
faire quelque chose, to solicite one,
to entreate one instantly to doe a
thing.

Soliciter vn homme à faire quelque
chose, & l'en requerir, to solicite a
man and require him to doe a thing.

Soliciter vn proces, to followe a suite.

Vn Soliciteur de proces, an Attour­
ney, a solicitor: m.

Solicitude, carefulnesse: f.

Solicitation, soliciting: f.

Solide, fast, massie, sound.

Faire, or getter vn fundement solide,
 to lay a sure foundation.

Iugement solide, a sound iudgement.

Dur & solide comme diamant, a 
sound & hard thing as a Diamond.

Solier, a shooe, seeke Soulier: m.

Vn solier ou grenier, m: a soller or
garret.

Solitaire, solitarie.

Cercher les lieux solitaires, to seeke
for solitarie places.

Solitude, solitarinesse: f.

Vne solive, the rafter of a house, a
beame: f.

Soliveau, a ioyce of a house.

Soloir, to be wont, seeke Souloir.

Solstice, the greatest and shortest day
of the yeare: m.

Solsticial, m: pertayning to the time
when the Sun is at the furthest.

Solsie, seeke Soulsie.

Estre solvable, pouvoir payer ses
detes, to be able to paye his debts:
com.

Solution ou payement, payment, an 
answere: as bailler la solution d'­
vne question ou doubte, to giue a 
solution, resolution, or answere of
a doubt: f.

Solution ou dissolution du corp &
de l'ame, the breaking a sunder or
departing of the body and soule.

Vn sols, ou sold, a shilling: m.

Vint sols, twenty shillings, a pound:
sound son, and sous.

Temps sombre, drowsie weather.

Sommaire, the summe: m.

Sommairement, summarily.

Somme d'argent, f: a summe of mo­
ney.

Somme ou charge de charbon, a
horse lode of coales, a burthen: f.

Sommer, to cast account, to summe,
to fill to the toppe or finish, also to
summon one, as sommer quelcun
à garant, to call for a warrant.

Sommer quelcun de sa promesse, to
call vpon one to fulfill his promise.

Somme, sleepe: m.

Sommeil, slumbering: m.

Sommeiller, to slumber.

Le sommeil m'a prins, the sleep hath
taken me.

En sommmeillant, slumbering.

Sommeilleux, sleepie, drousie: m.

Sommeillard, which slumbreth often,
a drowsie one, a sluggish one: m.

Vn sommelier, a bottle bearer: m.

La sommelerie, the wine Celler: f.

Le sommet, ou coupet de quel­
que chose, the toppe or height of





any thing.

Sommité, f: the top of any thing.

Sommier musical, m: see Canon.

Vn sommier, Cheval portebahuz, 
 a sumpter horse: m.

Vn sommier en charpenterie, a piece
of timber called a sommer: m.

Somptuëux banquet, a sumptuous
banquet.

Sumptuosité, superfluitie, sumptu­
ousnesse: f.

Somptuëusement, sumptuously.

Loix Somptuäires, lawes for apparel
and excesse: f.

Son esclatant, a crashing, a rough or
great sound and noyse.

Danser au son du menestrier, to
daunce after the minstrels piping.

Sonnaille, the bell which cattell haue
about their necke: f.

Mouton sonnaillier, the Wether that
beareth the bell: m.

Sonner, to sound, to ring, to call.

Arains sonnans, ringing plates.

Sonnette, a little bell: f.

Sonoreux, which giueth a sound.

Du son, branne: m.

Vne sonde à marinier, f: a sounding
plummet.

Sonder la riviére, to sounde the depth
of the riuer.

Songer, to dreame.

Songé, dreamed.

Songeard, a dreamer: m.

Songearde, a dreaming woman: f.

Tu as songe cela de nouveau, thou
hast imagined this now of late.

Songe-malice, com: an imaginer of
mischiefe.

Vn soner, a Sonet, a Metre of four­
teene verses: m.

Sophisme, Sophistry: m.

Sophistiquer, to falsifie, corrupt, or
counterfeite.

Sor, as harenc sor, a red herring.

Faulcon sor, a hawke of this yeare
without mue, and yet hath fled: m.

La pippée du Sor, when the weather
waxeth colde.

Sorcier, a Sorcerer: m.

Sorciére, a Sorceresse: f.

Sorcelierie, Sorcerie: f.

Sorceler, to bewitch.

Sori, seeke Souri, a mouse.

Vne sornette, a gaude, a toy, a iest: f.

Conteur de sornettes, a teller of
tales.

Sorte & maniére, f: sorte and man­
ner.

Mon Sororge, m: my sisters hus­
band.

Sort, a lot: le sort tomba sur Mathi­
as, the lot fell vpon Matthias: m.

Ilz ont par sort departi entre eux
l'office de ramer & gascher, they
haue cast a lotte who shall row with
oares: m.

Prendre argent à cinq pour cent à
tous-jours sans repetition du sort,
 to take money fiue to the hundred
for euer without calling backe or
repeating the principall.

De ceste sorte, on this manner: f.

Sortable, sortable: com.

Sortilege, witchcraft: m.

Sortir & saillir hors, to goe foorthe,
to issue out: je sors, je sorti, je suy





sorti, je sortiray.

Faire sortir à force de coups, to beate
him out.

Sortie, issuing out, going out: f.

Sorti & garny, sorted and furni­
shed.

Sorti de fil & d'aguille, garnished
with needle and threed, a prouerbe.

Vn sot, a foole, an idiote: m.

Sot & legier, a rash fellowe: m.

Chose sotte & contraire à soymes­
me, a fond thing, and contrary to
it selfe: f.

Sottelet, m: a little sotte.

Sottement, foolishly, fondly.

Sottie, ou sottisse, fondnesse, foolish­
nesse, dotage: f.

Sotbriquet, a nicke-name, a taunte:
masc.

Sou, be hogges feete kept in brine, or
greene sauce made with greene Rie.

Vn soubassement de colomne &
autre chose, the foot or bases of a 
columne, or piller, also a gallerie or
vaulte vnder the earth: m.

Soubchantre, seeke Subchanter.

Soub-contrerolleur, which is vnder
the controller.

Subcurateur, which is vnder the tu­
tor.

Soubdain, sodaine.

Soudain, ou soubdainement, so­
dainely, immediately, swiftly.

Soubdaineté, f: sodainenesse, swifte­
nesse.

Soubdepensier, an vnder-butler: m."under-butler" antedates the earliest OED citation (1611).

Soubdiacre, a Subdeacon: m.

Soubhaster, seeke subhaster.

Soubhastation, selling of forfeyte
goods by porte sale.

Soubject, ou subject, a subiect.

Subjection, subiection: f.

Soublever, to heaue vp, to staye.

Submerger, to drowne.

Soubmettre, to vnder prop, to sub­
mit: see mettre: for the decl.

Soubmission, submission: f.

Soubmis, as il s'est submis à sa mer­
ci, he hath submitted himselfe to
his mercie.

Subministrer, to serue or minister
vnder an other.

Soubministration, Subministring:
fem.

Soubpenduës, ou souspenduës de
maisons, The pentises of houses,
garrets: f.

Soubpeser, to weigh, to ponder.

Faiseur de soubresaults, a fetcher of 
gamboldes, a tumbler: m.

Se soubrire, to smile.

Soubris, smiling: m.

Soubs, vnder.

Soubscrire, to vnderwrite, or to sub­
scribe.

Soubscription, f: subscribing.

Soubsigner, to vnder signe.

Soubtenir, ou soubstenir, to sustaine,
to beare.

Soubson, f: suspition: see Souspe­
çon.

A peine me soubstiens je de peur
que j'ay, scarcely doe I stand vpon
my feete for feare.

Soubstenement, m: a proppe.

Soubstenance, f: vpholding.

Soubstenable, to be sustained, obser­
ued, vpholden, maintained, com.





Soub-terrains, as lieux soub-ter­
rains, places or boles vnder the
earth: m.

Maison soubterraine, f: an house vn­
der the earth.

Soubtraire, to withdrawe, to take a­
waye priuily, to allure, as soubtraire
à soy le serviteur d'autruy, to en­
tise another mans seruant, to with­
draw him from his seruice.

Soubtraire la fame d'aulcun, to al­
lure or entise an others wife.

Se soubtraire de l'amitié d'aucun
peu peu, to retire, or withdrawe
himselfe from another mans freind­
ship by little and little.

Serviteurs soub trayans, seruants
pickers.

Soubz, vnder.

Soubz vmbre d'amitié, vnder the
shadow of friendship.

Soubz le Roy Henry huictiesme,
 that is vnder the raigne of King
Henry the eyght.

La souche d'vn arbre, the body of a 
tree, a logge: f.

Qui est sorti d'vne mesme souche,
 which is come of the same stocke.

Souci, care: marigolde, a flower: m.

Enfans sans souci, carelesse chil­
dren.

Du souci, marrigolde: m.

Soudain, swifte.

Soudan, a Soldan: m.

Soudard, a Souldier: m.

Souder, to sunder.

Souëf, seeke Sœf.

Souëvement, smoothly.

Souffire, to suffice.

Du souchet, a kind of galingale: m.

Soustenance, f: ou sustenement, m: 
 maintenance: see Soubstenir.

Souffler, to blowe, to breathe.

Souffler le feu, to blowe the fire.

Souffleurs de charbons, blowers of
coles: m.

Soufle, as ce sont soufles, m: they be
tales: also ones breath.

Vn soufflet à souffler le feu, a payre
of bellowes: m.

Vn soufflet sus la jouë, a boxe on the
eare: m.

Souffleter, ou bailler des soufflets,
 to boxe, to clappe on the eare.

Suffre, seeke Soulfre.

Souffrir, je souffre, je souffri, j'ay
souffert, je souffriray, to beare, to 
suffer.

Souffrance, sufferance, forbearance: f.

Souffrette, neede, penurie: f.

Soufreteux, a needie person: m.

Souhait, a wish: m.

Tout nous vient à souhait, it hap­
neth vnto vs as we would wish.

Souhaitable, a thing desirable to bee
wished for: com.

Souhaiter, to wish or desire.

Souillard, a dogges name who was
the beginning of a notable race of
hunting dogges in Fraunce: see
Bauds.

Souiller, to soyle, to defile, to beraye,
leaue i.

Souillé, soyled, rayed.

Soillure, soyle, filth.

Vn souillon, a slouenly fellowe, a
scullion: m.

Soulacier, to Solace, to be or make





one merie.

Soulagement, m: solace, or solacing.

Soulas, solace, ease, ioy: seeke Solas: m.

Soulager, to cheere vp, to ease one.

Se Soulcier, to take care.

Soulci, m: carefulnesse, marigold.

Soulcieux, m: carefull.

De quoy te Soucies-tu? what doest
thou care for?

Ie ne me Soucie de rien, I care for
nothing.

Souldan, m: Solean or Soultan, in
the Moorish tongue signifieth a
Prince or Soueraigne."Solean" not found in OED; perhaps a form of "suleiman," a proper name.

Soulder, to soulder.

Souldure, f: souldring.

Souldoyer & payer la Soulde aux
gents de guerre, to pay Souldiers
their wages.

La Soulde & gages qu'on baille aux
gents de guerre tous les mois, the 
Souldiers monthly wages: f.

Estre à la Soulde d'vn prince, to take
wages of a Prince in Martiall af­
faires.

Vn Souldart, or Soldat, a souldier.

Vn viel Souldart cassé, an old soul­
dier put out of wages.

Souldre vne question, to resolue a
question.

Que ay-je à faire, ne que souldre a­
vec toy? what haue I to deale with
thee?

Soulfre, brimstone: m.

Soulfreux, or Soulfureux, full of
brimstone.

Vn Soulier, a shooe: m.

Souliers à poulaine, shooes opened 
vpon the foote and tyed with a
latchet.

Souloir, to be wont.

Vn Souls, Sols, ou Sold, a shilling, a 
souse, there bee three score in a 
French crowne, pronounce vn Sou,
trois Sous.

Soulsie: f: ou soulsi: m: herbe, ma­
rigolds.

Soumettre, to submit, seeke Soub­
mettre.

Soupçon, suspition: f.

Soupçonneux, full of suspition.

Vne Soupe, a soppe: f.

Il est yvre comme vne soupe, he is
as dronke as a sop.

Tu me fais de tel pain soupes, thou
makest me good cheare at mine
owne costs and charges.

Souper, to sup.

Soupple & aisé à plier, supple & ea­
sie to be bent.

Tour d'abileté & soupplesse, a trick
of nimblenesse: f.

Iouër de soupplesse, to play with pup­
pets to tumble: f.

Source, the spring, the beginning: f.

Le Sourcil, the eye brow: m.

Les sourcilz pelez, or rasez, when
the haires of the eye browes are pil­
led and plucked.

Ces sourcilz monstrent que tu es
malicieux, those eye browes doe
shewe that thou art malitious.

Sourciller, to moue vp and downe the
browes.

Sorcilleux, hauing great browes: also
a thing risen or lifted vp: m.

Sourd, or Sourdault, m: deafe.

Raisons sourdes, dum reasons, hauing





no demonstration.

Sourdesse ou sourdeté, deafenesse: f.

Sourdre, se lever, se dresser, se mon­
strer, to rise out, to boyle out, to
spring out.

Sourdant, springing out.

Surgeon & rejecton des arbres, a
branch or twig of a tree, a flower:
masc.

Le surgeon d'vne fontaine, the spring
of a fountaine.

Vne souris ou sori, a mouse: f.

Vn Sourisseau, a little mouse.

Vne souriciére, a mouse trap: f.

Les souriez du corps qu'on appel­
le muscles, les parties charnuës du
corps, the muscles of the body, or
the brawne: m.

Sous, see Soubz.

Souspeçon, suspition, deeming: f.

Par souspeçon, by suspition.

Souspeçonneusement, Idem.

Souspçonné, suspected.

Estre souspeçonné, to be suspected.

Souspeçoneux, suspitious: m.

Fame souspeçnneuse, a suspitious
woman: f.

Souspenduë, or souspente, garrets:
fem.

Souspir, a sigh: m.

Souspirer, to sigh.

Il souspire apres le ciel & le regret­
te, he sigheth after heauen, and wi­
sheth for it.

Vn souspiral de cave, m: a celler win­
dowe, a breath or passage whereby
the breath passeth.

Soustenir, or soustenance, see soub­
tenir.

Soustraire, see soubtraire.

Vne soutane, a kind of apparell.

Souterrain, see soubterrains.

Se souvenir, il me souvient, il me
souvint, il m'est souvenu, il me
souviendra, to remember, to call to
memorie.

Selon qu'il m'en peult souvenir, as
I may remember.

Il me souvient, I remember.

Faire souvenir, to put one in remem­
braunce.

Souvenance, remembrance: f.

I'ay souvenance de cela, I remem­
ber that.

Faites qu'ilz ayent souvenance,
 cause them to remember.

Souvent, ou souventessois, often, ma­
ny times.

Souverain remede, & excellent con­
tre la morsure des serpens, a soue­
raigne & excellent remedie against
the byting of a sarpent.

Les cours souveraignes, the high
courts.

Souveraine puissance, the high po­
wer.

Souveraineté, the soueraignety: f.

Soy, he himselfe, or she her selfe: as
que chacun regarde à soy, let eue­
ry man looke to himselfe.

Soye comme de porceau, hogges
bristles: m.

Soyeux, or sieux, full of bristles.

Soye à faire habillement, silke: f.

Soymesme, ou soimesme, him­
selfe.

Spasme & retirement de nerfs,
 shrinking of the sinewes: m.

Sublime, high, loftie, honorable.

Du sublimé, sublimie, a kinde of poi­
son: m.

Submerger, to drowne.

Submerge, ouerflowen, drowned.

Suborner vn accusateur ou tes­
moing, to bribe an accuser or wit­
nesse: to corrupt a witnesse.

Suborneur de filles, an intiser of
young wenches to folly: m.

Subornement, an intising, a subuer­
ting, a corrupting: m.

Subornation, f: Idem.

Subroguer, or subroger, mettre en
la place d'vn autre, to appoynt one
in an others place.

Subsequent, which followeth imme­
diately, as la nuict subsequente,
the next night following.

Subside, ou secours, subsidie, help: m.

Substance, substance: f.

Substantifique, com: see Humorale.

Substantieux, full of substance.

Substituer, ou mettre aucun en la 
place d'vn autre, to substitute one
in an others place.

Substitution, substitution: f.

Le substitu d'un aultre, the Lieute­
nant, or he that supplyeth the place
or charge of another, as an Vsher of
a schoole: m.

Subterfuge, delayes, craftie and dou­
ble proceeding in the law: m.

Cercher les subterfuges, to seeke the
corners and hiding places.

Subtil, subtil, craftie, slie.

Subtilement, subtilely, craftily, slily.

Subtilité, subtiltie, craft, slight: f.

Sans subtilité, without subtiltie.

Subtilizer quelque moyen, to inuent
and imagine some meane.

Subtiler les humeurs, to diminish 
ones humours when they bee too
grosse, and make them thinner, and
purifie them.

Subvenir, seeke survenir.

Subvertir, to subuert: je subvers,
je subverti, j'ay subverti, je subver­
tiray.

Subversion, ouerthrowing.

Suc, iuice: m.

Sucer, to sucke.

Sucement, a sucking: m.

Succeder à aucun & estre mis en
sa place, to succeede in the place
of another.

Cela te succedra mal, that will haue
an ill successe for thee.

Noz successeurs, our successours: m.

La succession d'vn trespassé, the suc­
cession of one that is dead: f.

Par succession de temps, in continu­
ance of time.

Successivement, successiuely.

Succes, an euent or happe, mon cas a
heu mauvais succes, my matter
hath had an ill successe or end: m.

Succinctement & en peu de parol­
les, briefly, and in few wordes.

Sucomber, cheoir, to fall downe vn­
der a burthen.

Sucre, sugar: m.

Sud, see Zud.

Le suil d'vn huis, a thresholde: also
the place where the wild Boare doth
wallowe: m.

Suër, to sweate.

Ie suë de toutes pars, I sweat on euery





side.

La suëur, sweate: f.

Suëur, qui sue, a sweater: m.

Suant, sweating.

Suement, or Suerie, sweater: f.

Suffire, to suffice: a verbe imperso­
nall: il suffist, il suffisoit, il suffit, il
a suffit, il avoit suffit, il suffira.

Suffire à vne femme, to satisfie a wo­
man.

Cela ne suffist pas, that sufficeth not.

Vous suffise, je vous prie, let this suf­
fice I pray you.

I'ay des biens à suffisance, I haue
goods sufficiently: f.

Suffisamment, sufficiently.

Temps à suffisance, sufficient time.

Suffoquer & estouffer, to strangle, to
smoother.

Suffocation, smoothering: f.

Vn Suffragant, the deputy of a Bishop
in the Church of Rome: m.

Suggerer, bailler & fournir, to giue
or furnish, to prompte.

Suggestion, f: a prompting, an intiseing.

Il a fait cela, par la suggestion du
dyable, he hath done that by the
diuels intisement or solicitation.

Suïf, tallow: m,

Suivre, Suite, seeke Suyvre.

Suïn, laine avec le suin, the oyle that
is in wooll: m: wooll vnwasht with
a certaine fatnesse.

Suïnter, to giue, as in rainie weather
the stones doe.

La playe suïnte, the wound casteth
out moystnesse, or sweateth.

Sumelle, seeke Semelle.

Sumerger, to drowne, seeke Submer­
ger.

Superabonder, to abound.

Superabondance, ouermuch: f.

Superbe, proud, com.

Vn bastiment superbe, a magnifi­
cent and sumptuous building.

Superficie, the vttermost part of any
thing: f.

Superficiellement, ouercasting.

Le superficiel & extérieur de quel­
que chose, the outward or vpper­
most part of any thing.

Tout le superflu qu'on jecte de
quelque chose que ce soit, the su­
perfluitie or casting off of any thing:
masc.

Superflu & ne servant de rien, su­
perfluous seruing to no vse.

Superfluité, superfluitie: f.

Avoir la superintendance des af­
faires de la ville, to haue the charge
and ouersight of all the Citie: f.

Supérieur, a superiour: m.

Supériorité, superioritie: f.

Superlatif, in the third and highest
degree.

Superlativement, passingly.

Supernaturel, supernaturall, ouerna­
turall.

Supernaturellement, beyond the or­
der of nature.

Supernel, Supernall, high, that is a­
boue.

Supernellement, an high, from a­
boue.

Supernumeraire, ouer the number,
that is, which cannot be numbred.

Superscription, tiltre & escripteau
qu'on fait sus quelque chose pour
la cognistre, superscription or note: f.





Superstition, superstition: f.

Superstitieux, qui fait scrupule &
danger ou il ne fault pas, supersti­
tiouns, that maketh scruple of that
he needeth not: m.

Superstitieusement, superstitiously.

Suplice, punishment: m.

Supplanter, to supplant, to roote vp, to
goe betweene one and home.

Supplantez, supplanted, rooted vp.

Suppléer, & amender la faute de quel­
que chose par vn autre, to make a­
mends by another, to supply a thing,
as il faut suppléer & aider à la let­
tre, we must supply or help the letter.

Suppliment & remplissement, a fil­
ling, a performing: m.

Supplier aucun, to beseech one.

Suppliant, a suppliant: m.

Le suppliant a esté debouté de sa re­
queste, the suter or suppliant hath
been put beside his request.

Supplication, a supplication: f.

Supporter, endurer, to support, to
beare, to suffer.

Supporter aucun, to maintaine one.

Supporte moy, beare with me.

support faict à aucun, fauour shew­
ed to one: m.

Support & apuy de quelque chose, 
 a prop or stay.

Cela est supportable, that is to bee
borne, insupportable is the contra­
rie, com.

Supposer & mettre dessoubs, to put
vnder.

Supposer vn enfant, to chaunge a 
child.

Vn Suppositoire, a Suppositarie: m.

Supprimer, cacher & receler quel­
que chose, to suppresse, or conceale
a thing.

Supprimé, suppressed.

Suppression, an oppression: f.

Supputation, reckoning, counting: f.

Sur, ou tirant sus l'aigre, sower or
sharpe.

Suret, somewhat sharpe: m.

Sur, ou sus quelque chose, vpon.

Sur tout que, &c. before all.

Sur le vespre, on the euen.

Surabonder, to ouerflow, to exceed.

Suracheter, to ouerbuy.

Suranné, that is ouer a yeare.

Suradjouster, to adde more.

Suranné, m: hauing more yeares.

Surattendre, to goe softly by the way
looking or staying for another.

Surboire, to drinke vpon ones meat.

Surcharger, to ouerlade.

Vn surcot, such apparell as a woman
putteth on her next peticote: m: a
kirtle.

Surcouvrir, to couer ouer.

Surcroist, qui est baillé oultre la me­
sure, ouerplus, that which is more
then measure: m.

Surcroistre, to ouergrowe: see Croi­
stre.

Sirdoté, deaffenesse: f.

Surdorer, to gilt ouer.

Sureau, as de Sureau, of alder tree:
masc.

Surelle, or ozeille, sorrell: f.

Surfaire vne marchandise, to holde
ware at too great a price.

Surflorir, to flourish ouer a thing.

Surfloter, to swim vpon.





Surgeon, a sprigge, seeke Sourgeon.

Surgir, je surgis, je surgi, j'ay sur­
gi, je surgiray, to rise out of the wa­
ter, also when a ship taketh land in
some coasts.

Surhaster, to cause one to make more
hast.

Se Surhaucer, as vn bon cueur se
surhaulce contre fortune, a stoute
heart riseth against fortune.

Surjetter, to ouercast.

Surject, or surjettement, an ouerca­
sting: m.

Surintendans, as les surintendans
des vivres & fortifications, the o­
uerseers of victuals and fortify­
ing: m.

Surlier, to tye or bind ouer or vpon.

Surmarcher, to tread vpon.

Surmonter & vaincre, to ouercome.

Surmonté, ouercommed.

Surmontement, an ouercomming:
masc.

Surnager, to swim ouer or vpon.

Surnaistre, to ouergrow.

Surnom & sobriquet, a surname, or 
nickname: m.

Surnommer, to surname one.

Sur-oindre, to annoynt ouer.

Sur-onder, to waue vpon the waues
of the sea.

Suros, a disease in horses: m.

Sur-passer aucun, to passe one, to bee
more excellent.

Super-arbitre, a numpeer."numpeer" (not found in the OED) seems to be the lexicographer's error for "nonpareil".

Surpendant, ouerhanging.

Le surplus & ce qui est de reste, the
ouerplus, that which remaineth.

Au surplus, further that, that more is

Surprendre, to take one at a sodaine.

Estre surprins, to be taken vnawares.

Surprinse, sodaine taking: f.

Sçavoir toutes les surprinsez & cau­
telles, or finesses qui se font en
proces, to know all the tricks, crafts
and subtilties which be vsed in the
law.

Surroguer, seeke Subroguer.

En Sursault, vnawares, sodainly.

Séveiller en sursault, to awake star­
ting.

Il m'a prins en sursault, he hath ta­
ken me vpon a sodaine: m.

Sursemer, to sowe vpon.

Vn porc sursené, a mesled hogge: m.

Surseoir, to surcease, to pause.

Surceance, delaying, or deferring: f.

Survendre, to ouersell: see Vendre.

Survenir, to come on a sodaine, to come
by chance, also to assist and help one
with his goods.

Survenant, comming by chance.

Survenuë: f: ou suvenement: m:
 a sodaine chauncing vpon a com­
panie.

Survestir, to clothe vpon, or to put a­
loft.

Survivre, to ouerliue, to outliue: see
Vivre.

Survivant, the outliuer.

Survuïder, to emptie out of one vessel
into another.

Sus, ou sur, vpon.

Il est remis sus, he is set vp againe.

Sus devant, goe to, goe forward.

Susceptible, as l'ame de la fame est
susceptille de vertu, aussi bien que
celle de l'home, soules of women­





kind are as able to receiue the print
of vertue, as &c.

Susciter & mettre en avant quelque
chose, to raise vp, or bring a thing
to light.

Susciter à quelqu'vn un accusateur,
 to raise vp an accuser against one.

Susciteur de proces, a stirrer of sutes
in the law.

Vn suseau, ou sureau, an Elder tree:
masc.

Le suslambris, or voutis d'une mai­
son, the feeling of the house: m.

Suspect, suspected: m.

Ie le tiens pour suspect, I haue him
in suspition, I doe suspect him.

La chose est suspecte, the matter is
to be suspected: f.

Suspection, soupçon, souspeçon, or
suspicion, suspition: f.

Suspendre aucun de son office, to
suspend one from his office.

Estre suspens & en doubte, to be in
suspence or doubt.

Sustenter, to maintaine.

Sutin, as le sutin d'Angleterre, the
sweate that was here in England:
masc.

Suye, the soote of a chimney: f.

Suyet, the Elder tree: m.

Suyvre, je suis, je suivi, j'ay suivi, je
suyvray, to follow.

Suyvre autruy à mal faire, to followe
other in ill doing.

Suyvant, following.

Le jour suyvant, the day following.

Suyte, following, suite, traine: f.

Suyte & accompaignement, the
traine or companie of men that no­
ble men haue.

Tout de suyte, one following another,
by order, one after another.

Vne syllabe, a syllable.

Syderé, as le couteau philosophal
de Saint Thomas d'Aquin se trou­
va si bien syderé, que par icelluy
lon coupa vne enclume à travers,
 the knife of Saint Thomas of A­
quine was found so well temperated
and forged by the course and con­
stellation of the starres, that there­
with an anuill was cut through.

Syer, seeke Sier.

Symbole, a note, a signe, or collation:
also it is taken for the short summe
or abbreuiation of the Creede, as le
symbole des Apostres, the Creede
of the Apostles: m.

Symbolizer, to agree in nature, will
and affection, one with another, as a 
man and his wife, or two louers.

Symbolization, the same agreement
of two in one mind and affection: f.

Leurs ames symbolizans l'vne avec
l'autre, their soules answering in
like affection one with another.

Symmétrie, or mesurage raporté au
naturel, a measuring compared or
reported to the naturall: f.

Chose bien Symmétriée, a thing well
compassed, worke or writing well
proportioned.

Sympathie, pronounce Sympatie, it
is a similitude, and as it were a con­
iunction or ioyning togither of two
natures, as Il y a je ne sçay quelle
Sympathie & symbolization en­
tre noz deux cœurs, que &c. there





is I know not what coniunction togi­
ther, or agreement of both our harts,
that &c. agreement of natural qua­
lities.

Symphonie, an agreement of voyces
or instruments: f.

Symposiarque, ou maistre du ban­
quet, the ouerseer of a feast or ban­
quet: m.

Symptomes, the alteration or change
in ones bodie, by often swouning.

Symptomes bons & favorables, al­
terations or chaunges betokening
good hope of recouerie.

Synagogue, a Synagogue: f.

Syncere, whole, pure, sincere, without
dissimulation.

Syncérité, puritie, sinceritie: f.

Syncérement, purely, simply, sincere­
ly, without dissimulation.

Syncope, a cutting, a swouning for
feeblenesse: f.

Syncopizer, to swoune often, to cut.

Syndereze, or remors de conscien­
ce, the worme of the conscience, a
scruple of conscience: m.

Syndic & procureur d'vne commu­
nauté, an Atturney for the whole
communaltie: m.

Les Syndiques de Geneve, the Ma­
gistrates and rulers of the common
weale of Geneua: also two or more
committed by a common weale to
deale in affaires with a forreine
Prince.

Syndiquer, to aske reason of another
mans behauiour, to examine an o­
thers life.

Syndicat, such office: m.

Estat Syndicable, an office subiect, or
which may bee researched or con­
trolled.

Synode, an assemblie of the Clergie
vpon Ecclesiasticall matters: m.

Synodal, pertaining to that assembly.

Synople, a colour among the Haralds:
a greene shield: m.

Syre, or Sire, Lord, or master, Syr: m.

Syringue, a squirt: f.

Syringer, to swinge one.


T ante A.

TAbellion, a publique Notarie: m.

Tabifier, to corrupt, to infect, to
marre, to spot, or to blot.

Tabifié, infected, marred, spotted, or
blotted.

Tabernacle & pavillon, a Taber­
nacle, a Pauillion.

Vne table de cuivre, d'arain, d'estain
ou plomb, assez espesse, a plate of
any mettall: f.

La table ou comptoir des change­
urs, banquiers ou Argentiers, the
Marchants counting table.

Table d'vn livre, monstrant som­
mairement le contenu en iceluy,
 the table of a booke, shewing briefly
the contents of the whole.

Mettre la table, to lay the table.

La table est mise, the table is layd.

Tenir table à tous venans, to keepe a
good table or house for all commers.

La fin de table, the fruit.

Les tables pour jouër aux dames, a
paire of playing tables: f.

Tablette, a little table: f.

Tablette cirée en laquelle les an­





ciens escrivoyent, waxed Tables in
which the Ancients wrote.

Tablettes, bordereaux, ou memoi­
res, writing tables.

Tableau de peincture, a Table of
Painters worke, a picture: m.

Tablier à jouër, a chesse bourd: m.

Tablier ou devantier, an aprone: m.

Tablier, also is taken for a long and
large tablecloth: also a boarder: as
il a beaucoup de tabliers, ou pen­
sionnaires, he hath many boarders.

Tabourer, to strike one vpon the but­
tocks.

Tabourement such striking: m.

Vn tabouret, ou esplinglier, a pin­
ner: m: also a little couer-stoole: a
coutchin stoole.

Tabourin, a drumme, a timbrell, a ta­
ber: m.

Tabourineur, a drumplayer: m.

Tabourineresse, or tabourineuse, a 
woman that plaieth on a timbrell: f.

Tabouriner, to play vpon the drum.

Tabuter vne personne, to push, to iolt
to but.

Vne tache, a spot, a tatch: f.

Tachette, a little staine: f.

Tacher, to spot, to staine.

Tacheter & marqueter, to spotte, to
marke.

Tacheté, spotted.

Tacite, holding his peace, com.

Tacitement, without noise.

Taciturnité, silence: f.

Taciturne, silent, holding his peace: m.

Tacle, a bolt or an arrow, whose fea­
thers be glewed: m.

Tacon, a yong Salmon: m.

Taffetas, taffeta: m.

Vn tahon, qui tormente les che­
vaux ou vaches en esté, a Hornet,
an Oxe flie: m.

"ox-fly" antedates earliest OED citation (1601).



Taie en lœil, seeke Taye.

Taion, m: my grandfather.

Taillandier, one that maketh billes,
chopping kniues, and such like sharp
instruments: m.

Taille, coupeure, or crenure, a cut­
ting, indenting, or notch: f.

Vne taille de bois , a tale of wood: f.

Taille ordinaire, ordinarie custome
or taxe.

Vne taille qu'on leve sus le peuple,
 a taxe leuied on the people.

Taillable, com: qui paye tribut &
taille, that which payeth tribute or
taxe: or which may be ceased.

Taillon, a little fifteene: also a little
slice of flesh: m.

Tailler, to cut, to hew.

Tailler & engraver, to graue.

Taillé, cut.

Chose Taillée en bosses & enle­
vées, a thing cut in bosses.

Vn home, vn cheval bien taillé de
ses membres, that is, bien formé,
bien faict, a man, a horse wel made,
well proportioned of al his members.

Il est taillé, he is cut in his cod.OED appears not to records this collocation.

Tailler la vigne, to cut vines.

Le taillant d'vn ferrement, the edge
of a toole: m.

Tailleur de pierres, a cutter of stones: 
masc.

Tailleur ou graveur, a cutter, a gra­
uer: m.

Taillure ou coupure, cutting: f.





Vn tailloir, a trencher: m.

Vn bois taillez, vnder-woods.

Vne taillade, a cut, as il luy a baillé
vne taillade sur la jambe, he gaue
him a slash or cut on the legge.

Se Taire, to be still, to hold his peace,
je me tais, je me teu, je me suy teu,
je me tairay.

Tais toy, hold thy peace.

Qui se Taist, that holdeth his peace.

Sçauroit-on faire taire vne fame?
 can one make a woman for to holde
her peace?

Taisible, com: silent: commande­
ment expres ou taisible, an expresse
or silent commandement.

Taisiblement, in silence.

Tais, seeke Tests: a pot shard: m.

Taisson, ou blaireau, a Badger, a
Brocke, a Gray, a Bauson: m.

Vn talent qui valoit six cents escus,
 a talent in money: m.

Talent, or desir, as si tu as si grand
talent de t'en aller, va t'en, if thou
hast such desire or lust to be gone, go
thy way: m.

Vne talle, seeke thale.

Vn talion, m: an equall or like paine
in recompence of an hurt.

Talmouse, a kind of cake made with
Butter and Cheese, otherwise at
Molins in Bourbonnois, vne Par­
rodelle: in Picardie, vne Goyel­
le.

Taloche, as je te bailleray taloche I
will strike thee: but properly when 
one sweareth, and for his punish­
ment some of the companie do cause
him to gather his fingers togither,
and so doe strike him either with a 
knife, or the like: f.

Le talon, the heele: m.

Vn Taluz, or chaussée, a cause, a
banke or leuie.

Taluzer contre l'impetuosité de
l'eauë, to make a rampier, a leuie or
causie against the breaking in or
violence of the water.

Talonner, to kicke, to spurre.

Tamaris, nom d'arbre, the name of a 
tree: m.

Tamis, a boulter: m.

Tamiser, to boult.

Tan, seeke Tahon: m.

Tan, the barke of an Oke wherewith
leather is tanned: m.

Tanneur, a Tanner: m.

Tannerie, the place where they dresse
leather: f.

Tané, yrked, wearie.

Taner aucun, to wearie and molest
one.

Tanche, poisson, a Tench: f.

Tandis, the whilest, in the meane
while.

Tanesie, herbe, an hearbe called Tan­
sey: f.

Taniére, & autres lieux où les be­
stes se retirent, a beastes caue or
hole.

Couleur tannée, tawney colour.

Tanné obscur, darke tawney.

Tanser aucun, to chide, to checke.

Tansé & reprins aigrement, chid­
den, checked.

Tant & si fort, vntill, so long as, so
much that, &c.

Tant seulement, onely.





Tant y a que, &c, but so is that, &c.

Tant que j'ay peu, as much as I
could.

Tant s'en fault, que, &c. so much
wants it.

Tant soit peu, how little so euer it
be.

La tante, the Ant: f.

Vn tantinet, neuer so little.

Tantost, euen anone, immediatly.

En tapinois, slylie, lurkingly.

Tapi & caché, hidden or lurking.

Tapis: m: ou tapisserie: f: tapistrie,
arras.

Tapisser, or tapir, to hide: as le peu­
ple se tapissant sur sa face de cra­
inte, the people falling or hidding
himselfe vpon his face through
feare.

Tapir, to stampe with the feete.

Tapisser vne sale, to hang a hall.

Taquel, or taquet, a piece of wood nai­
led against a post, or like, to stay
some other, left it should slide away:
also the clapper of a mill: m.

Vn taquin, vilain, avare & trop te­
nant, a very niggard, a pinchpeny:
masc.

Tarault, a kinde of play at cards, as
jouër au tarault: also an augar:
seeke Tariére: m.

Qui est tard, late.

Trop tard, too late.

Tarder, to hinder, to slacken.

Tardant, ou demourant, tarying long.

Homme tardif, a slow man.

Poires tardives, peares ripe vpon the
latter season.

Tardivement targer, ou tarder, to
stay or tarie long.

Tardement, or tardivement, slowlie,
slacklie.

Tardiveté, slacknesse, slownesse: f.

Tare, drosse or wast in any kinde of
mettall: f.

La tare & dechet pour le change de
quelque piéce d'or ou d'argent,
 the losse in exchange of money.

Du quintal d'Angleterre à celuy de
France, y a quatre livres de tare,
 betweene the quintall or hundred
pounds waight of England to that
of Fraunce, there is foure pounds
lost.

Chevaux, vin, & vne fame, est mar­
chandise de tare, Horses, Wine, &
a woman, is a ware or merchandise
of wast.

Tarell, ou terelle, seeke Tariére.

Tarelet: m: or petite Tarelle: f: a
little augar.

Vne petite targe & bouclier de­
quoy vsoyent les Espagnols, & 
ceux d'Afrique, a little Target or
buckler: f.

Se Targer, to couer himselfe with a
target.

Targer, to tarie, to abide, to remaine.

Se targer d'vne raison, to excuse or
couer my selfe with a reason.

Targement, a tarying, or couering:
masc.

Targue, targe: f: ou pavois en fa­
çon de croissant, a shield.

Vn tariére ou tarault, an augar or
wimble: f.

Tarir, to drie: je taris, je tari, j'ay ta­
ri, je tariray,





Les fleuves sont taris, the riuers are
dried vp.

La source de mes larmes est tarie,
 the spring of my teares is dried.

Vne Tarte, a tarte: f.

Vne tarte de figues, a tarte of figs.

Payet la Tarte de sa nativité, to
make a banquet at his birth day.

Vne Tartelle, looke Triquette.

Vn tas de quelque chose que ce
soit, a sort or company of any thing,
a heape: m.

Par tas by companies or heapes.

Mettre tout en vn tas & monceau,
 to put all togither into a heape.

Il y a vn tas de babillards, there is a
sort of brablers.

Vn tas de scripts, a deale, a riffe raffe
of such writings.

La tasche ordinaire que par chas­
que jour on doibt faire, a dayly
taske.

Faire ou achever sa tasche, to make
an end of his taske.

Tascher de prendre avec les mains
 to goe about to take with his hands.

Tascher & s'efforcer de faire quel­
que chose, to goe about or enforce
himselfe to doe any thing, to ende­
uour.

Il tasche àe se faire grand, he goeth
about to rise on high, to become
great.

Il a tasché & s'est efforcé de me
nuire, he is gone about to annoy and
hinder me.

Taschement & effort de faire quel­
que chose, endeuouring to doe a
thing: m.

Vne tasse à boire, a cup to drinke out
of: fem.

Taster, tastonner, to stroke.

Taster & gouster devant, to tast be­
fore.

Tastonner les Chevaux de la main
tout doulcement pour les amig­
noter, to stroke horses.

Aller tastonnant, or à tastons, to goe
groping.

Tastonnement, groping: m.

Se taudir, to couer or hide himselfe
vnder some ditche, trenche, boorde
or like to auoide a shot, blow, &c.

Vn Taudis, a vaulte or like hollowe
thing, also the bourd where Tailors
doe cut their worke, as Coucher
soubz le taudis, to lye vnder the
bourd as Tailors doe, or poore folkes
vnder the stalles: m.

Tavelé, vsez des formules de mar­
queter & moucheter, spotted or
marked.

Tavelure, or mouscheteure, the
same spotting: f.

Taverne, a Tauerne: f.

Taverner vne chose, to tauerne a
thing.

Tauernier, a Tauerner: m.

Vne taulpe, a Mole: f.

Vn taureau, ou toreau, a Bull: m.

Taute, a kinde of fishe, also a round
piece of wood to remoue and roll a
great stone, peece of timber, or like,
a ginne, seeke Orgueil: f.

Taux, m: tauxe, f: ou taxe, f: a sea­
zing.

Taxer aucun & reprendre, to re­
proue or checke one.





Les vivandiers payent au Taux de la
Rynne, the Purueiours doe pay af­
ter the Queenes price or ceasing: m.

Taxer aucun & reprendre, to reproue
or checke one.

Tauxer le payement aux batail­
lans, to cease the paiment to those
that fought.

Tauxer les despens d'vn proces, to
giue the charge in law,

Rebattre & diminuër la tauxation
des despens, to rebate of the char­
ges alreadye giuen in lawe by the
Iudge: f.

Vne taye & tache blanche en l'œil,
 a perle in the eye: f.

Tayes de l'œil, spots in the eye.

Vne taye d'oreillier, a pillow beere:
fem.

La taye qui est au milieu de la noix,
 the partition of a wal-nut which di­
uideth the kernell.

Le tect or toict d'vne maison, the co­
uering of a house, the roofe: m.

Mettre les porceaux au tect, to put
hogs into their stie: m.

Le tect aux oyes, the place for geese,
the geese house.

Teigne, the scurfe of a skall: f.

Teigneux, which hath the skall, scur­
uie: m.

Teigneuse, f: a scuruie woman.

Teiller du chanuré, to strip or shell
hempe.

Teindre d'autre couleur que la cou­
leur naïve, to die into any colour: je
teins, je teigni, j'ay teint, je tein­
dray.

Teinct, dyed: m.

Teinct de fame ou d'home, the co­
lour of a man or woman, as cest vn
beau teinct de fame, a faire colou­
red face of a woman, carnation white­
nesse.

Home de bon teinct, a man of a good 
colour.

Teincture, dying: f.

La tincturerie, a dye house: f.

Tincturier, a Dyer: m.

Teinturiére, a she dyer: f.

Tel, such: m.

Tu est tout tel que tu estois au para­
vant, thou art like as before.

Il est tel quel, he is so so.

Ce sont beaux dons, mais ilz n'ont 
garde d'estre telz que les nostres,
 those be faire giftes, but I warrant
you they be not like ours.

Tu n'est pas tel que je n'estimoye,
 thou art not such as I iudged thee
to be.

Sa nature est telle, such is his na­
ture: f.

Tellement, in such wise, tellement
que, &c. so that, &c.

Estudier tellement quellement, to
apply his booke but so so.

Telier, tixier, or tisseran, a weauer of
linnen: m.

Du telon, seeke Tiretaine.

Temeraire, sot & leger, rash, foolish
light.

Temerairement, rashly.

Temerité, rashnesse: f.

Temperé & moderé, temperate, mo­
derate.

Temperance, temperance: f.

Temperément, temperately.





Temperature, temperatenesse: f.

Temperer, to temper.

Tempeste, tempest, storme: f.

Tempester, to storme at a thing.

Tempester, & tormenter, to tor­
ment.

Homme tempestatif, a wrangling
man: m.

Fame tempestative, a wrangling stur­
ring, and vnquiet woman: f.

Tempesteux, Tempestuëux, Idem: m.

Mer tempestuëuse, a raging Sea: f.

Vn Temple, m: & eglise, f: a church,
a Temple.

Les Temples, ou mieux tempes
de l'homme, the temples of a
man: m.

Templettes, wyers for women to dresse
their head: f.

Tempre, quicklie.

Elle est Tempre-moure, she is ma­
riageable.

Allez temprement, goe apace.

Le temps, time: m.

Bon Temps, good time, prospe­
ritie.

Beau temps, faire weather.

Le temps passé, olde time.

Passer le temps, to passe the time, to
playe.

Il est maintenant temps, It is now
time.

Il a esté vn temps que, &c. there was
a time when, &c.

Long temps, long time,

Long temps devant, long time be­
fore.

Vn peu de temps, a little time.

Vn autre Temps, an other time.

Du temps de noz peres, at the time
of our Fathers.

En peu de temps, in small time,
shortly.

Le temps viendra, qui n'est venu,
qui je mordray: qui ma mor­
du, the time will be which is not
come, that I shall bite him, which 
hath bitten me: if it were lawfull to
say so.

Tempre-meure, when a maiden is
ripe or mariageable: f.

Ce temps pendant nous ferons bon­
ne chére, in the meane while we wil
make good cheere.

Les quatre temps, Imber daies.

Temporiser, s'accommoder au 
temps, to agree with the time, to
yeelde and obey as the time requi­
reth.

Temporiseur, a man liuing as the time
goeth: m.

Temporisement, delaying time.

Tenaille, a paire of pinsers: f.

Tenailler vn malfacteur, to bite an ill
liuer with red hot pinsers.

Tenant, a nigard, as cest vn home
fort tenant, he is a wretched coue­
tous villaine: m.

Les Tenants ont perdu le prix
au tournoy, the defendants haue
lost the price against the chalen­
gers: m.

Tout d'vn tenant, without breaking
or discontinuing: m.

Voisin tenant & aboutissant de
moy, my next neighbour.

Tenable, as chasteau, ville, or fort
tenable, a castle, towne, or forte,





which may holde against the ene­
mies: com.

La place n'est point tenable, the
place cannot be kept or defended a­
gainst the assault of the enemie.

Tencer, seeke Tancer.

Tenche, poisson, a Tench: f.

Tendre, to stretch out, to spread a­
broad, to bend, to reach.

Tendez moy ce plat, reach me that
platter.

Ie ne peux attaindre or avenir au
plat, I cannot reach to the ditch.

Le tout tend à cela, the whole tendeth
thereunto.

Cela tend en mont, that giueth vp­
ward.

Où tendez vous? whither walke
you?

Tendez moy la main, reach me your
hand.

Tendez moy cela, reach me that.

Tendu, vn arc tendu, a bowe bent.

Tendre aux oyseaux, to laye for
birdes: je tends, je tendi, j'ay ten­
du, je tendray.

Tendu, stretched out, bent.

Tendu & roide, stretched out and
stiffe.

Tenture, a stretching forth: f.

Vne Tente, f; & pavillon, m: a tent
or pauillion.

Qui est tendre, which is tender.

Tendret, tender, soft, nesh: m.

Tendrette, a tender and delicate wo­
man or maiden: f.

Tendrement, tenderly, softly.

Tendreté, tendernesse: f.

Tendron, comme celuy de l'oreille,
ou du nez, the gristle of the eare or
the nose.

Le tendron du bout des arbres ou
arbreaux, the tender braunches or
tendrels of a tree.

Les tendrons de la vigne de quoy
elle s'agrape, & se tient à quelque
chose, the little tendrels of vines
whereby they take holde of thinges
and growe about them.

Vn tendron, m: a delicate man, com.

Cest vne petite tendron, she is a fine
tender yong wench.

Tenebres, darkenes: f.

Tenebreux, darke: m.

Tenement, the Countrey, landes
and possessions which one doth pos­
sesse.

Tenir, je tiens, je tins, j'ay tenu, je
tiendray, to holde.

Tenir au vent, to holde fast sayling
against the winde.

Ie tiens tout cela à fable, I holde that
for a tale.

Il tient son cheval à perdu, he iud­
geth his horse to be lost.

Si je l'aime, m'en tenez vous à vil
& à sot? If I doe loue her, will you
esteeme or iudge me therefore to be
a foole?

Tien, pren, holde, take, haue.

Tien, regarde, holde, looke.

Tenir compte au chapistre des
receptes, to holde accompte of
such thinges as haue beene recei­
ued.

Ne tenir compte de soy, not to care
for himselfe.

Tenir ordre, to keepe order.





Tenir sa promesse, to keepe pro­
mise.

Tenir propos avec quelqu'vn, to 
holde talke with one.

Tenir court, to hold short.

Se tenir nettement, to keep himselfe
cleanely.

Se tenir debout, to stand vpright, to
stand.

Ie ne me puis tenir que, &c. I can
not forbeare, but &c.

Tenir à quelque chose, ou contre
quelque chose, to hold or cleaue to
a thing.

Estre tenu à aucun, to be beholding
to one.

Tenir contre aucun, to stand against
one.

Tenir bon, to stande to it, not to
shrinke.

Tiens pour certain que, &c. holde it
for certaine, that, &c.

Tenant & taquin, a niggard, a snudg:
masc.

Les tenans & aboutissans, the li­
mits or bounds: m.

Deux paires de lettres de mesme
teneur, two pair of letters of like te­
nure or continuation.

Le tenon qui se met en vne mor­
taise, a Staple: m.

Tenser, seeke Tanser.

Tente, ou pavillon, seeke Tendre.

Vne tente qu'on met en vne playe,
 a tent to put in a wound.

Tenter & assayer à faire quelque
chose, to attempt or assay to do any
thing.

Tentation & esprouve, temptation
or proofe: fem.

Tenuë, as vous estes vn home de
prouësse et de tenuë, you are a man
of promise, holding or keeping pro­
mise.

Tenuë ou Tenure, thinne.

Tenuité, thinnesse, sleightnesse.

Tenuément, ou tenurement, thinly,
weakely.

Tenure, as laisser les biens à ses sub­
jects sans tenure, prestation de 
soy, ny d'hommage, to leaue the 
goods to his subiects, without te­
nure or any bondage.

Tercer, Tercéer, or Tiercer, labou­
rer pour la troisieme fois la terre,
 to till the ground for the third time.

Térébinthe, the tree that yeldeth the
turpentine: f.

Térébinthine, turpentine: f.

Terelle, ou Tarelle, a perser: m.

Tergiversation, excuse, going about:
fem.

Terme, terme: m.

Long Terme, long terme.

En sommes nous en ses termes?
 what, are we in this point?

Estre mis en termes, to be put to
termes, or in deliberation.

En mesmes termes, in the same
termes or words.

Terminer, to ende, to finish.

Ternaire, the number of three.

Se Ternir, je me ternis, je me terni,
je me suy terni, je me terniray, to
waxe pale and wan, to become like
blacke and blew, a deadly colour.

Il est terni, he is wanne or of dead co­
lour, swarf: m."swarf" antedates earliest OED citation (1619).





Couleur ternie, colour wan, pale, dus­
kish: f.

Ternissure, a deadly colour like
blacke and blew, a duskish colour.

La splendeur beauté ou lustre du
miroir est Ternie, the brightnes of
the glasse is duskish.

Terrasser, to cast to the ground.

Terrasser vne muraille par dedans
la ville, to strengthen a wall with
earth within the towne.

Terrasser vn home, to couer a man
with earth, that is to cast downe
the ground.

Vne Terrasse or Terrine, an earthen
pan, also a little vaute vnder earth.

Droit de terrage, the cuntrie tole.

Terre, land, ground, earth: f.

Prendre terre, to lande.

Terroir, or sol, the soile or ground:
masc.

Terrestre, earthly.

Terrestreté, an earthly light: f.

Terrier, a claper of Cunnyes, or like
beastes: m.

Papier terrier, the register or paper
where all the names of a Lords Te­
nants be written: m.

Le territoire d'vne ville, the territo­
ries belonging to a towne: m.

Grand Terrien, a man of great
landes.

Terrasse, f: or terrin, m: a fort made
of earth.

Terre-plein, idem.

Terrier, m: a cunnie hole.

Terreur, terrour, feare: f.

Terrible & donnant effroy, terrible, 
fearefull, com.

Terriblement, dreadfully.

Vne terrine, an earthen pot or pan: f.

Vn tertre, an hillocke: m.

Vn tesme, ou thesme, la chose qu'on
a proposée pour en parler & dis­
puter, a theame: m.

Tesmoing, a witnesse: m.

Prendre à tesmoing, to take to wit­
nesse, to call for witnesse.

Recoler tesmoings, to examin fresh­
ly the witnesses.

Tesmoigner, to witnesse.

Tesmoigné & confermé, witnessed
and confirmed.

Tesmoignant, witnessing.

Tesmoignage, m: & deposition, f:
 witnesse and deposition.

Tesniere, see taniere, a denne or
caue.

Test, seeke Teste.

Testament, a Testament, a will: m.

Testateur qui a laissé vn laiz, a testa­
tour that leaueth a Legacie: m.

Testamentaire, pertaining to Testa­
ments and wiles: com.

La teste, the head: f.

Se trouver à la teste d'vne armée, to
be at the front of an army.

Faire teste à aucun, to withstand
one.

Le cerf gette sa teste entre Febvrier
& Mars, the hart casteth his horns
betweene Februarie and March.

Trencher la teste, to behead one.

Il a mauvaise teste, a stubborne
one.

Parler teste à teste, to speake or
reason face to face, as fellowe to
fellow.





Testu, a headstrong fellowe, a wilde­
braine: m.

Vne testiére ou salade, a skull or
sallet: f.

Testellette, a little head: f.

Vn testicule, a mans stones: m.

Testifier & dire appertement, to te­
stifie and speake plainely.

Testification, a testification or testi­
fiyng: f.

Testonner, to curle or frisell ones
head, to trim.

Testonné, curled or frisled.

Vn testu, poisson, a cod: m.

Le tests de la teste, the scalpe or scull
of the head.

Vn test, the peece of an earthen pot, a
pot sherd: m.

Tette Mammelle, a dugge, a teate, a
brest: f.

Tetter, to sucke.

Tetine, f; or le tetin, m: a dugge.

Tetasse, a long, vile, foule withered
dug: f.

Vn Tevot, a Thraso, a treuet: m.

Texte, the text: m.

Iuges qui sont bons textuels, Iud­
ges which be learned hauing their
text ready: m.

Talent & ardente volonté, feruent
desire: m.

Vne Thale, a greene: f.

Thaller, to bud, to waxe greene.

Théatre, édifice public ou le peu­
ple s'assembloit pour voir jouër les
jeux, a Theatre or common place of
shewe.

Theatre, see Appentissage.

Theme, seeke Tesme.

Theologie, Diuinitie, as vn docteur
en Theologie, a Doctour of diui­
nitie.

Theologien, a Diuine.

Theorique, any science without acti­
on.

Teust, il se teust, he helde his peace.

La Tiphaine, or theophaine, the
twelue daies.

Ventouse Thiriaque, cupping: f.

Vn thresor, or tresor, a treasure.

Vn thrésorier des guerres, a treasu­
rer in warres.

Thrésorier de l'espargne, the high
treasurer.

Vn thriacleur, m: he that maketh or
selleth triakle.

Thiriaque or thriaque, a kinde of phi­
sicke, treakle.

Throne, a throne, a royall seate:
masc.

Thézoriser, to gather a treasure.

Thun poisson, a kinde of fish called
Tunny: m.

Du thym, an herbe called Time: m.

Tiéde, ne chauld ne froid, luke­
warme.

Se tiédir, to waxe warme.

Tiédeur, warmth: f.

Tiédement, coldely.

Tien, thinne.

Cela est tien, that is thinne.

Ie te prie d'autant que tu aimes
les tiens, & tes biens, &c. I be­
seeche thee by that loue whiche
thou bearest to all thine, and thy
goods, &c.

Il est tiers, he is the third.

Fievre tierce, a quarten ague.





Tiercer or Tiercir, to plough for the
third time.

Tiercement, thirdly.

Tiercelet d'autour or de Faulcon, a
Tierselet, a Hauke: m.

Tifer, or atiffer, to trim, to praunse.

Fame bien atiffée, a woman finely
trimmed.

La tige de quelque herbe que ce
soit, the stalke of any herbe: f.

Tigette, f: a little stalke.

Tigne, tigneux, seeke Teigne.

Vn Tigre, a Tiger: m.

Vne Tigresse, f: a shee Tiger.

Le tillac d'vne navire, the hatches
of a ship: m.

Tillacquer, to boord or floore the hat­
ches.

Tiller au chanuré, to breake or peele
hempe.

Tillet, Tilleul, or til, arbre, a tree bea­
ring fruite as big as a bean, the seed
wherof is like to Orenge seed, some
doe call it Teile.

De la tille, of that tree: f.

Vn tiltre ou escripteau, qu'on fait
sus quelque chose pour cogno­
stre que c'est, a title written vpon
a thing to know it.

Specifier les tiltres de quelque grand
seigneur, to specifie the titles of
some great Lord.

Tiltres, as produire ses tiltres &
enseignements, to shewe his eui­
dences.

Timbre de cloistre, the Bell which
is rung to come to dinner or sup­
per, or assemble together, also fe­
thers or other trimming of an hel­
met, whereby we say, Timbrer vn
heaulme: m.

Il avoit au Timbre de sa sallade vn
lyon peint, he had at the cresset of
his helmet a Lyon painted.

Timbrer vn heaulme de panaches
ou aultres choses, to florish an hel­
met with feathers or other such like
things or colours.

Timide & recreatif, fearefull.

Timidité, fearefulnes.

Timidement, fearefully.

Timon d'vn chariot, the axeltree of
a cart, the draught tree, the sterne of
a Ship: m.

Vne Tine, as il a respandu la tine
pleine de goudale, he hath spilled
the full stand of Ale: f.

Vn tiné, the Brewars tree, or others
bearing burthens  togither v­
pon a staffe: m.

"brewer's tree" not found in the OED.



Vne tinette ou cuve à se baigner, a
bathing tub, a little tub: f.

Tintamarre, a noise made either
with olde iron, woode ouerthrowen,
or such like: also the strife, outcry,
or wrangling of many persons toge­
ther: m.

Tinter & sonner clerement, com­
me fait vn verre, or, ou argent,
 to ring as siluer doth, golde or
glasse

Les oreilles me tintent, me font tin,
or me cornent, mine eares do din­
gle or dindle, mine eares glowe or
tingle.

Tintoner, to wispe or ring often, to
dingle or dindle, to glow or tingle.

Tintant & resonnant, ringing.





Tintement, a ringing: m: dingling.

Tique, ou tiquet, a worme called a
Ticke: m.

Tiran, as le tiran d'vne bourse the
strings of a purse: m.

Tout d'vne tire & continuëment, al
in one length, or draght: f.

Boire à Tirelarigaud, to tipple and
drinke carouse.

Tirer & trainer, to draw or traile.

Tirer par force, to draw by force.

Tirer ou mettre dehors, to drawe
out.

Tirer à la fin & se mourir, to draw on,
or lie in dying.

Tirer a l'aviron, to draw at an Oare.

Tirer de l'arc, to shoote with a long
bowe.

Tirer en Italie, to take his iourney
towards Italy.

Se Tirer arriére, to draw backe.

Se Tirer pres, to draw nigh.

Tirer les vers du nez, to creepe into a
man to know his mind.

Tiré, drawne.

Tireurs à l'aviron, Rowers: m.

Le ventre luy Tire, comme vn ta­
bourin, his bellie is full: his bellie
doth strout.

Tinel, as le tinel du commung or
salle du commun, a hall: m.

Tireurs d'or, a goldwier-drawer.

Only as "gold-drawer" in OED.



Le Tirouoir, or Tiroir d'un huis: m:
 the ring or like thing to pull the
doore.

Tire-fond de tonnelier, an instru­
ment of coopers to draw to the rigoll
the hogshead.

Tiretaine, a kind of tree.

Tirement, a drawing: m.

De la tisane, or orge mondé, a kinde
of drinke called Tisan, or Barley
water: f.

Tisanne de Ris, Tisan that is made of
Rice.

Vn tison allumé, a firebrand: m.

Tison de feu esteinct, a quenched
brand.

Tisonner, to stirre the firebrands to­
gither.

Titre, seeke Tiltre.

Titulaire, which hath title.

Tistre, faire de la toile, je tiez, je tis­
si, j'ay tissu, je tistray, to weaue.

Tisserie, the art of weauing: f.

Qui est Tissu, which is wouen.

Tissure, weauing: all kinde of wouen
cloath, but specially of silke, gold and
siluer: f.

Tissier ou Tisserand, a weauer: m.

Tisserand de toile, a linnen weauer.

Tisserande, a woman weauer: f.

Vne toge, togue ou robbe longue, a
long gowne: f.

Toffe muse, f: seeke Touffe.

Le Toict & couverture d'vne mai­
son, the couering of a house: m.

Estre caché soubs le toict, to be hid­
den vnder a couert.

Toffu, vn lieu toffu, a place shadowed
with boughes and leaues, see Touf­
fu.

Toile, linnen cloath: f.

Chasser à la toile, to dogge a wilde
beast behinde a horse or painted
cloth and so to shoote at her.

Tendres ses toiles & retz, to set his
toiles and nets.






Toise, a measure of sixe foote long, a
fadome: f.

Toiser, to measure with such a mea­
sure.

Toiseur, m: such a measurer.

Toison, a fleece of wooll: f.

Les chevaliers de la toison d'or, the 
knights of the golden fleece.

Tolerer, endurer, souffrir, to tole­
rate or suffer, to beare with.

Tolerable, as cela est tolerable that
is to be borne: com.

Tolerablement, tollerably.

Tollart, or bourreau, a hangman: m.

Tollir, to take away, to abrogate.

Il m'a tollu mon bien, he hath taken
away from me all my goods.

Des Tombes, m: gurnards, fish.

Tombe, f: ou tombeau, m: a graue or
tombe.

Tomber, to fall downe, seeke Cheoir.

Tomber en vn danger, to fall into
daunger.

Tombé, fallen.

Tombement du hault en bas, a fal­
ling downe headlong: m.

Vn tombereau, a tumbrell: m.

Vne tomberelée, a tumbrell loded.

Tombissement, the rusteling or noise
made by the earth through stam­
ping of horses: m.

Tombir, to make such a noyse.

Tome, a volume or great booke: m.

Ton, a tune, as garder le ton, to keepe
tune: it is also a sea fish called a
Tunie: m.

De la tonnine, f: the meate of that
fish.

Tondre, je tonds, je tondi, j'ay ton­
du, je tondray, to shaue or clippe.

Tondu, shauen, clipped.

Tondeur, a Sheareman: m.

Tonderesse, a woman that sheareth: f.

Tonsure, a shearing: it is also the be­
nefit of the clergie, or of ones booke: f.

Tonneau, a tunne or fatte: m.

Tonnelier, a Cooper: m.

Chasser à la tonnelle, to driue the
Partridges into a nette by dogging
them with a horse or paynted cloth.

Tonneler, or prendre les perdrix à
la tonnelle, to take Partridges af­
ter that sorte.

Tonneleur, a catcher of partriges: m.

Tonner, to thunder.

Le tonnerre, ou tonnoirre, m: the
thunder.

Tonsure, seeke Tondre.

Vne topase, a precious stone: f.

Popiaire, a knotte in gardens & or­
chards, the making of images or ar­
bours in hearbes.

Toque, toquement, coëffure, or af­
fulure, a couering or dressing of a 
womans head: f.

Toquer, coëffer, or affuler, to dresse
his head.

Toquessing, clapping or striking of
the bell: an alarme: look Sing.

Torche qu'on allume, a torche: f.

Porter la torche, to beare a torch.

Torche, torse, f: or tourchon, m: a
wad of straw or cloute, that wenches
vse to put on their heads when they
cary any thing.

Torcher, nettoyer, to wipe, to make
cleane.

Torché & poli, wiped and polished.





Vn torchon à torcher les souliers,
ou vaisselle, a shoe clout: m.

Vn tordoir, a mill wherein oyle is
made: m.

Tordre, je tors, je tordi, j'ay tors, je
tordray, to wring, to wreathe, to goe
out of the way.

Tors, as chemin-tors out of the way.

Torsure, f: a going out of the way: al­
so a wrenching.

Torsement, Idem.

Donner la Torture, f: to racke one.

Examiné par Torture, examined by
racking.

Interrogatoires & responses faites
en Tortures & questions extraor­
dinares, examining and answere
had or done by an extraordinarie
racking or pin-banke.

Toreau, ou taureau, a Bull: m.

Tors, ou destors, wreathed.

Torse, as aller deux lieuës de torse,
 to goe two leagues about that you
may come to the right way: f.

Torsement, a wreathing: m.

Torture ou gehenne, a racke or pin-
banke: f.

Torment, torment, extreme paine: m.

Tormente & tempeste de vents,
 storme or torment of winde: f.

Tormenter, to torment, to vexe, to
grieue.

Tormentant, tormenting.

Estre tormenté, to be tormented.

Tormentille, f: an hearbe hauing
seuen leaues.

De la tormentine, Turpentine: f.

Torpille, poisson, a fish that when it
is taken, benummeth the hands of
the taker for a while: f.

Torrent, vne abondance d'eauë qui
par grande roideur chet des mon­
taignes, a great floud of water, a 
brooke: m.

Torride, as la zone torride or adu­
ste & rostie, the circle in the fir­
mament, which is vnhabited be­
cause of the exceeding heate.

Tors, torse, torsement, seeke Tordre.

Tort & dommage, iniurie, wrong,
hurt: m.

A tort & sans cause, wrongfully, with­
out cause.

A tort ou à droict, by right or by
wrong, by one meanes or other, by
hooke or crooke.

Vous me faites tort, you doe mee
wrong.

I'ay tort, je le confesse, I am to blame
I confesse it.

Vous avez grand tort, you are great­
ly to blame.

Tortement, crookedly, crabbedly.

Torteau, a pan-cake: m.

Tortionnier, an extortioner: m.

Sentence Torcionnaire, f: a seuere
sentence.

Vn Tortis de fieurs, a garland of flo­
wers: m.

Vn Tortis de cire, a waxe Candle
writhed.

Vigne Tortisse, f: a Vine winding a­
bout.

Tortionnaire, as execution tortion­
naire, a wrongfull execution.

Tortuer, to wrest, to depraue, to make
crabbed.

Tortu, crooked: m: crabbed.





Tortuëment & pliement de quel­
que chose, a crooking or bending of
any thing: bowing.

Tortuëment, en tournoyant, wrilie,
crookedly: crabbedly.

Tortuosité, crookednesse: f: crabbed­
nes.

Vne Tortue, a beast called a Tortoise:
fem.

Torture, seeke Tordre: a racke or
racking.

Tost, quickly, sodainly, swiftly.

Vne Tostée, a toste of bread: f.

Totalement, wholly, effectually.

Payer la Totalité, or le Total, to pay
the whole: f.

Touäige, m: a certaine remouing of
the ship from one place to another.

Touäille à mains, a towell: f.

Vne pierre dicte touche, sus laquel­
le on esprouve l'or, a touchstone.

Or, argent, home de haulte touche,
 gold, siluer, a man of the finest met­
tall or highest degree.

La touche de quoy on escript sus
les tablettes, a pen to write on ta­
bles, also a fescue: f.

Toucher, to touch.

Toucher devant soy, & mener son
bestail, to driue out beasts before
him.

Cela me touche, that toucheth me.

Touchement, a touching: m.

Touchant cela, c'est sa faulte, as for
that, it is his fault.

Touchant son pere, about his father.

Touchant ce que tu m'escris par tes
lettres, &c. concerning that which
thou writest to me in thy letters, &c

Toudi, in Picardie, is euery day or all
daies: in true French we say, Tous­
jours, alwaies.

Vne touffe de cheveux retors les
vns entre les autres, a wemlocke or
locke of haire: f.

Touffe de bois, a little groue: f.

Touffillon, m: a little groue.

Bois bien touffu, a very thick groue,
arbre touffu, a tree with thicke
braunches.

Touiller & mesler, to mingle, to med­
dle.

Touillon, or Souillon, a Skullion: it
is attributed or ascribed either to
man or woman: as tu est vne To­
uillon, thou art a sluttish skullion:
speaking to a womankind: Cest vn
sasle Souillon, he is a slouenly skul­
lion.

Vn Toupeau, m: a knot or tassellike
made of silke, gold or siluer: a flocke
of wooll or silke.

Toupier, to whip a top: also to goe a­
bout.

Toupil: m: ou Toupie: f: a top.

Toupillon, m: a little top.

Vne Tour, a tower: f.

Tournette, Tourelle, ou Tournelle,
 a turret: f.

Vn Tour: m: & finesse: f: a feate, or
pranke.

Il m'a fait vn bon tour, he hath done
me a good turne vn mauvais tour,
an ill turne, a tricke of knauerie.

Cest vn fait de maistre mousche, it
is a tricke of meere knauerie.

Qui sçait les tours de cour, which
knoweth all the knaueries, which





are vsed at the Court, or amongst
Lawyers.

Par tournées, chacun sa fois, or à son
tour, euery one at his turne: f.

Le tour du soleil, the compasse of 
a towne.

Le tour d'vne ville, the compasse of
a towne.

Le tour & rond des rouës, the circle
of the wheele.

Vn tour ou tournoir, a turnepike: m:
a turne, as boule faite au tour, a
boule made at the turne.

Tourbe, presse, & foule de gens, a
prease and thrust of people: f.

Tourbillon de vent, a whirlewinde:
masc.

Vn Touret à caver, a wimble or per­
ser: f.

Vn tourd: m: or grive: f: a thrush:
a feldfare.

Touret de nez, or cache-nez, a 
moufle: m.

Tournelle, f: see Tour.

Tourner, to turne.

Tourner son esprit à faire quelque
chose, to turne his minde to doe
some thing.

Tourner d'vn language en vn au­
tre, to turne out of one speech into
another.

Il tourne & panche vers le midy,
 it turneth and hangeth towards
the South.

Tourné, turned, conuerted.

Par Tournées, chascun à son tour,
tour à tour, by turnes, or euery one
in his turne

Tournement, a turning: m.

Tourne-virer, to tosse vp and downe.

Tournoyer, to compasse or goe a­
bout.

Tournoyant, rolling, or going a­
bout.

Tournoyement, a rolling, or the go­
ing about: m.

Vn tournoy, ou joustes, a tourney­
ing or iustling.

Vn tournois, ou Denier, a peney
French: m.

Vne tourte, a great houshold loafe of
halfe a bushel or more: f.

Vne tourte, ou tourterelle, a Turtle
doue: f.

Tourteau, a pan-cake: m.

Tous, all persons: m.

A toutes les heures, at all houres.

Tous les ans, euery yeare, tous les e­
stez, euery Summer.

Ie t'aymé sur tous, I loue thee aboue
all.

Touser, to shaue, seeke Tondre.

La toussaints, Alhallownday: f.

Toussir or tousser, seeke Toux.

Tousjours, alwayes, euer, perpetual­
lie.

Il n'y a rien qui tous-jours dure, no­
thing endureth for euer.

Tout, all.

Tout autant, euen as.

Tout au plus, at the most.

Tout par tout, euery where.

Tout ce que tu voudras, plutost
que, &c. what thou wilt rather
than, &c.

Tout vn, all one.

Il sont deux, mais l'vn fait tout, they
be two, but one doth all.





Tout incontinent, by and by.

Toutes & quantesfois, as often as,
&c.

Toute bonne sorte d'herbe autre­
ment dicte Orvale, an hearbe like
to horehound.

Toutes-fois, neuerthelesse, as often.

Tout-puissant, almightie: m.

La toux, the cough: f.

Toussir, je tousse, je toussi, j'ay tous­
si, je toussiray, to cough.

En toussant, in coughing.

Toy, thou.

Il est en toy de le faire, ou de ne le
faire pas, it is in thee to doe it, or to
doe it not.

Toymesme, thou thy selfe.

Trac, Nier tout à trac, to denye it
flatly.

Tracasser, to range, to rome, to trot vp
and downe.

Tracasseur, a busie bodie, a toyler to
little purpose: m.

La Trace, soit d'homme ou de be­
stes, the trace of a man or beast: f.

Le Trac, Idem: m.

La trace de l'ancienne bonté, the
trace or pathe of that auncient
Aunt, and simple goodnesse or sim­
plicitie.

Tracer, to make a trace, to seeke.

Tracement, a tracing, a seeking for: m.

Traditive, as science traditive a sci­
ence taught only by mouth from the
father to the sonne, &c: f.

Cest vn precepteur qui a vne bonne
& fort aisée traditive, he is a tea­
cher which hath a faire and easie
deliuerie.

Traduire, translater, ou tourner d'­
vne langue en autre, to translate
out of one speech into another: je
traduis, je tradui, j'ay traduit, je
traduiray.

Trafiquer, to traffique, to occupie.

Avoir quelque trafique avec vn
autre, to traffique with another.

Tragedie, a tragedie.

Traguetter & passer vne riviére, to
passe ouer a riuer.

Trahir aucun, to betray one, je tra­
his, je trahi, j'ay trahi, je trahi­
ray.

Trahi, betrayed: m.

Elle a esté trahie, she was betrayed: f.

Trahison, treason: f.

Traistre & desloyal, a traytor, or an
vnfaithfull person.

Vn Traict: m: ou ligne: f: a draught
or line.

Poignants traicts, sharpe words or
rebukes, nipping words: m.

Les traicts des lettres, the draught
of letters.

Le traict & façon de quelque chose,
 the draught or figure of any thing.

Les beaux Traits de vostre face
m'ont navré: the good feature of
your face hath wounded me.

Vn Traict ou dard, an arrowe, or
dart: m.

Par Traict de temps, in length of
time.

Gens de traict, bow men.

L'espée traicte, the sword being dra­
wen.

Vne bonne traicte, or traite de che­
min, a good long way.





Vn traict d'arc, a bow shot.

Vn traict d'eauë, de vin, de biére, a
draught of water, wine, beere.

Traicter & manier, to treate, or to
handle.

Traicter aucun soit en bien ou en
mal, to vse or intreate one either
well or ill.

Traitez nous bien pour nostre ar­
gent, make vs good cheere for our
money.

Nous avons esté bien traictez à dis­
ner, wee haue had good cheare at
dinner.

Traicter de quelque affaire, to en­
treate of certaine things.

Mal Traicté, ill intreated, or enter­
tained.

Traicté, vsed or entreated.

Vn Traicté & livret, a treatise or
small booke: m.

Vn Traicté & accord, a treatie and
agreement.

Alliance Traictée, alliance, league,
couenant made betweene Princes.

Traictement, a treating, an vsing:
masc.

Traictable, tractable, com.

Traime, ou Trame, the quill of a 
Weauer where the threed is winded
about: f.

Traimer, or tramer, to weaue.

Le Train d'aucun Prince, the traine
of a Prince: m.

Tout d'vn train, all in one way.

Veu le Train ou la disposition en
quoy est ton pere, seeing the trade
that thy father is in.

Train, the trace of a wild beast.

Ce cheval va bon train, this horse
goeth a good pace.

Se mettre en train, to take his way, to
put himselfe in vre.

Il est en vn mauvais train, he is in an
ill way.

Prendre le train de la guerre, to goe
to warfare.

Trainer, to traile, to drawe by the
ground.

Il le Traina en prison, he drewe him
by force to prison.

Se Trainer, to creepe.

Vne Traine, a sledde: f: a dray.

Traiter, see Traicter.

Vn Traineau, vne sorte de rets, a
tramell net: m: a drag-net.

Traire vne vache, brebis, & autres
bestes qui ont du laict, to milke a 
cowe or sheepe.

Le traict du laict d'vne beste, one
meales milke: m.

Vn Trayer, a milking paile: m.

Traistre, seeke Trahison.

Traistreau, m: a little treater.

Traite, apres longue Traite de temps,
 after a long time: f.

Trame, seeke Traime.

Traimontaine, an Italian worde, the
Northerne wind: f.

Tranchet, Trancheplume, seeke
Trencher.

Tranquille & paysible, quiet, still,
peaceable, com.

Tranquillité, quietnesse: f.

Tranquillité d'esprit, quietnesse of
conscience.

Tranquillement, quietlie, peacea­
bly.





Transaction, f: an agreement between
parties.

Transcrire & copier, to write out, to
coppie.

Transe, as estre en transe to quake
for feare, to be in a trance: f.

Transfigurer, changer d'vne forme
en autre, to change from one forme
to another.

Transfiguration, a transforming: f.

Transformer, to transforme.

Transgresser & outrepasser, to trans­
gresse, to ouerpasse.

Transgresseur, a transgresser: m.

Transi, in a swoune or trance: m.

Estre Transi de froid, to bee almost
dead with cold.

Moy povre fille, je suy Transie de
froid, I poore wench, I am dead for,
or through cold: f.

Transiger & appointer, to agree, to 
fall to a point.

Vne Transaction, vn accord, an a­
greement, an attonement: f.

Transitoire, transitorie, com.

Translater, ou tourner en autre lan­
guage, to translate.

Translaté, translated.

Translation, a translation: f.

Translateur, a translator: m.
