Transmettre, to send one forth.

Transmis en tel lieu, sent to such a 
place.

Transmuër, to change.

Transmutation, f: changing or alte­
ring.

Transparant, very light.

Transpercer d'oultre en oultre, to
pearce through.

Transplanter, to plant from one place
to another.

Transplantation, f: planting, enter­
mingling.

Transporté, transported or carried
from one place to another.

Transporter, to carrie ouer, to tran­
sport.

Se transporter d'vn lieu en autre, to
goe from one place to another.

Transport d'vn lieu en autre, the tran­
sporting from one place to another.

Transportement, a transporting.

Estre transporté & hors de soy, to be
out of himselfe.

Transposer d'vn lieu en autre, to
transpose from one place to other.

Transposé, ou rejecte, transposed or
reiected.

Transposition, f: a setting, planting or
transposing out of one place to ano­
ther.

Vne trape, a trap as we see in sellers: f.

Vn home trape, a low well set man.

Traquet, thyon or groulard, a bird
called a bunting: m.

Vn tracquenart, or traquenard, an
ambling gelding: m.

Travail, trauaile, labour, toyle: m.

La peine & travail qu'on prend à
faire quelque chose, the trauell
and labour that we take to doe a 
thing.

Le Travail d'vne femme pour en­
fanter, the trauell of a woman in
childbirth.

Endurer beaucoup de peines &
travaux, to suffer much paine and
trauell.





Le Travail où les mareschaux met­
tent les chevaux ou boeufs pour
ferrer, the barre wherein the Far­
riers settles vnruely horses to shooe
them.

Travailler, to trauell, to labour, to
toyle.

Travailler & ennuyer aucun, to
greeue, to annoy one.

Travaillé, trauailed, wearied.

Travaillement, trauelling: m.

Travée, the space betwixt one beame
to an other in building.

Iecter au travers, & faire passer de
navire en autre, to strike ouer­
thwart: m.

De travers, ouerthwart, crosse.

Regarder de travers, to looke askew,
to leere.

Traverser le chemin, vn champ, la­
ville, to crosse the way, a fielde, to goe
through the towne.

Traverser & percer tout oultre, to
pierce thorow.

Traversant, going ouerthwart.

Traversé, pierced thorow.

Traversin de lict, a bolster: m.

Elle m'a fait et donné beaucoup de
traverses, shee hath caused vnto
me many crosses and ouerthwart
matters.

Vne Travoison, a way made with
boards.

Vn Treau de saffron, a bed of saffron:
masc.

Trebucher, to fall downe, to offend.

Trebuchant, offending.

Trebuchement & heurt, an offence:
masc.

Vn trebuchet à prendre oyseaux, a
pitfall to catch birds in: m.

Vn trebuchet à peser or ou argent,
 golde weights: m.

Vn terf, ou poultre, the beame of a 
house, also the saile of a ship: m.

Dresser les trefs & tentes, to set vp
pauillions and tentes.

Tref ou voille de navire, as à plein
Tref, that is, full sailes.

Treffle, herbe, an herbe called three
leaued grasse.

Vne treille, an arbour: f.

Treillis, lattises, grates: m.

Fenetres à treillis, a windowe with a 
grate.

Treillisser, treiller, or environner de
Treillis, to compasse with grates.

Treluire, to shine somewhat.

Tremble arbre, an Aspe: m.

Trembler, to tremble, to shake, to
quake.

Faire Trembler, to make one to
quake.

Trembler de froid, to quake for
colde.

Trembler de peur, to quake for
feare.

Tremblant, quaking.

Tremblement, a quaking: m.

Le Treme, ou Traime d'vn tisse­
rand, a weauers woofe: m.

Trémeur, feare: f.

La tremie, or tremuye d'vn moulin,
 the mill hopper: f.

Trémousser, to stirre, to moue.

Tremper, to wet, to moysten, to soften
in any liquour, to dip.

Estre trempé & mouillé, to be wet,





to be dipped in.

Trempement, a moystning, a dipping
masc.

Tremper en vin-aigre, to dippe in vi­
neger.

Ayant trempé le morceau, il le don­
na à Iudas, after he had dipped the
morsell, he gaue it, &c.

Trempé, dipped.

Tremper l'acier, le fer, l'armeure de
quelque chevalier, to temper the
steele, iron, armour of some knight.

Trempe, a dipping, tempering, and if
one should say, the seasoning of any
steele, iron, or edge of any instrument
of iron, edge or armour.

Taillant, pointe, lance, armure de 
bonne trempe, an edge, point, spear
well tempered or dipped.

Il est maintenant en bonne trempe
 now he is in a good minde: f.

Afin de ne vous laisser plus long
temps en ceste trempe, je vous
diray ce qui en est, that I leaue you
not longer in this case or state, I will
tell you how the matter standeth.

Trenchée, a trench, also fretting and
wringing in ones belly: f.

Les ennemis ont couru jusques sur
les trenchées, the enemies are come
euen to the trenches.

La trencheme d'vn mors de bride,
 the bit of a horse: f.

Trépan, an instrument of Surgeons to
tripan or open ones head: m.

Trépaner, to open ones head being
wounded.

Tréper & saulter, to leape.

Trencher to cut, to thwite.

Fort Trenchant, sharpe, well cut­
ting.

Le trenchant ou taillant d'vn ferre­
ment, the edge of a toole: m.

La tren-chefile, the sharpe bit for a
horse.

Le Trenchet d'vn courdouännier, a
shoemakers cutting knife.

Vn Trencheoir, a trencher: m.

Vn Trencheoir rond, a round tren­
cher.

Vn Trenche-plume, a penknife:
masc.

Les trenchées, maladies de ventre, a
disease in the belly, the gnawing of
the guts: f.

Trente, thirtie.

Trente foys, thirtie times.

Trentisme, the thirtieth.

Trepan de cirurgian, a trepane.

Trepaner vn patient, to trepane, that
is, to open a patients scull.

Treper & saulter, to leap and hop.

Vn trepied, a treuet: m.

Trepigner & danser, to trample, to
daunce.

Qui est tres-beau, very faire.

Tres-a-certes, most earnestly, as Elle
a mis tres-a-certes son amour en
luy, she hath put her most affectio­
nate loue in him.

Il est tres-affetté, he is very subtile, a
likorish one.

Tres-bien , very well.

Tres-bon, very good.

Tres-cher, very deere.

Mon Tres-cher ami, my very deere
friend.

Tres-digne, very worthy.





Tres-doulx, very sweete.

Tres-excellent, very excellent.

Tres-fort, very strong.

Tres-fort, Grandement, most grea­
test.

Tres-froid, very colde.

Tres-grandement, very greatly.

Tres-hardy, very hardy.

Tres-hastivement, verye quicke­
lye.

Tres-heureux, very happy.

Tres-loing, very farre.

Tres-long, very long.

Tres-mal, very euill.

Tres-mauvais, worst of all.

Tres-mauvaisement, most mischie­
uously.

Tres-meschant, very mischieuous.

Tres-meur, very ripe.

Tres-ord, very filthy.

Trespas & la mort d'aucun, the
death of one: m.

Tres-passer, seeke Mourir, to die.

Tres-passer le commandement de
Dieu, to trespasse the commaunde­
ment of God.

Tres-passé, dead.

Elle est Tres-passée, she is passed out
of this worlde.

Les Tres-passez, the dead.

Il pisse pour les Tres-passez, Rabe­
lais, doubtfully spoken, for it may
be taken as it is pronounced, he pis­
seth for the dead, alluding to the 
custome of the Papists, sprinkling
the graues of the dead with holy wa­
ter to clense their soules: but indeed 
it should be written, Il pisse pour
les traicts passez, that is, he pisseth
for, or because of the draughtes of
Wyne or drinke which he hath swal­
lowed downe.

Tres-petit, very little.

Tres-renommé, very renowmed.

Tressaillir, to leape for ioy.

Tres-çauant, very learned.

Tresteaux, the trestles of a table:
masc.

Trestons les autres ont failli, all o­
thers haue erred.

Cecy est dit à nous Trestous, this is
saide vnto vs all.

Tres-voluntiers, very willingly.

Tres-vtile, very profitable.

Treves & cessation de guerre jus­
ques à quelque temps dict, truce
or ceasing from warre for a time:
fem.

Faire treves, to make truce.

Treu, tru or truage, a subsidie, a fif­
teene: also the custome leauied v­
pon marchandise, &c. the custome:
masc.

Treize, thirteene.

Treisiesme, the thirteenth.

Triacle, seeke Thriacle: m.

Vn triangle, a Triangle, that is three
cornered: m.

Triangulaire, three cornered wise, or
after three corners.

Vne Tribe, estoit anciennement
la trentecinquiesme partie du
peuple de Rome. Et la douzie­
me partie du peuple d'Israel, a
tribe.

Les Tribuns qui furent créez à
Rome pour empescher que les
grans magistrats ne foulassent le





peuple, the tribunes of the people
of Rome: m.

Tribulation, Tribulation, trouble:
fem.

Tribut, tribute: m.

Rendre vn peuple tributaire, to sub­
due a people.

Tributaire, tributary, paying tribute.

Tricher, tricotter, & tromper, to de­
ceiue.

Tricherie, deceite, guile: f.

Tricheur, a deceiuer: m.

Tricheuse, a she deceiuer.

Tricoter l'apureté d'or et d'argent,
 to alter, change, delay, rise, embase
the coine of golde or siluer.

Tricoteur de proces, a tosser of sutes,
a pettifogger, a crafty lawyer.

Trident, as le trident de Neptune,
 the scepter of Neptune the God of
the Sea: m.

Triennal, of three yeeres.

Triennalle possession, the possession of
three yeeres continuance.

La trieule, or triule d'vn puys, the
beame or round wood whereabout
the corde of a well is winded, some
doe call it a winch: f.

Trier & eslire, ou separer l'vn d'a­
vec l'autre, to choose.

Vne Tringle, a fastning of two peeces
of wood togither, which the Carpen­
ters call a doue taile: f.

Tringuille, or grenouille, a Frog: f.

Trinité, f: the number of three.

Trinquet, seeke Artimon: m.

Triomphe, entrée solennelle &
magnifique qu'on faisoit à vn
Capitaine, a triumph: m.

Triompher, to triumph.

Triomphant, triumphant.

Triomphammant, triumphantly.

Triomphement, a triumphing: m.

Trihoris, as danseur de trihoris a 
dauncer on tiptoe or capers.

Triper & fouler aux pieds, to treade
vnderfoote.

Des Tripes, tripes: f.

Et va, va gros tripier, goe thie way
great guts: m.

Tripiére, a tripe wife.

La triperie, the place or market wher
they sell tripes: f.

Tripe de velours, veleure: f.

Triple victoire, triple or threefolde
victorie.

Tripler, to make three double.

Triplication, multiplying by three:
fem.

La triplique du demandeur, the
third reply in the law of the plan­
tife: f.

On ne triplique gueres, the 
third reply is seldome graunted in the
lawe.

Tripoly, a townes name, also the sand
or earth wherwith Goldesmiths doe
pollishe their plate: m.

Tripot, jeu de paulme, a Tennis
court: m.

Tripoter, to play at tennis.

Tripotage, as fais tellement ton
tripotage, que tu ne m'y me­
sles point, do they bargaine in such
a sorte, that thou minglest me not
in thy dealings: it is taken in euill
parte: m.

Vn triquebalarideau, a nicke-name





a nothing worth: m.

Triquesniques, cest vn monsieur
de triquesniques, hee is a Gentle­
man of strawe.

Vne triquette or tartenelle, a whirle­
gigge: f.

Triquetrac, as jouër au triquetrac,
 to play at ticke tacke: m.

Triquehouse, boote-hosen: f.

Trique-madame, f: herbe called
Sengreene.

Cognoistre le trist et volubilité de
Fortune, to know the vnstedfastnes
of Fortune: m.

Triste, sorrowfull, heauy.

Tristesse, sorowe, heauinesse: f.

Tristesse & douleur de cueur, sorow,
or hart-griefe.

De tristesse & douleur, of sorow and
griefe.

Tristement, heauily, sorrowfully.

Troc, seeke troquer.

Trochée, a cluster or branch of an
appletree or peare tree, hauing ten
or twelue peares or apples togither:
masc.

Trocheure, seeke Entouiller.

Des troschiques, espece de medi­
cine, pilles: m.

Troesne, arbre ayant les fueilles
plus larges que l'Olivier, a tree so
called: m.

Trofée, seeke trophée.

Trois, three.

Trois cens, three hundreth.

Troisieme, the third.

Trompe & museau d'Elephant, the
snoute of an Elephant: m.

Trompe, ou sabot de quoy se jou­
ënt les enfants, a casting top.

Trompe ou Trompette, a trumpet,
fem.

Vn trompetteur, a Trumpeter: m.

Tromper, to beguile, to deceiue.

Trompé & deceu, beguiled and de­
ceiued.

Tromperie, deceite, craft, falshood,
subtiltie: f.

Trompeur, a deceiuer, a beguiler:
masc.

Tromper les trompeurs, to beguile
and deceiue the deceiuers and craf­
tie beguilers.

Le tronc d'vn arbre, the body of a 
tree, a stumpe.

Vn tronc aux temples, the poore
mens boxe in Churches: m.

Vn tronchet, a truncheon.

Troncir or rompre, to breake in
two.

Tronquer, Idem.

Qui est tronqué, a thing broken.

Trone, seeke Throne.

Trongne, a face or countenance: f.

Tronson, Diminutif de Tronc, a
troncheon: m.

Tronsonner, to loppe trees.

Trop, to much.

Trophée, the spoiles and booties got­
ten in warres vpon our enemies:
masc.

Eriger vn trophée or trophées, to set
vp one, or many monuments in signe
of victorie ouer our enemies, as we
see in Churches.

Troquer, to barter, to change.

Troc, exchange, bartring: m.

Trotter, to trotte.





Trot de cheval, the trot of a horse:
masc.

Trotteur, vn villotier, a trotter, a
trampler: m.

Cheval Trotier, a trotting horse:
masc.

Vne Trotieré ou coureuse, a gadder
about streetes, a fisgigge: f.

Vn Trou & pertuis, a hole: m.

Trouër, to make holes.

Vn trouble, bruict, m: & esmeute: f.
 a trouble.

Vne chose trouble, a thicke or vnset­
led things.

Troubler, to trouble.

Troublé, troubled.

Troublement, a troubling: m.

Vn trouble-feste, he that marreth all
the sporte or play, an importunate
one: m.

Trougne, see Trongne.

Vne trouppe & multitude gents,
 a troupe or multitude of people:
fem.

Troupeau de bestial, a flocke of cat­
tell.

Par troupeaux & bandes, by heapes
and bandes.

Trousse tes rins, prepare thy selfe or
be ready, rise vp, come forwards, set
thy hand to worke, dispatch, tary no
longer, or girde vp thy selfe, or girde
vp thy loynes.

Vne Troussoire, a girdle, a belte: f.

Vne trousseure, Idem: also a trusse
as such as those which are broken
doe vse: fem.

Il m'a joué d'vne trousse, he hath 
shewed me a tricke, he hath decei­
ued me: f.

Vne trousse, f; ou Carquois, m: a
quiuer.

Trousser sa robbe, to tucke or trusse
vp his gowne.

Trousser bagage, to packe vp things
and goe his way.

Trouve-dance, com: an inuenter of
a daunce.

Trouver, to finde.

Trouver à la trace, ou apres a­
voir bien cerché, to finde by the
trace.

Trouver en chemin, to finde by the
way.

Trouver à dire, to lacke or want of
those things which we had before.

Ie ne trouve rien à dire en cela, I can
finde no fault in that, the same is
well spoken, done, or is perfect.

Trouvé, found.

Trouvé sur le faict, taken with the
deede, doing.

Trouveur, a finder: m.

Truage, or Treu, a fifteene, subsidie,
toll, or custome: m.

Truand, or truan, a truant: m.

Truander, to play the truant.

Truandaille, a company of truants:
fem.

Vn truble, a little net to take fishe in
poundes: m.

Truculent, monstrer vne conte­
nance truculente & severe, to
shewe a terrible and fearfull coun­
tenance.





Vn Trucheman, an interpreter: 
masc.

Vne truelle, a trowel.

Vne truellée de plastre ou morti­
tier, a trowell full of plaister or
morter.

Truffer, seeke Mocquer.

Truffes ou saligots & chastaignes
de riviére, see Chausse-trapes.

Vne Truite poisson, a fishe called a
Trout.

Vne truye, a Sowe.

Petite truye, truyette, a little Sowe.

Tuassent, see tuer.

Truyettes, f: or maquereaux, m:
 those markes which are seene in the
legges of those which in Winter
time doe sit long by the fire, scor­
ching.

Les tuberositez des os, the roundnes
within the knitting of the bones.

Tudesques or Theutoniens, the high
Dutchmen.

Tuer aucun, to kill, to slea, to murther.

Tuer cruellement, to kill cruellye, to
murther.

Qui est tué, which is killed.

Tueur de gens, a mansleaer, a mur­
derer.

Tuerie, slaughter.

Tuement, a sleying.

Tuile, a tile.

Vne tuilerie, a tile kill, or where
they make brickes.

Tume, Timber, seeke tombe, tom­
ber.

Tumbreau, seeke Tombereau.

Tumultuairement, seditiously, rebelli­
ously.

Vn tumultuaire, rebellious, seditious

Tumulte, a tumult, an vprore.

Tuph, ou tuf, sorte de pierre, a kinde
of stone.

Vn Tupin, a Pipkin, an earthen
pot.

Turban, such hats as turkes weare.

Turbentine, Turpentine: f.

Turbit, herbe, an herbe called Tur­
bit: m.

Turbulant, troublesome, vnquiet.

Vne Turse or Turcee de figues ou
raisins, a plaister or cluster of
figges or grapes, see Grappe.

Vn Turlupin, a grub, a newnothing,
a man of small value.

Coleur Turque ou asurée, a Skie
colour, blew.

Turquoyse, pierre prétieuse, a preci­
ous stone called a Turkie: f.

Turbot, a Birt or Turbot: m.

Vn Turc, a Turke: m.

Vne Turque, a woman Turke: f.

Turquesque, as fait à la Turques­
que, made or doone after the Tur­
kish fashion: f.

Arc turquois, a Turkish bowe: m.

Turquin, a kinde of colour betweene
blew and azure: m.

Turturelle, a turtle doue, seeke tour­
te: fem.

Tuteur, a tutour, an ouerseer: m.

Tuteurs & curateurs des orphelins,
 tutors, gardians, those that haue
the tuition of a Ward.

Tutelle, a Warde-ship, custodye of a
childe in nonage.

Tutelaire, pertaining to the custodye
of a Ward.





Tutrice, a woman gardean or defen­
der: ta main tutrice O Seigneur,
&c. thine helping hand O Lord,
&c: f.

Tutelle, safegard: f.

Tuyau, a pipe, a reede, a Canell, a
quill: m.

Tymbre, is the ornament or decking
vsed in armes vpon an helmet: also
the bason or vessell made either with
marble, porphire, or stone, or receiue
the water of a fountaine: last of all
the little bell in religious houses,
Colleges, or Innes, to call the com­
pany togither: m.

Tympan, a timpan: m.

Tyran, vn mauvais & cruel roy
ou seigneur, a tirant, a cruell king:
masc.

Tyrannie, tirannie, cruelty: f.

Turanniquement, tirannously.

Tyrannizer, to play the tirant.


V ante A.

VA par cy, goe this way.

Va devant, goe before.

Va t'en, goe thy waies.

Va, va, get thee hence.

La chose va bien , this geare goeth
well.

Ie vay, tu vas, il va, I goe, thou goest, 
he goeth.

Nous allons, vous allez, ilz vont, we
goe, ye goe, they goe.

Vacation, ou estat, calling or estate,
an Arte or handycraft: f.

De quelle vacation es tu? of what
trade art thou?

Temps de vacation, vacation time

Vne vache, a Cowe: f.

Vne vache pleine, a Cowe that is 
with calfe.

Vache laictiére, a milch Cowe.

Vn vachier, a Cowe-heard: m.

Vacherie, where kine doe resorte at
night, a stable for kine: f.

Du Vaciet, a kinde of purple flower,
our Ladies flower: m.

Vaciller, to wauer, to stagger.

Vacuïté, emptinesse: f.

Vagabond, a vagabond.

Vagir, to cry as a childe, je vagis, je
vagi, j'ay vagi, je vagiray.

Vne vague, a waue of the Sea: f.

Vaguer & aller ça & là, de costé
& d'aultre, to wauer, to remoue
from one place to another.

Vaillant, vaillamment, seeke Va­
loir.

Vain, vaine, vnprofitable.

Vainement, vainely.

Vainité, vanitie: f.

Vaincre, je vaincs, je vainqui, j'­
ay vaincu, je vaincray, to winne,
to ouercome, to surmount or van­
quish.

Vaincu & surmonté, ouercome and
surmounted.

Vainqueur, a conquerour: m.

Vair, m: a kinde of greenish colour in 
painting of armes.

Vaisseau, a vessell.

Vaisseau à vin, ou laict, a wine or
milke vessell.

Vaisselle, vessell.

Vaisselle d'argent, vessell of siluer,
plate.





Vaisselle dorée & ouvrée, plate gilt
and wrought.

Valeur, vallable, seeke valoir.

Val, m: & valée, f: a valley.

Vn vallon, a little valley.

Valeriane, f: an hearbe called valeri­
an.

Vallet, ou varlet, a page, a seruant: m.

Vallet de chambre, a groome of the
chamber.

Valleter, to submit himselfe too much,
to doe like a seruant.

Vallet de cuisine, a childe of the
kitchin.

Vallet d'huis, c'est vn engin qui fer­
me l'huis, a deuice to shutte a doore
after one.

Valider le dire des tesmoins, to con­
firme or strengthen the deposition
or wordes of witnesses.

Arguments valides, reasons and ar­
guments of force and weight:
com.

Valise, f: a wallet.

Cest vn vali-dire, m: a seruant onely
for errands.

Valoir, je vaux, je valu, j'ay valu,
je vauldray, to be worth, to bee of
value or worth.

Valuë, value: as cela est de nulle va­
luë, that is of no value, or nothing
worth.

Cela vault & sert autant que loy,
 that is as good as a lawe.

Il vault mieux, que, &c. it is better
then, &c.

Il vault mieux d'aller à luy, it is bet­
ter to goe to him.

Cest homme vault son pesant d'­
Or, that man is worth his weight
of golde.

Tu ne vault pas l'eauë que tu bois,
 thou art not worth the water that
thou doest drinke.

Estre plus valable, to be more worth,
of greater price, com.

Vaillant, valiant, handy, couragious.

Vaillamment, couragiously, vali­
antly.

Vaillantise, valiantise, valiantnesse: f.

Valeur, value or worthinesse: f.

Chose de petite valeur & estime, 
 a thing of small value.

Valeureux, valiant.

Valeureusement, valiantly.

Vandoise, a kinde of fish: f.

Vn van, a fanne: m.

Vanner, to fan, to winnow, to curse.

Il m'a vanné tant & plus, hee hath
cursed me throughly.

Vanneur, a fanner, a curser: a win­
nower of corne: m.

Ce bled n'est point bien vanné, this
corne is not well fanned.

Vanger, seeke venger.

Vangeron, m: a kinde of fish in the
lake of Geneua.

Vanité, vanitie: f.

Vanoyer, to become as nothing.

Se vanter, to vaunt or boast, to crake.

Vanterie, bragging, vaunting, boa­
sting, craking: f.

Vn vanteur & glorieux, a bragger,
a boaster, a craker: m.

Vapeur & exhalation, vapour, breath.

Vaquer & entendre à quelque cho­
se, that can intend to doe a thing.

Vaquer à ses estudes, to apply his





minde to his booke.

Demander vn office vacant, to aske
the place or office voyd by the death
of another.

Vn benefice vacant, a benefice which
is voyde.

Vacation d'office, the vacation of
an office: f.

Varangues, certayne parte of a ship.

Varier, dire puis d'vn, puis d'autre,
 to varie, to holde on both sides.

Variable, com: changeable, vnconstant.

Amitié variable, a wauering friend­
ship.

Varieté diversité, variety, change,
diuersitie: f.

Varlet, seeke Vallet.

Le premier vallet de chambre, the
first groome of the priuie chamber.

Valeton, m: a little young seruant.

Vn vase, ou vaisseau, a vessell: m.

Vne vasquine, a wastcoate: f.

Vassal, qui tient quelque chose d'­
aucun à foy & hommage, a Vas­
sall, who oweth homage by tenour:
masc.

Vassausie, the right which a Soue­
raigne pretendeth ouer his vassall:
m.

Vasselage, the subiection of a vassall
or subiect, one may say Vasselage,
or Villenage: m.

Vaticiner, to foretell things.

Vaticination, prophesiyng: f.

Vaticinateur, a prophet: m.

Vau, a valley: aller par mons & par
vaux, to goe through mountaines
and valleyes.

Avau l'eauë, downe the water, with
the streame.

Vavasseur, a lord hauing subiectes &
vassals, and yet he is subiect vnto
an higher lorde of whom he holdeth
his land: m.

Vavassorerie, f: the estate of such a
Lorde.

Vaucrer sur la mer, to row on the sea,
to wander.

Vault, seeke Valoir.

Vaulx, promettre monts & vaulx,
 to promise mountaines and valies,
that is mountains of golde: m.

S'en fuir à vau-deroute, to run away
and turne his backe to the enemy.

Vaultenant, an vnthrift, one that is
nothing worth.

Vn vaultour, espece d'oiseau de
proye, a gripe: m.

Vaultre, a kinde of dogge betweene a
hound & a mastife to hunt beares
and wilde Boares: m.

Vaultrer, to hunt with such dogs.

Vaultroy, a common worde among
hunters, a wilde Bore: m.

Et va, va grand veau, get thee hence
great calfe.

Eh, que tu es veau, what a calfe art
thou.

Chair de veau, veale.

Tu n'as non plus d'arrest qu'un jeu­
ne veau, ou vn cheval deslié, thou
art as wanton as a young calfe, or
an vntamed horse.

Veau en labourage, it is a baulke
vntilled betweene two furrowes, it is
also called Faulte, or Banc.

Veau marin, a sea fish: m.

Veautre, the fleece of a Ramme: f.





Se veautrer, or voultrer en la bouë,
 to wallow in the mire.

Veautrement, wallowing: m.

Vedet, a groseheaded lubber: m.

La Vedette d'une gallere, the highest
place or maste of a galley to discouer
far off: f.

Ceste place sert de Vedette, serueth
for a sight of discouering.

Veller, est, quand la vache fait son
petit veau, to calue.

Vefve, a widowe: f.

Vefvage, a widowhood: m.

Vertu vegétative, vertue, force or
strength, which is in plantes and
trees: f.

Vegeter, to budde or come foorth as
hearbes and plantes doe, to refresh, to
make liuely.

Vehement, violent, vehement, force:
masc.

Vehemence, vehemencie, violence,
force: f.

Le vent soufle Vehement, the winde
bloweth vehemently.

Veiller, to watch.

Veillant, watching.

Vne veille, an holy euen.

Veillement, watching: m.

De la veillere, ou Liset, herbe, an
hearb called Bindweede: f.

Veine, a veine: f.

Veines d'or, ou d'argent, veines of
golde or siluer.

La veine luy vat, his veine doth beat

Veinu, full of veines.

Vela, voila, or voyez-là, beholde
there.

Veloux, ou velours, veluet: m.

Robbe de velours, a veluet gowne.

Tripe de velours, veleur: f.

Velu, rough, hairie.

Venaison, as vn pasté de venaison,
 a pastie of venison: f.

Le Sanglier, le Cerf ont chargé leur
venaison, the wilde Bore, the Hart
is fatte.

Ce cerf a troys doigts de venaison,
 this Hart or Stagge is three inches
fatte.

Vendange ou vendenge, wine har­
uest, vintage: f.

Vendanger, to worke in vintage, to
cutte grapes.

Vendangeur, m: a Wine-haruest
man.

Vendoise poyson, f: a fish called a
Gogion.

Vendre, je vends, je vendi, j'ay ven­
du, je vendray, to sell.

Vendeur, a Merchant: m.

Vendible, vendible: com.

Vendition, a selling: f.

Vente, sale: f.

Mettre en vente quelque chose, to 
put a thing to sale.

Exposé en vente, put out to sale.

Lots & ventes, the Kings siluer, such
money as commeth to the King for
the sale of any land.

Ventes, is the wood in the Forrest
that is marked to bee cutte downe
and solde: f.

Venalité d'offices, f: the sale or sel­
ling of offices.

Vendredi, ou venredi, Friday: m.

Vener, to hunt.

Veneur, a hunter: m.





Venerable, digne qu'on luy face re­
verence, & qu'on l'honore, wor­
shipfull, com.

Venger, to reuenge, to wreake, to a­
uenge.

Vengeur, a reuenger: m.

Vengeresse, a she reuenger: f.

Vengeance, vengeance: f.

Qui fait la vengeance de quelque
injure faite, the reuenger of the in­
iury done.

Dieu en fera la vengeance, God will
punish it.

Venim venime, poyson: m.

Venimeux, venymous, full of poyson.

Venir, to come.

Venir & approcher, to come, to ap­
proch nigh, je viens, je vins, je suy
venu, je viendray.

Mais viens ça bon home, que dis tu?
 come hither honest man, what say­
est thou?

On vient à moy, comme si j'estoye
plein d'argent, they come to me as
if I were full of money.

Ie ne puys venir à bout de mes af­
fayres, I cannot bring mine owne
affayres vnto a good poynt.

I'en viendray bien about, laisse moy
faire, I will rule the matter well e­
nough, let me alone.

Ie ne puy venir about, or je ne puys
chevir de ce babouin, I cannot rule,
order, or frame that villaine.

Venez au devant de luy, come to meet
him.

Venir & arriver, to come and arriue.

Venir àe rien, to come to naught.

Venir devant, to come before, to preuent.

Venir au devant, to come and meete
one.

Venir en bruit & avoir nom, to
come to a name.

Venir tout à poinct, to come in sea­
son, to come in the nicke.

Venant, comming, approching.

Venu, come.

A ma venuë, at my comming: f.

Vous ferez cela tout d'vne Venuë si
vous voulez, ye may doe that all at
once if you will.

Que veulent dire tant d'allées &
venuës? what means such goings &
commings?

Payer sabien venuë, pay for his wel­
come.

Venne, or vesse, a fist: f.

Vent, winde, vent: m.

Il vente, it venteth, it bloweth.

Le vent de midy commence à souf­
fler fort, the south winde begin to
bluster.

Venteux, windie.

La ventaille d'vn heaume d'home
d'armes, where a man of armes ta­
keth winde or breath in his helmet.

Les Ventailles du ciel, the windowes
of heauen, the damme or floud-gate
of heauen: f.

Se venter, seeke vanter.

Vne ventose, or ventouse, a cup­
ping glasse that phisitions doe vse to
drawe bloud: f.

La ventose tient, or la ventose est at­
tachée, the cupping glasse or boxe
sticketh fast.

Ventoser, to applye to one a cupping
glasse: to boxe.





Vente & ventes, seeke vendre.

Flux de ventre, the flixe, the laxe: m.

Ventru, a gorbelly: m.

Ventrée, ce que la mere porte en
son ventre, the burthen of a wo­
mans wombe: f.

Le ventre, the belly, the wombe: m.

Il dort sur son ventre, hee sleepeth
groueling.

Ie lay trouvé se trainant sur son ven­
tre, I found him groueling, or cree­
ping vpon his belly.

Se ventrouiller en la bouë, to tumble
in the dirte or mire.

Vénus, ou paillardise, whoredome, al­
so tinne, mettall.

Venerien, m: giuen to venerie, to
lust or lecherie.

Veoir, or voir, je voye, je vei, j'ay
veu, je verray, to see, to looke, to
spie.

On le voit, it is seene.

Chose qu'on doit aller voir, or dig­
ne d'estre veuë, a thing worthy to
be seene.

La fame entre en chaleur, quand
elle est veuë, the womans flesh is 
moued, when she is seene.

Qui a esté veu, which hath been seen.

La veuë, the sight, the vewe: f.

Ma veuë ne se peult estendre si loin,
 my sight cannot stretch so far.

Veuë aiguë, a sharpe sight.

Cela se voit à veuë d'œil, the same
is seen with the sight of the eye, that
is, it is playne or euident.

Vequit, or vécut, liued: see vivre.

Vn ver, a worme: m.

Tirer les vers du nez, to enquire
subtilly and by pollicie to gette the
trueth of any prisoner or other per­
son.

Les vers d'vn poëte, the verses of a 
Poet: m.

Versifier, to make verses.

Vereux, full of wormes: it is spoken of
fruit: m.

Vne noix vereuse, a worm-eaten nut.

Il est vereux de verolle, hee is full of
the french poxe.

Vergobret, ce que le Alemans ap­
pellent Burgmaister, the maior of
a towne.

Vn vermet, a little worme: m.

Versifier, to make verses, to versifie.

Vn ver de Poëte, a Poets verse.

Du vératre, or veraire, herbe, an
hearbe called Helleborus, beares-­
foote: m.

Du veraire blanc, lingwort.

Verd, greene: m.

Aucunement verd, or verdatre, gree­
nish.

Ver de gris, verdegrey, a colour: m.

Vn verdier, forestier, or gardebois,
 a foster, a keeper of a forrest, also
hee that hath the charge of gar­
dens and orchards, also a kinde of
tode or hedge frogge called other­
wise vn Greisset: m.

Verdir, je verdis, je verdi, j'ay ver­
di, je verdiray, to waxe greene.

Verdoyer, to be greene, to flourish.

Verdoyant, flourishing.

Verdeur, ou verdure, greenenesse: f.

Verdillon, greene grapes: m.

Verdon, petit oiseau qui nourrit
les petits d'vn aultre pensant





qu'ils soyent siens, a hedge spar­
rowe: m.

Vne verdugalle, seeke vertugalle, a 
verdingall: f.

Vn verdun, a wine trough, also a lit­
tle rapier: m.

Vn verdurier, vne verduriére, an
hearbe man or woman which furni­
sheth a house with hearbs, boughes,
and such like greene things."herb-woman" antedates earliest OED citation (1609 [Shakespeare]). 

Vere, or la prime-vere, the spring
time: also an hearbe called cow­
slips.

Verécond, shamefaste, m: elle est
veréconde, she is shamefaste: f.

Vne vergaye, a kinde of galliard or
daunce: f.

Verge, a wand or rodde: f.

Vergette, a small wand: f.

Poignée de verges, a handfull of
roddes.

Des vergettes, a brush: f.

Vergier, a garden, an orchard: m.

Verglas, frost vpon raine: m: also
glasing vpon a wall: paynting re­
presenting glasse.

Verglacer, to freeze after the like
sorte.

Vergongne, shamefastnesse, the
shamefast partes of one: f.

Il n'a point de vergongne, he is not
ashamed.

Il monstre sa vergongne, he sheweth
his shamefaste partes.

Vergongner aucun, to make one a­
shamed.

Se vergongner, that is, avoir honte
de quelque chose, to bee ashamed
of a thing.

Vergongneux & honteux, shame­
fast, bashfull: m.

Vérifier & ratifier, to verifie and ra­
tifie.

Verisimilitude, likelyhood of truth: f.

Vérité, truth: f.

Véritable, a true man, an vpright
man: com.

Véritablement, truly, certainely.

Verjus, veriuice, as if you would say
Verd jus, greene iuice: m.

Verm, or ver, a worme: m.

Vermet, see Ver.

Vermeil, reddish, claret colour: m.

Estre vermeil, to haue a fayre reddish
colour.

Du vermillon, vermilion, a kinde
of redde colour made of quickesil­
uer: m.

Vermillonner, to blush, or to waxe
redde.

Vermine, toute sorte de petites
bestes qui s'engendrent de pour­
riture, vermine, all sorte of small
beastes that are ingendered of filth
or rottennesse.

Vermoulu, mouldy, or rotten.

Vermoulissure, mouldinesse or rot­
tennesse: f.

Se Vermoulir, to mould, to wax rot­
ten, je me vermoulis, je me ver­
mouli, je me suy vermoulu, je me
vermouliray.

Du vernis, or verny, varnish: m.

Le Verny à la damasquine fait sem­
bler les parois estre de voirre, var­
nish after the damasking fashion do
cause walles to be like glasse.

Vérole, ou rougeole de petits en­





fants, the smallpoxe: f.

La grosse verole, f: the Frenche
poxe.

Il est vray gentil-home, il a sué la
vérolle neuf fois, he is a right gen­
tleman, for he hath sweated of the
French poxe nine times.

Vn vilain véroleux, a pockie one, one
full of the french poxe, it is called
also le mal de Naples, because the
Frenchmen were first infected of
that disease at the siege of Naples,
Anno. 1528.

Elle luy a baillé la vérolle, she hath
giuen him the french poxe.

Vn veron, a little small fish: m.

Veronique, or herbe aux ladres, as
if one would haue, an hearbe of La­
zarus, also an image or similitude
of the true image: f.

Vn verrat, a tame Bore: m.

Vn verre, verrier, seeke voarre.

Droict de verre, see Droict.

Qui est de verre, glassie, or of glasse.

Verri, as parchemin verri virgine
parchment: m.

Verriére, or verrine, a glasse window: 
seeke Voirre.

Vn verrouil, a bolte of a doore: m.

Verrouiller l'huis, To bolte the doore.

Vne verruë & petit morceau de
chair eslevée sus le corps, f: a
warte.

Veres, towards.

Vers luy, towards him.

Il ira de main vers le Roy, he will go
to morrowe to the King.

Vers la fin, towards the ende.

Regarde vers moy, looke towardes
mee.

Verser hors, to powre out.

Verser ou converser avec aucun, 
 to be conuersant with one.

Versé, powred out.

Versement, m: a powring out.

Versez moy à boire, fill mee some
drinke.

Verset, a versicle: m.

Vertau, Tampon, Bondon, a stop­
ple, a bunge, a wherue of a spindle:
masc.

La vertebre & os de l'eschine du
dos, the backe or chine bone: f.

Verticalle, wauering vnconstant: as
estoille verticalle, an vnconstant star.

Verticalle, is as if it were ouer the
head.

Vertiginosité, or tournoyement de
teste: dizzinesse, giddinesse: f.

Vertir en quelque lieu, to come to
be conuersant in some place.

Vertu & force, strength & might.

Avoir force & vertu, to haue strength
and power.

Vertuëux, full of vertue.

Vertuëusement, manly, stoutly, ver­
tuously.

Vertu-galle, or verdu-galle: f: a ver­
dingall: f.

Vervelles, the armes, marke, or to­
ken whereby a hawke is knowen to
be such a Lords or Gentlemans: f.

Verveine, an hearbe called veruen: f.

Verveu à prendre poisson, a dragge:
masc.

De la vesce, f: fitches, a kinde of
pulse.

Vescheron, m: wilde fitches.





Vescu, seeke vivre, j'ay Vescu, I haue
liued.

Vesé, seeke Vezé.

Le vespre, the euen: m.

Sur le vespre, vpon or towardes the
euening.

Aller à vespres, m: to goe to euening
prayer.

La vesprée, the euening tide: f.

Il vesquit, or vescut, he liued.

I'ay vescu cinquante huïct ans, I haue
liued fiftie and eight yeares.

Vne vesse, a fiste: f.

Reculez vous dicy, car vous avez
vessi, or vessé, get you backe, for you
haue let a fyste.

Cest vn gros, vn grand vesseur, a
great farter or fister: m.

Vn viel vesseur, vne vieille vesseuse,
 an olde man or woman which doth
nothing but fiste.

Vessir, je vesse, je vessi, j'ay vessi, or
vessé, je vessiray, to fiste.

Vessifier, Idem.

Vessifient, fysting.

La vessie, the bladder: f.

Vessietre, f: a little bladder.

Suivre les vestiges de ces ancestres,
 to follow the steppes of his forefa­
thers: m.

Vestir, je vets, je vesti, j'ay vestu, je
vestiray, to clothe, to put on.

Vestu de robbe de soye, clothed with
a silke garment.

Vestements fripez & regratez,
 olde garmentes newe dressed by vp­
holsters.

Vestiaire, the vesterie, where the pa­
pisticall Priests doe laye vp all their
church apparell: m.

Vesture, a clothing, a putting on: f.

Vn veu, a vowe, seeke Vouër.

Veu, as j'ay veu I haue seene: see
Veor, or voir.

Veu que, for as much as.

Veu ce que tu me dis, that is, heu es­
gard, or consideré ce que, conside­
ring that, or hauing a regarde or
respect to that which thou tellest
me, &c.

I'espere veu ta prudence, que tu me
feras droit, I hope, considering thy
wisdome, thou wilt doe me right.

Veu l'occasion laquelle se presen­
te, je feray, &c. Considering the oc­
casion which is offered, I will doe it.

La veuë, the sight of our eyes, nowe
the sight or looking of a thing, as
vous m'ostez la veuë de ma bien
aimée, you take my welbeloued out
of my sight: f.

Maison de belle veuë, a house hauing
a fayre prospect.

Aller à la veuë, among hunters when
one riseth early in the morning, and
goeth out to seeke a wilde beast to
hunte, marking the place where
she lyeth, for to shewe the pastime
to the Prince or Lord: shepheards
doe the like heere in Englande
when they haue seene a Hare in her
forme.

Veu, or ce que tu me racomptes,
il est meschant, seeing either to
that thou tellest me, he is wicked.

Veu l'heure du jour, seeing the houre
of the day.

Veu l'occasion, seeing or conside­





ring the occasion.

Vn veuf, or veufve, a widdowar: m.

Vne veufve, a widdowe: f.

Veufvage, widdowhood: m.

Ie veulx, seeke Vouloir.

Vexer & tormenter, to vexe, to tor­
ment.

Estre vexé & tormenté des gens de 
sa maison mesme, to bee vexed 
and tormented with his owne hous­
hold.

Vexation, a vexation: f.

Vexateur, one which vexeth: m.

Vezé, as cest vn gros vezé, a gorbel­
lie, a fat guts: m."fat guts" antedates earliest OED citation (1598; [Shakespeare]). 



Viable, which shall or may liue, as
enfant viable, a child which may
liue, com.

L'home nay devant le septiesme
mois, n'est pas viable, the man
which is borne afore the seuenth
moneth, is not like to liue.

Viagier, rente viagiére, during ones
life, a rent during ones life.

Viaire, a visard, a face, a counte­
nance: m.

Viande, meate, foode, but properly
of flesh: f.

La viande est bruslée & havie, the
meate is burned.

Viande friande, daintie meate.

Aprester force viandes, to prepare
great plentie of meate.

Viande indigeste, meate not dige­
sted.

Viander, properlie spoken of redde
Deere and such like, that is, to
feede.

Viandy, pastis or pasquis, the fielde
or pasture where they feede, also
their meat: m.

Vibrequin, ou villebrequin, a per­
cer: m.

Vicaire, a Vicar: m.

Vice, vice: m.

Vicier & corrompre, to corrupt.

Vicieux, vicious, giuen to naughti­
nesse.

Vicié, corrupted.

Vice-regent, a Liuetenant: m.

Vice-roy, or viroy, a Viceroy, he that
keepeth the place of a King: m.

Vice-conte, a Vicount: m.

Vicinité, neighbourhoode, neerenesse,
likenesse: f.

Victoire, victorie, triumph: f.

Rapporter la victoire, to cary away
the victorie.

Victorieux, victorious: m.

Estre victorieux, to be victorious.

Victuäilles pour vne armée, victu­
als for an army: f.

Vidame, the dignitie of a Vidame.

Espouser fame par vidasme, to mary
a wife by a lieftenant as princes do.

Viduité, widowhood: f.

Vie, life, as il me coustera la vie, ou
&c. it shall cost my life, or, &c.

Il est en vie, he is liuing, or aliue.

Vie, vie, away, away, make haste: the
Italian saith, via, via, when they will
goe post haste.

Vieil, olde, auncient: m.

Vieillir, to waxe olde.

Vne vieille, an olde woman: f.

Vieillot, a little olde man: m.

Vieillotte, a little olde woman: f.

Vieillard, an olde man: m.





Vieillesse, old age: f.

Vieillement, anciently.

Vielle, f: a kinde of violl which beg­
gers doe vse from house to house: al­
so a kind of sea fish.

Vn vielleur, a player vpon such in­
struments.

Vierge, a mayd, a virgin: f.

Virginal, of a virgin.

Virginité, virginitie, maydenhood: f.

Vif, quicke: m.

Elle est vive, she is aliue: f.

Vivement, liuely.

Vivacité, quicknesse, liuelinesse: f.

Vivacité d'esprit, sharpnesse of wit.

Vigilant, watchfull: seeke Veiller.

Vigilance, f: diligence.

La Vigile de Saint Iehan, Midsom­
mer euen.

La veille de la Saint Iehan, Idem.

Vigne, a vine: f.

Vigneron, a Vineworker: m."vineworker" not found in OED.

Vignoble, a vineyard: m.

Vignoble, as païs de vignoble a
countrie full of vines.

Vignottes, & fleurs en Livres im­
primez ou enluminez, la taille,
drapperie, ou fuillages qu'on faict
en menuïzerie, ou pierres, cer­
taine flowers or deckings printed in
bookes: also branches in any other
kind of worke: f.

Vignoter, to make such kinde of
worke.

Vigueur, vigour, strength: f.

Vigoureux, strong, well brawned.

Dire Vigoureusement, to declare
strongly.

Vendre à vil pris, to sell for a lowe
price: m.

Chose vile, f: things of vile & small
estimation.

Vileté, ou vieuté, bon & grand mar­
ché de toutes choses, good cheape
of any thing: f.

Vileté, la vileté de sa personne m'a
gardé de manger de la viande
qu'il avoit touchée, the vilenesse or
foulenesse of his person hath let me
to eate the meate which hee had
handled: f.

Vilain, a villaine: also a kind of fish:
masc.

C'est vn vilain tout fait, we call vil­
laines all, such niggards, pinchpe­
nies and couetous, which set more
by a peny, than they doe by their ho­
nestie.

Il est vilain & meschant, leude and
vncleane.

Vn vilain fait, a naughtie deede, fil­
thie.

Vn faux vilain, a false knaue: m.

Vilainement, vilely, villanously.

Vilener & enlaidir, to ray or defile, to 
dishonour one by words.

Se Vilainer, or Vilener, to beraye
himselfe, to make himselfe a vil­
laine.

Vilenie, villanie, filthinesse: f.

Vne personne pleine d'ordure &
de vilenie, a person that is full of 
filth.

Commettre quelque vilenie, to com­
mit a villanie.

Vilenaille, or truandaille, raskals:
fem.

Vileté, seeke Vil.





Vilipender, to esteeme but a little, to
dispraise, to reuile one by words, to
defame one.

Village, a village: m.

Petit village, a little village.

Vn villageois, a man of the coun­
trey: m.

Parler en villageois, to speake like a
countrey man.

Ville, ou cité, a towne, or citie: f.

Vilette, a little towne: f.

Villoter, to run from one towne to an
other.

Vn villotier, a lande loper, a runna­
gate: m.

Vne villotiére, a woman running
from towne to towne: f.

Ville de tonnelier, a long Augar
which Coopers doe vse: see Barroir.

Les villes: f: fleaux: m: ou tendons:
m: de la vigne, the yong tendrels of
vines, whereby they take holde of
things.

Ville-brequin, an auger or percer: m.

Villette: f: or foret: m: Idem.

Vin, wine: m.

Vin de pressourage, the after pressed
wine.

Le vin des vallets, seruants wine.

masc.

Des pieds de mouton à la vinai­
grette, trotters with vineger.

uenge: m.

Fame Vindicative, a wreakefull wo­

Vindice or vengeance, a reuenge­
ment: f.

Vindicte, as l'appetit de vindicte
regne fort en luy, the desire of re­
uenge raigneth much in him: f.

Vinette, ou ozeille sauvage, wilde
sorrell: also a barberie tree: f.

Vingt, twentie.

Vingtiesme, as  le vingtiesme jour,
 the twentie day.

Violent, violent.

Violence, violence, force: f.

Violemment, violently, forcibly.

Violenter les loix, to force or breake

Vipere, vne sorte de serpent, a kind
of serpent called a Viper: f.

Vne vire: f: ou traict d'arbaleste: m:
 a quarrell for a Crossebow.

Virer & tourner, to turne.

Mau de tarre te vire, a maner of cur­
sing in Gascoyne: as if you would
say, a mischiefe on thee: or a poxe,
&c.

Virement: m: virevoustes: f: tur­
ning, friskes or gamboles.





Virevoter, to turne about.

Vn vireton, the crosse of a crossebowe:
m: also a cock-shittle.

Virginité virginal, seeke Vierge.

Viril & vertuëux, manly, couragious.

Virilement, couragiously.

Vne virole, a little yron ring put in
the ende of staues, least they should
cleaue: f.

Vis de pressoir, ou maison à mon­
ter par degrez, the vice of a paire
of staiers: f.

Vis à vis, face to face, ouer against.

Le visage, the face: m.

Mot à deux visages, or deux enten­
tes, a word which is doubtfull, with
double vnderstanding.

Vn home à deux visages, a man
which keepeth not his promise, not
so good as his word.

Viscosité, see Visqueux.

Viser bien droict, ou frapper dedens
le blanc, to leuell right, to hit the
white.

Visée, leuelling: f.

Vn Visener, he which taketh his le­
uell: m.

Vn faulx visage, a visard: m.

Ole beau visage, Oh faire face.

Changer visage, to chaunge counte­
nance.

Qui ne vise point à l'advenir, that
regardeth not the time to come.

Visible, com: visible, that may be seene.

Visiblement, visibly.

met of a man of armes: f.

Visiter, to visite, to ouersee.

Visitation, a visitation.

Visqueux, clammie, glewish: m.

Visqnosité, limnes, a thing limmie: f.Not found in OED unless forms of "gleimous" and "gleimy".

Visqueuse, as matiére visqueuse a 
limmie matter.Not found in OED unless forms of "gleimy".

Viste & soubdain, swift, sodaine,
quicke.

Plus viste que le mot, plustost fait
que dit, sooner done then it is spoken.

Il va viste en besongne, that is, il est
subtil, fin & cault, he is a craftie
foxe.

Vistement, quickely, swiftly.

Vistesse, swiftnesse: f.

Vne Vistre, or vitre, an oyster: f.

Vit de chien, or vit de prebstre, an
hearbe, wag robbin: m."wag robbin" not found in OED.

Le vit, a mans yard: m.

Vn vit de cot, a woodcocke: m.

Vn vit de bœuf, de cerf, &c. an Oxe
pizell: m.

Vits de gouvernat, great hookes of
yron which holde fast the sterne of
the ship.

Vital, qui à vie, vitall, that hath life.

Humeur vitale, f: humour entertai­
ning or maintayning life.

Vitier, vitieux, seeke vice.

Vituperer & blasmer, to reuile or

med.

 blame, reuiling.

and blamer: m.

Les Vivandiers d'vn camp, those
that do bring victuals to the Camp.

Vivandiers de la cour, the Kings ta­
kers: m.

Vne vive, a kind of sea fish: f.

Vn vivier or estang, a little poole, or
pond to keepe fish, to haue it nye at 
hand: but Estang is a great poole,
which must be dried before we can
come to haue any fish: m: a fish­
pond or stew.

Viviers & fosses de poissons aupres
de la mer, où on les sale, great
pooles and pondes nye the sea side,
where fishes are salted.

Vivre, je vis, je vesqui, j'ay vescu, je
vivray, to liue.

Vivacité, seeke Vif, liuelinesse.

S'il eust Vescu, if he had liued.

Homme vivant, a liuing man.

Il n'y a ame vivante qui die cela,
 there is neuer a liuing soule that
will say so.

Vivoter, to liue poorely.

Le Vivre, meate.

Les Vivres sont chers, victuals bee
deere.

Vie, life.

O ma vie, O my life, my sweete heart,
thou my sweet soule.

Finir sa vie en misere, to end his life
in miserie.

Viable, which may liue, com.

Vielles, viesles, violles, or violes, In­
struments of musicke.

Raccorder ses Vieles, to tune his vi­
oles.

Viviers, m: little stewes.

Vlcere, a sore, a byle.

Partie, or membre vlcerée, a part or
member of the bodie full of sores.

Plein d'vlceres, full of sores, or scabs.

Vlcerer, to exulcerate, to raise a bli­
ster.

Vlceration, vlceration, breaking out
into a scab or sore.

Vltime, the last of all.

Vltion, reuengement, taking of pu­
nishment, vengeance.

Vmbelle de fenouil, a bunch of Fe­
nell.

of Geneua.

Vmbre, Vmbrager, seeke Ombre.

Vn, one.

Vn à vn, one to one.

Vn, & puys vn autre, one and then
another.

Vn, ou deux, one or two.

Vniesme, deuxiesme, troisiesme, as
le vingt & vniesme iour de &c.
 the one and twentie day of &c.

Ce m'est tout vn, it is all one to me.

Vous estes obligez les vns aux au­
tres, ye are bound one to another.

Vnguent, a salue, seeke Oindre.

Vnicorne, f: an Vnicorne.





Vniforme, of one manner or fa­
shion, vniforme.

Vniformément, with one consent,
with vniformitie.

Vnir, j'vnis, j'vni, j'ay vni, j'vniray,
 to vnite, to set at one.

Plain & vni, plaine and smooth.

Vniement & applanissement, ma­
king plaine and smooth.

Vniement faict, equally done.

Vnion, vnion.

Vnion & accointement, vnion and 
acquaintance.

Vnique, il n'avoit qu'vn filz vnique,
 he had but one onely sonne.

Il luy a baillé sa fille vnique en ma­
riage, he hath giuen vnto him his 
onely daughter to wife.

Vnité, vnitie.

Vniversel & general, vniuersall and 
generall.

Vniversellement, vniuersally.

Vniversité, an vniuersitie.

L'vnivers, as toy qui gouverne tout
l'vnivers, thou which rulest the
whole world.

Voarre, ou verre, a glasse.

Voarrier, Verrier, on Vitrier, a glas­
sier.

Vne Voarriére, a glasse house where
glasses be made.

Vœu, a vow, seeke Vouër.

Vogue, as avoir la vogue to be in e­
stimation, to beare the sway.

Voguer, to flote, to saile.

Voguement, sayling.

Vn Voile, a vayle, such as Nunnes do
weare vpon their heads, or wid­
dowes in France, or a woman when
she is churched.

Voici, voila, see here, behold there:
seeke Voy.

La Voie, or Voye, the way.

La Voile, the saile of a ship, it is also
taken for the same vessel, as vne ar­
mée de mer de cent voiles, an ar­
mie of the sea of an hundred sailes.

Voiler, couvrir & cacher, to vaile, to
couer, to hide.

Dire Voir, to tell true.

Voir, je voy, je vei, j'ay veu, je ver­
ray, to see.

Voire & desja, but now.

Voire dea, Ouy dea, mor dict par
mocquerie, yea ywisse.

Voiries d'vne ville, the laystall of a 
towne.

Voirre: see Verre, or Varre.

Voisent maintenant où ils vou­
dront, now let them goe where they
will.

Voisin , a neighbour.

Voisinage, neighbourhood.

Voisiner, to be next neighbour: also to
goe visite his neighbours.

Voistrer, see Veaultrer.

Voiteure, ou voicture, carriage,
fraught.

Oultre, or sans la voiture, besides the
fraught.

Voicturier, a Carrier.

La voix, the voyce.

Voix cassée, hoarse voyce, broken or
hallow.

La voix des eslisants en la creation
de quelque office, the voyce of the
choosers.





Ie luy donne ma voix, I giue him my
voice, I hold of his side.

Voler, je volle, je vollay, j'ay volé,
je volleray, to flye: to rob and spoile
one by the high way.

Voler aucun, to rob one.

Il a volé mon bien, he hath set me
beside my goods.

Voleurs, theeues in the high way.

Volerie, robberie.

Il a fait beaucoup de Voleries, he
hath committed many robberies.

Qui vole, that flyeth.

Le vol des oyseaus, the flying of
birds.

Le vol du chapon, is a little parcell
about an acre of ground ioyning to
a Manour which the eldest sonne
hath besides his other brethren.

Vol, robbing or spoyling by the high
way.

Faire quelque chose à la volée, to do
a thing at all aduentures, or rashly,
vnaduisedly.

Parler à la volée, to speake at random.

Volage, a shittle headed fellow, and in­
constant man, com.

Volement, flying.

Voleter, to flitter.

Voliére, a bird cage, or where birds
be brought vp.

Voltiger, to houer, to flye, to praunse.

Volter, or voltiger vn cheval, to ma­
nage a horse.

Chelval voltant, or voltigeant, a
praunsing horse.

Volte, or voltigement, praunsing.

Prendre la volte de Londres, to goe
to Londonwards.

Vn volet, a light shaft to shoote fur­
ther.

Vn volume & partie d'vn livre, a vo­
lume or part of a booke.

Volume d'or, d'argent ou de cuy­
vre, a lumpe, masse or largenesse of
gold, siluer or copper.

Volunté, volontiers, volontaire, vo­
lontairement, seeke vouloir.

Volupté, fleshly pleasure.

Voluptuëux, giuen to fleshly desire:
masc.

Voluptuëuse, a voluptuous woman:
fem.

Voluptuëusement, voluptuously.

Vomir, je vomis, je vomi, j'ay vo­
mi, je vomiray, to parbreake, to vo­
mite, to spue.

Vomitif, or vomitoire, a vomitorie, a
thing or phisicke giuen to prouoke
one to vomite: m."vomitory" antedates earliest OED citation (1601).

Vomissemens contraires & nuisans
aux yeux, vomiting is hurtfull to
the eyes: m.

Vostre, yours.

Par Vostre moyen, by your meane.

Voz amys & les miens, your friends
and mine.

Vouër, to vow.

Voué, vowed.

Veu, ou vœu, a vow: m.

Le veu que les anciens faisoyent au
Diable, the vowe that men of the olde
time made to the diuell.

Vouge, a hunters knife, a hunting
staffe, a Bore speare: m.

Vouloir, je veux, je voulu, j'ay vou­
lu, je vouldray, to will.





Le vouloir & intention, the will and
intent: m.

Bien voulant, a well willer.

Volonté, will: f.

La volonté ou vouloir d'aucun, the
will of one.

Volontiers, willingly, gladly, lightly
or commonly.

Volontaire, that is of our owne free
will, a very willing man, com.

Home volenteux, a man subiect to
his owne will and mind.

Volontairement, freely, willingly.

Vne voulte, a vaute: f.

Voulter, to vaute.

Voulté, vaulted, sometime crooke-­
backed.

Voulsure, or voulture, vaulting: f.

Voultis, or planché, the seeling: m.

Vous, you.

Vous-aultres, as je parle à vous-au­
tres, I speake vnto ye: as if the La­
tines should say, Ego loquor vobis
alteris: the like phrase is of Nous-­
aultres, the Spaniards doe say, Vo­
sotros, nosotros.

Voutrer, seeke Veautrer.

Voy-cy, Voy-là, comme qui diroit
Voy-le cy, Voy-le là, here, there,
see here, see there.

La Voye, the way: f.

Vne Voye ou Voicture de quelque
chose, the weight of a thing: f.

Suivir la Voye & l'exemple, to fol­
low the way or example of other.

Voyage, a voyage, a iourney: m.

Voyager, to iourney.

Voyageur, a wayfaring man: m.

Voyagement, a iourneying: m.

Le Voyer, the bounds of lands: m.

Voyerie, or Voirie, seeke Voiries.

Vray, true.

Cest vn Vray calomniateur, he is a
very wrangler, a flatterer or euill
speaker.

Vray-semblance, likely to be true.

Sçavoir au vray, to know certainly.

Vrayement, truely, certainly.

Voire, voirement, comme s'il n'e­
stoit pas ainsi comme je dis, yea
forsooth, verily, euen as it were not
so as I say.

Vrbanité, Civilité, good manner, vr­
banitie, curtesie: f.

Vrbec, or liset, a worme gnawing or
eating the vine when it doth bud: 
masc.

Vrgent, pressant, vrgent, pressing,
nigh.

Affaires vrgens, vrging affaires.

Vrine, vrine, chamber lye, pisse: f.

Vriner, to make water, to pisse.

Vn Vrinal, a champer pot, an vrinall:
masc.

Vne vrne, ancien vaisseau de terre
ayant le col estroict, servant à por­
ter & garder l'eauë comme vne
cruche: Servant aussi ancienne­
ment au Preteur à mettre le nom
des Iuges & des parties quand il
faillot vuïder quelque chose par
sort, & à mettre & garder les cen­
dres des trespassez, an earthen ves­
sell with a narrowe necke that ser­
ueth to keepe water in, as in a pot: it
serued the Magistrates also to put
in the names when they should de­
cide any thing by lot: and also to





preserue the ashes of the dead: f.

Vrne, a pitcher to cary or keepe water
an earthen pot for water.

Vsé, worne.

Vsance, the wearing or waste of any
thing, and cheefely in plate, chaines
iewels of golde or siluer: f.

Vser, to weare.

Vser sa vie en proces, to bestow all his
life time in the law.

Vser de cautelle & de finesse, to vse
craft.

Vser de conseil, to take good coun­
saile.

Vser de force, to take a thing by vi­
olence.

Vser de raison, to doe all things with
reason and good aduise.

Vser mal de quelque chose, to abuse
a thing.

Vsiter & exerciter sa mémoire, to
vse or exercise the memorie.

Se vsiter à faire quelque chose, a­
fin puis apres d'y besongner, to
accustome himselfe to doe a thing,
to the end we may worke at it after­
ward.

Cela n'est pas vsité entre nous, the 
same is not in vse amongst vs.

Vsité & duit à quelque chose par
long travail, well practised in a 
thing through long trauaile.

Il est fort vsité au droit civil, hee is
very skilfull in the ciuill law.

L'vsage de la parole, the vse of the 
speache, as when one hath the vse
of his tung, speaking without impe­
diment.

Vsages & pastis, the plaines or com­
mons where cattell doe feede: m.

Bien vsité aux livres, well exercised
in his booke.

Vsance, f: ou vsage: m: vsance, vsu­
rie, wearing or vse.

Vsurfruict, droict d'vsage & jouïs­
sance sus les choses, dont la pro­
prieté appertient à aultruy, the
vsance of another mans ground &
reaping the fruites thereof: m.

Vsure de souliers ou habillements,
 wearing of shoes, &c.

On ne preste plus à vsure, mais à
interest tant que vouldrez, Ma­
rot, they lend no more money at vsu­
rie, but at interest as much as you
will.

Vsuraire, as argent vsuraire money
taken or giuen at vsurie.

Vsurier, an vsurer: m.

Vsurper, to vsurpe.

Vsurper souvent vn mot, to take
& vse often one word or maner of
speeche.

Vsurpateur du bien d'aultruy, an
vsurper of other mens goods.

Vsurpatrice, a woman vsurper: f."woman usurper" not found in OED.

Vtensile, toute chose necessaire à
nostre vsance, any kind of tool that
a man doth occupie: m.

Maison bien vtensilée, a house well
furnished with all kinde of houshold
stuffe.

Vtile & proufitable, profitable, com­
modious, com.

Vtilement, profitably, commodiou­
slye.

Vtilité, profite, commoditie: f.

Walon, one of the lowe countrie, in





Burgundie: m.

Vne walonne, a woman of the same
countrie: f.

Warlouque, in Picards speech is a 
goggle eye: m.

Vne Warloppe de menuïsier, f:
 certaine instrument of a ioyner.

Waudrée, f: or escouillon: m: the
cloute wherewith they clense or
sweepe the Ouen, called a Maukin.

Vueuil, as cest vn mesme vueuil or
vouloir que d'eux deux, it is the
selfe same will of them both: they
be both of one like will: m.

Vuïder, to emptie, to voyd.

Vuïder vn proces, to iudge a matter
hanging in the law.

Vuïdons ce poinct, or cest affaire,
dont est question & puis nous
viendrons au demourant, let vs
dispatch this matter wee are about,
and then we will come to the rest.

Ce poinct vuïdé, this point or matter
dispatched.

Nostre different se vuïdera à l'espée,
 this our strife will be ended or dis­
patched at the edge of the sword.

Fay vuïder ceste tourbe, cause this
people to auoyd.

Vuïde, voyd, emptie.

Vuïdé, voyded, emptied, com.

Vuïdement, a voyding: m.

Vuïdange, voyding, emptinesse: f.

Faisons vne Vuïdange de ce point,
 let vs decide or make an end of this
poynt: f.

Vuïdanges d'vne ville, the place
where Scauingers doe emptie their
carts and filth of the towne.

Vuïdeté, emptinesse: f.

Vulgaire & commun, vulgare and
common.

Le vulgaire, com: the common people.

Cela est vulgaire, that is common.

Parolles vulgaires & communes, 
 common words, common talke.

Vulgairement, commonly.

Vule or la luette, as la vule luy est
tombée, the Vvula, otherwise the
pallet of his mouth is fallen, the
Vvula: f.

Droict & vz de franchise, the right
and custome of a freedome.

Aux vz & coustumé, after or accor­
ding to the vse and customes.


Y ante A.

YA il chose en quoy je vous puis­
se servir? is there any thing wher­
in I may doe you seruice.

Y, is an Aduerbe rehersing the place
before spoken, as qu'y a-il? what is
the matter?

Va voir qu'il y a là, goe see there
what the matter is.

Yeux, eies, seeke Oeil.

Yeux verds, gray eyes.

Yeux estincelants & esveillez,
 twinckling quick eyes.

Yeux qui se mouvent ça & là, rolling
eyes.

Yeux chassieus, dropping eyes.

Yeux enfoncez, hollow eyes.

Yeux brodez, red eyes.

Bander les yeux, seeke Ciler.

Cliner les yeux, to winke.

Pocher les yeux à quelcun, to put





out ones eyes.

Medecin des yeux, a Phisition for
the eyes.

Arbre nommé Yf, an Ewe tree: m.

Ysser la voile, to lift vp the sailes.

Yve musquée, or Ive, an hearbe called 
by the Apothecaries Ivam muscatam.

Yver, ou Hyver, winter: m.

Yvernade, wintring: f.

Le cours de l'yver, the course of win­
ter.

Iour d'yver, a winters day.

L'yver approche, the Winter draw­
eth nye.

La my yver, the middest or the hart
of the winter: f.

Temps d'yver, Winter time.

Passer l'yver à couvert, to passe the
Winter at home.

Brouillars & brouëes d'yver, Myste
in Winter.

Yverner, to winter.

Yvoire ou Ivoire, dent d'Elephant,
 Iuorie, Elephants tooth: m.

Elle a le col blanc come Yvoire,
 she hath her necke as white as I­
uorie.

Les dent d'yvoire, teethe of Iuo­
rie.

Yvorin, as col yvorin a necke of
Iuorie: m.

Qui est d'yvoire, that is of Iuorie.

Yvre, drunke.

Il est yvre comme vne soupe, he is
drunke as a toste, or as a rat.

Et va yvrongne va, goe, goe drunken
beast.

Ie haïs les yvrongnes & les fuis com­
me la peste, I hate and shunne such
drunkards as the plague.

Yvrongne, a drunkard: m.

Vne Yvrongnesse or yvrongne, a 
woman drunkard: f."woman drunkard" not found in OED.

Yvongner, to drink till one be drunke.

Yvrongnerie, drunkennesse: f.

Yvroye, herbe, Darnell: f.


Z ante A.

ZAgaye, is a staffe longer & more
slender then a pike, otherwise
called Azagaye: m.

Zele, comme qui ont zele, zeale
that be zelous: m.

Zelateur, a zealous man: m.

Zeler, to be zelous.

Vn Zero, m: a cypher or naughts.

Le Zodiaque, the circle in heauen
where be the twelue signes, the Zo­
diake: m.

Zone, a girdle, also the circles in the
firmament: f.

Zephyre, vent d'Occident, quy com­
mence à souffler au printemps,
lequel faict germer toute plante,
 the westerne winde: m.

Zizanie, toute semence bastarde,
quy croict parmy le bon blé, au­
trement appellée Yvroye, Cockle:
fem.

Zoucet, a little birde plunging or
ducking in the water, which wee
call also Castagneux: m.


FINIS.
